(1902,NZ Illustrated Magazine,4/374 [see notes p.4])

rack feeding¶

1 n. (Rural) the provision of stock feed in racks.

Few New Zealand farmers will agree that rack feeding is the most economical and safe way to consume lucerne. (Feb 1, 1930,NZ Farmer,153)

rack off¶

v. go away [From N.Z. English to U.S. English Dictionary at http://nz.com/NZ/Culture/NZDic.html. Not known to DEH]

rack on¶

v. to rabbit on (pejorative)

He was still racking on about the weather (Dec 1986,Marist Messenger,33) [NOTES: (Joy Cowley).]

rack-a-rock¶

n. an explosive (? trade name ca1900)

MYERS We've got to make a tunnel straight through a mountain-range!' ...That'll mean dynamite and rack-a-rock like Hell!' (1941,Valiant Love,11)

Later on came the days of blasting [stumps] ... At first we used Rac-a-roc which looked like sausages in a skin of muslin ... (1967,Tang of The Bush,71)

racy¶

adj. racegoing

HISLOP In the following chapter I make use of a racy saying, one so often used by those in and out - mostly out - investors who at least have picked a winner, ... as they rush away to the tote to collect. (1943,Pure Gold,34)

raddle¶

v. to rob (esp. be raddled)

raddled: This word means robbed' in the sense of being deprived of one's proper payment. It is an extension ofraddling', carried out by unscrupulous farmers before the Shearers' Union looked after shearers' interests. Any sheep considered unsatisfactorily shorn was marked with red or blue raddle and such a sheep would not be counted in the shearer's tally. The raddle stick was also called a `Toby'. This must not be confused with [27] marking a sheep for other purposes, such as identification of certain sheep for easy selection later. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/26-27) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

n.

I did not brand the bales, but marked them with raddle, and if there were two sorts I would mark them so. I also sent tickets describing the wool. I have sometimes known mistakes between the raddling and branding; with a large lot and different men mistakes might easily arise. (Jun 23, 1892,Otago Witness,17)

Bath bricks, raddle, linseed oil ... (Dec 15, 1852,Taranaki Herald,1)

ON SALE, by the undersigned:- Woolpacks, sheepshears, sacks, pitch, linseed oil, lamp black, raddle, fencing wire and iron standards. (Dec 27, 1876,Tuapeka Times,2)

Direct from Calcutta. Wool Packs .. full stocks raddle, marking oil, boiled oil, stencils, wool hooks ... (Nov 1, 1898,Feilding Star,2)

Same day - S.S. Storm Bird, 67 tons, Malcolm, from Melbourne, 995 bags Chilian flour .. 10 cases axes, 1 case levels, 1 cask raddle, 5 cases drapery ... (Dec 29, 1860,Otago Witness,4)

North of Ireland Chemical Dip, Red Bolme Yellow Green Raddle, Sheep Marking Oil (4 colours), Johnson's English Galvanised Wire (6, 7, 8, and 4 and 6-inch barb) Galvanised staples (all sizes), Hay Rake and Lever Harrows. (Dec 19, 1902,Wanganui Herald,6)

PRICE LIST .. Raddle 0[s] 8[d] ... (Nov 2, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,4)

Raddle in those days [1880's] was in great demand, and when the boss of the board was in a bad humor [sic] or perchance did not like the color of the shearer's hair he used the raddle on the sheep shorn by the shearer and the raddle sheep were counted out and the shearer not paid for them. (Mar 29, 1912,Maoriland Worker,55/12/2)

MASTERS Les and Alex got hold of several lumps of raddle, some red and some blue, caught Dinny, put broad red and blue stripes on the natural white background of his coat, ... (1959,Tales of the Mails,77)

ON SALE .. Wool Packs, Sheep Shears, Lamp Black, and Raddle ... (Nov 17, 1880,Tuapeka Times,2)

1 v. (Rural) to mark sheep with a raddle stick for identification purposes.

Briefly stated, the complaint of these shearers is that Mr John McCaw, who is described as manager for the Bank of New Zealand Estates Company, went to this particular shed, at which there were twelve shearers, accompanied by his under-manager, and made the under-manager umpire to decide which sheep should be 'raddled,' or 'marked,' and which should not. (Dec 14, 1895,Observer (Auckland),2)

Well, boss' says he,I shear for myself in the morning, and for my girl in the afternoon, and he wouldn't be much of a man who could raddle a sheep on a girl, would he, boss?' (Oct 15, 1910,Maoriland Worker,2/4/3)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Raddle. To declare a sheep badly shorn and therefore not included in the shearer's tally. This practice was outlawed in the 1890s. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,97)

And the new rousie instructed to raddle (mark with colour for the farmer's attention) the cut pizzle on the underside of a ram. (Mar 1988,More Magazine,31)

He asked accused to raddle the sheep's face so that he would know it again. (Oct 24, 1914,Stratford Evening Post,3)

If rams remain with the ewes for more than 4 weeks, they should be raddled on the brisket so that the late-lambing ewes can be drafted off. (Mar 1955,NZ Journal of Agriculture,264)

MALLOCH For 65 years he raddled lambs for that firm and even in his 80s he could be seen clutching the drafting gate at Waikaia Plains. (1992,From the Tops,112)

WoolPro strongly recommends to growers and shearers that they raddle flystruck sheep (on the head) as they go over the board, then treat them afterwards in the pens outside the shed. (2000,Wool Grower,Spring 5)

The scattered fleeces about the floor of the busy station shed, / Or the new-chum shears on the struggling ewe, black-tarred and raddled red ... (Oct 23, 1909,Poverty Bay Herald,11)

raddle money¶

n. [(shearers')]

MILLS This [South Island] shed is often said ... to have been paid for with `raddle money', a term that many of our younger shearers have never even heard. In those days ... a shearer had to shear cleanly, or have many of his sheep heavily marked in the count-out pens and excluded from his tally. Inevitably the boss stood to benefit from such a one-sided bargain, hence the term, raddle money. (1960,Sheep-O,122)

1 n. (Rural) a deduction made to a shearer's pay for sheep that are cut during shearing [such sheep being marked with raddle.]

MILLS In those days .. a shearer had to shear cleanly, or have many of his sheep heavily marked in the count-out pens and excluded from his tally. Inevitably the boss stood to benefit from such a one-sided bargain, hence the term, raddle money. (1960,Sheep-O,122)

raddling¶

n. [(obs.)]

I did not brand the bales, but marked them with raddle, and if there were two sorts I would mark them so. I have sometimes known mistakes between the raddling and branding; with a large lot and different men mistakes might easily arise. (Jun 23, 1892,Otago Witness,17)

Raddling.-An old-time shed practice, whereby the shed boss put a raddle-mark on any sheep in the counting-out pen not shorn to his satisfaction, and the shearer was not paid for it. Old hands often spoke of this practice. I think the great shearers' strike at the beginning of the 'nineties ended it. (Jan 27, 1934,Press, The,15)

ACLAND In 1886 there is mention of `raddling' (and not paying for) badly shorn sheep. I think by the 'nineties the shearers had managed to get this custom abolished. (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,167)

adj.

This is like going back to the good old raddling days. (Dec 8, 1911,Maoriland Worker,14)

1 n. (Rural) the marking of sheep with raddle stick for identification purposes.

RIDDOLLS Check pens may also be used for such jobs as raddling and dagging. (1958,Farm Engineering,333)

radi¶

n. (See rari)

radiata¶

n. also called Monterey pine, pinus (radiata) the member of the pine family most commonly cultivated to provide timber and wood products in New Zealand. -->see PINE @n2, RADIATA PINE - [aka radiata pine; aka aka pinus]

By the time the first logging crew reached the scene, up an obscure side trail flanked by young radiata, the car had been burning several minutes. (Aug 14, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

radiata n. (also pinus radiata, radiata pine) Californian variety of pine grown for timber in NZ. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,622) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 401]

HILL The rows of two-tiered spectator benches within the corrugated-iron enclosures are composed of radiata from Ballantyne's Sawmills - undressed rather than dressed radiata, one should mention. (1985,More from Moaville,22)

It is admitted by timber merchants, builders and carpenters that, if improperly used, radiata.. will deteriorate. (Sep 24, 1955,Dominion,10)

Planting radiata forests looks a sure fire bet. (Sep 27, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,18)

Though radiata won out as the base for our exotic forestry industry, the pinetum holds examples of many other Pinus species. (Oct 2, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

He recommends .. the radiated cone pine (radiata), having all the merits of the ensignis, and equally well adapted to New Zealand, yielding a fine boat-building timber. (May 30, 1868,Timaru Herald,2)

The plants shown by Mr Falconer for competition were .. Pinus. 12 varieties - Austriaca, Radiata, Insignis, Ponderosa ... (Nov 17, 1876,North Otago Times,2)

ORNAMENTAL TREES .. Pinus Insignis, Maritima Canarienses, Radiata, Persica, &c ... (Sep 3, 1885,Poverty Bay Herald,1)

radiata pine¶

n. the Monterey pine, Pinus radiata [aka pinus; aka radiata]

Rows and rows of radiata pine seem to have put us off using pines in the garden setting, but don't judge all pines by the sombre dark green of the Monterey Pine (Pinus radiata). (Feb 2001,Growing Today,58)

Boring old radiata pine trees?... Radiata pine grows faster here faster here than anywhere else in the world, with an average age-to-harvest of under 30 years, which helps to make forestry New Zealand's third-biggest export industry. (Mar 24, 2003,Dominion Post,C2)

That radiata pine had become widely, though not universally frowned on is probably because of unfair comparison with its more feral cousin, P. contorta. (Feb 10, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

radiator¶

n. a radiant electric heater [Jim Cameron writes: In the sense of a radiant electric heater, Collins records this as Austral & NZ. This was the ordinary NZ term for this object at least up to the 1960s. A notice published in the press in 3/00 mentions electric radiator. Not in DNZE or NZPOD Also often called bar heater.]

radio-sode¶

n. short radio episode

A funky new 'radio-sode' targeting youth will air every day in a bid to encourage a new generation to speak Maori. (2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.tetaurawhiri.govt.nz/maori/press_m/brownst.shtml]

The public campaign will focus on seven projects in its first six months: a game show for Maori Television; a radio drama serial for native speakers; a bilingual "radio-sode" (or short episodes) aimed at young people; an interactive website; a resource kit for new parents; phrase booklets; and a language event to promote Matariki, or Maori New Year. ... "That we now have funding to undertake specific projects - such as the quiz show for Maori Television and the funky new 'radio-sode' - is a sign of the positive commitment that the Government has made in its role to support the Maori language. ... Radio "Brown Street", a series of 30-second bilingual "radio-sodes" - or short episodes - produced by youth music station Mai FM in association with Te Taura Whiri. (May 2005,Kokiri Paetae,6)

radish¶

n.

radish [s] Raphanus sativus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,62)

2 n.

radish, horse [s] Armoracia rusticana G., M., & S. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,62)

2 n.

radish, sea [s] Raphanus maritimus Sm. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,62)

2 n.

.. Wanganui Technical School has received a shipment of nine cases of plaster casts ordered last year. As there is considerable interest in the school, we herewith publish the general list which is as follows:- Panel from Bonn .. female arm with breast, cherries, two foxglove leaves, two rhubarb leaves, apple, wild radish leaf (2) ... (Feb 16, 1893,Wanganui Herald,2)

Wild radish, or white charlock, had already formed many seeds [sic] pods, but the other weeds were in full bloom. (Nov 4, 1908,Otago Witness,8)

The principal annual and biennial weeds are - black mustard, wild radish, corn poppy ... (Sep 8, 1882,NZ Tablet,25)

POLACK The turnip is found in a wild state over the entire country, as also wild radishes, garlick, celery, cress, &c. radish, wild [s] Raphanus raphanistrum L. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/291)

HILGENDORF WILD RADISH (Raphanus sativus) is found in many scattered localities. It is much like the garden plant, with the same shaped leaves, purplish flowers, and jointed poda. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,96,1967 ed.)

wild radish [s] Raphanus raphanistrum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,62, 86)

TAYLOR WILD RADISH (Raphanus rephanistrum and R. maritimus) ... This European plant was first recorded in New Zealand in 1935 and is now common in several districts. very common on roadsides and in vacant sections in Blenheim district. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,171)

RADS¶

abbr. Regional Alcohol and Drug Service

"No one can give you any guarantee [of a safe level for use of P]," says Ian Scott, lead medical officer for detox services at the Regional Alcohol and Drug Service (Apr 5, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

rafferty¶

adj. raffish [ca1920 (W.H.B. Orsman) (eg. A old car, dress, front door etc. She looked pretty rafferty even in her new dress. You're not going out with that rafferty pub clique.)]

Rafferty rules¶

n.

And you should have seen what a mess we made of it. Rafferty Rules was the order of the day and our company ... were all over the place. (Mar 17, 1918,Great Adventure,237,1988 ed.) [NOTES: (Hutton)]

LAMBERT The day was hot, ... and the rules were those of the well-known `Mr. Rafferty'. (1936,Pioneering Reminiscences of Old Wairoa,189)

Rafferty('s) rules¶

n. espec.(BE) RUN ON RAFFERTY RULES, of a game, a household, a raffle, etc, (be run) without a sense of order, method, correctness, etc; with no rules at all

Labor's adoption of Rafferty rules, in order to silence its opponents, has been evidenced in New Zealand and Australia. (Jun 14, 1924,NZ Truth,4)

System termed muddle'.Rafferty's Rules', said Miss M.B. Howard M.P. as soon as ... the Board had finished discussing the housing plight of two of its registrars. (Mar 4, 1953,NZ Truth,3)

Rafferty or Rafferty's rules pl. n. Austral. & N.Z. sl. no rules at all. [C20: < ?] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,942) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 623; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 401]]

OVENDEN `Out here it's always been Rafferty's Rules. Make 'em up as you go along, (1986,O.E.,236)

MITCHE;LL Rafferty's rules: Standing Orders of the House of Representatives. Named after William Ewart Rafferty, the second Speaker who, because of his high voice, was also referred to as Mr Squeaker. (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,183)

A second special attraction will be an old-timers' football match, "under Rafferty's rules." It is intended to get teams composed of experienced footballers used to the various games, and "Rafferty's rules" are described as being gloriously indefinite and contradictory, so that the burlesque game should be unusually attractive. (Aug 25, 1914,Evening Post,2)

raft¶

v.

Employed in Bush cuting rafters and wootles [Feb 9] Employed carring [sic] wootles and rafters Out of the bush. [Feb 11] Employed wootling and Rafting the boats sheads and the new house (Feb 6, 1839,Piraki Log,76)

sc. oil =?rafting it in casks to Brig in bay people employ'd cleaning bone and rafting oil. [cf Oct 15 p10 towed another raft in the bay] (Aug 22, 1839,Piraki Log,96,(ed. Anson 1911) ed.)

raft fish¶

n. Hoplocoryphis physaliarum

GRAHAM Raft Fish Hoplocoryphis physaliarum Whitley (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,405) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 405]

raft-canoe¶

n. a Moriori canoe

SHAND Raft-canoes: Perhaps this term may be accepted as more explanatory [than canoe simplex] of the kind of canoe used [by the Chathams Moriori]. Those accustomed to Maori canoes might otherwise be misled regarding their form. (1911,Moriori People of the Chatham Islands, The,5fn)

rafter¶

n. a log (in a driving dam) squared on three sides, at the lower end let into a chamber in the bed of a creek, and leaning back onto, and rising above, the stringer, to which it is bolted (cf SWINGING RAFTER DAM) [(kauri bushmen's)]

? a batten over or rafter under thatch Employed in Bush cuting rafters and wootles [Feb 9] Employed carring [sic] wootles and rafters Out of the bush. [Feb 11] Employed wootling and Rafting the boats sheads and the new house (Feb 6, 1839,Piraki Log,76,ed. Anson 1911 ed.)

REED Rafters were then put in position, their lower ends firmly embedded in rock, and these formed the framework for the walls (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,201)

rafting-spear¶

n. [(kauri millers')]

At the mouths of streams a line of floating [kauri] logs have been previously fastened together with iron dogs' and short chains; this is called aboom', and prevents the timber getting away to sea. The logs are then fastened together in rafts, and, guided by men armed with long poles shod with iron (called rafting-spears), are conveyed to the mills, ... (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,365) [NOTES: (E. Tregear: Labour in NZ)]

At the mouths of streams a line of floating [kauri] logs have been previously fastened together with iron dogs' and short chains; this is called aboom', and prevents the timber getting away to sea. The logs are then fastened together in rafts, and, guided by men armed with long poles shod with iron (called rafting-spears), are conveyed to the mills, ... (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,365) [NOTES: (E. Tregear: Labour in NZ)]

rag¶

n. a one pound note

Following are other local money-names: - 1 pound note - flimsy, rag or carpet... (Jan 14, 1899,Sydney Bulletin,(Red Page)) [NOTES: (Letter from Loafer, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]]

The pound note of pre-decimal days was varously [sic] known as a quid, nicker, smacker, flimsy, rag, and carpet. The latter term was apparently peculiar to New Zealand and Australia. (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,16)

n. ?ratbag; ?joker

CRUMP I was a worried man just then. There were some tough rags in that little bunch [of belligerent bush-whackers]. One king-hit and I was a goner. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,164)

rag bag¶

n. alteration of ratbag

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the [slang] expressions listed by children in two schools are: Up the shoot, going eyes out, bullswool, go jump in the lake, ... shivery dick, shiver me timbers, ... you're telling I, got it on the brain, like smoke in a wheelbarrow' (Kaitaia),Sheila, crow, bud, frig it, grub, holy moses, blast it, mole, balls to you, shut your face, ... nerts to you, go bite your back, have a roll, fluff off, scram, ants in your pants, rag bag, ... you're bats, dronk, drongo, dill, dip, dippy, ya big lug, greetings gruesome, who dented your beak. (South Wellington). (1953,Unorganized Games,2/677)

rag-planter¶

n. a newspaper proprietor. [principally 19th century usage]

G H Scholefield Rag-planter's paradise ..The rag-planters waged a picturesque struggle in the back-blocks, vying with each other for the favour of bush farmers and cow-cockies. (1958,Newspapers in New Zealand,18)

Byrne, J Both sets of isolated communities attracted roving printer-editors with a penchant for starting marginal, short-lived papers - and then moving on. New Zealand had a colourful name for them:"rag-planters". (1999,American Studies International,XXXVII/57,1 ed.)

'Joe Iviss: rag-planter' (1944,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10/6,244 ed.) [NOTES: heading Iviss sic in citation? (correctly Ivess)]

Griffith, Penny, Ross Harvey & Keith Maslin They were established by such 'rag-planters' as Joseph Ivess and J.H. Claridge ... (1997,Guide to Print Culture in Aotearoa, A,129)

rag-planting¶

n. establishing of a newspaper. [principally 19th century usage.]

The year 1880 saw another burst of 'rag-planting', first in Taranaki (Hawera Times) then near Christchurch ... (1993,Dictionary of NZ Biography,II/240)

Ivess's 'rag-planting' continued until at least 1908. (1993,Dictionary of NZ Biography,II/241)

rage¶

v. to party [meaning unclear in 1984 cit.]

Gilbert said that he had plenty of money as he played pool, toss the coin and won quinellas at the races. He refused to point the finger' at where Mr Maddox got the dope.... this has spoilt a good day. I have been raging all day. I punched him over because he tried to punch me over, and put me in my place. He reckoned he was a Liverpudlian seaman who had been here for 20 years, a big toughie,' Gilbert had told him. (Dec 7, 1984,Press, The,4)

Tonight is club night, ... when Butch's group of dauntingly attired females ... show how staunch they are in the chapter by showing up to rage. (May 1986,More Magazine,22)

One trendy group of new singles used to meet at the Last And First Cafe at the top of Symonds Street in groups of up to 40 and then rage all night. (Jul 1986,Metro,133)

n. a party or dance [(adolescent's) 1984 17 M E96 Pakuranga Coll. 34 RAGE -->1984 15 M E62 Pakuranga Coll. 34 RAGE,A -->1984 16 F E39 Pakuranga Coll. 18 RAGEY -->1984 16 M E85 Pakuranga Coll. 33 RAGING]

[I.A. Gordon]...confessing [my] ignorance of the origin of the verb to skull' (to drink quickly), the verbto flag' (to waive something, to put it aside, not to bother about it), and the....nouns stir' andrage' [adolescents' party names]. (Dec 6, 1980,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

a rage: Punk rock; a stir (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

rage ... 5. N.Z. & Austral. sl. a dance or party. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,943) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 402]]

Rage¶

abbr. Revolt Against Genetic Engineering [ORIGIN: acronym]

Protesters from Rage (Revolt Against Genetic Engineering in Food) were outside the hearing in the Wellington District Court this morning. (Aug 25, 1999,Evening Post,2)

rager¶

2 n.

[A 15-year-old writes] Finally, I don't turn up my nose at flash new clothes that my relations give me. As I said before, I'm not into some gears, so I just give them to Mum, who's my size too. (My mum's a bit of a rager.) So please elders, don't generalise. All teenagers aren't the same. We're different in our own ways. (Jun 30, 1986,NZ Woman's Weekly,76)

ragfish¶

n.

GRAHAM Ragfish Melanostigma flaccidum Waite (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,112) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 112]

AYLING RAGFISH Icihthys australis ... It has soft easily damaged fins ... The name ragfish was suggested by the soft flesh and weakly ossified bones of this species that give the body a distinctively limp feel. ... A very similar species is found in deep northern oceans. (1982,Collins Guide,303,1984 ed.)

[species name] ragfish .. [scientific name] Icichthys Australis .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] ragfish 875 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] limp ragfish 2173 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

ragged robin¶

n.

COCKAYNE But ... the ragged robin, ... and the foxglove, to mention only a few British plants, are now wild in various places. (1910,NZ Plants,135)

ragged school¶

n.

It is instructive to note how adroitly the terms "Ragged School" and "Albert-street Public School" are used in reference to this job; the former is always trotted out for local eyes; while the other is invariably used in reports to be seen by the Minister's eye at Wellington. (Oct 11, 1890,NZ Observer,9)

raggie¶

n.

Kiwi designer Karen Walker: 'If it wasn't for the fashion designers at the top of the triangle there'd be nothing for the raggies to follow'. (May 27, 1999,Dominion,15)

ragtown¶

n.

The sentiments of the verse are prudent and public - 14-'18 jingoism, boozy West Coast camaraderie ...; even the lusty heyday of the ragtowns with their brothels and casinos and boatloads of dancing-girls from Sydney is diluted into a nostalgic wink at the waywardness of the boys. (Sep 1952,Landfall,212) [NOTES: (Pearson `Fretful Sleepers')]

ragweed¶

n.

ragweed [=] ragwort [s] ... ragweed [s] Ambrosia (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,62)

ragwort¶

n. ragwort [=] hoary ragwort: marsh ragwort: St. John's wort [s] ... ragwort [s] Senecio jacobaea L.

What was described as "the menace to farmers and settlers".. of ragwort growing in the Parakuai district.. was referred to in a letter. (Dec 22, 1944,Hauraki Plains Gazette,5)

BACON ragwort - An introduced wild flower which ran riot under New Zealand conditions and has now become a vigorous noxious weed. Has a bright yellow daisy-like flower. (1963,In the Sticks,183)

ragwort [=] hoary ragwort: marsh ragwort: St. John's wort [s] ... ragwort [s] Senecio jacobaea L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,62)

TAYLOR RAGWORT (Senecio jacobaea) ... This European weed occurs throughout the farmed area of New Zealand where rainfall exceeds 800 mm per annum. (1981,Weeds of Lawns,91)

Ragwort Touch, his startling 1997 debut, was like a road trip through the rural North Island of some indeterminate past, pulling up at dairies, pubs and pas along the way. (Sep 15, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

[They] are offering their services, "maybe under a task-force green type initiative", to pull ragwort and clip thistles before these problem Waikato weeds get out of hand. (May 23, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

1 v. (Rural) to poison or ragwort.

ADDENBROOKE Ragworting. I used my motorbike and sidechair to cart out to the paddocks when ragworting and topdressing. (1992,Home from the Hill,107)

ADDENBROOKE Tidying up, mending fences, yards, ragworting and heaps of other jobs had to be done before my cows arrived from my brother-in-law at Matiere. (1992,Home from the Hill,116)

2 n. RAGWORT (Senecio jacobaea)

RAGWORT (Senecio jacobaea) ... This European weed occurs throughout the farmed area of New Zealand where rainfall exceeds 800 mm per annum. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,62)

2 n.

ragwort, purple [=] purple groundsel [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,62)

ragwort ewe¶

1 n. (Rural) a paddock or store ewe used to graze ragwort.

ADDENBROOKE Ragwort Ewes. The following year I bought two hundred ragwort ewes in real good order. (1992,Home from the Hill,108)

rah¶

exclam. short for hurrah

PARTRIDGE Rah! A coll. abbr. of hurrah!: orig. and mainly U.S., anglicised ca. 1910. N.b., rah! (shouted thrice) forms the termination of the Maori war-cry, now-and since late C. 19-affected by Maori and other New Zealand Rugby teams ca1940 A Campbell: especially in the bastard, non-Maori hakas down South (Dunedin, Otago, Canterbury), but not heard much up North. (but cf Boomeranga.) WF interj since ca1875. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,684)

Rahere chocolate pudding¶

n.

FUTTER `RAHERE' CHOCOLATE PUDDING ... brown bread ... cake ... chocolate ... sherry ... strawberry jam ... whipped cream. Grate up bread and chocolate and mix ... layer ... jam ... breadcrumbs ... chocolate ... soaking ... in sherry as you add layers ... spread ... with whipped cream ... (1926,Home Cookery for NZ,156)

rahi¶

n. slave

They then became the vassals (rahi) of the dominant tribe. (May 21, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,28)

n. a variety of blueberry

Watch out too for rahi - a New Zealand-produced blueberry with very high levels of anti-oxidants that will come on board later in the season. (Jan 4, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),12)

rahirahu¶

n.

HOOKER Rahu-rahu, Lindsay. Pteris aquilina. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

CHEESEMAN [Pteris aquilina. Linn. var. esculenta, Hook.f.] Common fern; Bracken; Rau-aruhe; Rahurahu; of the root, Aruhe, Roi. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,971)

raho¶

n. as a term of abuse perhaps from orig Maori abusive. pron [ra:h] perhaps influenced by <i>whore</i>. [ca1935 Havelock, Marlborough (especially schoolboys', probably from Maori children) eg. You dirty raho. (usually [ra:'h) ca1943 S.P.C. Silverstream (cf espec. a class snigger when scientist Raoul was mentioned)]

rahu¶

n. basket [[? omit as purely Maori context] Williams 320 Rahu ... Basket.:]

Where my rahu, she would ask me. Where my rahu? And I would help her look for it. I knew always that the basket would be under her bed, but Nanny, she liked playing pretend,... (1977,Listener Short Stories,91) [NOTES: 1979 Ihimaera `The Child' in 1977 Listener Short Stories 91]

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of rye corn. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Our work has demonstrated that Nui ryegrass is severely affected when sown under the biennial ryegrass Paroa, less so under Tama, and most successful with Rahu ryecorn and Amuri oats. (Mar 1979,NZ Journal of Agriculture,58)

Rahu ryecorn - High-producing, dual-purpose cultivar. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,72)

2 n. `testicles',

rahui¶

n. a prohibition or ban [ORIGIN: Maori]

Before the stripping of coastal rocks and the placing of a rahui [harvesting ban] by local Maori to save the remaining shellfish on Aucklands west coast ... (Dec 26, 2004,Sunday Magazine (Auckland),p18)

The natives always treat a rahui with much respect, considering it an act of great dishonesty to catch eels, or any other fish, to hunt pigs, snare ducks or parrots, or in fact destroy in any way or [sic] game of whatever kind which it is erected to preserve. So strictly is this code carried out, that a short time ago - (and even now in some parts of the island) the infringement of a rahui would be considered quite a sufficient casus belli to give rise to a bloody war between two tribes. (Nov 2, 1850,New Zealander, The,3)

Tangaroa decreed that.. when necessary elders will place a rahui (ban) on taking seafood until Tangaroa is appeased. (Dec 14, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C3)

"Heremaia's things had been put into a house that was marked (rahui), and it was burnt; and if the General got them into a house, even though it was marked as sacred, they would be served in the same way." (Mar 29, 1866,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,4)

The fruit of the tutu is sometimes preserved for the owners by means of a rahui, which warned persons (1910,TrNZI,42/477)

". . . . We can start by placing a rahui [ban] on smoking at our marae." (Oct 20, 2005,NZ Herald,-)

Claimants will dredge up evidence about historical rights to traverse various regions, to hunt and gather, and - most interestingly - to impose bans on use and passage to mark deaths or drownings or conserve resources (rahui), or preserve sacred areas (wahitapu). (Aug 9, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

Oh I know rahui, I can look up and talk to people and when I go and film rahui I've got my script, the funders know what they want and they will tell me what the public wants. (Nov 14, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C15)

A kaumatua would visit the site to lay a rahui (ban) on the area later. (Sep 20, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

But Dad must have been hit on the head by the boat, and never came up. Till later, when he was washed ashore. Caused a week-long rahui on fishing in the area. (2003,Huia 5: Contemp. Maori Fiction,41)

v. place a rahui (prohibition) on

A Maori will Rahui or tapu any convenience that you derive or use through him, - such as pahs, or roads, fire, wood, or water ... (Jan 3, 1846,New Zealander, The,3)

rahuia¶

n.

WILSON Linum monogonum ... The Chatham Island flax is the same as that in New Zealand except the white blossom is here flaked with blue ... Chatham Island Flax. NAU, RAHUIA. (1952,Chatham Islands,32)

rail¶

n. . [various birds of rail varieties, unspecified]

CRAIK Among them are many sorts of wild ducks, large wood-pigeons, sea gulls, rails, parrots, and parroquets. (1830,New Zealanders, The,187)

MORRIS Rail, n. common English bird-name. There are many varieties in New Zealand and Australia, especially in the former colony, and the authorities differ as to whether some should be classed as distinct species. Some are common to Australasia, others endemic in New Zealand or Australia; their distribution in this respect is marked below in parentheses. Several species receive more than one vernacular name, as the the following list shows - Banded Rail (N.Z. and A.)- Rallus philippensis,Linn. ... Dieffenbach's R. (...) Rallus dieffenbachii, Gray. Hutton's R. (N.Z.)- Cabalus modestus, Hutton. Land R. (N.Z. and A.)- Rallus philippensis, Linn. ... Swamp R. (Australasia)- Ortygometra tabuensis, Finsch. ... Weka R. (N.Z. see Weka) see also Takahe and Notornis. (1898,Austral English,378)

FORSTER Though these Water-hens or rather Rails have so short wings ... (Apr 17, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/257)

FORSTER Though [the dog] had been in the woods during a fortnight, yet it was by no means famished ... A large species of rails, which we called water-hens, and which are very numerous in this part of New Zeeland ... afforded it sufficient support. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/155)

ANDERSON (Queen Charlotte Sound) We likewise killd [sic] two or three Rails of a brown or yellowish colour variegated with black, ... (Feb 1777,Journal) [NOTES: 1777 Feb's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/807]

NICHOLAS Towards the southward there are also water hens of a large species, rails in vast numbers, cormorants, oyster catchers, or sea-pies, penguins, and some other sorts of aquatic birds. (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/256)

HAY Pigeons, nestors, parrots, rail, kiwi, swamp-fowl, water-fowl, owls, parson-birds, all these and more were eaten; while the native dogs and rats were held to be great dainties. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/151)

TREGEAR ... the quail (koreke: Coturnix N.Z.), the rail (mohoperu and moeriki: Rallus sp.) and many other land-birds were cooked or potted down. (1904,Maori Race, The,105)

I recall, however, a pretty little rail (Hypotaenidia philippensis) which was taken in the bush at Littlebourne. (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,IV/278) [NOTES: (Bathgate, Otago)]

SKINNER & BAUCKE Rail and pukeka were caught by snares set in their sphagnum moss runs, ... (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs,IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 362) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 362]

McNEISH A rail sounded to his left. `Swamp country,' he muttered. (1970,Mackenzie,11)

n. a tease [n2 (obs children's, ?rare)]

THOMSON It was'.It wasn't.' You're a rail.'You're another!' flew back and forth [among the boys] (1905,Bush Boys of NZ,52)

n. of a fence

Fencing all the day and finished all the places that can be mended with sods, the remaining ones must have rails. (Sep 13, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,58,1950 ed.)

rail gang¶

n. a railway work gang

From [Manganoho] the rail gangs were building the Makohine Viaduct. (Dec 2001,NZ Memories,No. 27/38)

rail trailer¶

n. one who follows a rail trail

It's early days yet, the rail trail opened in 1999, but feedback from the community is that the rail trailers are bringing in business with the added bonus that farming is better than it has been in years. (Sep 29, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C14)

rail-bus¶

n.

LEITCH The two rail-buses built in 1926 were just that - Ford Model 'T' buses on flanged wheels. (1911,Railways of NZ,193)

rail-fence¶

n. a Maori fence made out of vertical rails; ?=a paling fence

POLACK We remember seeing a pig ... both of whose ears had been bored ... through which a stick was thrust, ... to prevent the animal from entering between the rail-fence. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers) [NOTES: 1/194fn]

rail-sitter¶

1 n. (Rural) an observer or non-participant in farming activities. (See gate-leaner)

ROBERTS Branding may not have been as spectacular as a Roman holiday, but it usually attracted a few rail-sitters. (1856,Diary) [NOTES: in Beattie (1947) Early Runholding in Otago]

railer¶

n.

HINTZ The railers flocked to it. These are so-called fishermen whose greed for fish far outruns their angling skill. They are a pest likely to be encountered on many Taupo waters. They stand in a swift current, peel off the whole length of a dressed line and let it float down the stream, generally with 40 or 50 yds. of backing as well. Then they fish the [218] fly on the reel. It is illegal under the Taupo fishing regulations, but it is a practice which the rangers cannot easily detect or suppress. (1964,Trout at Taupo,217)

railing¶

n.

HINTZ The owners of the lines, a husband and wife who had made themselves thoroughly objectionable during a week of unashamed railing, were roused to action. (1964,Trout at Taupo,219)

railway cup¶

n.

No more thick white cups and saucers with the distinctive Railway stripe though. (Feb 1989,North & South,19)

Nowadays you can find them in bohemian-but-trendy cafes and student flats, but for many people the dependable Crown Lynn railway cup is the reminder of nightmare journeys through the tearooms of hell. (Aug 13, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

PARK The tea came in a Railway cup. The rim was so thick that the drinker felt he had grown a thick lip. (1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,87)

railway settlement¶

n. an area of housing for Railways Department staff

[Caption] One of the flooded streets at the railway settlement, Lower Hutt. (Aug 22, 1928,NZ Free Lance,25)

[Hdg] Life in the Ngaio Railway Settlement 1930-1940... My father worked for the New Zealand Railways and my first five years were at Waipukurau the Railway Settlement there. In 1930 my father turned our family up-side-down when he announced "we are shifting to the Railway Settlement in Ngaio." (Jan 2004,Onslow Historian,No. 34(1/2) : 1)

Some strange characters were noticed in Waipawa last night, disguised with paint and false moustaches and wearing what are known to the initiated asrailway stockings `...' (Feb 1, 1913,NZ Truth,397/1/6)

rain river¶

n. [[=?:? technical term] -]

HAAST 2. Rain Rivers - a second class of rivers are those which have their origin in the outrunning spurs of the Southern Alps bounding the plains' appropriately named by the settlers rain rivers in contra-distinction to the larger ones, which are formed by the glaciers, and to which the term snow rivers has been applied. (1864,Report on the Formation of the Canterbury Plains,30)

rain rot¶

n.

HILLIARD (1960,Maori Girl,9) [NOTES: [check use and quot]]

rainbird¶

n.

Like the Cuckoos in other parts of the world, they appear before rainy weather or coincident with it, and have thus come to be known in many widely different localities as Rain-birds' andStorm-birds'. In many parts of Otago and Canterbury they were called by the early settlers Potato-birds', as they invariably came on the scene as the potato-planting was going on; similarly, in the North Island they got the name ofKumara-birds'. (1904,TrNZI,36/134)

When the rain-bird sings in the teatree.. / I'll be riding down the track. (1969,AUTC Song Book (3rd ed.),Song No. 36)

n. a name given various to birds in different parts of the world [AND any of several birds (esp. two cuckoos) 1827]: in NZ, the following (esp. and chiefly 1) are `rainbirds') (See mohua)

Observations on Puffinus gavius (Forst.), Rain-bird, (Hakoakoa), their Habits and Habitats. (1886,TrNZI,18/9) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

2 n. grey warbler, riroriro

MOORE Riroriro or Rainbird, the only true song bird in New Zealand. (1937,Reminiscences) [NOTES: (1860's). (Letter 3.)]

HULME I hear them singing in the hills, kui kui kui, whiti whiti ora. Rainbirds. I used to think, O hell, rain coming. (1986,Te Kaihau,119)

rainbird n. NZ = RIRORIRO. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,624) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

3 n. wet-bird, shearwater,? laughing jackass, hakoakoa

HUTTON 125. PUFFINUS GAVIUS. Forst. Rain-bird or Wet-bird. Shearwater. Laughing Jackass(?). Hakoakoa. P. opisthomelas. COUES. P. assimilis. HUTTON (1871,Birds of New Zealand,45)

BULLER PUFFINUS {GAVIA. (FORSTER'S SHEARWATER.) ... Native name.- Pakahaa: `Rainbird' of the colonists. ... {237} They fly low but swiftly, and utter a note resembling the native name by which the bird is called, but somewhat prolonged, as paka-ha-a - paka-ha-a.} (1873,Birds of New Zealand,318,{1888 2nd edn 2/236-237} mainly 1888 edn ed.)

(1886,TrNZI,18/93) [NOTES: (Reischek) [get quot.]]

WILLIAMS Pakaha, n. Puffinis gavia, rain-bird. = hakoakoa. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,292)

3 n. mottled petrel [Also called: Scaled petrel, Peale's petrel, rainbird, korure, titi.] (See mottled petrel)

He states that the rain-bird is the only petrel seen in that locality. (Feb 5, 1910,Evening Post,13)

MONCRIEFF .... Like other Petrels calls at might before rain, hence name. Horrible scream. [check quot] (1948,NZ Birds,56)

FALLA et al. MOTTLED PETREL Pterodroma inexpectata Other names: Korure, Rainbird. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,50)

Mottled Petrel Pterodroma inexpectata (FORSTER, 1844) ... OTHER NAMES: Scaled petrel, Peale's petrel, rainbird, korure, titi. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,76)

4 n. [ca1956 Said to be because its call foretells rain. According to R. McGueen the name and story come from the South-West of the South Island (R.Mason) -->[? 1968 or 1960] Mar 15 NZ List 6/3 [?cuckoo] Screech! went a rainbird, not really meaning it [check quot.]]

rainbow¶

n. tuinal capsule [(criminal')]

NEWBOLD RAINBOW (n) Tuinal capsule. So called because of its colour. (1982,Big Huey, The,252)

rainbow cake¶

n.

THE WAIMATE SHOW .. COOKERY SECTION. .. rainbow cake, Mrs Hunt 1, Mrs Philips 2 ... (Feb 17, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,5)

Rainbow Cake (by request) - One cupful of butter, two cupfuls of sugar, three cups of flour, five eggs, one cup of milk, half teaspoonful of soda, one teaspoonful of cream of tartar. (Sep 27, 1894,Otago Witness,47)

Rainbow Cake... Divide the mixture into three parts... As ordinary tins are not big enough, as the cake rises very high, cut the bottoms of three petrol tins, leaving them with sides about 3 ins. high. (Mar 6, 1926,NZ Observer,22)

The following is a tested recipe for rainbow cake:- Beat lb of butter to a cream; add lb of sugar and 3 eggs separately (not beaten), a cup of milk, lb of flour, 1 teaspoonful cream of tartar and a teaspoonful carbonate soda; essence to taste ... (Dec 30, 1893,Bush Advocate,5)

Rainbow Cake. Three-quarters lb. butter; ?lb. sugar; 1lb flour; 1 teaspoon cream tartar; teaspoon carbonate soda; 4 eggs; ? cup milk, cochineal, enough to color; 2 tablespoons Cadbury's chocolate; vanilla to taste. (Sep 25, 1930,NZ Truth,20)

... rainbow cake (1901,NZ Illustrated Magazine,IV/855 ed.)

FINLAY RAINBOW CAKE... Divide mixture into 3 parts. Flavour 1st with teaspoon grated lemon rind., Flavour 2nd with teaspoon orange rind, and colour pink with cochineal... Add to the 3rd 1 dessertspoon cocoa... Bake about hour in 3 sponge sandwich tins... Fasten together with lemon honey, and ice all over with chocolate icing. (1948,Dunedin City Gas Dept. Cookery Book,120)

BASHAM Rainbow Cake... Divide into three lots. Make one pink; leave one plain; and add 1 dessertspoon cocoa or allspice to the next. Cook in three tins and stick together with jam. (1968,Aunt Daisy Cookbook, The,99)

"Rainbow cake" was a birthday treat; the chocolate, raspberry and vanilla sections all had to be separated and eaten slowly to be apreciated. (Feb 12, 2005,Dominion Post,E3)

Rainbow Rage¶

n. (Sport) an annual 106 km adventure bike race from St Arnaud to Hanmer, first held in 1996.

The annual Rainbow Rage event is a 106km mountain bike adventure ride that starts outside of St Arnaud, goes through some of the South island's awesome sub alpine high country and finishes in the Hanmer domain. (2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.rainbowrage.co.nz]

Rainbow Rage. The 11th year of this very popular point-to-point event that travels the 106 km from St Arnaud to Hanmer via the gravel Rainbow Road. (Nov 2005,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.vorb.org.nz/article-31310.html]

Sporting events included the annual mountain bike races the Rainbow Rage, with over 1000 competitors, and Molesworth Muster, with 560 participants. (Jun 2007,Conservation Action,26)

rainbow sneeze¶

n. a bout of vomiting, and its result - cf. technicolor yawn [ca1960 Auckland. (V. O' Sulliwan)]

Rainbow Warrior¶

n. the Greenpeace vessel scuttled in Auckland by French secret service operatives [e.g. in the phrase the Rainbow Warrior affair]

[Hdg] End of the 'Rainbow': the French perspective. After two bomb blasts sent the Rainbow Warrior to the bottom of Auckland Harbour on July 10 last year, the French press reported the condolences offered by the French ambassador in Wellington to the bereaved Greenpeace team. (Feb 15, 1886,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

Reports from France suggest that one of the few things French President Mitterand and his new right-wing Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac, have in common is a strong desire to retrieve the Rainbow Warrior bombers. (Apr 19, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

Later that year French secret-service agents bombed the Rainbow Warrior as it was preparing to sail from Auckland to Moruroa, killing a photgrapher on board. (Jun 21, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

2 n.

Around Peter Wilson's stable the kids have nicknamed him `Rainbow Warrior'. Punters know him as Harbour Road, the jumper who bombs out all the time. (Jul 20, 1986,Sunday Star (Auckland),B16)

rainbow-fish¶

n.

MORRIS Rainbow-fish, n. a New Zealand fish, Heteroscharus castelnaui, Macl. (1898,Austral English,379)

AYLING RAINBOW FISH Suezichthys sp. 2 (Halichoeres sp.) ... The rainbow fish is closely related to the crimson cleaner but is even more colourful ... (1982,Collins Guide,260,1984 ed.)

PAUL Rainbow fish Suezichthys sp. Another small and slender wrasse, even more colourful than the crimson cleaner ... (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,109)

[index to common names 283-293] rainbow-fish 1099 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Rainbows¶

n. WWI soldiers who reached the front too late

PARTRIDGE [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... Rainbows, such reinforcements as had not reached the front when Armistice was signed, from their arrival after the storm; (1935,Slang Today,286) [NOTES: 1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today 286]

raindrops payment¶

n. [(Unionists')]

Their refusal to ferry electricians in mini-vans to and from smoko sheds unless they get a time-and-a-half `raindrops' payment has led to their suspension - and 350 sparkies as well. (May 28, 1985,Evening Post,2)

rainforest¶

n. woodland in a mild climate with heavy rainfall, typically having many tree varieties but dominated by one, e.g. in New Zealand often by podocarps. Also called temperate rain forest.

The rainforests may be locked up to loggers, but since the end of felling in my area (Buller District) the chains and padlocks have come down and the forests are open once more to the public. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,304/42)

Rainmaker, the¶

n. nickname of John Ballance, premier of NZ 1891-1893

But it is difficult to understand why anyone called [Ballance] "The Rain-maker". Presumably, rain-makers make magic - and this Ballance failed to do. (Jul 29, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

rainwater tank¶

n.

His neighbour.. ushers us.. past the neat stacks of firewood and the big, never-less-than-three-quarters-full rainwater tank. (1992,North & South,60)

Mr. Peat's farm does not appear to be well watered naturally, but art has been applied to produce a full supply by the "ram" system which lifts the water through pipes from a running stream at the bottom of the estate. (Jun 30, 1883,Auckland Weekly News,23)

Maclean The majority of the townspeople [sc. of Wellington] were dependent on shallow wells, rainwater tanks, and some on water from running streams. (1964,Challenge for Health,68)

raised board/raised board woolshed¶

1 n. (Rural) a shearing shed in which catching pens and shearing board are raised on a platform, allowing ease of picking up and sweeping by shedhands.

Variations include centre-board, side-port, across-the-board, U-board, raised board and return race. (Apr 24, 1980,NZ Farmer,36)

top woolshed, 3 stand raised board with large covered yards. (Aug 5, 2000,Otago Daily Times,F10)

.. raised board woolshed with covered yards ... (Dec 2, 2000,Press, The,59)

Modern 3 stand woolshed - raised board. [r/b shed] (Nov 3, 2001,Dominion,49)

raised tin¶

n. a loaf = double tin

BYCROFT Double or Raised Tin (1934,Baking in NZ)

raisin jack¶

n. alcoholic liquor made from raisins [(prisoners')]

All the queens . . . had been drinking raisin jack and swallowing pills . . . and were falling all over the place . . . . (1982,Big Huey, The,NEWBOLD,127 ed.)

rajah¶

n. an erection, a tumescent penis [ca1938 -->ca1941, 1942 St Patrick's College (Silverstream)]

McGILL rajah tumescent penis; eg `Boy, the moment she came into the room I could feel this gi-normous rajah coming on.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,91) [NOTES: nf P. [check]]

RAK day¶

n. Random Acts of Kindness day, established in 2005. [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

R.A.K. Day Today. A day when you could 'R.A.K.' a family member, a friend ... (Sep 1, 2006,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.biggie.co.nz/editorial/news/rak_day.html]

RAK Day was launched by Josh de Jong and Marshall Gray in 2005 ... (Aug 29, 2007,Capital Times,3)

RAK day is the brainchild of Josh de Jong and Marshall Gray who thought it would be great to have a day where people throughout New Zealand did something nice for someone else for no reason at all. (Aug 26, 2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.aucklandcity.govt.nz/news/council/200708/26/a17.asp]

RAK day is on Father's Day this year! (2006,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.rak.co.nz]

rakapika¶

n. (See rata-piki)

rakau¶

n. dart

The brothers attemtped to secure Te Ika a Maui and struck him with their rakau and patu. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/17)

MANING Kawiti, who is himself a tohunga, throws a rakau for his own path. (1973,Old New Zealand,255) [NOTES: Original edition 1973]

n. flagstaff

wood - ra'kkoo [rakau] -->=flagstaff - (1835,Boultbee Journal,111,1986 ed.) [NOTES: >c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 111]

The fighting ought to be stopped at once by our Govt. (not by Potatau), who as our natives working here tell me is but a `rakau' (flagstaff). (May 10, 1858,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/396,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

MANING (1863,Old New Zealand,225)

BENNETT rakau, wood; wahine, woman; [etc] (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,93)

n. (Rural) mustering stick [also known as a nibby, hillpole or hillstick]. [ORIGIN: Maori]

SINCLAIR I swung my rakau hard. Bang! The stick hit the bull a home run right on the soft end of his nose. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,79)

LOUGHNAN rakau: musterer's staff. The word is Maori for a stick. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,65)

Mustering stick: rakau. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

n. rod as learning tool [ORIGIN: Maori, (from the net) Te Ataarangi is an immersion style of learning with rakau (rods). It focuses on developing oral fluency in te reo Maori, including tikanga Maori, ...]

The focus is on developing your oral fluency, following the Te Ataarangi immersion style of learning with rakau. (Dec 2, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

rakau momori¶

n. a Moriori tree carving

Just 50 years ago 1145 dendroglyphs, known to the Moriori as rakau momori, had been identified in the island's forests - at the last official count in 1998 there were just 185. (Oct 21, 2000,Timaru Herald,3)

The rakau momori was shipped back to the Chathams in time for the opening of the first-ever Moriori marae .. DOC is working with Moriori to identify future management needs for around 180 other internationally significant rakau momori. (Jul 2005,Conservation Action,53)

[caption] Jack Fry, a wood conservator, with rakau momori that he restored. (Jun 23, 2005,Footnotes,15)

Every known rakau momori was re-surveyed by a team of DOC staff last year and this revealed a continual gradual decline in overall tree health .. so management options are being considered in consultation with Hokotehi Moriori Trust. (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 6)

rake¶

v.

McLEAN "Rather than kicks at Duggan.. I intended to rake him." (1977,Winter of Discontent,92)

n. [(?mining)] (See cf. race noun hom.2 in DNZE)

HENDERSON RAKE: Trucks in single file. (1961,Friends in Chains,188) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 188]

FOXTON Specially prepared trucks were used to have the gravel out of the pits. Ralph found his duty was to help fill the trucks with gravel. Eight or nine trucks were used for each ballast train. This was called a `rake' of empty trucks (1921,At The Front,59)

EVANS [The coal] was then taken to a focal point in the mine and a rake of trucks was formed. A `rake' consisted of, on the average, from ten to twelve trucks. (1962,Waikaka Saga,78)

McARA Rake: `The rake' referred to the forty or so trucks of ore hauled constantly through Waihi by steam locomotives to the battery at Waikino. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),331)

1 v. (Rural) to snow-rake sheep.

MORRIS We raked them onto ridges where the wind has blown bare ground, and into scrubby gullies ... (1997,Different Worlds,30)

rake in¶

v. (Rural) to muster stock.

LANCASTER We've only raked in [i.e. mustered] seven hundred [sheep] (1905,Sons o' Men,11)

GUTHRIE-SMITH .. a further 500 sheep would be stragglers raked in at various draftings from the neighbouring stations... (1921,Tutira,155)

GUTHRIE-SMITH We lived on wild pig, wild beef shot on Kaiwaka, and the fat wild sheep and double-fleecers that could be raked in from river cliffs ... (1921,Tutira,221)

rake your wool¶

exclam. wake up! pull your finger out! [>ca1949-50 Wellington Teachers' College (C.D.Orsman) From literal meaning comb one's hair' P: rakecomb' jocular, from ca1860]

raker¶

1 n. set of teeth on shearing piece

BOWEN Hollow combs with big long rakers for the outside teeth are to my mind rather dangerous, and unless carefully used can make for rough shearing, especially when the inside raker is bent or winged out. (1955,Wool Away!,84)

2 n. elliptical for gully-raker

raker.See gully-raker. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

raki¶

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of paspalum (Dallas grass, Paspalum dilatatum). [ORIGIN: Maori]

Raki - high producing over summer, especially suited to moist northern regions of New Zealand and moist subtropical situations. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,27)

raking¶

1 n. hayraking

HENDERSON Here you are boss. Start raking. (1970,Open Country Harvest,189) [NOTES: First edition 1965]

Birds had little success in finding nesting material after the double raking that paddocks received when the sweeping was done. (Jan 1972,NZ Dairy Exporter,39)

2 n. snowraking

HENDERSON It's only in the worst winters.. and why 'raking' I don't know, because you don't use rakes at all. (1965,Open Country,187)

Rakiura¶

n. Stewart Island [ORIGIN: Maori]

rakkoo¶

v. (See rakau)

rakkyo¶

n. a small Japanese onion

A new vegetable said to be ideal for stir-frys, curries and salads is ready for planting and could be in the shops in time for Christmas dinner. It is a small onion, described by Crop and Food Research scientists who developed it as a cross between shallots and chives. Its taste is mild, somewhere between garlic and onion, and it is crisp in texture. Known in Japan as rakkyo and used in a popular pickle called tsukemono,it was brought to New Zealand in 1997 to be tested as a commercial vegetable. (May 25, 2002,Dominion,7)

rallykaboo¶

n.

Then he discovered that the he had a fearful thirst on him (This invariably follows a champagne rallykaboo) and he looked in vain for an open wet goods emporium. (Oct 13, 1906,NZ Truth,69/1/5)

ram¶

n. a pump

HARPER A ram pumped the water to a small reservoir near the house, ... (1975,Eight Daughters,36)

HENDERSON With the faint distant call of the creek and the Ram ticking, I knew writing had collected me, for keeps. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,105)

2 n. [ca1949]

FERNANDEZ That dirty old man of Erina's!'That fellow, the classer, he the Number One Ram.' cf WF ram bam 1943; P v. only `coit'. (1973,Tussock Fever,22)

Among young people greetings like Hophead',Ram', Burglar',Sheik', Stopout', are accepted as flattery:burglar' I heard only in the army. (Sep 1952,Landfall,208) [NOTES: (Pearson `Fretful Sleepers')]

2 n. male homosexuality; or perhaps its more bestial station objects -->cf. the Marlborough verse: `When I think of all the rams and the wether(s) I've been through/ There'll never be another you.' cf SHEPHERD'S GRUMMET

ELDRED-GRIGG On the wool stations women were hard to find so that consolations were homosexuality (known in Canterbury as 'ram') and grog. (1980,Southern Gentry,52)

ram block¶

1 n. (Rural) a large fenced area on a station where rams are kept, with little attention.

WHEELER Lake Hawea's history as a separate station is relatively short. It was formerly a ram block on the gigantic Morven Hills run of Big Jock McLean. (1971,Historic Sheep Stations SI II,32)

ram fair¶

n.

PERRY The rams are usually shorn early, especially those intended for the ram fair, so that they can have a fair growth of wool on them. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,83)

AYSON About this time I went to the Gore Ram Fair where I saw a pen of rams which ... were Corriedales. (1937,Pioneering in Otago,102)

RICHARDS My next job was to attend a ram fair' and buy some rams ...These were put in the best paddock toflush them up' before putting them out with the ewes, ... (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,148)

ram muster¶

1 n. (Rural) the gathering in of rams for inspection.

KERR Bill, Arthur's stuck for the ram muster. (2000,High Times in the High Country,15)

ram paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a field or paddock on a farm where rams are grazed, separately from the ewe flocks or a viewing paddock for ram buyers.

The improvements, which are very complete and in thorough good order, consist of stone dwelling-house, stone woolshed, men's hut, shearers' hut, barn, stable, sheepyard, stockyard, outhouses, grass-paddock, oat-paddock, horse-paddock, and ram-paddock, forming the home station. (Jan 17, 1885,Otago Witness,16)

In the ram paddock, on taking final delivery, the defendant said that he was between 300 and 400 short. (Mar 21, 1868,Otago Witness,6)

26 Australian Merino Rams, bred by Messrs. Buten and M'Masters, imported to Napier last year, and have since been running in Ram paddocks. (Jan 21, 1870,Hawke's Bay Herald,2)

The Hangaroa dogs trials, which were held in the ram paddock of "Strathlane" on Saturday last, proved quite successful. (May 20, 1919,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

This is the ram paddock. ... I don't go in for fat lambs right through. Like to breed my own ewe-hoggets. (1953,Breakfast at Six,17)

T.C.K. and Hughie fencing in ram paddock at Kaikanui. (Jan 4, 1879,Tutira Station Diary)

MCLEOD The traditional story has always been that they used Hallelujah Flat as a ram paddock. (1970,Many a Glorious Morning,59)

ram power¶

1 n. (Rural) the ability of a ram to inseminate ewes.

Mulvaney believes 'ram power' - the ability of a ram to inseminate a ewe and with high potency sperm - is a very important factor for successful mating performance, but says rams are often the most underdone animals on the farm. (2002,Wool Grower,24)

ram-tipping¶

1 n. (Rural) the turning of rams on to their backs, for inspection or shearing.

They did all that fencepost digging, trailer-backing and ram-tipping stuff, plus heaps more. (Nov 9, 2002,Dominion,A12)

rama¶

n. rum [ORIGIN: Maori, transliteration]

"Rum" (Rama) and "Brandy" (Parani) are merely "tots" of humanity, the names of children, "reincarnations" of bottles perhaps held in high esteem by the parents. (Jun 9, 1906,Evening Post,6)

ramarama¶

n. a shrub or small tree, Lophomyrtus bullata, of coastal and lowland forest, having shiny blistered leaves (more common in the North Island). [ORIGIN: Maori, [1919 July 29] Ver.(WB). = Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W.Best, Otaki (And) Myrtus bullata rum-a-rum]

R|ama r|ama; A shrub so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,LEE & KENDALL,99 ed.)

The ramiram for ramming in the posts in fencing [in Taranaki] (Jan 15, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/97)

Other edible berries include..ramarama (Lophomyrtus bullata), "very much like guavas" when fully ripe... (Apr 30, 2006,Dominion Post,E12)

HOOKER Myrtus bullata, Banks et Sol. ... Nat. name, `Rama-Rama', Cunn. ... An erect shrub or small tree, 10-15 feet. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 71)

HOOKER Ramarama, Col[enso]. Myrtus bullatus. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... (e.g.) the Houhere, Hoheria populnea ...; the Horopito Drimys axillaris ; the Manuka-rau-riki, Leptospermum ericoides ; the Kohuhu, Pittosporum tenuifolium ; the Kowhai, especially the small-leaved mountain variety Sophora tetraptera var.: grandiflora ; the Koromiko-taranga, Veronica, several species; the Mairehau, Phebalium nudum ; the Toro, Persoonia Toro ; the Pukapuka, Brachyglottis repanda ; the Northern Maire, Santalum Cunninghamii ; the Tawari, Ixerba brexioides ; the Tipau, Myrsine Urvillei and M. salicina ; the Tangeao, Tetranthera calicaris ; the Ramarama, Myrtus bullata ; the Ti, Cordyline australis ; the Kahikomako, Pennantia corymbosa ; the Pate, Schefflera digitata ; the Horoeka, Panax crassifolia : and, on the sea-coast, ... the (1869,TrNZI,1/III/5) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Karo, Pittosporum crassifolium ; and the truly evergreen Ngaio, Myoporum laetum ... Ibid. -1/III/31 the curious red fruit of the Titoki, or Titongi, ( Alectryon excelsum ); the fruit of the Tutu-papa ( Coriaria thymifolia ); of the New Zealand Bramble, Tataramoa, ( Rubus australis ); of two of the New Zealand Myrtles, the Ramarama ( Myrtus bullata ), and the Rohutu ( M. pedunculata ); of several species of Coprosma , - particlularly the Karamu ( C. lucida ), and C. robusta ), of the Papaauma ( C. grandifolia ), and of the two littoral speciedepressa ); ... and of the Kareao, or Pirita, ( Rhipogonum parviflorum ). s, Taupata ( C. retusa ), and Tataraheke ( C. acerosa ); of the Koropuku ( Gaultheria (1869,TrNZI,1/III/5 (cont.))

HAY The Rama-rama (Myrtus bullata) has a good hard wood, but is small. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/196)

[Native name] Ramarama .. [Settlers' name] Ramarama .. [Family] Myrtaceae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 122]

MYRTUS BULLATA. (Banks & Sol.) ... The `RAMA-RAMA'. This singular leaved species is almost confined to the Northern Island; where it ... varies from a small upright shrub, to a tree twelve to fifteen feet in height, ..Ibid. 178 Ramarama [Maori name] .. Ramarama [Settlers' name] .. Myrtus bullata .. Shrub (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,166)

Ramarama .. Myrtus bullata .. Timber reddish brown, hard, tough, and often prettily figured; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,13)

MORRIS Rama-rama..Maori name for a New Zealand shrub, Myrtus bullata, Banks and Sol. The name is used in the North Island. It is often corrupted into Grama. (1898,Austral English,379)

Rai.ma-rai.ma (ra.i.m&adot.-ra.i.m&adot.; colloq.r&ubreve.mi.$a-r&ubreve.mi.$a), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) A New Zealand myrtaceous tree Myrtus bullatus). [Local, N. Z., & obsoles.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2029)

CHBEESEMAN M[yrtus] bullata, Sol. ... Ramarama. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,168)

LAING & BLACKWELL Myrtus bullata [(The Ramarama)] ... A shrub or small tree.. Maori name Ramarama. ... rare in South [Island]. (1907,Plants of NZ,288,1940, p. 305. ed.)

GUTHRIE-SMITH The limestone range east of the lake [Tutira] at one time grew ... dense fern, high tutu, koromiko, and a considerable area of `whitey-wood' bush, kowhai, fuchsia, rama rama, ngaio, kaiwhiria, etc., etc., ... . (1927,Birds of New Zealand,2)

ramarama, a tree (Myrtus bullata), often corrupted to rummyrum. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157)

SARGESON rummy-rum: native running plant with small leaf; a bundle is springy when cut and dried: some call it micky-mick. [qv] (1949,I Saw in My Dream,279) [NOTES: (Waikato)]

LEVY ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, lacebark, wineberry, fuchsia, kowhai, with tree ferns, weki, and mamuku. Toetoe, phormium, cabbage tree, with swamp coprosma and hupiro may figure as a developmental phase on wet soils. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,87,1970 ed.)

~ n. New Zealand shrub [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

rama-rama... n. N.Z. shrub [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

JOHNSON During the warm months there was a long season for koninis from the kotukutuku trees (native Fuchsia) then ... the ramarama berries (Myrtaceae) were ripe. (1970,Life's Vagaries,16)

BROOKER et al. Lophomyrtus bullata (A. Cunn.) Burr. Common name: Native myrtle Maori name: Ramarama ... It was known as Myrtus bullata Sol. ex A. Cunn. (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,72)

ramarama n. NZ variety of myrtle. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,625) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

612 Ramarama slab. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,28)

Crowe Ramarama is also known to contain bullatenone, a derivative of furfural known to have antiseptic properties. (2009,Which Native Forest Plant?,50)

There are even a few ramarama, small shrubs with trademark "bubbles" on their olive and red upper leaf surface, and a carpet of parataniwha. (Dec 26, 2005,Dominion Post,B2)

2 n. Myrtus Ralphii

KIRK (1889,Forest Flora)

Rameka diorite¶

n. Geol. definition

Again the colour and the symbol for the talc-serpentinite and chlorite schist (mos) of the Onekaka Schist are about the same as those for the Rameka Diorite (rr). (Jun 1972,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,32/27)

rammer¶

n. a tool used to consolidate earth around a post [(fencing)]

The ramiram for ramming in the posts in fencing [in Taranaki]] (Jan 15, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/97)

(Annual Contracts, Col.Secretary's Office) -->a blasting tool [heading] TOOLS FOR ROAD PARTIES ... Blasting Tools/ Crowbars ......per lb./ Jumpers ......per lb./ Rammers .....per lb./ Spoons and Needles ......per lb....Saws/ Hand .....per foot./ Cross Cut .....per foot./ Pit ......per foot. (Dec 21, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/31/193)

Across the paddocks a man in a black singlet was planting a post, steadying it with one hand while he tamped the earth around it with short even strokes from a rammer. (1967,NZ Short Stories III,68) [NOTES: Middleton `Killers']

Rammer: Tool used to consolidate earth around a post. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary)

ramp¶

v. to leave, clear out [(criminals')]

WHITWORTH I was down there with Old Ashmore's lot, doing the trampoline, and so on; but things was very quizby. Everything went crooked somehow, and the gorger had a hawful cramp in his kick. Well, ramp was the word, and vamose we did, the lot on us; some here, some there. I was reg'lar beached, and I tell you when a cove 'as to spout his smish it's about time to look out. However, I got a job at a livery stable, but although that kep' me in grub, and I slep' in a spare stall, the billet was very multy, and I kep' on the kivvy for something better. [fn] 1. [trampoline] Vaulter. 2. [quizby] Bad. 3. [crooked] Wrong. 4. [cramp in his kick] Emptiness in his pockets. 5. [ramp] Clear out. 6. [vamose] Go. 7. [beached] Hard up. 8. [smish] Shirt. 9. [multy] No good. 10. [kivvy] Look out (qui vive.) (1879,Spangles and Sawdust,5)

A pickpocket ... `ramped' the captain, getting away with 7/10 (Aug 17, 1905,NZ Truth,9/7/8)

1 n. (Rural) a style of silage stack.

Some interesting information resulted from the survey of 49 wedges, buns and ramps made with the buckrake. (Jan 15, 1953,NZ Journal of Agriculture,33)

If above-ground silage is made, buns appear to have some advantage over ramps on flat ground ... (Jan 15, 1953,NZ Journal of Agriculture,38)

ramping¶

n. [as ODE verb ramp: rush about uncontrollably?]

Cath McWhirter's accent and ramping as Sharlene might be reined in more once established. (Nov 7, 2000,Dominion,27)

ramshorn shell¶

n. Spirula spirula

POWELL RAMS HORN SHELL (Spirula spirula). This is the white openly coiled shell about an inch long, which washes ashore in great numbers on our West Coast beaches. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,32)

SANSOM Ramshorn shells, the spirula, the internal shells of a small squid and coiled like a watchspring but papery-looking, lie ... among the `violets' [sc sea-snails]. (1970,Stewart Islanders,186)

WILSON RAMSHORN: see Squid. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,197)

ranch¶

v. to feed (possums) in close confinement [applied (?as an up-market alternative to farm) to the business of possum farming, salmon farming]

At the possum farm, animals are caught live and `ranched': fed in close confinement for three months prior to killing...Ranch the wild animal for three months and the fur becomes a much better commodity, says Keber. (Feb 6, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

ranchslider¶

n. sliding glass door

It hasn't got glass ranch sliders yet, so when the weather is bad, the roller doors are down and it looks closed. (Jul 17, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

ranchslider NZ glazed sliding door opening onto outside terrace etc. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,626)

MANTELL Smart looked once at Danny, remote on his humpty by the ranchsliders then he pulled a rocker closer to his wife's wing chair .. (1980,Murder or Three, A,169)

There are ... quite a few cases where there is a distinct New Zealand word - cutty grass, freezing works, graunch, ranch-slider, pie-cart, sheepmeat and jandals ((P) for proprietary name); no etymology is given for the last-named; I am told it is a portmanteau word from Japanese sandals; (Apr 26, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46) [NOTES: (Forrest Scott)]

Tidy 3-bedroom brick home, private section. Ranchsliders from lounge, double garage plus games room..he;FLY-SCREEN (Apr 22, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5) [NOTES: 1989 Mar 23 Property Press in 1989 Apr 22 Listener 5]

... jewellery worth about $120 was taken when someone entered the kitchen of a house through a fly-screen. (Apr 22, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5) [NOTES: 1989 Feb 25 Gisborne herald in 1989 Apr 22 Listener 5]

Our boxy green bach with uncool aluminium ranch sliders on a cliff outside Opononi is the place my husband Geoff and I are truly happy. (Mar 2003,North & South,122)

Owen Marshall They had ranchslider doors that opened onto a broad concrete patio... (2005,Watch of Gryphons,172)

Melanoma could have been an island off the coast of Sumatra for all the difference it made to the sun-crazed New Zealanders of legend, with their golden beaches and sandflies, baches and ranchsliders. (Jan 5, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),95)

random¶

adj. unacceptable, crazy? [international E?]

"It's really common for young guys to drive past and yell really random stuff." (Sep 15, 2005,Dominion Post,A8)

Another was proud of how having children meant he was always on top of kidspeak, like "munted" (for broken), "random" (for crazy), and "gay" (for unfashionable). (Nov 26, 2005,Dominion Post,B4)

Ranfurly Shield¶

n.

FRASER All Blacks Cooke, Mill, Johnson and Grenside played for the "Magpies" who retained the Shield this year [sc. 1926]. (1952,Ungrateful People,1952) [NOTES: Pagination from 1985 edition]

McMENAMIN Many people have tried to explain what Makes Ranfurly Shield rugby so special. (1986,Glory Days,12)

Hawke's Bay had lost the shield and that after getting Cookie and half the All Blacks to go and live in the capital of the province of the wool kings... Hawke's Bay had lost the Ranfurly Shield the only way they could lose it - by pinching. (Jun 9, 1926,NZ Observer,6)

The little country was growing up. Its footballers since 1902 had been playing for something called the Ranfurly Shield, donated by Governor-General Ranfurly. (Dec 5, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C7)

AUCKLAND VERSUS WELLINGTON SHIELD GAME DRAWN. (Aug 22, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,5) [NOTES: Headline]

THE RANFURLY SHIELD. The Ranfurly Challenge Shield presented by his Excellency the Governor to the New Zealand Rugby Union, was formally handed by his Excellency to Mr. A. C. Norris, Hon. Secretary of the Union, at Government House yesterday afternoon. (Jun 19, 1902,Evening Post,2)

GLOVER ... no one was to know that the Ranfurly Shield would become the most prized possession of the province. The village now feels the cynosure of all eyes ..., and though we have no players in the Shield team as yet, I appear to have belittled Rugby ... (1963,Bedside Book,110)

DAVIN . they were talking about who was going to win the Ranfurly Shield ... (1975,Breathing Spaces,44)

Ranfurly Shield premier trophy in NZ Rugby football. [fifth Earl of Ranfurly, Governor of NZ 1897-1904] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,626) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 403]]

Still, I could see they wanted someone outside themselves to believe in rainbows and trout and pots of gold and that Southland would win the Ranfurly Shield ... and Dad would win on his ticket to Tattersalls and take us all home to Galway where he'd come from. (Aug 29, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46) [NOTES: (Davin)]

But this Saturday will be the first time he has ever called a Ranfurly Shield challenge. (Sep 26, 1987,Dominion,2)

The decision of the Taranaki Rugby Union not to play Wellington for the Ranfurly Shield this season has not been favourably received... If Taranaki can lift the Shield, it will mean matches next season that we will otherwise not get. (Oct 17, 1904,NZ Observer,10)

Wellington will meet our reps. in Auckland in a special Ranfurly Shield match. (May 17, 1913,NZ Observer,10)

Three Ranfurly Shield matches between Hawke's Bay and Canterbury were played in the 1923-28 period. (Jun 11, 1940,Evening Post,5)

To be candid, the Ranfurly Shield has no great bearing on the selection of New Zealand teams. (Jun 5, 1935,NZ Free Lance,51)

The same season, Auckland regained the shield. (Jun 5, 1935,NZ Free Lance,51)

Ideal weather prevailed for the Bay of Plenty Challenge match against Hawke's Bay for the Ranfurly Shield. (Sep 7, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,54)

Southland made Rugby history when it won back the Ranfurly Shield from Otago in the same season in which it lost the trophy. (Sep 21, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,65)

rangatahi¶

n. [[Ma. rangatahi modern youth] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 211.]

But personally I like mixing with rangatahi like those at the secondary school, national waka ama competitions in Rotorua or the Whakawhanaunga hui hosted by EIT in Hawke's Bay last month. (May 2005,Kokiri Paetae,32)

It's hard for our rangitahi in this town. They don't have any money and there's no public transport. (Apr 15, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33) [NOTES: check spelling "rangitahi"]

Shew concludes, wrongly, that Te Kooti was a later name of the prophet. It was mentioned in 1852, when he was merely a troublesome rangatahi ("wild boy"), and was, as he himself said, his baptismal name. (Apr 2, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),109)

It has inspired so many rangatahi out there in Aotearoa. (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,8,Autumn ed.)

We get a bad rap when we go into town, and our rangatahi are going through that still, being picked up for nothing. (May 20, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

This book .. tells "the story of the rangatahi, modern Maori youth living in the city". (Oct 30, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

Ten years ago, it started as a vehicle for rangatahi on Marae .. Pomana continued music with hip hop group Dam Native before moving on to other rangatahi TV projects like Korero Time and Haka Time ... (Dec 2, 2003,Dominion Post,7,TV Week ed.)

rangatara¶

n. (See rangatira)

rangatera¶

n. (See rangatira)

rangatira¶

adj. [mostly adj]

He asserts that the rangatira company have a promise of a loan, whereas the diggers could not get the same. (Jun 11, 1859,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

The grace and gentle bashfulness of this rangatira damsel were in strong contrast with the coarse and rude appearance of the half-clad slaves .. (1847,Savage Life,2/85)

Te Puea says that the family are convinced that Rugby is the rangatira code, and the one on which the elect of all the tribes can meet in friendly contest. A minor victory of the kotahitanga movement. (Aug 24, 1935,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/200) [NOTES: Ngata 1935 Aug 24 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/200]

Some aptitude for carving was expected of all men of rangatira status, .. (1984,Te Maori,155)

n. a chief or noble person [ORIGIN: Maori, Commonly used by English speakers for people of public or private importance or mana]

BAUCKE I knew she was a rangatira's daughter when Te Rauparaha took her with others prisoner to Kapiti. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,216)

He was explaining how the children of the rangatira around here were carted off to Tasmania and seriously sexually abused. (Aug 14, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

BIG RANGITIRA EX-MINISTER of the crown and a champion of his people as well as their guide and mentor, Dr. Peter Buck (Te Rangihiroa) has returned to New Zealand for a brief season. (Mar 27, 1930,NZ Truth,4)

An old rangatira was farewelling the young warriors, explained Mr. Bennett, and in doing so remarked that he had heard the Germans were in sore straits for food. (Dec 17, 1914,Evening Post,6)

COLLINS Etang-a-te[acute]da Eti-ket-ti-ca, means a principal chief, or a man in very great authority. ... Etanga-roa, or E-ta-hon-ga, is a priest; whose authority in many cases is equal, and in some superior to the Etiketica... Etan-ga-teda Epodi, a subordinate chief or gentleman.'Ta-ha-ne Emo-ki, a labouring man.' (1804,English Colony in NSW,344)

SAVAGE Rungateeda. .... A friend (1807,Some Account of NZ,77)

NICHOLAS Duaterra immediately recognised [the chief], and ... behaved to him with particular respect, touching noses with him, the usual mode of salutation in this part of the world, when any honour is to be paid, and which he did not do with the other chief. The latter he contemptuously described as an ittee ittee rungateeda, or a chief possessing very little power. Ibid. 1/227 He assisted us ... but reflecting at intervals on the rank he held among his countrymen, which was that of a rungateeda, or gentleman, he would several times shake his head, and cry out against this indignity, ... Ibid. 1/292 All the males belonging to the family of the chief are styled rungateedas, and these have generally servants of their own to wait upon them. Ibid. 2/339 A gentleman Rungateeda (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/91)

CRUISE ...saying, `that if it were the child of a rungateeda, or gentleman, it should be laid in tabbooed ground, and every funeral rite paid to it; but that a cookee could not be allowed even the decency of burial, ... (Apr 26, 1820,Journal,87,1957 ed.)

LEE & KENDALL R|anga t|ira; A gentleman or lady. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,200)
