McCRAE Pomarre[acute] .. .. Rungatyeeda no te Kaaingha. E Wharre[acute] .. .. Whaheene[acute] no Pomarre[acute]. Poaka .. .. Tamyte[acute] no Pomarre[acute]. ... E Po .. .. Koeteedo no Pomarre Whaheene no Tenana. (1820,Journal,27,1928 ed.)

BEGG [| = macron precedes] ... giving them to understand Capt K was a Rangata|ra Nue (great Chief) ... (1979,World of John Boultbee, The,196) [NOTES: 1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 196]

[They] exaggerated ... amongst their own countrymen, giving them to understand Capt.K. was a Rangatira Nue (great Chief), ... Ibid. 112a chief - rangata'ra [rangatira] (1835,Boultbee Journal,79,1986 ed.) [NOTES: >c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 112]

McNAB They are divided into two classes, viz., ranghateeroos (or chiefs) and their relations of different degrees of consanguinity, and cookees (slaves), who are nearly black, and much shorter, and appear a different race of people. (1908,Historical Records,1/696) [NOTES: 1829 Mar 2 Atkins's Narrative in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/696]

MARKHAM You may see the Cookee [kuki] or Slave / doing that, and throwing it to the Chief or Rangitara [rangatira] or his Wife. [fn] Merely a Maori form of the English `cook'. Polack gives this explanation ... [NZ 2/110-111]. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),37)

WAITE `I, Toawick, are now become Rangatera or Chief of these Southern territories', and he affixed his moko (the tattoo marks on his face) to the deed. (1940,Port Molyneux,37) [NOTES: 1835 Dec 31 Tuhawaiki's confirmation in 1940 Waite Port Molyneux 37]

McNAB To all whom it may concern be it known that I Toawick [Tuhawaiki] are now become Rangatera or Chief of these Southern Territories ... Witnesses ... George Moss, Mowry, x his mark. Tomarama, Mowry x his mark. (1913,Old Whaling Days,96) [NOTES: 1835 Dec 31 Deed in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 96]

BIDWILL It appears that if two tribes are at war, and the chief of most consequence in one tribe were to marry the only daughter of the corresponding `rangitera' of the other, that would not do anything towards making peace between the two tribes; ... (1841,Rambles in NZ,33,1952 ed.)

SARAH GREENWOOD He is so much liked by all [the natives] especially by the rangatiras or gentlemen. (Nov 10, 1844,Letter) [NOTES: 1844 Nov 10 Sarah Greenwood Letter in 1960 Drummond Married Gone NZ 79]

MANING ... all these qualifications combined made him unquestionably `a great rangatira', and, as he had never been defeated, his mana was in full force. Ibid. (viii) 120 The fighting men and petty chiefs, and everyone indeed who could by any means claim the title of rangatira - which in the sense now use it means gentlemen - were ... possessed of this mysterious quality. (1863,Old New Zealand,(vi) 90)

CAMPBELL No, no!' exclaimed the native vehemently.Martinera is a raugaturahchk sic =rang-, he will not betray Okinga; see, there is the pah.' (1864,Martin Tobin,1/67)

I then called out to them not to keep a rangitira bound with ropes but to put the handcuffs on me ... (Jul 4, 1868,Chudleigh Diary,224,1950 ed.)

... the two Pakehas who had come to live with them were Rangatiras. (1881,Poenamo,Bk3/2/141)

HAY Accompanied by a score or so of the rangatira of his hapu, the ariki rode over to the young settler's place. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/175)

Te Kooti is at Puketapu with many Rangatiras. (Dec 21, 1893,Otago Witness,11) [NOTES: (Morris)]

Rangatira, n. Maori word for a chief, male or female; a master or mistress (Williams); therefore an aristocrat, a person of the gentle class, distinguished from a tau-rikarika, a nobody, a slave. (1898,Austral English,379)

BAUCKE (1905,Where the White Man Treads,216)

~ n. a chief, male or female; an aristocrat; a person of rank; an employer, the master or mistress. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,9)

rangatira, a chief, male or female: rangatiratanga, evidence of breeding and greatness (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

rangatira: chief. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

HENDERSON As Inspector of native schools, I was much attracted by the old type of Maori rangatira, both men and women ... (1948,Taina,vii)

The Maori word for a chief or the members of a chief or the members of a chief's family, an aristocrat. (Pronounce the ng as in `hanger'.) (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),329)

MASTERS When he died he was buried in the little Maori Cemetery on Taylor's Hill, where Tu Taylor, and other Maori Rangatiras are also interned; which was certainly something of an honour for a pakeha. (1959,Tales of the Mails,83)

SINCLAIR Within each tribe the population was further divided into slaves, who were mostly prisoners of war, tutua or commoners, and the numerous class of chiefs, rangatira. At the head of the tribe there was a paramount chief, the ariki. Ibid.. 302 [Maori glossary] rangatira Chief (1959,History of New Zealand,20)

FRANCES He was a rangatira and, above a chief, he was a tohunga pouwhiro, high priest and teacher ... (1964,Johnny Rapana,2)

~ n. Maori Chief, an aristocrat [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

rangatira ... n. Maori Chief, an aristocrat [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

rangatira n. N.Z. a Maori chief, of either sex. [-->[1983 Otago] - (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,946) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 626; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 403]]

BELICH rangatira chief (1986,NZ Wars, The,337)

MANING The chief also, having made some enquiries ... - such as, whether I was a rangatira, if I had plenty of taonga (goods) on board, ... gave me a most sincere welcome. (1863,Old New Zealand,(i)6)

CARBERRY He [a Maori] also said that one of the Militia officers that was killed here was a very brave Rangatira as when lieing mortally wounded a Maori struck him on the back of the head with a Tomahawk and was leaving him for dead when he saw the wounded man turn on his back ... (Nov 18, 1863,Journal)

GUSTAFSON Maui our Ancestor fished up this Aotearoa of ours from the dark waters of Kiwa. Today it is our Rangatira Savage who is fishing up this Maoriland of ours from the gloom and slime of depression .. (1986,Cradle to Grave,[facing 232) [NOTES: >1938 Labour pamphlet for Northern Maori in 1986 Gustafson Cradle to Grave]

CRAIK ... Rungateedas, or, as it has been more recently written, Rangatiras, which appears to answer nearly to the English term gentry. (1830,New Zealanders, The,204)

Rai.nga-tii.ra (ra.i.ng&adot.-t&emacr.i.r&adot.), n. [Maori.] A Maori chief; a magistrate; lees exactly, a leading citizen. [New Zealand] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2029)

KEENE rangatira: chief, male or female; well-born noble. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

The natives shrewdly observed that he was the only Rangatira, or gentleman, among them and that the rest were only cookees or slaves. (1839,New Zealand in 1839,30)

They all jabbered and cut capers when they knew the taurikarike pakeha had mated up with the daughter of such a rangatira. (1900,Auckland Weekly News,Xmas No. / 17)

The "rangatira" handed round the beer in a bucket, the source of supply being an 18-gallon keg... The [Maori] witness explained that the Maori who ordered the beer and called the meeting was the "rangatira" for the occasion... On Christmas Day at the .. kainga, everyone was more or less a "rangatira." (Mar 4, 1916,Wairarapa Daily Times,4)

2 n. [of status, from Maori to general NZ use]

Mr SEDDON is not, we beg to say, the chief rangatira of the pakehas. So long as the Queen is represented by a Governor, that Governor will be our chief rangatira, save only under the pen of a "Ministerial journal." (Apr 12, 1894,Otago Witness,3)

F. MATHEW I first visited a native Pah ... and I made myself known to them as a Rangatira or chief in the service of Her Majesty. (Mar 14, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Mar 14 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 80]

WAKEFIELD I took care to tell them that the rangatira, or `chief' missionaries, would come out with the settlers. (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/173)

DOMETT Though roughly drest and travel-stained,/ A Rangatira' - of the sort/ Who paid for all attentions shown:/ [fn]Chief or Gentleman'. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,ii/289)

rangatira (Oct 19, 1918,Featherston Camp Weekly,17) [NOTES: (Les Cleveland)]

BAKER rangatira, a leading citizen, a magistrate (taken directly from he Maori), in very early use. (1941,NZ Slang,59)

SOLJAK New Zealand colloquialisms which are of Maori origin include; ... rangatira: leading citizen (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),117)

BACON rangatira-A chief; a leader amon men. (1963,In the Sticks,18)

DAVIS The big rangatira standing by him's the meat inspector. (1964,Watersiders,36)

WILSON Remember, I'm a chief, Ken. Too right I am.'Is that dinkum? Dinkum? You're a - rangatira?' `Too blimmin right I am. ...' (1965,Outcasts,91)

BOYD A buggy became the status symbol of a rangatira. (1984,City of the Plains,10)

rangatira girl¶

n. a high-born young Maori woman [? a coinage of Miller's in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 141 or does it echo or copy an original in Chapman]

H.S. CHAPMAN [quotation marks enclose Chapman's original] Unable to bear the solitary life, not a few acquired Maori wives', which wasthe conventional name for a Maori mistress'. The native women often welcomed the squatters with bouquets of flowers and became very attached to their young men. The high-born Rangitira girls were sometimes richly beautiful, displaying a lithe elastic figure, soft brilliant eyes and rose brown complexions, set off by glossy black hair falling to the knees. (Nov 24, 1847,Letter) [NOTES: 1847 Nov 24 H.S. Chapman letters to His Father [TS, ATB] in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 141]

MILLER :cf MAORI WIFE] The native women often welcome the squatters with bouquets of flowers and became very attached to their young men. The high-born Rangitira girls were sometimes richly beautiful ... Ibid. 166 Always quick to imitate new fashions, the young Maoris would turn out for their own flat and hurdle races attired in true jockey style ...; while the attractive Rangatira girls also took to the saddle, equipped with gauntlets and silver whip, habit, hat and plume. (1958,Early Victorian NZ,141) [NOTES: [possibly reflecting Chapman Letter 24 Nov 1847; with cap: is this Miller or reflects Bell in Stafford Papers 21/12/1851]]

rangatira landlord¶

n.

There are many of these rangatira landlords, who have leased large blocks of first-class land at a good figure. (Mar 12, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,22)

rangatira Pakeha¶

n. a well-to-do European [ORIGIN: Maori, Also, rarely, 'rangatira Pakeha-Maori']

"Lady Stout suggests," said Mrs. Pomare, "that the Maori girl could learn domestic work and the rudiments at least of the art of housewifery at the domestic college, and then? - and then go out to service in rangatira pakeha families to finish her education. .. Will any of the ladies of the rangatira pakeha families have the girls sitting at their tables with them? I think not." (Jul 20, 1908,Evening Post,7)

In such opinion, we concur, not only on that account, but for the further reason, that the natives cannot long keep a secret, - and now these rebels have all received full pardon themselves, they will not scruple to talk of their rangatira pakeha correspondents. (Jan 31, 1846,New Zealander, The,2)

She then told me that Mr Hyman (Jack, as she called him) would be home by five o'clock and his dinner was being cooked then, but she expected he would bring some fish with him, as he always caught some on his way back from Herd's Point, where he had gone with a lot of poultry and sucking pigs for the hotel, as a party of rangatira pakehas were on their way there. (Mar 19, 1898,Southland Times,6)

HENDERSON I replied that I wanted to stay with ... my father, who was a rangatira pakeha, just as my Mother was a rangatira Maori. (1948,Taina,134)

MANING Rangatira - A chief, a gentleman, a warrior. Rangatira pakeha - A foreigner who is a gentleman (not a tutua, or nobody, ...), a rich foreigner. (1863,Old New Zealand,236,(Auckland edn ed.)

CAMPBELL The excitement consequent upon our arrival, which extended through the whole tribe, was not simply because two Pakehas had arrived, but because they were two Rangatera Pakehas who had come to live amongst them. The ordinary Pakehas the natives had hitherto come in contact with had been for the most part runaway sailors - ... (1881,Poenamo,3/2/140)

GRIEVE And here was the rangatira Pakeha a whole day before his time. Aue Aue. [fn] rangatira - a chief. Pakeha - a white person. Aue - a wailing expression of grief. (1939,Sketches from Maoriland,46,1961 ed.)

The Maori look to Makarini, the rangatira pakeha-Maori, and he gets blamed by both parties, Maori and pakeha, when anything goes wrong. (Jul 30, 1873,Timaru Herald,2)

Rangatira spider¶

n. (Environment) a spider found only on Rangatira Island in the Chathams [ORIGIN: Maori]

The island is also a haven for various rare plants, insects and the Rangatira spider, one of the largest known in New Zealand. (Aug 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 52/ 88)

[caption] The threatened Rangitira spider. (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 13)

rangatira wahine¶

n. a high-born Maori woman [ORIGIN: Maori]

DOBSON This good whata belonged to Purua, a rangatira wahine, who lived here with her servants (1930,Reminiscences,68)

rangatiratanga¶

n. chieftainship; (Maori) sovereignty, self-determination [ORIGIN: Maori] (See tino rangatiratanga)

A New Zealander's "Mana" is his "Rangatiratanga"; that is, his Influence, or his Respectability. (Jun 5, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,3)

This, and the inherent pride of the Ngatimaniapoto people, has given rise to jealousy amongst them of the attempt on [sic] the King to establish a rangatiratanga or chieftanship over the land. (Jul 5, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Rangatiratanga is a collective concept. You can't sell your rangatiratanga. In the Treaty of Waitangi, the word "rangatiratanga" appears in article 2. It is translated as "ownership" in the English version. Maori are guaranteed their rangatiratanga over lands, forests and fisheries. (Sep 4, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

Judging from his speeches to the natives, it would appear that it is their absolute independence he requires - nay the "rangatiratanga," the chieftanship for Israel, who are the Maoris, over the Gentiles, who are the Europeans, in the Parihaka vocabulary. (Sep 1, 1880,Hawera & Normanby Star,3)

T.S. GRACE Some time before we came to Taupo a handsome Pataka' (viz. a Maori store for food) had been burned. Sir George Grey when on his visit to Taupo saw the said Pataka and told Te Heuheu (no doubt in a jocose way) that it was a sign of hisRangatiratanga.' (Mar 24, 1858,Letter) [NOTES: 1858 Mar 24 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 76]

BELICH rangatiratanga sphere, authority, of the chiefs (1986,NZ Wars, The,337)

The Principle of Self-Management The Rangatiratanga Principle The iwi have the right to organise as iwi, and, under the law, to control their resources as their own. Ibid. 11 The New Zealand Maori Council has explained the concept of Rangatiratanga as meaning more than possession':it means the wise administration of all the assets possessed by a group for that group's benefit: in a word, trusteeship' (Te Wahanga Tuatahi, 1983, p 5) In the Crown's view, the First and Second Articles of the Treaty are both strong statements which necessarily qualify one another. Kawanatanga is subject to a promise to protect Rangatiratanga. Rangatiratanga is subject to an acknowledgment of Kawanatanga. The working out in practice of the balance between the two Articles must depend upon a case by case consideration. ... It is the right of all citizens, Maori, Pakeha, and other New Zealanders, that there be effective Government or Kawanatanga in such matters. (1989,Principles for Crown Action,7)

More insidiously, the actual terms of the treaty such as "rangatiratanga" and "full and exclusive possession" are being redefined to proscribe Maori rights. (Nov 19, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

The first, on behalf of the Whakatohea iwi, is seeking rangatiratanga and kaitiakitanga - authority and guardianship - over a 50km stretch of Bay of Plenty coastline east of Whakatane. (Sep 30, 2005,NZ Herald,A2)

Michael King To Heke, it seemed that the rangatiratanga promised to the chiefs in the Treaty had been usurped... (2003,Penguin History of New Zealand,163)

rangaturah¶

n. (See rangatira)

range¶

n. (esp. as the ranges) mountainous or high country not necessarily forming a single divide

Snow was to be seen upon the Tararua range on the 6th of May, for the first time this year. (May 9, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

In the direction of W. by S. we thought to distinguish Kapiti about 60 miles distant, and the sea from which several ranges of hills separated us. (Sep 12, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

CHAPMAN The tops of the high range of hills are covered with snow.] (1840,Papers,15) [NOTES: (T.M. Partridge)]

... to the Northward the Range called [Tararua] banded our view.) (1840,Journal of Ensign Best,229,1966 ed.)

~ n. a mountain.-rang'y a. hilly, mountanous. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,9)

JOHNSTON Mr Parkins and Stan were to leave a 3 a.m. for the range, the former working his two dogs and the latter his faithful Pat. `Stan, you know your beat,' announced Mr Parkins ... (1968,Turn of the Tide, The,63)

The land between the Inch Clutha and these ranges, much of which is swampy, is laid off in section extending 16 miles from the coast, and containing nearly one half of the Otago block. (Jan 1855,Australian & NZ Gazette) [NOTES: 1855 Jan Australian and NZ Gazette in 1856 Fitton NZ 180]

As the roads always run on the tops of the leading ranges (as they are styled), ... a more extensive prospect than the eye can embrace is frequently presented. (1862,Otago: Its Goldfields and ReSources,34)

It is a fine sight you see the river flowing down between mountains 3 and 4000 ft., the [70] lofty back ranges looking blue and the tops covered with snow. (Dec 13, 1962,Chudleigh Diary,69,1950 ed.)

ASHWELL ... Wooded ranges. (1863,Letters & Journals,IV/460)

BARRINGTON This place forms a basin with low ranges and made hills. [ed fn] Presumably gravel hills - i.e. the remnants of high gravel terraces formed (made) by the river in the past. (Mar 27, 1864,Diary) [NOTES: 1864 Mar 27 Barrington Diary in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 404]

The others went down the sides of the ranges, clearing the sheep off as they went... Ibid. 202 Mustered down to the Coal Gully and camped there. (Oct 4, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,146,1950 ed.)

MUELLER The greatest drawback with beach diggins is, they are so quickly washed out. Unless they find gold in the Ranges, and have deep sinking, there is very little prospect of the diggers now at the Coast remaining long. (Jan 2, 1866,My Dear Bannie,100,1958 ed.)

BARKER ... F-- asked me if I would like to ride across the hills, and pay my first visit to some ... old friends ..., who were among the earliest arrivals in the province, and who have made a lovely home for themselves ... on the other side of our range. Ibid. 117 Behind the lower hills ... rises a splendid snowy range ... (1866,Station Life in NZ,75,1870 ed.)

LINDSAY Hence a Spear-grass Scrub' on the hill ranges is frequently most formidable ... to men and horses, though it forms one of the favourite hunting grounds of the Wild Pig. In the Matukituki Valley,Bayonette-grass' forms an undergrowth in a dense scrub of prickly thorn ... (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,49)

ST JOHN The most violent sentiments ... were naturally expressed by [Opotiki] men who saw that their lives ..., and the safety of their houses and crops, were daily in peril at the hands of savages inhabiting the back ranges. (1873,Pakeha Rambles Through Maori Lands) [NOTES: 1873 St John Pakeha Rambles in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 560]

The two made little excursions up and down the Gorge, and over the ranges, and when tired they returned to their anchorage; .. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/viii/30,(1889,1974) ed.)

KENNAWAY After crossing the steep ranges which I have names as forming a rugges barrier between the harbour and the open country, we struggled up ... to the banks of the river .. Ibid.. 50 ... we found ourselves clear of the ranges, on level country, ... Ibid. 135 ... this done, and our greetings over, one of the sheep was seized and (while C., who had been on the ranges all day, was refitting himself) we killed it by starlight ... Ibid. 204 The cattle ... were half-wild, restless brutes, imported from Australian back-stations, or bred on the equally wild ranges to the north of our own island. (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,11)

MEREDITH The wild dogs had been among the sheep, and were evidently camped in the ranges at the back of the outstation, as we could hear them howling quite close at night. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,65,1935 ed.) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 65]

WOOD c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 65 (1875,Waiting for the Mail,43)

HAAST The view from Major Scott's station is really very striking. First, Lake Coleridge lying like a deep blue mirror amongst the curiously shaped ranges, formed the centre of the landscape. A number of high hills, which from their remarkably regular form, have aptly been designated Sugarloaves by the settlers, appear in several directions; Ibid. 125 High snowy ranges ... rose above, but owing to their distance ... they did not impress the mind with their truly gigantic dimensions ... (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,121)

HAY ... an abrupt succession of ranges, gullies, and basins. Ibid. 2/11 The logs are easily collected ..., as they can be sent down the sides of ranges by means of screw-jacks, rollers and slides. (1882,Brighter Britain,1/179)

MORRIS Ranges, n. the usual word in Australia for mountains.' Compare the use oftiers' in Tasmania. (1898,Austral English,379)

COWAN [In February 1864] he suceeded in getting commissariat through to the troops ... by rapidly cutting a pack-track from Raglan Harbour over the ranges to the Waipa ... (1922,NZ Wars, The,1/303)

HYDE It was a good life on the hydro. Men dragged home quarters of deer from the ranges to fill the cook-pots, ... or learned from the Maoris to make eel-traps, wickerwork structures which caught the big black-sided fellows down in the stream. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,126)

CRESSWELL For not content with settling the flat lands and accessible ranges, in their frenzy they laid bare even the steepest and most inaccessible mountains, ... (1939,Present Without Leave,9)

Willie and his old man were panning for uranium in the ranges at the time. (Mar 1952,Here & Now,27)

TURNER English topographical words which are much commoner here are gully, flat, terrace and ranges. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,161)

SLATTER Real cobbers up in the ranges, Brian Brooks climbing Woolshed Hill, yarning around the camp fire, the possums' eyes gleaming above. (1968,Pagan Game, The,172)

FOUND ON THE RANGES. (Aug 10, 1906,Bay of Plenty Times,2)

1 v. (Rural) to inspect or supervise stock or activity [e.g .dog range, bush range, forest range.]

HINDMARSH He ranged the bush blocks and employed the predominantly Ngapuhi bush gangs ... (1997,Come Be a Pioneer,79)

range alongside¶

v. [(horseracing)]

Peter Johnson on Flying Luskin ranged alongside ensuring Horlicks went back behind those ahead. (1991,Radio NZ Sporting Annual,31)

range country¶

n.

MASTERS Deer were then starting to, and have now become, something of a problem in our range country; ... (1960,Back-Country Tales,57)

range gum¶

n.

The [kauri-gum] samples analysed were - (a) Resin recently secreted by the tree; (b) resin which had been a long time exposed to air or lying in store (bush gum); (c) fossil resin (range gum); (d) resin obtained from peat-bogs (swamp-gum). (1930,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,11/303)

range maggot¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep. (See maggot magnet; maggot taxi)

TARRANT Sheep are known as range maggots, in the summer as maggot taxis, and shepherds as sheep shaggers. (2002,Glossary,1)

range nut¶

n. a type of kauri gum

... one ingenious individual, knowing that white range nuts' were twice as valuble as blacknuts', obtained a quantity of the latter and carefully shook them up with some white pipeclay from the hillside. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/96) [NOTES: (Firth)]

... fossil resin (range gum) (1930,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,11/303)

range up¶

v. of a racehorse, runner etc, to come up within range, or level with, another; used also of a rugby player, to come up in support of a runner [cf. range alongside]

GEE (1966,Short Stories (various authors),277) [NOTES: [get quot: Check OEDS.] 1959 Gee in 1966 Short Stories 277]

PHILLIPS At the turn it was the same except that she was pleased to hear Royal Return had ranged up on the outside of Conformist. (2000,First Past the Post,240) [NOTES: Maurice Gee "The Losers" in Landfall 50 June 1959]

Laughing Prince went up to Admiral Drake, and Vertigern also ranged up (Sep 16, 1929,Evening Post,6)

At the turn it was the same except that.. Royal Return had ranged up on the outside of Conformist. (Jun 1959,Landfall,13,No. 50/153 ed.)

Ranging up on the outside, Autosweep won going away from Eupatrid. (Aug 31, 1940,Taranaki Herald,24)

ranger¶

n. [general or unspecified, implies official role of warden]

Poaching is rampant at the upper end, and yet the upper ranger never brought a charge home to any one during the whole season. (Aug 20, 1896,Timaru Herald,3)

Stop. I am a ranger. You are breaking the law. (1989,Chosen Place,6)

49 Vict. 30/77 Any ranger or other person may drive any cattle or other animal.. to the nearest public pound. (1885,NZ Statutes)

The Minister may.. appoint such honorary rangers as he thinks fit for the purposes of this Act, and all persons so appointed shall be deemed to be Forest officers within the meaning of this Act. (1921,NZ Statutes,12 Geo.V 43/338)

That on and after November 1 the Ranger be instructed not to impound cattle, sheep, or horses, grazing on roads within the Otangaki, Hiwinui, Taonui, Makino, Raumanga, and Mangaone ridings, between the hours of 7 a.m. and 5 p.m.; this, however, not to apply to entire animals nor swine; rangers are instructed to inform the county solicitor of cases of swine and entire animals grazing on roads, and the owners to be prosecuted; the rangers are further instructed to impound at all hours animals wandering on the river beds and so destroying the settlers' protective work. (Oct 10, 1908,Feilding Star,4)

In this district the services of Rangers and Surveyors were requisitioned to make inquiries with a view to supplying those in need with grass-seed to replace the grassed land that had been destroyed. (1908,AJHR,C-1/22)

Witness said he was a ranger for the Auckland Acclimatisation Society. (Apr 6, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,45)

rangership¶

n.

Having passed accounts for Papanui and Hooper's Inlet roads, and deferred the consideration of several tenders for the rangership, the Board adjourned to Monday, 28th December. (Dec 12, 1874,Otago Witness,10)

Applications for Rangership of Havelock Commonage close at Mr. F. Oudaille's, Havelock. (Jan 7, 1880,Tuapeka Times,2)

ST LEONARDS JULY 9. - The cattle nuisance has altogether ceased since the rangership was handed over to the police constable. (Jul 12, 1894,Otago Witness,23)

BAUCKE But there can be no finality to a system of inspector, valuer, and rangerships; where coercion is juxtaposed to base compliance; ... where `good enough' is labelled on loop-hanging wire fences, [303] despondent cowsheds, dogleg stockyards, wire-hinged field-gates, ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,302)

Those duties would generally be to impound all unlicensed cattle found trespassing on Crown Land or public roads within the limits of his Rangership, but not to impound cattle of licensed persons in one Hundred merely overstepping the boundaries of an other, except in cases of constant and extensive encroachment. (Jan 31, 1851,Daily Southern Cross,3)

At all events, it is high time that the rangership be established on a better footing. (Aug 31, 1866,North Otago Times,2)

ranges¶

n. [see also at range n.]

BARKER It was a true New Zealand day, ... the ranges of mountains in the distance covered [18] with snow, and standing out sharp and clear against this lovely glowing heaven. (1865,Station Life in NZ,17)

CAMPBELL No longer solitary are the waters of the Waitemata, stretching away from our primitive whare on the beach to the foot of the western ranges - ... (1881,Poenamo,Bk4/7/300)

He has had a rough time of it surveying a block on the ranges up the Wai-o-hine in the Wairarapa ...[sic] Once ...[sic] they had nothing to eat but a tui and a more-pork. ... They were stewing the two birds when a kuku-pa (bush pigeon) flew up and perched. Bob shot it ... This is not exactly what the Britishers call `sport' - but there is more of nature about it than 30 gents in pink and tops ... waiting for a wretched little fox who, when he is killed, is not equal for culinary purposes to a more-pork. Once coming up the Waikato in 1851 your Uncle James got a pot-shot at a lot of parera (grey duck) ... (Mar 22, 1894,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/597,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

HARPER There is also the rata tree, the prince of firewoods, ... miki-miki, kamahi, or so-called red-birch, white and black birches (which are really beeches), the mountain broom, ribbon wood, broad leaf, totara, and many others, ... and always available in the Ranges [sc. Alps]. (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,35)

VIRTUE The hills were called the Ranges. The Ranges spread along the skyline all the way to Wellngton. (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,34,1984 ed.)

ranghateeroo¶

n. (See rangatira)

rangi¶

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of rape, a brassica forage crop. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Rangi forage rape - highly palatable. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,72)

Rangi rape is his preferred choice ... (Sep 25, 1997,NZ Farmer,14)

n. tune [ORIGIN: Maori]

The rangi they like to break to is old school and techno. (2002,Te Mana Taiohi,4,Summer 2002 ed.)

Rangi¶

n. a Maori god

LADY MARTIN (1884,Our Maoris,213)

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,IV/435)

BAUGHAN Rangi (Rah-ngee): The sky. -Ibid. 198 Rangi, etc. (Rang-ee, Pah-pah): Heaven and Earth (1908,Shingle-Short,56)

Rangiatea Church¶

n. the historic Otaki Anglican church built in 1851, destroyed in 1995 by fire, and re-built and opened 23/11/2003 as a replica of the original.

Even those who have lived all their lives in Otaki can hardly believe their eyes. Rangiatea Church is back. The totara church, known as the oldest in Maoridom, has risen from the ashes eight years after it was destroyed by fire. (Nov 24, 2003,Dominion Post,A4)

Rangie¶

n. a Range Rover or similar vehicle

It snowed softly as the Rollers and Rangies glided to a stop. (Oct 1999,North & South,130)

The active stabiliser bars of the cheaper Land Rover I can't praise highly enough. No doubt they'll surface on the new generation Rangies for their ability to tame the roll-steer of sports utility vehicles. (Jun 2, 2000,Evening Post,Autopost : 2)

ranging¶

n.

FRANCIS Without the past years of stock farming, horse riding ... I could not have coped with the varied ranging duties, which were the first step towards my becoming New Zealand's first Wildlife Oficer. (1983,Wildlife Ranger,6)

rangiora¶

n.

Often overlooked as a vase choice, a few stems of the native Rangiora Brachyglottis repanda blooms look very classy by themselves in a large glass vase... (Nov 2, 2002,Dominion Post,F14)

FARRELL She takes a rangiora leaf and wipes Tia's watery eyes. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,273)

n. a broadleaved evergreen New Zealand tree. [Maori] Brachyglottis repanda, broadleaf, pukapuka, a shrub

The Wharangi kura does not produce gum in the North; there is, however, a tree of the same variety callled Rangiora, which does. (Oct 3, 1857,Taranaki Herald,6)

HOOKER Rangiora, Col[enso]. Brachyglottis repanda. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

36 Puka puka or Rangiora (1868,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Botany of North Island)]

CHEESEMAN B[rachyglottis] rangiora, Buch. ... Rangiora. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,367)

LAING & BLACKWELL Plants of this genus [Brachyglottis] are well-known to the Maoris, under the name Rangiora. The leaves were much used by them for application to wounds and old sores. (1907,Plants of NZ,435,1940, p. 472 ed.)

LEVY ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, lacebark, wineberry, fuchsia, kowhai, with tree ferns, weki, and mamuku. Toetoe, phormium, cabbage tree, with swamp coprosma and hupiro may figure as a developmental phase on wet soils. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,87,1970 ed.)

MASTERS On one occasion the buggy horses were tethered to some rangiora bushes. For something better to do while they were waiting, they had a good old feed of leaves from the bushes, which, of course caused them to become intoxicated. (1959,Tales of the Mails,68)

rangiora n -s [Maori] : a New Zealand shrub or small tree (Brachyglottis repanda,) of the family Compositae having stout branches and lower leaf surfaces densely covered with white tomentum and small heads of flowers crowded in terminal clusters (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1881)

rangiora [s] Brachyglottis repanda Forst. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,62)

rangiora n. a broad-leaved shrub of New Zealand. [< Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,946) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 626; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 403]]

DAWSON Accompanying species may be the two common larger-leaved coprosmas both known as karamu: C. robusta and C. lucida, the bubbly-leaved ramarama (Lophomyrtus bullata), wharangi (Melicope ternata), the `tree daisies' heketara (Olearia rani) and the familiar large-leaved rangiora (Brachyglottis repanda). (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,103)

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] an indigenous tree of the spp. Brachyglotti, known to hunters, musterers, and trampers as 'bushman's friend'.

GUTHRIE-SMITH Later, appeared slender matapo .. rangiora. (1921,Tutira,51)

MASTERS On one occasion the buggy horses were tethered to some rangiora (1959,Tales of the Mails,68)

2 n. Brachyglottis repanda

LAING AND BLACKWELL (And) (1906,Plants of NZ)

(And) (1907,AJHR,COCKAYNE) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island]

COCKAYNE (And) (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest]

rangiriri¶

n. inanga, a smelt [([Ngai]Tahu.)]

MANNERING Another Maori name for the smelt is rangiriri'. I have witnessed the autumn migration of these fish to the sea, both in Hawke's Bay and Taranaki, and seen Maoris filling sugar bags with them ... They usually call themMother Whitebait'. (1943,Eighty Years,158)

Rangitata goose¶

n. paradise duck

FALLA et al. PARADISE DUCK Tadorna variegata Other names: Putangitangi, Rangitata Goose. Description: 25' Of intermediate size between the ducks and the larger species (Canada Goose and swans). (1966,Birds of New Zealand,87)

Rangitata skink¶

n. (Environment) a skink discovered in 2004, resident only on Mt Harper in the Rangitata gorge; closely related to and coexisting, but not interbreeding, with the Long-toed skink. [Oligosoma "Rangitata"]

Jewell This skink is known from a single mountain, but unless specimens are examined up close they are easily mistaken for the much commoner McCann's skink, so Rangitata skinks could well have been overlooked at other localities. (2008,Reptiles and Amphibians of New Zealand,83)

Rangitata skink: Discovered in Canterbury this year. Much larger relative of the long-toed skink. Chestnut brown with prominent pale stripes. (1999,BLANK ENTRY) [NOTES: Date fabricated no details for this citation. Looks to be same format as Sinbad Valley skink.]

Rangitawa pumice¶

n. Geol. defn

Another widespread silicic airfall tephra reported from southern North Island is the Rangitawa Pumice and its possible correlatives, the Omahina Tephra (Pillans 1979), the Lower Finnie Road Ash (Seward 1974 ; Pillans & Kohn 1981), and the Mangaroa Ash (Neeser et al. 1980), all with fission-track dates in the two-standard deviation age range of 370 +- 70 ky BP (Pillans & Kohn 1981; Kyle & Seward 1984; Kohl 1986, oral presentation). The site 594 tephra could therefore be equivalent to the Rangitawa Pumice and its correlatives. (Nov 1988,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,82/36)

rangiterer¶

n. [transf. to an upper-class colonist; a local (Wellington) leader] (See rangatira)

MANSON There is not many days but some of our rangiterers are walked to jail for debt. I hope I shall soon be a rangiterer but not go to jail. (1971,I Take Up My Pen,27) [NOTES: 1842 S. Retter in 1971 Manson I Take up My Pen 27]

Rangitoto¶

n. the iconic Auckland Harbour island volcano

From the air, Rangitoto's 258 m high sunmmit looks more like a green poached egg than a rugged volcanic cone. Molten lava spewed from around the crater as recently as 600 years ago and plenty of raw rock is still visible between the clumps of encroaching trees. While the eruptions left Rangitoto with a black and scaly skin, ash deposited on neighbouring Motutapu Island.. smoothed the topography and endowed it with up to two metres of rich topsoil. Ibid. 24 ...[Tamatekapua's] fate endures in the island's full name - "Te Rangi I Totongia A Tametakapua" or "the day the blood of Tametekapua was shed"... The early eruptions of Rangitoto were the most ferocious, driven by seawater flashing steam as it encountered fresh magma at 1200 degrees C. (Jul 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 68/21)

Rangitoto Yank¶

n. a non-Auckland nickname for Aucklanders

Waihi. The Rangitoto Yanks. - S. Island name for Aucklanders, c.1960-1970 (Apr 19, 1984,Personal Communication) [NOTES: Submitted by David More]

McGILL It seemed downright peculiar to be leaving what Dad called Auckland's dolsi vita' ...Do you know what they call us in Wellington?' Dad asked on the way. What?'Rangitoto Yankees.' I had never heard it, but I figured it was a small price, ... to pay for what Dad reckons is Paradise. Ibid. 171 I miss that underground mutton.'Eh?' `Rabbit. You are back in 10 minutes with your supper.' ... We need an Eric Partridge to record these Kiwi colloquialisms like underground mutton, Rangitoto Yankees, leather ladies (possums hit by trains in tunnels, where the flies don't get to them and they petrify) and the Waiouru blondes (sheep). (1985,G'day Country,49)

It's always good to beat the Rangitoto Yanks,' [the Wellington rugby coach] said,and a lot of Wellington guys feel really strong about that. (Apr 11, 1987,Dominion,40)

The rest of New Zealand has always hated Auckland and Aucklanders, seeing us variously as parasites and Rangitoto Yanks' ... <i>(May 1987,Metro,66</i>) [NOTES: RogerAuckland Life']

McGILL Rangitoto Yankee Aucklander, allegedly of the brash imitation American variety, equivalent of Fitzroy Yank in Melbourne, Woolloomooloo Yank in Sydney. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,91)

Not for me a bout of fisticuffs when provoked by natives of Canterbury bleating, "Our power keeps you Rangitoto yanks afloat." (Oct 1992,Metro,56)

With some justification, Wellingtonians are pleased to call us "Rangitoto Yanks" and affect to scorn Auckland's big-city excitement and glamour. (Feb 6, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

Rangoon cane¶

n. a fishing rod

They'd started out with rangoon canes, fishing off the rocks and now they were a bunch of people with a few small boats fishing off a coast with South America in one direction and Antarctica in another. (Mar 25, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

ranguru¶

n.

FALLA et al. CHATHAM ISLAND PETREL Pterodroma axillaris Maori name: Ranguru. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,52)

[45.1 Pterodroma axillaris] (Salvin, 1893) Chatham Island Petrel (Ranguru) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,24,1980 ed.)

Chatham Island Petrel Pterodroma axillaris (SALVIN, 1893) ... OTHER NAME: Ranguru ... Fewer than 20 specimens of this rare petrel have been banded. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,81)

adj.

rangy ... adj. large, loosely built (of a beast). (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

rank¶

adj.

rank: terrible, repulsive (behaviour, appearance) (1981,Auckland Secondary Teachers College) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

ranunculus¶

n.

JAN WELD ...several veronicas of great beauty, wild thyme, dwarf yew, Alpine rose (consanthenum), white violet, a ribes, several heaths, gentianella, harebell, a lily, and several varieties of ranunculus. (Jan 1851,Letter) [NOTES: 1851 Jan Weld Letter in 1851 Feb 21 NZGG 34 ...]

2 n.

SEDDON Daisy-like celmisias grew in drifts and between rocks near the series of little lakes at the top of the pass, and fields of mountain lilies which older people called ranunculas opened their white petals and nodded to the passer-by, ... (1968,Seddons, The,57)

3 n.

This pure colour saturation and kaleidoscope of colour belongs to one flower - what we in New Zealand prosaically call garden ranunculus. They are called Persian Buttercups overseas, or Turban Ranunculus, Fair Maids of France and Persian Kingcups. (Sep 16, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

3 n. Ranunculus Haastii

3 n. Ranunculus crithmifolius

raoulia¶

n.

BRASCH The raoulias [Otago] grew in irregular circles, slightly mounded, dew-green, milk-green, fresh light jade-green, silver, palest turquoise. (1980,Indirections,410)

HENDERSON No other tree grew in sight, only dead thistles and orange and silver-grey raoulia flat on the stones. (1974,Open Country Muster,205)

Now these spurs are a desert, except where immense scab-like raoulias almost cover the surface. (Oct 7, 1924,Otago Witness,31)
