WILSON Pseudopanax edgerleyi RAUKAWA ... Small tree. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,82)

DAWSON Raukawa ( Pseudopanax edgerleyii) has palmately compound juvenile leaves with up to five deeply lobed leaflets. (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,37)

raumanga¶

n.

RICHARDS [Polypodium] diversifolium ... Climbing Polypod. RAUMANGA. (1952,Chatham Islands,15)

raunu¶

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a New Zealand-bred cultivar of ryegrass.

All the seed is certified, the Raunu is mother seed and the Huia is first generation. Here is the mixture he uses per acre: Ryegrass (Raunu) 4lb ... (Oct 1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,33)

rauparaha¶

n. native convolvulus (See also pohue)

Of course, the introduced, white-flowered convolvulus is not to be confused with our native convolvulus - raparaha or pohue - the small edible namesake of awesome Ngati Toa leader Te Rauparaha. According to the Dictionary of New Zealand Biography, soon after Te Rauparaha's birth, a Waikato warrior who had killed and eaten a relation of his, threatened to eat the child as well, roasted with rauparaha leaves - and the child was named Te Rauparaha in defiance of this threat. (Nov 1, 2003,Dominion Post,E13)

Introduced white-flowered varieties [convolvulus]are not to be confused with our native convolvulus, rauparaha or pohue. This small edible plant gave its name to the awesome Ngati Toa leader, Te Rauparaha... A coastal plant, rauparaha has curled leaves in a rounded heart-shaped, quite thick and waxy, with pink striped flowers of the distinctive morning glory form. (Nov 8, 2001,Contact (Wgtn),18)

raupatu¶

n. (Politics) confiscation [usually of land] [ORIGIN: Maori]

Like many Maori, they appear to regard such a law as another raupatu, another forcible seizure of Maori property rights, and are understandably upset. (Dec 14, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C3)

As Maori, we had stories about land we used to have and the raupatu was a point of shame for us. (Dec 1998,Mana,37)

Beulah, my mum, is a product of raupatu. (Oct 1998,Mana,No. 24: 21)

A claim was also made to the land laying [sic] to the north of Waikawa stream, through the "raupatu" of Pakanui and Rongopakeiwi, and also from occupation. (Jul 10, 1885,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

One fine old chief said that "If Mahuta climbed a tree he would do the same; if Mahuta jumped over a precipice, he would follow; but they would have none of Messrs. Heke and Ngata's Bill," which they termed and attempted "raupatu," or conquest. (Sep 17, 1900,Evening Post,7)

The Whatonga people had fled and though the mana of the different incoming tribes over land had been at least partially determined by "take raupatu" (conquest), rights were still subject to challenge. (May 20, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

"As one who grew up on a farm on raupatu land in the Waikato, where our family's presence felt like it had been for ever, I cannot even begin to imagine the scale of loss felt by Waikato Tainui from the mid-19th century, but I hope that I and my government have played our part in putting right" she [Helen Clark] said. (Apr 9, 2009,Dominion Post,A3)

A claim was also made to the land laying north of Waikawa stream, through the "raupatu" of Pakanui and Rongopakeiwi, and also from occupation. (Jul 10, 1885,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

We are still open and anxious to meet them and combine for the good of the native race, but we are not going to submit to a raupatu, conducted by a small party, who don't own the bulk of the land, or, at any rate, of marketable land in the North island. (Sep 17, 1900,Evening Post,7)

The Raupatu Commission has recommended your Taranaki people a fund of ₤5000 per annum, Waikato ₤3000, Whakatohea ₤300, and N'Kahungunu, Wairoa ₤300. (May 6, 1928,Na To Hoa Aroha,1/90 and fn) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

SORRENSON But the most notable of the grievances was the raupatu - the confiscation of Maori land during the New Zealand wars of the 1860s in Taranaki, Waikato, Bay of Plenty, and the East Coast. (1986,Na To Hoa Aroha,1/33)

In his judgement, Justice Cooke noted the Crown did not challenge that the raupatu of Tainui lands in 1864 was in breach of the treaty. (Nov 20, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),126)

2 n. confiscation

The iwi were reluctant to sign off on a deed of settlement until they had a report from the tribunal ... on the raupatu [confiscation] aspects, to guide both parties and confirm the historical background. (Oct 29, 1999,Dominion,3)

Nabb's report.. provides a snapshot of the fading of a dream to take the $170 million raupatu settlement and quickly turn it into a legacy of wealth for generations to come. (Feb 9, 2000,Evening Post,5)

raupeka¶

n. the native Easter orchid. [Maori]

raupeka, a fragrant orchid (Earina autumnalis), flowering in autumn as name suggests. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

RICHARDS E[arina] autumnalis ... Brides' Bouquet. RAU PEKA (branch plant). (1952,Chatham Islands,22) [NOTES: [spg RAU PEKA]]

SALE Here [in the bush] we found, growing on a fallen log, the spiked fronds and the tiny deep-scented flowers of the New Zealand Easter orchid - raupeka or Ereaua autumnalis. (1982,Four Seasons,116)

WILSON Earina autumnalis EASTER ORCHID ...Raupeka (1982,Stewart Island Plants,288)

raupeti¶

n.

HOOKER Raupeti, Col[enso]. Solanum nigrum. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

Also, the cooked leaves and herbaceous tops of [32] the Toi (Barbarea Australis), and of the Poroporo, or Raupeti(Solanum nigrum); and the baked inner stems and sago-like pith of the large black fern tree, Korau, or Mamaku (Cyathea medullaris). (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31-32) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

raupeti, a plant (Solanum nigrum), doubtful if native or introduced; but name and habit suggest native. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

raupo¶

v.

CAMPBELL Had they shown the same assiduity in raupo-ing the walls of the house as they did in smoking their pipes we should have had no cause to grumble, ... (1881,Poenamo,4/4/276)

adj. [attrib. See also raupo hut, r. cottage, r. church, r. house, r. whare, et al]

POLACK The sail is made of raupo flags or kiakia [a's-acute], grass, etc., of triangular shape; it is fastened to two small rickers or poles, which serve for both mast and yards, and is fixed upright between the gunwales. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/23)

CAMPBELL ... a great number of `rapeoo forras' ... (1840,Present State of NZ,17)

JENKYNS ... rapu bushes. (1892,Hard Life,213)

..sea-borne breeze/ Trill on the lute-edged toi-toi spear,/ And passing up the valley to the falls/ Curtseys the rapa reeds the creek. (May 25, 1942,NZEF Times,9) [NOTES: 1942 May 25 NZEF Times 9 in 1979 Cleveland The Iron Hand 23 .]

Another highly curious article of vegetable food was the pungapunga, the yellow pollen of the raupo flowers- the common bulrush, or cat's reed mace (Typha augustifolia... To use it as food it is mixed up with water into cakes and baked. It is sweetish and light, and reminds one strongly of London gingerbread. (1881,TrNZI,XIII : 28)

Understanding I needed plenty of; oldest boy in a family of eight on a raupo-ridden dairy farm; in the sugarbag years. (Mar 31, 1993,NZ Tablet,12)

WILLIAMS The circumstance of the burning of Capn. Duke's house has made us somewhat thoughtful relative to raupo buildings. ... This question will require some consideration but wattle and dab is exceedingly expeditious and very durable. (Dec 17, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,91,1961 ed.)

What was once boxthorn-covered farmland near the cottage, with its raupo-lined pond,. is being tamed as the couple plant natives in accordance with a planting guide. (Mar 8, 2003,Dominion Post,F5)

Another measure which has excited surprise and alarm in this District, is called the Raupo House Ordinance, by which the Governor is empowered to issue a proclamation fixing a day after which all houses constructed wholly or in part of thatch, reeds, flax, and other materials extensively used in building, are subjected to the enormous tax of twenty pounds per annum. (Apr 2, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a swamp-growing bulrush Typha orientalis or T augustifolia.

MILLER Although the Maoris had burned only 'a few bundles of raupo', this was made the occasion of an armed expedition proceeding to the Wairau to arrest the chiefs on a charge of arson. (1958,Early Victorian NZ,70)

The roof was thatched with raupo and strips of totara bark called "flags." (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,205) [NOTES: Writing of 1940]

A shadow would sometimes darken those eyes coloured light brown, like the velvety heads of raupo. (Mar 13, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

Houses are built by the natives for the settler in the bush of a species of rush called "Raupo," which is found in abundance in all the swamps, this being cut and dried, neatly tied with strips of "Koradi" or native flax, to a frame-work of wood, and the roof is thatched with a tough species of grass; they are sometimes very tastefully lined with reeds. (Oct 28, 1843,Daily Southern Cross,4)

Now it was a mud-filled hollow, with just the tips of raupo showing above cracked mud. (May 29, 2004,Dominion Post,E16)

NICHOLAS Flaggy grass Roupo (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/339)

LEE & KENDALL Raup|o, s. A species of reed of a soft and spungy nature. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,201)

EARLE Another party was collecting rushes, which grow plentifully in the neighbourhood, and are called raupo.' - <i>(1827,Narrative of a Nine Months Residence in NZ</i>) [NOTES: 1827 Augustus Warle,Narrative of Nine Months' Residence in New Zealand,' `New Zealand Reader,' p. 67: (Morris)]

WILLIAMS He was left for dead, but ...he crept amongst some rushes, and afterwards constructed a canoe of raupo , and crossed over to the main. (Mar 31, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,304,1961 ed.)

MARKHAM ... the Thatch is the Toie Toie [ toetoe ] a kind of Flags that is used for the Huts, and an other one more like what our Coopers use for putting between the seams of a Cask, called Rappoo [ raupo ]. Ibid. 37 [cf COOPERS' FLAG] Rappoo is a Flag or Marsh Reed, used in England by Coopers to put between Staves of Casks; ... (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),35,1963 ed.)

MATHEW Fairburn's house is built by the natives of what they call `rapou', that is, long reeds matted thickly together and tied ... (Feb 26, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 26 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 63]

POLACK ... and a flax-house at [186] Uwoua, eighty feet long by twenty-four broad and forty feet high to the ridge-pole, was built by a chief and a large company of natives for a small keg of powder 25lbs. in weight. The house was extremely water-tight and warm, and several streams and marshes had been denuded of their rushes ( raupo ) to cover the roof and sides; ... Ibid. 1/206 ... a thick coating of bulrushes ( raupo ) cut from the marshes in the spring, and left to dry during the summer, packed up in long bundles. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/185)

The raupo, the reed-mace of New Zealand, always grows in swampy ground. The leaves or blades when full grown are cut and laid out to dry, forming the common building material with which most native houses are constructed.' <i>(1842,NZ Reader,122</i>) [NOTES: 1842. W. R. Wade,A Journey in the North Island of New Zealand,' `New Zealand Reader,' p. 122:]

DOMETT Section 2. ... there shall be levied in respect of every building constructed wholly or in part of <i> raupo, nikau, toitoi, wiwi, kakaho </i>, straw or thatch of any description [... 20 [pounds]' <i>(1843,Collection of Ordinances</i>) [NOTES: 1843.An Ordinance for imposing a tax on Raupo Houses, Session II. No. xvii. of the former Legislative Council of New Zealand': -->[From A. Domett's collection of Ordinances, 1850.]]

... lined with rapo, a kind of bulrush, ... (Feb 16, 1842,Letters from New Plymouth,5) [NOTES: (1842 Feb 16) 1843 (1968) Letters from New Plymouth 5]

DIEFFENBACH The same species [Typha augustifolia] is common to both hemispheres. Under the name of repo, or raupo, it is a most useful building-material to the natives ... [bundles of which] they tie together with the mangi-mangi, a climbing fern, the Lygodium articulatum of Achille Richard. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/426)

BROWN rapou (cooper's sedge) (1845,New Zealand and Its Aborigines,66)

ANGAS Close to Pipitea is a ware karakia , or chapel, belonging to the Christian natives, which is built of raupo and tohi-tohi grass, according to the native fashion. (1847,Savage Life,1/235)

Another chief comes and stays with us ... He and I go and get rappoo , that is the native name for firewood; he takes a tune on the trump; different natives can play, they say is is capi, that is, good. (Jul 20, 1848,Letters from Otago,16,1978 ed.)

WAKEFIELD Together with the succulent root of the raupo (Typha angustifolia), a kind of bulrush which grows in the swamps, the fern-root affords an excellent maintenance to the wild hogs. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,148)

[The Waikato river] runs through a rich level of deep fern fringed with raupo (a bullrush). (Mar 25, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/80) [NOTES: J.C. Richmond]

Raupo! Raupo!! Raupo!!! The Undersigned is prepared to supply the Inhabitants of the town with this invaluable article. It can be warranted free from maggots, &c. &c.. A bed made from this article will be found a colonial substitute for goose's down. (Jun 28, 1851,Lyttelton Times,2)

Typha angustifolia , L. ... Nat. name, `Raupo', Col. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 238)

FITTON The land ... growing flax or `raupo' (a weed like a bulrush, which generally grows on peaty soil,) is generally the most fertile, .. (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),261)

Went for rapu (Apr 10, 1860,Puketoi Station Diary)

VON TEMPSKY sp. raupu The troops had hutted themselves for the winter in huts built of a sapling framework, walls of `raupu' (a species of rush in New Zealand swamps) and roofs of long grass. (1864,Memoranda,181)

HOOKER Raupo, Col[enso]. Typha angustifolia. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

Raupo. Typha angustifolia, Linn. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/49) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Typha latifolia Raupo (1870,TrNZI,2/126) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

TINNE There was some difficulty in picking one's way ... through the tall raupo (rush) and tohi-grass; ... (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,28)

ANON `It was thatched with raupo or native bulrush, and had sides and interior partitions of the same material.' (1877,Colonial Experiences,10)

DOMETT Green rushes ( Raupo ) ..... O. Typhaceae; G. Typha; S. T. angustifolia. `Extensively used for making walls.' (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/303)

MORRIS Raupo, n . Maori name for a New Zeland bulrush, Typha angustifolia , Linn. The leaves are used for building native houses. The pollen, called Punga-Punga (q.v.), was collected and made into bread called pua . The root was also eaten. It is not endemic in New Zealand, but is known in many parts, and was called by the aborigines of Australia, Wonga , and in Europe `Asparagus of the Cossacks.' Other names for it are Bulrush, Cat's Tail, Reed Mace , and Cooper's Flag . (1898,Austral English,382)

Rá.u-po (ra.́.u-po.; colloq. roú.po.), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) A very common bulrush ( Typha angustifolia ), much used by Maoris and New Zealand settlers for thatching roofs, and for making hurdles, rafts, etc. [ New Zealand ] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

The roof was ... covered with raupo - sometimes with an inner sheeting of totara-bark - while an upper layer of toetoe-grass, secured by ropes of mangemange ..., preserved the raupo from wet. (1903,TrNZI,35/22)

CHEESEMAN T[ypha] angustifolia, Linn. ... Bulrush; Raupo. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,743)

BAUGHAN Raupo (row-po): A kind of bulrush. (1908,Shingle-Short,184)

~ n. a plant like a bulrush, used for building huts, thatching, etc.; the source of punga-punga. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,9)

BEATTIE What we used to call flags then [in the 1840s], but now known as bulrushes or by the Maoris called rapo (or raupo), were used by the coopers then. They were inserted between the joints and kept the oil casks as tight as a drum. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,29)

ANDERSEN The word is commonly mispronounced `rapoo', and was so pronounced and spelt as far back as 1840. (1942,Maori Place Names,276)

ANDERSEN raupo , a waterside plant (Typha angustifolia), bulrush; much used for thatch: often mispronounced rapoo. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146)

ZIMMERMAN The poi is an egg-shaped thing, made of the pith from a swamp plant covered with a woven cover of raupo, somewhat like the leaves of the cattail. (1946,Where the People Sing,18)

BEATTIE Early in 1859 we read [in the Puketoi Station Diary] of .... the cartage of what is variously spelt rapu, rappo, raupu, and raupo' <i>Ibid.</i> 111 Raupo, which we had always heard calledrapu' (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,77)

raupo : bulrush. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

At one time the gully slopes were covered with toitoi, rapu and scrub. (Dec 30, 1954,NZ Farmer,3)

SINCLAIR Sometimes the walls themselves consisted only of raupo , a plant resembling the bulrush, or even of reeds. (1959,History of New Zealand,101)

HILLIARD You can see the swamp and the raupo and toetoe. (1960,Maori Girl,215)

McLINTOCK The vocabulary of New Zealand English has been influenced by ... the adoption of Maori words and phrases. ... Examples of the native words now in general use are the names of birds, fish, plants, and trees: kea, tui, hapuku, tarakihi, koromiko, raupo , and kauri . (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/769) [NOTES: (Wall NZ Speech)]

McLINTOCK Raupo (bulrush).. .. koreire, raupo .. .. Typha muelleri (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

~ n. New Zealand giant bulrush, the Australian wonga (q.v.) [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

BRATHWAITE RAUPO Type of reed. - (1967,Evil Day,381)

raupo ... n . N.Z. giant bulrush, the Australian wonga (q.v.) [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

63 raupo [s] Typha orientalis Presl. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds)

BURTON The inner parts and roots of the raupo (Typha orientalis) provided a meagre amount of food, but the seed heads were prized for their bright yellow pollen which was made into loaves known as pungapunga . (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,5)

raupo n. a marsh reed common in New Zealand. [<Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,950) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 628; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 404]]

WILSON In my spare time I went continually down to our muddy creek among thick blackberry bushes, dark soft raupo and high teatree. (1984,South Pacific Street,7)

By the banks, the typha angustifolia, or raupo, flourishes. (Nov 5, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

Several days search in a boat in the beautiful bays of Lake Ianthe, where raupo grows rank,.. gave the same results. (May 18, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

GUTHRIE-SMITH On Tutira grew a few acres of tussock-grass (Poa caespitosa) a few score acres of flax (Phormium tenax) and of raupo (typha augustifolia). (1921,Tutira,104)

TAIT The peat still grew raupo, flax, niggerheads and rushes. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,24)

KEENE Trying not to panic, I ran along the ridge skirting the raupo swamp. (1978,Mimiwhangata Station,25)

2 n. [ellipt. for raupo hut or cottage]

SARAH MATHEW (Mar 20, 1840,Journal)

LUSH Reached Mr. Lusk's raupo cottage about 1/2 past 12.) (Oct 26, 1850,Auckland Journals,30,1971 ed.)

LUSH Reached Lusk's raupo about 9. (Apr 25, 1851,Auckland Journals,1971)

raupo bread¶

n.

'Smell'.. 'Musky. Spicy. Raupo bread and a horseblanket spread on a summer hillside.' (1999,Sport,40)

raupo church¶

n.

For several years previous the Roman Catholics of the district were without a clergyman, and the only indication of Catholic worship in the parish was a rather delapidated [sic] old raupo church erected by some natives a few years before, at the instigation of Father McDonald, brother to the popular Father Walter of Howick. (Aug 5, 1889,Bay of Plenty Times,4)

The earth which covered the bodies of the brave of both races who had fallen in battle was still without vegetation, and the rough, hard boards, carved by loving, faithful comrades, indicated the names of the fallen in the little graveyard which surrounded the raupo church at Rangiriri. (Apr 5, 1909,Taranaki Herald,7)

.. in a short space who will there be that can recollect the raupo church on Mount Elliot ... (Feb 27, 1864,Taranaki Herald,2)

A raupo church, 25 x 18 feet, was built, ... (1940,Matthews of Kaitaia,58)

raupo cottage¶

n.

Has about 35 acres under cultivation; all fenced with 5 sod ditch and bank; 3 acres manuka cleared; wooden house and outhouses erected; a considerable quantity of draining done; raupo cottage erected on north side of farm. (Feb 28, 1877,Bay of Plenty Times,2)

AUCTION SALES. PROFITABLE INVESTMENT. CONNELL & RIDINGS WILL SELL BY PUBLIC AUCTION, At their Mart, Queen-street, on WEDNESDAY, 2nd August, at 11 o'clock, unless previously disposed of .. 1 ? acres of land fenced and cultivated, and well stocked with choice fruit trees, together with a Raupo Cottage thereon; of this lot immediate possession can be given. (Jul 29, 1848,Daily Southern Cross,1)

raupo house¶

n. [also raupo-house]

140 acres of land had been laid down in grass, for which he claimed GBP140; five head of cattle lost, GBP50; two cows, GBP30 .. raupo house, GBP60 ... (May 2, 1865,Daily Southern Cross,5)

He had not been gone above a few minutes when a loud scream was heard from the raupo house. (Jul 24, 1915,NZ Truth,9)

Another measure which has excited surprise and alarm in this District, is called the Raupo House Ordinance, by which the Governor is empowered to issue a proclamation fixing a day after which all houses constructed wholly or in part of thatch, reeds, flax, and other materials extensively used in building, are subjected to the enormous tax of twenty pounds per annum. (Apr 2, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

Mrs Bowen lived with her parents in a raupo house until her father drowned in the gusty harbour. (Oct 30, 1900,Star, The,1)

The immigrants by the Amelia Thompson and Oriental squatted down on land near the beach at the foot of Mount Eliot, living in tents and raupo houses built by the Maoris. (Jul 2, 1891,Taranaki Herald,1)

JOSEPH WYLIE SENR., 280 acres - About 30 acres in cultivation; fenced with 4 sod ditch and bank, set with thorn quicks, at present engaged in ploughing and clearing; good garden; resides in raupo house, intends erecting a wooden house; has plough horses[,] 2 cows, and states he has cattle on the way from Auckland. (Feb 28, 1877,Bay of Plenty Times,2)

WILLIAMS Gave instruction for the erection of a small raupo house for any of us who might be up there. (Mar 29, 1831,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,174,1961 ed.)

WILLIAMS It was determined ... to erect some raupo houses. (Sep 3, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,329,1961 ed.)

WILLIAMS The natives had prayers this evening by themselves, and while singing the hymn, the Europeans, who were near us in a raupo house, and who rank amongst the New Zealand merchants, struck up their vocal powers, and gave us the well known ballad, Old King Cole ... (Nov 14, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,347,1961 ed.)

YATE A raupo-house, forty feet by fourteen, was erected [by the New Zealanders] in a few days; in which both [missionary] families lived during the first year. Ibid. 205 ... to engage the natives to build raupo, that is, rush-houses; .. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),176)

TAYLOR it [an earthquake] made our raupo house creak & shake (May 1843,Journal,18)

Each labouring emigrant has had one-eighth of an acre allotted to him ..., and with the assistance of the natives some raupo-houses (a typha, sort of bullrush) are springing up. (Apr 1847,Establishment of New Plymouth Settlement,65) [NOTES: 1847 Apr Establishment of New Plymouth Colony in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 65]

They have a large raupo house, very roomy and very draughty. (Mar 25, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/81) [NOTES: (H.R.Richmond)]

MATTHEWS Before leaving Kaitaia sites were chosen and staked out for three raupo houses - Mr. Baker's 30 x 18, and Matthews's and Puckey's 30 x 14. Ibid. 49-50 They therefore arranged with Pana-[50]kareao to build two small rush houses for them to live in till the raupo houses for their wives were erected. (1940,Matthews of Kaitaia,42)

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The)

raupo hut¶

n.

MILLER Surrounded by a rough, genial camaraderie of native attendants, surveyors, sawyers and a sprinkling of ex-convicts, Jerningham now lived in a large raupo building with a long table down the centre and a cask of rum at each end for each to help himself from. (1958,Early Victorian NZ,56)

They return to the filthy raupo hut, to occupy an apartment (in which dogs and fleas struggle for the mastery) with all and sundry who choose to spread their mat or blanket there - and so from year to year. (Jul 11, 1865,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

The procession now moved forwards to the rendezvous - a kind of square formed by the ranges of low raupo huts and tents. (Aug 7, 1858,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

Pieces of raupo hut, some in a state of good preservation, were found, while close by were the remains of a fence or palisade, of long pointed stakes of manuka, bound together with vines. (Oct 30, 1915,Evening Post,9)

The Turuturu-mokai redoubt was but a tiny work, so small that the officer in charge, Captain Ross, had to live in a raupo hut built outside the walls. (Oct 22, 1906,Star, The,4)

When we first came to New Zealand the Maoris would retire to their raupo huts as soon as it got dark, being frightened of the 'taipo' or devil. (May 29, 1935,NZ Free Lance,18)

MRS WILLIAMS Within an enclosure of paling stood our raupo hut, which had, except in shape, the appearance of a beehive. [15] On Sunday, Mr. Williams opened another raupo hut for a chapel. (Sep 15, 1823,Journal) [NOTES: 1823 Sep 15 Mrs Williams Journal in 1940 Tales of Pioneer Women (1988) 14, 15]

SARAH MATHEW It contains a number of Rapoo houses or huts, and one of the neatest looking is a church where native missionaries perform the services. (Apr 12, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Apr 12 Sarah Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 109]

LUSH ... an empty Raupo cottage which a Captain had lately vacated, and this he had immediately fitted up with bedding ... Cooper escorted me to my Raupo hut - where I had a glorious night's rest - (Mar 14, 1866,Waikato Journals,72,1982 ed.)

The excess of my care of both bottles caused me to place them on a shelf in the raupo hut ..., and one day some `old hands' (surveyors' men) were having dinner in the hut ... (1870,TrNZI,2/173)

COAD Lord of his own lands, king of his own castle; at least, owner of his own raupo hut. (1931,Such Is Life,29)

HYDE And the last of the raupo huts/ Let down its light behind./ (1937,Selected Poems,48,1984 ed.)

Their first act of protest was to burn the raupo huts in which the surveyors were camped, but to their honour, it must be recorded that before doing so they removed to the boats lying upon the beach, all the food and the instruments belonging to the surveyors, for they admitted that what was not produced from the land did not come under their jurisdiction. (Sep 24, 1896,Star, The,4)

The bell tents, raupo huts, cook and storehouses were dotted about on the tops and sides of the hillocks, and from one point of view alone I counted 40; there were two rows of 8 bell tents each on the top of a hillock which had been an old Maori pa and which was shaded by luxuriant karaka trees. (Jan 20, 1881,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

Clinging tenaciously to his raupo hut, old Patrick Carr saw no reason why he should vacate it at the behest of the authorities. (Jul 25, 1929,NZ Truth,9)

Moreover, the Church enshrines a Wesleyan tradition in Wellington that began in 1840 in a raupo hit on the Hutt River. (Dec 11, 2002,Capital Times,2)

In October 1843, when a GBP20 tax on raupo huts was introduced, the [Mechanics'] institute was closed, and the books went into storage for several years. (Apr 21, 1993,Independent Herald (Wellington),14)

raupo outhouse¶

n.

FOR SALE. - A GREAT BARGAIN. SUBURBAN FARMS 122-26 acres, 123-20 acres, two miles south-west of Mount Eden. On one a weather-board and thatch dwelling with some Roupo outhouses. (Jun 17, 1843,Daily Southern Cross,1)

raupo pollen¶

n.

Next time I dine at Paua Bar I'd like a grilled pigeon breast, please, over kumara mash with game jus, miro berries and a dusting of raupo pollen. (Aug 10, 2000,Evening Post,21)

raupo swamp¶

n.

The remainder of the flat is equally divided between a raupo swamp and grassy plains. (Mar 19, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

Heteraka got wounded, and ran down the slope, falling in the raupo swamp pierced with three balls. (Mar 22, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,3)

None of these channels has been made for drainage purposes, with the exception perhaps of one about four miles in length, which might have served to drain a large raupo swamp between Blenheim and the Riverlands racecourse ... (Jun 14, 1910,Evening Post,8)

DONALDSON 'Entangled in a foul morass, A raupo swamp, one name we know.' (1860,Bush Lays and Rhymes,5)

The fire afterwards crossed a big ditch into the raupo swamp at the Maori pa, where a large area was swept, but the damage was unimportant. (Nov 6, 1907,Hawera & Normanby Star,7)

During this period the natural drainage system, dominated by large areas of Raupo swamp in pre-European time, was integrated into a rectangular network of open and covered drains. (Nov 1976,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,28)

The new road has been nearly completed, with the exception of the part over the Raupo swamp (Apr 5, 1857,Lyttelton Times,5)

... passing through an almost continuous raupo swamp ... we at last arrived at Awanui Township itself. (1897,TrNZI,29/342)

MANDER Allen liked even the raupo swamps smellful of patches of stagnant water, ... (1925,Allen Adair,53,1971 ed.)

Besides themselves there were none to dispute possession save only the sprightly pukaki of the raupo swamp. (Sep 4, 1890,Otago Witness,36)

A Maori boatman.. waits to ferry the party through a raupo swamp. (Jun 8, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,7)

raupo whare¶

n.

At this time one of Te Kooti's men jumped on the top of a raupo whare, and shouted out, "Are you Whanganuis?" (Jun 6, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,5)

So long as they are enabled to shift their cultivations, they will remain content with the raupo whare, put up at little cost or trouble, for the purpose of satisfying a temporary exigency. (Mar 25, 1859,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Huddled up together in the raupo whares belonging to Barrett, the old whaler, or in tents erected by the men - "rough," as Mr Cutfield remarks in his letter to the directors of the Company, "but better than being out of doors," was the way the "pilgrim fathers," with their families, passed the first night in this new and strange land. (Jul 2, 1891,Taranaki Herald,1)

CAMPBELL ... great number of `rapeoo forras' (1840,Present State of NZ,17)

CAMPBELL So we propounded this plan to Pama - that we should get the natives to build us a small raupo whare , which they could run up easily in a week, Ibid. Bk4/8/308 The Deputy-Governor's visit had, no doubt, left us with a small skeleton in the corner of our raupo whare , but we stowed it away out of sight, and it got lost for the time being, ... (1881,Poenamo,Bk3/3/147)

Raupo whares were put up for themselves, and another set apart for their goods ... (1883,TrNZI,15/428)

MANSFIELD - raupo whare in distance- Picture -At the City [sc. Murupara village] gates we pull up and walk into the `city'. There is a store - an Accomodation [sic] House - and a G.P.O. (1907,Urewera Notebook,49,1978 ed.)

SUTHERLAND Writing ... in 1837 ... of his stay with a Christian Maori in a two-roomed raupo whare , a medical man named Shaw, stated ... (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,38)

Then you build a tin hut or a wattle and daub humpy or a raupo whare, and call it an hotel. (Aug 2, 1913,NZ Observer,17)

SINCLAIR & HARREX First there was, especially in the north, the raupo whare, shortly to be followed by a simple cottage, made of pit-sawn timber. (1978,Looking Back,138)

NICHOLL ... the worst was that we could not see the Maoris as they were in the pits covered over with rapoo whares through the roofs of which they put their rifles ... (Apr 29, 1864,Journal,209)

raupo-fringed¶

adj.

These Raupo-fringed lagoons are the favourite haunt of ducks. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/26) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

raupo-taranga¶

n.

MOORE & IRWIN XERONEMA CALLISTEMON, island lily, raupo-taranga. A spectacular plant known only on islands of the Poor Knights and Hen and Chickens groups of the eastern coast of north Auckland. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,180)

raupoing¶

n.

WILKES The manner of making the roof is to tie the materials on the horizontal strips or poles ...; the rappooing is then cut square off at the upper horizontal beam or plate-piece ... (1852,U.S. Exploring Expedition,1/300) [NOTES: 1840 Mar in 1852 Wilkes U.S. Exploring Expedition 1/300]

raurau¶

n. [ca1935 Havelock often confused with rauriki.]

The next morning they appeared more favorable, and brought sticks of raurau to the whare, singing. (Oct 10, 1883,Wanganui Herald,3)

There are Maori carved pipes, Maori tobacco (rourou), pawa shells, eel baskets, haka balls, Maori gods, and Maori devils (fern beaters); in fact, the collection is too large for us to enumerate everything we saw. (Sep 19, 1892,Taranaki Herald,2)

LEE & KENDALL Rarau, s. A plant so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,201)

HAY [also used of bad tobacco] The Raurau ( Pteris aquilina , var. esculenta ) is a fern of the nature of English bracken. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/203)

OWEN He considered [tobacco] a luxury for a man who was often reduced to rou-rou on a back country block. .... `I'm not sure a pipeful of niggerhead ain't as good' [FN] Locally grown tobacco of vile flavour. (1909,Lovelock,82)

rauraua¶

n.

HOOKER Rau-raua, Edgerley. Panax Edgerleyi. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

raurekau¶

n. Coprosma australis (formerly C.grandifolia ), =BULLOCK'S KAI Maori

At noon we stopped at a small settlement called Kiatoka, where we made a meal of some tuies toasted in the leaf of a tree called herarekau, these leaves will not burn, and they are wrapped round the bird so that none of the fat can escape, the bird cooked in this manner is really very delicious. (Jun 29, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

We had some eels for breakfast, cooked in a way which was new to most of us, called kohe or kope, and which is done in the following manner:- fern stalks are run down the whole length of the fish (which is not skinned or in any way prepared for cooking) from the mouth to the tail - then two eels thus skewered are wrapped in leaves of the raurekau tree, and tied together with flax, when they are roasted before the fire with one end resting on the ground and the other leaning against a stick supported in a horizontal position in front of the fire for the purpose. (Sep 4, 1850,New Zealander, The,3)

.. I will not wrap up my speech in raurekau leaves, but say that this man Rusden is telling lies! (Mar 12, 1884,Wanganui Herald,2)

I visited Day's Bay for the first time last week; and, within half a mile of the sea, and below 150 feet above sealevel, I saw, without leaving the footpath, the following trees, shrubs, etc. : - Koromiko (several species), kohekohe, mahoe,.papauma (not Griselinea), kotukutuku, manuka (Leptospermum scoparium), karamu, taupata, raurekau ... (Aug 29, 1912,Evening Post,8)

KELLY [The eels] are then covered with the broad leaves of the raurikau (or bullock's kai as it was known by the early settlers). (1892,Journey Through Waitara,3)

TREGEAR The officiating priest stuck a twig of the shrub ( raurekau ) in the middle of the stream ... (1904,Maori Race, The,45)

BAUCKE It was an appetising display ... a mound of potatoes, haangi steamed, ... alternated with stacks of eels enclosed in wrappings of `raurekau' leaves (coprosma grandifolia), baked on a framework of rickers over a clear fire, ... delicate of flavour. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,253)

MASON An old rock garden, writhing with weeds. A jungle of raureka and gorse, ... (1970,End of the Golden Weather, The,27) [NOTES: 1970 Mason `Golden Weather' in 1981 Solo 27]

LAING & BLACKWELL Coprosma [australis (The Southern Coprosma)] ... leaves ... broad ... Maori name Raurekau. [1907, C. grandifolia] (1907,Plants of NZ,394,194-, p. 421 ed.)

(1949,Landfall,3/1: 31)

WODZICKI Miss Mason identified the leaves of the following plants [Egmont National Park]: ...both leaves and fruit or seed of haumakaroa ( Nothopanax simplex ), ...raurekau ( Coprosma grandifolia ), ...and broadleaf ( Griselinia littoralis )... (1950,Introduced Mammals of NZ,164)

RAUREKAU/ Coprosma australis / (1982,Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs,26)

C[oprosma] australis raurekau (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

n. rangiora, Brachyglottis repanda [ORIGIN: Maori]

WILLIAMS Raurakau, Raurekau 1. Brachyglottis repanda, a shrub ... Rangiora. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,330)

raurenga¶

n.

Hybrids between northern rata and pohutukawa.. dominate Rangitoto's forest and provide pockets of shelter for moisture-loving plants such as kidney fern (raurenga) which survive just metres away from open lava that heats to 70 degrees C in summer. (Jul 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 68/28)

WILSON Cardiomanes reniforme KIDNEY FERN ... Raurenga ... Fronds unmistakable, roundly kidney-shaped ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,456)

rauriki¶

n. Sonchus oleraceus the prickly sow thistle [Maori] MAORI CABBAGE (cp PUHA) [ca1935 Havelock.]

The little boys often carried to their father for his mid-day lunch ... a basin of boiled rauriki (sow-thistle), which was used as a vegetable. Ibid. 207 For vegetables there was plenty of pora, the Maori turnip, and puwha (rauriki) or sowthistle. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,78) [NOTES: Written of 1940]

LEAFLETS FOR GARDENERS AND FRUITGROWERS. No.2.- MOTH-CATCHING PLANT, CRUEL PLANT, CODLIN MOTH PLANT (aranja albens). BY T.W KIRK, F.L.S., &c., Lond. .. I have reared specimens from groundsel, meliolotus, and the recently introduced Neogeora burr, while the common sow thistle or rauriki is everywhere attacked, and seems to be the favourite food plant. (Apr 4, 1895,Otago Witness,4)

Snails, meaning the shellback tribe, do not harbour under weeds so much as slugs, but they shelter among such things as cabbages, and large weeds like rauriki; but look for them more beneath hedges. (Jun 14, 1913,Evening Post,12)

The native wild cabbage and `rauriki' (sow thistle) were used as vegetables until gardens had been made. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,21)

CHEESEMAN S[onchus] oleraceus , Linn. ... Sow-thistle; Pororua; Rauriki. ... Perhaps not truly native. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,338)

HILGENDORF SOUR THISTLE [SOWTHISTLE] ( Sonchus oleraceus /) is frequently called milk thistle, from its milky juice, and in the north is quite commonly given its Maori name of Rauriki. It is exceedingly common and well known in all gardens and cultivated fields. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,209,1967 ed.)

(1944,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn))

BEAGLEHOLE By vegetables, the Maori ... tends to think of wild turnip-tops, wild water-cress, or puha (known to pakehas as the sow-thistle weed or rauriki) boiled up with meat and potatoes ... (1946,Some Modern Maoris,97)

DE MAUNAY By vegetables, the Maori ... tends to think of wild turnip-tops, wild water-cress, or puha (known to pakehas as the sow-thistle weed or rauriki) boiled up with meat and potatoes ... (1949,Huntsman in His Career, The,122)

LYON The younger pigs did little harm, except to graze on the raoriki, which the Maori boils and as `puha' uses as cabbage ... . (1952,Faring South,198)

WALL Sowthistle . Here I note a case of what is called folk etymology'. I hear this native plant (and introduced weed) assour thistle'. The speaker mistrakenly supposes the plant to be named from its taste. It is actually edible and much used by the Maoris as rauriki, corruptly `radicky'. (1958,Queen's English, The,48)

rauriki n -s [Maori, fr. rau leaf + riki small] NewZeal (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1886)

... the sow thistle, better known as rauriki' in the Wellington district, which, marketed [in East Coast and Rotorua districts] aspuha' finds a ready sale. (Nov 22, 1962,Evening Post,72)

If he were sure he could recognise it, writes Mr T. P. Moloney, he would gather rauriki and get his wife to cook it, for he enjoyed it years ago in Maori cooking, in the King Country, where it was called by the pakeha Maori cabbage.' <i> Rauriki </i> is the common succulent thistle, growing 2ft to 3ft high, that the children gathering it for pet rabbits and guinea pigs, call milk thistle, because of the abundant flow of milky white sap from it. Actually there are two species' Sonchus oleraceus, whose lobed leaves are only mildly prickly and flat, or at the most very slightly waved at the edges, and S. asper, very similar except that the leaves are much more prickly, and are waved or crimped around the edges. The flowers are yellow, rather like those of a dandelion, about three-quarters of an inch in diameter. <i> Chewing Gum </i> According to some people, rauriki is the Maori name of the former and puwha of the latter, but I do not know that the Maoris went in for such nice distinctions. Different tribes had different names for the same thing. Puwha, as well as being one of the names for the sow thistle, seems to have been also used sometimes as a general term for any cooked greens, of which sow thistle was the favourite. <i>(Jan 7, 1963,Otago Star</i>) [NOTES: (I.W.T. Munro onMaori Cabbage')]

At Oxford, Makereti (Maggie Papakura) wrote: `I myself gather the sow thistle here and cook it to eat, as it reminds me of our own puwha, of which I am very fond. Puwha was used only as a vegetable ... The succulent stems contained a bitter milky juice which came to the surface when the flower tops were plucked off. This was left, on a sunny day, for a few hours, then gathered between the thumb and first finger, adding the thick creamy mass of several plants together. This was used as a sort of chewing gum, called pia or ngau, which tasted very bitter at first. But after a little chewing, the bitterness disappeared, and this gum was much enjoyed, especially by the women, who vied with each other in seeing who could make her pia crack the loudest.' (Jan 7, 1963,Otago Star)

rauriki [=] sow thistle [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,63)

rauriki [=] sow thistle [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,63)

rauriki n. NZ = PUHA. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,628) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 404]]

A decoction made from the rauriki (Sonchus), and the expressed juice of the `pig's ear' ( Mesembryanthemum sp.) were used locally ... (1905,TrNZI,37/67)

2 n. the edible centre of a NIKAU

LYON Beyond potatoes, vegetables were entirely absent [on the early West Coast goldfields], if we except a little rauriki or the inner part of the nikau palm which, divested of its many envelopes and boiled, made a feeble substitute for cabbage. [Is the or disjunctive or correlative] (1952,Faring South,195)

3 n. occas heard for unpalatable greens; unpalatable tobacco (? mistake or confusion for raurau

Raurimu spiral¶

n.

Tiny raurimu (population 600) is known for two things: it's home to the Raurimu spiral, the 360 degree loop in the main trunk railway line that allows trains to descend and ascend a steep gradient ... (May 23, 2006,Dominion Post,A13)

The locomotive steamed to its new home with another older loco, but when the two reached the foot of the legendary Raurimu Spiral, the boiler of the older locomotive failed. (Sep 28, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

The Raurimu Spiral was one of the most wonderful engineering feats in the world. (Aug 18, 1926,NZ Observer,6)

It has been said that the Raurimu Spiral would never have been constructed if aeroplanes had existed when the reconnaissance surveys were made. (Sep 1936,NZ Railways Magazine,35)

Had they not heard that we have the unique Raurimu Spiral, the amazing span of the Mohaka viaduct and the death-defying precipice of Staircase Gully? (Feb 13, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

rauroroa¶

n. [Botany]

CHEESEMAN 388 [Sonchus asper, Hill,] Sow-thistle; Rauroroa; Tawheke; Puwha. ... As this was collected by Banks and Solander it must be regarded as indigenous. (1906,Manual NZ Flora)

rautahi¶

n. Carex ternaria:

HOOKER Rautahi, Col[enso]. Carex ternaria. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

... the outer thatch [was] Toetoe, ( Cyperus ustulatus), or Rautahi ( Carex ternaria,) or Ririwaka ( Scirpus maritimus), or of two kinds of Wiwi, or Rushes ( Juncus maritimus, and effusus); ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/34) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Rautahi. Carex ternaria, Forst. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/51) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

2/127 Carex ternaria Rautahi (1870,TrNZI)

rautahi [s] Carex coriacea Hamlin Carex geminata Schk. Carex lessoniana Steud. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,63)

rautawhiri¶

n.

MASTERS `From this point back to Moawhango the track, for some mile, leads through a lovely piece of bush where again native mistletoe rautawhiri and other lovely shrubs were in bloom.' (1959,Tales of the Mails) [NOTES: c1880s an anonymous tourist in 1959 L. Masters Tales of the Mails 49]

Amongst smaller trees and shrubs the most prominent are the horoeka( Panax crassifolia), and its congeners Panax simplex and P. edgerleyi, both exhibiting such excessive luxuriance as frequently to require an examination of the fruit before their identification can be determined; the rautawhiri ( Pittosporum tenuifolium, var. colensoi), the kotukutuku ( Fuchsia excorticata), the mako ( Aristotelia racemosa), the mapau ( Myrsine australis), the pokako ( Eloeocarpus hookerianus), also Carpodetus serratus, Myrsine divaricata, both of which are abundant. The remarkable `weeping tree', Myrsine montana, with its crowded recurved branches and small foliage, affords a picturesque effect (1884,TrNZI,17/216) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

rautini¶

n. (Environment) an endangered indigenous shrub Brachyglottis huntii [ORIGIN: Maori, P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 215. *(Chatham Islands) also known as Chatham Island Christmas tree]

A noticeable feature of the bush just now is the rautini (senecio Huntii), tree groundsel, indigenous to the island. (Jan 24, 1902,Star, The,4)

These plants are classified as nationally critical, meaning they are at very serious risk of becoming extinct .. Rautini ( Brachyglottis-huntii ): A rare tree daisy, sometimes known as Chatham Island Christmas tree. (Mar 28, 2009,Dominion Post,A11)

COCKAYNE In the neighbourhood of these [Chatham Island] bogs the margin of the forest often consists entirely of the rautini (Senecio Huntii), a mag-[123]nificent tree-groundsel, which produces immense bunches of yellow flower-heads. (1910,NZ Plants,122)

SHAND Inihina - Hinahina or Mahoe, in Maori - was considered the best wood for the rubber [in firemaking]; but Karamu, Karaka, Ake, Rautini, and Kokopere (Maori, Kawakawa) were used as the Kahunaki, or grooved piece of wood. (1911,Moriori People of the Chatham Islands, The,8)

Senecio Huntii F. Muell .. Rautini. (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/144)

RICHARDS Senecio spg Senecio .. Huntii .. This tree-groundsel has a stout erect trunk .. RAUTINI. (1952,Chatham Islands,68)

HOLMES Senecio Huntii (Rautini) - this endemic tree grows in the natural forest [at the south of Chatham and Pitt Islands] .. Flower-heads are clusters of yellow on almost every branchlet. (1984,Chatham Islands,93)

Unfortunately some rautini (Brachyglottis huntii) in the south-east were dead or showing severe dieback ... (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 7)

Status : Nationally Endangered Species : Brachyglottis huntii Authority : Brachyglottis huntii (F.Muell.) B.Nord. Qualifier : CD, RC, HI, IE Family : Asteraceae Common Name : Rautini, Chatham Island Christmas tree Synonyms : Senecio huntii F.Muell. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nzpcn.org.nz/nz_threatenedplants/detail.asp?PlantID=55]

rauwiri¶

n.

FEATON In other parts the Kahikitoa', [sic] orRiwiri', [sic] foliage is very striking. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,157)

rave¶

n. enthusiastic conversation or monologue

BEATON HELEN:... It was two people...talking. We had some good raves, too. Solving all the world's problems. (1984,Outside In,102)

rave on¶

v. talk non-stop [1981 Auckland Savings Bank, Queen Street (Goldie Brown Collection) Rave on: talk non-stop]

raw discharge¶

phr. the head count as people leave or are discharged from hospital

Likewise, "raw discharge" was no cause for environmental alarm, it was just the name given to the head count as people left, or were discharged, from hospital. (Feb 21, 2002,Dominion,3)

rawai¶

n.

HECTOR It may be useful to give a list of the different fishes the Maoris distinguish in the Taupo district, ... Rawai. - A large kind of Kokopu [lake only]. (1872,Edible Fishes,129)

rawara¶

n. (See rawaru)

rawarawa¶

n. (See rewarewa)

rawaru¶

n. [ORIGIN: Maori] (See cod,blue cod)

cod fish - rao'oroo [rawaru] (1835,Boultbee Journal,113,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 113. Also >1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 286 (|= macron precedes) cod-fish, ra|ooroo [rawara]]

SHERRIN KOKOPU ( Galaxias fasciatus). ... Kokopu,' Dr. Hector says,is the general Maori name for several very common fishes in the New Zealand streams and lakes, belonging to the family of Galaxidae. ... The kokopu of the stream is caught by them with bobs; but is not much cared for. Not more, as a rule, than one or two fish will be found in a pool; half a dozen at the most. It is also called rawaru and para. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,138)

HAM,ILTON ... with the following results: 581 eels (from 1ft. to 4ft. in length); 8 dozen flounders, of various sizes, large numbers of aua, or kataka (mullet); about 70lb. or 70lb. weight of pilchard, or mohimohi; a few snapper and kahawai; hundreds of red cod and rarii; and a number of kokopu or rawaru. (1908,Fishing and Sea-Foods,64)

PARAPERCIS COLIAS (Forster). Blue Cod; Rawaru. A highly esteemed food fish; secured in water up to 100 fathoms. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,IV/123) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

Parapercis colias (Forster). Blue cod. Rawaru. (1938,TrNZI,68/413) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

BEATTIE The above list of fish to be caught along the Canterbury coast has some notable omissions, as hoka (red cod) ... though I am not so sure about the rawaru (blue cod). Others omitted are the tarakihi, or terakihi, the moki, the komutumutu (trevalli), the puhaiwhakarua (red-jacket), koiro (conger eel), tuere (blind eel), whai (skate), and the koekohe [sic] (trumpeter). (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,62)

... large numbers of aua or kataha ( Agonostoma forsteri); about 60 lb. ... weight of pilchard or mohimohi ( Clupea sagax), two varieties; ... hundreds of young red-cod, rarii ( Lotella bacchus), and what I believe are young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru ( Percis colias). The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length, and the rawaru, or, as the natives here call them, toitoi' orpanepane', from 2 in. to 6 in. long. (1903,TrNZI,35/319) [NOTES: Mair Fish in Piako River]

PARROTT THE BLUE COD Parapercichthys colias (Bloch & Schneider) ... Maori name: RAWARU Ibid. 141 This [Blue Cod], is the fish known to Captain Cook as the Coal-fish', and it has frequently been referred to by older authors as theRock Cod' It was known to the Maoris as Rawaru' orPakirikiri' (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,140)

DOOGUE & MORELAND BLUE COD ... Other names: Parapercis colias; coal fish; rawaru, pakirikiri, patutuki (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,264)

Blue cod an edible fish; rawaru (1979,Heinemann NZ Dictionary,113)

WILSON COD, BLUE (Rawaru) Parapercis colias: .. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,37)

AYLING BLUE COD (Blue weever, rawaru) Parapercis colias (1982,Collins Guide,267,1984 ed.)

POWELL BLUE COD ( Parapercis colias) Rawaru of the Maoris, is our most esteemed food fish. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,69)

STARK cod-fish - raooroo [rawaru] (1986,Journal,113) [NOTES: quote from 1827-28 BOULTBEE; grave accent on "o" of "rao"]

rawena¶

n.

I tasted it again.. when chef Charles Royal presented it with a kawakawa pesto on flaxseed rawena bread and paired it with Tohu Gisborne Reserve Chardonnay 2002. (Jun 24, 2004,Wellingtonian,26)

rawhine¶

n. potato

She explained that she acquired five of the notes as a result of digging rawhines (potatoes). (Mar 18, 1919,Pukekohe & Waiuku Times,2)

rawiri¶

n. kanuka

DIEFFENBACH Rawiri - a shrub ( leptospermum ericoides) (1843,Travels in NZ,2/382)

HOOKER =KANUKA Leptospermum ericoides, A.Rich. ... Nat. name, Rawiri', Northern Island, <i> Cunn</i>;Manouea', Middle Island, D'Urville. A scarcely less common plant than [L. scoparium], attaining a greater size (20 feet) ... (1853,Flora NZ,II Flora Novae-Zelandiae I Flowering Plants 70)

HOOKER Rawiri, Northern Island, Cunn. Leptospermum ericioides. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

... the rawiri ( Leptospermum ericoides) or tea-tree, with spray-like branches laden with myriads of white flowers ... (1872,TrNZI,4/249) [NOTES: Kirk Brit. and NZ Floras]

KIRK MANUKA - RAWIRI - TEATREE.- ( Leptospermum ericoides.) (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,14)

HAY The Manuka or Manukau ( Leptospernum scoparium et ericoides) is the `ti-tree' of the settlers. In one condition it is low shrubbery, not unlike heather, called then Rawiri by the Maori. ... There are red and white varieties. The Maori particularize it as Kahikatoa, when in tree condition. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/195)

FEATON Rawiri [Maori name] .. Tea tree [Settlers' name] ..Leptospermum ericoides .. Tree (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,178)

n. prayer book

It is a Maori rawiri (prayer book) still embedded with the Turkish bullet which had been heading for Hone's heart. The book was in his breast pocket. (Jul 19, 1986,Dominion,1)

Rawleigh's salesman¶

n.

VIRTUE Tom Lamb had been a Rawleigh's salesman before the Depression. (1991,Always the Islands of Memory,96)

[Woollaston] took a job as a Rawleigh's salesman, which he maintained until the mid-60s, when McLeavey offered to be his dealer. (Sep 26, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),39)

Rawleigh('s) man¶

n.

BACON We sat talking, then before she left, the Rawleigh Man called and he stayed until lunch time. He only calls once in six months, and when he does come, it's a major social event. Ibid. 183 RAWLEIGH MAN-A travelling representative of a firm specialising in household requirements ranging from prepared foods to laundry soaps. In country districts, and in towns too, the Rawleigh Man is an institution, not only because of the service he renders, but because he is invariably a cheerful fellow, a good companion to chat with over a cup of tea. (1963,In the Sticks,83)

O'SULLIVAN Well - not as though I'm a Rawleighs' man or something. I mean I don't have to sell anything. JACKO: Christ! Rawleighs' man! Ever known any? (1985,Shuriken,22)

ray¶

n. various fish species (see also STING-RAY, STINGAREE)

[species name] rays .. [scientific name] -- [other name(s)] unspecified. See also EAGLE RAY, ELECTRIC RAY, STINGRAY (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n.

WILSON BLIND TORPEDO RAY: see Rays (Numbfish). Ibid.198 BLIND TORPEDO RAY A rare ray, Typhlonarke aysoni, as he is called in Latin, has the ability to emit sparks and make a needle magnetic - yet not to see. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,28)

GRAHAM BLIND TORPEDO RAY OR NUMBFISH Typhlonarke aysoni (Hamilton) [ibid. 92]. This uncommon fish has several names, all of which relate to its manner of producing electric shocks, some of which are Numb-fish, Crampfish and Electric Skate. These vernacular names are given by fishermen on account of the fish benumbing or paralysing the person who unwittingly grasps one with his hands. The last name is from the somewhat similar shape to that of a skate or ray, ray being another common term for skates and also the scientific family name. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,90,2nd ed.)

GRAHAM Blind Torpedo-Ray Typhlonarke aysoni (Hutton) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,398) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 398]

2 n.

HECTOR The New Zealand Electric Ray (Torpedo Fairchildii) ... is an interesting addition to our fauna ... (1872,Edible Fishes,121)

2 n.

2 n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] ray, shovelnose 299 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

AYLING SHORT-TAILED STINGRAY Dasyatis brevicaudatus (1982,Collins Guide,79,1984 ed.)

2 n. [?=eagle ray see stingaree for main discussion of variants] (See stingray)

[see quot elephant fish] (Mar 1880,Banks Journal,2/57)

We got only fish, ... and these of various sorts, such as Shirks [check], Sting-rays, Breams, Mullet, Mackarel ... (Dec 5, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/219,1955 ed.)

NICHOLAS On these stages were placed a quantity of the dog-fish and sting-ray, which were drying there as a supply against the winter; ... (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/269)

POLACK Many other fish are equally numerous, answering to our hakes, tench, bream, snapper, haddock, elephant-fish, pollock, salmon, gurnards, pipe-fish, parrot-fish, leather-jackets, cole-fish, John Dorys, sword-fish, cod; various kinds of skate and cat-fish, sting-ray and dog-fish. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/322)

WILLIAMS oru ... 3 sting-ray. (1892,Dictionary of the NZ Language,117)

Sting-rays (whai) sometimes get into the net. (1926,TrNZI,58/615) [NOTES: (Buck)]

PHILLIPPS Dasyatis brevicaudatus (Hutton). SMOOTH STINGAREE or STING-RAY. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,11,1971 ed.)

SPEIGHT ...the order is represented in Canterbury by a Skate, a Stingray and an Electric Ray (1929,Natural History of Canterbury,193) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 193]

BEST The whai, or sting-ray, was taken by means of a hardwood spear,.. (1929,Fishing Methods,43)

Dasyatus brevicaudatus: Sting-ray, stingaree. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,71)

GRAHAM Stingray Bathytoshia brevicaudata (Hutton) (Syn. Raia rostrata Taylor, preocc.) ..Stingray Bathytoshia thetidis (Waite) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,398) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 398]

GRAHAM STING RAY or STINGAREE (WHAI REPO) Bathytoshia brevicaudata (Hutton) ... The name Stingaree is a corruption of Sting Ray - a lackadaisical habit we have with some of the vernacular names of the fauna and flora of New Zealand. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,100)

MORELAND EAGLERAY [Myliobatis tenuicaudatus] ... Whiptail, stingray and cowfish are among other names in use. (1967,Marine Fishes,14)

SORENSON SKATE (a) Scientific name: Raja nasuta. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Skate. (c) Other common names: Smooth Skate (R. nasuta); Rough Skate (Raja australis); Stingray; Stingaree; Flaps (trade name for Skate `wings'). (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Wellington, Nelson, Picton, Banks Peninsula, Timaru, Greymouth. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,43)

[species name] smooth skate .. [scientific name] Raja innominata .. [other name(s)] Sometimes called (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

[species name] smooth skate .. [scientific name] Raja innominata .. [other name(s)] Sometimes called (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n.

HUTTON TORPEDO FAIRCHILDI. sp. nov. Torpedo. (1872,Fishes,83, 134)

MORRIS Torpedo, n. a fish, well known elsewhere, and also called elsewhere, the Numb-fish and Cramp-fish. For the Australian species, see quotation. (1898,Austral English,475)

SPEIGHT The Torpedo Ray (Typhlonarke aysoni) or blind numb-fish is a small brown, soft-bodied fish which lurks on the bottom in moderately shallow water. (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,193) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 193]

Typhlonarke aysoni(Hamilton). TORPEDO-RAY. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,10,1971 ed.)

PAUL In a separate family (Torpedinidae) [from skates] there is the torpedo or electric ray Torpedo fairchildi, similar to an Australian species and to others elsewhere. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,35)

Eagle rays are the most numerous, with groups of five to ten animals working a patch of broken ground together. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/20)

ray grass¶

n. (See grass,ray grass)

razoo¶

n. a small or worthless (imaginary) coin; a jot (usu. in neg. constructions) [>ca1920-1930 at least W.H.B. Orsman (brass razoo)] (See also brass razoo)

In reply to Mr. Curtis's further questioning, Maxwell admitted that he had not a razoo to pay the costs of the action against "Truth" if it went against him. (May 20, 1926,NZ Truth,13)

BAKER razoo ... is in currency for a small coin. The term also has wide use .us;in Australia and ... is heard mainly in the negative phrases I haven't a razoo or I haven't a brass razoo for `I have no money at all' (1941,NZ Slang,52)

SOLJAK New Zealand colloquialisms which are of Maori origin include; ... razoo: small coin; from the Maori raho (a trifle). E.g. I haven't a brass razoo (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),117)

SARGESON I hadn't a razoo left. (1946,That Summer,78)

MUNDY I haven't got a rarzoo. (1948,There's Gold in Them Hills,93)

PARK No work, no custom. Nobody's got a razoo left anywhere, especially to buy fish with. (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,177)

SUTHERLAND When I was up before him that time last year he never found [sc. fined] me any fiver - never found me a dam' razzoo. (1956,Green Kiwi,197,1960 ed.)

ASHTON-WARNER And I've got nothing in my pocket ... I haven't got two razoos to rub together. (1964,Bell Call,142)

SARGESON razoo: hadn't a razoo left, was penniless. (1964,Collected Stories,302) [NOTES: Pearson Glossary]

TURNER (1966,Austral English,133)

razoo n. (Sl.) farthing, smallest coin; not a razoo, destitute. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

DUGGAN But the car, she questioned, surely he had some capital in that `Not a razoo, old thing. Borrowed.' (1970,O'Leary's Orchard,100)

This year, after two New Zealand tournaments he had not won a razoo. (Dec 3, 1972,Sunday Times (NZ),9/1)

razoo n. Austral. & N.Z. inf. an imaginary coin: not a brass razoo; they took every last razoo. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,950) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 629; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 404]]

n.(slang). smallest possible coin, especially in phrase not a brass razoo. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

SARGESON And she didn't give a razoo whether they knew already or they didn't. (1976,Sunset Village,53)

HUNT It benefits the petrol people, the shops and the butcher ... But the rank and file ... I don't think it affects us one razoo. (1981,Speaking a Silence,127)

Many of his expostulations dated from time spent in the Middle East during World War II: "brass razoo... shickered... buckshee... shufti... doolally" and "going butcher's hook". (Jan 1992,North & South,88)

The America's Cup was ours. We did it. Little ol' us, with a couple of bent razoos and some No 8 fencing wire, became only the second country to sail away with what is grandly known as sport's oldest prize. (Feb 20, 2000,Sunday Star Times,C6)

We've never had any grants. Not a razoo. (Jun 1992,Metro,73)

razor gang¶

n.

Cabinet razor gang Chairman Doug Kidd, on his frustration in the state-owned enterprise and finance portfolios: We are constantly paying out on dead horses and disposing of the skeletons as they fall out of the cupboard. (Apr 14, 1991,Dominion Sunday Times,8)

A razor gang of Prime Minister Jenny Shipley, Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer Winston Peters and Finance Minister Bill Birch have already met several times to discuss where cuts will be made. (Jul 6, 1998,Dominion,2)

Only the Razor Gang - the ministers who "gate-keep" (meaning cut) departmental spending - are saying anything much, and they have clearly all been at Ruth Richardson's old steroid supply. (Apr 5, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

Prime Minister Jenny Shipley said Sir William - also known as King of the Razor Gang or Mr Think Big - would be hard to replace as he had made an outstanding contribution. (Oct 8, 1999,Evening Post,1)

[Hdg] Axing of razor gang cheers farmer groups. Agriculture Minister Jim Sutton's plans to axe a producer board hatchet team have been welcomed by farmer groups across the spectrum. (Jan 18, 2000,Evening Post,17)

By Scrooge-like behaviour toward the writers they might prepare the public, psychologically, for the wounding pre-Christmas cuts the "razor gang" would inflict. (Jan 7, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

Mr Goff becomes a member of Dr Cullen's new "razor gang" scrutinising departmental spending. (Oct 20, 2005,NZ Herald,A6)

Greens co-leader Rod Donald said he did not know what the razor gang would do. (Oct 21, 2005,NZ Herald,A6)

The razor gang has been slashing public spending in areas such as health, welfare and super because the cupboard is supposed to be bare. Ibid. 20 In the name of cutting back on government spending, the MPs have agreed to buy their own magazines this year but have rejected appeals from the Parliamentary Service Commission and a razor gang of officials to limit their travel perks. (Oct 14, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

Bolger had already, however, determined to set up a so-called razor gang to cut spending in three departments - Inland Revenue, Labour and Social Welfare. (Nov 12, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

The ministers and their advisers feared it was a "razor-gang" exercise. (Aug 24, 2001,Dominion,2)

n. (Marine)

In the next hour we moved twice but caught nothing but members of the razor gang, along the way losing about 20 flasher rigs, four jigs and a fair few sinkers and hooks. (Jul 8, 2005,NZ Herald,D19)

razor mussel¶

n.

POWELL RAZOR MUSSEL (Solemya parkinsoni). A thin-shelled bivalve about 2 inches long covered with a dark chestnut coloured shining epidermis which extends beyond the edge of the shell as a scallop fringe. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,19)

NATUSCH BIVALVES ... . 2. Razor mussel, Solemya (1967,Animals of NZ, The,78 Fig. 20)

razor-backed¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of ridges] steep and sharp spurred [common in hill country and difficult to muster.]

BATHGATE .. the spurs and ridges are razor-backed, and the intervening gullies are of a similar formation. (1874,Colonial Experiences,70)

DAVIS Along the razor-backed ridges of the high paddocks belonging to Bill Waikai a few flocks of goats pursued a carefree existence ... (1962,Mutton on the Menu,84)

ALLEN It was steep, razor-backed country, especially the Airimatia section which we called "The Peninsula." (1980,Farm on the Wanganui River, A,7)

HOLDEN He scanned higher and soon spotted a high, razor-backed ridge snaking to the tops - the razor-backed ridge overlooked Whale creek. (1996,Great Hunting Yarns,190)

razorback¶

n. (Rural) a steep-sided, sharp-backed ridge, common in NZ hill country.

After walking over about three miles of fern hills, from which, at several intervals, we obtained various fine views of the country we had left behind us, as well as some very pretty peeps at the wooded gullies which ran down from each side of the razor-back ridge on which we were travelling, we entered the forest of Hautere at 7 a. m. (Dec 18, 1850,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,4)

.. to an ordinary observer, it [the country] would look like a series of ridges of a 'razorback' character. (Aug 1888,NZ Farmer,298)

A recently returned explorer, who after many adventures up the main Trunk Line, discovered Mangaweka in a swamp picturesquely surrounded by razor-backs on which even goats would starve ... (Feb 27, 1906,Hawera Star,6)

GUTHRIE-SMITH .. the softer rock has melted into cones, domes, razorbacks, and peaks. (1921,Tutira,10)

LOUGHNAN razorback: a spur on a mountain which falls away to either side 'as steep as a hen's face.' In places it could even be impossible to walk along its very crest. An unnerving piece of geography. [razor back; razorback] (1981,Loughnan Glossary,66)

n. (Rural) a wild pig.

NEWTON A lean old razorback with the long snout of the real New Zealand 'Captain Cooker', she was followed by a cluster of tiny offspring ... (1972,Sheep Thief,71)

STACEY Wally had told me that he had no experience in pig country, so when I saw a big pig up a side gully, I thought it would be a good chance to intitiate him into the noble art of wrestling razorbacks. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,111)

wild pig: razorback. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

n. a steep-sided, sharp-backed ridge; used in NZ chiefly for a sharp-backed ridge, or for a (wild) boar, a Captain Cooker, from the general English attrib `having a sharp-edged back' (OED

For Mr Lilburn, their introduction to his steep razoorback hill-country farm in 1998 was an act of desperation borne of the need to break free of an endless spiral of dispiriting hard work and debt. (Jan 31, 2003,Dominion Post,C4)

Razorback for a narrow steep-sided ridge or hill was used here..some twenty-seven years before the earliest O.E.D. example. (Sep 1959,Tararua,13/47) [NOTES: Cf. Haast 1861 Rep. Top. Nelson 131; Park TNZI 17 : 353]

BAINES At length ... from a high `razor-back', I had a magnificent view of the Waikato. (1874,Edward Crewe,247)

Supposing the traveller to be standing on a narrow spur, or razor-back leading, to the mountain-top. (1889,TrNZI,110)

KELLY On the best, the ridges are wide, on the inferior country they approach to razor backs. (1892,Journey Through Waitara,6)

Your section is behind that, You have two razor-backs and a gully and no way in except a cow-track. (1902,NZ Illustrated Magazine,v/379)

We entered on a long narrow ridge, like the roof of a church, ... It is what the New Zealand people call a razor-back. (1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,7/91)

The troops in December, 1861, marched along the Maori track over [250] the range called the Razorback, ... (1922,NZ Wars, The,1/249)

Razor back.- Sharp ridged spur or hill. A very common local name. (C.) (Nov 18, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

SUTHERLAND By the time we reached the end of the ridge which ended by pinching in to a sharp razorback, (1953,Golden Bush, The,138,1963 ed.)

... if he were only young again, by God he'd be with us too [working on the road], but looking ruefully at the razorbacks saying but I'd need baghooks in the arse of my pants to get me up there!' and thenA man cannot live on scenery alone.' (Aug 1954,Here & Now,17) [NOTES: (R.Alley)]

razorback NZ & Austral. lean scraggy bullock or cow; steep-sided narrow ridge. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,629) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

At 4,700 ft. the `razorback' disappears, giving place to a rounded hill ... (1910,TrNZI,42/20)

I added to my gallery of mental landscapes an impression of a gloomy forest region of stupendous cliffs and birch-covered razorbacks through whose sombre masses a deep swift river darkling ran. (Mar 9, 1899,Taranaki Herald,3)

n. [attributive uses below]

... the sharp, razor-back ridges that extend between Waikouaiti River and the Snowy Mountain .. (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,1) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

CARMAN The razor-back track ... . (1925,Broad Stairway, The,174)

ANTHONY The top of the hill was a huge see-saw, razor-back ridge. ... Even on a fine day most people preferred to ...do the razor-back on foot ... (1927,Follow the Call,111,1975 ed.)

WILSON ... we carried Alf down ..., along the snow covered, razorback ridge from the ski hut ... (1976,Pacific Star,141)

2 n. a wild pig with a sharply ridged back, a CAPTAIN COOKER or a bullock in poor condition

~ n. bullock in poor condition. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

razor-back n. bullock in poor condition. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

... Mrs Whip looked on the razor-back with brimming eye. (Dec 1976,Spleen,6/19)

HOLDEN An experienced pig-hunter would have classified him as a `razorback' pig, a type which was far more common in the South Island. (1984,Razorback,25)

razorback NZ & Austral. lean scraggy bullock or cow; steep-sided narrow ridge. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

3 n.

POLACK The RAZORBACK is so termed from that part being remarkably serrated; its snout is very much pointed, like to the porpoise. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),II/407)

POLACK The RAZORBACK is so termed from that part being remarkably serrated; its snout is very much pointed, like to the Porpoise. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/407)

razz¶

v. to give the raspberry to; to barrack; jeer at; (of dogs) to annoy, provoke (cattle)

MASTERS If the wild cattle didn't respond to these tactics on the first try, or try [sic] to break a wrong way, in would go the dogs like a flash to raz them again until they were glad to respond in the way desired. (1960,Back-Country Tales,218)

The crowd. - razzed the same batsman as he stretched a pad persistently to counter the Alabaster spin. (Feb 8, 1961,Dominion,12)

Brown told the police that he sent off the blue' because the trainees had beenrazzing' his `Hell's Angels' associates who had supported him (Jul 20, 1971,NZ Truth,21)

razz up¶

v.

MASTERS Bill filled the lorry with benzine, went to the cookhouse and razzed the cook up for breakfast. (1960,Back-Country Tales,172)

razzing¶

n.

MASTERS In the meantime most of the rest of his team of dogs would be sent in to give the offending wild beasts a good razzing. Arnold would sneak in as close as possible to where the hullabaloo was going on and plant himself behind a tree or bank. Directly he thought the cattle had been given a sufficient razzing, he would give a low whistle. (1960,Back-Country Tales,218)

RBA¶

abbr. Reserve Bank Act

I can't begin to tell you how passionately some people feel about the Reserve Bank Act 1889... However, since the RBA was passed, both National and Labour politicians have sworn allegiance to it with the sort of fervour that Americans reserve for their flag... The RBA sets out how our central bank is to be run... (Jan 29, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

RBNZ¶

n. Reserve bank of New Zealand

RBNZ frets about the effects of a slowdown on high-risk markets. (May 18, 2005,Dominion Post,C1)

RCD¶

abbr. rabbit calicivirus disease

However, in some pockets, especially in Oatgo, numbers were rebounding thanks to rabbits becoming immune to the virus, which was initially called rabbit calicivirus disease or RCD. (Apr 15, 2004,Dominion Post,A4)

RD¶

abbr. rural delivery (See rural delivery)

We can still number by thousands the homes (not all of them R.D.) where meals are cooked on the wood range and where bathing the children means chopping the kindling, lighting the copper ... and bailing it out again. (Oct 1949,Here & Now,17)

The first run, RD9 is over for the day. RD8, seventy-nine miles begins after breakfast (1987,MsCellany: Women Writers' Prose & Poetry,25)

Next day, the RD man left a note asking us to put our box on the other side of the road for his convenience. (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,65)

Oh to be a farmer in England, where mail is delivered not to the RD box, but right to the front door. (1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,86)

Check if you would get RD out there. (Oct 17, 2001,Lifestyleblock.co.nz)

RD run¶

1 n. (Rural) a rural delivery run [in which mail, newspapers, bread, groceries, farm produce and materials and recently milk are delivered.]

GORDON By this stage Snow had given up the farm and taken over the RD run and calling on the old chap was was part of his round. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,136)

GORDON In late 1984 a couple arrived to lease the store and do the RD run, so Pat Harper feels that she really is retired! (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,138)

Rural delivery run - for sale. (Dec 7, 2001,Hawke's Bay Property Guide,47)

RD1¶

n. (Rural) a national chain of rural retail stores, owned by Fonterra dairy co-operative.

RD1 is a wholly owned subsidiary of Fonterra co-operative group and operates 51 dairy specialist rural retail outlets .. A rare opportunity has arisen to join our RD1 store based in New Plymouth. (Jun 12, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,22)

1 n. (Rural) [orig.] a rural delivery address [ now applied widely and symbolically to rural brands eg website, restaurant, vineyards etc.]

MUDGWAY Rural Deliveries: RD1. Otane-Pukehau-Anaroa-Argyll East. This rural delivery commenced in 1919 .. RD1.com. (1999,125 Years Off the Beaten Track,16)

The label worn by one of Central Otago's newest wines is about as Kiwi as they come. RD1, the wine is called, and the illustration is of a galvanised country mailbox, its flap half open. Coming up from RD1 are also a pinot noir, pinot gris and sauvignon blanc. (Jun 9, 2001,Dominion,7)

Often spilling out on to the winery lawn, this lunch-only restaurant offers seasonal produce in a slightly more casual ambience than its partner, RD1, across the hallway. ..Vicky Bruhns Bolderson, chef at RD1, Sileni Estates.[cp] (Jul 2001,Cuisine,198)

The food and beverage operation includes a fine dining evening restaurant RD1 and Mesa, a brasserie-style lunch operation. (Aug 22, 2001,Dominion,38)

RD1.com¶

1 n. (Rural) a multi-functional world-wide-web site of New Zealand Dairy Group.

The rival New Zealand Dairy Group site, RD1.com, has reported more than 12,000 registered users. (Apr 26, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,18)

In effect Fencepost.com is competing with the rival dairy site set up by New Zealand Dairy Group, RD1.com, as only one of the two is expected to survive the dairy industry's mega-merger. (May 10, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,14)

Mr Allen said RD1.com had been a successful investment for his company. (Dec 7, 2001,Dominion,12)

To replace a broken post, tighten a slack wire or partly re-batten is not a big job. (Jan 16, 1941,NZ Farmer,21)

n.

This year the organisation has successfully re-homed 128 pups. (Oct 5, 2000,Contact (Wgtn),1)

The most intransigent opposition to Te Roopu Rapu's continuance came from the Department of Labour and local Regional Employment Access Council, which approves funding of Access schemes.
