reactor¶

n. audience reactor

Alastair Bull Labour's Helen Clark was next with 6mins 29secs, though her effectiveness was hard to judge as her reddish coat suspiciously clashed with the colour of TV3's worm - now called an "audience reactor". (Aug 12, 2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: accessed 04/01/06]

..featured the "worm" - an audience reaction gauge (now called the Reactor) - which was dumped by TVNZ for this election. (Aug 12, 2005,Dominion Post,A3)

"keep your hands on your Reactors," the stage manager has told them sternly. (Aug 12, 2005,Dominion Post,A3)

reader¶

n.

LELAND reader: Literacy is assumed, but not required for this position, an academic rank corresponding with a U.S. PROFESSOR (who is not a department head). Another misleading N.Z. name for the same rank is Associate Professor. For those familiar with the English academic system a Reader in N.Z. is not the same as a Reader in England; as it is a teaching position in N.Z. rather than a research title as in England. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,85)

readied¶

adj. (of a police case or evidence) manufactured [obs.; cf. ready n., ready up v.]

Two men (strangers to each other) recently came out of the Police Court after listening to evidence in a case. Said one: It looks like a "readied" case'; to which the other replied:Yes.' They said no more and went their several ways; but the joke of the matter lies in the fact that it came out later that the first man intended to libel the police, while the second sought to libel the defence. (Aug 6, 1910,NZ Truth,267/7/2)

ready¶

n. a have-on

ANDERSON I remembered that old saying If you're not one up you're one down.' I am sure, however, that the auditor sensed that this was a bit of aready'. (1975,Milford Road,120)

ready up¶

v. (?) to contrive (in an underhand way) {??here ?ready cash], to arrange illegally cf OED Racing: to prevent (one's horse) from winning .... to secure a handicap in another race (1887), P: prepare, contrive illicitly or not honourably: Austr: 1893 (Morris) (as a noun, `conspiracy').

[Horse-racing] No matter how we readied up things .... some of us were getting pretty stoney. (1896,Tom Bracken's Annual,38)

FANNING They have no more notion of straight running then the jockeys in a `readied-up' race at an unregistered meeting. (1910,Players and Slayers,25)

ready-cut¶

n. sliced bread

FINLAYSON [A Maori speaks:] Mum baked the bread and Maori scones there. Somehow the bread she bake taste good. Look at the ready-cut there for the kids' school lunch tomorrow. (1966,Brown Man's Burden,119,1973 ed.) [NOTES: 'The New House']

ready-made¶

n. a tailor-made cigarette, a factory-made (cigarette) [ca 1935 at least (Havelock) -->ca1938 espec. Maori (Marlborough)]

Thick paper is used in the manufacture of ordinary ready-made cigarettes. It makes them look fresh longer, but it doesn't improve the taste. Make your own cigarettes with fresh tobacco and "A.G." Cigarette Paper - the thinnest of thin cigarette paper. You'll never want a ready-made cigarette again when you discover how much more you like your own. (Apr 5, 1913,Evening Post,14)

If you're a cigarette man.. you know what time it is by how many you've rolled.. No matter if you've bought nothing but ready-mades before you get busted. You'll roll them one-handed after a while. (Jan 1952,Here & Now,2(2) : 32)

[Advt] I want a tobacco with character. I've been used to 'ready made' cigarettes. (Dec 9, 1940,Dominion,10)

n. an off-the-peg garment

HYDE No more Little Miss Blair [the local dressmaker]. Ready-mades glossy-new from the shops, ... (1938,Godwits Fly, The,138,1970 ed.)

real dinkum¶

phr.

I will give you a brief description of the little I saw of the real dinkum part of soldiering. (Jun 17, 1915,Rangitikei Advocate,4)

real gun¶

phr. very good

[Aviemore visitors' book] ... entries in the `remarks' column of the visitors' book at the Aviemore power project [Otematata include] ... real gun ... (Oct 15, 1966,Dominion,3/1)

reamers¶

n. trousers

SLATTER If [the freshers] did not please [at the initiation ceremony of the students' hostel] the dread chant of reamers would rise and off would come the trousers ... [84] Conformity was the [University hostel] House Code. A room mate was always a wife, trousers were always reamers, old boy was always pronounced air bair, the board at the bottom of the bed was the power board, a shower was a soak, all other hostels were inhabited by morons, freshers answered the phone. -->Check P: OED (1968,Pagan Game, The,83)

REAP¶

1 abbr. (Rural) Rural Education Activities Programme, initiated in the 1970s in many provincial areas.

Wairarapa REAP is facilitating the development of a regional education strategy, incorporating early childhood, primary and secondary schools and post compulsory education. (Sep 15, 2010,Wairarapa News,40)

NASH The first four REAPS:An investigation and evaluation of the Rural Education Activities Programme in Central Otago, East Coast, Marlborough and Ruapehu-Taihape 1979-1981. (1982,First Four REAPS, The,1)

ANDERSON REAPS were established in selected areas between 1979 and 1982. (1997,REAPS : making a difference in rural education,1)

BRADSHAW & WILLIAMS The day was organised by REAP (Rural Education Activities Programme) as part of the Wairarapa Drought Relief Programme. (1998,Information and Communication Needs,18)

She is a member of the board of the Southland Rural Education Activities Programme. (Feb 28, 2002,Southland Times,7)

reap-hook¶

n. [compare SICKLE]

MARSDEN ..., also iron, steel, spades, shovels, cast-iron pots of (various) sizes, and reap-hooks to the amount of [pounds]300. (Jun 10, 1815,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,136,1932 ed.)

To those who wish to speculate, the things that would pay best are, oatmeal, ... hardware, such as spades, grub-hoes, ... a few reaping hooks and scythes. ... also pots with handles, camp ovens. (Oct 9, 1848,Letters from Otago,20,1978 ed.)

reaping match¶

1 n. (Rural) a contest of reaping cocksfoot, based on speed, style and cleanliness [early 1900s.]

A cocksfoot reaping match will take place shortly between RA Pettigrew of Barry's bay and Tom Shaw, a brother of Mrs J Gaskin of Duvauchelle. The match will take place in Mr J Libeau's paddock at Duvauchelle and the two men are to reap an acre. ((7/0/1913),BLANK ENTRY,39) [NOTES: Akaroa Mail Jan 7 in COULSON Golden Harvest (1979)]

rearea¶

n.

BULLER ANTHORNIS MELANURA. (BELL-BIRD.) ... Native names. Mako, Makomako, Komako, Kokomako, Korimako, Kohimako, Kokorimako, Titimako, and Kopara. Of the above names, Korimako is most generally used by northern and Makomako by southern tribes. The Ngatiawas call this bird Rearea; and the natives of the Bay of Plenty distinguish the male and female as Kokorohimako and Titapu. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,91,{1888 2nd edn 1/85} ed.)

rearend loader¶

n.

McGILL rearend loader active male homosexual. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,92)

rearing¶

adj. =raring (from NZ ear/air merger?) [ca1935 Havelock.]

WALSH I am rearing to talk this business over with her (1947,Fourth Point of Star,34)

adj. = raring, in rearing to go (?from NZ ear/air merger)

NEWTON After their months of isolation, [they]were fairly rearing to go. [to begin drinking] (1947,Wayleggo,39)

SARGESON Come on boys, Jack said, ... I'm rearin' to go, Len said, and he closed his eyes and snored. (1949,I Saw in My Dream,111,(1974 ed. Rhodes) ed.)

Seddon The hounds were fighting fit and giving tongue - the hunters rearing to go and the riders alert - the stag was not! (1968,Seddons, The,53)

n.

McARA Rearing: See timber rearing. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),330) [NOTES: (Glossary of Waihi Mining Terms)]

2 adj. anxious

RICHARDS As the weeks went by I became like a young colt straining at the bit. I was rearing and longing to have a `lash'. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,75)

rearing shed¶

1 n. (Rural) a shed in which newborn calves are reared.

Tony Gumboot ..it doesn't explain why some calves get spring eczema while still in the rearing shed and not been out on pasture. (Feb 9, 2001,Fencepost.com)

.. I haven't seen spring eczema in calves which are solely confined to a rearing shed, ie no access to outside at all. (Feb 13, 2001,Fencepost.com,Hopkinson)

rebel¶

n. (historical) a hostile Maori; an anti-Crown Maori, esp. one captured in Hauhau wars and sent to Dunedin jail [also adjective/attributive use below]

At a meeting of the Magistrates this day, it was decided that Mr. Spain should proceed to the coast, and have an interview with the rebel chiefs; he is the only man that can settle the disputes about land, and maintain a good feeling with the natives. (Jul 15, 1843,Daily Southern Cross,2)

This officer's advancement to the rank of Commander was made a reward for his conduct in command of a breaching battery, in an attack made upon a rebel New Zealand chief, named Kawiti, whose strongly fortified pah, situated many miles inland, was stormed on the 11th of January, 1846, after several days of labour and fatigue, and triumphantly carried, notwithstanding a desperate fight of four hours. (Mar 2, 1850,New Zealander, The,2)

Calling them traitors and factious demogogues, on evidence that a sober-minded man would have regarded with suspicion, he sent down Lieutenant Shortland with a body of troops to overawe the supposed rebels. (Apr 9, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

GRACE Had the Treaty of Waitangi been fully and faithfully carried out, the war would not have occurred; instead, it has been ignored until now that it is useful to make rebels of the Natives. (Oct 23, 1860,Letter) [NOTES: 1860 Oct 23 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 94]

MORGAN A body of men has lately been formed to, whose express purpose will be to scour the bush, and follow up the rebels. (Aug 1863,Journal,68,1963 ed.)

TONKIN Altogether some 76 rebel savages were transferred to Dunedin gaol, among them being the chief Taurau - (1980,Dunedin Gaol,16) [NOTES: c1875 Otago Guardian in 1980 Tonkin Dunedin Gaol 16]

Orakau [a poem] The swarthy rebels answered with a fierce defiant shout,/ `Ka whawhai tonu! Ake[e-grave]! Ake[e-grave]! Ake[e-grave]!' [fn] We will fight for ever, and ever, and ever. (Jul 22, 1876,Saturday Advertiser,3)

I used to hear how [Te Kooti] was a rebel and all that, and I didn't think I was connected with him. (1987,NZ Journal of History,17) [NOTES: (Binney) 17 -->[Hei Ariki Algie, 1983 Nov 26]]

WAKEFIELD From these valleys ... the rebel natives under Rangihaeata were driven in the skirmishes of 1846 (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,112)

Rebels¶

n. (usu. as the Rebels) an Otago-based netball franchise competing in the National Bank Cup.

...the Shakers can still make it given their remaining matches against the lower North Island Flyers, the Auckland Diamonds and the Otago Rebels. (May 10, 2004,Dominion Post,D1)

recapitation¶

n.

It seems that I walked into something at Newtown School with my comments on recapitation... Their action could result in one or more schools having to close as the ministry amalgamates smaller schools into larger ones or pressure comes on the smaller schools to augment their rolls by recapitating. (Dec 2, 1999,City Voice,18)

recast¶

v. of sheepdogs, to CAST again [(farmers')]

NEWTON She recast, and was hitting out after another lot [of sheep]. (1947,Wayleggo,62)

1 n. (Rural) [sheepdogs] to cast a second time in order to head sheep more completely.

LOUGHNAN Keep out: Command to a heading dog to recast it wider around its sheep. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,46)

LOUGHNAN It is sometimes necessary to cast out a dog on one line, stop him, and then recast on another. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,66)

receival¶

n. Hawke's Bay term for Inwards Goods

Grape receival and processing. (1997,NZ Journal of Agriculture)

Wool Receivals. Sign by Williams & Kettle, No. 4 Shed (in private road till recently Colin St, Ahuriri, Napier). (Aug 4, 2000,Hawke's Bay Today,21)

Fruit Receivals Hours. Coventry Rd Juice Factory Hours from Monday, February 25... (Feb 24, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,24)

receiver¶

n. a vessel that receives the milk from one or more milk pipelines and feeds the releaser [(dairy farmers')]

Receiver: A vessel that receives the milk from one or more milk pipelines and feeds the releaser. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,42)

receiving yard¶

1 n. (Rural) an outer yard in a set of stock yards, where stock are first driven.

CORRESPONDENCE. EGMONT A. AND P. SHOW GROUNDS. The few improvements which were asked for at the annual meeting last year have not been given effect to. Where is the circular judging pen you speak of? Have the committee erected a race for the pig pens and a proper place for loading? Has the drinking trough in the receiving yard been shifted? (Nov 16, 1907,Hawera & Normanby Star,7)

The dimensions of the yards, pens, &c., are as follows:- Receiving yard, 63ft. by 45ft.; drafting yard, 72ft. by 50ft.; sale pens (six) each 18ft. by 18ft. (May 17, 1878,North Otago Times,2)

At milking time, 6 a.m. and 2.30 p.m., the cows are gathered into the receiving yard, from which twenty at a time are drafted into the shed yard. (Aug 26, 1886,Taranaki Herald,3)

The City Engineer, reporting at the City Council last night on arrangements for the extension of the Municipal Abbatoir .. stated that the work consisted principally of (1) extension of the stormwater culvert, construction of a large receiving yard for cattle, to be partly covered ... (Nov 4, 1910,Evening Post,10)

WAITAHUNA FARMERS' CLUB. .. The President stated that a receiving yard was still required, but it would not cost much to put it up. (May 27, 1891,Tuapeka Times,3)

Councillor Melton said a receiving yard, to be attached to the pound, was much wanted, and there was sufficient material left from the old pound to make such a yard - the putting up of which, together with filling up the post holes at the old pound, could be done for about GBP1 10. (Nov 25, 1868,Timaru Herald,2)

PERRY [The sheep yards] should consist of at each end, forcing pen, and drafting race. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,16)

A very large yard which sleep come into first when brought into the sheep yards (q.v.). (C.) (Nov 18, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

In general large drafting yards embody the following subsections or divisions ... The receiving yards, into which the sheep enter, which usually have a large capacity .. (Jul 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,7)

BOWEN Receiving yards. These must have the capacity to take incoming mobs. They communicate with the forwarding yards, or diamond pens, which are much smaller, and lead up to the crush pens or forcing pens. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

PERRY They [sheep yards] should consist of receiving yards at each end, forcing pen and drafting race. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,16)

The receiving yards usually communicate with the forwarding yards or pens. (Jul 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,07)

GASCOIGNE The pattern of present-day construction has come down to us directly from these emergencies of our early settlement - the great receiving yards , the 'diamond' or 'crown' pen leading into the crush pens with the drafting race and gates opening into yards for the finally separated sheep. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,12)

The long summer morning's muster, beginning before the dawn, has finally ended at about 11 a.m. with the big herd of cows and calves safely confined behind the slip rails of the receiving yard. (Mar 23, 1967,NZ Farmer,33)

LOUGHNAN receiving yard: the large pen into which sheep or cattle arrive when brought into the yards for close handling. Naturally it adjoins the holding paddock. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,66)

reception¶

n. a newly arrived prisoner, prisoner at arrival [(prison)]

A few inmates ... ambled around, curiously looking at the new receptions (1982,Big Huey, The,24)

reck¶

adj.

McGILL reck a bad thing; eg `That stuff you got off Sibby, I tried it, it's reck, eh.' [Alison Gray] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,92)

recolonial¶

adj.

Our chances are certainly better than they would have been during the depths of the recolonial era. Ibid. C5 These problems are less likely to be resolved if we fail to recognise their recolonial roots. (Oct 28, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C1)

The recolonial era hid or denied difference, emphasised harmony, and played up Britishness. Belich's book traces a Great Tightening that shaped much of New Zealand life during recolonialism. (Nov 17, 2001,Dominion,11)

recolonisation¶

n.

Belich divides the period covered by the volume, the 1880s to the present, into three broad phases: the progressive colonisation which was the dominant feature of Making Peoples; the rise of recolonisation, which tightened the relations between Britain and colonies up to the 1960s and made them co-owners of imperial culture and heritage; and finally decolonisation, the period since the 1960s in which New Zealand has achieved economic diversification, greater independence in foreign policy and a great socio-demographic "coming-out" of difference. (Nov 17, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),57)

But one pattern looms high above the rest, recolonisation, whose rise, reign and fall is the master variable of modern New Zealand history. (Oct 28, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C5)

By recolonisation he means the powerful tightening of economic, social and cultural ties to Britain that began in the 1880s and lasted till the 1970s. It turned New Zealand into "a town-supply district of London" while "London became the cultural capital of New Zealand." (Dec 8, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,12)

recolonised¶

adj.

In fact, New Zealand remained a colony, albiet a privileged one, from the 1880s till the 1960s. Belich dubs this era, which followed four decades of colonisation, as New Zealand's "recolonised" period. It was a time of tightened economic and cultural links to Britain and a role for this country as Britains "town supply district". (Nov 17, 2001,Dominion,11)

recount¶

n. a court recount and review of votes cast at an election following the Returning Officer's declaration of the result. [Jim Cameron writes : A recount in the UK is made by the Returning Officer on election night before the result is announced. Electoral Act 1993, s. 180, 181.]

recreational fisheries¶

n.

Commission policy manager Craig Lawson said the commission had not intended to try to "take over" recreational fisheries but was simply offering to assist in managing it. (Mar 5, 2001,Dominion,3)

recreational fisherman¶

n. one who fishes only for recreation as opposed to a professional fisherman

Recreational fishers can continue marine fishing free, but it's not plain sailing yet as the different fishing sectors vie for the piece of the big blue sea. (Mar 14, 2001,Norwester,3)

Recreational fishermen want their rights recognised in law and greater say in how fisheries are managed. (Nov 18, 2000,Dominion,2)

recreational fishing¶

n.

Recreational fishing needed legal protection to ensure public rights were not eroded, Fisheries Minister Pete Hodgson told the Recreational Fishing Council conference yesterday... Recreational fishing opportunities would become increasingly sought after around the world and New Zealand was uniquely placed to benefit, he said. (Jul 14, 2001,Dominion,7)

recreational hunter¶

n. someone who hunts for "sport"

The policy contends recreational hunters are only able to cull enough deer to protect regenerating plants in areas with easy vehicle access. (May 10, 2001,Evening Post,31)

recreational hunting¶

n.

Recreational hunting is important in developing self-reliance and a love of the outdoors among many young New Zealanders. (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,306/2)

Recreational hunting will be encouraged but deer numbers will not be maintained at levels "that cause severe and long lasting forest damage just to provide easy hunting." (May 10, 2001,Evening Post,31)

Recreational hunting has never been able to hold these populations in check. (Jul 2, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

recreational lease¶

n.

WHEELER Glentanner has moved into tourism. Taking a recreational lease' over the property, Ian has built a motor camp complex, incorporatingHeliski', or helicopter skiing, on the Ben Ohau Range. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,30)

recruit¶

v. recuperate, put on condition

Besides this, they let the cattle, for which there is very little food in the Teramakau valley, recruit here, since it is a grassy place, near ... Hokitika where feed grows. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,82)

recruity¶

n. a new recruit [(WW1 ? coinage)]

Our `recruity' is a married man. (Aug 1917,Flare, The,13)

red¶

adj. as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants see AZOLLA, BEECH; BEECH, SOUTHERN; BIDDY-BID, BIRCH; BURR, NEW ZEALAND; CAMPION, CENTAURY, CESTRUM, CLOVER, DEAD NETTLE, FAT HEN; FERN, WATER; FIR; GRASS, FESCUE; GUM, HEATH, HOROPITO, ink plant, KAMAHI, KIEKIE, KOWHAI, MALLOW, MANUKA, MAPAU, MAPLE, MATIPO, MISTLETOE, MYRTLE, ORACHE, PARROT'S BILL, PINE, PIRIPIRI; RATA, CLIMBING; RUSH; TARWEED, TEA-TREE, TUSSOCK, UNCINIA, VALERIAN -->as a distinguishing epithet in names of fish see: BAITFISH, COD; COD, ROCK; CRAB, SWIMMING; CRAYFISH, DORY, GURNARD, GURNET(-PERCH), HERRING, MOKI, MULLET, PERCH; COD, ROCK; SCORPIONFISH, SNAPPER, SOLDIER(FISH), SPOTTY, SQUID: see also RED BAIT, REDFISH

n. elliptical for red cent in negative construction (still extant) not to have a red cent (cf RAZOO)

EVERSLEY [see QUOT DO] (1889,NZ Voices,36)

n. sodium seconal capsule [(criminal's)]

NEWBOLD RED (n) Sodium seconal capsule. So called because of its colour. (1982,Big Huey, The,252)

Red Admiral¶

n. [aka kahukura]

We sometimes are surprised at the sudden appearance of a great Red Admiral butterfly in our rooms in midwinter. (Jan 18, 1889,Otago Witness,37)

The red admiral, as I have called this butterfly, though it is not the same as the insect of that name so well known to English lepidopterists, is said to live in the larval stage only on the nettle. In the face of the abundance of the mature insects and the scarcity of nettles, this is a statement requiring verification ... (Apr 13, 1899,Otago Witness,61)

I have even seen specimens of the large "Red Admiral" butterfly caught in the flowers. (Mar 28, 1893,Bruce Herald,4)

Near the Nairn we found a clump of the Chatham Island nettle, a fine plant with very large leaves, interesting to the entomologist as it is simply alive with the larvae of Pyrameis gonerilla - our Red Admiral butterfly. (Feb 12, 1924,Otago Witness,7)

New Zealand butterflies and moths are likewise graced with pretty names. There's the Red Admiral (above), known in Maori as the Kahukura or "red cloak"; and the Yellow Admiral, aka the Kahukowhai or "yellow cloak." (Sep 19, 2010,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),31)

If your last sighting of a Red Admiral is a distant memory, it's likely due to the introduction of the Pteromalus puparum wasp in 1932, reckons butterfly enthusiast Rob Jones. (Sep 19, 2010,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),31)

New Zealand Red Admiral butterfly, characterised mostly by dark red, black and brown colours, usually deposits its eggs on a leaf of the common native nettle. (Oct 28, 1924,Otago Witness,6)

red back¶

n. (obsolete) a 50-pound note (Not recorded of the 50-dollar note)

RED BACK' POISON [headline] Mr. Percival cashed a cheque six months ago and asked for a 50 [pounds] note as part payment. He tried unsuccessfully to cash thered back' in Auckland hotels, and hoped for better luck in Wellington. (Jul 31, 1966,Sunday Star Times,5)

red bag¶

1 n. (Rural) an everted vagina or uterus of a ewe [usually before or during lambing.]

The term 'red bag' is frequently used, arising from the appearance of the everted membrane. (Jun 15, 1939,NZ Journal of Agriculture,468)

red bait¶

n. a fish, Emmelichthys nitidus

Ayling RED BAIT Emmelichthys nitidus ... The fins are pink and the tail is pink-red. (1982,Collins Guide,223,1984 ed.)

[species name] red bait .. [scientific name] Emmelichthys .. [other name(s)] rock salmon, rockfish, bonnetmouth, job fish (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

Paul Redbait Emmelichthys nitidus Sometimes called red baitfish. Also occurs around southern Australia. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,95)

Red Bands¶

n. (Rural) gumboots, particularly those shorter forms made by Skellerup since 1958. [proprietary name]

Alongside red bands (gumboots) and "Swannis", a black woolly singlet is classic Kiwi-wear, worn by generations of good keen men and women. (Mar 2009,North & South,108)

Skellerup Red Bands celebrate 50 years as a cultural icon.[hdg] Launched in 1958, the Red Band broke away from previous gumboot designs - it was wider than a normal gumboot, shorter in the leg and able to be 'stepped into' easily. (2008,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.betterbydesign.org.nz/news-and-resources/design-news/news-details?objI...]

Fonterra chairman Henry van der Heyden got the equivalent of a knighthood - a DCNZM .. but it wasn't for him.. "It didn't take me long to realise that this isn't about me," he told the NZ Herald. "This is a recognition of all the hard work that the farmers have done .." Well, he would say that wouldn't her Most people seem to, seeing as it's the Kiwi way to be humble or, at least, profess to be. It's that or to be thought to be too big for your red bands. (Jan 2009,Internet - see Notes,2)

There must be millions of them that over the last forty years or so have been pulled onto thousands of Kiwi feet, thrust into red bands, work boots, tramping boots and slippers. I'm talking about Norsewear socks. (Oct 17, 2007,Wairarapa News,4)

As part of the celebrations, Red Bands will feature in the Skellerup heat for the Rural Bachelor of the year competition at National Fieldays at Mystery Creek. .. We've also been asking Kiwis around the country for some of their memorable Red Band moments... (Jun 16, 2008,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.skellerup.co.nz/fileadmin/newsletter/160608.pdf]

The red-band rule of thumb (a waterway that is deeper than a red-band gumboot or too wide to jump) allows for a farmer to opt out of planting these crucial small streams. On most farms, even a large river narrows to the point where it could be stepped across. Similarly there will be a wide point where even a larger river can be crossed wearing red-bands. (Jul 7, 2008,NZ Herald,13)

Often there is the hilariously quirky juxtaposition - Taranaki Regional Council general manager Basil Chamberlain seated midstream in a leopard-skin love chair, the water threatening to fill his Red Bands. (2008,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.pukeariki.com/en/Library/rev_c_03.htm]

It's Christmas Eve at the bach, the children are dreaming of pavlova, and Santa turns up in Red Bands and a black singlet ... (2004,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.bookcouncil.org.nz/education/brat/bratautumn2004.html]

Get out your red bands and swannies, it'll be a wee cracker! (2006,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.port-nicholson-rotary.wellington.net.nz]

The contestants all regular attendees at the Stadium designed the concept of the Golden Gumboot while celebrating Mercy's win last Sunday. Racing over 200 metres the contestants are racing in a costume (including mask) of their choice and must wear red bands. (May 23, 2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.greyhounds.co.nz/aticles/article_2007_05_23_2432.html]

red beech¶

n. Nothofagus fusca, aka red birch, tawhai-raunui

Fagus fusca. - In Auckland this tree is called black-birch'; in Wellingtonred-birch'; in Nelson, Marlborough and Westland it is called brown-birch'; and in Otago it is called bothred-birch' and bull-birch.' The most suitable name isred-beech.' (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/308) [NOTES: (E. Phillips Turner)]

The chief indigenous trees of commercial value are: Kauri (Agathis Australis), Kahikatea or white pine ... red and hard beech (Nothofagus fusca and Nothofagus truncata), silver beech (Nothofagus Menziesii), black beech (Nothofagus Solandri) ... (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,578)

LAING & BLACKWELL N. fusca (The Red Beech) ... North Island: mountainous districts; South Island: abundant. The Red Birch. A somewhat similar species is N. truncata, the Clinker Beech, often called the Hard-Beech. (1940,Plants of NZ,139)

LINKLATER Ferns and tree-ferns flourish [on Stewart Island], ... supple-jack entwines your heels, and stinkwood is garlanded with little red flowers. There is red or black beech, there is mutton-bird scrub with thick green leaves that have white undersides, there are, perhaps, a dozen others. (1953,Year of Space, A,203,1954 ed.)

DAWSON Five species of Nothofagus were formerly recognised in New Zealand, but more recently two of these have been combined as varieties of one species. ... Nothofagus fusca: red beech (the timber is reddish in colour). (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,121)

DENNIS ... red beech (Nothofagus fusca) and hard beech (N. truncata) are regular components of the forests on the crest of the scarp above. (1981,Paparoas Guide,157)

McLINTOCK Beech ... Red .. tawhairaunui Nothofagus fusca (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/710)

HENDERSON Red or brown beech/birch, `steaming wood', good fill-in wood. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,60)

MOORE & IRWIN NOTHOFAGUS FUSCA. Red beech is widely but discontinuously distributed in the North Island and is dominant in extensive South Island forests. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,80)

(red-beech) (1909,AJHR,C-6, Appendix D) [NOTES: Jourdain Report on the Mokau River (And)]

(red-beech) (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Turner Botanical Examination of the Higher Waimarino District in AJHR C-11]

COCKAYNE ... N.fusca and N.Menziesii, called respectively the red and silver beeches, ... (1910,NZ Plants,49)

(1910,TrNZI,42/) [NOTES: (And)]

(1916,Official Trade Register of Nurserymen) [NOTES: (And)]

(1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue) [NOTES: (And)]

Built of red beech slabs, the hut had a tin roof, a clay floor, ... and accommodated eleven (in five sacking bunks). (1971,VUWTC'71,20)

Crowe As a timber tree, red beech has been put to much the same uses as hard beech - railway sleepers, mine props, house construction, wharves and bridges. (2009,Which Native Tree?,32-33)

red berry¶

n. Coprosma robusta [1919 W,Best (Otaki) Vernacular (Andersen)[1919 July 29] Ver.(WB). = Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W.Best, Otaki (And)]

red birch¶

n. [(?Wellington, Nelson, Otago, Southland). [1919 July 29] Ver.(WB). = Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W.Best, Otaki (And)]

The Tawhai, and Tawhai-rau-nui, or Black and Red Birches, (Fagus Solandri and F. Fusca,) often form large ... trees (1869,TrNZI,1/iii/44) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

HECTOR Nothofagus fusca, Hook. Tawhai Tawhairaunui, Black-birch of Auckland and Otago (from colour of bark), Red-birch of Wellington and Nelson (from colour of timber). --This is a noble tree 60-90 feet high the trunk 5-8 feet in diameter. The timber is excessively tough and hard to cut. It is highly valued in Nelson and Wellington. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,125,3rd ed.)

[Notho]fagus fusca, Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occured in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood. (1885,TrNZI,17/300) [NOTES: (Kirk, NZ Beeches)]

English Name Native name Botanical Name Red Birch .. Fagus Fusca Black Birch .. Fagus Solandri White or Silver Birch .. Fagus menziesii (1889,Catalogue, Canterbury Court Exhibition,35)

Red Birch of Otago, Black Birch of Nelson, Beech etc (Fagus Menziesii); Black Birch of Otago (F. fusca) White Birch of Otago (F. Solandri)[get full citation] (1869,TrNZI,1/32) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Tawhai-rau-nui - Red Birch. (1869,TrNZI,1/44)

KIRK BLACK BIRCH of Auckland and Otago, RED BIRCH of Wellington and Nelson: HUTU-TAWHAI.- (Fagus fusca.) The true black birch is a noble tree, found from Kaitaia ... to Otago ... (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,15)

HETLEY & RAOUL (1889,Fleurs Sauvages) [NOTES: (And)]

kir (1889,Forest Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

163 Test piece, red birch (tooth leaved beech) .. .. [525lbs.] (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,19)

The timber on the western side consists of red- and white-pine, matai (or black-pine), totara, kawhaka (or cedar), rata, and occasional silver-pine, besides black- and red-birch (Fagus fusca). (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,19)

MATTHEWS Nothofagus fusca (1905,Tree Culture in NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

CHEESEMAN F. fusca, Hook.f. ... A noble forest-tree 60-100 ft. high; ... bark dark-brown or black in old plants, deeply furrowed, smooth and greyish-white on young trees; ... rare in Canterbury and eastern Otago. ... Tawhai; Tawhai-rau-nui; Black-birch; Red-birch. ... [642] Wood bark-red, ... more durable than that of other species, ... (1906,Manual NZ Flora,641)

(1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/307) [NOTES: (E. Phillips Turner) see cit. 1 b. above.]

LAING & BLACKWELL N. fusca: Red Beech: North Island, mountainous districts; South Island, abundant. (1940,Plants of NZ,139)

red birch n 3 a : a valuable New Zealand timber tree (Nothofagus fusca) - called also clinker beech, red beech b: the hard wood of this tree (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1901)

McLEOD In the forests on the north side of the Waimakariri there are substantial stands of Nothofagus fusca, the red beech, which we called `red birch' in those days [late 1920's]. (1970,Glorious Morning,83)

HENDERSON Red or brown beech/birch,`steaming wood', good fill-in wood. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,60)

n. = red matipo.

KIRK Rapanea Urvillei (1889,Forest Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

(1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: Turner Botanical Examination of the Higher Waimarino District]

(1916,Official Trade Register of Nurserymen) [NOTES: (And)]

Mapau, red-mapau, or red-birch (Myrsine urvillei) (1892,NZ Official Handbook,150)

n. = kamahi

HARPER There is also the rata tree, the prince of firewoods, ... miki-miki, kamahi, or so-called red-birch, white and black birches (which are really beeches), the mountain broom, ribbon wood, broad leaf, totara, and many others, ... and always available in the Ranges [sc. Alps]. (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,35)

COCKAYNE Weinmannia racemosa (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

LAING & BLACKWELL [The Kamahi] ... is particularly common in the forests of Westland, ... where it is usually termed red birch (!), but most of the popular names there are misnomers. The foliage of the Kamahi is much used particularly in Christchurch for decorative purposes, and sold under the name `red birch.' (1940,Plants of NZ,197)

red birch [=] kamahi [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,63)

Weinmannia racemosa (1877,TrNZI,9/)

KIRK (1889,Forest Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

n. Nothofagus menziesii, aka silver birch

Red Birch of Otago, Black Birch of Nelson, Beech, etc. (Fagus Menziesi), a valuable timber tree, found from the sea level to 4000 feet altitude, sometimes attaining a diameter of 12 feet. (1869,TrNZI,1/iii/44) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

HOOKER Fagus Menziesii, Hook. fil. ... HAB. Mountains of the Northern and Middle Islands. ... Nat. name, Tawai', Col.Red Birch' of the colonists. ... A very handsome tree, 80-100 feet high, ... Bark silvery, outer layers peeling off and exposing a red surface. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 229)

KIRK RED BIRCH.- (Fagus menziesii.) (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,17)

HAY The Tawai (Fagus Menziesii), called `red birch' by settlers, is a favourite for fencing when young. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/190)

HOOKER (1864,Handbook NZ Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

(1872,Catalogue of the Colonial and Vienna Exhibition) [NOTES: (And)]

HECTOR Nothofagus menziesii, Hook. Tawhai, Red-birch (from the colour of the bark). --A handsome tree, 80-100 feet high; trunk 2-3 feet in diameter. The timber is chiefly used in the lake district of the South Island. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,125)

[Notho]fagus menziesii, Hook. f. ... Silver Beech. Brown Birch, White Birch, Red Birch. Silver Birch. Although this species exhibits a considerable amount of variation in the shape, toothing and texture of the leaves, it is the most easily recognized of all the New Zealand beeches, especially when the fruit is fairly developed (1885,TrNZI,17/298) [NOTES: (Kirk, NZ Beeches)]

(1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/307) [NOTES: (E. Phillips Turner) see cit. 1 b. above.]

Fagus cliffortioides Hook. f. .. Mountain beech or birch. [Fagus] fusca Hook. f. .. Tawhai, black-birch. [Fagus] Menziesii Hook. f. .. Silver or red birch. [Fagus] Solandri Hook. f. .. White-birch. (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/144)

Colour Coding [heading] ... St Patrick's Day sports organiser, Mr Lyn Thompson yesterday inquired about the difference between red, black and brown birch. It was `clearly' explained for him by a prominent axeman, Mr Bill Evans. The bark of the red birch is silver, [?HWO thus N. menziesii] but the timber is pink when it's green. Brown birch often has black bark, but the green timber is red. Sometimes the bark of the black birch is white, but the timber is yellow and sometimes it's brown when it's green. (Mar 11, 1972,Otago Daily Times,1) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

n. -

1/iii/44 The Tawhai, and Tawhai-rau-nui, or Black and Red Birches, (Fagus Solandri and F. Fusca,) often form large ... trees (1869,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

[Notho]fagus solandri, Hook. f. ... Myrtilloides cinerascens, Banks & Sol., MS. Cliffortiordes oblongata, Dryander. Entire-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Wellington, Canterbury, and in part of Otago and Southland. White Birch of Nelson, and in part Otago. Black-heart Birch of Otago. White, Black, Red, and Brown Birch of Oxford and Alford Forests. A fine tree, sometimes attaining the height of 100 feet, but usually 60-80 feet, with a trunk from 2 to 4 feet or more in diameter. (1885,TrNZI,17/301) [NOTES: (Kirk, NZ Beeches)]

KIRK (1889,Forest Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

CHEESEMAN (1906,NZ Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

(1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/307) [NOTES: (E. Phillips Turner) see cit. 1 b. above.]

n.

Three facets of its character stood out:.. the warm nutty tones of the timber work - hand-adzed pews of Southland red birch and roof principals and rafters of Australian iron bark and jarrah... (May 1994,NZ Historic Places,47/23)

red bottom¶

SLATTER Goes into action with a rifle and a sugar-bag. No other gear. What's the bag for says the red bottoms. Loot cries old Stonker. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,181)

red boy¶

Roughly 75,000 of the "red boy" and 112,000 of the "blue boy" were sold. (Jan 29, 1947,NZ Observer,8)

Red Checkers¶

n. an RNZAF acrobatics team

The biggest drawback the Red Checkers aerobatic team have is the machines they fly - the New Zealand designed and built CT4 Air Trainer, which replaced the North American Harvard as the RNZAF's basic trainer. (Jun 22, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),25)

red cod¶

n. Pseudophycis bachus (also listed as Physiculus bac(c)hus, and in early texts Lotella bacchus), fam Moridae, an often abundant food fish of mainly SI waters; .in early writings under a listing Lotella bacchus, occas. and confusingly referred to as rock cod or yellowtail qqv. [Contrast bastard red cod.]

(Black Stewart Island) It was no unusual event ...to land ... Moki, Latris ciliaris; Trumpeter, Latris hecateia; Blue cod or Rock cod, Percis colias; and Red cod, Lotella bacchus. (1872,Appendix Proc. Otago Prov. Council,39)

HECTOR 75. RED COD. ... (Lotella bacchus) is a well known fish on some parts of the coast, being the species that is cured and sold as Findon Haddock at Port Chalmers. (1872,Edible Fishes,115)

[Native or Common Name] Red Cod .. [Scientific Name] Lotella bacchus (1877,TrNZI,9/485) [NOTES: (P. Thomson, Otago)]

SENIOR There is another fish somewhat resembling [the haddock] cured and sold in Dunedin as the Findon haddock. This is in reality a red cod, and is beautifully coloured. (1880,Travel & Trout,298)

SHERRIN RED COD (Lotella Bacchus). ... Red-cod ... is a well-known fish on some parts of the coast, being the species that is cured and sold as the Findon haddock. It is a handsome fish, with a brilliant play of metallic colours when alive. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,16)

Red cod (Lotella bacchus) (1890,TrNZI,22/375) [NOTES: (G.M. Thomson)]

Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand ... while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are confined to the south. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,167)

DRUMMOND & HUTTON The snapper, the mullet, and the trevally are essentially northern; while the trumpeter, the red cod, and the ling are just as essentially southern. (1902,Nature in NZ,71)

... hundreds of young red-cod, rarii (Lotella bacchus), and what I believe are young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru (Percis colias). The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length. (1903,TrNZI,35/319) [NOTES: (Mair Fish in Piako River)]

Physiculus Bachus ... Red Cod. (1911,Records of the Canterbury Museum,1/183) [NOTES: Waite]

Hoka, n. Lotella bacchus, red cod. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,67)

PHYSICULUS BACHUS (Forster). Red Cod; Hoka. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/121) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

BUICK Next in progression came the shoals of red cod - the hoka of the Maori - chased from the [Waitaki] river-mouth by the assaults of the voracious kahawai. (1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,176)

BEATTIE The above list of fish to be caught along the Canterbury coast has some notable omissions, as hoka (red cod). (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,62)

GRAHAM Red Cod Physiculus (Pseudophycis) bachus (Bloch and Schn) (Syn. Blennius and Brosmius venustus Richardson, Gadus and Blennius rubiginosus Richardson) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,403) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 403]

PARROTT THE RED COD Physiculus bachus (Bloch & Schneider) ... Maori name: HOKA. ...When removed from the water the grey colour rapidly gives place to a uniform red: hence the common name `Red Cod'. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,47)

red cod n 1 : a gadid food fish (Physiculus bachus) of Australia and New Zealand that is reddish gray above and pink beneath but quickly becomes red when removed from the water b : RED ROCK COD (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1901)

SORENSON COD, RED (a) Scientific name: Physiculus bachus (Family Moridae). (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Red Cod. (c) Other common names: Red Rock Cod (Australia); Cape Cod. (d) Principal localities where taken: Cook Strait, Nelson, Picton ... Lyttelton, Akaroa, Timaru, Port Chalmers, Greymouth. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,17)

BURTON [Title] Cod, red his stout, reddish-grey fish, known to the Maori as hoka, more closely resembles its English counterpart than other New Zealand `cod'. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,70)

HULME Simon made the acquaintance of barracouta, ling, trumpeter, and rig, and red cod, kelp cod, and rock cod. (1983,Bone People, The,251)

red crayfish¶

n. Jasus edwardsii, aka spiny crayfish, common crayfish

WILSON CRAYFISH ... The biggest saltwater variety is the Packhorse Crayfish, so named because he grows to a prodigious size compared with his offsider, the spiny, or red crayfish. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,39)

BURTON The red crayfish, or koura papatea of the Maori, is a type of lobster found only in the New Zealand region, although it is related to Australian and South African species and is a member of a worldwide family, the Palinurids. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,66)

[species name] rock lobster .. [scientific name] Jasus edwardsii .. [other name(s)] crayfish, crayfish spiny, crays red, lobster red, red crayfish, spiny rock lobster (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

Red Dandy¶

n.

The "Red Dandies" of Waihi and Wellington.. are merrymakers all. (Sep 19, 1912,Evening Post,6)

red deer¶

n.

Unfortunately, red deer favour the same tussock species as takahe, and their method of feeding - simply severing the leaves with their teeth - does not stimulate regrowth. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/47)

Farm escapes and illegal releases over the last 15 years have spread all deer species throughout New Zealand, with the most commonly farmed species - red, fallow and sika deer - accounting for the majority of new populations. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,No. 304/6)

red dory¶

n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] dory, red 1045 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

red eye¶

n. a Merino wether

red eyes: Merino wethers (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/27) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary).]

red fantail¶

2 n. (Environment)

BULLER The Red Fantail ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,1/169)

Red Fed¶

adj. (derogatory) left-wing, socialist

[Hdg] Red Fed. Radishes... When the Red Fed candidates came before the electors last December, they included quite a number of the "radish" fraternity... The Red Fed radish - with the white outside - did not prove a very popular vegetable last December. (Jan 6, 1920,NZ Free Lance,8)

[Hdg] Red Fedism. Akin to Prussianism... Professor J. Macmillan Brown... contended that the ideals of the I.W.W. and the Red Fed element resembled, in many cases, the Prussianism against which we were fighting. (Apr 18, 1917,Wanganui Herald,23)

The aspirants for Red Fed. fame left the scene of their exploit adder but wiser men. (Aug 8, 1912,Grey River Argus,4)

DAVIN `Isn't that the red-fed lawyer?' Hugh laughed ... at the combination of respect for a headline name and honour of political notoriety so characteristic of the New Zealander. (1956,Sullen Bell,59)

SUTHERLAND When it comes to the pinch you can trust the New Zealander. We don't go for these red-fed ideas here ... (1978,Elver, The,44)

Baxter It is not Marxist' orRed-fed' - it is a certain kind of love ... (May 13, 1963,Letter) [NOTES: 1963 May 13 Letter in 1990 McKay James K. Baxter 195]

SINCLAIR & HARREX [Caption] The 'Red Fed villains' as they appeared in a rogue's gallery in the Otago Witness on 26 November 1913. (1978,Looking Back,173)

n. originally one who supported the socialist ideals and policies of the Red' Federation of Labour; a RED FEDERAL; (informal) a socialist or leftist; a slightly abusive term for a left-wingagitator', militant unionist, or other assertive person of the left

"It must be the red-feds," someone suggested amidst laughter. (Nov 6, 1928,Evening Post,10)

[Caption] A Slap in the Face for the "Red Feds". (Jun 22, 1912,NZ Free Lance,1)

It is Town Talk... That a nick-name has been found for Bob Semple's Federation of Labour. It's the "Red Fed."... That the Red-Fed's game is about up in New Zealand. That Waihi strike has just about put their pot on the fire. (Jun 22, 1912,NZ Free Lance,26)

It is Town Talk... That Mr. Red Fed Parry will "shake the country from end to end". (Sep 28, 1912,NZ Free Lance,22)

The aviator pinned the tribute to the breast of the Right Honourable R. Fedd. "He died for a principle!" (Dec 1, 1920,NZ Free Lance,Xmas Annual 45)

Suddenly two women, a red fed. and a loyalist, attacked each other with their umbrellas. (Oct 4, 1912,Grey River Argus,6)

No farmer who disapproves of disloyalty and lawlessness, of the foreign agitators who deluded the true working man into law-breaking, could desire to be classed as a Red Fed. (Nov 28, 1914,Grey River Argus,3)

Some of the Red Feds are now fed at the State's expense. (Sep 28, 1912,NZ Free Lance,22)

BOLLINGER As things turned out, the O.F.O.L. never became much broader than the old 'Red Fed.' (1968,Against the Wind,100)

The Waihi affair led to a bit of an "argument" on the wharf yesterday afternoon between a Socialist of the Red Fed brand and a believer in peaceful arbitration. (Nov 14, 1912,Grey River Argus,4)

The notorious "Red Feds" gained political representation in the House, and in the longer term were to be a driving force in the emerging Labour Party... Ibid. 33 Most of us were out and out Red Feds. (Jul 28, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

The notorious "Red Feds" gained political representation in the House, and in the longer term were to be a driving force in the emerging Labour Party... We'd always have a piece of red in the lapel of our coats. Most of us were out and out Red Feds. (Jul 28, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

The Red Feds are obviously not included under the general definition. (Feb 15, 1913,NZ Observer,4)

McRobie apparently did not count on the Unity Schemers' and theRed Feds' burying the hatchet-... (Feb 15, 1913,NZ Truth,399/1/6)

RED FED: colloq. male supporter of the 1913 strikers; ... [?quot. or LC's gloss: check] (Nov 29, 1913,Hutt Valley Independent,1)

Red Feds' and force. ... The charge you prefer against theRed Feds' ... (Jan 14, 1914,Evening Post,10)

If you want a good electric torch I'll get one from the Ossies; they're white, they are. Of course, they call me a bit of a Socialist.'I heard you were a Red Fed,' interjected my companion. (1917,New Zealand At the Front,90)

Have I not sent many Redfeds into Jug. (1918,NZ Black Watch Transport Magazine,3)

ANZAC DAY is an excellent thing. It shows these gentry that there is a big body of the public that holds different views from themselves. ... The incident of the flag-burning, too, in Sydney, was very instructive - bitterly instructive to the Red Feds. They must realise that there are many to whom the magic word Unionmakes no appeal. (1921,Auckland University Carnival Book,17)

HICKEY [See Red Federation 1925] (1925,Red Fed. Memoirs,48)

COAD `They [sc NZ customs officials] are on the look-out for Bolshevists, Red-Feds and I.W.W's,' replied the New Zealander, looking at him suspiciously. (1931,Such Is Life,24)

HYDE ... they were the worst people in Calver Street - the poorest, anyhow, and not well thought of, since John had become a Red Fed and started spending his evenings in Carl Withers' bookshop. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,37,1970 ed.)

SINCLAIR In contrast to the United Labour Party, the `Red Feds' eschewed political action ... They would fight in the factories ... the strike would be their weapon. Consequently they were bitterly antagonistic to the arbitration system which sought to minimize class antagonism, ... Ibid.. 303 [Colonial-N.Z. glossary][?also 320] Red-Fed. Member of the Red federation [check] (1959,History of New Zealand,199)

SEDDON The attempt of the `Red Feds' to call a general strike throughout New Zealand failed. (1968,Seddons, The,217)

MITCHELL red fed: Non-member of National Party. (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,183)

STEWART Red-feds they call this Labour crowd. The priests. Communists in disguise, they reckon. (1981,Hot & Copper Sky,74)

red-fed n. NZ colloq. socialist, left-winger. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,636) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 408][Federation of Labour, founded 1909]]

In 1912 the federation pledged support for the disgruntled tramwaymen in Wellington, and the Evening Post made its contribution to history by declaring: `A victory for the Reds in the present quarrel would be a public disaster, possibly on a national scale. The Reds are out to fight ...' The tramwaymen struck and won, and henceforth that first Federation of Labour became known as the Red Federation and its leaders as Red Feds. (May 20, 1988,Dominion,8) [NOTES: (W. P. Reeves)]

SOLJAK In contrast to the Federation of Labor [sic], which a hostile press had labelled the `Red Fed,' the Labor party aimed to achieve public ownership ... gradually and by purely political measures. (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),60)

DAVIN Who cares if he is a red-fed? I've gone a bit bolshy myself after some of the balls ups I've seen out here. Ibid. 138-139 I was like you myself once, a bit of a redfed. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,102)

128 The cow was mad, Gil thought. Only a madman would want to go to a war unless he had to. These redfeds were always thinking about killing someone; ... Ibid. 152 That crazy young redfed, .... who landed himself in trouble over at the works with his gabbing and got the boot. (1948,Cunninghams, The,1976)

I have always prided myself on my British descent and our fair play and am not a Red-fed, but I admire the natives for kicking over the traces and striking on this account. (Mar 9, 1959,Christchurch Star,2)

HILLIARD `Thirty bob? ... Is that all your dolie old man can afford, thirty bob?' ... to the well-off it seemed that all who worked for wages [in the 1930s] were dolies or red-feds, whatever that was. (1965,Power of Joy,213)

) Look what happened to the Russians when they tried to do without churches - turned into a mob of worthless red-feds. (1966,NZ Short Stories,50,1976 ed.) [NOTES: Grenfell `Old Tolly']

SARGESON (1969,Joy of the Worm,134)

DAVIN (1970,Not Here, Not Now,280)

SINCLAIR & HARREX It took the 'Red Feds' some years to realize the irrelevance of such a doctrine [sc. workers taking over industry] in a country where the biggest factories were the railway workshops and where large-scale urban industries did not exist. (1978,Looking Back,169)

FARRELL Nancy-boy Gilchrest who was of the opinion that the country's salvation had lain with Campbell Begg not some ex-Red Fed. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,58)

Red Federal¶

n. a member of the RED FEDERATION (infrequent usage; ? coined by Evening Post)

Messrs. Semple, Hickey, Fraser and other leading Red Federals. (Jan 17, 1914,Evening Post,9)

Red Federalism¶

n. (historical) the policies and beliefs of the RED FEDERATION

Two years ago Red Federalism concentrated itself in what it called "the industrial field." (Nov 10, 1913,Evening Post,6)

The creed of Red Federalism. (Jan 17, 1914,Evening Post,9)

Red Federation¶

n. (historical)

On the West Coast the miners Federation changed its name to New Zealand Federation of Labour (soon known as the red Federation, or simply the Red Fed) and sent out organisers to win support from other unions. (1993,Wharfie,p28)

HICKEY ... I issued a circular, stating that the Federation would stand behind the tramwaymen in any action that they might take. I had no authority whatever for issuing the circular, and in looking back on that time now, can only account for my impetuous action through my anger at the contempt displayed towards organised Labour by the City Council and the press. The leaflet (which happened to be printed on red paper, this giving the idea to the Evening Post' [in early 1912] that was responsible for the coining of the termRed Federation,' which was afterwards abbreviated to `Red Fed.') caused a wave of militancy to sweep through the tramway service, and a meeting was called for the p.m. shift the following day. (1925,Red Fed. Memoirs,48)

MORRELL & HALL A conference in 1910 with the Dominion Exective of the Trades and Labour Councils failed to achieve unity, and next year the Councils brought their own Federation into being. In the competition for support which followed, the militant Federation, which its opponents nicknamed the `Red Federation', had valuable assets in the eloquence of its leaders and the propaganda of its organ The Maoriland Worker. (1957,History of NZ Life, A,207)

SINCLAIR In 1908 there was a local strike [on the West Coast] and shortly afterwards the miners formed a Federation of Labour to which, within a few years, were affiliated most of the miners and water side workers. The 1912 constitution of the `Red Federation' began with the preamble of the IWW ... (1959,History of New Zealand,198)

Red Federationist¶

n. (historical)

There is a diversity that doth hedge a "strike" is practically the doctrine of some of the Red Federationists. (Sep 16, 1912,Evening Post,6)

Red Fedism¶

n.

Red Fedism hasn't a hope in rural New Zealand. (Sep 1, 1920,NZ Free Lance,6)

[Hdg] Red Fedism. Akin to Prussianism... Professor J. Macmillan Brown... contended that the ideals of the I.W.W. and the Red Fed element resembled, in many cases, the Prussianism against which we were fighting. (Apr 18, 1917,Wanganui Herald,23)

That Sir Joseph Ward appears to realise that the strike is going to have its effect upon the general election is evident from a statement which he has made to the Ashburton "Guardian." "Farmers in the North Island," he said, "were giving their whole-hearted support to the Liberals, and although the Prime Minister was endeavouring to make party capital out of 'Red-Fedism,' the farmers had not forgotten that the Government had helped to secure the return of active supporters of the Red-Fed. movement." (Nov 23, 1914,Grey River Argus,5)

GLOVER There was one defender of freedom in those dark days [1930] when many ... a student was being hauled across the coals for radicalism, Communism, red-fedism, and all sorts of other nonsense. (1962,Hot Water Sailor,93,1981 ed.)

red gum¶

n.

HOWARD Some of the timber trees are of large growth, particularly three sorts; the first is of the pine tribe and is known by the name of Pimise (Pinus??) in three varieties on the north. The second is something like the Lucombe Oack, and the third is called the Red Gum or Eucalipticus I have seen it in England. ... The three varieties of pine are very tall and handsome, and one in appearance like the Lucombe oak grows tall but not so straight, the Eucalipticy grows to a great thickeness in the stem and frequently not less than fifteen feet in girt but not more than 15 or 20 feet in height before it spreads its large branches in every direction, ... (1940,Rakiura,356) [NOTES: 1826 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 356]

red gurnard¶

n. Chelidonichthys (Currupiscis) kumu, (common) gurnard, =kumukumu.

MORELAND RED GURNARD [Trigla kumu] ... Other names are gurnard, common gurnard, and the Maori kumu-kumu. (1967,Marine Fishes,28)

DOOGUE & MORELAND RED GURNARD ... Other names: Chelidonichthys kumu; gurnard, common gurnard; kumukumu (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,291)

PARROTT Red Gurnard Currupiscis kumu N.Z. Gurnard (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,169)

FORSTER We found they had hauled in the Sein in the Indian Cove & got some Mullets, (Mugil albula), some red Gurnards (Trigla Cuculus) [[ed. fn] Probably the kumukumu (Chelidonichthys kumu).] & one new Stargazer (Uranoscopus) [[ed. fn] Uranoscopus maculatus of Descr. Anim., p.118 ...], which we described & drew. (Apr 21, 1777,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/263)

HECTOR 42. GURNARD. ... The Red Gurnard or Kumukumu (Trigla kumu) is very abundant during the summer months in the harbours in the north, ... (1872,Edible Fishes,113)

SHERRIN GURNARD (Trigla kumu). ... [37] The red gurnard, or kumukumu, is very abundant during the summer months in the harbours of the North, ... (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,36)

Chelidonichthys Kumu ... Red Gurnard. (1911,Records of the Canterbury Museum,1/352) [NOTES: Waite]

Chelidonichthys kumu Lesson and Garnot. The red gurnard is named Trigla kumu in the original list. (1913,TrNZI,45/230) [NOTES: (Thomson, Otago)]

CHELIDONICHTHYS KUMU (Lesson and Garnot). Red Gurnard; Kumukumu. Commonly secured by trawlers up to 40 fathoms. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts (rarer in the south). (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,IV/122) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Chelidonichthys kumu (Lesson and Garnot). RED GURNARD; KUMUKUMU. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,54,1971 ed.)

SPEIGHT et al. The common Red Gurnard (Chelidonichthys kumu) and the larger, but less common Spotted Gurnard (Pterygotrigla picta) are mail-cheek' fishes (order SCLEROPAREI), which are perch-like in all but that the head and the gill-covers are strongly armoured and freely studded with strong spines. <i>(1927,Natural History of Canterbury,201</i>) [NOTES: ArcheyNative Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury]

48.Chelidonichthys kumu Lesson and Garnot. Red Gurnard. Maori: Kumukumu (1929,TrNZI,61/149) [NOTES: Young]

Chelidonichthys kumu: Gurnard or red gurnard. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,72)

Chelidonichthys kumu (Lesson and Garnot). Red gurnard. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/417) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

POWELL RED GURNARD (Chelidonichthys kumu), Kumukumu of the Maoris, is easily recognised by its parchment-like side fins which resemble wings, and curious finger-like processes associated with these fins. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,72)

GRAHAM RED GURNARD (KUMUKUMU) Currupiscis kumu (Lesson) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,359,2nd ed.)

PARROTT THE RED GURNARD Currupiscis kumu (Lesson) ... Maori name: KUMUKUMU. Ibid. 169 Red Gurnard Currupiscis kumu N.Z. Gurnard (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,167)

McLINTOCK Red gurnard .. .. kumu, kumukumu .. .. Chelidonichthys kumu (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705)

DOOGUE & MORELAND RED GURNARD ... Other names: Chelidonichthys kumu; gurnard, common gurnard; kumukumu (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,291)

NATUSCH Family TRIGLIDAE. The handsome gurnards belong to this group ... Only the red gurnard is really common - a beautiful fish, with its pectoral fins coloured and burnished like great, filmy butterfly wings. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,231)

MORELAND RED GURNARD [Trigla kumu] ... Other names are gurnard, common gurnard, and the Maori kumu-kumu. (1967,Marine Fishes,28)

BURTON [Title] Gurnard (kumukumu) Easily recognised by its large side wings, the red gurnard occurs in most parts of New Zealand except the extreme south. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,75)

AYLING RED GURNARD Chelidonichthys kumu (1982,Collins Guide,197,1984 ed.)

[species name] gurnard .. [scientific name] Chelidonichthys kumu .. [other name(s)] red gurnard, latchett [sic], N.Z. latchett (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Gurnards ... They are good at producing sound and may grunt when captured. New Zealand has five species. Red gurnard Chelidonichthys kumu ... Often simply called gurnard, being the commonest species seen in New Zealand. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,80)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] gurnard, red 1200-25 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

RED HOROPITO/ (Red Pepper Tree)/ Pseudowintera colorata/ Small tree up to 3m. Branchlets and leaf stalks reddish. Leaves ... blotched with red. (1982,Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs,5)

Red katipo occupy the remainder of the country, with the exception of the deep south, but there is some overlap. (May 2005,NZ Geographic,No 73 / 11)

red knee¶

n.

HENDERSON We new arrivals [in Egypt] are known as red arses',red knees', `red necks'. Hawkers, beggars, touts, small mischievous boys or wallids, discern this and our hesitant demeanour instantly, and swoop like shite-hawks. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,260)

red kowhai¶

n. kaka-beak (See kaka-beak,kowhai ngutukaka)

LAING & BLACKWELL Clianthus puniceus (The Scarlet Clianthus)... This tree [shrub] is known as the Red Kowhai, Parrot's Bill, or Kaka's Beak Native name Kowhai-ngutu-kaka, signifying the Parrot-beaked kowhai. It is also called in the Urewera Country Ngutu-Kakariki, the Parroquet's Beak. (1907,Plants of NZ,210,1940, p. 221 ed.)

BRACKEN Clianthus puniceus (1884,Lays and Rhymes,21) [NOTES: (Morris)]

CHEESEMAN [Clianthus puniceus] Kowhai-ngutu-kaka. ... it is now commonly cultivated in gardens throughout the colony under the name of `red kowhai'. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,121)

LANG & BLACKWELL Clianthus puniceus (The Scarlet Clianthus)... This tree [shrub] is known as the Red Kowhai, Parrot's Bill, or Kaka's Beak Native name Kowhai-ngutu-kaka, signifying the Parrot-beaked kowhai. It is also called in the Urewera Country Ngutu-Kakariki, the Parroquet's Beak. (1907,Plants of NZ,210,1940 p. 221 ed.)

COCKAYNE (And) Clianthus puniceus (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

MATTHEWS Clianthus (Red Kowhai, Parrot's Beak or Kaka Beak) (1943,NZ Gardening Dictionary, The,43)

red light¶

1 n. (Rural) a warning call for shearers of an approach of a female[and the need for polite language.] (See sixty-nine)

PORTER I [Grace Porter] used to wonder why the boys called out `Red Light' as I approached the shed ... and later found it was their signal to stop all flowery language. (1970,Nor'west Arch,29)

red louse¶

1 n. (Rural) Damalinia ovis, a body or wool louse common in sheep.

STEVENS There are several species of lice found on sheep, but those which occur in New Zealand are: 1) the red louse or body louse, or wool louse (Damalinia ovis) [body louse; wool louse] (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,83)

red manuka¶

n. usu. (if the colour adjective is used) Leptospermum scoparium, and having a reddish wood and underbark, and perhaps redder flowers than white manuka; cf also manuka

Red manuka (Leptocpermum scoparium) becomes co-dominant with the [L. ericoides]. (1936,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,17/724)

WILLIAMS Kahikatoa, ... leptospermum scoparium, a tree = red manuka. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,83)

The insect is found associated with both red manuka (Leptospermum scoparium) and white manuka or kanuka (Leptospermum ericoides). (Oct 1959,Tararua Tramper,7)

red manuka [=] manuka [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,63)

DAVIES Red manuka is heavy wood ... (1975,Outback,75)

BROOKER et al. Leptospermum scoparium J.R.& G.Forst. Common names: Tea tree, red manuka Maori names: Manuka, kahikatoa Leptospermum ericoides A.Rich. Common names: Tree manuka, white manuka Maori name: Kanuka (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,71)

Leptospermum scoparium red manuka (1877,TrNZI) [NOTES: (And)]

MATTHEWS Leptospermum ericoides red-manuka (1905,Tree Culture in NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

TANNOCK The popularity of native plants has increased greatly since the red manuka (Leptospermum Nichollii) received the gold medal ... at the International Horticultural Exhibition ... a few years ago (1921,Manual of Gardening,135)

Manuka. Red or stunted manuka. (Leptospermum scoparium)... Inadequate **** (1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60/5)

red mapau¶

n. Myrsine australis [ca1935 Havelock Marlborough (Red Matipo)]

Red Mapau (Myrsine Urvillei). A small tree common at Dunedin. Trunk 6-13 inches diameter. Wood dark-red, very astringent, used as fence stuff, but subject to the attack of a boring beetle. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/37) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

DOMETT Rapanea Urvillei red mapau (1872,Ranolf and Amohia) [NOTES: (Andersen)]

(1872,Catalogue of the Colonial and Vienna Exhibition) [NOTES: (And)]

Rapanea Urvillei red mapau (1875,Durability NZ Timbers) [NOTES: (And)]
