red matipo¶

n. M. australis [ca1935 Marlborough.]

Broadleaf, five-fingered Jack, (Panax arboreum) lacebark, matipo, red matipo, New Zealand coffee, titoki or native ash. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,184)

WILSON Myrsine australis RED MAAPOU ...Matipou ... Small tree, sometimes reduced to a shrub. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,104)

Rapanea Urvillei red matipo (1878,NZ Country Journal) [NOTES: (And)]

Broadleaf [fn Griselinia littoralis,.. matipo [fn Pittosporum.], red matipo [fn Myrsine urvillei.], .. and the totara pine [fn Podocarpus totara.] jostle one another in the dense dry bush. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,184)

Rapanea Urvillei red matipo (1907,AJHR) [NOTES: (And) Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island]

Rapanea Urvillei red matipo (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: (And) Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

LAING & BLACKWELL [Suttonia australis (The Red Matipo)] ... Native name Mapau, Mapou, or Matipo. The name Matipo is generally applied by Europeans to Pittosporum tenuifolium, but this is apparently the plant to which the Maoris attached it. This tree bears some resemblance to Pittosporum tenuifolium, but can be readily distinguished by the reddish colour of the leaves. [Rapanea Urvillei, 1907] (1907,Plants of NZ,332,1940 p. 353 ed.)

STUDHOLME In this bush were ... Ohau, (panax or five-finger), ini-ini (whitey wood); konini, white and red matipo; koromiko and other shrubs. (1940,Te Waimate,246,1954 ed.)

red mistletoe¶

n. Elytranthe tetrapetala

Two small red mistletoe plants, pikirangi (Peraxilla tetrapetala) have established on black beech and.. look set to continue thriving... The red mistletoe growing at Otari-Wilton's Bush is from fruit collected and dispersed, not by a bird, but by a mistletoe enthusiast from plants growing on his Eastbourne property. (Oct 9, 2004,Dominion Post,E15)

Red mistletoe which produces masses of red or orange-yellow flowers in summer has been found in the Tararua and Rimutaka ranges while the two dwarf varieties are most common in the Wairarapa. (Nov 29, 2001,Contact (Wgtn),17)

COCKAYNE Elytranthe tetrapetala red mistletoe (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

Today, only a few dozen stands of red mistletoe endure in this vast area, and each stand supports only a handful of plants. (Sep 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 59/82)

red moki¶

n. Cheilodactylus spectabilis, nanua

4/115 LATRIDOPSIS AEROSA (Hutton). Red Moki. ... Known only from the waters of the South Island. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Chironemus spectabilis Hutton. RED MOKI; NANUA. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,38,1971 ed.)

Chironemus spectabilis Hutton. Red moki. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/411) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM RED MOKI (NANUA) Chironemus spectabilis Hutton (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,253)

PARROTT THE RED MOKI Chironemus spectabilis (Hutton) ... Maori name: NANUA ... This is a northern species and is common around the Northern coasts of the North Island, and occurs rarely south of the Bay of Plenty. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,118)

GRAHAM Red Moki Cheilodactylus spectabilis Hutton (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,408) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 408]

DOOGUE & MORELAND RED MOKI ... Other names: Chironemus spectabilis; banded morwong (Australia); nanua (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,251)

McLINTOCK Moki, red .. .. nanua .. .. Chironemus spectabilis (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

MORELAND RED MOKI [Chironemus spectabilis ] ... known as banded morwong in Australia and by the Maori name nanua in some of New Zealand's northern areas. (1967,Marine Fishes,40)

NATUSCH The red moki or nanua, C. spectabilis, red above, orange below, increases north of Cook Strait. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,222)

SORENSON The Red Moki (Chironemus spectabilis ), although not closely related to [Moki], is lumped for purposes of convenience with Moki. It is most abundant north of East Cape, but reaches Cook Strait in moderate numbers during summer months. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,37)

PAUL Red moki Cheilodactylus spectabilis Also occurs in southern Australia, where it is known as banded morwong. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,104)

[species name] red moki .. [scientific name] Cheilodactylus spectabilis .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

AYLING RED MOKI (Banded morwong, nanua) Cheilodactylus spectabilis ... Coloration of the red moki is particularly distinctive with eight red-brown vertical stripes on the body and fins ... (1982,Collins Guide,243,1984 Alpers ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] moki, red 1571-83, 1606 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

red mullet¶

n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] mullet, red 1474-86 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

AYLING GOATFISH Upeneichthys lineatus (Upeneichthys porosus) (Red mullet, ahuruhuru) ... A steeply sloping forehead ends in a small downward facing mouth and beneath the chin are a pair of conspicuous long barbels. (1982,Collins Guide,225,1984 ed.)

red neck¶

n. [(WW2)]

HENDERSON We new arrivals [in Egypt] are known as red arses',red knees', `red necks'. Hawkers, beggars, touts, small mischievous boys or wallids, discern this and our hesitant demeanour instantly, and swoop like shite-hawks. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,260)

red Ned¶

n. strong drink [(I have never heard this. HWO)]

BAKER ... such terms for strong drink as lunatic soap, Africa speaks, plonk, steam, red Ned. [Shared with Australia] (1941,NZ Slang,62)

Red ned. Also in New Zealand. (B. 1941). (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1152)

red ochre¶

n. kokowai

MOSER The low eaved huts with their deep gables smeared with kokowai (red ochre), ... (1863,Mahoe Leaves,5)

ANGAS The whole of this carved wah was painted red, with an ochre, called `kokowai.' (1866,Polynesia,154)

BEATTIE Another of my early recollections of Matannic is that I used to see lying around great lumps of what was called red ochre. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,62)

red parrotfish¶

n.

WILLIAMS Puwaiwhakarua, ... Pseudolabrus coccineus, red parrot-fish; when caught considered a sign that a north-west wind will blow. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,1957,318 ed.)

red pepper tree¶

phr. aka RED HOROPITO Pseudowintera colorata

RED HOROPITO/ (Red Pepper Tree)/ Pseudowintera colorata/ Small tree up to 3m. Branchlets and leaf stalks reddish. Leaves ... blotched with red. (1982,Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs,5)

red perch¶

n. Alternative name for the butterfly perch; brightly and variably coloured; common around northern NZ. [Caesioperca lepidoptera aka butterfly perch, red snapper, St. Peter's Fish, or bastard long-fin'] (See butterfly perch)

[species name] alfonsino .. [scientific name] Beryx splendens .. [other name(s)] red perch (name used by Sealord (Nelson)) (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PARROTT The Red Perch, as is the case with many of our common fishes, has received many popular names. .../ It is also known as the Red Snapper',St. Peter's Fish' or Butterfly erch'. It probably received the name ofSt. Peter's Fish' on account of the two black marks, one on each side of the body, which suggest the thumb/and finger marks of St. Peter, as I have previously explained in the case of the John Dory. ... One of the popular names in Australia for [Red Perch] is `Butterfly Perch', so called from its specific name Lepidoptera. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,73)

MORELAND BUTTERFLY PERCH [Caesioperca lepidoptera] ... Other names are red perch when this colour predominates. (1967,Marine Fishes,38)

DOOGUE & MORELAND BUTTERFLY PERCH ... Other names: Caesioperca lepidoptera; red perch; oia (Maori). The name red perch is better reserved for another species, particularly as butterfly perch has been in common usage for many years. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,228)

McLINTOCK Butterfly perch .. .. oia .. .. Caesioperca lepidoptera (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

PAUL Butterfly perch Caesioperca lepidoptera New Zealand and southern Australia. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,84)

PERCH, MAGPIE (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] perch, magpie 1571-90 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

AYLING BUTTERFLY PERCH (Oia) Caesioperca lepidoptera (1982,Collins Guide,207,1984 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] perch, butterfly [TS] 1260 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] perch, red 1260 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

CAESIOPERCA LEPIDOPTERA (Forster). Red Perch. Called red snapper' orSt. Peter's fish' in Queen Charlotte and Pelorus Sounds, where it is occasionally taken in the seine net during July and August. ... Distribution North Iisland coasts and northern coasts of the South Island. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/115) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Caesioperca lepidoptera (Forster). RED PERCH; OIA. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,33,1971 ed.)

Caesioperca lepidoptera (Forster). Red perch. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/410) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM Red Perch Caesioperca lepidoptera(Bloch and Schn.) (Syn. Scorpis hectori Hutton) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,406) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 406]

GRAHAM RED PERCH (OIA) Caesioperca lepidoptera(Bloch and Schneider) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,233)

PARROTT THE RED PERCH Caesioperca lepidoptera(Bloch & Schneider)... Maori name: OIA. Ibid. 73 The Red Perch, as is the case with many of our common fishes, has received many popular names. It is known in Australia as the Bastard Long-fin', a name probably associated with its long dorsal fin. It is also known as theRed Snapper', St. Peter's Fish' orButterfly Perch'. It probably received the name of `St. Peter's Fish' on account of the two black marks, one on each side of the body, which suggest the thumb/and finger marks of St. Peter, as I have previously explained in the case of the John Dory. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,72)

WILLIAMS Oia, ... Caesioperca lepidoptera, red perch, a fish. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,238)

DOOGUE & MORELAND BUTTERFLY PERCH ... Other names: Caesioperca lepidoptera; red perch; oia (Maori). The name red perch is better reserved for another species, particularly as butterfly perch has been in common usage for many years. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,228)

MORELAND [=BUTTERFLY PERCH] BUTTERFLY PERCH [Caesioperca lepidoptera] ... Other names are red perch when this colour predominates. (1967,Marine Fishes,38)

[species name] butterfly perch .. [scientific name] Caesioperca lepidoptera.. [other name(s)] red perch (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

red pine¶

n. (obsolete) [either totara or matai (black pine) 1844, (1898) Hocken Contributions, 1869 TrNZI, 1889 KFF (Andersen) (c) (rare) P.totara, =TOTARA]

HAY The Matai, or `Red Pine' (Podocarpus spicata), needs special mention. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/194)

red pine n 3 a : RIMU b : a black pine (Podocarpus spicata) of New Zealand (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1904)

POLACK There is scarcely a more splendid sight to behold than a New Zealand forest. In the one we now entered, we did not perceive any kouri, or yellow pine-trees; but the totara [a's-acute], or red pine, grew in vast abundance. ... The rito, and innumerable other palm-trees, were in great quantity. Ibid. 2/391 Totara [a's-acute] (taxus australis) g. coniferae ... is known as red pine. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/105)

MONRO In the woods [near Molyneux Bay, Otago] there are not many red and white pines, but a large proportion of rima. (1844,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner [=totara in contrast to `rima'] July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 249]

Polack .. the most superior [canoes] are to be found at Wairoa, (Hawkes' Bay) the tribes at that place employ the totarra or red pine, the kouri or white pine being rarely found beyond the Thames (Horake). (1840,Mangamaire School,1/227)

On drier ground [in Marlborough Sounds] he would find the Mai or Red Pine (Podocarpus spicata) ... festooned with parasites. Ibid. 12 In an economic point of view, the chief trees of the Middle Island, are the Red and White Pine, respectively called by the Maoris: the former Mai or Matai (Podicarpus spicata),[fn] the latter the Kahikatea (Podocarpus dacrydioides)[ed. fn] Black Rue of Otago, Hook., f.; Miro, Black Rue or Black Pine in Otago, Hector; Miro, often confounded with Black Pine, Balfour; Matai, Colenso, - Mai or Matai (Taylor). (1869,TrNZI,1/ii/10) [NOTES: (Monro)]

1 n. rimu, used instead of rimu in very early days of the North Island settlements probably before European settlers became accustomed to the Maori word: ?esp. a bushmen's use; occas. used as a descriptive generic (from colour of wood) for other genera and species; (In New Zealand) - Dacrydium cupressinum, Soland; called also Rimu(q.v.). ... [Rimu has replaced Red-pine in the North Island and in Marlborough, Nelson and Westland; in Canterbury and Otago (and to some extent Westland) the timber has up to fairly recently always, and the tree chiefly, been Red-pine, although <i>Rimu</i>' was by no means unknown, and by 1984 had generally replaced <i>Red-pine</i> except perhaps in the South South Island. ca1952 DunedinIt's built out of red-pine; you know, timber from a rimu-tree'. ca1952 Hollyford Valley Red-pine (the tree), never rimu ; (In Australia) - Frenela endlicheri, Parlat.]

Mr. M'Gruer prides himself a good deal on the specimen of the rimu or red pine ( Dacrydium cupressinum ) which he had transplanted from the bush, and which is a plant very difficult to start. (May 27, 1871,Otago Witness,5)

The upward movement with regard to red pine began at Southland, due, it is said, to the increased difficulty of procuring that sort of timber. (Jun 22, 1912,Poverty Bay Herald,3)

The ceiling and structural timbers are of specially selected figured red pine and oiled, a dado of oiled oregon covers the bottom half of the walls, the top half of the brick wall being painted cream. (Feb 28, 1928,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3)

26 Rimu (red pine) figured slab. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,16) [NOTES: 1890 PWD Catalogue of Timbers : NZ and South Seas Exhibition Vol / Page 16]

McDONALD Q. Are there many harbours there [on the west side of New Zealand]? A. Several ... All covered with wood Q. Of what sort? A. Of white and red pine and a wood called black oak'. Q. Is it of the species calledkaikatua'? A. It is. Q. Did you see any of the species called `cowrie'? A. I did not. Ibid. 1/560 Q. Whereabouts do the red and white pine trees grow? A. The white pine grows in wet swampy places. The red pine grows on the sides of hills. Q. Is the red pine like the cowrie? A. It is the same grain, but not the same color. (May 1821,Evidence of McDonald before Commissioner Bigge) [NOTES: 1821 May Evidence of McDonald before Commissioner Bigge in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/559]

Walked about it [sc. Peel Forest], fine totaras, white and red pines: ... (Mar 28, 1849,Torlesse Papers,70,1958 ed.)

DIEFFENBACH [Rimu] which sawyers call red pine (1841,NZ Journal,2/29/51)

The red pine is splendid timber for furniture, it is like mahogany. (Feb 10, 1842,Letters from New Plymouth,1843 ed.) [NOTES: (1842 Feb 10) 1843 (1968) Letters from New Plymouth 4]

Red pine (1847,McLean Papers,4/67)

Dacrydium cupresssinum (1848,NZ Journal) [NOTES: (And)]

Went to Gurdon [Peel] Forest ... Walked about it, fine totaras, white and red pines. (Mar 28, 1849,Torlesse Papers,70,1958 ed.)

(Jul 10, 1850,Papers & Proc. RS Van Diemen's Land) [NOTES: (And)Collinson Timber Trees of NZ]

TORLESSE Kaikatea, (white pine), mahi, black pine, remu, (red pine) (1851,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,6)

The timber in [the groves] is chiefly Kaikatea, (white pine), Mahi, (black pine), Remu, (red pine), Pokaka, Kowai, and Totara. ... That in the other forest [ie. not Harewood or Alford] is principally tawai, (black birch), the best timber for boat and ship building, but sometimes unsound: ... (Jun 28, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

[Taranaki] Artistic James ... wants to preserve a magnificent red pine ... that a good burn would probably have killed. (Feb 19, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/143) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

HURSTHOUSE (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles)) [NOTES: (And)]

THOMSON Dacrydium cupresssinum red-pine (1906,Introductory Classbook of Botany) [NOTES: (And)]

Dacrydium cupresssinum red-pine (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: (And) Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest]

Dacrydium cupresssinum red-pine (1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: 1909 Turner Botanical Examination of the Higher Waimarino District]

Dacrydium cupresssinum red-pine (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology) [NOTES: (And)]

BEATTIE Rimu is the red pine, and for the miro I never heard an English name. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,13)

The chief indigenous trees of commercial value are: Kauri (Agathis Australis), Kahikatea or white pine (Podocarpus dacrydioides), rimu or red pine (Dacrydium cupresssinum ), totara (Podocarpus totara and Podocarpus Hallii), Miro (Podocarpus ferrugineus), Kaikawaka or mountain cedar (Libocedrus Bidwilli), yellow pine or silver pine (Dacrydium Colensoi and D. intermedium), red and hard beech (Nothofagus fasca and Nothofagus truncata), silver beech (Nothofagus Menziesii), black beech (Nothofagus Solandri), black maire (Olea Cunninghamii), northern and southern rata (Metrosideros robusta and Metrosideros lucida). (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,578)

ANDERSEN The rimu is a rakau rangatira, once called a red pine, a name now seldom used. (1942,Maori Place Names,287)

red pine n 3 a : RIMU b : a black pine (Podocarpus spicata) of New Zealand (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1904)

McLINTOCK The European name for rimu, especially in the South Island, is red pine. Ibid.. 3/705-12 Pine, red .. .. rimu .. .. Dacrydium cupresssinum (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/85)

MOORE & IRWIN DACRYDIUM CUPRESSINUM, rimu, red pine. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,208)

McGILL Ruatapu has a sawmill, New Forest has, appropriately, red pine for prefabs ... Maimai is logs, Reefton coal. (1985,G'day Country,149)

BROOKER et al. Dacrydium cupressinum Lamb. Common name: Red pine Maori name: Rimu (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,31)

WILSON Dacrydium cupresssinum RIMU ... Red pine (1982,Stewart Island Plants,48)

red pine NZ = RIMU. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,636) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 409]]

HEAPHY The red pines are the Totara, Towa, Mahi, and Rata, all of which are close-grained and moderately hard. ... They are all of a red colour, and when oiled and polished are very ornamental. (1842,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,42)

POLACK These boxes are cut from red pine ... A stone adze was once shown to us whose carved handles had been destroyed in a succession of fires. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/229)

Hope you like the tree. "Dacrydium cupressinum," blathers the tag, before continuing in plain English, "Rimu, Red pine. Excellent specimen tree with pendulous branchlets when young. Prefers rich moist soil. Bird attracting seed. Slow growing." (Jun 25, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

The Committee recommends the disuse of the terms red-pine',white-pine', and `black-pine', in favour of rimu, kahikatea and matai, in order to prevent their being confused with timbers having similar names in Europe. (Jul 17, 1896,AJHR,H-24) [NOTES: Interim Report No. 3 (i) of Timber Conference]

North Island Red-pine District. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,118)

CHEESEMAN D[acrydium] cupressinum, Soland. ... Rimu; Red-pine. ... The wood is deep-red, strong, hard, and heavy, but often twisted in grain. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,654)

The timber on the western side consists of red- and white-pine, matai (or black-pine), totara, kawhaka (or cedar), rata, and occasional silver-pine, besides black- and red-birch (Fagus fusca). (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,19)

MATTHEW Dacrydium cupresssinum red-pine (1905,Tree Culture in NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

... sawing up Rimu, that is Red Pine. (Sep 1, 1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,45,1914 ed.) [NOTES: 1857 Sep 1 Harper Letters from Canterbury (1914]

In the decoration of the [Otago Horticultural Society] show-room, the graceful young Red Pine, and the Ti and Fern Trees, ranked first among our native trees. (Jan 19, 1861,Otago Witness,5)

Here [at Taeri] was the tall and graceful black pine; the manukau, a shrub like the [Victorian] tea-tree scrub, only more greenly leaved; a few broad leaved grass-trees; the mappo, the kolu, the red pine, and others too numerous for me to remember; but their leaves were ... delightful to one accustomed to the dingy foliage of Victorian forests. (Sep 27, 1861,NZ Goldfields,23,1976 ed.) [NOTES: 1861 Sep 27 Tuapeka in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 23]

CARBERRY A large Torch is maid [sic] from the Red Pine (Remu) which will last for about 3 hours. (Feb 24, 1865,Journal)

HOCHSTETTER (1867,New Zealand (various authors/titles)) [NOTES: (list of trees from Taylor 1848) (And)]

HOCHSTETTER (1867,New Zealand (various authors/titles)) [NOTES: (list of trees from Taylor 1848) (And)]

HOOKER Pine, red. Dacrydium cupresssinum . (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

Red Pine, or Rimu ... [In <i>Botany of Otago</i>', European names precede Maori, as above; inBotany of North Island' Maori names precede European] (1869,TrNZI,1/31) [NOTES: (Botany Otago)]

PYKE (1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The) [NOTES: (And)]

PRENTICE Black, white and red pines, totara .... (1870,Tale of NZ,33) [NOTES: (Otago)]

the native name for this tree, is now tolerably well known in Otago. So if professional men and timber merchants would only encourage its use, it would soon supercede the vague conventional term of `red pine'. (1876,TrNZI,163) [NOTES: Blair Rimu]

[Native name] Rimu .. [Settlers' name] Red-pine .. [Family] Coniferae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

MUELLER (1888,Select Extra-tropical Plants) [NOTES: (And)]

Rimu (red-pine) .. Dacrydium cupressinum .. A strong, handsome, reddish coloured timber, grain beautifully marked and figured; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,14)

... terrace flats [in Westland] ... covered with Red and Black Pine, Rata and Totara .... (1892,Letter) [NOTES: 1892 Letter to Strauchan in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 175]

McGill Their wartime job was to drain .. the stunted manuka swamps Bill calls parkee (pakihis). it was once, he said, a great area for red pine, rimu, and the black pine, matai. (1985,G'day Country,156)

FOR SALE - Polished Red Pine Table, 5ft 6in. x 2ft 10in. (Aug 2, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,2)

Red Pine. Dacrydium cupressinum, Sol. (1869,TrNZI,1/iii/49)

rimu, a fine tree (Dacrydium cupressinum), red-pine; the young tree, a fountain of weeping foliage considered one of the most beautiful trees in the world. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

POLACK ... the most superior [canoes] are to be found at Wairoa, (Hawkes' Bay) the tribes at that place employ the totarra or red pine, the kouri or white pine being rarely found warm and cheery ... (1840,Mangamaire School,1/227)

Mr M'Gruer prides himself a good deal on the specimen of the rimu or red pine ( Dacrydium cupressinum ) which he had transplanted from the bush and which is a plant very difficult to start. (May 27, 1871,Otago Witness,5)

TUCKETT [?rimu] I observed a fine stream of water, and the wood with abundance of timber - the red pine, or, as it is here [Otago, Tuckett had come from ?Nelson] called, the black ... throughout the district. (Apr 19, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: 1844 Apr 19 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 208]

red piripiri¶

n. Acaena novae-zelandiae [Botany.]

KIRK Acaena novae-zelandiae red piripiri (1899,Students' Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

red rock cod¶

n. a scorpionfish Scorpaena cardinalis.

SCORPAENA CARDINALIS Richardson. Red Rock-cod; Matuawhapuku. Very common throughout the year in rocky localities around North Auckland Peninsula, but not greatly utilized as a food fish. Distribution: A northern species; occasionally seen on the northern and western coasts of the South Island. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/121) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Scorpaena cruenta Richardson. RED ROCK-COD; MATUAWHAPUKU. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,53,1971 ed.)

Scorpaena cruenta Richardson. Red rock cod. (Australia) (1938,TrRSNZ,68/417) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

WILLIAMS Matuawhapuku, n. Scorpaena cruenta, red rock cod. = rarai. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,195)

PARROTT THE RED ROCK COD Ruboralga cardinalis (Richardson) ... The Red Rock Cod is a fairly common fish in the North Island but becomes less plentiful in southern waters. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,163)

The scorpion fish, variously known as red rock cod, grandfather hapuku, Jock McKenzie or scarpee is not good to eat and its spines are capable of inflicting painful cuts. (Aug 20, 1965,Evening Post,29)

AYLING SCORPION FISH Scorpaena cardinalis (Grandfather hapuku, red rock cod, pahuiakaroa) ... [196] They are basically red in colour ... (1982,Collins Guide,195,1984 ed.)

PAUL There is another very similar [to red scorpionfish] but more variably mottled species, S[corpaena] cardinalis, the red rock cod, in northern New Zealand; it can reach 40 cm, and is often called grandfather hapuku. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,79)

red rock daisy¶

n. Pachystegia rufa

[caption] The red rock daisy, Pachystegia rufa (Mar 2005,Open Space,No 63)

red rock lobster¶

n. Jasus edwardsii

PAUL Red rock lobster Jasus edwardsii ... Closely related to J. novaehollandiae of southern Australia and J. lalandii of South Africa ... Crayfish' has been regularly used as a common name, although it is more properly applied to freshwater species. Some combination ofred', spiny', androck lobster' is more appropriate. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,150)

red rover¶

n. a children's game

THOMSON Others wanted [to play] Prisoners' Base' or Chivvy',Brewer', Egg-in-the hat',Duck-stone', Red Rover', orKingy-seeny'. The boys did not know where this east game came from. They did not know its proper spelling or pronunciation. `Kingy-Seeny' it was to them and they did not care whether that had a meaning or not. This rough and tumble game was the most popular of all. (1905,Bush Boys of NZ,84)

Red Shed¶

n. a Warehouse retail building; the Warehouse company as a whole

Red Shed raises advertising stakes (Aug 3, 2005,NZ Herald,A3) [NOTES: headline]

[heading] DDB wins 'red sheds' (Jul 7, 2005,NZ Herald,C4)

"I was disappointed with the New Zealand red sheds, but in terms of Australia they were spot on."... The red sheds, the New Zealand retail stores, posted a 3.2 per cent increase in overall sales... (Feb 6, 2003,Dominion Post,C1)

Cast like some damp, ugly devil into a vast sea of car parking, it was no place for the living - and certainly few enough had gathered inside the centre's enormous red shed, the Warehouse, for the imminent arrival of rugby league legend Stacey Jones. (Jul 6, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52)

The last building proposed for the site is the most contentious. Three words: Big Red Shed. (Apr 24, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

The company said yesterday that it had taken the first steps towards obtaining a liquor licence for a Tauranga "red shed". (Nov 4, 2005,NZ Herald,C1)

This [increase in sales] would have helped it boost margins, particularly from its "red shed" stores, an analyst said yesterday. (Sep 5, 2002,Dominion Post,C2)

The Warehouse has three core businesses - The Warehouse New Zealand or "red shed" stores, The Warehouse Stationery referred to as the "blue sheds", and The Warehouse Australia called the "yellow sheds". (Sep 7, 2002,Dominion Post,C1)

Sales at The Warehouse's Te Rapa "laboratory" store were the strongest of all 85 Red Sheds since its July opening, Mr Morrice told November's annual meeting. (Mar 11, 2006,Dominion Post,C4)

Sales from the Warehouse's "red shed" stores in New Zealand rose a modest 3.9 per cent... Sales in the red sheds were "artificially depressed" because it had "massive sales in the same quarter last year to get rid of excess stock... Mr Muir expected red shed sales to bounce back in the next quarter. (Aug 8, 2002,Dominion Post,C1)

red snapper¶

n.

[species name] red snapper .. [scientific name] Centroberyx affinis .. [other name(s)] golden snapper, nannygai, redfish (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

There's also a red snapper, sometimes known as golden snapper, sometimes available in Auckland. Despite the name, it is quite unrelated to the true snapper and is, in fact, more similar to the roughys. The Australian snapper is the same as ours. (Aug 1986,Metro,148)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] snapper, red 1020-1, 1307 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

HECTOR RED SNAPPER ... (Scorpis Hectori ). This is described as a new species by Captain Hutton, and is not unfrequently caught in the sands on the west coast of Otago, ... (1872,Edible Fishes,106)

SHERRIN RED SCHNAPPER (Anthias Richardsoni ). ... The red schnapper belongs to the same family as the hapuku and kahawai, the Percidae. ... [84] It is generally called the red schnapper by seamen who are acquainted with the fish of the coast, the colour being a uniform bright red, ... (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,83)

The following is a list of the fishes which are chiefly met with in the market: hapuku, kahawai, red-snapper, snapper, tarakihi, moki, trumpeter, frostfish ... gurnard, mullet, sea-mullet, ... flounder or patiki, ... grayling, smelt, kokopu, sardine, sprat, eel (tuna), black-eel, conger-eel [168], and silver-eel. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,167)

CAESIOPERCA LEPIDOPTERA (Forster). Red Perch. Called red snapper' orSt. Peter's fish' in Queen Charlotte and Pelorus Sounds, where it is occasionally taken in the seine net during July and August. ... Distribution* North island coasts and northern coasts of the South Island. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/115) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PARROTT The Red Perch, as is the case with many of our common fishes, has received many popular names. .../ It is also known as the Red Snapper',St. Peter's Fish' or Butterfly Perch' It probably received the name ofSt. Peter's Fish' on account of the two black marks, one on each side of the body, which suggest the thumb/and finger marks of St. Peter, as I have previously explained in the case of the John Dory. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,73)

DOOGUE & MORELAND RED SNAPPER ... Other names: Trachichthodes affinis; golden snapper; nannygai (Australia); koarea (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,211)

MORELAND RED SNAPPER [Trachichthodes affinis ] ... Also known as golden snapper, and koarea (Maori). (1967,Marine Fishes,36)

WILSON GOLDEN SNAPPER Not a snapper at all but a relative of the Roughy. This big-eyed, Golden (or Red) Snapper is usually taken accidentally when bottom fishing for snapper. Ibid. 227 Red snapper or sometimes reef snapper, is a name given to those fish which have spent a good part of their time in rough-bottom areas; they are a deeper, golden red than the normal open-water snapper. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,114)

AYLING GOLDEN SNAPPER Centroberyx affinis (Trachichthodes affinis) (Nannygai, red snapper, koarea) ... In spite of its name the golden snapper is not related to the true snapper and is in fact more similar to the roughys. ... Schools of golden snapper often move out over open sand flats ... and are then regularly caught in bottom trawls and sold as red fish. (1982,Collins Guide,177,1984 ed.)

PAUL Red snapper Trachichthodes affinis Alternatively the golden snapper, and redfish or nannygai in southern Australia. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,72)

red snow¶

n.

At this place, 6,050 feet high, may be seen small patches of that peculiar 1-celled plant, Protococcus or red snow. The presence of this growth is said to be an indication of the very permanent character of the snow on which it occurs. (1884,TrNZI,17/353) [NOTES: (Park)]

red socks¶

n.

He is not the type, he insists, that files red socks in the red-sock drawer. (Jul 10, 2004,Dominion Post,A19)

Over the years many New Zealanders contributed to the campaign to bring back the Cup with red socks, etc. (Feb 7, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

All wore red socks in memory of their friend, who made lucky red socks a symbol of New Zealand's unified efforts during the 1995 America's Cup Challenge off San Diego. (Dec 15, 2001,Evening Post,1)

This time, Team NZ and Blake seemed much more the big guys, splashing about conspicuously in the local pond, buying in red socks from Korea. (Mar 12, 2000,Dominion Sunday Times,A9)

[Hdg] A red socks moment. (Oct 7, 2004,Wellingtonian,47)

Schnackenberg was the only central figure remaining from those glorious red sock days when the America's Cup was first declared New Zealand's cup. (Dec 4, 2004,Dominion Post,D2)

I sat in my red socks, alone in my retirement home room, happily absorbed in what I was seeing and hearing and life felt very flat when it was all over. (May 2000,North & South,14)

Jim Bolger, in his most natural television performance yet, ably fronted the red socks campaign. (May 27, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

This coming America's Cup will be huge and, if the Kiwis keep busting their millennium masts at the current rate, we'll not only have to all wear Red Socks, but Red Knickers as well. (May 8, 2002,Capital Times,2)

It did cross my mind that it might have been a bit red socky in getting involved in the Olympic spirit. (Jun 2000,Radio NZ / National Radio,Al Morrison)

He's got up this sort of Dunkirk-Red Socks campaign to get public-spirited Kiwis to do their bit and Switch Off. (Dec 27, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

[Hdg] Sir Michael to wear red socks for Team NZ. Smelly red socks hardly go with Sir Michael Fay's classic ensemble of navy blazer, blue plaid shirt and caramel trousers. (Feb 15, 2003,Dominion Post,A11)

Skipper Dean Barker will don lucky red socks and ensure the spirit of Sir Peter Blake remains aboard the Black Boat when Team New Zealand and Alinghi clash in the first America's Cup race on Saturday. (Feb 9, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A3)

The previous red-socks gimmick was innocent fun, but the "loyal" campaign is a shameful promotion. (Mar 8, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

First it was the virgin in a condom. Now an artist has done something extraordinary with that symbol of yachting good luck, the red sock. He put it on the penis of a carved Maori warrior. iBID. F3 Pakeha artists are often pulled up for their appropriation of Maori imagery but now contemporary Maori artist Chris Bryant has appropriated that rather perverse icon of Kiwi culture, the red sock. (Aug 27, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A5)

New Zealanders felt they were part of it all and Blake's inspirational red socks campaign gave everyone a down home chance to get in behind. (Sep 2004,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,2)

Whose idea was the America's Cup red sock campaign?... This was one of those promotional success stories that took off when Kiwis bought numerous red socks to suppport the New Zealand team on the water in 1995... English journalist Jane Redford casually remarked to someone that skipper Peter Blake always aseemed to be wearing red socks when the team did well. Some marketing whiz-kid at TVNZ put two and two together and came up with way more than four; thousands of pairs of patriotic pinky-warmers flew off the production line. (Oct 3, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),92)

Taylor said the Red Socks campaigns for Team New Zealand were typical of Sir Peter. "It touched the whole of New Zealand. Hundreds of people went out and bought red socks." (Dec 7, 2001,Evening Post,17)

red spotty¶

n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] spotty, red 1725 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Red Squad¶

n.

It was a natural progression from task force to Red Squad. (Mar 25, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31)

The thousands of people who turned out at the Springbok tour demonstrations saw the effect of the psychological preparation of the Red Squad as they exercised the legitimate use of force in pre-emptive strikes against demonstrators. (Jun 4, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

red sticker¶

v. [to apply, or have applied, a red sticker; in Wellington this indicates the highest risk of earthquake damage, while in Chch it indicates the highest outcome of earthquake damage and renders a property unusable. The verb appears most often as red stickered. Abbreveiated to red, and redded]

An inspection lasting just 20 minutes has ended an "infuriating" three-month wait for the owners of Lyttelton homes incorrectly red-stickered in February. (Jun 8, 2011,Press, The,1)

"I understand the knee- jerk reaction of safety first, but three months to say, 'Well, you shouldn't have been redded in the first place', that's just crap." (Jun 8, 2011,Press, The,1)

Sixty-three properties on Christchurch's Port Hills have been red-stickered this week as a result of Monday's aftershocks. (Jun 17, 2011,NZ Herald,internet)

Red stickered: This block of Basin Reserve shops owned by the New Zealand Transport Agency is one of the first buildings in the city to be red stickered by Wellington City Council under its new policy to force owners to strengthen or demolish earthquake-prone buildings. (Jul 2, 2011,Dominion Post,B14)

n. [The label indicating highest level of earthquake damage and renders a building unusable; Christchurch origin but spreading to other centres where the indication is of risk rather than damage.]

The red sticker is not a demolition order. It means the building is either so damaged there is a risk of collapse or nearby unstable buildings pose a safety threat. Civil Defence figures show that as of Thursday, 42 buildings have been demolished, with 94 partially "deconstructed". (Mar 19, 2011,Press, The,8)

The large four-storey brick mill in Wise St, Addington, was built at the turn of the 20th century but yesterday its fate was decided with a red sticker. (Mar 10, 2011,Press, The,6)

To their immense credit, our trio of hard-hats were wonderfully kind and quick to check on our emotional state. The inevitable did happen. The red sticker was produced. The old brick lady was wrapped in red tape, the warning notice was stuck on the garage door and the neighbour's garden cordoned off. Our house was deemed unsafe to inhabit. .. The red sticker was a moment of clarity. The house was unsafe while the aftershocks were occurring; walk away. (Sep 18, 2011,Press, The,10)

Experts in related fields were doing preliminary assessments to ease the workload although they could not recommend a red sticker. (Mar 8, 2011,Press, The,11)

red stickered¶

adj. [having had a red sticker applied; this indicating the highest level of earthquake damage and rendering a property unusable; Christchurch earthquake context but extended to other places with implications of high risk as opp to damage already done.]

A meeting with other owners of red-stickered homes on April 20 put them in touch with geotechnical consultant David Bell. Bell was the only official able to give a ruling, and proved to be a "lifesaver". (Jun 8, 2011,Press, The,1)

However, two remain red-stickered because of separate, structural issues. (Jun 8, 2011,Press, The,1)

Blackhead: Three houses red-stickered because of slip damage. Road blocked and access for owners only. Te Awanga: More than a dozen houses and campground flooded. fourteen houses were red stickered because of flooding. (May 7, 2011,Dominion Post,6)

red stilt¶

n.

LIST OF NAPIER BIRDS. ... Zosterops lateralis. (Blight-bird; tauhou.) ... Himantopus leucocephalus. (Red Stilt.) (1901,TrNZI,33/215)

red stripe¶

1 n. (Rural) a top quality grade of animal sold for the butchery trade.

In the red stripe section a yarding of about 820 fat sheep of mainly good quality sold on a strong market. (Aug 15, 1996,NZ Farmer,35)

The addition of an extra buyer lifted values for red stripe ewes by a few cents per kg ... (Oct 1, 1998,NZ Farmer,35)

Prime sheep: Quality was also good for a red-stripe yarding of about 1590. (Mar 19, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,11)

red teal¶

n. (Environment) pateke [aka brown teal, see]

Another protected species of duck is the brown teal, sometimes known as the red teal. (Jul 10, 1937,Evening Post,17)

HUTTON 98. ANAS CHLOROTIS. Gray. Red Teal. Pateke. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,36)

PEACHE Our bag was 4 brace of swamp hens, 11/2 brace of Red teal, 1 brace of Blue duck and 1 brace of Grey duck. ... we shot 2 brace of Black teal ... (Apr 10, 1876,Journal) [NOTES: 1876 Apr 10 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 43]

red tribe¶

n. [NZ war]

BUICK A number of the red tribe who had not joined in the attack on our pa came at our people with rush ... (1906,New Zealand's First War,118) [NOTES: 1906 T.C. Buick New Zealand's First War 118 in 1984 Barber Red Coat to Jungle Green 15]

red tussock¶

n.

Chionochloa rubra, the red tussock, is the species that imparts the rich, red-brown colour to areas bordering the Desert Road and other tussock grasslands. (Aug 27, 1999,Dominion,14)

Down there, webs of standing water transect a rippling carpet of red tussock, Chionochloa rubra... red tussock thrives on waterlogged or frosty flats... [29] In the wetter areas, such as Southland, red tussock raced across the low-lying hills. Ibid. 35 Red tussock, Chionochloa rubra.. grows to a metre high and is one of the most widely distributed tall tussocks, occurring from the volcanic plateau of the central North Island, through most of the South Island and into Stewart Island. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/26)

Maori names for tussock varied from region to region. In one southern dialect, wi was used for silver tussock (furher north the same word was applied to rushes) and patiti seemed to be a general term for tall tussocks, with maania an alternative or the word for red tussock in particular. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/40)

Some of these grasses, such as red tussock (Chionochloa rubra), can live for more than 100 years and reach 2 metres in height. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/36)

1 n. (Rural) a native tussock grass, Chionochloa rubra, usually grazed only by cattle.

The land is mainly easy rolling contour with some steep sidlings, covered generally by red tussock, fern and manuka scrub. (Apr 1968,NZ Journal of Agriculture,55)

NEWTON A big proportion of Ngamatea - the homestead end - is easy rolling country, heavily covered with red tussock two feet or so in height, and difficult country in which to get a clean muster. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,149)

Red tussock is the least attractive to stock and is usually cropped at the tips of the leaves. (1970,NZ Journal of Agriculture,Research 535)

WHEELER Jack has seen photos of the Gentle Annie area in the 1890s, all in native red tussock with odd stands of bush. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,80)

This red tussock, or snow grass, grows abundantly in the Mataura district, and would be used very extensively but for the fact that it is very stubborn to work, requiring a long treatment in the digester and a strong solution of soda, which reduces its bulk very much, making it more profitable to use made material, of which a good supply is now procurable. (Feb 24, 1888,Otago Witness,10)

Even the humourously [sic] described duck ponds, swamps, and red tussock land off Taringatura would grow this fibre plant. (Jan 30, 1890,Otago Witness,24)

This evening there was paper made in New south Wales from maize, and also a specimen of paper pulp from the red tussock grass of New Zealand, presented by Mr E. M'Glashan. (Jun 20, 1874,Otago Witness,6)

In Southland, owing to the methods universally adopted from the Canterbury farmers, land that was covered with "red tussock," wet, cold and bleak, has been brought into cultivation. (Sep 11, 1920,Grey River Argus,6)

red water fern¶

n. Azolla rubra

The talk was of Lake Kohangapiripiri beyond the lighthouse, of the yellow poppies that grow out of the black sand and look as delicate as paper, of the red water fern called Azolla rubra. (Nov 27, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

Red, White and Blue¶

n. a betting game played with darts thrown into a board with stripes of the three colours. Money is placed on a chosen colour [ca1935 Havelock Easter Sports]

BELTON [Sideshowman speaks] Can a man play Red, White and Blue tomorrow. (1939,Outside the Law,204) [NOTES: nf. P]

red-bill¶

n.

To the trout-fisherman wandering over the gravelly river beds, bird life just now will be found specially interesting, for Paradise ducks, and other ducks, red bills, and dotterel, and other birds, that usually are to be found along the rivers, are now nursing their young broods. (Nov 12, 1910,Evening Post,13)

DIEFFENBACH [The] native rat still lingers here and there [in the central North Island], although it has disappeared on the coast; the native dog has become a mongrel; ducks, teals, the red-billed porphyrio or pukeko, a large bittern, a tern, two kinds of gulls, cormorants ... are found here.] (1843,Travels in NZ,1/362)

CRUISE (1823,Journal,142) [NOTES: [see quot quail: check =PUKEKO]]

The red-bill, porophyrio melanotus or pukeko of the natives. (1851,Canterbury Papers,79) [NOTES: 1849 March 10 Strange's Journal (Naturalist `Acheron') (1851 Canterbury Papers 79)]

MORRIS Red-bill, n bird-name given to Estrelda temporalis, Lath. It is also applied to the Oyster-catchers (q.v.); and sometimes to the Swamp-Hen (q.v.). [Aust. contexts] (1898,Austral English,383)

redbill n. gregarious bird, the swamp-hen. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

n. short for red-billed gull [(obs)]

DEVANNY Seagulls and red-bills poised upon the flat tide water. (1928,Dawn Beloved,132)

2 n.

HAEMATOPUS UNICOLOR, Forst. - Black Red-bill. (1886,TrNZI,18/126) [NOTES: (Hamilton)]

Grey teal .. together with the red-bill or oyster-catcher, formed another part of the collection. (Feb 15, 1873,Otago Witness,2)

red-billed gull¶

n. Larus scopulinus, tarapunga

FORSTER The Capt & Gentlemen returned late from a shooting party & brought a large white Heron (Ardea alba), a white & brown Gull [267] (Larus naevius) [[ed. fn] Larus scopulinus of Descr. Anim., p.106; ... Now Red-billed Gull Larus novaehollandiae scopulinus Forster, 1844.] & a young Sky Lark (Alaudaar vensis). [ed. fn] Alauda littorea of Descr. Anim., p.90; ... Now the new Zealand Pipit Anthus novaeseelandiae novaeseelandiae (Gmelin, 1789). (Apr 25, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/266)

BULLER LARUS SCOPULINUS. (MACKEREL- {RED-BILLED} GULL.) ... Native name{s}. Tarapunga, {Makora, and Akiaki}. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,273) [NOTES: {1888 2nd edn 2/55}]

WILLIAMS Akiaki, ... larus scopulinus red-billed gull. = tarapunga. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,9)

RED-BILLED GULL, or AKIAKI (Larus novae hollandiae). (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/208)

POWELL RED-BILLED GULL (Larus novaehollandiae), Tarapunga or Akiaki of the Maoris, is abundant throughout New Zealand, Australia, New Caledonia and South Africa. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,80)

WILSON L[arus] novae hollandiae ... Red-billed Gull, Jacky. TIAKI-AKI. (1952,Chatham Islands,83)

McLINTOCK Red-billed gull .. .. akiaki, tarapunga .. .. Larus novaehollandiae (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

FALLA et al. RED-BILLED GULL Larus scopulinus Other names: Tarapunga, Mackerel Gull, Jackie (Chathams). (1966,Birds of New Zealand,154)

53 194. Larus novaehollandiae scopulinus Forster, 1844 Red-billed Gull (Tarapunga) New Zealand (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,1980)

Red-billed Gull Larus novaehollandiae scopulinus FORSTER, 1844 ... The red-billed gull is one of the commonest gulls on the New Zealand coast; it rarely lives inland. ... OTHER NAMES: Silver gull, tarapunga, akiaki, mackerel gull, jackie. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,222)

The red-billed or mackerell gull - .. the Maoris' tarapunga - is a smaller and prettier bird. (Aug 13, 1908,Auckland Weekly News,38)

red-breasted plover¶

n. . [aka tuturiwhatu]

  1. Charadrius obscurus, Gml. Dusky, Red-breasted, or Mountain Plover, Big Dottrel [si], Tuturiwatu, Paturiwhata, Tituriwhatu-pukunui. - This excellent gamebird formerly bred on the Canterbury Plains ...; since farms and settlements have occupied the waste lands of the plains, for the most part it has retired to the mountains of the back country. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,506) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

.. "Ornithologist" mentions any or all of the following as a first draft he wants information upon:- The dotterel, red-bill .. red-breasted plover ... (Sep 5, 1906,Otago Witness,88)

red-crowned kakariki¶

n.

DoC technical support officer Lynn Adams said the red-crowned kakariki population on Kapiti Island was believed to be in the hundreds and had been increasing since the removal of rats. (Apr 29, 2004,Wellington Contact,35)

Offspring have been produced by the supposedly "male" contingent of red-crowned kakariki transferred to Matiu/Somes Island from Kapiti Island last June. (May 2004,Footnotes,No. 21/6)

red-crowned parakeet¶

n. a small parrot, Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae, in several subspecies, with red forehead and crown (also called powhaitere).

221.b. Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae novaezelandiae (Sparrman, 1787) Red-crowned Parakeet (Kakariki) New Zealand; North Island ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,59,1980 ed.)

SANSOM ... Half Moon Bay straight out to the ... island of Herekopare, at one time a paradise for native birds, especially red-crowned parakeets. (1970,Stewart Islanders,146)

Red-crowned Parakeet Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae (SPARRMAN, 1787) ... There are four subspecies of the red-crowned parakeet in New Zealand: the New Zealand red-crowned parakeet Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae novaezelandiae, the Kermadec parakeet C.n. chathamensis, and Reischek's parakeet C.n. hochstetteri. ... OTHER NAMES: Kakariki, New Zealand parakeet, Antipodes red-crowned parakeet. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,248)

According to these analyses, the nearest relative to the orange-fronted is the red-crowned parakeet. (Aug 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 52/14)

Moon The red-crowned parakeet is becoming increasingly rare on the mainland, due to the fact that they often feed on the ground and are subject to predation by feral cats and stoats. (2002,Photographic Guide to Birds of NZ, A,103)

Red-crowned Parakeet Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae (SPARRMAN, 1787) ... There are four subspecies of the red-crowned parakeet in New Zealand: the New Zealand red-crowned parakeet Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae novaezelandiae, the Kermadec parakeet C.n. chathamensis, and Reischek's parakeet C.n. hochstetteri. ... OTHER NAMES: Kakariki, New Zealand parakeet, Antipodes red-crowned parakeet. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,248)

HUTTON 48. PLATYCERCUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. Sparrm. Crimson-top Paroquet. Kaka[r]iki. P. Forsteri. FINSCH. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,19)

FALLA et al. RED-CROWNED PARAKEET Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae Maori name: Kakariki. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,174)

221.b. Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae novaezelandiae (Sparrman, 1787) Red-crowned Parakeet (Kakariki) New Zealand; North Island .. (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,59,1980 ed.)

Maori knew the three mainland parakeets - red-crowned, yellow-crowned and orange-fronted - collectively as kakariki. (May 2001,NZ Geographic,51/10)

red-dot¶

adj. bargain

[Hdg] Sinclair's red-dot special. (Mar 17, 2001,Evening Post,17)

red-fronted parakeet¶

n. kakariki

BULLER PLATYCERCUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (RED-FRONTED PARRAKEET.) ... Native names. Kakariki, Kakawariki, Powhaitere, Porere, and Torete ...[59] The Red-fronted Parrakeet is very generally dispersed over the whole country - but is more plentiful in the southern portion of the North Island than in the far north, where the yellow-fronted species predominates. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,58,1888 2nd edn 1/137 ed.)

Cyanorhamphus novaezealandiae Sparr. Red-fronted Parrakeet. Philpott (1919) states that this species, so far as south-west Otago is concerned, still occurs far back in the great timbered areas, but is much more timid than in the old `shanghai' days. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/86) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

GUTHRIE-SMITH It was a delight once again to see New Zealand forest unspoiled. Birds noted were Weka, Bellbird, Tui, Red-fronted Parakeet, ... Grey Warbler and Yellow-breasted Tit. (1936,NZ Naturalist,100)

NATUSCH The red-fronted parakeet (Cyanorhampus novaezelandiae .. ranges the North, South and Stewart Island forested hills ... Other subspecies occur on the Kermadecs, Chathams and Antipodes; the Macquarie parakeet has died out. [Other species are known: the yellow-crowned C.auriceps auriceps (same distribution as the red-fronted), the rare forbesi (confined to Little Mangere in the Chathams), and the rare orange-fronted C. malherbi ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,290)

  1. Platycercus novae-zealandiae, Sparrm. Red-fronted Parroquet, Kakariki. - Years ago it was very common in the numerous Fagus woods in the Malvern district ... (Jul 1885,NZ Journal of Science,480) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

kakariki n. red-fronted NZ parakeet. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

There have been a number of red-fronted parakeets about here since last I wrote. (Apr 1, 1924,Otago Witness,76)

red-fruited maire¶

n. Eugenia maire

Eugenia maire (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: (And)Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest]

red-headed parakeet¶

n. = red-crowned parakeet [early forms red head, red-headed, red-topped]

One of the party of naturalists on the Hinemoa on her last trip to the Southern Islands was Mr. R. Gibb, who went at the request of the Otago Acclimatisation society to procure some specimens of the red-headed parakeet indigenous to the Antipodes Island, for shipment to India. (Aug 5, 1903,Otago Witness,55)

HOWARD [Stewart Island birds include] the fern-bird (Bowdleria fulva),.. Yellow-fronted parakeet (Cyanorhampus auriceps), Red-headed parrakeet (Cyanorhampus novae zealandiae), .. and in the second class: Weka (Ocydromus) .. and Kiwi (Apteryx). (1940,Rakiura,323)

Then, what about our native red head parrakeet, one of the best little birds in the world? (Jun 11, 1913,Evening Post,7)

ka[a]ka[a]riki, a bird (Cyanoramphus novae zealandiae), red-headed parakeet (riki, little; whence little kaka). (1846,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/143) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

Platycercus novae-zealandiae, Sparrm. (Red-topped Parakeet.) (1897,TrNZI,29/188) [NOTES: (Buller)]

red-jacket¶

n.

The above list of fish to be caught along the Canterbury coast has some notable omissions, ... though I am not so sure about the rawaru (blue cod). Others omitted are the tarakihi, or terakihi, the moki, the komutumutu (trevalli), the puhaiwhakarua (red-jacket), koiro (conger eel), tuere (blind eel), whai (skate), and the koekohe [sic] (trumpeter). (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,62)

red-shanked plover¶

n.

BARLOW [At Kaipara] ... birds of various kinds, including duck, teal, shags eel-hawks [77], and flocks of godwit and red-shanked plover, added further life to the scene. (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,76)

red-sock-it to 'em¶

phr.

Wood is right - we may well red-sock-it to 'em [sc. the Italians] on the Hauraki Gulf - but we are left floundering in their wake when it comes to charm, flair and fronting up. (Feb 23, 2000,Evening Post,10)

red-zoner¶

n. [resident of the red zone post eq Chch]

Richard Long But these red-zoners are in many ways the lucky ones: they can get their money and go, getting the pick of available houses in undamaged suburbs and the pick on new subdivision land. (Jun 28, 2011,Dominion Post,B4)

Richard Long The red-zoners get nine months to make decisions on the form of their package. (Jun 28, 2011,Dominion Post,B4)

redarse¶

n. a rookie; new recruit (cf PONGO) - [(WW2 soldiers)]

DAVIN A man couldn't have bloody young redarse telling him what to do. Ibid. 312 That'll teach those redarses to start digging in at this stage ... Ought to know the army better than that. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,209)

DAVIN You were only a bloody redarses in those days. (1947,Gorse Blooms Pale, The,193)

SARGE Glossary. Redbottom: (Kiwi-ism) a newly arrived reinforcement. - the word bottom is a polite version of the term. (1950,Excuse my Feet!)

DAVIN ... a lot of them [newcomers] I'd never even seen before, just new chums and red-arses (1975,Breathing Spaces,126)

HENDERSON We new arrivals [in Egypt] are known as red arses',red knees', `red necks'. Hawkers, beggars, touts, small mischievous boys or wallids, discern this and our hesitant demeanour instantly, and swoop like shite-hawks. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,260)

redback spider¶

n.

...it may be prudent to mention that the Australian red-back spider (Latrodectus hasselti) has become firmly established in New Zealand in the last couple of years, so we can deal with three closely related comb-footed spider species in the space of one story... In other words, the black widow is really nothing more than the American katipo, and the red-back is the Australian katipo. (Dec 4, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

redback spider : a theridiid spider (Latrodectus hasselti) that is closely related to the American black widow and prob. identical with the katipo, has a venom which produces neurotoxic symptoms in man, and occurs in Australia, New Zealand, and the major islands of the East Indies - called also red-streaked spider (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1900)

redbanded perch¶

n. A fish distinguished by vertical brown bars on otherwise reddish body, found in NZ and southern Australian waters. [Hypoplectrodes huntii, previously Ellerkeldia hunti]

PAUL Redbanded perch Ellerkeldia hunti New Zealand and southern Australia. ... Sometimes called the banded sea perch, which causes some confusion with the scorpaenid sea perches ... (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,85)

AYLING REDBANDED PERCH Ellerkeldia huntii ... The redbanded perch is the smallest member of this family found in New Zealand ... Inshore specimens are orange on the back and whitish beneath with a green-tinged head. (1982,Collins Guide,1984)

Redbands¶

1 n. (Rural) gumboots [orig. trade name ''Redband''.]

Dippies, aggies, Redbands and Swanndris - forever tied to Massey University ... (Apr 23, 2002,Midweek,24)

redfin bully¶

n.

McDOWALL Although whitebaiters know them by the name "whalefeed" they are in fact the young of several species of freshwater bully: the redfinned bully (Gobiomorphus huttoni), the bluegilled bully (Gobiomorphus hubbsi) and the common bully (Gobiomorphus cotidianus)... The redfinned bully is a handsome species, perhaps the most beautiful of New Zealand's freshwater fish. (1984,NZ Whitebait Book, The,21)

A survey of the Kaiwharawhara Stream near Ngaio has uncovered a range of freahwater fish .. Bluegill bullies, Eels, koaro, banded kokopu and redfin bullies were also found in the catchments. (Jan 25, 2005,Independent Herald (Wellington),p9)

[caption] Under water: Native fish found in the region's [Wellington] rivers and streams are, clockwise from top left, inanga, redfin bully, torrent fish, banded kokopu, giant kokopu and kaoro. (May 7, 2005,Dominion Post,A21)

n.

Among the species found in abundant numbers were redfin bullies, torrent fish (in fast flowing rivers only), koaro, banded kokopu and giant kokopu ... (May 7, 2005,Dominion Post,A21)

DENNIS Tiny, largely transparent bullies are also amongst the migrants ... common bully (Gobiomorphus cotidianus), redfinned bully (G. huttoni), and bluegilled bully (G. hubbsi). These are sometimes caught in large quantities by whitebaiters. The fishermen call them Dan Doolin Spawn' orWhalefeed'. (1981,Paparoas Guide,189)

redfish¶

n.

SPEIGHT A very beautiful member of the same family is the rare Red-fish (Plagiogeneion rubiginosus) known only from a few specimens stranded on beaches. (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,199) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 199]

Lampris guttatus Brunnich: The Opah, Moon Fish, or Red Fish. (1929,TrNZI,61/plate 16) [NOTES: (Young)]

GOLDEN SNAPPER Centroberyx affinis (Trachichthodes affinis) (Nannygai, red snapper, koarea) ... In spite of its name the golden snapper is not related to the true snapper and is in fact more similar to the roughys. ... Schools of golden snapper often move out over open sand flats ... and are then regularly caught in bottom trawls and sold as red fish. (1982,Collins Guide,177,1984 ed.)

[species name] red snapper .. [scientific name] Centroberyx affinis .. [other name(s)] golden snapper, nannygai, redfish (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

[index to common names 283-293] redfish 1450 REDFISHES 1445-53 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

redhead¶

n. a variety of whitebait

The redheads we soon began catching for ourselves: smaller and less flavoursome than the inanga, the prized main whitebait variety (there are five in all), the redheads did indeed have a small flush of red colouring behind their heads. They also possess two sets of fins - all the better for climbing up waterfalls, and for climbing part-way up the sides of our bucket. (Nov 30, 2004,Dominion Post,E8)

redrain¶

1 v. (Rural) to add more drains to a swamp or to replace shingled drains with tiles.

TAIT The swamp has been redrained by dragline. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,42)

redroot¶

n. (also called redshank) either of two varieties of amaranth, found chiefly in the North Island. =amaranth, redshank, pig weed

HI;LGENDORF RED ROOT (Amaranthus [hybridus and A. retroflexus), also called red shank and pig weed, is found in gardens and waste places all over the North Island and as far south as Nelson [Canterbury]. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,70,1967 ed.)

LEVY Many introduced weeds typical of subtropical climates are present, the more common ones being wild portulaca, inkweed, redroot, thorn apple, and apple of Sodom. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,4,1970 ed.)

redroot [s] Amaranthus hybridus L. Amaranthus retroflexus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,63)

TAYLOR REDROOT (Amaranthus powellii syn. A.hybridus and A, retroflexus) Redroot is a frost-tender annual of tropical American origin,. . . (1980,Weeds of Crops,8)

TAYLOR REDROOT (Amaranthus powellii syn. A.hybridus and A, retroflexus) Redroot is a frost-tender annual of tropical American origin,. . . (1980,Weeds of Crops,8)

redshank¶

n. (Occasionally) =willow weed (See redroot)

HILGENDORF WILLOW WEED (Epilobium sp[p].). - This is also called herb willow, swamp willow, and by confusion redshank and fireweed. It is a native that occasionally grows as a weed in or near ditches. The name is sometimes given to redshank [p.59], and it is true that both polygonum and epilobium grow in damp places, have willow-like leaves and are about 2 feet high. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,126,1967 ed.)

redshank [=] redroot: willow weed: pale willow weed [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,63)

TAYLOR WILLOW WEED OR REDSHANK (Polygonum persicaria) ... This cosmopolitan weed is common throughout New Zealand, mainly in cultivated ground. (1980,Weeds of Crops,118)

2 n. persicaria, spotted persicaria, knot weed, smart weed,=willow weed, lady's thumb, ? water pepper, ? walker's weed

HI;LGENDORF REDSHANK (Polygonum persicaria) is also called persicaria, spotted persicaria, knot weed, smart weed, willow weed, and lady's thumb. Perhaps also it is this weed that on the west coast of the South Island is called water pepper or Walker's weed. It is an annual weed of gardens, crops, and wet pastures. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,59,1967 ed.)

3 n. red root

HILGENDORF RED ROOT (Amaranthus [hybridus and A. retroflexus), also called red shank and pig weed, is found in gardens and waste places all over the North Island and as far south as Nelson [Canterbury]. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,70,1967 ed.)

redtop¶

n. (See grass,redtop)

reduction-works¶

n. [goldmining]

KNOX ... auriferous rock, which was carried directly to the reduction-works, where it was crushed and the precious metal extracted. (1888,Boy Travellers,214)

reed¶

2 n.

reed, canary grass [s] Phalaris arundinacea L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,64)

Reed canary grass is an internationally renowned weed of wetlands, where it forms dense sprawling stands up to 1 m tall. (Jul 2006,Climate Update, The (NIWA),Aquatic Biodiversity & Biosecurity)

2 n. Typha angustifolia

MARKHAM (And) (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles))

2 n.

ROBERTS It was constructed of ti-trees plastered with clay and mud, and covered with the native reed or wiwi. (1914,History of North Otago,9,1978 ed.) [NOTES: 1875 Rev.A.B.Todd in 1906 W.H.S.Roberts in 1914 History of North Otago (1978) 9]
