reedmace¶

n. raupo

FORSTER ... a kind of sowing through small holes with strings of the Flaxplant or Arakeke [a2-macron, e1-grave]. The seams are caulked with the pappus of the Reed-mace or Typha. (Jun 18, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/300)

FORSTER The seams between [the canoe planks] are caulked with the downy or woolly substance of the reed-mace (typha latifolia). (1777,Voyage Round the World,2/217)

HOOKER Reedmace. Typha angustifolia. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

reef¶

v.

Any expectations of great gold finding until the dry summer weather s [sic] decidedly premature, and even then `quartz reefing' will, I am convinced, be the main source of a gold export. (Aug 23, 1862,Otago Witness,5)

Reef (r&emacr.f), v. i. (Mining) To be engaged in quartz reefing, that is, in mining for gold in a quartz reef. See under QUARTZ (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

n. [(goldminers')]

The Paparoa Range is swarming with men out prospecting for reefs, while some are busy testing reefs already taken up. (Oct 29, 1896,Otago Witness,22)

REEFTON, October 11. The manager of the New Big River mine reports that stoping was continued on the eastern and branch reefs as usual. (Oct 14, 1908,Otago Witness,29)

The Alexandra Company have, at a new level, cut the reef, which is about four feet six inches wide, and is, in the words of one of the party, looking well. (Feb 22, 1872,Tuapeka Times,5)

Lightband is out somewhere between the Para Para and Appoo's Flat; report says he has found a quartz reef. (Jun 9, 1858,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

... on the hill sides there are a number of large quartz reefs. (Aug 23, 1862,Otago Witness,6)

BARRINGTON Farrell went down to the gorge to see the reefs; found any amount of specks to a shovel of dirt in several places, also found gold in the reef. (Apr 6, 1864,Diary) [NOTES: 1864 Apr 6 Barrington Diary in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 405]

A main vein or lode. Ibid. 82 Five men's ground, ... Large reef and leaders. (1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,55)

BAINES Our reef, or leader, measuring only four inches in thickness, a drive for a considerable distance following the course of the gold-bearing quartz had to be carried out, ... (1874,Boy Travellers,262)

KNOX Some of the mines are wholly alluvial, or placer, diggings, others are wholly quartz-mines, which are called reefs in New Zealand and Australia, ... (1888,Boy Travellers,215)

MORRIS term in gold-mining; a vein of auriferous quartz. Called by the Calfornian miners a vein, or lode, or ledge. In Bendigo, the American usage remains, the words reef, dyke and vein being used as synonymous, though reef is the most common. (See quotation, 1866.) In Ballarat, the word has two distinct meanings, viz. the vein, as above, and the bed-rock or true-bottom. quotations, ...1869 and 1874.) Outside Australia, a reef means `a chain or range of rocks lying at or near the surface of the water.' (Webster.') (1898,Austral English,385)

~ n. a vein of gold-bearing quartz;-v.t. to work at a reef. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,9)

~ n. vein of auriferous quartz (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

reef n. vein of auriferous quartz (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

McARA Reefs: The quartz veins which were contained in the country rocks at Waihi. They were more correctly described as fissure veins; the term reefs' is considered to be more appropriately applied to them than the termlodes' formerly used. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),330)

reef track¶

n. [goldmining; aka reef-track]

A promising reef track is now being followed. (Nov 9, 1885,Inangahua Times,2)

The contractors are making fair headway, following the reef track west. (Mar 17, 1890,Inangahua Times,2)

There is a reef track on both foot and hanging walls, with hard sandstone between them. (Mar 27, 1905,Colonist (Nelson),4)

For the week NNo, 3 level has been extended south 14ft, making a total of 56ft, now driven on the reef track. (May 25, 1911,Grey River Argus,2)

When they contain only small veinlets of quartz or merely bands of faulty pug, vein-fissures are referred to as reef-track' by the miners. 1948 <i>Ibid.</i> 38 ... a crosscut put out eastward for 800ft, from which three reef-tracks were explored. 1948 <i>Ibid.</i> 58 The Blackwater company also explored the ground north of their boundary ... but found merelyreef-tracks' (1948,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No. 42 (NS)/18) [NOTES: (Gage: Reefton)]

reef bottom¶

n. [goldmining]

The wash-dirt is of rich yellow color, and a hard reef bottom; the ground in some places is very good to drive in, but in other claims a drift exists which will cause the occupants to slab the hole. (May 10, 1862,Otago Witness,3)

THE ACRE CREEK RUSH. .. "The only party who have as yet tried to or got gold are the prospectors, who have driven a tunnel from the creek, in an easterly direction, into the terrace for 180ft on top of the ordinary blue reef bottom covered with a thin clayey crust of a chocolate colour. ..." (Jul 8, 1887,Otago Witness,12)

As a rule, the coarse and nuggety gold is confined to a reef bottom, while the false bottom of whatever description carries fine gold. (Jun 29, 1899,Otago Witness,20)

This dredge eventually proved that the bed of the Molyneux River was practically lined with gold, one week's return being 1189 oz. and another week 1158 oz., but the gold was found to be the richest in the jointy reef-bottom and crevices of the river bed. (Jun 9, 1927,NZ Truth,14)

The basement rock is known to alluvial miners as 'reef bottom'; ... The 'reef bottom' may be slate and sandstone, as in Victoria; mica-schist, as in Otago; or granite, as in some parts of New South Wales and Queensland. Ibid. 42 Towards the dip it passes off the schist or `reef' bottom on to the lignite series. (1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No. 5 (N.S.)/37) [NOTES: (Park: Cromwell)]

reef country¶

n.

The discovery of reefs at Mahakipawa and Waikakaho is about to give an impetus to the reef country at Wakamarina. ... (Oct 25, 1888,Evening Post,2)

Golden Fleece Mine: The only point now being attacked is in No.15 level, which is extended 89 feet - a portion is in a likely reef country - but which has exposed nothing of real importance. (Apr 20, 1908,Evening Post,7)

They are of opinion that it will prove a payable reef country, but will await finer weather before going in again. (Jun 4, 1895,Wanganui Herald,2)

"..Nevertheless, any amount of similar reef country is still open to the miner and small capitalist." (Dec 16, 1865,Otago Witness,11)

REWARD FUND. (To the Editor.) Sir,- Allow me to explain a paragraph which appeared in your issue of this morning to the effect that I offered to contribute GBP200 towards GBP1000 as a reward fund for the discovery of a payable gold-bearing quartz reef country in the County of Westland, south of the Teremakau. (Jul 5, 1872,West Coast Times,2)

Excellent reef country is being penetrated. (Aug 1, 1912,Evening Post,2)

BROWN Similarly in the Lyell, Antonio Zala had discovered a reef in 1869 ... Naturally, this led to a renewed search for gold ..., and an endeavour to trace the gold back to `reef country'. (1976,Difficult Country,107)

KENNAWAY These fields - or reefs, as they are called - are at present worked by many thousands of digers ... (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,230)

reef fish¶

n. (figurative)

[He] has been overseas some of the time, running foreign exchange dealing rooms in Hong Kong and Los Angeles, and the term "reef fish" is new to him. I have to explain that it's a derisive term coined by David Lange to describe the behaviour of the money markets... Lange once referred to market operators as demented reef fish - a term inspired by the aberrant behaviour of tropical fish which dart backwards and forwards en masse in a manner that defies rational explanation. (Nov 27, 1993,Evening Post,17)

Highly addictive, with low unit cost, [crack] makes an attractive retail opportunity for resting reef fish or person with experience in the hospitality or service industry. (Dec 2, 1993,City Voice,2)

In Mr Lange's book, this is an individual who, like the "demented reef fish" of the money markets, reacts mindlessly to conform with everyone else's mindless reaction (Mar 24, 1996,Sunday Star Times,C2)

Those who feel appalled at the influence the so-called reef-fish - the financial market traders - have over our economy will not be reassured by the tale of [this] man. (Mar 31, 1996,Sunday Star Times,E4)

As the currents of the market-place permeate through New Zealand society, it is the voters who have become the new generation of reef fish. (May 27, 1996,Dominion,2)

It may even be that the reef-fish who temporarily converge upon [new restaurants] are essential, providing a kick-start for a relatively out-of-the-way new venture. (Oct 19, 1999,Evening Post,21)

Since when did the reef fish in the share market attest to anything, I was told, in stern tones. (Dec 4, 1996,Norwester,14)

Colin James I've been talking to some of the reef fish this morning. (Dec 11, 1996,Radio NZ / National Radio)

Last week distress signals were beginning to show; the Reserve Bank hung out a flag, the reef fish shoaled, and interest rates headed north. (Dec 4, 1994,Sunday Star Times,C2)

What I saw happen here.. was a sort of reef-fish mentality taking over the public debate. (Aug 22, 1997,Dominion,2)

Once again, TVNZ's trustworthy reporter Ewart Barnsley intoned ominously as he watched the financial reef fish swirling in yet another frenzy of self-interest over the dollar, home mortgage rates - life itself. (Aug 6, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94 ed.)

In South Africa that commercialism is much more up front than in New Zealand and players' agents and various other rugby reef fish are given fairly short shift by the new coach. (Mar 15, 2002,Evening Post,21)

[Lange's] characterisation of foreign exchange dealers as "demented reef fish", and of rival political operatives as "poll-driven fruitcakes" have entered the New Zealand lexicon. (Feb 26, 1995,Sunday Star Times,C2)

A decade or so ago, Burge had his bright star, Krondorf, whisked from under his nose by stockmarket reef sharks... (May 25, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

These are things which strike fear into the hearts of many who run the economy today, particularly those David Lange once described as financial reef fish... Financial reef fish.. point out that the country's comparatively stable economic outlook is based on three fundamental policies - the Reserve Bank Act, the Employment Contracts Act and the Fiscal Responsibility Act. (Oct 1995,Metro,88)

reef formation¶

n. [goldmining]

The greater part of the auriferous belt is locally termed `reef formation', and consists of much crushed and contorted mica-schist. (1918,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No 19 (N.S.)/37) [NOTES: (Marshall: Tuapeka)]

reef gold¶

n. [aka reef-gold]

WHITE'S REEF GOLD MINING COMPANY (LIMITED). (Feb 17, 1888,Otago Witness,18)

In other words, from the distributed river-gold the geologist works back to the reef gold in the hills. (Sep 12, 1925,NZ Truth,17)

`That alluvial gold is of a higher quality than reef-gold from the same neighbourhood.' (1890,TrNZI,22/402)

reef heron¶

n. (Environment) Egretta sacra sacra, also called blue heron , occas, blue reef heron (see b. and c. below). See also (blue) crane, matuku-moana. [AND Egretta sacra of coastal mainland Austr. and elsewhere 1848.]

Ardea sacra , Gml. Blue, Purple, or Reef heron, Matuku. - May be observed alighting on reefs immediately on the ebb of the tide so that the birds stand in the water. (1885,NZ Journal of Science,557) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

POWELL REEF HERON ( Demigretta sacra ), Matuku-moana of the Maoris, is a graceful dark slaty grey bird with long beak and legs of bright yellow. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,83)

  1. Egretta sacra sacra (Gmelin, 1789) Reef Heron (Matuku-moana) Asia to Australia, eastern Polynesia and New Zealand. (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,35,1980 ed.)

WILLIAMS Matuku, n. ... 2. Demigretta matook, blue heron ; a shore bird. = matuku-moana ... m&amacr.tukutuku. ... 1. Reef heron (blue heron).= matuku, 2.: a wading bird with long legs, neck and beak. (1971,Dictionary of the Maori Language,195)

Reef Heron Egretta sacra sacra (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Blue reef heron, eastern reef heron, blue crane, blue heron, matuku-moana. ... Reef herons in New Zealand are at the southeastern limit of their mostly tropical range, and for that reason alone may never be common. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,132)

Bird enthusiasts are in for a treat with a good chance of seeing .. shags, white-fronted terns, reef herons and oystercatchers ... (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 8)

reef in with¶

v. to throw in with (a person); join with [is this a coinage or nonce use?] [an Italian fisherman speaks]

GRACE reef in alonga you an' Rock Codda. (1914,Tale of a Timber Town,I)

reef off¶

v.

ELDRED-GRIGG The landlady was slightly mad ... She kept reefing off about how she was going to do this and going to do that to the house ... (1987,Oracles and Miracles,230)

reef shark¶

n. (See reef fish (fig.))

A decade or so ago, Burge had his bright star, Krondorf, whisked from under his nose by stockmarket reef sharks... (May 25, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

reef snapper¶

n. (See snapper,reef)

WILSON Red snapper or sometimes reef snapper, is a name given to those fish which have spent a good part of their time in rough-bottom areas; they are a deeper, golden red than the normal open-water snapper. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,227)

reef-fish¶

v. (figurative) [cf. reef fish n. (figurative)]

We said he would reef-fish the financial markets and frighten off investment. (Oct 18, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

reef-fish swings of sentiment¶

phr.

The Privy Council judges aren't swayed by "the reef fish swings of sentiment to which we are prone", as Franks put it. (Aug 3, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

reef-fishlike¶

adj.

We all go reef-fishlike whenever we read that the local worthies consider the time may have come to jettison the trains and make everybody come in by road. (Jan 28, 2002,Dominion,11)

reefer¶

n.

The death is announced of William Williams, who was a pioneer gold reefer. (Sep 30, 1902,Colonist (Nelson),3)

The inquest on the body of William Davies was held at the Reefers' Rest, Deep Creek, on Tuesday last, the 23rd instant, before Mr John Allen, Coroner. (Jan 26, 1883,Marlborough Express,2)

Reefi.er (-&etilde.r), n. (Mining) A quartz reefer. See under QUARTZ (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

As a reefing country, I am convinced that the small portion of land now open is wonderfully rich. Let the reefers once obtain machinery, and depend upon it the yield will be enormous. (Oct 27, 1867,Trip to the Thames Gold-fields,29,1978 ed.)

THATCHER A digger comes up here [to Grahamstown], say from the West Coast,/ To go out prospecting, .../ .../ Discovers a reef, and his fortune is made./ .../ He rides in a carriage, race-horses he buys,/ And the people who fawn on this reefer the most,/ Would have turned up their nose at him on the West Coast./ (1869,Wit and Humour: Local Songs...,24) [NOTES: (Gold) Also in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 55]

McGILL Joseph Berry wrote in the Cromwell Argus:/ Gone is the old `forty-niner',/ Gone, like the days that are past,/ Gone is the sturdy old reefer,/ Gone to his haven at last! (1982,Ghost Towns of NZ,46)

reefing¶

n. [goldmining] (See also quartz-reefing)

As a reefing country, I am convinced that the small portion of land now open is wonderfully rich. Let the reefers once obtain machinery, and depend upon it the yield will be enormous. (Oct 27, 1867,Trip to the Thames Gold-fields,29,1978 ed.)

As a reefing country, I am convinced that the small portion of land now open is wonderfully rich. Let the reefers once obtain machinery, and depend upon it the yield will be enormous. (Oct 27, 1867,Trip to the Thames Gold-fields,29,1978 ed.)

HOLLOWAY The rising reefing district of Lyell. (Jun 24, 1874,Journal of a Visit,121)

... the oldest reefing-district in New Zealand [is] ... Coromandel. (1887,Handbook NZ Mines,362)

1890 Mines Report 157 in 1948 NZ Geol. Survey Bull. No 42 (N.S.)/39 (1890,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No 42 (N.S.)/39) [NOTES: (Gage, Reefton)]

Stone is found in detached blocks along the line of reefing country for 600ft. to 700ft. and runs in narrow scams rich in gold ... . (1890,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No 42 (N.S.)/39) [NOTES: 1890 Mines Report 157 in 1948 NZ Geol. Survey Bull. No 42 (N.S.)/39 (Gage, Reefton)]

... a central belt of reefing-country. (1890,Papers Read at the Mining Conference,33)

The Try Fluke vein or branches of this vein carrying payable values, were soon traced into the Mariposa, Red Mercury, Great Mercury, and other claims, and it was therefore considered that here at least, a permanent reefing-field existed. (1907,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,4(N.S.)/16) [NOTES: (Fraser and Adams, Coromandel)]

n. [goldmining]

An application for a licensed holding at Mahakipawa has been lodged at the Warden's office. It is north of the Bright Smile and west of the Welcome claims. The name is the Success Coy.; area, 30 acres; capital, GBP10,000; mode of working, quartz reefing by machinery; term, 21 years; day of hearing, 21st prox.; James R. Brimor and party. (Oct 31, 1888,Evening Post,2)

PFAFF As to reefing, the efforts to prospect have been largely sporadic, and ... there is a feeling that this main source of Westland's gold supply has never been truly tried. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,88)

BATHGATE Quartz crushing for gold ... [or] `reefing' (1874,Colonial Experiences,95)

BARRY We must sell out the business and go reefing. (1879,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,164)

Reefing is being carried out at a number of places. (1906,Mining Handbook,5)

HEINZ Reefing is made more difficult by the bush cover over most of the hill country and no doubt many rich reefs have thus been passed over. (1952,Prospecting for Gold,21)

reefing country¶

n.

There is good reefing country in the crosscut now. (Jun 14, 1904,Grey River Argus,3)

For this week the western crosscut from No 3 level south has been extended 16ft; total 112 ft through good reefing country with more leaders than previously. (Dec 22, 1911,Grey River Argus,2)

Mr. Bleazard had charge of this party of seven men, and remained with them in Coromandel for about three months, at his own charge, while giving his time for nothing. On his return to Auckland, he gave a written report to the treasurer, Captain Salmon, the purport of which was that Coromandel would in all likelihood prove a good quartz reefing country, but would never be worth for alluvial diggings. (Jun 24, 1862,Daily Southern Cross,3)

As a reefing country the Inangahua bids fair to be unsurpassed. (Nov 9, 1870,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

Dunn.. is satisfied that the country.. is both an alluvial field and good reefing country. (Sep 26, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

reefing district¶

n. [goldmining]

According to promise, I send you a few lines about our Thames goldfield. .. There is no doubt about this being a rich reefing district, but you must wait patiently until the stone can be crushed before you have gold in any quantity sent to town. (Sep 16, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,4)

Great attention is now being given to the Paparoa reefing district. (Oct 14, 1897,Otago Witness,19)

Everything seems to point to the fact that the time is not far distant when a valuable reefing district will be opened up in the neighbourhood of Browning's Pass. (May 2, 1905,Grey River Argus,2)

No great importance need be attached to the fact that the quartz is rather peculiar looking and very different in quality and appearance from any seen in the Inangahua or any other known reefing district in New Zealand or Australia, because Nature shows diverse methods in the composition of her auriferous lodes. (Oct 29, 1910,Grey River Argus,4)

reefing field¶

n.

This little game has been enacted on every reefing field, but yet people do not take warning. (Mar 3, 1883,Otago Witness,15)

This is the primary and essential difference between such a reefing field as that at the Thames and an ordinary alluvial digging. (Sep 28, 1868,Daily Southern Cross,2)

Vigorous prospecting will now follow, and as all such legitimate enterprise is being liberally subsidised by the Hon. Mr Cadman- who, by the way, has become a fast favourite among the diggers here - the chances are that next summer may see a permanent and payable reefing field opened up in this locality. (Jul 19, 1894,Otago Witness,16)

That formation in a reefing field means a prolonged life of exploration, of working activity, of steady gold returns depending upon the length of the "makes" or "runs" of gold in the reefs operated upon. (Aug 4, 1923,NZ Truth,13)

reefing locality¶

n.

When on the ground Mr Travenor also went to see most of the now deserted mines in the neighbourhood of Macetown .. and expressed himself surprised that such mining chances were allowed to lie unimproved ; and it will only depend upon the success of the works now in progress at the Premier whether or not Macetown will come once more to the fore as a reefing locality. (Mar 31, 1892,Otago Witness,15)

This is a very satisfying result, as, in addition to being encouraging to the enterprising prospectors, it is another proof of the richness of the Rough Ridge as a reefing locality. (Jan 1, 1881,Otago Witness,14)

I am personally acquainted with many of the old Coromandel miners, whose faces I meet in the various reefing localities. (Sep 20, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,3)

reefy¶

adj. pertaining to a quartz-REEF [goldmining]

What little prospects have been got are not of an alluvial character at all, but a light reefy nature. (Aug 29, 1867,Grey River Argus,2)

They found what they term a "reefy rock" about two feet in thickness. (Feb 22, 1872,Tuapeka Times,5)

.. for instance, one hole may show a grayish drift from under the surface soil to the washdirt, another yellow clay mingled with small quartz, and the next a brown reefy formation, and so on. (Jul 25, 1885,Otago Witness,12)

.. but in two or three driblets of creeks coming out from Arm Chair mountain (and evidently on "the strike" of Bradcock's reef) we got several very nice prospects of course [sic] reefy gold. (Mar 5, 1898,Marlborough Express,2)

The gold won from Glasseye Creek [Mt. Radiant] was for the most part of a coarse `reefy' nature, the particles generally varying in weight from 0.5 (half)gr. to 5 dwt. (1910,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No. 11 (N.S.)/37) [NOTES: (Webb)]

reelerman¶

n. [(papermakers')]

HILLIARD `I'm in the papermill ... I'm number two reelerman on number one paper machine.' (1978,Glory and the Dream, The,251)

reelman¶

n.

reelman n. Austral. & N.Z. the member of a beach life-saving team who controls the reel on which the line is wound. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,963) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 409]]

Reevesian¶

adj.

Dr Sinclair's approach to history is New Zealand `whig' or Reevesian, and Reeves has pride of place in his dedication. (1959,Comment,1/28)

referee¶

n. a person deciding claims in a disputes tribunal [Jim Cameron writes : a special NZ meaning]

referee abuse¶

n. abuse of and attacks on sports referees

Referee abuse has reared its head again, this time in Manawatu club rugby... Manawatu Referees Association president Terry Silcock confirmed referee abuse had happened in the FOB-Oroua match and that it was called off four minutes early. (May 26, 2003,Sunday Star Times,D1)

reference sire¶

1 n. (Rural) [stud stock breeding] a select and closely studied ram or bull used for artificial insemination.

Some reference sires are used in successive years to create genetic links, which allows EBVs to be compared across years. Other reference sires are replaced by superior rams, identified by their across-flock EBVs. Thus the reference sires have a dual role, creating genetic links across flocks and years and producing more rapid dissemination of genetic improvement. (Sep 27, 2002,Dominion Post,C7)

reffo¶

n. (informal) a referendum

The great compulsory super reffo is held. (May 16, 1997,Independent (Auckland),18)

reform fatigue¶

n.

While a lot has been made of the Prime Minister of New Zealand's reform fatigue, I don't subscribe to it. (Feb 16, 2006,NZ Herald,A14)

Reform Party¶

n.

SINCL,AIR The agitation over these two issues [land and labour] led to a double revolt which split the Liberals and led ultimately to the formation of the two chief parties of this century - the Reform Party which, in combination with the remnants of the Liberals, eventually became the modern National Party, and the Labour Party. (1959,History of New Zealand,196)

reformative detention¶

n. (historical) [also as RD below]

BURTON If one man gets five years' H.L. and another five five years' R.D. the latter is likely to emerge perhaps six months before the former. (1945,In Prison,132)

At the other end of the scale is the indeterminate sentence of preventive detention. A sentence of the same name existed in Britain from 1908 to 1967. Introduced in New Zealand in 1954 to replace the sentence of reformative detention (1910) and declaration as an habitual offender and habitual criminal (1906), it remains very much alive here. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

refreshing¶

n.

It does not appear to me that this Bay has been much used for the purpose of refreshing, ... (Nov 1, 1831,Journal) [NOTES: 1831 Nov 1 J.Biscoe Journal in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 415]

refreshment counter¶

n.

MULGAN `If you make me tea blacker than the foulest brew ever stewed [197] at a railway refreshment counter, I'll drink it with delight.' (1934,Spur of Morning,196)

refreshment room¶

adj.

A man named Morting a refreshment room keeper at the Station, was fined today for abusing and assaulting the station master. (Aug 5, 1881,West Coast Times,2)

SHADBOLT There were three stale-looking refreshment room sandwiches inside. (1959,New Zealanders, The,42,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (After the Depresssion)]

n. (See also refreshment rooms)

WARNER'S HANDSOME COUNTER ENGINE for refreshment rooms in railway stations or other public buildings, or for raising water to washhand stands in Gentlemen's houses . . . (Feb 24, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,4)

The recently erected Refreshment Room by Bealey Flat. which has been completed by the Railway Department, was handed over to the proprietor, Mr. John Brake, last week, and was opened on Saturday evening last by a splendid ball at which the whole of the community was entertained. (Sep 1, 1914,Grey River Argus,3)

Early this morning a fire broke out in the refreshment room at Te Aute, and the whole of the station buildings and post and telegraph offices were destroyed. (Oct 11, 1895,North Otago Times,3)

You'd have a problem finding a cup of tea at the Taumaranui railway station - the refreshment rooms were closed down in 1975. (Sep 28, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

At about two o'clock yesterday morning the railway station, refreshment room, and ladies' waiting rooms at Mercer, were completely destroyed by fire, caused by a heated stove pipe passing through the wooden walls. (May 20, 1879,Hawke's Bay Herald,2)

A PASSENGER was left behind in a railway refreshment room recently. He got new bread in a sandwhich and swooned. (Sep 12, 1929,NZ Truth,6)

McNAUGHTON One or two faces, wanner than the rest, had grown familiar to me during innumerable excursions to railway refreshment rooms the day before. (1986,Countless Signs,175) [NOTES: From R.A. Copland (1977, first published in Listener 1950) :Yes, to the Very End]

refreshment rooms¶

n.

At Mercer railway station are large refreshment rooms where most of the trains and expresses stop for all meals on the long journey between Wellington and Auckland. (Feb 9, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,1)

In the case in which a man was charged with a breach of a prohibition order, he being found in the bar of the Railway refreshment rooms, Magistrate James decided that a refreshment room was not a licensed house within the meaning of the Act, the license for refreshment rooms being now issued by the Minister for Railways, not by the Licensing Committee, as prescribed by the Act. (Nov 21, 1903,Northern Advocate,3)

TURNER ... the New Zealand refreshment rooms on railway stations are notable. -->[check KMansfield Urewera Notebook] (1966,BLANK ENTRY,157)

WILSON I walked across [the Palmerston North platform] and went into the refreshment rooms. (1976,Pacific Star,150)

refreshment station¶

n.

FENWICK [Towai] is not a refreshment station ... as the train stops for only a few minutes ... (1922,Romance of the Flora & the Farthest North,44)

refreshments¶

2 n. fresh non-salt food and water [(whaling)]

ELDER The establishment of the Mission there will tend to the security of the South Sea whalers, who put into the island for refreshments (Mar 15, 1814,Marsden's Lieutenants,46,1934 ed.) [NOTES: 1814 Mar 15 Marsden in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 46]

ELDER On this day also, Captain Edwards of the Mercury brig, a South Sea whaler belonging to Mr. Jones of London, went into the harbour of Whangaroa for refreshment, ... (Mar 5, 1825,Marsden's Lieutenants,238) [NOTES: 1825 Mar 5 William Hall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 238]

... besides, having a chance of procuring refreshments from that Island, our salt provisions being of first consequence (should we [416] not succeed in falling in with anything in passing round) for the remainder of the voyage. (Oct 10, 1831,Journal) [NOTES: 1831 Oct 10 J.Biscoe Journal in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 415-416]

So you pop off to Refreshments for a cupper tea and pie In Taumarunui, Taumarunui, on the main trunk line. (Sep 28, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

regatta shirt¶

n.

Anyone purchasing a Regatta Shirt for 9s 6d will receive a Real Silver Set of Studs. (Sep 20, 1890,Taranaki Herald,1)

Stripe and regatta shirts. (Sep 3, 1840,New Zealand Advertiser and Bay of Islands Gazette,2)

Regatta shirts, new patterns, usual price 4s 9d, sale 1s 11d. (Jul 22, 1909,Evening Post,1)

Here will be found the newest things in ties, regatta shirts, boater straw hats and the latest in felts. (Dec 19, 1916,Grey River Argus,4)

Men's regatta shirts, 2s 6d, 2s 9d, and 3s, &c., &c., &c. (Dec 23, 1872,Evening Post,1)

In SHIRTS and MEN'S MERCERY, CASEY AND M'DONALD have just opened up a complete choice in men's Oxford shirts, men's regatta shirts, undershirts and pants, boys' Oxford shirts, boys' regatta shirts, white shirts, scarfs, bows, braces, belts, &c. (Nov 23, 1883,Evening Post,1)

Give to Richards Whaheen 10 regatta shirts, ... and 5 pairs of lambs-wool hose to get daubed. (Jul 14, 1842,Piraki Log,139,(ed. Anson 1911) ed.)

ANGAS Young Tamiti may now be seen on horseback, riding swiftly along the shores of the lake [Taupo], his only garment consisting of a regatta shirt, that flutters loose in the breeze. Ibid. 2/161 The payment which I made each of them [sc Maori guides] consisted of a couple of large blankets, a regatta shirt, and a pair of trousers, with which they were highly delighted and perfectly satisfied. (1847,Savage Life,2/112)

[TABLE of Duties of Customs] Slops, Trousers, Moleskin and Tweed, per pair ... 0 4 [d] ... shirts ... Regatta and cotton striped ... (1854,Canterbury Almanac, The,93)

HUNT Upon that day I had donned a fancy regatta shirt of a most florid pattern. (1866,Chatham Islands,12)

reggie¶

n. (item of) registered mail

MACRAE Warwick the mailroom supervisor stood at her elbow. A sheaf of blue-crossed letters was in his hand. `Only five reggies today.' While she signed for the registered mail ... (1988,Awful Childhoods,53)

regib¶

v. to reline with Gib(raltar board)

It's not going to prevent you re-gibbing and insulating your lounge. (Nov 5, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

Every external wall has been insulated and every internal wall re-gibbed, with the main bedroom having been stripped back to the framing... (Jun 4, 2003,Dominion Post,C12)

Since then the back of the house has been opened up into a north-facing kitchen-dining-living area, two small rooms upstairs have been turned into ensuite bathrooms, and the rest of the house regibbed and recarpeted. (Jul 18, 2001,Evening Post,18)

The walls in the two original bedrooms were regibbed, and the lean-tos and garage at the back of the house were strengthened and joined to the main house... (Dec 28, 2002,Dominion Post,E8)

Mr and Mrs Edwards have re-piled, re-wired, re-plumbed, re-gibbed and insulated the 85-square-metre dwelling. (Apr 28, 2004,Dominion Post,C12)

We've re-gibbed throughout.... (Jul 21, 2004,Dominion Post,C15)

I have been waiting for the council's decision before regibbing and renovating the units so I can start earning a living again"... (Jul 13, 2004,Dominion Post,A6)

regimental boys¶

n.

SINCLAIR & HARREX The third [echelon] turned up in Egypt in a new uniform and were referred to by 'grim digs' (old Kiwi hands) as 'the regimental boys'. (1978,Looking Back,215)

Regional Council¶

n.

In an updated assessment only last April, the Otago Regional Council proclaimed a much reduced risk in Alexandra. (Dec 4, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

regional plan¶

n. [Jim Cameron writes : also district plan. These compounds have a distinctive meaning in NZ in relation to resource management that DNZE does not record. See Resource Management Act 1991.]

regional station¶

n.

The four YZ stations - at Rotorua, Napier, Greymouth and Invercargill - were termed "Regional Stations"; they put out a good healthy ten kilowatts of signal and they were regional in fact as well as in name. (Aug 2005,NZ Memories,55 / 13)

registrar¶

n.

registrar ... 4. Austral. & N.Z. the chief medical administrator of a large hospital. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,967) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 410]]

registry office¶

n. the preferred NZ form to "register office" which seems to be increasingly used in the UK [NZ Catholic March 7 2004 reprints "register office" in an editorial from The Tablet of London, Jan. 24, 2004.]

rego¶

n. Aust. abbreviation of 'registration' (of a motor vehicle), used loosely in NZ for what is strictly 'relicensing' [also spelt reggo below]

The fine for normal possession is $120, which is less than no reggo on the car. (Jun 27, 1998,Dominion,15)

On arriving at the site, your rego sticker is checked against a database... (Aug 20, 2002,Dominion Post,D3)

The tyres are down to the canvas and they have no rego or warrant. (Jan 17, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,2)

n. motor-vehicle licence plate number [Austral. abbreviation of 'registration']

I then left but as I was not happy I recorded the rego of the red car. (Sep 17, 2003,Norwester,1)

regrassing¶

n.

[He] began regrassing at the rate of 100 hectares a year. (May 16, 2003,Dominion Post,C5)

Staggers is a problem for his stock in the autumn and he is part-way through a regrassing programme using novel endophyte ryegrass, though he says he still has reservations about the benefit of regrassing. (Mar 14, 2003,Dominion Post,C8)

Rehab¶

n.

Mr Saleman said his father went through "rehab" after the war and became a carpenter, mechanic and ran his own stevedoring company. (Mar 16, 1999,Dominion,3)

`Now, chaps, what about a spot of Rehab.?' (1945,Sixes & Sevens,16)

SCOTT `This block's a Soldiers' Settlement. You know the sort of thing. Under Rehab.' I didn't know till he explained. Rehab meant the Rehabilitation of Returned Soldiers, a Government department. It advanced money to buy farms ... (1953,Breakfast at Six,12)

n. [incl. attrib. uses]

A Rehab. officer outlined the scheme; he offered opportunities for learning carpentering, ... and a host of other trades. (1945,Sixes & Sevens,5)

I had a bursary,' said the Grim Dig.Reading, writing and rehab. - every soldier's right.' (Mar 25, 1959,Upper Hutt Leader,5)

SLATTER I was living in Christchurch at different times, at varsity on Rehab [no stop] for a while. Ibid. 146 -Rehab was the caper you jokers. Got on the carpentry course. Gone into building. Ibid. 163 While the other Rehab jokers got through I was doing everything but swotting. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,28)

KEINZLY `There's a dozen jobs waiting to walk into. I can even apply for my rehab and crash out on my own.' (1960,Tangahano,50)

PEARSON When he came out of the army he got a Rehabilitation grant to finish his B.A. The clerk at the Rehab. office advised him to do this. (1963,Coal Flat,26)

TURNER Rehab, ... was a common word in the years following the Second World War for `rehabilitation', referring to loans, bursaries and other help given to returned soldiers (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,172)

HILLIARD ... he'd never really thought of himself as a soldier or an ex-soldier even though he'd had two years of it before ... eventually going farming on rehab money. (1969,Green River,22)

WILSON Well, the Rehab people were sympathetic to my request. (1976,Pacific Star,156)

rehab (farm sold on favourable terms to returning soldier) Ibid.. 6 We lived out in the wop-wops then - on a rehab place, miles from town up a metal road. Apart from a mate on the next farm I didn't have much to do with anyone outside the family. There was the Plunket Nurse, of course, when the baby was little. And the Bon Brush man, and a few other salesmen. (1988,University Entrance Board Bursaries Exam)

n. the Rehabilitation Department, which was set up to help servicemen returned from World War II. [ORIGIN: abbreviation, Formed [?d] and ceased as a separate department [?d]: also freq. attrib. or in combin. REHAB. DEPARTMENT, -LOAN (special low interest loans to servicemen), -MONEY etc; and used a a noun. Rehab. is fixing me up with a loan' or, esp.,I got my loan under Rehab.' referring to the Department or its officers or policies in general. Contract with NZ WW1 repat qv, and British and Austr. Repat. WW2 (1952 Apr 28 Bluey and Curly, Austr cartoon, use repat. (R.Mason). The abbrev. is the usual or expected one: (cf Part: rehab. official abbrev. of rehabilitation ward or department in a hospital since ca1945)]

The smaller ones [sc. builders], however, are shying away.. from "rehab. jobs". (Aug 6, 1947,NZ Observer,11)

Most rehab farmers did make some sort of a fist of it. (Jun 4, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

KEINZLY My rehab. housing loan and part of my capital has made it possible. (1960,Tangahano,255)

Rehab bursary¶

n.

The others made good use of their Rehab Bursary, made up for the years in the services or behind the wire in the stalag, but I was a washout. Ibid. 239 Blew my back pay on God knows what. Loused up my Rehab Bursary. Never even sent for my campaign medals. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,37)

SLATTER While on a Rehab Bursary he gained his Masters Degree. (1968,Pagan Game, The,16)

rehab block/ rehabilitation block¶

1 n. (Rural) a farm, composed of marginal land or from a large privately-owned property, for which returned servicemen ballot.

FEARON He built his house and woolshed on a flat section of land above the river, and in the 1920s procured an extra portion of land from the 'Rehab' block lying to the west ... (1980,Te Wharau,182)

FEARON Rollet lived in an Army hut close to the Tyneside homestead - as did the other single men who had drawn Rehab. blocks. After extensive repairs and replacement of the rabbit fence around all the Rehab blocks .. a programme of poisoning was embarked on. (1980,Te Wharau,189)

When the men came home from World War I, they were given the rehabilitation blocks. (Dec 22, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,13)

rehab farm¶

n. [WW1]

Dave McGovern took over until after W.W.I. when.. a returned serviceman was settled on it as a Rehab. farm. (1987,Alfredton,315)

SIMPSON I sent the local secretary of the RSA ten pounds towards expenses in getting the man secure on his farm, which was a rehab. Farm. (1974,Sugarbag Years,48)

n. [WW2]

We saw his name in the paper for winning a Rehab. Farm ballot. (Mar 1954,Landfall,8(1) No. 29 : 18)

They were breaking in their 526 hectare rehab farm - Anerley - nearly 70km east of Masterton, (Jun 24, 1983,Dominion,P6)

1 n. (Rural) a farm for which returned soldiers ballot.

PEAT The real managers of this 'rehab' farm were the rabbits. (1992,Falcon and the Lark, The,46)

STACEY They were mostly rehabilitation farms and the majority were not dedicated farmers but were placed by the government on unsuitable country where they eked out a peasant lifestyle until mortgages and other miseries drove them to walk off. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,42)

STACEY Lindsay Ferguson offered me a job with him on a rehab farm at Tetley Brook. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,155)

After returning from war duty, Mr Luxton drew a ballot for a rehab farm at Okato. [rehabilitation farm] (Nov 29, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17)

Rehab farmer¶

n.

Most rehab farmers did make some sort of a fist of it... I fully agree.. about the rehab farmers' wives. (Jun 4, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

HENDERSON Mac, a canny rehab. farmer, took his truck into Invercargill, let loose his two prize dogs, and said, "Now enjoy yourself, have a good time, but be back in two hours or no more leave." (1990,Soldier Country,141)

Till the 1980s, a generation of people unique to Australia and New Zealand owned the land. They were rehab farmers, granted their land from a grateful nation for deed and suffering endured in two world wars. (Apr 4, 1993,Sunday Times (NZ),25)

Rehab League¶

n.

?Rehab League, for rehabilitation of handicapped accident victims The Rehab League [title] I am writing to express concern about the article on the Rehabilitation League NZ (Inc) published in the April issue of your magazine. (Jun 1987,NZ Outlook,5)

Rehab loan¶

n. [also Rehabilitation loan below]

Our little nest egg grew slowly and 1950 we had the opportunity to buy a furnished house in Miramar on a Rehab Loan available to returned servicemen. (Apr 2002,NZ Memories,35/48)

With the help of a rehab loan, I belatedly sat for and obtained my engineering qualifications. (Jan 1992,North & South,61)

SLATTER My own house and paying it off on the Rehab. Loan at three percent. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,117)

TURNER A house may be bought with a rehab loan or a State Advances loan. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,172)

DAVIES As soon as the land was ours, Charlie applied for a Rehabilitation Loan to build a house. (1984,Bread and Roses,74)

rehab man/rehab cocky¶

1 n. (Rural) a returned soldier farming a rehab block in a soldier settlement areas.

FEARON His land was not much good for dairy cows however, and when he sold out, the land was subdivided between Engal and two other 'Rehab' men from the Westmere - Bannister and Wyeth. (1980,Te Wharau,183)

HILL I'd have been farming today on my own, and there's not many Rehab. cockies that've gone broke. (1990,Between the Rivers,108)

Rehab officer¶

n.

[Hdg] Value of Maori Rehab. Officers. (Dec 5, 1945,People's Voice,3)

SCOTT It was the Rehab officer in charge of this settlement and others. (1953,Breakfast at Six,53)

rehab scheme¶

1 n. (Rural) a policy that allowed returning servicemen to purchase farms, usually undeveloped and from larger holdings.

The original owner, who had acquired the farm under the rehab scheme after World War II was still running the property. (Nov 16, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,15)

rehab settler¶

n. (Rural) a farmer settled on the land through a Returned Soldiers' Rehabilitation Scheme.

John and Margaret Thomas came to Stronvar as rehab settlers 35 years ago .. When you started as a young rehab settler in the days when the main aim was to quickly become debt-free and stay that way, it's not easy to add even more to your debt load.. (May 27, 1982,NZ Farmer,14)

GORDON Perhaps because so many of our clients were Rehab settlers who, with wives and young families were working hard to establish themselves ... (1996,Trouble with Stock Agents, The,77)

rehabilitation¶

n. (See Rehab)

BOYD The way in which the executive committee of diggers' immediately opened its ranks tokiwis' and gradually made way for them ensured the RSA strong, continuing support. A postwar rise in membership of `diggers' indicated their willingness to help with rehabilitation. (1984,City of the Plains,312)

Rehabilitation Department¶

n. [also Rehab Department below] (See Rehab)

Rehabilitation Department n. N.Z. a government department set up after World War II to assist ex-servicemen. Often shortened to rehab. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,968) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 641; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 411]]

CASEY I might have known there was something fishy when he said he'd been so messed up by the Rehab. Department that he wasn't going back to them. (1963,As Short a Spring,110)

HILLIARD He'd had to bum around for a few years before approaching the rehab - [for a loan]. (1969,Green River,39)

rehe¶

n.

Names - The general name is upokororo (`head full of brains'), derived from the fatness which characterizes it. The small ones are also called rehe, and the large size tirango. (1926,TrNZI,58/638) [NOTES: (Buck)]

rehia¶

n. a species of seaweed [ORIGIN: Maori]

A few also of the sea-weeds were eaten; such as, the Karengo, (A tidal species of Laminaria found plentifully from the East Cape to Cape Turnagain), the Rehia, the Rimurapa (D'Urvillea utilis, and some others . (1869,TrNZI,I/III/32) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)..]

Reinga¶

n. (usu. as the/Te Reinga) the northernmost place in NZ, where the departed spirits take flight

This area includes all the most northern portion of New Zealand from Te Reinga Point (where the spirits of the old Maoris were supposed to plunge off into the unknown) down to Matapai, on the east coast. (Aug 1, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,5)

From the far-off Ruapuke's coast / To Reinga's haunted height, / The warrior Clans, a countless Host, / Are gathering in their might. (Apr 17, 1858,Taranaki Herald,2)

COLLINS In his chart Too-gee has marked an imaginary road which goes the lengthways of Ea-hei-no-mawe, viz. from Cook's Strait to the North Cape, which Too-gee calls Terry-inga. While the soul is received by the good Ea-tooa, an evil spirit is also in readiness to carry the impure part of the corpse to the above road, along which it is carried to Terry-inga, whence it is precipitated into the sea. (1804,English Colony in NSW,345)

Whether in Niu Tireni or Te Reinga/ Now you live, or in countries over the ocean - (1949,Centennial Treasury of Otago Verse,110) [NOTES: 1949 Currie Centennial Treasury of Otago Verse (`Epilogue') 110]

LEE & KENDALL R|einga, s. The place of flight, a descent on the side of a rock near the North Cape ... where it is supposd that the departed spirits of the natives take their flight; (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,202)

I am told the spirit hovers about the body and place of the deceased until the third day, when the priest prays and directs the spirit to the reinga, a place at the North Cape where the natives say the spirits go to and descend. (Aug 2, 1822,Journal) [NOTES: 1822 Aug 2 John King in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 254]

WILLIAMS She spoke of the excellency of the Reinga as having conversed with many from thence. (Dec 23, 1832,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,269,1961 ed.)

WILLIAMS They had much to say about Te Uarahi having died and after taking a survey of the Reinga returned to deliver his account. [ed fn] Te Reinga, the abode of the dead. It was the Maori belief that the dead travelled to Te Reinga [lit., `the leaping place'] at the northernmost tip of the North Island, and there jumped over the cliff into the place of the dead. (Jun 23, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,320,1961 ed.)

W.G. PUCKEY The whole body of New Zealanders firmly believe in the Reinga as the only one place for their departed spirits. As soon as the soul leaves the body it makes its way with all speed to the western coast; if the spirit of a person who resided in the interior, it takes with it a small bundle of the branches of the palm tree as a token of the place where it resided; if one who lived on the coast, the spirit takes with it a kind of grass which grows by the seaside, which it leaves at different places on the road to the Reinga. (Dec 1834,Journal) [NOTES: 1834 Dec W.G.Puckey Journal in 1863 Maning Old New Zealand (1948 edn) 318]

YATE to the Reinga, a place of torment (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),140) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

WILY & MAUNSELL When a great man dies, it is customary for a slave to be killed, whose spirit, it is said, departs with him to the Reinga to minister to him. (1938,Robert Maunsell,67) [NOTES: 1839 Nov 2 in WILY & MAUNSELL Robert Maunsell (1938) 67]

POLACK The chiefs are accounted of divine origin by their followers, whose spirits after death are supposed to reign in an abode of the gods called Te Reinga, whose entrance is situated at the gloomy caverns beneath the sea-worn cliffs of the North Cape, (Muri wenua. ) (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/58)

TAYLOR A singular circumstance was related of this fish [Hinanga], that it comes from the Reinga - (Hades) that there are many openings in the side of Tongariro ... (Jun 26, 1846,Journal)

TAYLOR We were off the Reinga this morning when I went on deck, (May 22, 1847,Journal,V/166)

BULLER The abode of spirits, they ascribed to a place called Te Reinga, at the north cape. (1883,Forty Years in NZ,201)

DOMETT (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/250)

LADY MARTIN This cliff was called the Re-i-nga, i.e., the leaping-place. Some who lived near this spot used to affirm that on certain nights they could hear the rush of the spirits as they passed on their way. (1884,Our Maoris,79)

FINLAYSON The time was opportune for another feat-day. ... there had not been a marriage ... for months now; and among the long-lived little community, neither had the occasion for a tangi arisen, altough it was evident that poor old Honi Tawa was not far now from the road to the Reinga. [134 ed. note] 2. `not far from the road to Reinga.' [sic] A traditional Maori way of saying close to death, when the spirit of the dead was said to join its ancestors in the mythical homeland of the Maoris, Hawaiki, across the Pacific Ocean, departing fom New Zealand at Cape Reinga. (1938,Brown Man's Burden,3, 134,1973 ed.) [NOTES: (Wedding gift)]

HULME Love of dolphins, love of whales/ show me the way to Te Reinga/ (1982,Moeraki Conversations,38) [NOTES: 1982 Hulme The Silences Between (Moeraki Conversations) 38]

n. (as the/Te Reinga)

MANING One of the ancestors of Haurake ... hearing, even in the R[ei]nga, (the Maori hades) of the warlike renown of one of his sons, became jealous of his fame, . (1862,War in the North,22 fn)

All were alike firmly believed to be remembrances of what they had seen in the reinga, or unseen world (or place of the departed,) whither the spirit (Wairua) was supposed to have been during the sleep of the body. Ibid. I/III/42 ... this haunting spirit, or phantom, (Kehua,) which haunted its former place of residence, when in the body, ... differed widely from the sensible intellectual spirit (Wairua), which had departed to the reinga and which was not feared. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/41) [NOTES: (Colenso Maori races)]

To `te Reinga', or into the darkness under the earth, went the spirit of the ordinary Maori. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,159)

TREGEAR The spirits of dogs were supposed, like those of men, to pass to the World of Shadows (Te Reinga) but they travelled by a different path than that taken by the souls of human beings. (1904,Maori Race, The,169)

COWAN Her warrior brother Hitiri ... was not long in following her to the Reinga. (1935,Hero Stories of NZ,115)

Reinga: spirit world. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

reinsman¶

n. a harness-race driver

Leading reinsmen at Rangiora were astonished by the ease with which he worked. (Dec 26, 1999,Sunday Star Times,B14)

reinstouchments¶

n. [(WW2)]

Bruno [The cook] hearing of the unexpected arrival of a number of reinstouchments snarled to his offsiders. (1944,Desert Daze,49)

reinstoushers¶

n. reinforcements [WW1]

The last reinstoushers rush the mess-room tables. (Sep 19, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,63) [NOTES: -->nf P:]

REINZ¶

abbr. Real Estate Institute of New Zealand

REINZ president Rex Hadley says the figures bode well for the 2002 residential property market. (Jul 2, 2002,Independent Herald (Wellington),1)

The Real Estate Institute of New Zealand (REINZ) believes that an auction " will always achieve the best price available since it is no different than a private treaty negotiation where a buyer and seller will haggle until they agree... Ibid. 21 The REINZ reports that "bait pricing, price banding and vendor conditioning are actively discouraged by the REINZ." (Sep 18, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

Reischek's parakeet¶

n.

Red-crowned Parakeet Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae (SPARRMAN, 1787) ... There are four subspecies of the red-crowned parakeet in New Zealand: the New Zealand red-crowned parakeet Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae novaezelandiae, the Kermadec parakeet C.n. chathamensis, and Reischek's parakeet C.n. hochstetteri. OTHER NAMES: Kakariki, New Zealand parakeet, Antipodes red-crowned parakeet. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,248)

221.d. Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae hochstetteri (Reischek, 1889) Reischek's Parakeet Antipodes island. (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,59,1980 ed.)

reject¶

n. a silly person [1984 15-17 F E2 Pakuranga Coll. 1 REJECT [a silly person] [F12 M15] -->1984 14 F E141 Wgton Girls C. 1 REJECT -->1984 14 F E123 Wgton Girls C. 10 REJECT [useless person]]

1 n. (Rural) [drafting] a cull or an animal deemed not prime enough for slaughter.

MILLS ET AL When drafting was finished my mate and myself helped the drovers take 5000 'fats' four miles across country to the main road, while the rest of the shepherds returned the rejects to their block. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,119)

GASCOIGNE It is a relief to finish a pen and run the sheep off through the race; sound mouths, which have been headmarked, to the right and rejects to the left. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,14)

rekamaroa¶

1 n. (Rural) a variety of kumara. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Since the variety of "Waina" came into possession of the Natives they have gradually discarded most of the other varieties with the exception of a few varieties such as the Uti-uti, Taromahoe and Rekamaroa, the other kinds being mostly small, rough, and irregularly shaped and light croppers. (Oct 20, 1914,NZ Journal of Agriculture,280)

The group is seeking "the varieties of kumara in Aotearoa be restored to the control of Maori" and full commercial rights to the hutihuti, rekamaroa and taputini varieties ... (Feb 1, 2007,NZ Herald,1)

Rekohu¶

n. the main island of the Chathams

Moriori call Chatham Island Rekohu and neighbouring Pitt Island Rangiauria. (Jul 10, 2004,Dominion Post,E6)

The Moriori are said to have arrived 1000 years ago and they called the main island Rekohu, meaning the misty sky or misty sun. (Jun 26, 2004,Dominion Post,E1)

relax¶

n. At C.U.C. a week free of lectures before finals exams. Ex relaxation'. Whencerelax. ball'. [? 1930s Canterbury University College Seems to go back a long way.]

release agent¶

n.

Release agent- Substance usually applied to the form face to prevent adhesion of the concrete to the form. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,52)

release pen¶

n.

She found the release pen full of sheep. (Apr 6, 1966,Weekly News,454)

releaser¶

n. a mechanism for removing milk from under vacuum and discharging it to atmospheric pressure [(farming)]

The Game Releaser.. is automatic in action, being operated by and working simultaneously with the pulsator. (Aug 28, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,5)

TURNER The parts of the [milking] machines are named, the cups which attach to the cow's teats, the rubber inflations inside the cups, the pulsators which regulate the vacuum and the releaser. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,149)

Releaser: A mechanism for removing milk from under vacuum and discharging it to atmospheric pressure. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,42)

relief¶

n. (historical) esp. in phrase on relief: doing relief work

Jackson could not get regular work and in the end he went on "relief". (Jan 1937,Tomorrow,3 (5): 154)

HYDE You can always pick the new chums on relief. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,207)

DAVIN The Depression was knocking at the door ... half the people on Relief, ... (1959,No Remittance,190)

Then the Slump came. The builder went broke [153] and for months I was on relief. (1984,Some Other Country,152) [NOTES: 1970 Middleton `The Loners' in 1984 Some Other Country 152-153]

TAYLOR With the leak days of the Depression only a little behind men who had known relief camps and pannikin bosses had no zest for more mud and for Army sergeants; ... men still on relief had little urge to fight for the country that had given them so little. (1986,Home Front,1/72)

relief camp¶

n.

The methods adopted by the Public Works Department in several relief camps is not one that commends itself as an argument for registration. (Mar 6, 1930,NZ Truth,1)

VIRTUE Tom was in a relief camp, somewhere south of Hamilton, digging ditches and felling trees for the Government. (1991,Always the Islands of Memory,95)

Unemployed men on relief works marched to the Town Hall at midday to interview the Mayor and to protest against the relief camps. (Apr 13, 1932,Auckland Star) [NOTES: 1932 Apr 13 Star (Auckland) in 1974 Edwards Riot 1932 14]

HYDE Wicked, I call it, taking men away from their families and sending them to those relief camps, leaving [296] the women at home. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,295)

SINCLAIR The unemployed were put to work draining swamps, making roads-or golf courses-planting trees, and were paid a miserable sum party raised by special taxation. In many of the rural `relief camps' conditions were extremely primitive; ... (1959,History of New Zealand,250)

SHADBOLT You remember what it was like in the depression? All the single men being shipped off to relief camps? (1965,Among the Cinders,140)

RENEE If you go with them you might as well give up and go to the relief camp. (1985,Wednesday to Come,39)

There's a Public Works Relief Camp a bit along the road,' he said.A few bob a week and tucker, better than nothing.' (Aug 1986,Islands,37)

TAYLOR With the leak days of the Depression only a little behind men who had known relief camps and pannikin bosses had no zest for more mud and for Army sergeants; ... men still on relief had little urge to fight for the country that had given them so little. (1986,Home Front,1/72)

relief centre¶

n. a charitable centre

...it should be added that Raewyn Dalziel.. oddly ignores the phrase "relief centres" in her title and leaves the charitable aid system quite out of the picture... (Sep 3, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),109)

relief depot¶

n.

HYDE They ... work three days a week shovelling bits of coast in the relief gangs, for whom award wages are a bright and sweet dream from a dead generation. They cadge vegetables and coal at relief depots and welfare departments, ... (1936,Passport to Hell,15)

The rapid rise of in the number of unemployed in 1931 put the relief system under severe strain ... Relief depots began to run out of provisions. ... dismissing workers and and re-employing them at relief rates. ... But of all the schemes to help the unemployed help themselves, the one that aroused most hostility was that of the relief camps; ... (May 1987,Metro,143)

relief gang¶

n.

HYDE They ... work three days a week shovelling bits of coast in the relief gangs, for whom award wages are a bright and sweet dream from a dead generation. They cadge vegetables and coal at relief depots and welfare departments, ... (1936,Passport to Hell,15)

FINLAYSON (1936,Brown Man's Burden,65)

relief milk¶

1 v. (Rural) to relieve as a dairy milker.

In addition, Tim White relief-milks from mid-August until AB has finished at the start of December. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,28)

If you need someone to relief milk after the 20th of January .. I relief milk and I charge $15 an hour when assisting and $30 an hour sole charge plus mileage. (Nov 2000,Fencepost.com,4)

Farm staff wanted, partner to relief milk ... [relief-milk] (Jan 5, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,29)

relief milker¶

1 n. (Rural) a milker of a dairy herd, employed on a relieving basis.

Then there is the time the relief milker put the treated cows' milk in the vat when you were away for the day. (Mar 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,48)

Relief milker wanted for weekend milking.. (Feb 24, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,24)

Those farmers will then be able to employ relief milkers or have enough employees who can work a 40-hour week. (Mar 23, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,16)

The real issue runs deeper than what to pay a relief milker. (Feb 22, 2001,Fencepost.com,Generaldogsbody)

Several of my friends are relief milkers and won't step into the shed for less than $40. (Sep 5, 2001,Fencepost.com,gelynos)

Relief milker required ... (Nov 13, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,23)

Have you booked a relief milker? (Nov 2001,Dairying Today,15)

relief milking¶

1 n. (Rural) the temporary milking of a herd for its owner or permanent milker.

I think the money expected for relief milking is getting a bit out of hand. (Dec 29, 2000,Fencepost.com,Trossachs1)

I've just started out doing a bit of relief milking around Rangiora. (Feb 1, 2001,Fencepost.com,Stucameron)

Couples available for relief milking ... (Dec 22, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,25)

relief officer¶

n.

HYDE `You waiting to see the relief officer? He's a friend of mine.' (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,273)

relief pay¶

n.

FINLAYSON (1938,Brown Man's Burden,16)

relief shafter¶

n.

She [sc. a horse] was a relief shafter. (1988,Recollections (various authors/titles),30)

relief work¶

n. work provided under scheme 13 during the Depression

SARGESON relief: a Government work scheme for unemployed during the depression. Relief work was often part-time and often work of little perceivable immediate value -- clearing drains, grubbing gorse, draining swamps, making roads, planting trees, etc. (1964,Collected Stories,302) [NOTES: Pearson Glossary]

NORRIS ... a scheme for creating some work for the unemployed was developed at Te Kauwhata ... The men on relief work cleared the ground of scrub and 810 acres were then ploughed by contract. nf P8: [but relief was general US term for govt work scheme 1930's : also covered non-work aid on relief] (1964,Settlers in Depression,210)

relief work(s)¶

n.

[Hdg] Relief Work on the Road. (Aug 2004,NZ Memories,No. 49/30)

As one of the Waikato military settlers, I suggest an amendment in the proposition of Norton Butler's Waikato relief works. To his project of a Government experimental farm we have no objections. (Apr 2, 1866,Daily Southern Cross,5)

Two hundred and eleven men have been taken on the relief works, and no more can be accommodated. (Aug 20, 1895,Wanganui Herald,3)

The stone masons are asking for no concessions, no relief work, but merely for the right to perform work on behalf of the country that wants doing, and that has been decided by the peoples' representatives should be done. (Mar 27, 1915,Evening Post,3)

CHRISTCHURCH, June 15. The City Council discussed the unemployed trouble last night, and resolved to start relief work for the most necessitous cases of married men, provided permission is obtained from the union secretary to pay incompetent men less than the minimum wage. (Jun 15, 1909,Hawera & Normanby Star,5)

Government is providing relief works for the unemployed. (Mar 11, 1886,Grey River Argus,2)

WAIKATO RELIEF WORKS. (Feb 27, 1862,Daily Southern Cross,6)

BRADSHAW The New Zealand Government is pestered by applicants who desire more `relief works' to be undertaken at public expense. (1888,New Zealand Of Today,175)

A number of local bodies also provided a limited amount of `relief work' [for unemployed]. (Sep 10, 1921,Quick March,36)

Unemployed men on relief works marched to the Town Hall at midday to interview the Mayor and to protest against the relief camps. (Apr 13, 1932,Auckland Star) [NOTES: 1932 Apr 13 Star (Auckland) in 1974 Edwards Riot 1932 14]

HYDE Relief works have occupied the energies of more than one New Zealand writer who, by using brain instead of pick, shovel ... (1934,Journalese,45)

HYDE Men on relief works were being turned off, unless they had wives and families. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,274)

SINCLAIR ... the ragged army of men on the dole' - as they called the payments forrelief work'; architects, teachers, carpenters, chipping chipping weeds on the footpaths; ... (1959,History of New Zealand,250)

ELDRED-GRIGG Then he was on a scheme they had going [c.1930], what they called relief work. (1987,Oracles and Miracles,23)

relief worker¶

n. (historical) a scheme 13 worker

BOOTH He had worked with shovel and wheelbarrow building that road he pointed out with such pride and yet with such bitterness, its pattern snaking up the Wainui-o-Mata hill above Wellington Harbour, where he had worked with hundreds of other Relief workers from rough, cold camps spread across New Zealand in those first years of the 1930s. (1997,Deadline : My Story,32)

Should investigate conditions of relief workers employed by his department. (Apr 3, 1930,NZ Truth,1)

Can anyone explain why the same amount of road work done by the relief workers at 10s a day is done by the "Cockie friends" of the Reform Party at 18s per day or more on contract in the summer time? (Oct 14, 1922,NZ Truth,13)

FINLAYSON (1938,Brown Man's Burden,16)

SARGESON But the first of these people with a purpose was a fellow relief worker, and I will call him X. (1975,More Than Enough,42)

STEWART Frank used to pick up groaning loads of scoria from a quarry in Onehunga and lumber them out to the road's end, wherever that was: groups of `relief' workers lived under canvas, a sad army separated from wives and families in pursuit of the only work available to them, moving on as the road moved. (1981,Hot & Copper Sky,63)

So he often was [a man of leisure], between leaving Auckland Grammar School without matriculation in 1921 and returning to Auckland as a married man in 1933, to go on the roads as a relief worker. (Feb 6, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

relief workers' jam¶

n. golden syrup

LOCKE She regularly walked two miles to a shop which sold "relief workers' jam" (golden syrup) a halfpenny cheaper. (1984,Kauri & The Willow, The,175)

reliefer¶

n. person on relief work

The case of the reliefer today was particularly hard when sickness came his way. (Feb 27, 1934,Feilding Star,5)

reliever¶

n. a relieving teacher [ca1930s at least]

relieving teacher¶

n.

Mr Snelson gave notice to move for the appointment of an assistant inspector, who should be also relieving teacher when occasion required. (Jul 26, 1882,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

EDUCATION BOARD. .. That a relieving teacher be appointed at a salary of GBP175, with bonus and travelling fares. (Jul 28, 1883,Otago Witness,8)

Sir, - Allow me, through the medium of your paper, to protest against the action of the Education Board in sending Mr Moore, the new teacher of Dudley Road School, to be relieving teacher to some other school, as by so doing it is most unfair to Mr Moore and the children ... (Sep 14, 1900,Taranaki Herald,1)

EDUCATION BOARD. .. Resolved that subject to the approval of the School Committee, a relieving teacher be at once sent to this school, and that Mr. Payne leave for Hawera on the arrival of the relieving teacher. Leave of absence to attend the Supreme court sittings in New Plymouth, as a witness, was granted to Mr. Payne. (Mar 15, 1898,Hawera & Normanby Star,3)

Miss Kelly, who has been relieving teacher for the last term, left to-day for Gore. (Dec 20, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3)

TURNER Later he may become a relieving teacher (corresponding with the English teacher on supply). (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,158)

relievo¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH Further, because He was an awesome person, he had to be very carefully chosen, and so the mysterious counting-out rhymes were used. Despite his powers, however, his potency could be minimized in many games by the fact that the players helped one another fight against him (e.g., Bedlam, Relievo, Kick the Block). (1981,History of Children's Play,52)

religious Rawleighs people¶

phr.

Just how the religious Rawleighs people [sc. door-knocking evanglists] face up to enough rejection to flatten a therapist is the big question - along with why they even bother. (Mar 10, 1999,Evening Post,23)

religo¶

n. a religious objector to war service (See cf. hoon)

HAMILTON They reckoned he'd stuck to his religion all through and the Hoons [fn Non religious groups.] gave me the impression that he took his religion seriously and to them he was a bit of a joke. You couldn't take much notice of the Hoons of course, not about a thing like that. Most of them just lumped the religoes together ... Ibid. 164 There was a sort of line drawn in the [detention] camps betwen the Hoons and the religoes. ... The religoes were divided again into God knows how many sects and amongst the hoons were absolute pacifists, pacifists, Communists, Anarchists, humanists, and plain dodgers. Ibid. 215 The third group [in conscientious objectors' detention camps], the religoes, could hardly be called a group at all. It was a mixed bag of Methodists, Presbyterians, Brethren, Church of England and some Catholics. (1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,154)

CRYER People who were conscientious objectors on other than religious grounds were known to the military as hoons (the other were called religoes). (2001,Curious Questions,102)

relish¶

n. in New Zealand, a sweetened savoury preserve made of chopped and grated vegetables or occasionally fruit

Relish can also be used in a generic sense to mean a spoonful of something tasty served to enhance a plain food, although in New Zealand a relish is usually a sweetened savoury preserve made of chopped or grated vegetables - occasionally fruit - in which the vegetables retain some firmness of texture. Therefore, you could say that a New Zealand relish is a type of pickle, or that a New Zealand pickle is a type of relish. (May 15, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

rellie¶

n. (informal) a relative [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Basingstoke in Hampshire is the buckle on England's computer belt, and was our base for the excellent reason that there we could sponge off rellies. (Mar 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 50/4)

Some of our best friends and rellies studied the law and they seem to be perfectly nice people. (Jun 12, 1992,Dominion,6)

Last Saturday Manuel deftly polished balding heads and passionately embraced diners he had mistaken for rellies from Barcelona. (Mar 3, 1992,Evening Post,7)

When the rellies left, he went to a particularly grotty tattoo parlour in an old whaling port and said "Pierce the damn ear." (Oct 30, 1999,Dominion,18)

"If we go away for a holiday we don't stay in flash pubs, we stay with rellies. (Jul 1991,Metro,51)

For Jake and Beth Heke there's nothing that can't be solved by an all-night drunken party, their "reles" and friends crowded round the beer crates, singing sentimental songs into the wee small hours. (May 14, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48)

Artistic Connie.. has come on her own to the family hut in the Wairarapa to avoid the rels and her 50th birthday. (Aug 4, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

Where else are they so big on hypocorisms? ... They're those dinky little words we make up, like these: kiddies (children), cardies (cardigans), boatie (person who sails boats), yachtie (person who sails yachts), drinkies (drinks), bikies (people who get together to ride motorbikes), wrinklies (old people), rellies (relations), wellies (Wellingtons, as in gumboots), wallies (variation on wankers), littlies (children). (Sep 1988,North & South,41)

Those strangely infantile condensations - prezzies' andrellies' (for presents and relatives) were bandied about on the radio quite a bit recently. It looks as if they are going to join veges, ciggy, brekky, cardy - and all the rest as OK idiom. But there is one antipodean expression that charms people internationally ... That is the word `naughty', for sexual intercourse. (Jan 10, 1989,Evening Post,6)

rellie-hunt¶

n.

Visiting British junior minister for schools.. limbered up one of his officials for a big rellie-hunt at the Waitangi Foundation AGM the other day. (Apr 20, 1993,Dominion,6)

relocatable¶

adj.

PEDDIE Now she also has the use of one of the "relocatable" classrooms across the lawn from the staff-room. (1977,Christchurch Girls' High School,195)

n. relocatable building, prefab (classroom)

They look like very faded, very shrunken relocatables ("relocatables" being Ministry of Education jargon for.. prefabs). (Apr 24, 1992,Dominion,11)

reluctant fish¶

phr. a watersider scared of working under the hook

EVANS Union officials who had sought a paid union job because they were work-shy were sometimes called 'reluctant fish', because they were deemed to be scared of going near the hook. (1999,Where Giants Dwell:,59)

remand home¶

n.

(1966,Short Stories (various authors),101) [NOTES: 1963 Duggan in 1966 Short Stories 101]

remanufacturing¶

n.

The partnership also covers the Waipa mill, Waipa remanufacturing plant and a wood-processing plant at Mt Maunganui, which together employ more than 500 people. (Nov 16, 2002,Dominion Post,C3)

remark¶

v. to mark again (See cf. track)

DOC contractors cleared vegetation and remarked sections of track along 16 km of track in the western Tararuas. (May 2004,Footnotes,No. 21/2)

remerchandise¶

v. "shuffling the shelves" - a Placemakers employee's definition

Sign in Placemakers, Thorndon: We hope you will bear with us while we are remerchandising. (Apr 6, 2005,Ephemera)

remit¶

n. a recommendation sent by a branch or by an affiliated organisation of a body to the main body (often an annual conference) for consideration, and possible adoption and action. [(1921) ?d. B. Sutton-Smith A History of Children's Play [TS] 277 [footnote] quoting 1921 Feb Journal of Education -->18th Meeting NZEI Remit 12 (Southland) -->ca1930's (mid) R.Mason]

A number of remits referring to classification and salaries were withdrawn. (Jan 6, 1902,Colonist (Nelson),3)

A further recommendation to the Directors was then carried "That they forward a remit to the next Conference of the South Island Dairy Association, pointing out the advisability of bringing down a standard set of articles for use in the South Island." (Sep 13, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,4)

Mr. Johnson moved the Taranaki remit, That the desirableness be urged upon the Minister of having a uniform set of text books in use in the schools throughout the colony. (Feb 1, 1902,NZ Journal of Education,3/247)

A `remit' proposed by Mr Johnson was adopted. (Oct 1, 1902,NZ Journal of Education,4/177)

To Shear and Expert That Remit No. 7 be struck out, i.e. - ...That no shearer be allowed to shear and expert on the same board.' ... That no shearer expert and shear on a board of more than five shearers.' <i>Ibid.</i>. 15 Mount Watkins Remit No. 3:That an allowance in the case of daggy sheep be arranged for,' was dealt with; ... it was decided: `That all members refuse to dagg [sic] sheep during shearing except the dagging rate be added to the shearing rate, as we are of the opinion that dagging is not shearing. (1912,NZ Shearers (Report Third Annual Conference),11)

Some N.Z. Remits. [heading] The following are some of the remits proposed for discussion at the Empire Conference by the N.Z.R.S.A. (Feb 10, 1921,Quick March,40)

REMIT PROPOSED / LABOUR DAY CHANGE ... the Wellington Labour Day Committee has again discussed the desirability of having this statutory holiday changed to a more seasonable time of the year. (Nov 10, 1947,Evening Post,8/8)

TURNER The noun remit ... means a directive from a branch to a central organization for consideration. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,174)

MITCHELL remit: Resolution. (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,183)

remit ... 7. proposal from branch put up for central decision (1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,412) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; NZPOD 644]]

remittance¶

n.

MACKIE It is frequented by young men of some education with a little money, and whilst their money lasts they give themselves up to riot and excess. ... they remain in obscurity until their remittance brings them again to the Wakatu. (1852,Journal) [NOTES: c1852-53 Frederick Mackie Journal in 1973 Traveller Under Concern p? in 1979 Noland Bad Old Days 43]

ROCHFORT The other two ... had just finished their `cadetship,' that is, they had been learning sheep-farming under a settler, and were waiting for a remittance from their friends in England to begin on their own account. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,20)

MACKIE This inn - the Wakatu - is the most disorderly and uncomfortable house that we have seen in the colonies. It is frequented by young men of some education with a little money, and whilst their money lasts they give themselves up to riot and excess. They are probably such as their friends in England are glad to send to a distance and as if to confirm their ruin supply them with a small income. As soon as this is squandered they go to the Wairau as shepherds ... Here they remain in obscurity till their remittance brings them again to the Wakatu. (Apr 26, 1853,Traveller under Concern,102,1973 ed.)

HARPER A few days later he came, and told me his story, common enough in Australia, but at present much less so in New Zealand, where we have fewer of those failures at home who are sent out to the Colonies, in the faint hope that a man who is a ne'er-do-well in England will succeed elsewhere, and in too many cases sent out with the promise of small remittances, to be out of sight and out of mind. (Jul 20, 1861,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,61,1914 ed.)

THATCHER They [swell loafers] swear they'll tip without fail,/ And gammon with wondrous anxiety,/ They expect a remittance next mail,-/ It's an ancient dodge... ./ (1862,Auckland Vocalist,2)

Rumor gave out that a small annual remittance from the old country kept the Squire's head above-water (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,25) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

BATHGATE `Oh! bother my uncle, though he did send me a small remittance the other day,' was Arthur's rejoinder; ... (1881,Waitaruna,145)

BELL ... in a low but displeased voice he led the way outside. `What the devil brought you here? Did I not tell you to keep to yourself and not cross my way, except when you come to my office for your remittance. ... (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,126)

Take the `jackaroos' on a station; ... They get a remittance which keeps them in clothes, l[e]ggings and riding breeches, and an occasional trip to town. ... They are practically banished from the old country to save the family from being disgraced, and this place is being made a dumping ground for these wastrels. (Jul 2, 1910,NZ Truth,262/6/7)

~ n.-remitt'ance man n. a person living on periodical remittances from his family. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,9)
