LANCASTER No good record attached to this young sprig of the nobility who (said rumour) had been cashiered from the Hussars and squeezed by anxious relatives into an infantry regiment sailing for the colonies, the relatives promising that he would receive a handsome remittance so long as he stayed there. (1938,Promenade,135)

(Oct 1982,Metro)

McGILL Remmers Remuera, in the trendy nickname Remuera-ites have given what they regard as Auckland's - and New Zealand's - most exclusive suburb. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,92)

remittance day¶

n. the day a REMITTANCE MAN'S allowance is paid

When remittance day comes round furtive townspeople hang around the post-office to waylay if possible the Englishman, and if waylaid he is the soul of honour, and squares up all his debts. (Oct 14, 1905,New Zealand Free Lance,12)

LEE Fill it up [with whisky] it's remittance day. (1944,Shining with the Shiner,76)

McLAGLAN Each remittance day they used to get very drunk indeed, often got the D.T.s and had to be taken into the Auckland Hospital for treatment; . (1965,Stethoscope & Saddlebags,185)

remittance man¶

n. (Rural) [joc] a station cadet from England.

station cadet from England: remittance man. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

1 n. (Rural) a victim of the British class system paid to live and work in New Zealand to avoid bringing shame to his family in the home country [usually employed in rural areas as shepherd, boundary keeper, musterer etc.]

Socially, the better type of remittance man - for there are grades even in remittance men - is a great favourite. (Aug 14, 1912,Otago Witness)

We learn from the Wellington Post that one of the first uses made of the Australian cable was by a remittance man. He telegraphed to his friends in England "Lend me GBP20." The answer received was "Paid for your telegram and this - balance per mail." He is now waiting for the mail that will bring him about enough to acknowledge the receipt by post. (Mar 4, 1876,West Coast Times,2)

SCRYMGEOUR Some slackness had been apparent, especially amongst the "Remittance" or Imported Men. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,68)

It was explained by the police that Jones is a "remittance man." (Oct 20, 1938,NZ Observer,7)

He gave evasive answers to the police and others who inquired the whereabouts of a remittance man, who subsequently was found drunk in the hotel. (May 21, 1901,Colonist (Nelson),3)

There were the Remittance Men. Rather colourful characters, the so-called 'Black Sheep' of some well to do family in far away England. The 'R'Men received a regular allowance from home, accompanied by a polite note suggesting that it would be better for all concerned if they would remain out in the colonies. (Jun 2002,NZ Memories,No. 36/16)

MARSH The Remittance Man. The chap whose people used the colonies as a wastepaper basket. (1966,Black Beech & Honeydew,203)

These young men were soon known as "remittance men" and in some cases remained so until the end of their lives. (Feb 8, 1956,Weekly News,44)

See that house? A remittance man from Ireland lived there. Got his sister in the family way. (Mar 2005,NZ Geographic,72/25)

There were the remittance men, rather colourful characters, the so called "black sheep" of some well to do family in faraway England. The "R" men received a regular allowance from home. (Sep 1999,Ohinemuri Regional History Journal,43 : 14)

BATISTICH A Remittance Man meant of good family, maybe a lord's family even, but they didn't want him at home where they could see him, so the black sheep was shipped off to New Zealand, well out of sight, and money sent out regularly to support him. (1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,82)

How often the remittance man would get to the letter-box, only to get the reply, "No letters." (Nov 5, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

He was a drinker, as were, I believe, a number of other remittance men. (Aug 1994,Quote Unquote,16)

Remittance Man 'Black sheep' of often upper class family sent to the colonies and paid a remittance. (1989,Chosen Place,104)

Just on the edge of The Settlement there lived a person called Sam, who it was said was a remittance man and from a well to do family in England. (Jan 2004,Onslow Historian,No. 34(1/2) : 6)

....There was the litle chap who wore shorts,.. 'Jack', the remittance man from England who lived at Waiheke and came up on the boat to hob-nob with the trammies waiting to change shifts down town... (Aug 2003,NZ Memories,No. 43/45)

BRADSHAW He ultimately settled down into the position of a 'remittance man' - living, that is, upon a pittance sent out from home and doled out in weekly instalments by a solicitor. (1888,New Zealand Of Today,171)

TINSLEY Speegles was what was known as a remittance man. (1985,Cheese Punchers' Ball, The,83)

HARTLEY Remittance men were so out of place - like a giraffe amongst the manuka. (1993,Colonial Outcasts: A Search for the Remittance Man,27)

HARTLEY One of Southland's earliest landowners was a remittance man. (1993,Colonial Outcasts: A Search for the Remittance Man,79)

remittancer¶

n. a remittance man

D'AVIGDOR [Colonialisms] A remittancer' in Australia is a ne'er-do-well who has been sent out from England by his friends and receives a monthly remittance as long as he [170] keeps away. No one will give aremittancer' work if he can obtain anybody else to do it, and the remittancer generally spends his monthly allowance in three days, living very badly on credit till his money next arrives.) (1888,Antipodean Notes,169)

SCRYMGEOUR Another memory that lingered on the trip, was that from Napier to Gisborne, to inspect a property known as Te Rapa' and nearby was apubbery' (certainly not a hotel, for anybody would wonder why the Licensed Victuallers Association ever granted a licence for meals or liquor to be dispensed), and was typically designated The Trap'. Truly, this pubbery was just short of shanty, typical of theOuter Barcoo', but where Maories, their Wahines, or broken down Remittancers' could drown their sorrows, wander into thearms of Bacchus' or chase pink elephants. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,157)

Remmers¶

n. the Auckland high-rent suburb of Remuera -

"We don't go: 'Yo, I grew up in Remmers, I had it so bad!' she laughs. (Jul 11, 2004,Sunday Star Times: Escape,8)

Come on Remmers, Fendalton, Khandallah, pull your socks up! (Sep 26, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

He may be slick at baring tits and bums in his trashy Daily Phews but commercially he lacks that touch of class that distinguishes the real Remmers socialist from the brash Sydneysider or Melbournite. (Jun 1999,Metro,25)

New National candidate Richard Worth is an elegant, traditional Remmers Tory figure, a partner in a major law firm, a Northern Club type. (Nov 20, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

Simply everyone's yapping about D'Argento's - an ultra ritzy little boutique in Remmers. (1982,Metro,13)

No I could not book a table for 7pm at scorching hot new Remmers bistro Banque, I was told firmly. (Nov 2005,North & South,134)

Any alliance that combines unwashed lentil munchers with Remmers blond bobs deserves to be stopped. (Feb 16, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A9)

...she insists she is no "Remmers girl", pointing to one of Ms Hasler's blue-and-white billboards. "Look at that billboard. So who looks like a Remuera girl?" she snipes. (Jul 20, 2002,Dominion Post,A8)

The Parn-hell post office.. has been sold to.. a man.. who.. has operated out of humble and unassuming Remmers. (Apr 1993,Metro,24)

Who lives in Remmers? Answer the Newly Weds and the Nearly Dead. (Aug 4, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

remora¶

n. suckerfish

GREY The little remoras, or sucking fish, were clinging to him, and dropped off as we hauled him astern. (1926,Angler's Eldorado,39)

REMORA, SHARK-SUCKER, SWORDFISH-SUCKER or SUCKING-FISH, Remorophysis brachypterus (Lowe) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,340,2nd ed.)

DOOG UE & MORELAND REMORA or SUCKERFISH ... Other names: Remora remora; suckerfish, shark sucker. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,286)

MORELAND SUCKERFISH or REMORA [Remora brachypterus] ... Shark-sucker is an alternative name. (1967,Marine Fishes,52)

WILSON REMORA The Remora, or Suckerfish, is a common inhabitant of our warmer, northern waters. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,182)

AYLING REMORA (Suckerfish) Remora brachyptera ... The remora is well known to most people as the shark's companion; ... (1982,Collins Guide,214,1984 ed.)

[index to common names 283-293] remora 1334-46 REMORAS 1334-46 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

remu¶

n. (See rimu)

Remuera taxi¶

n.

Dubbed the Remuera Taxis, they are otherwise known as Sports Utility Vehicles (SUVs), All Purpose Vehicles (APVs), Four-by-Fours (4 x 4), Recreational Vehicles (RVs) and four-wheel-drive (4WD) trucks. For many, they are now the family vehicle of choice, replacing the sedan and the stationwagon. (Jul 1998,AA Directions,60)

Remuera tractor¶

n. [cf. Fendalton tractor (and Australian Toorak tractor)]

"Who's got a four-wheel drive and who really needs one?" "Remuera tractors." said a provincial caller... "Remmers bitch waggons, for picking up the kids outside St Kentigerns," said another caller. (Aug 26, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),63)

Another winning strategy will be to develop fuel-efficient "hypercars" rather than foster a growth of gas-guzzling 4WD Remuera tractors. (Aug 28, 1998,Dardanelles Driveller,6)

Four wheel drive vehicles are in. Apparently called "Remuera tractors" by one of our more colourful MPs, they are now to be seen everywhere. (Jul 1997,AA Directions,36)

"The Remuera tractor or the Merivale taxi," says the dealer. "Mums feel safe in it..." (Nov 30, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

..it features 12 chapters on Jafanese culture with tips on cellphone fashion, ordering coffee, and how to get the best from your Remuera tractor. (Jul 21, 2004,Capital Times,10)

However, even tractor-drivers in the remotest corners of rural New Zealand must realise the harsh effect on the economy as the Remuera tractors grind to a halt, twice a day, entangled in Auckland's Spaghetti Junction. (Dec 7, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C7)

Remuneration Authority¶

n.

Earlier in the day, the House dealt with the Remuneration Authority Bill, which gives a renamed Higher Salaries Commission the power to determine certain expense allowances for MPs but, controversially, keeps the power to determine other allowances with a parliamentary body. (May 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 63/70)

remuremu¶

n.

LAING & BLACKWELL Selliera radicans (The Rooting Selliera) ... Maori name, Remuremu. (1940,Plants of NZ,345)

RICHARDS Selliera ... radicans ... Creeping Selliera. REMU-REMU (tail feathers). (1952,Chatham Islands,45)

Goodieniaceae Selliera radicans remuremu (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

remuster¶

1 v. (Rural) to make a second muster or gathering of stock.

EVANS This [poor weather during a muster] meant remustering parts of the block and inevitably sheep were missed. (1975,Silver Tussock, The,6)

So that meant remustering them [lambs] a couple of weeks later for a vaccination jab. (Dec 2000,Growing Today,63)

renga lily¶

n. variant of rengarenga (See rengarenga)

Liliaceae Arthropodium cirratum renga lily (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri]

rengarenga¶

n. also called renga lily, rock lily a drooping-leaved lily with branching flower-stems, found in open rocky situations from Cook Strait northwards [ORIGIN: Maori]

The coastal lily rengarenga is replacing agapanthus and nikau palms and cabbage trees are much in vogue. (Oct 14, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

Seek ye the rengarenga that holds the drifting spray, / And bring your offspring forth likewise in numberless array. (Oct 21, 1897,Otago Witness,46)

Rengarenga roots were eaten by Maoris after being either roasted or cooked in the steam oven, and said to taste like potato. (Dec 3, 2005,Dominion Post Indulgence,23)

LEE & KENDALL R|enga r|enga; A plant so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,202)

YATE ... or the root of the Rengarenga (Arthropodium cirratum), scraped and applied ... to bring forwards any abscesses or tumours, where matter is forming. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),89)

HOOKER Arthropodium cirrhatum, Br. ... Nat. name, Renga Renga', in Northern Districts, andMaikai Ka', in Southern, Colenso. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 254)

HOOKER Rengarenga, Col[enso]. Arthropodium cirrhatum (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

The blanched bases of the leaves of the harakeke (Phormium), and the roots of the rengrenga or maikaika (Arthropodium cirrhatum), were sometimes roasted and beaten to a pulp and applied warm to ... abcesses. (1869,TrNZI,1/1-58) [NOTES: 1869 Colenso TrNZI 1/1-58 (On the Botany of the North Island) in 1981 Brooker et al. NZ Medicinal Plants 15]

TREGEAR .. the roots of the New Zealand lily (rengarenga: Arthropodium cirrhatum) had to be cooked in the oven before becoming fit for food. (1904,Maori Race, The,99)

CHEESEMAN A[rthropodium] cirrhatum, R.Br. ... Rengarenga. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,719)

On the rocky knoll near the middle of the [Karewa] islaet the rengrenga, or rock-lily (Arthropodium cirratum), grows in profusion ... (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/187) [NOTES: (Sladden)]

rengarenga, a lily (Arthropodium cirrhatum), likes open rocky situations. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,66/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

McLINTOCK Rengarenga (New Zealand lily) .. .. rengarenga .. .. Arthropodium cirrhatum (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

BROOKER et al. Arthropodium cirrhatum(Forst.f.) R.Br. Common name: Rock lily Maori names: Rengarenga, maikaika, maika ka (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,63)

The [cliff-hanging] plants chosen were the poor knights lily (Xeronema callistemon) and ringaringa, also called the New Zealand rock lily (Arthropodium cirrhatum). (May 10, 1973,Dominion,5/1)

rengarenga lily¶

n. Arthropodium cirratum

Renga-renga lily or rock lily (Arthropodium cirratum) - Tufted, fleshy leaves are surmounted by numerous, usually arching stems bearing many clusters of white, pendulous flowers. (Nov 11, 1993,Evening Post,14)

The rengarenga lily edges part of his long sweeping drive, and he says the plant is a "landscaper's dream. (Dec 21, 2000,Evening Post,15)

This is.. a good year; the rengarenga (lily of the valley) is in bloom. (May 3, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,17)

This is no hardship for the native Renga-Renga Lily (Arthropodium cirratum) which grows in drifts here. (Jan 1990,NZ Gardener,24)

CROWE Rengarenga, Rock Lily... The plant is sometimes known as renga lily or Mabel Island lily (after an island of this name near Picton, where the plant is particularly striking). An alternative Maori name for the plant, maikika, is shared with two native orchids that have similar, starchy, edible root-like tubers. (1995,Which Coastal Plant?,44)

renos¶

n. (informal) renovations [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Something about dipping into a late pal's estate (well, he wasn't going to complain, was he?) to finance the renos on his lavish pile. (Sep 26, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

rent-racker¶

n. variant of rack-renter

It [N.Z.] is the Paradise of the wealthy squatter, the fat landlord, and the rent-racker. (Apr 8, 1911,NZ Truth,302/1/1)

rental¶

n. NZ Library jargon -->ca1930s when started dropping subscription libraries and moving to free libraries (with special and limited rental sections for light popular fiction) -->cf W.J. McEldowney History of NZ Library Association 1910-1960 -->No spec mention cf W3 something rented

McELDOWNEY The Fiction Committee of the Association in 1942 compiled a list.. with the division into free and rental collections in mind. (1962,NZ Library Association,75)

How would life without rentals be carried on? (Aug 1968,NZ Libraries,31(40 : 131)

A recent review.. has shown that desk income from rentals is not keeping pace with spending on the collection. (Jun 1981,NZ Libraries,43(6) : 98)

rental collection¶

n. [(librarians')]

TURNER Another of New Zealand's contributions to library science, the rental collection or pay collection, reflects the other side of the New Zealand character. Rental collections in free Public Libraries provide `popular' books not justifiably bought with public money, and sometimes also duplicate books in heavy demand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,159)

Rentokil¶

n. [proprietary name]

The obvious solution is for Labour and National to take time from their busy schedules of blackguarding one another, and do a Rentokil job on Winston. (Jun 11, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

reo police¶

n. Maori language police

It wouldn't impress the reo police. (Jun 1998,Mana,No. 22: 35)

reo, te reo¶

n. (the Maori) language [ORIGIN: Maori]

The growth of kohanga reo and kura kaupapa has created families where the youngest children are comfortable speaking te reo, but their older siblings, born too early, are less so, and their parents can hardly speak their own language. (Jul 24, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),66)

It is hard to imagine anyone outside the tiny Te Reo Maori clique wasting time watching Tuku Morgan's million-dollar series on Pacific migration. (Mar 10, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C6)

[Hdg] $11 million for te reo teachers. The Government yesterday announced it would spend $11 million over three years to help teachers in te reo Maori (Maori language). (Nov 25, 1997,Evening Post,2)

IN THE PRESS AND WILL SHORTLY BE PUBLISHED, TE HIKOI TUATAHI KI TE REO MAORI: or, First Step towards the Maori language; with Conversational Phrases, and a short Vocabulary of easy words; arranged as an Anglo-Maori School Book by R.D. (Mar 30, 1861,Hawke's Bay Herald,6)

Says Kiwitea to Makino, / I'll run into you clean O. / Says Makino to Kiwitea, / (i te reo Maori) - Pea. (May 10, 1895,Feilding Star,2)

E KORERO KOE I TE REO MAORI? (Do You Speak Maori?) (Jun 13, 1927,Evening Post,8)

"This will have people talking," noted Wells happily, "possibly in te reo." (Dec 18, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),71)

I really want to be fluent in te reo. I love the language .. The Maori language is exquisite. (Nov 27, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

We would like to see it reach everyone, so there is a holistic, committed approach to making te reo Maori accessible to all New Zealanders. (Jul 4, 2000,Dominion,2)

We need at least 100,000 speakers of Te Reo if we want the language to survive. (Jun 28, 2001,Contact (Wgtn),1)

So that puts to rest the theory that here was another young sportsman (like Adam Parore) with a Maori name and a tendency to mispronounce the reo. (1995,Mana,10 : 9)

I had lost my reo big time ... (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,15,Autumn ed.)

The film stars Maori actors speaking te reo, subtitled in modern English. (Feb 9, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)

And given the tedious showing-off that occurs every time Maori is spoken in Parliament .. the whole house could do with a course in both te reo and common good manners. (Jan 26, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

HOWE Reo - while the word is often translated as 'the language', this explanation hides the fact that the Maori language is revered as a living record of its people, and enshrines the ethos of the people. No one can fully know `te reo' unless one is acquainted with the proverbs, legends, histories and knowledge of all tribal groups and areas. Yet it is a lifetime work knowing 'te reo' of one's own tribal area. (1985,Towards Taha Maori,22)

And to top it all off, the Royal New Zealand Navy has allowed Timothy to regain his reo rangatira. (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,15,Autumn ed.)

[Miria Simpson's] contribution was such that she was heralded simply as "Te Reo" by the hundreds who gathered to farewell her at Victoria University's Te Reo Waka Marae on Tuesday and yesterday. (Jun 13, 2002,Evening Post,9)

reoreo¶

n.

358 ... the most important [Chatham Island] edible sea-birds: AS WRITTEN AS PRONOUNCED ENGLISH hopo ho[macron]p' albatross hakoakoa ha[macron]ko[macron]k' mutton bird taiko tchai[macron]k' pied shear water tupoupou tchu[macron]poup' pied blue billie reoreo ro[macron]ro[macron] Mother Carys chicken turiwati tchu[macron]riwat' dottrel [sic] kuaka ku[macron]k' snipe (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs,IX No. 5 pp. 343-382)) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382)]

n.

LEE & KENDALL R|eo r|eo; A shell-fish so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,202)

rep¶

n. a member of a representative sports team [ORIGIN: abbreviation, cf P: politician, athlete, cricketer representing a State: Austr ca 1920; (?) cf WF n. (3) since c 1900]

I would like to see our reps. rigged out in new amber and black jerseys. Some of those in use at present are "holey" unfit to be donned by a rep. (Jul 14, 1892,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

Nothing daunted, this ex-Southland and ex-Wellington Rep. (who, by the way, appeared in a Wellington jersey and long pants) secured from the next line-out to break through and dribble 25 yards in an astonishingly expert manner. (Jul 19, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3)

A paragraph in last night's Herald, re the football match on Saturday "Reps" v. "All-comers," concludes thus - "It is to be hoped that every endeavour will be made toward the inclusion of the Turakina contingent." (Aug 25, 1891,Wanganui Chronicle,3)

Eyton The Tauranga Reps. (1896,Rugby Football,10)

There is little doubt but that Mr. Arneil will succeed in getting together a fifteen that, even if not quite up to last year's touring "reps.," will nevertheless be equal to making a good fight of it with the best the sister provinces can put in the field against them. (Jul 6, 1900,Auckland Weekly News,Suppl. 9)

HISLOP Everybody knew him as a rep. in the Otago [rugby] team, ... (1943,Pure Gold,36)

rep 3 ... 2. N.Z. inf. a rugby player selected to represent his district. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,974) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact]

adj. representative (often collocated with match, player, etc.) [some noun uses in citations below (see also rep, reps noun)]

REP. FIXTURES. SENIOR. September 16 - Manawatu v. Taranaki, Hawera. JUNIOR. September 14 - Manawatu v. Taranaki, New Plymouth. (Sep 9, 1893,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

Western District football enthusiasts should feel proud of their two representatives in the Southland Rep. team. (Aug 23, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,2)

RUBGY REP MATCH. (Sep 13, 1920,Grey River Argus,3)

THE "REP" TEAM. (Aug 25, 1891,Wanganui Chronicle,3)

... junior rep. match. (Aug 12, 1905,NZ Truth,8/2/8)

BARR Colin Gilroy, rep. footballer and Rhodes scholar ... (1908,British Rugby Team in Maoriland,39)

THORNTON Didn't you play wing-threequarters in such and such a `rep' match. (1916,Wowser, The,270)

INGRAM ... the afternoon was spent in watching the 1st. and 2nd. Batalion football reps. in action against each other. (Sep 16, 1917,Anzac Diary,44,1987 ed.)

`Rep.' Rugby Matches [heading] A representative Rugby match between Auckland and Canterbury ... (Sep 2, 1929,Evening Post,15)

Peter, survey chainman, matriculated, rep-footballer: ... (Jun 1953,Here & Now,29)

SUTHERLAND Family came from up river early in the summer - plays rep. tennis and hockey and handles a horse better than most men. (1956,Green Kiwi,140,1960 ed.)

SLATTER [see Maul] Ibid. 174 The rep games when the log of wood has gone. (1968,Pagan Game, The,50)

STEWART The rep selector is here today. ...' And that's what the reps need too, a few good country forwards who know how toget stuck in.' (1985,Gumboots and Goalposts,13)

2 n.

Rep.- Sometimes shed r. Under the arbitration award it is laid down that `the shearers should elect a representative' who deals with the employer whenever any dispute or question arises. If the r. is a sensible man of good will, shearing goes through with hardly a hitch. (C.) (Nov 18, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

NEWTON REP: In a shearing gang a man is elected as a representative in the event of any disputes. He is known as the `rep.' - (1949,High Country Days,197,1950 ed.)

BOWEN REP. Shearers' voted representative who speaks for all the shearers in the gang in regard to complaints, decisions, etc. (1956,Wool Away!,156)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Rep. In the terms of the 1894 Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act, shearers were to elect a representative to negotiate any disputes or grievances directly with their employer. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,97)

repartnered family¶

n. a reconstituted family (one or both parents previously married)

Which is one of the reasons why Rodwell prefers a different term : repartnered families... The book, Repartnered Families: Creating new ways of living together - beyond the nuclear family, was originally prompted by what she was seeing in her work.. in interviews as a family therapist.. She presents different ways that repartnered families live together... The term repartnering is one not everybody is comfortable with. (Mar 3, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C4)

Repat¶

n. the Repatriation Department (after WW1) [ORIGIN: abbreviation, cf WW2 REHAB [AND Repatriation Commission 1920]]

SCANLAN That coot' who just got out is one of the Repatheads'. (1925,Much in Little,10)

Repatriation Department¶

n. a post-WWI Government Department to assist ex-servicemen back into civilian life

ANTHONY I had an order for GBP75 worth of furniture that I had applied for from the Repatriation Department... (1936,Follow the Call,105)

ANTHONY I had an order for [pounds]75 worth of furniture that I had applied for to the Repatriation Department ... (1924,Follow the Call,57,1975 ed.)

BOYD The Repatriation Department was wound up in 1922. (1984,City of the Plains,208)

repatriation farm¶

1 n. (Rural) a training-farm where injured or weakened ex-soldiers learned the practice of light farming and horticulture.

Fig 1. A general view of the Tauherenikau repatriation farm establishment, showing the men's quarters etc. (Apr 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,236)

Tauherenikau Repatriation Farm: training for tubercular returned soldiers. (Apr 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,237)

Fig 5. Harvesting the wheat crop on the Tauherenikau repatriation farm. (Apr 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,239)

reperepe¶

n.

PARKINSON A Vocabulary of the Language of New Zealand. [...] Egooree, A dog. Teyka, Fish. Hewhai[a-grave], A skate. Eraperape, A fish called Chimaera. Hepaooa, Ear-shells. Hekohooa[a-grave], Small ear-shells. [...] (1770,Journal,126)

CALLORHYNCHUS MILII (Bory). Elephant-fish; Reperepe. In Christchurch large numbers are sold under the name of `silver trumpeter.' ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts (rarer in the north). (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/123) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Callorhynchus milii Bory. ELEPHANT-FISH; REPEREPE. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,11,1971 ed.)

Callorhynchus milii Bory. Elephant-fish. Reprepe. (1938,TrNZI,68/401) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM ELEPHANT-FISH (REPEREPE) Callorhynchus milii Bory de St. Vincent (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,84,2nd ed.)

DOOGUE & MORELAND ELEPHANTFISH ... Other names: Callorhynchus millii; reperepe (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,194)

MORELAND ELEPHANTFISH [Callorhynchus milii ] ... Other names are elephant and reperepe; the latter is Maori and seldom heard today. (1967,Marine Fishes,12)

WILSON ELEPHANT FISH Only one species of this oddity appears in New Zealand waters, Callorhynchus milii , which also bears the Maori name `reperepe.' (1981,Fisherman's Bible,63)

WILSON ELEPHANT FISH Only one species of this oddity appears in New Zealand waters, Callorhynchus milii , which also bears the Maori name `reperepe.' (1981,Fisherman's Bible,63)

BURTON This bizarre, silvery fish, known to the Maori as rerepe, [sic] a trunk-like snout and occurs mainly along the east coast of the South Island. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,73)

repertory¶

n. In England a repertory theatre is usually one with a professional cast who perform a repertoire of plays, changing plays, say, once a week. In NZ it is merely the name of an amateur theatre group, undistinguished from other such groups except (in Wellington at least) in the more popular appeal of the plays performed. (J. Wright). 1963 (Also, as General English, the Rep).

repile¶

v. [Jim writes: DNZE records the special NZ use of pile and block [or post] of wood or stone [or concrete] on which the underfloor beams of a building rest. It does not have entries for repile or reblock. These terms are in common use and often seen in ads for old houses e.g. "recently repiled", "needs some reblocking". "Repiling" is a heading in the Yellow Pages.] (See reblock)

replacement¶

1 n. (Rural) an animal that augments a herd or flock after culling; usually home-bred.

Mr Walton has used marked heifers of his own breeding for his replacements. (Oct 1, 1938,NZ Dairy Exporter,14)

ARMY EDUCATION A one man unit of this type will carry six hundred to a thousand ewes according to the suitability of the country for the breeding of replacements. (1945,How to Start Farming,28)

He carries 4000 Corriedale ewes and 1800 hogget replacements. (Oct 22, 1953,NZ Farmer,4)

For sale by public tender, finishing land - Motukarara, Strong summer finishing country for lambs and steers/replacements. (Dec 2, 2000,Press, The,59)

The property is situated 25 km from Whakatane, finishing 1200 bulls, 500 other cattle and carrying 3000 ewes and replacements. (Jun 22, 2002,Dominion,50)

replica¶

v.

Director Rose Hudson and her very large cast of actors have done much to replica these well-known characters. (Jun 11, 2005,Dominion Post,A22)

Representation Commission¶

n. a statutory body whose function is to readjust general and Maori electoral boundaries periodically to ensure equal representation of the people in Parliament. [see also Electoral Commission]

In the next few months the Representation Commission will draw up the new general and Maori electorate boundaries. (Feb 3, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

representative¶

adj. provincial

MULGAN Unfortunately for his prospect of representative honours, the 'Varsity team ... was at the bottom of the senior grade. (1934,Spur of Morning,75)

reps¶

n. a provincial representative team (espec. rugby union)

SLATTER Got into a good team in the city, got into the reps and when they won the Shield he was home on the pig's back. Never looked back. Everything went right for him. (1968,Pagan Game, The,158)

The Maori Reps under George Nepia defeated N.S. Wales by 9 to 8 on Athletic Park last Saturday - a good exhibition of football in the mud. (Sep 24, 1928,Na To Hoa Aroha,1/139) [NOTES: 1928 Sep 24 Na To Hoa Aroha (1986) (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 1/139 (Ngata)]

Republic of Don¶

phr. [i.e. Don Brash?]

...what I would fear about living in the Republic of Don is randomly being stopped by police to check I wasn't washing clothes unnecessarily. (Nov 7, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C10)

requin¶

n.

[Caption]Round-finned whaler, Carcharinus lamia. This species is the lamia,' orrequin,' of the early writers. It is found in the Pacific in small numbers, being most probably identical with [261] the fish recorded as Carcharinus macrurus (Rams. & Ogil. ...1888) (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/260) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

rere¶

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of lucerne (Medicago sativa). [ORIGIN: Maori]

Figures for the 1982-83 season show it yielded the same from four cuts as the other home-grown varieties, Wairau and Rere. (Nov 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,22)

reremai¶

n. also called basking shark a large (up to 13 m) plankton-feeding shark, found in New Zealand waters.

KEENE reremai: basking shark, New Zealand's largest shark, has blunt teeth about 1/4 in. in length; harmless; eats crustaceans. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

LEE & KENDALL R|ere mai; A fish so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,202)

PHILLIPPS Cetorhinus maximus (Gunner). BASKING-SHARK; REREMAI. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,8,1971 ed.)

POWELL BASKING SHARK (Halsydrus maccoyi), Reremai of the Maoris, is our largest shark. ... The Reremai occurs both in New Zealand and Australia. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,62)

NATUSCH Family CETORHINIDAE contains the enormous basking shark or reremai (Cetorhinus) ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,198)

rerepari¶

n.

TAYLOR Papaka, the crab: the largest is about two and a half inches across the carapace; a small crab, called the rerepari, abounds in the salt marshes. There is also a small crab found in the mussel, which has a very round red body and short legs. I have met with a little fresh-water crab, seventy miles inland; it is not above half an inch across the shell, delicately formed, of a dusky green color. There is no lobster in New Zealand. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,415)

rerepe¶

n. Williams nf ?a transliteration of English LILIPI (??or vice-versa) spg also rerepi (See reperepe)

MOORE & IRWIN Northern Wairoa [sc ?those of north Auckland] Maoris made a sort of porridge, called `rerepe', by boiling the [raupo] pollen in water (Boswell 1956) ... (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,190)

A kind of gruel (rerepi) was also made of the [hinau] meal by mixing with water and placing hot stones in the bowl. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,6)

Rerewhakaaitu Ash¶

n. Geol.

Recently three further dates on the Rerewhakaaitu Ash have been determined, all on samples of organic lake sediment (humic copropel) from cores taken from Lake Maratoto near Hamilton. (Oct 6, 1980,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,50/54)

The base of the section comprises ridges of pumice sand gravel mantled by Okareka Ash, Rerewhakaaitu Ash and Rotorua Ash now truncated by lake waters when the lake level was at an elevation of 284 m as against the present day elevation of 279.7 m. (May 1975,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,39/25)

The tephras dated (maximum ages, Libby half-life basis) are: Taupo Pumic [sic] . . . , Tuhua Tephra . . . Mangamate Tephra . . . and Rerewhakaaitu Ash. (May 1980,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,49/42)

RESA¶

abbr. Runway End Safety Area

Last week, the airport announced it had lodged a planning application with Wellington City Council to create a runway end safety area (RESA) at the southern end of its runway... Mr Draper said the total project cost for both southern and northern RESAs would be between $15 million and 20 million. (May 13, 2004,Wellington Contact,3)

rescraped bush¶

n.

SUTHERLAND Some of the classifications under which gum was exported give an indication of the appearance of some of the grades: bright, rescraped bush, bright chips, black flour dust, chalk, bright seeds and black sugar are some of the names. (1956,Green Kiwi,70,1960 ed.)

rescue tube¶

n. a lifesaving device

You catch them by surprise, and you go down with them knowing they'll be the first to yield, and when they break their grip then you are in a position to get the rescue tube around them. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/38)

reserve¶

n. a piece of bush or land `reserved' by statute for scenic, recreational or conservation purposes [also Maori reserve ca1935 Going up to the reserve today for a picnic.] (See also Maori reserve)

Allow me through the medium of your journal to call the attention of the Board of Education, or whoever has the management of Educational Reserves, to the injustice they are doing this would-be township, by not leasing the reserve. (Jan 5, 1878,Timaru Herald,4)

The members of the Christchurch City Council made their annual inspection of the cemetery and other city reserves yesterday. (Mar 9, 1900,Star, The,3)

These grounds and premises (presently occupied by Mr. A. Millar, who is about to leave the settlement for a time) being situated on the reserve outside the town, any occupier is not likely to be disturbed in the possession for some time. (May 8, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1)

There are six reserves containing 60 acres that have been set apart as sites for country schools, two of them have been confirmed, the others will be forwarded for the recommendation of the Council. (Oct 21, 1868,Southland Times,2)

The directors wish that, in forming the plan of the town, you should make ample reserves for all public purposes; such as a cemetery, a market-place, wharfage, and probable public buildings, a botanical garden, a park, and extensive boulevards. (Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

WAKEFIELD ... a town-site [for Wellington] was laid out, consisting of 1100 sections of one acre each, besides reserves for public purposes, and there were also laid out 1100 rural sections of one hundred acres each ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,94)

... Kite and Jim went mustering the reserve for stragglers. (Mar 1, 1879,Diary) [NOTES: 1879 Mar 1 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 128]

HOCKEN An instruction to Mr. Kettle when commencing his surveys was to lay off certain portions of land for public use, not open for sale, and termed `reserves.' (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,100)

KOEBELL A patch or two of `reserve' bush (1911,In Maoriland Bush,97)

81 How can a man fancy that a job as sawdust boy [in a sawmill up Taihape way] for a week or two can help him locate cattle in Mount Egmont Reserve beats me, ... (1927,Me and Gus,(1977 Gus Tomlins ed. Sturm) ed.)

The tip of Point Chevalier was a park known as `the Reserve', ringed with pine trees and macrocarpa which led to the Piper Rocks, where boys and men ... caught sprats and piper, which were excellent eating. (Aug 8, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),61)

2 n.

RESERVE. An area of land legally set aside for some given purpose. e.g. Education Reserve, Roas Reserve, Scenic Reserve, and earlier days, Forest Reserve. - (1952,NZ Forest Glossary)

Reserve Bank (of New Zealand)¶

n.

There shall be established in New Zealand in accordance with this Act a bank to be called the Reserve Bank of New Zealand.Ibid.56 There shall be established in New Zealand in accordance with this Act a bank to be called the Reserve Bank of New Zealand. (1933,NZ Statutes,24 Geo. V 11/53)

An act to amend the Reserve Bank of NZ Act, 1933. Ibid. 1/7 It shall be the general function of the Reserve Bank.. to give effect as far as may be to the monetary policy of the Government, as communicated to it from time to time by the Minister of Finance... The bank shall regulate and control credit and currency in New Zealand, the transfer of moneys to or from New Zealand, and the disposal of moneys that were derived from the sale of any New Zealand products and for the time being are held overseas. (1936,NZ Statutes,1/4)

The great temptation to any Government is.. to use Reserve Bank credit. Ibid. 1843 If money is in credit, we buy back securities from the Reserve Bank. (1952,NZ Parliamentary Debates,298/1223)

Sir Otto Niemeyer, however, in such a report, can only give us the technical framework of a Central Reserve Bank, leaving us to clothe it according to our own particular requirements, provided we do not violate the accepted principles which should govern such an institution. (Sep 29, 1931,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3)

SINCLAIR In the same year [1933] the Government set up the Reserve Bank of New Zealand so that it could secure cheaper credit for the state(...) and, more important, so that it could determine general monetary policy. (1959,History of New Zealand,254)

reserved¶

adj. of land, retained for public use

Her Majesty has, in the most decided terms, withheld from the Governor of New Zealand the power to grant any land in that Colony gratuitously, to any person whatever. This prohibition does not, of course, apply to the case of grants of land which it may occasionally be convenient to make to persons in trust for the public of tracts or pieces of land which it may be found convenient to dedicate to purposes of general utility; as, for example, roads, fortifications, public pleasure grounds, cemeteries, and the like. It is proposed that, with the exception of lands reserved or granted in trust for the purposes before-mentioned, all the lands of the Colony should be sold progressively, as surveys shall be completed ... (Apr 19, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

And all persons are warned not to clear, fence, or cultivate, or build in or upon any portion of the belt of reserved land surrounding the town. (Sep 11, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

reserved bush¶

n. [(cf. bush reserve)]

The reserved bush is within two minutes' walk of the house, ... (Apr 6, 1861,Otago Witness,7)

Residency¶

n. district officers of M.O.W., viewed collectively

KEN SMITHYMAN Have you noticed the M.O.W's resurrection of an old term? - their district officers are now designated as their Residency, reflecting the Indian origin (particulary Madras) of our survey system? (1975,Personal Communication)

Resident¶

n. [(obs) Bay of Islands]

There are 40 Europeans and their families residing at the Bay, independent of the Mission, and of the British Resident and his family. (Aug 9, 1834,NZ Independent,30,1979 ed.)

Resident Magistrate¶

n. an official stationed in various towns and settlements, having minor judicial and (particularly in frontier areas) administrative functions, especially in relation to Maori matters. [Jim Cameron writes : Historical 1846-1893. Shorn of administrative duties, resident magistrates were metamorphosed into stipendiary magistrates in the 1890s and legal qualifications were required. The term is not unique to NZ; there were resident magistrates in Ireland and elsewhere, but never in England. They played a significant part in NZ History which is recounted in Aland Ward A Show of Justice (1974). Not recorded in DNZE or other dictionaries, except perfunctorily (without definition) in NSOD.]

Resident magistrates, especially in frontier districts, were agents of government as well as having judicial functions. Towards the end of the nineteenth century resident magistrates lost their administrative functions and their office was metamorphosed into the purely judicial one of stipendiary magistrate. Generally known simply as magistrates (or SMs) they were legally qualified and exercised increasingly important judicial functions in magistrates courts (1999,NZWords,2(1) : 1)

resin¶

n. kauri resin

THE KOWRI. .. This tree yields a large quantity of resin of a white and amber colour, very transparent, burning with a bright flame, and having a very agreeable smell. (Oct 6, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

The Imperial Institute's Technical Department speaks favourably of Queensland resin. It hitherto was believed to be kauri resin, but probably it is derived from a species of callistris. (Jul 7, 1904,Southland Times,3)

resleeperer¶

n. [(Railways coinage) R. Mason noted a Railways Dept advertisement in the 1940's for resleeperers to renew railway sleepers.]

resource consent¶

n. [Jim Cameron writes : This is not recorded in DNZE but is in NZPOD. There are no entries in that dictionary for the different types of resource consent - land use consent, subdivision consent, coastal permit, water permit, discharge permit. See Resource Management Act, 1991, s. 87 for definitions.]

Timberlands is seeking resource consents.. to log 64,000 cu m initially and eventually up to 100,000 cu m. (Sep 18, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

If you want bigger, deeper dams you need a Resource Consent, and the dam must be constructed to specific standards. (Feb 2001,Growing Today,6)

Some obsolete terms (e.g. entail, foreclosure, probation) are not noted as historical only.Ibid 2 Even the Dictionary of New Zealand English (DNZE) (1997) is patchy in its coverage of legal terms, having for example no entry for disputes tribunal, family protection, incorporated society, Maori option, protection order, resource consent. Resource consents, defined in NZPOD, are of several types - land use consents, subdivision consents, coastal permits, water permits, and discharge permits. (Jan 1999,NZWords,1)

Resource consents, defined in NZPOD, are of several types - land use consents, subdivision consents, coastal permits, water permits, and discharge permits. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

Resource Management Act¶

n.

If the Timberlands' hearing had been allowed to go through the Resource Mangement Act process, the application would probably have been granted, albiet with stringent conditions. (Apr 2000,North & South,82)

The Resource Management Bill - Rembo for short - is basically the old Town and Country Planning Act on steroids. (Sep 17, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

Resource Management Act¶

1 n. (Rural) a controversial natural resource protection act of 1991, that gives instruction to landowners on how weeds, pests, water, mineral, topographical, and other resources on their properties are to be managed. [aka RMA]

ACKROYD That review [of the Land Act 1948] culminated in the Resource Management Act 1991 that has the single purpose of promoting the sustainable management of natural and physical resources .. Land management policies for the high country are now inextricably linked to the highly politicised policy and planning process underpinning the Resource Management Act 1991. (1993,Politics, Economics & Pastoral Land,38)

BRADSHAW & WILLIAMS The majority of those [farmers] interviewed do not see the Resource Management Act as a regulation requiring sustainable land management practices. (1998,Information and Communication Needs,20)

The RMA provides the opportunity for people who do not own land to tell land owners how they should manage their properties. (Sep 24, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,Farming Today Supplt 4)

They [farmers] are head butting Resource Management Act issues all the time. [RMA] (May 2002,Growing Today,17)

Protection of New Zealand's historic heritage has taken a major step forward with the passing of amendments to the Resource Management Act. (Sep 2003,NZ Heritage,No. 90/9)

responsible¶

n.

We have been asking a long time to have a branch railway brought to this town, and a big body of responsibles paid a call on Sir Joseph Ward; but he promised them nothing satisfactory. (Oct 30, 1909,NZ Truth,227/4/8)

rest area¶

n. a designated area off or alongside a road where vehicles may stop, sometimes with tables, seats, etc. [Jim writes: Approx BritE equivalent layby. In NZPOD but not NZD or DNZE. Not in NSOD. Collins tags it as Austral and NZ. Noted in Orsman database to check.]

restaurant¶

n. Up to the late 1950's at least or early 1960's more commonly applied in New Zealand hyperbolistically to any cheap eating-house serving fries, grills etc: HASH-HOUSE, HASH FOUNDRY qqv. (cf HOTEL). In the 1950's more expensive a la carte restaurants became commoner, a few to be finally licensed in 1962.

PASCOE [Quoting Dougla's recollections] The shanty keeper is a cross between the store and the pub [on the early West Coast]. ... He depends upon whiskey and card playing, and sometimes calls his place an Accommodation House or restaurant. (1957,Mr Explorer Douglas,14) [NOTES: [1860's?] 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 14]

[The Minister of Agfriculture] did not think any member would wish to see restaurants commonly referred to as `hash-houses' with a [liquor] licence. (Oct 31, 1962,Dominion,14)

restaurant glass¶

n. a standard wine glass

"What, you mean a 180ml restaurant glass is 1.8 standard drinks?" they ask in astonishment. (Nov 23, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

restorative justice¶

n.

[Hdg] Restorative justice urged... A senior district and youth court judge has called for the youth court principles of restorative justice - in which victims and offenders meet to "make matters right" - should be applied to all levels of the criminal justice process. (Sep 15, 1999,Dominion,15)

Restorative justice is by no means a new concept but it is gaining a foothold in New Zealand and overseas. (Mar 6, 2002,Dominion,13)

Most people would agree that restorative justice is a wonderful idea, but do they understand the reality of the schemes presently in place or being trialled? (Jul 22, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

A successful commumnity-based restorative justice programme in Wanganui has managed to extract something positive from this otherwise tragic event... The Wanganui Restorative Justice Trust was set up three years ago by a group of people keen to develop a restorative justice process in the city... A contract is worked out between the offender and the victim, which is then presented back to the court. (Jun 2002,Wel-com (Wellington),No. 186 : 13)

restraining order¶

n. a court order aimed at preventing the harassment of persons who are not in a domestic relationship with the harasser. [Jim Cameron writes : Introduced by the Harassment Act 1997, it is a milder counterpart to a protection order under the Domestic Violence Act. (The NZOD definition is confusing and the example incorrect).]

restrike¶

1 n. (Rural) a reinfestation of sheep by flystrike.

Irritant fluids such as kerosene should not be used; they may kill the maggots, but they will irritate the wound and tend to cause restrike. (Sep 1961,NZ Journal of Agriculture,230)

resultancy¶

n.

These days he runs a consultancy, O'Reilly [Un] Limited, which he calls a "resultancy - because we actually get things done", out of Napier and Wellington. (Feb 2005,North & South,89)

retail¶

n. shortened form of "retail therapy"

"I'm off to do a bit of retail." "Retail's always good." (Oct 16, 2001,TV2) [NOTES: Shortland Street]

reti¶

n.

MANNERING The Maoris used to fish there [mouth of Tukituki River, Hawke's Bay ca1897] with `reti' ... The reti consists of a canoe-shaped board about a foot long with a spinning bait attached with about four feet of strong line. The board is thrown into the current on its edge and is held against the current and allowed to drift out into the breakers, generally on about 100 yards of line. The moment a fish is struck the whole affair is brought in. (1943,Eighty Years,156)

retire¶

1 v. (Rural) [land] to allow to revert to its natural state.

HENDERSON I had gone out alone on skis to look for sheep on the Burnt Face, our old wether block soon to be retired from grazing by the Forest Service. (1969,Open Country Calling,50)

GORDON Retiring back valleys and land above the snowline (900m or 3,000 ft) is part of a soil conservation scheme to protect mountain lands. On Makarora 12,525 ha (31,000 acres) have been retired. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,179)

BARNES I was determined that we had to do something, so the Catchment Board agreed that if we retired certain areas of our higher altitude country they would assist financially to put in protection banks. (1987,Country Calendar (TVNZ),22)

DOMINY A run plan based on the report was drawn up by the Catchment Board, calling for compensation for loss of grazing land to be retired from use ... (2001,Calling the Station Home,108)

We retired the area from the gorge to the farm boundary - which was an awkward corner and difficult to get to anyway. (2002,Wool Grower,Autumn 22)

retired¶

1 adj. (Rural) [ high country station land] closed to grazing animals.

JOHNSON To assist in providing grazing for sheep from the retired lands, certain subsidies are available. (1970,Soil Conservation and Land Retirement,2)

JOHNSON The sheep displaced from the retired summer country would be found grazing on the more extrensive hill country below 4,000' ... (1970,Soil Conservation and Land Retirement,8)

MCMILLAN Now no mountain sheep are on Spear Peak to muster, they've shut up such land - it's retired, so they say ... (2000,Country Bloke and Other Verse, The,227)

retirement block¶

1 n. (Rural) a large area of high country land that closed to stock-grazing.

JOHNSON In the summer period there is a marked decline in both the retirement blocks and the extensive blocks. (1970,Soil Conservation and Land Retirement,24)

retirement fence¶

1 n. (Rural) a high country fence that acts as a snow boundary for stock, also allowing regeneration of natural flora.

JOHNSON A 100% subsidy is available for a boundary fence on such an area - i.e. a retirement fence. (1970,Soil Conservation and Land Retirement,2)

WHEELER The catchment board and the station have together put in a twenty-mile retirement fence at 3,500 feet to prevent stock from using potentially dangerous snow country. (1971,Historic Sheep Stations SI II,30)

GORDON One of the main restrictions on burning is that the snow's got to be down to the retirement fence. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,179)

retirement plan¶

1 n. (Rural) a conservation-motivated station plan to retire portions of high country land from grazing.

JOHNSON There are two kinds of benefit generated in a retirement plan of the kind discussed here. Firstly, there is the physical change in the land .. there are financial returns .. of the cultivation and improvement programme associated with the retirement plans. (1970,Soil Conservation and Land Retirement,17)

GORDON Retirement plans include subsidies to develop other areas of a station so that production lost from one area can be replaced by developing other country lower down. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,179)

DOMINY Land retirement plans and the surrender of Crown pastoral lands have decreased the area of back country used for sheep and cattle grazing. (2001,Calling the Station Home,169)

retireti¶

n.

HAY There are the native spinach or Renga-renga (Tetragonia expansa), the Pana-pana, or cress (Cardamine hirsuta), and the Reti-reti, or sorrel (Oxalis [211] magellanica), which do for salad and green vegetables. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/210)

retread¶

n. a nurse or teacher returning to their profession; a retired person returned to work;

"The group of us returning to the workforce were dubbed the 'retreads', and the name has stuck." (Dec 2002,NZ Nursing Review,12)

n. soldier who re-enlists; superannuated public servant who re-enters the Service as a casual officer. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

retread n. soldier who re-enlists; superannuated public servant who re-enters the Service as a casual officer. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

BREAM Mr Willis had taught for forty years, and then retired. He had now returned to the school ... to help relieve the teacher shortage. He was a very nice person, as were all our retreads, ... ?ca1980 (1974,I'm Sorry Amanda)

retro-personed¶

adj.

...Courtenay Place is set to become retro-personed - seething with rugged types not afraid to burp in public or masticate over a platter of bulls [sic] testicles while ruminating on the vagaries of life on the ponderosa. (Jul 15, 2004,Dominion Post,D3)

return¶

n. a second helping (esp. at a restaurant) [ca1945 `No returns']

New Zealand has developed many phrases that depend on local interpretation: e.g. The Limited',the six oclock rush', off the bitumen',motor camp', to farewell',to pencil in', to check up on',return (at meals)'. All these are immediately understandable to New Zealanders, but not always to others. (1950,Post Office English Course [TS],14)

return-box¶

n.

McARA Return-boxes: The hydraulic classifiers returning the plus-200-mesh through under-flow nozzles to the tube-mills for further grinding. The overflow from these boxes, being minus-200-mesh, went to the Wilfley tables for separation of the concentrates. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),330)

return-race/return-race shed¶

1 n. (Rural) an internal-race model of woolshed where sheep go to a pen behind, and at the same level as, the board, once shorn.

NEWTON It is an eight-stand board with return shutes [sic] to which are added automatic counters. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,77)

Return-race sheds may use space inefficiently but they do have certain advantages. Shorn sheep go to the back of the shed by return races which are on the same level as the pens and board. The return races can also be used for footrotting, inocculating and drafting. Unwelcome draughts are avoided in an internal-race shed. (Nov 27, 1975,NZ Farmer,14)

Variations include centre-board, side-port, across-the-board, U-board, raised board and return race. [return chute] (Apr 24, 1980,NZ Farmer,36)

returned¶

adj. (meaning as in returned serviceman)

Often "returned" men like Muldoon, went to him for financial advice. (Feb 1992,Metro,7)

returned invalid¶

n.

[Photo caption] Trooper R.G Perrean (Foxton), Third Contingent. Returned invalid. (Nov 14, 1900,Otago Witness,47)

returned man¶

n. = returned serviceman

Veterinary-Lieutenant Young responded to the toast of the returned men. (Feb 21, 1901,Wanganui Herald,2)

SLATTER Blue Smoke sung on an outward-bound trooper in Cook Strait. Rata singing Manu Rere in the hut and the Maori returned man shouting at the drunks who wouldn't quieten for his song at the smoko - (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,99)

Bas Tubert is an ornament to the broadcasting scene. I have never met him personally, but I had assumed he was a mere stripling probably crowding 50. Now, I learn from the Evening Post that Mr Tubert is 63 and a returned man. (May 2, 1986,Contact (Wgtn),2)

1 n. (Rural) [sp. to the rural area] a rehabilitated serviceman who is allotted land.

June 1 711 The private land acquired for soldier settlement purposes aggregated 1,279,235 acres, upon which 5715 returned men were settled ... (1922,BLANK ENTRY)

STACEY The best of the forest lands had been plundered and returned men were put on to areas called farms, which gave little in return for immense labour. The majority walked off in a few years. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,16)

STACEY At Ngaionui a returned man had taken over ... (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,18)

returned serviceman¶

n. one who has served (usually overseas) in the armed services, formerly also called returned soldier

They dance a jig the returned / servicemen used to do before they were lost in a war. (Jul 2, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

Returned Servicemen's Association¶

n.

SLIGO Well, ... today we dedicate the RSA club.'What?' ... `The Returned Servicemen's Association.' (1987,Final Things,30)

returned soldier¶

n.

LOCKE I could have managed my returned soldier's farm quite well, given half a chance. (1894,Inky Way, The,154) [NOTES: WWI]

It appears that his worship the Mayor had fully intended to do honour to the returned soldier by according him personal reception at the wharf ... (Jun 21, 1900,Otago Witness,29)

"See There!" exclaimed a returned soldier to a gaping crowd, as he exhibited with some pride his tall hat with a bullet-hole in it. "Look at that hole will you? You see that if it had been a low-crowned hat I should have been killed outright." (Jun 26, 1869,Evening Post,2)

Will there then be a banquet at which the returned soldier from the political battle field, who we are asked to believe has fleshed - aye to the hilt - his maiden sword, will be toasted and feted as the honoured guest[?] (Oct 22, 1875,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

HENDERSON Senney's father, who saw only his own great guilt anatomized in Thrumbull's wheelchair to prove he wasn't a Returned Man, a Returned Soldier. (1975,Log of a Superfluous Son, The,72)

It is lucky for the returned soldiers that they have the government for a landlord. (Apr 20, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

HYDE Returned soldiers come up and offer lady writers bootlaces - brown ones at that. (1934,Journalese,10)

HYDE Yet, potentially at [17] least, the returned soldier's desperate desire to fit in again ... is one of the most valuable things remaining in our world; ... (1936,Passport to Hell,16)

HYDE After the war, when it was decided that their father's gratuity, helped out by the State Advance mortgage (another little Government treat for the returned soldiers), should buy the Hannays a house of their own, ... (1938,Godwits Fly, The,76,1970 ed.)

Today the supervisor is a man of Maori blood, a returned soldier of the last war, .. . (1948,Our Own Country,53)

The intellectual is as snobbish in his attitude to books and writers as other New Zealanders are to many things, notably to returned soldiers - whether they had been cocoanut bombers' in the Pacific or had beenreally overseas' to Africa, ... (Sep 1952,Landfall,23/223) [NOTES: (Pearson `Fretful Sleepers')]

BACON ... Have you heard of the soldier settlement they had out here after the First War? ... ' ` ... The Government partly developed the land, then put returned soldier farmers on it. One by one they went broke and walked off. ... Now they say the Government is going to try again. This new aerial top dressing may make a difference.' (1963,In the Sticks,62)

TURNER An army ex-serviceman is called a returned soldier in Australia and New Zealand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,152)

A returned soldier, who was starting fishing, applied for this [land]. (Nov 9, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,59)

The returned soldiers hold their annual sports on Easter Monday. (Jun 17, 1924,Otago Witness,70)

A pathetic sight as the seemingly never-endless stream of returned soldiers descended the gangway from the Zealandic yesterday was the number of men wearing artificial limbs. (Apr 1, 1919,Evening Post,4)

n. (See RSA)

I see that a branch of the Returned Soldiers' Association has protested against conchies being taught massage! (Feb 2, 1919,Great Adventure,250,1988 ed.) [NOTES: (Hutton)]

McLINTOCK When they organised themselves, as they began to at the end of 1915, into Returned Soldiers' Associations, ... (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/67)

LEE Paddy Murphy had been District President of the Returned Soldiers [sic] Association since 1918 ... R.S.A. (1970,Mussolini's Millions,101)
