Truth saw one official at the Returned Soldiers' Club. (May 5, 1917,NZ Truth,2)

returned trooper¶

n.

RETURNED TROOPERS. .. The troopers who returned by the Rimutaka were entertained at luncheon by the Ministers to-day. (Feb 21, 1901,Wanganui Herald,2)

reua¶

n.

LAING & BLACKWELL Dianella intermedia (The Blueberry). This plant is found in woods or open fern lands. ... Maori name, Rena.[sic] (1940,Plants of NZ,99)

rev¶

n.

In the early days he used to give MAori a public rev ... (Aug 22, 2005,NZ Farmers' Weekly,14)

reversion¶

v. to re-edit a TV programme for various market requirements [Tom O'Brien on Kim Hill 14/09/00; also "reversioning"]

1 n. (Rural) the return of pasture or farmland to its former state.

On the farm of Mr G. F Hughes at Springston, cereals and grass were overdrilled into a runout towards brown top reversion. (Dec 31, 1964,NZ Farmer,8)

NEWTON .. when the property was purchased in 1956 by the present owner there had been considerable scrub reversion and the stocking had dropped to 9,000 sheep and 1,200 head of cattle. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,232)

revert¶

1 v. (Rural) [land] to regress to growing scrub or bush rather than pasture.

The property when taken over consisted of 28 acres of sandy gumland hills in weak browntop and danthonia pasture, reverting back to manuka ... (Jan 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,17)

Where the soil was poor and the rainfall high the tendency to revert to second growth was so strong that pastures could not be maintained. (Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,15)

NEWTON This block, now 10,000 acres, has reverted badly over the years ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,88)

The present trend in the hill country is for land to revert to fern and scrub beacuse of understocking and lack of fertiliser. (Sep 26, 1985,NZ Farmer,20)

WRIGHT The land slowly reverted to scrub and eventually he had to leave. (1985,Farming in the Mohaka State Forest,47)

We were turning over the farm and putting in new grass. But with dry summers, it is reverting ... (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,5)

In the South Island a lot of country is marginal and slowly reverting to native scrub. (Nov 18, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,18)

reverted¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of land] over-run with original cover, second-growth or bush.

Some of the high, windblown reverted country is not suited to farming. (Oct 11, 1951,NZ Farmer,19)

.. exceptionally high producing pasture has been established economically on an area of badly reverted and heavily gorse-infested land at Mullet Point, near Warkworth in the Rodney County. (Nov 5, 1953,NZ Farmer,4)

Not many people can be making a more praiseworthy effort to rehabilitate a run-out, badly reverted farm than Mr Bob Wech on the foreshore of Mahurangi harbour, Northland. (Dec 2, 1954,NZ Farmer,3)

TAIT The station was cut up and handed over. Giant discs are now being used to bring in reverted land. (1961,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III,127)

It is unlikely that John Read would have known anything about the ability of Friesian steers to forage and thrive in the demanding environment of New Zealand scrub-reverted hill country.. (Apr 25, 1968,NZ Farmer,5)

ALLEN He returned to Puraroto, built himself a whare up the valley and set about the enormous task of clearing this reverted property. (1980,Farm on the Wanganui River, A,16)

Their 146 ha property at Rawene, bought in 1973, is just the sort of rough reverted land people feel is ideal to run goats on. (May 27, 1982,NZ Farmer,21)

rewarewa¶

n. NZ honeysuckle; also called New Zealand honeysuckle a native forest tree with reddish flowers, poplar-like in appearance. [Maori] Knightia excelsa =BUCKET-OF-WATER-WOOD, =HONEYSUCKLE (N.Z.), a forest tree and its timber [check honeysuckle]

The pillars and styles of this are of rimu, the panels of ribbonwood, and the mouldings of riwariwa. (Oct 4, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,7)

Will you please say if rewarewa timber is durable if kept constantly under water? (Aug 20, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,28)

LAING & BLACKWELL Tree up to 100ft ... chiefly North Island. (1940,Plants of NZ,150)

rewarewa, a tall Lombardy-poplar shaped tree (Knightia excelsa); seed-pod shaped like Maori canoe with elevated stern-piece. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tall tree. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

A tall and beautiful New Zealand tree which produces a pretty timber; (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),344)

rewa-rewa n -s [Maori] 1 : a slender New Zealand tree (Knightia excelsa ) resembling the Lombardy poplar in habit but yielding a valuable timber 2 : the strong heavy mottled red wood of the rewa-rewa - called also New Zealand honeysuckle (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1945)

~ n. New Zealand honeysuckle [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

rewa-rewa ... n. N.Z. honeysuckle [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

rewarewa [s] Knightia excelsa R.Br. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,64)

rewa-rewa n. a tall tree of New Zealand, yielding reddish timber. [C19: < Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,987) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 654; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 417]]

YATE ... give him this Rewarewa-box, for his wife to put her needles and thread in. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),264)

Rewarewa (Knightia excelsa), a tall tapering tree, is a prominent object on the hill slopes. The wood of this tree makes beautiful furniture work. (1877,TrNZI,IX/507)

NICHOLAS The trees which the natives chiefly make subservient to their purposes, are [besides the pines cowrie, totarra, towha and zarida mentioned above] ... the henow, from which they extract a black dye, the towha, a tree resembling the sycamore, the river river, the grain of whose wood is similar to that of the beech, a species of cork-tree, called by these people vow, a large tree named eckoha, and another named kycata, a tall and beautiful tree, ... (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/245)

LEE & KENDALL R|awa r|awa; A tree so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,201)

M'DONNELL A great variety of hard-wood grows at New Zealand, admirably adapted for the timbering of any sized ships; among them is the boride[e-acute], rattar[as-acute], taraide[ase-acute], mai[a-acute], totara[a1-acute], koi katoa[a2-acute], toa[a-acute] toa[a-acute], tani raha[as-acute], to wai[a-acute], reiva[a-acute] reiva[a-acute], tana[as-acute], and many others (1834,Journal,19,1979 ed.)

YATE Rewarewa (Knightia excelsa) - This tree is found in dry forests, and where the soil is loose and gravelly in its texture. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),44)

POLACK Many other trees abounded in Pamaki [a's-acute], such as the kaikatea [a2-acute], towai, rewa-rewa, totara [a's-acute], puriri, rata [a's-acute], kahika [a2-acute], tipow, tanikaha [a2-acute], rimu, and various kinds of akkas, all of which will be found described in the Appendix (Note 7). Ibid. 2/396 The Rewa rewa [a's-acute], (pinus rewarewa,) is a handsome grained wood, very serviceable to the builder and joiner. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/109)

HEAPHY The Ruva-ruva or honeysuckle, is mostly used for timbers and other parts requiring great strength. (1842,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,43)

HEAPHY (And) [RUVA-RUVA] Knightia excelsa (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy))

DIEFFENBACH Rewa rewa - a tree (Knightia excelsa ) (1843,Travels in NZ,2/383)

WILLIAMS The Rewarewa Tree is not much used not being large enough for boards and soon rots, ... (1844,NZ Journal,105,1956 ed.)

WAKEFIELD 7. Rewarewa, (Knightia excelsa .) This tree is found in dry forests, and where the soil is loose and gravelly in its texture. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,142)

HOOKER Knightia excelsa, Br. ... Nat. name, `Rewa Rewa'. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 219)

HURSTHOUSE ... rewarewa (honeysuckle) (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/143)

The flagstaff was a rewarewa - the cap (or truck) of it I brought away. (Mar 25, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/100) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

HOOKER Rewarewa, Geolog. Surv. Dysoxylum spectabile. ... Rewarewa, Col[enso]. Knightia excelsa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

The Titoki (Alectryon excelsum), the Akeake (Dodonaea viscosa), the Ngaio (Myoporum laetum), and above all the Rewa Rewa (Knightia excelsa ), yield woods, out of which some very beautiful pieces of furniture have been made. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/14)

BAINES (1874,Edward Crewe,144)

HAY The Rewa-rewa (Knightia excelsa ) approaches to the second class of great trees. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/197)

HECTOR Knightia excelsa , Br. Rewarewa.--A lofty slender tree, 100 feet high. Wood handsome, mottled red and brown, (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,129)

121 [Native name] Rewarewa .. [Settlers' name] Honeysuckle .. [Family] Proteaceae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

Rewarewa (honey-suckle) .. Knightia excelsa .. Soft wood, straight grained, prettily mottled, and used largely for ornamental purposes of all descriptions (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,14)

MORRIS ~ pronounced raywa, Maori name for the New Zealand tree Knightia excelsa , R. Br., N.O. Proteaceae, the Honey-suckle of the New Zealand settlers. Maori verb, rewa, to float. The seed-vessel is just like a Maori canoe. (1898,Austral English,386)

CHEESEMAN K[nightia] excelsa, R.Br. ... Honeysuckle; Rewarewa. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,606)

LAING & BLACKWELL Knightia excelsa (The [Maori] Honey-suckle) ... Maori name, Rewa-rewa. It is sometimes called the Bucket-of-water-tree, because it is so slow of combustion. (1907,Plants of NZ,146,1940 p. 150 ed.)

rewena¶

n. leaven or leavened Maori bread [ORIGIN: Maori, a transliteration of leaven; see also rewena bread, paraoa]

Rewena is a transliterated word for 'leaven' which is what the bread is - it is bread that has 'risen'. (May 15, 2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.maori.org.nz/papa_panui/forum_topic.asp]

Grace ...he always brought shop bread to school for lunch instead of home-made rewena... (2001,Dogside Story,185)

rewena bread¶

n. (Cuisine) leavened bread [ORIGIN: Maori, often sp. rewana]

Accompanying rewana bread was also excellent, having all the sticky, yeasty, potatoey sponginess you could desire from this post-contact sourdough loaf. Aptly, this rewana bread was the centrepiece of a separate appetiser ... (Feb 28, 2009,Dominion Post Indulgence,11)

The menu features traditional Maori food such as pork, puha and dumpling boil-up, along with some New Zealand inspired dishes. Rewana bread is served at the table covered with a woven flax hood and the waitress offers a karakia or blessing before eating. (Sep 1999,Cuisine,No. 76 : 162)

The partners plant to ply the hungry with an eclectic assortment of dishes - seafood mornay, raw fish, lambs fry, whitebait fritters and rewena bread. (May 25, 2000,Contact (Wgtn),1)

I would have loved to have try the Paua Bar's rewena (wheaten bread risen with yeast brewed from flour and potatoes) but as our waiter explained, their baker was away and they wouldn't try to make it themselves. (Aug 10, 2000,Evening Post,21)

CARKEEK The Maori word for bread is paraoa which is a trans-literation of the word flour. Various kinds of bread were made by the whalers, traders, and missionaries and some of them survive today and are regarded by present-day Maoris as non-Pakeha items of diet. One of these is called rewena (leaven) bread, another is the panakeke, or pancake-type bread. (1966,Kapiti Coast,52)

EDWARDS I've a big rewena bread for lunch, made in the camp oven, brown and crusty. (1992,Mihipeka,29)

Taro, poke, tarua, green bananas, yams, red island mayonnaise and doughnnuts - and hangi food, pork bones and rewana bread. (1997,Mana,Autumn : 67)

Nesian Mystik is basically a tropical fruit salad with rewena bread on the side. (Apr 27, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),20)

rewena paraoa¶

n.

With Waitangi Day looming, why not celebrate by baking a form of sourdough much more suited to New Zealand's [sic] - rewena paraoa, or Maori Bread. (Feb 3, 2000,City Voice,8)

Dishes include a Tangaroa seafood platter with a piripiri (New Zealand chilli) dressing; steamed green-lipped mussels and wild herb tomato sauce with smoked suasage and grilled flaxseed paraoa (potato bread); and sauteed pasta with garlic and pikopiko (fern frond) pesto. (Sep 8, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

rewi¶

n.

These same two Australians on the previous weekend had turned up and peeled all our rewis (otherwise "spuds"). (Oct 30, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/5 : 107)

RFID¶

abbr. radio frequency identification tags

[Hdg] Kiwi RFID tags 'better' than global standard. Auckland hi-tech hope Sandtracker has secured the first paid trials for its Kiwi designed radio frequency identification tags... RFID tags for marathon runners are also expensive, hovering around $50 each. (Nov 15, 2004,Dominion Post,C10)

For the last few years, the wisdom has been that the next step on from bar-codes will be RFID (radio frequency identification tags; small computer chips that broadcast a product's identity over a short range. Using RFID, staff will only need to walk down an aisle with a receiver to count stock. (Apr 17, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),39)

RHA¶

abbr. Regional Health Authority

The RHA wants to buy a particular hospital service, of a particular quality and at a particular price. (Mar 13, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35)

rhagodia¶

n.

rhagodia [s] Rhagodia triandra (Forst.f.) Aellen (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,64)

RHD¶

abbr. rabbit haemorrhagic disease

But evidence shows the virus - also known as rabbit haemorrhagic disease or RDH - is failing as a sole means of pest control... (Dec 26, 2004,Sunday Star Times,A3)

Many regional councils which are responsible for monitoring rabbit populations, say hares are not becoming anything like the problem rabbits were before RHD's arrival. (Apr 15, 2004,Dominion Post,A4)

But the seasonal return of rabbit haemorrhagic disease at the end of the summer killed probably half the rabbits in those areas... Immunity to RHD in some areas was "creeping up year after year"... (Mar 20, 2002,Dominion,16)

rheumo¶

n. (informal) rheumatism. [ORIGIN: abbreviation, (? obsolesc)]

... get rheumo in after life. (Oct 21, 1905,NZ Truth,18/1/8)

rhino¶

n. money [(obsolesc)]

Mr Punch abhors all contact with filthy lucre', but he will accept, instead, any amount of the following substitutes, that is to say - any amount ofthe rhino', the ready',the stumpy', the brads',the tin', the brass',the dumps', the rowdy',the shiners', the mopusses' (wherewith people buy diamonds and topazes) (1860,Taranaki Punch,4/8)

THATCHER For Shadrach tries with drinks to coax the rhino out of you;/ (1865,Otago Songster,10)

THOMPSON ... he ...shtuck me oop in street ... und borrowed the rhino to file. (1909,Ballads about Business,11)

rhipogonum¶

n. Rhipogonum scandens

LAING & BLACKWELL climbing Rhipogonum (1906,Plants of NZ)

rhubarb¶

n. [flaxmilling]

CARR The cutter, armed with a sickle, stoops down and cuts the plant as near the base as he can get without taking in too much of the white growth, commonly called `rhubarb'. (1913,Country Work,43)

rhubarb fern¶

1 n. (Rural) a fern that grows readily in cleared bushland.

STEVENS The steers had also eaten off large patches of rhubarb fern. (Sep 16, 1914,Diary)

rhubarb season(, up you for the)¶

phr.

SLATTER Him and his cup of tea. Up him for the rhubarb season. Pommie bastard. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,233)

SLATTER Bert ... took it as a slight upon his family but Erik said it was of infinitesticle importance to him how he took it and up him for the rhubarb season. (1968,Pagan Game, The,168)

TUCKER Well we did the only thing possible by rushing back [27] to the bookies ... and seeking a refund of our hard-earned brass. This in the main was greeted with get lost' orrhubarb season' or several other epithets which are unprintable here, ... (1978,Thoroughbreds Are My Life,26)

RIANZ¶

abbr. Recording Industry Association of New Zealand

[IMNZ] has been set up to combat the influence of the recording industry association of New Zealand, which is dominated by multinationals. RIANZ is the voice most often heard when the government consults the recording industry. (Dec 5, 2001,Capital Times,3)

In fact, the New Zealand Top 50 singles chart - compiled and administered by the Recording Industry Association of New Zealand (Rianz) - isn't strictly a "sales" chart, and hasn't been since September 1999. (Mar 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

rib¶

v. ?irk; ?annoy; go against the grain with; ? swindle

McLEAN [He said] he would submit to any decision of the Court even though it `ribbed' him, but would not submit to any dictation from Dr. Featherstone (1870,Papers,34/94) [NOTES: (Maning)]

RIB¶

abbr. Racing Industry Board

Last November the Racing Industry Board, a largely government appointed organisation that oversees the funding and organisation of the industry, announced a new funding structure.. Ibid. 37 One negative effect of the RIB's restructuring is the possible closure of some small race clubs that will not be able to afford to keep going without the subsidies that have propped them up until now. (Feb 22, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

ribaldo¶

n.

Black cardinalfish, frostfish, ghost shark, ribaldo, rubyfish, sea perch, trumpeter, white warehou and yellow-eyed mullet have now been included... Other reductions to catch limits are to specific stocks of grey mullet, barracouta and oreo dory. (Sep 12, 1998,Dominion,2)

GRAHAM Ribaldo Mora pacifica Waite (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,404) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 404]

AYLING RIBALDO (Googly-eyed cod) Mora moro (Mora pacifica) ... The ribaldo is a plump-bodied cod ... (1982,Collins Guide,144,1984 ed.)

[species name] ribaldo .. [scientific name] Mora moro .. [other name(s)] deep sea cod, googly-eyed cod, mora (or morar) (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

Ribaldo Mora moro ... Alternatively googley-eyed cod. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,58)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] ribaldo 813 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Rick uses a species of cod.. that is different from any of the fish that we call cod. The only related species found in our waters are red cod and deep sea cod, also known as ribaldo. (Aug 7, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

ribbandfish¶

n.

In shape, they are usually long, deep and very much compressed and flattened on the sides, so much so that their local appellations always embody some idea of these peculiarities - such as ribband-fish, lath or deal fish, band fish or blade-fish, and also oar-fish. (1881,TrNZI,13/196) [NOTES: Clarke]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] ribbandfish 1100 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

ribbon fish¶

n. [aka ribbon-fish, ribbonfish]

[Caption] A ribbon-fish, 12 feet in length, the most perfect specimen yet found in New Zealand. (Sep 18, 1912,Otago Witness,45)

A ribbon-fish discovered at New Plymouth has attracted great attention. (Dec 3, 1895,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

There were the ribbonfish, from four or five inches to three feet in length; their eyes are very large, and protrude like those of a frog. (Apr 2, 1869,Star, The,2)

TAYLOR`625 A large fish, most probably a Lophotes (Matawa?) ribbon fish, thrown up on the Nelson coast ... was described by Mr. Travers as having a small head ..., and a body fifteen feet long tapering to the tail ... (1855,Te Ika a Maui)

SHERRIN Regalecus argenteus Parker Ribbon-fish, or Matarua (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,303)

DRUMMOND & HUTTON The flesh of deep sea fishes, such as the ribbon fish and the oarfish, becomes a jelly when boiled, and is quite unfit to eat. (1902,Nature in NZ)

PHILLIPPS Trachipterus trachypterus (Gmelin). RIBBON-FISH. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,26,1971 ed.)

I am of the opinion that some of these were Ribbon Fish, as the men stated that they fell to pieces when touched,... (1929,TrNZI,61/145) [NOTES: (Young)]

Trachipterus trachypterus (Gmelin). Ribbon-fish. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/407) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM Ribbon Fish Agrostichthys parkeri (Benham) ...Ribbon Fish Trachipterus arawatae Clarke (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,404) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 404]

GRAHAM RIBBON-FISH Trachipterus arawatae Clarke (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,185,2nd ed.)

NATUSCH RIBBONFISHES: Order ALLOTRIOGNATHI ... Long, thin fishes of this group ... sometimes come [ashore.] [captions Fig. 65] 1. Oarfish, Regalecus ... 5. Ribbonfish, Agrostichthys. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,216)

WILSON RIBBON FISH A rare, deep-sea dweller who is sometimes found washed ashore on ocean beaches. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,199)

AYLING RIBBONFISH (Dealfish) Trachipterus trachypterus ... The ribbonfish is similar to the oarfish but is much smaller ... (1982,Collins Guide,1984,189 ed.)

ribbon shopping¶

n.

Around the world there is a questioning of the value of malls compared with local and ribbon shopping. (Jan 18, 2000,Evening Post,4)

ribbon tree¶

n. occasional name for RIBBONWOOD (Andersen) =WHAUWHI [aka ribbon-tree; see also ribbon wood]

The ribbon tree is also a pretty tree, with large clusters of small white flowers produced in spring. (Jul 25, 1895,Otago Witness,49)

The spread was most liberal in quantity, and in quality unexceptionable, and the room was decorated with evergreens, among which a small ribbon tree in full blossom formed a conspicuous feature. (Feb 11, 1875,North Otago Times,2)

The Motu river, dark and placid, as it is from its source to the falls, fringed with fern trees and elegant shrubs, one of which - the ribbon tree or thousand jackets - was a mass of snowy bloom set in charming contrast with the surrounding evergreens. (May 4, 1903,Poverty Bay Herald,3)

HOOKER (And) [?] Plagianthus betulinus (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names))

FEATON PLAGIANTHUS BETULINUS (A.Cunn.) ... It is abundant in forests in most districts ..., reaching as far south as Otago, where it is generally known as the `Ribbon Tree', on account of the tough, fibrous, inner bark which it possesses (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,53)

NAIRN & SON (And) Gaya Lyallii (1912,Catalogue (Nairn & Son))

ribbon tree n : a New Zealand tree (Plagianthus betulinus) from whose inner bark a strong fiber resembling flax is obtained - see NEW ZEALAND COTTON (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1951)

ribbons¶

n.

HENDERSON RIBBONS: Slang term for reins. (1961,Friends in Chains,188) [NOTES: >c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 188]

ribbonwood¶

n. Hoheria papulnea [aka Lacebark. The tallest of three main ribbonwoods / lacebarks (12 metres), natural distribution just north half of north island.]

HOOKER Ribbon-wood of Otago. Hoheria populnea. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

HECTOR Hoheria populnea, A. Cunn. Hohere, Ribbonwood of Dunedin.--An ornamental shrub-tree, 10-30 feet high. Bark fibrous and used for cordage (1883,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),130)

FEATON HOHERIA POPULNEA (A.Cunn.) ... The HOUI' orWHAU-WHI'.- ... grows abundantly in both Islands ... Owing to the chaste [snow-white] appearance of its flowers, it has not inaptly been termed by some the New Zealand orange Blossom'. The inner bark is peculiar, and consists of layer upon layer of laced fibre, ...From this peculiarity it is called by the settlers theThousand Jacket', `lace-bark', or ... Ibid. 177 Houi [Maori name] .. Ribbon-wood [Settlers' name] .. Hoheria populnea .. Small tree (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,55)

NAIRN & SON (And) Hoheria populnea ribbonwood (1912,Catalogue (Nairn & Son))

houhere, a tree (Hoheria populnea), ribbonwood, lacebark, thousand-jacket. One of the three or four deciduous Maori trees. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/149) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

ribbonwood n 1 : a New Zealand shrub or small tree (Hoheria populnea) of the family Malvaceae having bark that is used for cordage and a profusion of small snow-white flowers in close axillary clusters - called also houhere 2 : RIBBON TREE (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1951)

Ribbon-wood or lace-bark tree ... Common on the central ranges and West Coast. (1868,TrNZI,1/33) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

WILSON Overhanging the tossing creek [at Lennox Falls, Otago] bend Ribbon-wood trees, [fn Hoheria populnea] with masses of soft, white blossom ... (1894,In the Land of the Tui,285) [NOTES: 1892 Jan 29 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 285]

n. names given to plants with a fibrous, lace-like inner bark espec. Hoheria, and Plagianthus spp =HOUHERE, =WILD CHERRY, =LACEBARK, =MANATU, =THOUSAND-JACKET [General; aka ribbon wood, ribbon-wood] (See houhere,mountain ribbonwood,lowland ribbonwood,marsh ribbonwood,saltmarsh ribbonwood et al)

No imported tree surpasses in lavishness of white blossom the New Zealand hoheria, variously called ribbonwood and lacebark, nor equals in beauty of shape or colour its intricately dentate and translucent green leaf. (Oct 12, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,14)

The woods, it appears, which struck the most were the Rewarewara [sic], Mangias, mottled Kauri, Ribbonwood, Totara, Mairi, Tanekaea, Matai, Rimu, white tea-tree, and white Kauri, the latter being much in quest by ship builders. (Jan 13, 1863,Wellington Independent,3)

LAING & BLACKWELL `Plants of both this [Hoheria] and of the next genus (Plagianthus), are popularly known as Ribbonwoods. The bast or inner bark is perforated by the medullary rays, and this gives to it a characteristic, ribbon-like appearance.' (1940,Plants of NZ,270)

... in some cases, such as the Ribbon woods, plants of different genera are included in the one group..Ribbon Wood (Plagianthus betulinus). A very ornamental tree, especially when in flower, being covered with small white flowers... Ribbon Wood (Hoheria populnea var. angustifolia)... Ribbon Wood (Pennantia corymbosa). This tree and the two former [Plagianthus and Hoheria], are often confounded, being very similar in general appearance, in soft, white, easily splitting, worthless wood; in the season, being covered with masses of small white fragrant flowers; ... Ribbon Wood (Hoheria populnea var. crataegifolia)... Ribbon Wood, or Lace-bark tree (Plagianthus Lyalli) A very ornamental shrub tree, with large leaves and flowers. Common on the central ranges and west coast... Ribbonwood. Plagianthus betulinus, A. Cunn. Ibid. 40 Ribbonwood. Hoheria populnea, var. angustifolia ... Ribbonwood. Pennantia Corymbosa (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

[Native name] Houi .. [Settlers' name] Ribbonwood ..[Family] Malvaceae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

WHITE Its vernacular names are Ribbon Wood' andLace Bark,' for when the bark is pulled off and cut into strips it reminds one of insertion lace. (1905,My NZ Garden,90)

CHEESEMAN The Maoris apply the names hoihere or houhere to varieties [of Hoheria populnea] indifferently; the European settlers usually call all the forms ribbon-wood' orlacebark', names which are, unfortunately, also used for Plagianthus betulinus and Gaya Lyallii. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,79)

LAING & BLACKWELL The varied names given by the Maoris in different districts to this plant [Hoheria spp.], are all said to spring from the same root. Whau [252] signifies wrapped about, netted, - like lace, and the treeis so called from the character of its inner bark. Thesettlers name it lace-bark, ribbon-wood, [1940 edn, no hyphens] or thousand-jacket. (1907,Plants of NZ,251,1940 p. 264 ed.)

175 ribbonwood: hoheria. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.)

A small New Zealand tree of the mallow family; also called `lacebark'. [both Hoheria and Plagianthus are mallows] (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),344,8th ed.)

HENDERSON ... picturing the start of the track and lacebark or ribbonwood in flower bringing thoughts of white glimpses of miners' sudden canvastowns. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,131)

ribbonwood n. a small evergreen malvaceous tree of New Zealand. Its wood is used in furniture-making. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,990) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 655]]

On the whole the beech forest is dark and gloomy, but here and there it may be lighted up by a tuft of scarlet or yellow native mistletoe [fn Species of Loranthus.], or in spring by the gay garlands of white clematis; while in the more open places grows the beautiful ribbon-wood [fn Gaya ribifolia, slightly different from the more western Gaya lyallii.], with a profusion of white flowers resembling pear-blossom. Ibid. Masses of Ribbonwood will give a pale green hue to a portion of a hillside, ... (1900,Canterbury Old & New,186)

On account of the fibrous nature of [Plagianthus Lyallii's] inner bark, it is popularly known in the Middle Island as one of the Ribbon Wood' orLace Bark' trees, as is the Hoheria populnea, and its varieties in the Northern Island. Ibid. 178 Whauwhi [Maori name] .. Ribbon wood [Settlers' name] .. Plagianthus Lyallii .. Small tree `Ribbon-wood'. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,54)

HARPER There is also the rata tree, the prince of firewoods, ... miki-miki, kamahi, or so-called red-birch, white and black birches (which are really beeches), the mountain broom, ribbon wood, broad leaf, totara, and many others, ... and always available in the Ranges [sc. Alps]. (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,35)

MORRIS Ribbonwood, n. All species of Plagianthus and Hoheria are to the colonists Ribbonwood, especially Plagianthus betulinus, A. Cunn., and Hoheria populnea, A Cunn., the bark of which is used for cordage, and was once used for making a demulcent drink. Alpine Ribbon-wood, Plagianthus lyalli. Hook. Other popular names are Houhere, Houi (Maori), Lace-bark (q.v.), and Thousand-Jacket (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,386)

CHEESEMAN [Plagianthus betulinus, A.Cunn.] Ribbon-wood of Europeans; manatu of the Maoris. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,78)

McLINTOCK Ribbonwood .. .. manatu .. .. Plagianthus betulinus (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

Houhere (lacebark or ribbonwood) head piece. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,182)

The pillars and styles of this are of rimu, the panels of ribbonwood, and the mouldings of riwariwa. (Oct 4, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,7)

MORELAND Another tree which sheds its leaves is the ribbon-wood... [Note.] Gaya Lyalli. (1911,They Led the All Blacks,83)

Their names have been burnt onto stakes identifying them as the planters of nikau, akeake, hoho, mahoe, and ribnbonwood, all Chatham Island natives. (Nov 2002,Footnotes,No. 18/7)

Over a dozen species and varieties new to the Chatham islands have been obtained and these include.. a ribbonwood (Plagianthus cymosus). (Mar 4, 1924,Otago Witness,70)

adj. [attrib, eg ribbonwood trees]

THOMSON Most of these valleys were covered with stunted scrub and large patches of ribbonwood trees, where the deer seemed to hide or camp during the day, ... (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,99)

Ribbon-wood "jacket" packed over swellings and lumps, made useful substitutes for dressings of abscesses and tumours. (Apr 20, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

rice grass¶

n.

PERRY There are a few other grasses used to a limited extent, such as Rice grass, Tall Oat grass, and Prairie grass, but they have a limited use, and need not be considered here. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,104) [NOTES: [?=meadow rice grass JD]]
