The fine-bladed grass is Microlena stipoides, or Rice grass, indigenous to the colony. (Dec 30, 1893,Auckland Weekly News,35)

rice rocket¶

n. an Asian driver

After chatting with our very own Finlay Macdonald about ordinary bad drivers, "rice rockets" and Roman chariot hoons, Sundae wheeled on regular Tuesdae guest Natural Ange, a naturopath with a real fondness for camomile tea. (Jun 1, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67)

rice-paper¶

n. in NZ, a thin, easy-burning paper used in roll-your-own cigarettes (as distinct from the edible rice paper made from the pith of a small tree, a member of the ginseng family (CCR)

rice-paper plant¶

n. [CC Ransom comments: a variety of ginseng. Dictionary of Gastronomy (Andre L. Simon and Robin Howe (Deitsch, London 1978) under `RICE-PAPER made from the pith of a ... tree and edible]

rice-paper plant [s] Tetrapanax papyrifera (Hook.f.) K. Koch (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,64)

rice-plant¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH We sucked honey from various spring flowers, but the most prized was a low-growing and a very prickly native heather with flowers about half or three quarters of an inch long that grew on the stony plain. There were masses of it which we called rice-plant because its masses of sweet, juicy white berries spread out near the ground resembled polished rice in appearance. A plant that we called `wild birch' (because its leaves resembled birch leaves, I suppose) had red astringent berries that we enjoyed. It grew among the manuka scrub. ... (1900; Lower Moutere) (1981,History of Children's Play,115)

Richard Cranium¶

n. synonym for dickhead

This had all been caused because some "Richard Cranium", who'd probably gained a degree in stupidity from somewhere, had been employed to come up with an idea to reduce accidents. (Jan 29, 2001,Evening Post,4)

Richdale's diving petrel¶

n.

Three [bones] were indentified as Richdale's diving petrel, and two, both juvenile, as sooty shearwater, confirming both these species bred on the island. (May 2005,NZ Geographic,No 73 / 9)

ricie¶

n. a Japanese motorbike

Japanese bikes were once known disparagingly as "ricies", but this prejudice seems to have disappeared, possibly because of their dominance of racing for the last thirty years. (2000,Directions,Summer 2000 No. 46 : 56)

rick-ma-tick¶

n.

Alison Nevill, of Dunedin, asks about the fascinating phrase "the whole rick-ma-tick". She says her Scottish grandmother employed a maid in the 40s who used it constantly, meaning something like "that's all there is to it". The maid came from Stirling, and the family always thought it was one of her home-town expressions, so when Alison got to New Zealand, she was surprised to hear it being used in the same context of finality. "The whole rick-ma-tick" has a long and honourable history as a Scottish version of "the whole kit and caboodle", an expression from the United States east coast that is widely understood here as an ornate alternative to "the whole lot". (Mar 19, 2003,Dominion Post,B7)

ricker¶

n. a young kauri in the pole stage [(? forestry or sawmillers')]

6 The fifty-feet kauri rika goal posts excited much admiration. (Jul 29, 1930,Northern Advocate)

ADAMS Kauri rickers made up the first cargoes. (1973,Kauri,16)

REED The young tree is known as a "ricker", a name derived from an old Anglo-Saxon word applied to a pole used in making hayricks, or to the spar of a boat. The name was probably first applied to the young kauri by the men of the Royal Navy in search of ships' spars. (1964,New Story of the Kauri, The,44)

At a given signal they gave one strong pull altogether to see if everything was safe; and the tall kauri ricker trembled and quivered from top to butt. (Aug 23, 1884,Wanganui Herald,2)

"I would advocate the reproduction of the kauri tree, as I am credibly informed that a kauri ricker when 20 years old exudes that white resinous matter which is the kauri gum in its primitive state. .." (Nov 12, 1902,Otago Witness,34)

A COMPACT FARM, situate in Soldier's Bay, on the North Shore, containing 21 acres 6 roods; it is well adapted for Dairy and other purposes, a considerable quantity being covered with grass of 3 year's [sic] growth; there are seven acres of fire-wood, and abundance of rickers for masts; bark for the tanner, various dye woods, and an overflowing stream of fresh water. (Apr 7, 1849,Daily Southern Cross,1)

In the Waitakere hills across the valley, kauri rickers are starting to poke their heads above the other trees. (Apr 27, 1997,Sunday Star Times,C7)

BOOTH [=a native pine] ... the roof [of the station buildings, Canterbury c1859] were of round pine framing covered with rickers (young pine plants) and thatched with snow grass. (1912,Five Years in NZ,24)

... a vigorous second growth interspersed with young kauri rickers soon appeared. (1949,NZ Geographic,57)

REED The sapling [of kauri] is known as a ricker', sometimes incorrectly speltrika' It is not, however, of Maori origin, but an old Anglo-Saxon term applied to a pole used in making hay-ricks, or to the spar of a boat. The name was probably first applied to the young kauri by the men of the Royal Navy in search of ships' spars. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,61)

Ricker: (b) A kauri tree in the pole stage, N.Z. (1956,NZ Timber Journal,4/9/56)

McLINTOCK Rikka, the bushman's word for a young kauri, long supposed to be a Maori word, turns out to be an English dialect word for a pole, apparently introduced by workers from England in the kauri timber trade as long ago as the 1790s. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679) [NOTES: (Wall NZ Speech)]

JOHNSON Out from the valley we came upon a company of young kauri ...; tall rickers fit for the early sailing ships. (1970,Life's Vagaries,80)

MOORE & IRWIN ... the spire-like young [kauri] tree is called a `ricker'. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,212)

ricker n. young Kauri tree (1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,418) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

OWEN & PERKINS Then it would be necessary to use the smaller kauris, the young trees known as rikkers. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,150) [NOTES: (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)]

There was a long bridge on the main road,.. the piles of which, totara rickers, had rotted away. (Sep 13, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,7)

OWEN & PERKINS Then it would be necessary to use the smaller kauris, the young trees known as rickers. Ibid. 162. They used kauri rickers as cranes. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,150)

In April and March the Moriori lashed rickers to the tree boles to climb up by. (Aug 10, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,18)

n.

Virtually all the gentler lower slopes are now covered in regenerating kanuka-kauri ricker forest 95-130 years old. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/20)

THOMSON In those days, when there were several in one tent, we used to make what was called a community bunk, as there was not enough room to erect ricker (small round rails or saplings) bunks for four men. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,48)

n. a pole or spar cut from a long, slender tree-trunk; the trunk of such a tree; (occas ?) such a tree [?d. Ed Fairburn Makaratanga 29 [cut] long, thin `Rickers' and made them into ladders. (Auckland bushmen's and forestry general) (occas. rika) a kauri sapling; a kauri-tree in the pole stage]

McNAB [Cargo from NZ] 10 logs of timber, 890 rickers, 165 handspikes, 13 casks of black whale oil, ... 3 tons flax, 86 bundles coopers' flags, ... [consigned to George Weller]. (1913,Old Whaling Days,102) [NOTES: 1834 Apr 26 Log Lucy Ann: Cargo in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 102]

1 RICKER, 53ft x 13in. at the butt. (Nov 24, 1847,New Zealander, The,1)

CONNELL & RIDINGS Will Sell by Auction, THIS DAY, 20th inst., at 11 o'clock, on the Beach, Mechanics' Bay, FIFTY KAURI SPARS and RICKERS ... (Jan 20, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,2)

May 31 - River Chief, brig, 158 tons, James H. Horseley, for Tahiti, with 15 spars, 13,600 feet of timber, 25 rickers, 7,700 feet sawn timber, 20,000 feet ditto. (Jun 4, 1851,New Zealander, The,2)

POLACK ... I was employed collecting a quantity of spars, for ships' masts, ... &c., logs, for sawing into plank, and rickers or trunks of trees, of narrow diameter but great length. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/93)

J. WHITE ... cutting rickers for Jess. (1847,Journal,74)

3/88 The noose made of a slender strip of flax leaf attached to the end of a ricker or rod. (1871,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Potts) [Canterbury]

... he picked up a ricker and twisted in the [fence] gap mechanically. (1900,NZ Illustrated Magazine,3/256)

On many farms in this colony `rickers' can be got for the cutting [for fence-making]. (1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,94)

BAUCKE That the walls are formed of posts sunk into the ground, covered with a network of rickers, overlaid with tongai (dried flax blades) toe-toe, or raupo ... Ibid. 253 It was an appetising display ... a mound of potatoes, haangi steamed, ... alternated with stacks of eels enclosed in wrappings of `raurekau' leaves (coprosma grandifolia), baked on a framework of rickers over a clear fire, ... delicate of flavour. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,7)

Having provided ... ricker saplings and other materials of wood, he [the Moriori] gathered dry flower stalks of Phormium ... (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs,. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 363) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 363]

THOMSON ... there was not enough room to erect ricker (small round rails or saplings bunks for four men. Ibid. 97 The bunks were made entirely from rickers (young birch saplings), while from several packing cases we constructed cupboards, making them mice-proof. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,48)

Ricker: (a) A long pole or sapling used for handling floating timber at the docks. (1956,NZ Timber Journal,2/9/56)

COLE (1949,It Was So Late,14)

CHEVASSE & JOHNS The dangerous job was then to roll the logs down to a stream or on to a skid road made of "rickers". (1983,NZ Forest Parks,27)

ridage¶

n.

Maria Priestly Giggling, McMullan says the few female participants is not because of the danger, it's because of uncomfortable ridage - a rowing requisite. "you have to put your togs up your bum." (Apr 2005,Capital Times,No 28? p5)

riddling¶

n.

REED Some of these peat swamps were so mixed with nuts and chips that it paid to put them through a washing and sifting process, known as `riddling,' and in this manner thousands of sacks of gum were retrieved in the summer months. (1972,Gumdiggers, The,63)

ride¶

v. to loaf on, to let somebody do part of one's share of work. (cp CARRY) [ca1951 Foxton Freezing Works.]

v. usu. ride in, sc. stock, esp. cattle

FITTON I have seen here clergymen ploughing, ... officers of the army ... riding in stock, and no one thought the worse of them, but the contrary. (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),354) [NOTES: 1852 Dec J.R.Godley's Address in 1856 Fitton NZ 354]

W.H.S. ROBERTS At Macfarlane's the men saddled fresh horses and rode in some cattle which we had a great bother to yard, ... The yard was divided into three - ... but as there was no crush pen, or drafting race, we had to head rope those requiring brands, and ... legroped and threw them ... (Dec 18, 1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. ROBERTS Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43]

THOMSON (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher) [NOTES: [see quot COVE.]]

BOOTH I learned to ride stock, shoe horses, shear sheep ... (1912,Five Years in NZ,30)

ride boundary¶

phr. (See boundary)

ride one's hobnails¶

phr. (Rural) to walk (See by hobnail express)

STAPLES Peterson rode his horse and Shiny rode his hobnails. (1964,Cooks and Shepherds Come Away,42)

They do not walk, they ride their hobnails, and on horseback they ride the pigskin. (Nov 22, 2002,Dominion Post,C6)

ride out¶

v. (Rural) to separate cattle in a mob, with the use of a stockhorse.

DAVIS Once the calves had mothered up again a few days later, they were quietly ridden out of the mob and sent to Waihora. (1994,Lab Coats to Gumboots,8)

ride round¶

v. (Rural) to block or inspect stock, especially during lambing or calving.

Rode round Raw paddock. (Apr 7, 1889,Tutira Station Diary)

MOWAT 'Riding round' the ewes. (Nov 23, 1906,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

SHARPE .. the shepherd spends several hours of each day in 'riding round the sheep', long the most popular job of any sheep farm. The job of riding round the sheep can be done by a schoolchild, the owner's wife or a land girl. (1962,Country Occasions,27)

NEWTON .. if any further argument against riding round ewes was needed ... (1966,Boss's Story, The,69)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR In the meantime my main job was to ride round the paddocks for cast sheep and keep an eye on growing lambs. (1981,Sunrise on Hikurangi,96)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR But Jim Clews had a theory that we did more harm than good in riding round the ewes in dirty weather. (1981,Sunrise on Hikurangi,112)

ride the block¶

phr. (Rural) [shepherding or lambing] to 'ride round' or inspect ewes and lambs.

DREAVER The job of 'riding the block' in the spring was great. (1994,Catlins River Wisp Run,57)

ride the gummy-gummies¶

phr. (Rural) [cattle] to walk astride a small tree (thought to be Nothopanax colensoi), eat the particularly glossy, palatable leaves, and on finishing, leave it to spring back.

BUCKINGHAM The cattle used also to 'ride the gummy-gummies' which were small trees with wide shiny leaves - good feed, they loved it. They learnt to straddle these trees and push them over so that they could get a the tasty leaves. (1969,From Hethersett to Quarry Hills,44)

ride the pine¶

phr. (Sport) to sit on the substitutes' bench

England's bovver boy hooker Richard Cockerill jeered at Norman Hewitt about Hewitt riding the pines in Dunedin. (Jun 28, 1998,Sunday Star Times,B2)

[Caption] Sitting it out: Lock Keith Robinson rides the pine after injuring his calk on Friday night. (Aug 2, 2004,Dominion Post,D8)

ride work¶

phr.

T. Buddicomb, after a long absence from the saddle, has once more commenced to ride work. (Dec 3, 1902,Otago Witness,47)

.. and I am of the opinion that jockeys disqualified for minor offences, such as "suspicious" riding or disobedience at the post ought to be allowed to ride work on the training tracks during the time of their suspension. (Jun 4, 1891,Otago Witness,26)

A.J. M'Flynn, who was unfortunate enough to receive a nasty crumpling right on the eve of the big winter fixtures, has now recovered sufficiently to be able to ride work and hopes to be fit enough to take a let up in public at Avondale next month. (Jul 22, 1913,Evening Post,2)

Jockeys are supposed to attend in the morning to ride work, and their licenses are issued on that understanding. (Oct 10, 1925,NZ Truth,11)

When Woodville finished, Hec. jumped aboard the Limited that night and hurried north to be at Takanini to ride work the next morning. (Dec 18, 1930,NZ Truth,13)

(1950,Landfall,4/1: 19)

GEE (1959,Short Stories (various authors),271) [NOTES: 1959 Gee in 1966 Short Stories 271]

ridge fence¶

1 n. (Rural) a fenceline on the outside of a ridge.

LEVY When there are ridge fences on a property, and there is good access to the tops of the hills for stock on each side of the fences as a result of bulldozing the ridges before the erection of fences, the cleaning of the country is greatly facilitated. (1970,Grasslands of NZ,202)

LEVY Ridge fencing is needed to control stock. (1970,Grasslands of NZ,260)

ridge-board¶

n.

The ridge-boards are carved to represent a number of ngarara, or lizards, running along the roof, and the maihi, or gable-boards, have carvings of the mythological animal known as the manaia - probably a kind of taniwha. (1895,TrNZI,27/674)

ridge-pole¶

n. (informal) the head

He.. told me several amazing anecdotes of his younger days - "days before the hatch began to blow off the ridge pole," as Bob observed, stroking the bald part of his head. (Dec 23, 1890,Otago Witness,17)

2 n. of a Maori meeting-house

ROCHFORT The church [at Otaki] is quite original ... the sides and ends are lined with panels of plaited flax ... these are continued as high as the ridge-pole. Ibid. 35 After a smoke a corrobery* ensued, then we began to think of taking some rest. The whare was built of toi-toi, about 12 feet by 8, and 6 feet to the ridge-pole; ... [fn] Conversation. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,27)

COWAN Kimble Bent, the pakeha-Maori, related to me that when Te Ua was in Otapawa pa ... a ruru flew from the forest at dusk and perched on the ridge-pole of the house in front of which the prophet was sitting. (1922,NZ Wars, The,2/7,1983 ed.)

3 n.

Mr White then said, that was his object too; why then should the Wanganui tribe be divided! it [sic] was one house, let there be but one ridge-pole. (Mar 28, 1863,Otago Witness,7)

IHIMAERA The whanau was my home. The love and affection they held for each other were the ridgepoles of my heart. (1986,Matriarch, The,107)

ridge-pole rafter¶

n. praying mantis

BARLOW Another curious insect found here is the Mantis,' commonly called, on account of its shape,the ridge-pole rafter.' (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,186)

ridge-riding¶

n.

GEELEN Like other experienced topdressing pilots he selected this ridge because it lay parallel to the sowing direction and he kept as close as possible to it thereby taking advantage of the added lift provided by the air rising off the ridge face. This procedure, known as "ridge riding", meant the aircraft was flown about five metres above the crest of the ridge and slightly to one side of it. (1983,Topdressers, The,111)

n. (Rural) the flying of an aircraft close to the top and one side of a ridge, in order to catch a lift or upwards draught.

GEELEN This procedure, known as "ridge-riding" meant the aircraft was flown about five metres above the crest of the ridge and slightly to one side of it. (1983,Topdressers, The,111)

ridgeline¶

n.

Much of the Town Belt is on ridgelines close to the city's urban areas... However, protection of some ridgelines is not always guaranteed... Do you want to help to develop criteria to manage activities on ridgetops and hilltops. (Dec 2000,Dominion,unpaged)

1 n. (Rural) [sp. use] the horizon of a grazing hill ridge.

Their 87ha block rises some 305, bounded below by stream bed and above by a ridgeline. (Jul 2001,Lifestyle Farmer,12)

They graze a strip of grass up near the ridgeline with an electric fence to keep them out of regenerating bush. (2001,Lifestyle Farmer,14)

ridging-plough¶

1 n. (Rural) a plough, used in swampy areas, to raise ridges upon which plants can be established.

It [the land] was again ploughed in the spring and worked into a fine tilth, being then drilled with a ridging-plough. (Jun 9, 1898,Hawera Star,4)

ridgy¶

1 adj. (Rural) [used elsewhere, but significant in NZ hill country]

Country ridgy and broken, approaching to mountainous (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,239)

Even on the ridgy lands the crops are better than for many years. (Feb 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,154)

riding¶

n. a territorial subdivision of a county

He considered his road the worst in the riding. (Jun 7, 1930,Northern Advocate,2)

The following are the divisions of [t]he Auckland counties into ridings so far as the work had progressed up to yesterday afternoon. (Nov 30, 1876,Daily Southern Cross,3)

The electoral roll for the County of Whangarei, on which the poll will be taken on Wednesday next, contains 802 names, distributed as follows:- Hikurangi riding 156, Kiripaka riding 110, Manaia riding 244, Maunu riding 203, Otonga riding 89. (Nov 4, 1899,Northern Advocate,5)

The voting is taking place for the County Council under the new riding system, whereby eight ridings return one member each, instead of three ridings three each. (Nov 10, 1920,Poverty Bay Herald,3)

BARLOW The main road through the county is supposed to be constructed by the County Council, which is composed of representatives from the several ridings or districts forming the county, each riding electing a councillor every three years. (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,95)

When the nine provinces were abolished in 1876 the colony was divided for local government purposes into counties, regard being had to boundaries of existing road districts, and the counties were subdivided into ridings, each riding being empowered to elect a certain number of members of the Council of the county. The ridings comprise one or more of the above three districts. They have no governing body - they are simply the electoral divisions of the county, and their maximum number is nine. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,142)

THOMAS The term `riding' as part of a county would have little meaning today. (1970,Way Up North,75)

riding ... NZ a sub-division of a local government authority (Kapiti riding). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,656) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 419]]

He noted that GBP400 had been allocated to the Waverley riding. (Jul 9, 1918,Hawera & Normanby Star,5)

RIFA¶

abbr. red imported fire ants

Some insects, instead of risking the hazards of riding the wind, take the safer option of hitchhiking on aircraft. This seems to hasve been the case with a nest of red imported fire ants (RIFA) found at Auckland Airport in March, 2001... RIFA originate in the swampy Pantanal area of Brazil, Paraguay and Argentina. (Mar 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 56/18)

riffle¶

n. [goldmining]

BLYTH Riffles: The diagonal, lengthwise or cross pieces or grooves in sluices which catch the heavier metallic particles allowing the clay and sand to pass. The value of the wash up is determined by the amount of gold or other metal caught in the riffles or other devices. (1935,Gold Mining Year Book,11)

MAY RIFFLE OR RIPPLE: both terms were used for the grooves cut across the bottom of a sluice-box or for the much more common wooden bars fixed at right angles, obliquely, or lengthwise, to the bottom of a sluice. The riffleboard' was detachable and formed afalse bottom'. Riffle' was probably a Californian term;ripple' seems to have been more usual on the goldfields of Australasia. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,528,1962 ed.)

NOLAN Riffle: shallow stretch of a stream or river, between pools, where the water runs fast and undulating. Also, probably by derivation, a raised wooden or metal crossbar in a sluice box. (1983,Gold Fossicker's Handbook,113)

riffleboard¶

n. (See riffle)

rifflebox¶

n. [(goldmining) 1868 [get quots from discards]] (See also ripple)

rifle game¶

n.

Thomson's stalking was not limited to red deer. He has followed most introduced rifle game in the South Island. (Apr 8, 1953,Freedom,5)

Rifle Ranger¶

n. (historical) (usually pl.) [cf. (bush-)ranger]

HURSTHOUSE The ranks of our Rifle Rangers, our Volunteer Corps [in Taranaki] (1865,England's NZ War,17)

rifle wren¶

n.

I have ... seen only one Bush Wren, two Rifle Wrens, two Saddlebacks, and no Rock Wrens [in Nelson]. (1893,TrNZI,25/59) [NOTES: (Buller)]

riflebeak¶

n. =RIFLEMAN ?misunderstanding or error

HULL I do not know to what to attribute the scarcity of small birds, ...such as crows, saddlebacks, thrushes, tuis, canaries, wrens, riflebeaks, fantails and many others. (1987,Richard Henry of Resolution Island,88) [NOTES: 1897 Apr 5 E.H. Wilmot Exploration and Topographical Survey in Fiord Country in 1987 Hill Richard Henry of Resolution Island 88]

rifleman¶

n. a tiny New Zealand bush bird, Acanthisitta chloris, [probably from green and bronze plumage resembling an early military uniform] (See also thumb bird)

HUTTON 15. XENICUS STOKESII. Gray. Grey Wren. Stripe-faced Wren. Rifleman. ... a broad white streak from each nostril over each eye to the back of the head; ... (1871,Birds of New Zealand,7)

BULLER ACANTHISITTA CHLORIS {ACANTHIDOSITTA CHLORIS}. (RIFLEMAN.) ... Native names. Titipounamu, {Kikimutu,} Kikirimutu, Pihipihi, Piripiri, Tokepiripiri, and Moutuutu. [(1873) 113] The Rifleman is the smallest of our New-Zealand birds; .... It is very generally distributed. [f.n. explaining Acanthidositta as more correct Greek] (1873,Birds of New Zealand,112)

BULLER ... to say nothing of Korimako and Pitoitoi ... we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even than the Huia. The Zosterops was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/14)

MORRIS Rifleman, n. a bird of New Zealand, Acanthisitta chloris, Buller; Maori name, Titipounamu. See quotation. The name is sometimes applied also to the Rifle-bird [? in Australia] (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,388)

Rii.fle-man (r&imacr.i.f'l-man), n. [Add.] 2. (Zoo.].) A small passerine bird of New Zealand (Acanthidositta chloris); so called from its green and bronze plumange, which is thought to resemble the uniform of the early British volunteer rifle corps. Buller. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

Amongs[t?] the creepers there are the bush-wren, the rock-wren, the rifleman and the yellow-headed native canary. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,195)

WILLIAMS Houtuutu, n. Acanthidositta chloris, bush wren. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,75)

Acanthisitta chloris Sparr. Rifleman. Owing to the uncertainty regarding the species denoted by the term wren' as used by the average observer, many records which may apply to this species have been left strictly alone. In the Wellington District the grey warbler (<i>Maorigerygone igata</i> Quoy & Gaim.) is often referred to in popular parlance as thenative wren.' (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/87) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

POWELL RIFLEMAN (Acanthisitta chloris). This is a wren and our smallest bird, being only three inches in total length. There are two forms, typical chloris from the South Island and A. chloris granti, the North Island rifleman....The Maori name is Titi-pounamu. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,86)

rifleman: smallest forest bird. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

SUTHERLAND The robins, riflemen and tomtits tamed very soon, the robins being an easy first in this respect. (1953,Golden Bush, The,108,1963 ed.)

WILLIAMS Houtuutu, n. Acanthidositta chloris, rifleman, a bird. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,63)

  1. A popular name for a New Zealand wren also called `bush wren' Its green plumage suggests the uniform worn by riflemen long ago. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),345)

EVANS Bush robins, parakeets, tomtits, grey warblers, riflemen, pigeons and the bush hawk are still to be seen. (1962,Waikaka Saga,129)

FALLA et al. RIFLEMAN Acanthisitta chloris Other names: Titipounamu, Thumbie (Nelson). (1966,Birds of New Zealand,191)

McLINTOCK Rifleman .. .. titi-pounamu .. .. Acanthisitta chloris (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

~ n. diminutive New Zealand bird. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

NATUSCH Our tiniest native bird is the rifleman ... , which lives in beech forests of the North and South island, from sea level to high country ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,277)

rifleman n. diminutive N.Z. bird. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

rifleman ... 2. a wren of New Zealand. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,992) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 656]]

Rifleman Acanthisitta chloris (SPARRMAN, 1787) ... South Island Rifleman A.c. chloris (SPARRMAN, 1787) North Island Rifleman A.c. granti MATHEWS & IREDALE, 1913. ... OTHER NAME: Titipounamu. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,264)

MASTERS A pair of dainty mountain riflemen hopped onto a tree within arm's length, ... Ibid. 79 ... maybe a pair of mountain riflemen and a bellbird, ... (1960,Back-Country Tales,77)

239.a. Acanthisitta chloris granti Mathews and Iredale, 1913 North Island Rifleman (1973,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,63)

239.b. Acanthisitta chloris chloris (Sparrman, 1787) South Island Rifleman (Titipounamu) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,63)

It's a titipounamu, and you often find him in the ti-tree scrub... It is the rifleman, very shy, and a friend of the scrub-cutter. (Feb 5, 1995,NZ Tablet,7)

I knew the tiny hole in the ribbonwood or the beech into which the riflemen crept. (Sep 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

rig¶

n. a small commercially fished shark; also called gummy shark, spotted dogfish (See dogfish)

One commercial fisherman was setting rig nets up to 800 metres long in the inner Sounds - a "wall of death" for fish - yet there were no rules in place to stop it, he said. (Jan 16, 2002,Dominion,9)

Year in, year out, Muriwai fisherman Nathan Adams sets his nets off the west coast of the North Island. Mostly he catches rig, the fish formerly known as dog fish, now exported to Australia for good money. (Mar 30, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

Mustelus antarcticus: Common dogfish, pioke (Auckland), rigg (Canterbury). (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,71)

But many wholesalers have told us they are moving away from marketing school shark,' Mr Gradwell said.They prefer rig, elephant fish or spotty shark.' (Nov 8, 1977,Dominion,1/7)

SORENSON SMOOTHOUND (a) Scientific name: Mustelus antarcticus. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Small Flake Fillets (restricted to this species); Smoothound. (c) Other common names: Kini; Pioke; Lemons; Lemonfish; Dogfish; Rig; Silver Strip (fillets); Sweet William; Flake. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,44)

AYL.ING SPOTTED SMOOTH-HOUND Mustelus lenticulatus (Gummy shark, spotted dogfish, rig, pioke) (1982,Collins Guide,56,1984 ed.)

It seems mystery surrounds the fish commonly served...in our fish and chip shops - the rig, or spotted dog fish. (Apr 2, 1983,Dominion,5)

HULME Simon made the acquaintance of barracouta, ling, trumpeter, and rig, and red cod, kelp cod, and rock cod. (1983,Bone People, The,251)

PAUL Rig Mustelus lenticulatus ... Other names include spotted dogfish, gummy shark, smoothhound and pioke. Often listed as Mustelus antarcticus, but this name now applies only to a similar Australian species. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,30)

[species name] rig .. [scientific name] Mustelus lenticulatus .. [other name(s)] spotted dogfish, gummy shark, kini, pioke, smooth hound, deepsea bream, lemonfish, spotted gummy shark, sweet william, dogi (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] rig 214 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

n. cf notes OED sb. slang and coll. cf EDD 1. chiefly in run (one's) rigs(s) upon (another). =to make sport, game of : now dial. [c1840 -] 2. trick; swindling racket 3b. run a (or the) rig, run (one's) rigs =play pranks, run riot : 1782-1886 ?dial - Nth? [prison slang]

(1865,Punch in Canterbury,42)

n. [?Otago-Southland]

SHAW & TARRANT At that [c 1860] time the land was ploughed in `rigs' five and a half yards in width, and each man when sowing or harvesting kept to his allotted strip. (1949,Taieri Plain,218)

SHAW & TARRANT At that [c 1860] time the land was ploughed in `rigs' five and a half yards in width, and each man when sowing or harvesting kept to his allotted strip. (1949,Taieri Plain,218)

rig shark¶

n. (See rig)

BROWN Not too many flat fish ... a good proportion of cod and elephants with a few rig sharks ... thrown in for good measure. (1986,Weaver's Apprentice, The,91)

rigger¶

2 n. orig. SQUARE-RIGGER, a square-gin bottle; thence any large flagon or demijohn for holding esp. draught beer. (or, Havelock, vinegar) cf PETER @n2 [(Jack Columbus 1980 Aug 25) ca1930's (Canterbury) for a square rigger; 40oz square green bottle of square (HJKZ) gin; also for stone jars, a gallon.]

A rigger (the modern plastic flagon) of Black Magic from the Sunshine Brewery in Gisborne won't set your mouth on fire but it will leave the taste of burning behind it. (Apr 25, 2001,Capital Times,17)

Any bloke who's had to carry a half-dozen riggers.. all the way.. to New Lynn could simply laugh at forced marches as child's play. (Dec 14, 1955,NZ Truth,4)

BENNETT A quart bottle of beer is a rigger, and a pint bottle a marine; doubtless neither of these terms is peculiar to New Zealand, but they are rarely, if ever, heard in England (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,89)

BENNETT A quart bottle of beer is a rigger, and a pint bottle a marine; doubtless neither of these terms is peculiar to New Zealand, but they are rarely, if ever, heard in England (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,89)

We were just getting back to normal again when he produced an old-time rigger which, he said, contained wampo. (Jun 1957,NZ Truth) [NOTES: 1957 June J.R. Sheehan in Truth in $72]

McGILL rigger quart of beer, precursor of the half-gallon jar; short for `squarerigger'. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,92)

This drew a crowd round, and he tried to humor [sic] her by first getting her home, and then getting a jar and two riggers of beer from the hotel. (Dec 16, 1911,NZ Truth,338/5/5)

I'd always bring a couple of riggers [of beer]. (1943,NZ New Writing,5) [NOTES: (Sargeson Episode)]

SARGESON riggers: large bottles of beer. (1964,Collected Stories,302)

TURNER flagon quoting Sargeson That Summer (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,137)

C.R. FRANCIS I notice that the word rigger' [in HNZD P.936] does not include the sense which used to be common, of a 1 litre JDKZ gin bottle filled at the pub with draft beer. I distinctly remember the notice atHis Lordships' a very scruffy tavern in St Asaph St.Ch-ch No jars or riggers filled after 5-45 pm.' This was deciphered by an elderly habitue for the innocent student.The word is apparently a contraction of the termsquare rigger' used to describe a JDKZ bottle... -->P: 5. `Quart of draught beer in square-faced gin bottle': Austr: ca 1918: (B 1942) (Feb 19, 1983,Personal Communication)

3 n. a 1.25 or 2 litre plastic bottle of beer

Many quality New Zealand beers are never bottled and are only available on tap from the brewery or a bottle store in 1.25 or 2 litre plastic bottles (called variously riggers, flagons or PETs depending on where you are from). I headed off to Regional Wines, and Spirits with a bag of empty riggers to sample some of their beers on tap... While beer in a rigger will keep fresh for a short time, ideally it should be consumed within a day or two of purchase. (Apr 6, 2004,Independent Herald (Wellington),6)

right as a bank¶

phr.

SLATTER Don't hang on to me, Bill. I'm all right I tell ya. Right as a bank .. I' not drunk drunk I tell ya. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,165)

WILSON How are you, Ted?' I asked.Right as the bank, boy.' (1976,Pacific Star,121)

right as a daisy¶

phr.

McGILL right as a daisy all is well; local variant of many right as ...' colloquialisms likeright as rain', denoting security or safety. [Shepard] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

right as pie¶

phr. good, well [right as pie is the usual form]

ANTHONY "Are you all right now, do you think?" she asked. [140] "Right as a pie," I replied, "When can I get up?" (1936,Follow the Call,139)

right as rain¶

phr. too right; most certainly

SARGESON ... right as rain (1946,That Summer,178) [NOTES: [cf also `right as rain, I'll hit him. ...'] [=too bloody right; most certainly] nf OED, EDD]

right of way¶

n. -

Way (w&amacr.), n. [Add.] Right of way. [Add.] (b) (Pl., RIGHT OF WAYS.) A narrow street; a lane. [Australia] This use of the legal term in a concrete sense originated in Melbourne. In laying out the city, passages ten or twelve feet wide were left between the large rectangular lots. These passages ran from one broad street to another and were intended to afford a right of way between the lots. Hence the term came to be applied to the passages themselves. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2034)

right out of the book¶

phr. indicating a `classical formal' nature of something done

Free kick be damned ... It was a good forward's try. Right out of the book. (1977,Listener Short Stories,6) [NOTES: 1944 Gaskell in 1977 N.Z. List Short Stories 6]

right-of-way¶

n. a lane, an access-way

MORRIS Right-of-way, n. a lane. In England the word indicates a legal right to use a particular passage. In Australia it is used for the passage or lane itself. (1898,Austral English,388)

`The main body of the men was located in the right-of-way, which is overlooked by the side windows of the bureau.' (Feb 3, 1893,Argus, The)

right n.-right' of way n. a lane. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,9)

Right-of-way n. lane or track. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

right-of-way n. lane, track. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

right-whale porpoise¶

n.

The right-whale porpoise (Lissodelphis peroni) can be at once recognized by the absence of a dorsal fin. It possesses a distinct beak, and about 44 pairs of small pointed teeth. The colouring is distinctive: the back is black, and this colour is sharply marked off from the under-parts, which are white, the line between the two passing above the tail, flippers, and snout. (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/140) [NOTES: (Oliver)]

righto¶

exclam. used in NZ as elsewhere to express affirmation, agreement, etc; =GOODO(H) spot on; correct

I say Bill, let's have a week off'Right-o!' (Oct 24, 1903,Bulletin, The (Sydney),8)

He's a lovely kid, a righto dinkum oner. (1917,Tiki Talk,8) [NOTES: [ca1920-30 Very frequent in novels: e.g. Rosemary Rees.]]

`Righto! Shove them in your valise ...' (1918,New Zealand At the Front,79)

WESTON (1918,Three Years with the NZers,78)

Right-oh!' said Bill,bring him in [to the bar] and we'll give him a wet.' (Jul 10, 1919,Quick March,21)

Come for a walk round the esplanade, Matilda. I can't stand this any longer.'Right-o. I'll put on my ulster. Isn't it an awful day!' (1920,Stories of Katherine Mansfield, The,193,(1984 Alpers) ed.)

GREY `'Right-o,' as these boatmen say,' I replied. (1926,Angler's Eldorado,53)

DEVANNY Why not call me Marigold? ...'Bless her heart! Why not indeed? Righto.' (1929,Riven,30)

COAD `O right-o. Only I thought you might like to hear the latest society spice.' (1931,Such Is Life,54)

SCANLAN Shall we?' and he turned to Maisie. She nodded encouragingly.Right-o!' (1934,Winds of Heaven,37)

LEE Sh-----'Right oh.' `Don't let them see you.' (1934,Children of the Poor,121,1949 ed.)

HYDE `Righto, coming out [on strike].' Out of eighty quarry-men, three stayed on the friendly road, and had to take to the bush for the day. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,171)

Goodoh and rightoh are used by everyone [in New Zealand and Australia] (1941,NZ Slang,62)

HENDERSON `Righto, start up!' Onward, men of the Second New Zealand Expeditionary Force; onward, as our fernleaf badges say, on against the foe; ... (1945,Gunner Inglorious,17)

PEARSON All jokes aside again, he said. `Right-oh then Paul.' (1963,Coal Flat,22)

SYDER & HODGETTS A form of assent, a token word in parting, a signal to proceed with the next sequence in the operation, or, an acknowledgment that the speaker has been understood. .in 4;Righto, then I'll leave Jack with you next trip, like you said.' 'I've got everything I wanted, I think. Righto, then, see you next week.'Wait till I give the word you let the tray go. Righto! Now!' `Righto! We're to leave any cleaning up till later, and load up and get back to the depot. O.K....' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],916) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust. and NZ English [TS] 916]

WILSON Righto. Righto.' [161] The man motioned with his hand. But the curious townspeople who were pressing up against the truck moved back a mere half inch, so he spoke again with quiet, lazy authority.Come on. Let your mother see the races.' (1965,Outcasts,160)

TURNER The words righto and goodo are not confined to Australia and New Zealand but are so prevalent here that they deserve mention. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,135)

McDERMOTT `Right oh,' as they say in New Zealand. (1976,How to Get Lost & Found in NZ,165)

`Righto, I'll be in touch.' A man of few words, obviously. (Mar 1988,More Magazine,29)

righty¶

n. (informal) a person (MP) on the right wing of a political party

Now JT is gone, odds are it'll be a righty, Damien O'Connor, who gets promoted. (Nov 13, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

rigis¶

n. patched-up old jeans (from "originals") [US?]

We can get into our rigis ("originals", patched up old jeans), kraut lid and all the rest of it... Otherwise we go just as we are - which isn't a hell of a lot better. (Jan 2, 1994,Sunday Times (NZ),6)

riko¶

n. a species of eel

GUTHRIE-SMITH (1926,Tutira,87)

rill board¶

n.

McARA Rill boards: Nine-inch-by-three-inch boards (10 ft long), used when extracting the last of the ore from a shrinkage stope to bring the ore back under the standing sets so that it could be safely handled. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),331)

rill stope¶

n.

McARA Rill stope: A filled stope worked on a 45-degree angle from one end progressively towards the other. It had the advantage that less shovelling of both quartz and filling was required and the material could be quickly and easily placed on the rill. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),331)

rilling¶

1 n. (Rural) [soil erosion] the formation of small gullies in cultivated hillsides.

CONNELL & HADFIELD On the more gently sloping land, especially where it is cultivated, puddle erosion, the loss of fine particles in muddy water run-off, and rilling, small gullies in cultivated hillsides, occur. (1961,Agriculture,251)

rimrod rock¶

1 n. (Rural) rock, of an extremely hard type.

TAIT The soil is of a pumice formation, running into clay and papa on the lower country where there are outcrops of rimrod rock. (1961,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III,159)

rimu¶

n. an important native timber tree, especially prized for furniture manufacture. Also called red pine. [RED-PINE (Cook's Spruce) a forest tree, and its timber: see also IMOU Rimu is used in North Island, and in Nelson and Marlborough and Westland. Red-pine has been used chiefly in Central Otago (for the tree) and Southland, and (for the timber) in Otago and Canterbury. Rimu seems to be replacing Red-pine as a tree-name even in the Southern South Island. Rimu is universally known, but not universally used. Morris (1896) remarks that Rimu generally used in North Island, Red-pine more generally in the South.]

Totara, Rimu, Matai, and White Pine supplied in any quantities. (Oct 14, 1882,Feilding Star,1)

FELLING A GIANT RIMU. (Dec 23, 1908,Otago Witness,37)

The Committee recommends the disuse of the terms red-pine',white-pine', and `black-pine', in favour of rimu, kahikatea and matai, in order to prevent their being confused with timbers having similar names in Europe (Jul 17, 1896,AJHR,h-24) [NOTES: ) Interim Report No.3 (i) of Timber Conference Appendix Journals H.24]

MORRIS Rimu, n. Maori name for a New Zealand tree, Dacrydium cupressinum, N.O. Coniferae; also called Red-pine. Rimu is generally used in North Island; Red-pine more generally in the South. See Pine. (1898,Austral English,388)

Rii.mu (r&emacr.i.mu), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) A New Zealand coniferous tree Dacrydium cupressinum) and its timber; - called also red pine. Mountain rimu (Bot.), the tree Dacrydium laxifolium. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

The timbers of commercial value are totara, rimu, miro, matai, rata, and kamahi, in mixed bushes; but Fagus fusca and other beeches predominate on the high lands between the lakes and the fiords on the west coast. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,30)

CHEESEMAN D[acrydium] cupressinum, Soland. ... Rimu; Red-pine. ... The wood is deep-red, strong, hard, and heavy, but often twisted in grain. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,654)

BAUGHAN Rimu (Ree-moo): Red pine. Ibid. Shingle Short 54 Kauri and Totara, Rimu, and Matai and Maire,/ Red-as-blood Rata, and bright-as-blood Pohutukawa,/ Manuka dark-ey'd, Convolvulus star-ey'd - / The glittering of you that morning! [f@n2 attached to the italicised names] 2. Kauri, etc. (Kow-ree, To[acute]-ta-ra, Ree[e acute]-moo, (1908,Shingle-Short,13)

rimu n. a tall tree; the timber of the tree, valuable for cabinet work, etc. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

The chief indigenous trees of commercial value are: Kauri (Agathis Australis), Kahikatea or white pine (Podocarpus dacrydioides), rimu or red pine (Dacrydium cupressinum), totara (Podocarpus totara and Podocarpus Hallii), Miro (Podocarpus ferrugineus), Kaikawaka or mountain cedar (Libocedrus Bidwilli), yellow pine or silver pine (Dacrydium Colensoi and D. intermedium), red and hard beech (Nothofagus fasca and Nothofagus truncata), silver beech (Nothofagus Menziesii), black beech (Nothofagus Solandri), black maire (Olea Cunninghamii), northern and southern rata (Metrosideros robusta and Metrosideros lucida) (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,578)

BEATTIE Rimu is the red pine, and for the miro I never heard an English name. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,13)

LAING & BLACK Rimu or Red Pine. (1940,Plants of NZ,75)

LAING & BLACK Rimu or Red Pine. (1940,Plants of NZ,75)

ANDERSON rimu, a fine tree (Dacrydium cupressinum), red-pine; the young tree, a fountain of weeping foliage considered one of the most beautiful trees in the world. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146)

rimu: red pine. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

LEVY White pine, pukatea, tawa, rimu, rata, matai, totara, hinau, rewarewa, kamahi, and tree ferns, with some beech on the ridges, were typical of the primary forest. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,16,1970 ed.)

DUFF In addition the boys have cut down rimu, totara, matai, and pinus growing on the property and built a 4-stand woolshed without help from outside. (Dec 22, 1954,Shepherd's Calendar,202,1961 ed.)

The Maori name of a tall New Zealand pine which yields valuable timber, also called `red pine' (Pronounce .us;reemoo]). (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),345)

SHADBOLT I grew to awareness rejecting as alien our scrubby backblocks farm, the thick bush of tall kauri, rimu and kahikatea ..., the mangroved tidal creek, ... the cabbage trees in the playground ... (1959,New Zealanders, The,10,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (The Woman's Story)]

rimu n -s [Maori] 1 : a tall New Zealand timber tree (Dacrydium cupressinum) with a small head, drooping terminal branches covered with tiny keeled linear leaves, and an ovoid terminal nut with a fleshy red receptacle 2 : the wood of the rimu tree used for furniture and general construction - called also imou pine, red pine (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1957)

KEENE rimu: tall, massive tree, 60 ft. to 110 ft. high, found throughout New Zealand; a good timber tree. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

McLINTOCK Rimu (red pine) .. .. rimu Dacrydium cupressinum (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

~ n. New Zealand tree, the red pine. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

rimu ... n. N.Z. tree, red pine. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

rimu n. a New Zealand tree. Also called: red pine. [< Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,993) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 658; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 420]]

COCKAYNE (And) Dacrydium cupressinum (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

...there's how he was buried alive in pumice, playing the part of a male rimu who died a nasty volcanic death in front of his female rimu lover. (Sep 10, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

Inside, the building has been tastefully furnished in figured rimu and smooth white plaster. (Apr 16, 1929,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,1)

OAK OR RIMU EXTENDING DINING TABLE, soundly constructed of Seasoned Timber. (Dec 23, 1919,Poverty Bay Herald,9)

MARKHAM A large Torch is maid [sic] from the Red Pine (Remu) which will last for about 3 hours. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles))

CRUSE ... we found ourselves at the edge of a very extensive wood abounding in cowry, and another very fine species of timber called demo; ... (Jul 3, 1820,Journal,122,1957 ed.) [NOTES: 1820 July 3 in 1823 Cruise Journal (1957) 122]

LEE & KENDALL Ko d|imu d|imu; A certain tree. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,165)

McRAE Here we found the trees ... of that kind called by the natives Demo and Totara. The former resembles the pine and the latter has a leaf like the yew tree ... (1820,Journal,20,1928 ed.)

YATE Rimu (Dacrydium cupressinum) - This elegant tree comes to its greatest perfection in shaded woods, and in moist rich soil. (1835,Account of NZ, An,40)

POLACK The Rimu, (cupressinum,) is one of the most graceful trees of the country. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/394)

HODGSKIN Maree, a fine large tree, produces a mohogany-coloured wood. Rema, a beautiful, high, and majestic tree, growing upwards of 80 feet in length ... (1841,Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A,27)

BIDWILL The Rimu [fn Dacrydium cupressinum] (the most beautiful tree in the world when young) has branches very slender and pendulous, ... (1841,Rambles in NZ,35 and fn,1952 ed.)

Remu mentioned by Captain Cook as `Spruce Fir' (1841,NZ Journal,2/31/81) [NOTES: (G. Bennett)]

TUCKETT spg remo ... the prevailing species of trees are remo [rimu], totara, and tall manuka, all indicative of inferior soil.... The bush-like woods on the east side are of white birch, likewise no recommendation of the soil, but the chief objection to the district is, that the prairie soil affords scarcely any food for cattle ... it grows only the wiry tree grass [tussock] ... and Phormium tenax [flax], no aniseed, perennial groundsel, or milk thistle, and very little couch grass. (Aug 16, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: 1844 Aug 16 Tuckett's Diary in 1898 Hocken contributions 223-224]

MONRO [rima] In the woods [near Molyneux Bay, Otago] there are not many red [?=totara] and white pines, but a large proportion of rima. (1844,Notes of a Journey,249)

WAKEFIELD 3. Rimu, (Dacrydium cupressimum.) This beautiful tree comes to its greatest perfection in shaded woods and in moist rich soil. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,141)

SHORTLAND The leave[s] of the manuka' (leptospermum scoparium) furnished Captain Cook with a substitute for tea ...; and ... he used the small branches of this shrub and of the treerimu', (dacrydium cupressinum,) in equal proportions, to make a decoction from which he brewed spruce beer, frequently referred to by him as a valuable anti-scorbatic. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,128)

TORLESSE Kaikatea, (white pine), mahi, black pine, remu, (red pine) (1851,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,6)

The timber in [the groves] is chiefly Kaikatea, (white pine), Mahi, (black pine), Remu, (red pine), Pokaka, Kowai, and Totara. ... That in the other forest [ie. not Harewood or Alford] is principally tawai, (black birch), the best timber for boat and ship building, but sometimes unsound: ... (Jun 28, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

HOOKER Dacrydium cupressinum, Don. ... Nat. name, `Rimu' (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 233)

HARPER ... at work in the forest, sawing up Rimu, i.e. Red Pine, a finely grained timber which literally seemed to bleed under the saw, as its red sap flowed out. (Nov 4, 1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,45,1914 ed.)

THOMSON Valuable ...furniture planks are sawn from the Rimu, Kakikatae, or white pine (Dacrydium excelsum), Matai, Mairi, and Manuka (Leptospermum scoparium). (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/20,1974 ed.)

HOOKER Rimu, Bidwill. Dacrydium laxifolium.. Rimu, Col[enso]. Dacrydium cupressinum. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

Red Pine, or Rimu (Dacrydium cupressinum), another valuable building timber, found abundant everywhere; ... Ibid. 1/III/49 (Buchanan Botany Otago) Rimu. Dacrydium cupressinum, Sol. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

[Native name] Rimu .. [Settlers' name] Red-pine .. [Family] Coniferae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

Rimu (red-pine) .. Dacrydium cupressinum .. A strong, handsome, reddish coloured timber, grain beautifully marked and figured; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,14)

n.

ANGAS Beneath the upper canopy of forest trees - such as the rimu pine, the kaikatea, the totara, kahikatoa, rata, and many others ... (1847,Savage Life,2/245)

DOMETT Rimu-tree ..... O. Coniferae; G. Dracrydium [sic] S. D. cupressinum. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/303)

26 Rimu (red pine) figured slab. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,16)

n.

BRUNNER The natives here preserved the birds ...in a rimu or sea-weed bag. (1847,Great Journey,1952,53 ed.)

HOWARD Thus prepared the [weka] meat is put into a rimu bag filled up with the fat extracted in cooking. (1940,Rakiura,390) [NOTES: 1850 May Acheron Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 390]

n. a kelp or seaweed (cf. RIMURAPA) [Also called rimurimu [Maori]]

HOCHSTETTER [Fn] When boiled,** Rimu, a seaweed, [Tutu] forms a jelly which is very palatable. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),139) [NOTES: Check original]

LEE & KENDALL D|imu, s. Sea weeds. D|imu r|apa; Name of a place. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,150)

kelp -lim|moo [rimu] (1826,Boultbee Journal,113,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 113 also 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 285]

BEATTIE Rimu - the kelp. It is quite edible if properly treated. (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,62) [NOTES: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 62]

BUICK The Natives here preserve the birds they catch ... in a rimu or seaweed bag. (1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,194) [NOTES: [quoting Brunner]]

2 n. [?to distinguish from MOSS, for which rimu can also be used)]

2 n.

MOORE & IRWIN CAULERPA BROWNII. Sea rimu grows in dense patches at or below low tide level on open rocky coasts. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,8)

WILSON Caulerpa brownii var. selaginoides SEA RIMU ... Green patches, often dense, the creeping stems giving rise to numerous more or less upright shoots resembling the foliage of rimu sc. red pine]. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,318)

FRAME [check quot] (1962,Edge of the Alphabet,110)

2 n.

EDDIE ATTWOOD The most curious Scrub here was the Pigmy Rimu or Alpine Rimu almost like big moss but where it gets support among other scrubs it will grow to a length of perhaps 18 inches. (Apr 15, 2002,Diary) [NOTES: Eddie Attwood's Diary in NZ Memories No. 36, June-July, 2002, p. 33]

KIRK (And) Dacrydium laxifolium mountain rimu (1889,Forest Flora)

(And) Dacrydium laxifolium mountain rimu (1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue)

mountain rimu n : a prostrate or suberect shrub (Dacrydium laxifolium) of New Zealand with slender trailing branches (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1478)

Rimu¶

abbr. Residual Health Management Unit [ORIGIN: acronym]

It appears that hospitals will access extra operating funds through the Residual Health Management Unit, or Rimu as it's known in the trade... It also gives a large number of Rimu, Treasury and health bureaucrats a lot of extra work to do, keeping track of the paperwork. (Jun 9, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

rimu stone vein¶

n. ? a `vein' of gravel growing up with a tree

LYON To use such [a well-ground] axe on rimu stone veins, as they were termed, on maire, or on certain hard timbers, meant many hours' grinding, and to `knock a shilling' out of the face of an axe brought one to the soft core. ... (1952,Faring South,182)

rimu suit¶

n. a coffin (cf U.S. wooden overcoat)

rimu-wooded¶

adj.

MYERS Today, they saw only the dense, rimu-wooded hills, ... (1941,Valiant Love,10)

rimurapa¶

n.

HULME & MORRISON And then there's rimurapa, bullkelp, Durvillea antarctica, a huge, magnificent plant that makes undersea forests round most of the southern coasts. (1989,Homeplaces,61)

Greig & Haddad (eds) Tutu juice was also boiled with dried bull kelp (rimurapa) to make a jelly. (2000,NZ Cook's Dictionary, The,00)

LEE & KENDALL D|imu, s. Sea weeds. D|imu r|apa; Name of a place. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,150)

HOOKER Rimurapa, Col[enso]. D'Urvillea utilis. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

A few also of the sea-weeds were eaten; such as, the Karengo, (A tidal species of Laminaria found plentifully from the East Cape to Cape Turnagain), the Rehia, the Rimurapa (D'Urvillea utilis, and some others ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/32) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

[Karengo] together with two other species of sea-algae, rehia and rimurapa (Gigartina and Gracilaria sp.), was mixed with the sweet juice of the tutu .. . (1881,TrNZI,13/29)

BAUGHAN Rimu-rapa: A seaweed. (1908,Shingle-Short,190)

SHAND The kelp used to make [the Moriori canoe] buoyant was of the Rimurapa, or broad, flat, bull kelp. (1911,Moriori People of the Chatham Islands, The,11)

The accepted tale that he [sc the Moriori] caulked the seams of his crate-like affair ... with `rim-rap',' bull-kelp, and used inflated bladders if this material ... is, to put it mildly, tosh! (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs,Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 363) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 363]

BROOKER et al. Durvillea antarctica (Cham.) Har. Common name: Bull kelp Maori names: Rimurapa, rimuroa (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,21)

BURTON Alternatively, it [tutu juice] was boiled with the pith of the pitau fern or pieces of bull kelp seaweed (rimurapu). Ibid. 9 Other edible varieties of seaweed commonly used by the Maori include rimurapu or bull kelp (Durvillea antarctica), which was also dried and then boiled with tutu juice to form a jelly, and the beaded Neptune's necklace (Hormosira banksii), which is palatable raw. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,6)

WILSON Durvillea antarctica BULL KELP ... Rimurapa ... Native to: New Zealand. Also right round southern hemisphere except Tasmania and Australia. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,307)

[Hdg] Bull kelp. The great bull kelp - rimurapa - with writhing slimy arms up to 10 metres or more long, clothes the coasts of many parts of New Zealand. (Feb 22, 1985,Dominion,9)

rimurimu¶

n. a moss

The material used among the Tuhow natives ... as a menstruating diaper is a variety of moss (generic term rimurimu) known as kohukohu or angiangi. It is probably Hypnum clandestinus. (1905,TrNZI,37/90)

n. seaweed Caulerpa brownii

MARTIN Rock pools ... are the favourite haunt of several species of Caulerpa, much the most widely distributed and commonest member being the RIMU-RIMU (C. brownii) thought confined to areas south of Castle Point (1961,Flora NZ,8,1929 ed.)

McNAUGHTON The finer rimurimu was in the still parts of the lagoons and we would feel round for it with our feet and hands, and pick it and put it into our sugar bags. (1986,Countless Signs,43) [NOTES: From Patricia Grace (1975) : Waiariki]

rimuroa¶

n.

HULME & MORRISON Neptune's necklace (again, just 'rimu') is tangy when you nibble it, and so are the young tips of rimuroa (bladderweed). (1989,Homeplaces,61)

n.

BULLER The Rimuroa is the bluebell. (1878,Forty Years in NZ,502)

ring¶

v.

MEREDITH It was risky swimming them over the rivers. If the cattle fail to make for the opposite bank the leaders may turn back and start `ringing' in midstream, the cattle in the middle of the ring being forced under water and drowned. At first it is difficult to get a clean swim-over; but the mob soon gets used to it. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,66,1935 ed.)

NORRIS To drive stock to Auckland it was necessary to cross the river twice ... The danger of swimming the stock across was that they might `ring', that is swim round and round in the centre of the water till exhausted and then drown. (1963,Armed Settlers,198)

v. (Rural) [stock] to circle in a gathered mob around a stationary centre.

MEREDITH If the cattle fail to make for the opposite bank the leaders may turn back and start 'ringing' in midstream, the cattle in the middle of the ring being forced under water and drowned. (1875,Adventures in Maoriland,66)

The centre of the mob may stand stand still or move slowly forward; but the outside sheep gallop round and round them. This is called ringing. (Jan 27, 1934,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

The sheep were ringed in 5min 54sec, but got out before the minute was up. (Mar 21, 1907,Star, The,3)

v.

PARTRIDGE To resemble or pass for another, Leverage, 1925: U.S.A.: since ca. 1918. Prob. ex Australian s. be the dead ring of, `to be a person's double'. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,569,1961 ed.)

n.

GORDON Pelters: make the arse-cuts, a cut around the ring so that it comes away from the inside. This is also called ringing or arsecutting (ringers and arse-cutters for men who do them). (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: ca1951 May 17 Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c. Colin Gordon]

n.

Colin Houlbrooke recalled the two main areas for battle with marbles as being the sealed area for 'rings' and the dirt behind the shed for 'holes'. (1987,Alfredton,75) [NOTES: Refers to c1935]

HISLOP I suppose at that time [c1860s goldrush] I would be more interested in grabbing my dumps' out of the ring at school, when some quick eye had noticed that a young pointer had tried to get away with placing a stinkie or a chalkie into play with the rest of his marbles. TheGrab your dumps' was the roar, as we all rushed in for our own, and anybody else's one could get. (1943,Pure Gold,22)

n. constr. THE RING [(prisoners')]

HYDE The Ring is the second-best institution in New Zealand Gaols, the best being the Dummy. The Ring is in the prison yard and about thirty feet in diameter. The game is to try and find the end of it; but you never do, although you are marched around it from eleven in the morning until five o'clock. (1936,Passport to Hell,57)

v. to ringbark

During these two months, July and August, let them ring' the trees, that is cut out a ring of bark and sap 3 or 4 inches wide round all the trees they intend to cut down orfall' during the next 12 months. (1875,TrNZI,7/186) [NOTES: (Firth)]

MORRIS Ring, v. (1) To cut the bark of a tree round the trunk so as to kill it. The word is common in the same sense in English forestry and horticulture, and only seems Australasian from its more frequent use, owing to the widespead practice of clearing the primeval forests and generally destroying trees. Ringed' is the correct past participle, butrung' is now commonly used. [1846] ... (2) to make cattle move in a circle. [1874] ... (3) To move round in a circle [1884] ... (4) To make the top score at a shearing-shed.' See Ringer. (1898,Austral English,388)

ring v.t. to kill a tree by cutting the bark round the trunk; to make cattle move in a circle;-v.i. to move in a circle, as cattle or birds; to win in a sheep-shearing contest. -ring'er n. the man who shears most sheep in a day. - ring'-bark v.t. to ring a tree.-ring'-neck n. a newly arrived immigrant, esp. from England; a jackaroo (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

v. to outshear (other shearers), have the highest tally of shorn sheep, usu. in phrase ring the shed or ring the board (cf RINGER n)

PATERSON The man thatrung' the Tubbo shed is not the ringer here.' (1896,Man From Snowy River, The,136)

MORRIS (1898,Austral English) [NOTES: see @v1 above to be the RINGER in (Pa. tense rang)]

BAKER the terms to ring a shed and to be a ringer, i.e. to be the fastest and most expert shearer in a shed, have been used for so many generations that they are quite orthodox in the Antipodes. (1941,NZ Slang,38)

ACLAND Jacky Howe.- Sleeveless singlet, cut nearly to the waist under the arms. Named after the famous Jack Howe who rang many of the South Island sheds in the 1890s. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,372)

McLEOD The fastest man is called the ringer and there is considerable prestige attached to it, besides the extra profit. Sometimes a man will `ring the shed' in the wethers by sheer courage or brute strength, but when the ewes come in with their softer and less bulky wool, some- one else may come to the fore and displace him. (1951,High Country,29)

MEEK RUNG THE SHED: The shearer with the highest aggregate tally, is said to have rung the shed. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,111)

BOWEN 6 [Young shearers should] take notice of the man who shears in a quiet, business-like way, and, ... [by] the end of the day rings them [his mates] by quite a few sheep - ... (1955,Wool Away!)

MILLS ... many a tense drama was enacted as individuals vied ... for the honour of ringing the shed'. For a shearer to be able to say that herang the board' at so-and-so station the previous year was as good a testimonial as he could wish for. (1960,Sheep-O,21)

(Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing) [See quot ringer n.]]

RICHARDS On the shearing board of Otupae,/ Shore six of the world's best,/ And with the best of kai, you bet,/ ... Starting from the end pen,/ Billy Richards rang the board./ (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,98)

ring: To outdo all other shearers by ringing the board' orringing the shed'. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/27) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

v.

MORRIS (1898,Austral English) [NOTES: see @v1 above]

ACLAND Merino sheep on the flat, especially when coming to a gate, are apt to circle. The centre of the mob may stand still, or move slowly forward; but the outside sheep gallop round and round them. This is called ringing. It is annoying to see the sheep racing past the gate instead of going through it, but the habit may be turned to the shepherd's advantage. By starting the sheep on one side ringing the reverse way, two streams of sheep can be made to meet at the gate, and carry one another through. (1933,Press, The)

v. (of a sheepdog) to turn in a complete circle around the sheep and come back to the handler; to stop after its out-run [sheep farming]

Ringing Sheep: Fault in a dog where it goes in a complete circle around the sheep and comes back to the handler. It fails to stop after its out-run, halfway around the sheep, and directly opposite the handler. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,25)

1 n. (Rural) an area of a dog trial course in which sheep are yarded.

Pulled straight and true and put in some fine work at the ring. (Jul 2, 1923,NZ Farmer,950)

The second dog, Sweep, ran out in a good cast to the right and took charge well. Under very good command, held his sheep well in the ring and yarded in 8 1/2 minutes. (1923,NZ Farmer,951)

GORDON On his way to complete the run by getting a balanced hold in the ring, Pauline's Boy ran rather wide ... (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,16)

2 n.

PARTRIDGE Anyhow, to give you the fair dinkum guts I put across a beauty when I found the double-headed penny in the ring, and that's how I won 200 francs. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

2 v. [(criminals' slang) sc a car, to change identification. (or from RING IN?)]

Ringed' cars and stolen property worth in total more than $25,000 was recovered by the Porirua CIB yesterday. ... He said the operation, which was not yet complete, began about a month ago when aringed' (changed indentification) Honda Accord stolen from Wellington in 1981 was found during police inquiries in Porirua. ... Mr Reeve said the arrested man also admitted `ringing' another car, which was stolen in 1980. (Oct 31, 1984,Evening Post,3)

ring bark¶

v. to cut away a ring of bark from around a trunk in order to kill a tree [aka ring-bark, ringbark]

THE WEEKLY NEWS .. CONTENTS FOR THIS WEEK.. To Ring-bark Trees ... (May 22, 1875,Daily Southern Cross,4)

The idea is to ringbark the trees and bore through the trunk with an augur a couple of holes which are filled with a composition and plugged. The composition soaks into the wood, rots it, and causes it to become inflammable. In about eight or ten months a match is applied, and the tree falls, the stump and roots which have become soaked with the mixture, being burned right out. (Jul 27, 1904,Tuapeka Times,1)

The dead tree by the gas works has been cut down, and the gentleman who ring-barked it for impeding his zig-zag progress can now absorb his whisky with a comparatively easy mind. (Feb 20, 1893,Hawke's Bay Herald,4)

Trees thus treated invariably die out as if ring barked, and hitherto we have heard of no remedy which has been successful in bringing them back to life by renewing the lost skin. (Apr 6, 1887,Tuapeka Times,2)

MacDONALD The selector in a timbered country, without troubling himself anout cause and effect, is aware that if he destroys the tree the grass will grow, and therefore hering-barks' his timber.' (1888,Gum Boughs,204)

MORRIS Ring-bark, v. Same meaning as Ring (1). (1898,Austral English,389)

BAUCKE And so, instead of felling these forest giants, he simply selected those parts where the underscrub was lightest, ring-barked the trees, and when they were dead ... burnt out a farm from the stubborn wilderness of forest around him. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,13)

BAUCKE And so, instead of felling these forest giants, he simply selected those parts where the underscrub was lightest, ring-barked the trees, and when they were dead ... burnt out a farm from the stubborn wilderness of forest around him. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,13)

Firewood was procured [by the Moriori] by ring-barking trees and waiting until some gale overthrew the tree at the ring-bark rot. (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs,Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 366) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 366]

Ringi.barki. (r&itilde.ngi.ba.rki.), v. t. To make a ring around by cutting away the bark; to girdle; to ring; as, to ringbark a tree. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

2 v. [figurative; aka ring-bark, ringbark]

A New chum Emerald Isler, travelling through some ring-barked country, couldn't make out why some of the trees were "all out in blossom, while the others didn't have the devil of a leaf on 'em at all bedad." (May 12, 1883,Wanganui Herald,2)

Secularism in the school has ringbarked morality, the shade of which is vanished and its verdure dead. (Aug 10, 1894,NZ Tablet,6)

Which is it better, to ringbark thistles on Sunday, or send a bad one pound note to Peter Campbell or the heathen? (Apr 11, 1883,Grey River Argus,4)

Only to be quite safe he should ring-bark the lamp-post at the corner, as a lamp-post, even when the lamp is alight, is a serious menace to the safety of gentlemen who have approached the "cant't-see-a hole through-a-ladder" [sic] stage of obfuscation. (Feb 20, 1893,Hawke's Bay Herald,4)

.. or, if [the hair] were too stiff and strong, to ring-bark and use a cross-cut saw. (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,1/1/1)

... barren, ring-barked hills. (Mar 17, 1906,NZ Truth,39/4/6) [NOTES: (but cf Morris 1893 Austr quot: `We were going through ring-barked country ...')]

ring crutch¶

v.

COOP With August shearing it is customary and generally advisable to ring-crutch' orbullseye' the ewes before putting the rams out at tupping. (1950,Shearing Ewes before Lambing,28)

RICHARDS As we completed shearing each mob of ewes, we would follow on by ring crutching their lambs. Ibid. As tupping season was approaching I also gave them a light ringcrutch (a honeymoon shear) before turning them out into a larger paddock (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,98)

v. (Rural) to take a small circle of wool from around a sheep's rear end. (See buttonhole,bullseye,tup crutch)

COOP With August shearing it is customary and generally advisable to 'ring-crutch' or 'bullseye' the ewes before putting the rams out at tupping .. in those cases where the ewes were normally ring-crutched at tupping and fully crutched in June, the latter operation is eliminated. (1950,Shearing Ewes before Lambing,28)

One man can ringcrutch approximately 200 per hour. (Jan 27, 1977,NZ Farmer,70)

One man can ring crutch approximately 200 per hour ... (May 1981,NZ Journal of Agriculture,79)

RICHARDS As we completed shearing each mob of ewes, we would follow on by ring crutching their lambs. [ring; ring-crutch; ringcrutch] (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,98)

1 n. (Rural) the removal of a small ring of wool from a sheep's rear end.

SALISBURY We continued home with the ewes which we were going to give a ring crutch. (1994,I Was So Lucky,201)

ring crutching¶

1 n. (Rural) the removal of a small area of wool at a sheep's rear end.

The job may be small, such as ring crutching, but those heavy sheep have to be handled. (Jun 1982,NZ Journal of Agriculture,49)

ring dollar¶

n.

SUTHERLAND In New South Wales, in 1813, this difficulty [of shortage of coin] became so acute that Governor Macquarie, in an effort to check the outflow of Spanish dollars, then the main circulating medium, caused the centres of these coins to be struck out, the centre-piece (about the size of a shilling) being stamped NEW SOUTH WALES, 1813, around a central crown, and on the other side FIFTEEN PENCE, the remainder or `ring' part of the dollar being impressed around the new inner rim with NEW SOUTH WALES, 1813 on one side, and FIVE SHILLINGS on the other. ... [67] 3,008 Dollars (mainly Holey or Ring Dollars) [pounds] 752 0 0/ 725 Dumps (centres of Spanish Dollars) 45 6 3 (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,66)

ring fence¶

v. (Rural) to fence off an area of land [originally used to form a boundary between neighbouring landowners.] [aka ring-fence]

I understand Mr S. Daniells is going to ring fence his farm. (May 18, 1893,Otago Witness,22)

All Highly Improved, ring fenced, and subdivided into 10 paddocks; also Holding Paddocks. (Aug 21, 1920,Poverty Bay Herald,5)

This could include ring-fencing ownership of the mainframes themselves by outsourcing them to a third party. (Nov 3, 2003,Dominion Post,C11)

Mrs E. P. Fisher wrote stating that she would accept GBP35 per acre for the cottage site on her property, the Council to bear all expenses and ring fence the section. (Jun 14, 1918,Poverty Bay Herald,7)

The clearing of forest-lands, ring-fencing and grassing them, will cost about [pounds]3 ... per acre. (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,486)

WEBB The section we were working on was nominally mine; that is, I was the lucky one who drew it in the land ballot. ... We had got it ring-fenced, because ... the drawers of the adjoining sections had done their share towards that, ... (1925,Miss Peters' Special,98)

SCOTTER The first job of the purchaser [of a run], that of ring fencing his whole property could not be done quickly or cheaply. (1948,Run, Estate and Farm,15)

LEVY As soon as possible after sowing, the burn was ring-fenced and later subdivided. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,245,1970 ed.)

THOMAS ... he decided to take up the other section `as forty pounds was sufficient at slump prices to buy wire for ring-fencing'. ... He then ring-fenced the new land, ramming as many as fifty posts into position in one day ... (1970,Way Up North,93)

RICHARDS The property was ring-fenced and divided into nine paddocks. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,164)

TAIT An area was ring-fenced. (1958,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol II,487)

LEVY As soon as possible after sowing, the burn was ring-fenced and later sub-divided. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,245)

HARTLEY .. the top [of a stump] yielded valuable battens to ring fence the farm. (1993,Colonial Outcasts: A Search for the Remittance Man,139)

v. (Rural) to contain an object, funding or person. [aka ring-fence]

MNZ [Merino New Zealand] Chairman John Perriam says it is essential that the monetary reserves held by the Wool Board be 'ring-fenced.' (Dec 7, 2000,NZ Farmer,8)

Ms King said she believed that there had been a misunderstanding of what should be ring-fenced, rather than any deliberate misuse of the money .. from the point of view of the Government they have always been very clear that that money was ring-fenced. [ring-fence] (Nov 2, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,5)

1 n. (Rural) a fence that surrounds an area of land for a specific purpose or a boundary fence. [aka ring-fence]

With the exception of about 30 acres of bush, this property is all good fern land with a quantity of natural and artificial grasses growing amongst it; there is some fencing erected thereon, and with the aid of the river and stream boundaries, very little more fencing is required to complete the whole in a ring fence. (Dec 1, 1866,Taranaki Herald,3)

FREEHOLD SHEEP FARM FOR SALE. .. Containing 6067 acres Freehold and 700 acres Leasehold, enclosed within a ring fence ... (Mar 1, 1873,Otago Witness,12)

Mr. St. George will sell about 20 Acres ( more or less) of Excellent Land, situated on the BELL BLOCK, price GBP60. Or will Let it on a Term, for a nominal rental, upon consideration that the Tenant will erect a ring fence, consisting of a Ditch and a two-feet bank, planted with furze, with a Rail on the top. (Sep 7, 1853,Taranaki Herald,4)

They were living on their purchases, which had a sort of ring fence round them, but as far as witness knew the sheep on the section were Smith and Gellibrand's. (Jun 9, 1883,Grey River Argus,2)

A writer in one of the Auckland papers appears to think that native reserves under the new arrangements will be a source of annoyance; and if he is correct in thinking that they are not to be merely so much land purchased beyond the wants of the purchaser, outside his ring fence, but that they are to be picked bits among his other fields, they certainly will be a nuisance of the first order. (Nov 16, 1844,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

A Tramp A ring fence has been placed round the property at the snow-line. (1891,Casual Ramblings,54)

The lessee shall, within two years from the date of his lease, have the land fenced with a ring-fence. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,77)

EVANS When he got his first sheep the only fences were known as 'ring' fences. There was one ring fence around the whole farm. (1962,Waikaka Saga,283)

WESTMACOTT We put up three-quarters of a mile of this fencing. It was not a ring fence, but it stopped the stock going back into the bush on the south side of the mountain (1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,166)

Incomplete ring fence; back line fenced. (Jul 4, 1917,Grey River Argus,1)

A TRAMP A ring fence had been placed round the property at the snow-line (1891,Casual Ramblings,54)

HENDERSON RING FENCE: Single fence surrounding a paddock or other enclosure. (1961,Friends in Chains,188) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 188]

(1.) The lessee shall, within two years from the date of his lease, have the land fenced with a ring-fence; and such fence shall be a sufficient fence within the meaning of The Fencing Act, 1895.' (VideFencing Act.') (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,77)

EVANS When he got his first sheep the only fences were known as `ring' fences. There was one ring fence round the whole farm. The ring fences were put round the turnip and oat fields. All the rest was one paddock. (1962,Waikaka Saga,283)

ring fern¶

n. = hard fern, Paesia scaberula

Although I crush carpet fern in my pastures by feeding out hay to cows during the winter, the fern still comes away in the spring. Total elimination of carpet fern (better known as hard or ring fern) under high rainfall conditions even under topdressing and stocking is not easy. (Mar 1967,NZ Journal of Agriculture,13)

EASY A spark would land on a clump of manuka or a patch of ring fern and instantly a fire would spring up. (1996,Looking Backwards,49)
