HINDMARSH The sweet fern, (also known as hard fern, ring fern and carpet fern) was burned and grass sown on about 250 acres of the hardiest country. (1997,Come Be a Pioneer,136)

HILGENDORF HARD FERN (Paesia scaberula), called also pig fern, ring fern, and silver fern, is abundant in both islands, ... (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,19,1967 ed.)

Paesia scaberula (hard fern, ring fern, scented fern, carpet fern) is considered one of the most troublesome weeds of the wetter hill farms of New Zealand. (1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,23/113B)

LEVY Attuned to the geographical region were some particularly troublesome growths, and of these, the hard fern (or ring fern) became a special pest difficult to control and to guard against. ... This hard fern and piripiri were greatly encouraged by set grazing with sheep, ... (1951,Grasslands of NZ,15,1970 ed.)

ring fern [s] Paesia scaberula (A. Rich.) Kuhn (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,64)

NEWTON One of the worst of the regrowth problems on this country [near Taumaranui] is the hard fern, or `ring' fern as it is sometimes known. ...Ring fern ... got the name because after burning the regrowth came up in the form of a circle outside the burnout area. (1972,Wake of The Axe,112)

WILSON Paesia scaberula LACE FERN ... Ring fern ... Scented fern ... Fronds yellow-green ... strongly scented in hot sunshine ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,428)

ring in¶

v. to enter (a horse) for a race under a false name (cf RINGING-IN) [racing slang]

But the manipulation of these races has now come to such a pass that local people have very little to do with them, and it is generally found that there are three or four racehorses "rung-in" under false names by the "clever" division, and the public are swindled. (Jan 16, 1886,Evening Post,4)

The Greymouth Trotting Club also wrote re the "ringing-in" of a certain horse in that district, stating that the club had authorized its secretary to proceed to the North Island with the object of identifying an animal alleged to have been "rung-in" at Greymouth; also suggesting that the association might financially assist the club in its efforts to stop "ringing-in." (Apr 15, 1897,Otago Witness,32)

REES He was not `ringing in' the horse. (1924,Heather of the South,90)

GLOVER When somebody or other rings in a racehorse even in those days, takes it to Australia with painted fetlocks ... (1962,Hot Water Sailor,59,1981 ed.)

v. to enter into a two-up game [(two up)]

REES The fly-manager rings in at a `two-up' school. (1913,Merry Marauders,71)

ring in a grey¶

phr. to use an illegal double-headed coin in a two-up game

... too often, he falls a ready victim to the crook and speiler [sic] who is adept in the art of `ringing in a grey'; i.e., using a double-headed penny, and resorting to other devious, and dirty dodges. (Jan 20, 1912,NZ Truth,343/7/3)

ring it on to¶

v. [(?criminals')] (See cf. to ring in)

This sort of excuses make his Worship tired. The same old cold,' he remarked.It is no use ringing that kind of stuff on to me.' (Jan 6, 1912,NZ Truth,341/7/2)

After giving the [counterfeit] coin to the cabby he (Croul) repented, and wanted to get it back, but Watson said, `Never mind, it's all right; he'll ring it on to someone else.' (Mar 16, 1912,NZ Truth,351/6/3)

ring off¶

v. (transf.) shut up (as imperative)

SARGESON (1940,Man & His Wife, A,27)

ring the board¶

1 phr. (Rural) [shearing] to have the highest tally of shorn sheep in a gang or in a particular shed.

NEWTON Lew was ringing the board by about twenty sheep ... (1949,High Country Days,41)

SUTHERLAND A claim to have 'rung the board' at such and such a station last season would be a more influential testimonial than a character reference signed by Angel Gabriel. (1966,Sixty Million Muster,75)

NEWTON Potae and Horton rang the board with a remarkable tally of 529 each. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,133)

ring the double¶

phr. to commit bigamy (?f. a two-up term)

Witness then went on to give the itinerary of life's journey up till the time when Nellie had `rung the double' in the marriage line at Parnell. (Nov 30, 1912,NZ Truth,388/6/2)

ring the sheep¶

1 phr. (Rural) [heading dogs] to circle a mob of sheep slowly before working them.

GORDON .. the dog trotted right up beside the sheep, walked right out in front and continued on round to return to the rear. This is known as 'ringing the sheep' and, out in the open, would cost several points. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,205)

ring-bark¶

v. [passive form]

[Caption] Puriris have been ring-barked by the cattle in their search for food, and the station management has taken the precaution of painting trees with creosote to prevent their wholesale destruction by the animals. (May 7, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

ring-fenced¶

adj.

FREEHOLD PROPERTY, NORTH TUAKITOTO. .. This property is intersected by the Main South Road, and the whole is ring fenced. (Apr 18, 1874,Otago Witness,17)

SHEEP FARM. 844 ACRES. 685 acres freehold, 159 acres l i.p., 650 acres in grass, balance in bush, ring fenced, subdivided into six paddocks, carrying capacity 1 sheep and 80 head cattle. (Aug 27, 1906,Hawera & Normanby Star,8)

acres in grass and turnips, ring fenced; .. (May 22, 1930,Na To Hoa Aroha,2/26,1987 ed.) [NOTES: 1930 May 22 Na To Hoa Aroha (1987) (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 2/26 (Ngata) 280]

HISLOP There are plenty of [hares] in that ring-fenced paddock, and as they can't get out of there you should have a lot of fun; .. (1943,Pure Gold,73)

adj. (Rural) [joc.] [of a person] kept at home.

Of a spouse, to be ring-fenced: to be kept at home. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

adj. (Rural) [of funding, products or organisations] isolated from others for a specific purpose.

One [clear option] was for the reserves to be returned to farmers, the other being for money to be vested in a 'tightly ring-fenced' trust fund. (Sep 3, 2001,Rural News,05)

1 adj. (Rural) [of an area] surrounded by a fence for a particular reason e.g. a boundary between neighbours.

HISLOP There are plenty .. in that ring-fenced paddock, and as they can't get out of there you should have a lot of fun. (1943,Pure Gold,73)

Sheep Farm: Good sheep-proof fences, ring-fenced with concrete, totara posts. (Sep 28, 1961,NZ Farmer,69)

ring-fencing¶

n.

THOMAS ... he decided to take up the other section `as forty pounds was sufficient at slump prices to buy wire for ring-fencing'. ... He then ring-fenced the new land, ramming as many as fifty posts into position in one day ... (1970,Way Up North,93)

1 n. (Rural) the enclosing of an area with a fence or railings.

BENNETT Around 1918 the Bryan brothers did a ring-fencing job for Dick Goodwin on a 100 acre block of recently chopped bush. (1990,Bryans, The: At Home on the Farm,37)

ring-in¶

n. a substitute; an outsider

ring in n. entering a disguised horse, dog or athlete in competitive sport (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

ring in ... ~ n. ring-in. 3. Austral. & N.Z. sl. a person or thing that is not normally a member of a particular group; outsider. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,994) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 420]]

ring-in/ringer¶

n. a fraudulently substituted racehorse

There is one thing in connection with trotting I cannot understand, and that is the lack of interest shown in some clubs, epecially in the south, to stamp out the "ringer." (May 21, 1896,Otago Witness,34)

THERE is an impression in some circles that the days of the "ringer" are not passed in New Zealand, and keen eyes are being kept on certain horses produced. (Mar 13, 1930,NZ Truth,11)

As Mrs Hedley and the "old prad" are also out for life, the "ring in" did not do the crowd behind the ex-New Zealander, Rawmire, much, if any, good, when that gelding won. (Feb 22, 1908,NZ Truth,2)

Scott He fumed at being beaten .... winding up his vituperation by saying that [the racehorse] was a ringer from Australia. (1900,Colonial Turf,222)

ring-keeper¶

n.

LEE "Come on, come on, come on!" the ring-keeper would yell as he gave the new chance to spin to the biggest better. (1937,Civilian into Soldier,99)

DEVANNY One man takes the kip and places two pennies on it ... He hands [his bet] to the ring-keeper. (1928,Dawn Beloved,162)

PARTRIDGE I'll admit I was stiff when I lost that fifty francs, but my cobber produced another ten; and when the ring-keeper said `Up and do 'em', I collected 200 francs. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

ring-master¶

n. [(two-up)]

Of course, there are [two-up] schools' here and there, and only ahead', in other words a true sport', knows their locale. Once upon a time the free and easyschool' with the ring-master,' and hisAll set - a fair go' broke upon the stilly night. (Jan 20, 1912,NZ Truth,343/7/3)

ring-neck¶

n. a white collar worker

You fight among yourselves till your ranks are broken through./ By carping critic ring-necks' and non-union alienage. ... Get rid of the Unioncuckoo' and the stool pigeon' as well / Thearrear fiends' and the `ring-necks' ' (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,28)

ring-raced¶

1 adj. (Rural) [dairy farms] furnished with a race that encircles the perimeter of a farm, adjoining most paddocks.

102 hectare recently converted dairy unit. Mainly flat with balance easy rolling. Ring-raced to 57 paddocks. (Nov 18, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,40)

The farm is also ring-raced to enable feeding to occur at the same time as milking. (Sep 20, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17)

ring-tree¶

n.

JENKIN He walked over to the dressing table where Mrs. Elworthy kept her rings on a ring-tree. (1970,NZ Mysteries,77)

ringa¶

n.

FORSTER A Comparative Table of the Various Languages in the Isles of the South-Sea ... [English] The arm or hand ... [New-Zeeland] Ringa [i-macron, a-grave] (1778,Observations Made During a Voyage,284)

ringa-ring¶

v. shake hands

WEEKES The natives here [in Taranaki] are in fear of their old enemies the `Wicatus' coming, but it appears their visit is intended for a friendly one, or to ringa-ring (shake hands). Ibid. t 68 They [Maoris] were very civil, indeed the habit of shaking hands with every one became at last disagreeable, for if you met them a dozen times a day the ringa-ring must not be omitted, ... (May 2, 1841,Journal) [NOTES: 1841 May 2 Weekes Journal in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 49]

ringanui¶

n. a groundwater crustacean [ORIGIN: Maori, The name Ringanui is derived from the Maori words ringa (hand) and nui (big) in reference to the very large gnathopod 1 characteristic of this genus. The name toonuiiti is derived from Maori toonui (thumb) and iti (little) and refers to the smaller robust seta defining the proximal end of the gnathopod 1 palm... The name koonuiroa is derived from Maori koonui (thumb) and roa (long) and refers to the very large robust seta defining the proximal end of the gnathopod 1 palm...]

The new genus, Ringanui, is a significant step in resolving this confusion. Ringanui differs from Paraleptamphopus on several characters and is most easily recognised by diverse gnathopods, the first of which is enlarged relative to gnathopod 2. The two species are described and illustrated in detail. They differ in size and gnathopod characteristics, but other differences are small. Ringanui koonuiroa is the smaller species and is most easily recognised by the single, very long robust seta defining the palm of gnathopod 1. The second species, R. toonuiiti, is the larger, but its palmar defining spine is relatively short. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2006f/z01148p025f.pdf Accessed on 14/03 2006]

ringaringa¶

n. (See rengarenga)

Ringatu¶

adj. [ORIGIN: Maori]

His [Te Kooti's] followers state that he received visions from on high, and here he laid the foundations of the Ringatu Church. (Feb 1, 1933,NZ Tablet,15)

He doubts if there are 70 non-Waitotara district natives present, and of the strangers there are some Wanganui and Wangaehu, probably 40, and a few of what are known as the ringatu natives, from Urewera district, some of Te Kooti's old people. (Jan 6, 1897,Evening Post,5)

4 There were Anglican, Roman Catholic, Mormon, Wesleyan and Ringatu services, and everywhere the singing could be heard. (Dec 30, 1911,Poverty Bay Herald)

I thought at first that the Ringatu Church meant a church at Ringatu. If it means a religion I think we ought to pause before we endow a faith which may, for all we know, be most pernicious. (Feb 9, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,22)

Many of the Maoris are followers of the Ringatu religion started by Te Kooti, the prophet, last century. (1948,Our Own Country,55)

Ringatu draws on the Old Testament; Rua Kenana, who claimed to be son of Te Kooti and the new Messiah, turned to the New Testament. (2005,AA Directions,Autumn p22)

[Caption] The famous temple of Rua, the Ringatu prophet. (May 6, 1950,Southern Cross (Wgton),8)

Nearly all these people were Ringatus... Not many people know much about the Ringatu faith... I knew that Ringatu was the name for some sort of religion, for on Sundays the people gathered at the carved meeting house which was the Ringatu church and chanted long karakias, guided by one who was their Ringatu Minister. (Apr 20, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,42)

At the native meeting up the river the diversity of religions caused some discussion. There are four religions altogether, Protestant (Church of England), Catholic, Salvation Army, and Te Kooti's religion (Ringatu). The latter is a bugbear to some of the natives, particularly the Catholics, but the meeting decided on freetrade in this matter, the main argument being that as Englishmen had hundreds of religions there was no reason why the Maoris should not have at least four. .. The term Ringatu is, we understand, derived from the fact that in place of saying "Amen," as usual in other services, they say "Glory." (Sep 16, 1889,Wanganui Herald,2)

The 1870-72 Urewera expeditions were driven by a vengeful Colonial Government (also known as the Kawanatanga), desperate to track down and destroy Te Kooti Arikirangi Te Turuki and his Ringatu guerilla force then regrouping within the boundaries of the Tuhoe tribe's forested rohe. (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

When she returned here [from treatment in a Pakeha hospital] I heard an old woman ask her, In what state are you now?' (i.e.,Have you deserted our ringa tu religion, are you noa?' (1905,TrNZI,37/87)

n.

The Ringatus always begin and end each prayer by raising their hands with the fingers extended. (Feb 1, 1933,NZ Tablet,15)

At the native meeting up the river the diversity of religions caused some discussion. There are four religions altogether, Protestant (Church of England), Catholic, Salvation Army, and Te Kooti's religion (Ringatu). The latter is a bugbear to some of the natives, particularly the Catholics, but the meeting decided on freetrade in this matter, the main argument being that as Englishmen had hundreds of religions there was no reason why the Maoris should not have at least four. .. The term Ringatu is, we understand, derived from the fact that in place of saying "Amen," as usual in other services, they say "Glory." (Sep 16, 1889,Wanganui Herald,2)

The Missionaries, the Mormons, the Ringatu, and the others, all worshipped the God of the Bible in slightly different ways. (Feb 25, 1887,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

I thought at first that the Ringatu Church meant a church at Ringatu. If it means a religion I think we ought to pause before we endow a faith which may, for all we know, be most pernicious. (Feb 9, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,22)

That's describing the place as it was in the early 1900s, when it was basically a Maori-speaking Ringatu community that didn't have a cash economy at all, just lived off the land, growing their own fruit and vegetables, and taking fish out of the estuary and out of the sea. (Oct 18, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

Te Kooti and his main force of Ringatu managed to elude the Kawanatanga. (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

Ringatuism¶

n. [Some tribes have the marae instinct and a psychology that influences the collection of food supplies. Such is Waikato. And you will find the same condition where cults like Ringatuism prevail]

ringawera¶

n. marae caterer, cook [ORIGIN: Maori, [Ma. ringawera marae caterer, kitchen helper] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 220.]

.. to all our kaumatua and ringawera who worked tirelessly in the background for us ... (May 12, 2006,NZ Herald,C9)

A special thanks to our whanau at Hei marae the ringawera, and also our Kaumatua on the pae. (Dec 13, 2005,NZ Herald,C8)

Our people are doing amazing things: from our ringawera and kaumatua ... (Jul 26, 2005,Wairarapa Midweek,32)

ringbarked¶

adj. elderly

HENDERSON A great old bushwhacker and scrubcutter and shearer in his day but now a bit ringbarked himself with a depressed and hagridden mustache but twinkling eyes. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,129)

2 adj. circumcised

NORGROVE Of course skinboys pick it up quicker than those who have been ringbarked.'Ringbarked?' `Circumcised.' (1987,Shoestring Sailors,138)

ringbolt¶

n. a non-paid trip on a ship aided by one or more of the crew;a clandestine passage aided by one or more of the crew;(used by shipgirls, escapees, etc.) [?f. a play on ring vagina; anus' and boltrun for it'; or from a play on ringbolt cf Golden rivet; or mere elaboration on bolt

NEWBOLD Because Mata was a seaman, he knew he'd have no trouble getting a ringbolt or a stowaway back to the Islands. (1982,Big Huey, The,192)

She went to Australia as a "ring bolt", a stowaway, on the Monowai. (Jul 1991,Metro,94)

WATSON ... they would go possum-trapping, ... or maybe even get a whitebait trench down on the West Coast, or do a ringbolt on [16] a ship somewhere. (1965,Stand in the Rain,15)

to ringbolt: to stow away (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

NEWBOLD RINGBOLT (n) Clandestine voyage by sea used by escapees. (1982,Big Huey, The,253)

McGILL ringbolt stow away, with crew connivance. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

Officially Hinckesman was a stowaway, but the Auckland Star said he had done a `ringbolt', paying a crew member to hide him during the voyage. (Jan 11, 1989,Dominion,3)

NORGROVE Maybe she's scared he'll do a ringbolt and take off. (1987,Shoestring Sailors,48) [NOTES: Of a girlfriend scared of losing her boyfriend: used as a synonym of bolt.]

NORGROVE Maybe she's scared he'll do a ringbolt and take off. (1987,Shoestring Sailors,48) [NOTES: Of a girlfriend scared of losing her boyfriend: used as a synonym of bolt.]

ringbolting¶

n. stowing away on a ship with the crew's connivance

For seamen, well-hidden ring-bolting was a way of getting between islands without paying. (Nov 14, 1981,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

He vanished ... possibly using a technique known as `ring bolting', catching an illegal passage on a crew member. (Jul 10, 1988,Sunday Star (Auckland),A10)

ringed dosinia¶

n. Dosinia anus

POWELL RINGED DOSINIA (Dosinia anus). A large, rather thickened and flat disc shaped shell, coarsely sculptured with concentric sharp ridges. It grows up to 3 1/2 inches across and is common washed ashore on sandy coastal beaches. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,22)

McLINTOCK Ringed dosinia .. .. tuangi-haruru .. .. Dosinia anus (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-12)

ringer¶

n. the shearer with the highest tally in a gang, or a shearing-shed; the fastest shearer in a shearing gang, who usually shears on the stand closest to the wool table

M'Kay, who was "ringer", put up a decent record with 111 sheep in four hours. (Jan 23, 1896,Otago Witness,24)

Robert Parker has even suggested that [this wine] is good enough to be used as a ringer in a tasting of top Burgundies. (Mar 3, 2001,Dominion,30)

Fastest shearer in a shearing gang who usually shears on the stand closest to the wool table. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,58)

WATSON All sorts of characters used to gather there, hunters and miners, ringers from outback stations. (1986,Address to a King,59)

RICHARDS For some time he had known that his reign as `ringer' would soon be over. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,76)

ringer ... NZ & Austral. fastest shearer in a shed. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,658) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 994; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 420]]

OGONOWSKA-COATES Ringer. The fastest shearer in a woolshed.The ringer is said to `ring the shed' by shearing the highest tally. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Ringer. The fastest shearer in a woolshed.The ringer is said to `ring the shed' by shearing the highest tally. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies)

ringer: The fastest shearer in the shed over the period of shearing, and different from a gun'. The ringer could be the best of several gun shearers in the same shed, but he could also be a ringer in a weak team and not even be a gun. A possible origin of the term can be found underquoits' but others are that the ringer `runs rings round the rest' and the ringer in Yorkshire dialect means anyone superlatively good. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/27) [NOTES: Wallace Shearing Glossary-]

Ringi.er (-&etilde.r), n. [See RING, v. t., 4.] [Add.] 3. One who makes the highest score in shearing sheep. [Australian bush cant] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

He's often the ringer and even though he's the best on the board, he takes time to give the younger men advice on their blade-shearing techniques. (Jul 20, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

We had been discussing Billy Blair, the "ringer" of the shed. (1913,NZ Observer,Xmas Annual : 4)

The majority of cries of "ringer" that are heard after a hitherto unknown, or poorly performed horse wins a heat in impressive style.. are simply the result of "pipe-dreams." (Feb 28, 1934,NZ Truth,2)

MEREDITH Two of them [sc shearers] were running one another for the title of `ringer' (the one who shore the most sheep in one day) and were cutting the sheep rather badly, necessitating the constant application of the Stockholm-tar brush to the cuts. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,143,1935 ed.)

And when each shearing season came,/ ... She'd take the snips' and put to shame/ Theringer' of the crowd. (Sep 1889,Sydney Bulletin) [NOTES: 1889 Sept 8 Sydney Bulletin in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 121]

And the ringers and the borses will be passed in long review./ (Oct 15, 1896,Otago Witness) [NOTES: 1896 Oct 15 Otago Witness in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 131]

WRIGHT Some [shearers] are so proficient at their craft that they can shear as many as a hundred and sixty sheep in a day, the best and quickest of whom is called the `ringer'. (1894,In the Land of the Tui,242)

McKEE WRIGHT (The bloke that ran across a snag') Though the ringer muttered,Likely'; and Dick Mason sneered, `perhaps'. (1897,Station Ballads,34)

MORRIS Ringer, n.a sheep-shearing term. See quotations. Mr. Hornung's explanation of the origin (quotation, 1894) is probably right. See Rings (1898,Austral English,389)

LANCASTER Michael, a ringer of an ordinary three hundred (1905,Sons o' Men,81)

Ringer,' of course, persists for the fastest hand in a shed; with about an equal probability of derivation from the man, horse, or ship that runsrings' round an antagonist, or from the ringer of the bell that has marked success in many games or contests besides that of the sportive `shooting gallery.' (Jul 7, 1911,Maoriland Worker,18/14/2)

The fastest shearer in the woolshed. He us said to ring the shed. [1898 Morris Austral-English] says the name was given because he runs rings round the other shearers. (Nov 18, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: 1933 Acland Glossary Press 18 Nov 15]

NEWTON [Gloss] Ringer: fastest shearer in the gang. (1947,Wayleggo)

NEWTON ringer: The fastest shearer in the gang. Fast men are also known as guns,' and the slowest man in the shed as thedrummer.' (1949,High Country Days,197,1950 ed.)

McLEOD The fastest man is called the ringer and there is considerable prestige attached to it, besides the extra profit. Sometimes a man will `ring the shed' in the wethers by sheer courage or brute strength. (1951,High Country,29)

MEEK RINGER: The shearer with the highest aggregate tally of sheep shorn. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,111)

BOWEN ..., and yet over the years it has developed into a competitive sport and for past years, right back in early blade-shearing history, it was always a race, and an honour to shear for the `ringer's' stand. Ibid. 156 RINGER. The fastest shearer on the board. He usually shears on the first stand next to the wool table. Any rival shearer must shear a bigger tally for three consecutive days before he can take the ringer's stand. (1955,Wool Away!,1)

HILLIARD (1963,Piece of Land, A,90)

HILLIARD (1963,Piece of Land, A,90)

Ring the board. Ringer ringie: the fastest shearer in the gang occupying the number one stand. In shed shearing the position of `Ringer' is sought after and competition among shearers has always been keen. (Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

NEWTON The fastest shearer in the gang. Fast men are also known as guns, and the slowest man in the shed as the drummer. (1966,Boss's Story, The,189)

~ n. shearer who shears largest number of sheep each day. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

RINGER (Ringie): The fastest shearer in a gang. He occupies the number one position on the board until successfully challenged. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20) [NOTES: [Shearer's language]]

ringer n.champion shearer with highest daily tally, who `runs rings round' other shearers. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),17)

n. (marbles term)

SUTTON-SMITH It is important to distinguish these `Action-Terms' of marbles from the innumerable merely descriptive marble terms which have no effect on the course of the action - terms such as Ringer, In, Smug, Dead Stick, Skun, Skinned, Sported off, Scat, Cannons, Dubs, Kills, Funs, Keeps, Pink. (1953,Unorganized Games,2/770)

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. Ibid. 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899: reference, game of Little Ring] Many heated arguments arose as to who said everythings' ornothings' first. If a player's taw' touched a marble and lay alongside it, the others would shoutknuckle down' just before his turn. ... Knuckle down' meant that the player had to hold his taw close to the marble attacked and fire it in that very inconvenient position. ... When a boy lost all his marbles at play he wasscat' [?related to skint ?HWO] . ... A ringer' was a taw which, when fired at the commencement of the game, lodged in the track of the ring itself; that, and knocking a marble out when hefired' were the perfect shots. ... To fire a shot while holding the hand nearer to the ring than where the taw had lain, was to `funk', an unforgiveable crime. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

n. a throw that rings the spike (?or object at hoopla) [(quoits)]

SATCHELL The click of quoits as someone threw a ringer. (1907,Elixir of Life,190)

quoits: In the early days when men were isolated at the sheds, quoits was a popular game. Iron rings or old horse shoes were used and the one who beat the rest was the ringer'. This termringer', and `good iron' could have drifted into the shed where it is still used today. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/26) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

n. ? one who works in a criminal ring'; ? one whorings in' stolen cars [(?criminals')]

POLICE believe several gangs of car ringers are active in Christchurch. They use identification plates and papers from wrecks to disguise stolen vehicles before resale....The ringers buy a late-model wreck written off by an insurance company and steal a similar car. The identification plates are then changed over and the stolen vehicle is sold as a rebuilt wreck. (Mar 20, 1983,NZ Times,5)

n.

COLIN GORDON Pelters: make the arse-cuts, a cut around the ring so that it comes away from the inside. This is also called ringing or arsecutting (ringers and arse-cutters for men who do them). (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: Feilding Freezing Works terms]

n.

MEREDITH As I was finishing the counting-out, the boss came towards the shed with a couple of towels in his hand and invited me to come for a swim. I said I would join him as soon as I had all the tallies. The two ringer contestants then called to him, `We're going.' (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,144,1935 ed.)

LANCASTER `That second is Maori ringer this year,' said Darien, looking down the dim broad board flecked with light from the little windows, with the flash of clicking blades, ... (1938,Promenade,441)

RICHARDS I was up with the guns' with a top tally of 163 and had my eye on theringer' status, the highest and most coveted accolade in any large shed. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,115)

n. from ca1930 for something `really good', superior: (cf BOTTLER, RUMPTY) [I have not heard it much used since 1941 in Wellington or Marlborough. Used only occasionally as an attrib.']

n. (Rural) a person in charge of a team of rural workers.

The person in charge of a team of farm workers: a ringer. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

1 n. (Rural) a fastest shearer in a gang.

The 'ringer' was J Aberfield with 252 sheep. (Mar 1895,NZ Farmer,91)

MEEK ringer - the shearer with the highest aggregate tally of sheep shorn. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,111)

BARNES The ganger is the boss and the Ringer is the fastest shearer. (1987,Country Calendar (TVNZ),118)

2 n.

I don't stand up to look for work, I come down to make a start; / For I'm classed among the `ringers', and from others stand apart. / Whilst on the job I'm set for life, and I'm doing well I vow. / For I've got the boss behind me, So I want no Union now. (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,24)

BAKER The term ringer is now applied to a person who is particularly competent at any manual labour. (1941,NZ Slang,39)

The best men on the killing board [ca1914], called the Ringers were Ellis and Pettit. (Jan 24, 1981,Evening Post,7) [NOTES: (Clem Goddard on Gear Meat Co.)]

ringeye¶

n. (See silvereye)

Mr Buller gives a curious account of the first appearance in the Province of Wellington of the little bird which we call here the Wax-eye, or Ring-eye. (Jul 17, 1869,Otago Witness,9)

".. It is the small native bird - the ring-eye I believe it is named - does the mischief here ..." (May 19, 1871,North Otago Times,2)

[It may here be stated, that the writer of the foregoing would long ago have written in English for publication in the newspapers what he knew of this little bird (Ring-eye), had he not from time to time noticed in several colonial papers the most strange assertions concerning it ...] (Aug 13, 1867,Hawke's Bay Herald,2)

Is the correct name waxeye or ringeye? (May 19, 1909,Otago Witness,86)

The beautiful little ringeye (which is generally considered to be not a native of New Zealand) builds in scrub along the banks of watercourses. (Dec 11, 1890,Otago Witness,41)

BULLER The natives distinguish the bird as Tau-hou (which means stranger), or Kanohi-mowhiti (which may be interpreted as spectacle-eye or ring-eye). It is also called Poporoke and Iringatu, names suggested by its accidental or periodical occurrence. Ibid. 1/82 By the settlers it [sc Zosterops] has been variously designated as Ring-eye, Wax-eye, White-eye, or Silver-eye, in allusion to the beautiful circlet of satiny-white feathers which surrounds the eyes; and quite as commonly as the Blight-bird', orWinter Migrant'. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/81)

MORRIS Ring-eye, n. one of the many names for the birds of the genus Zosterops (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,389)

ANDERSON tauhou, a wandering bird (Zosterops halmaturina), blight-bird; twinkie; button-eye; wax-eye; ring-eye. Tauhou means stranger and this name was given by the Maori when the bird appeared, in 1856, in the central part of New Zealand, gradually spreading north and south till the islands were occupied. It is an Australian bird, and was blown across the Tasman sea in the year mentioned. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159)

FRAME (1951,Lagoon, The,46, 47)

... but she was big and warm and knew about cats and little ring-eyes, ... (1951,Some Other Country,101) [NOTES: 1951 Frame `Swans' in 1984 Some Other Country 101]

(1953,Landfall,7/1/21)

NATUSCH Family ZOSTEROPIDAE (silvereyes). Zosterops lateralis ... , called ring-eye in the south, wax-eye, white-eye, silvereye, blightie, etc., elsewhere, is probably in actual fact a blown-away Australian. Not seen here before 1886, it is certainly plentiful ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,282)

DAVIN ... the very first time they tried it they caught a blackbird and two ring-eyes. (1975,Breathing Spaces,11) [NOTES: (Southland)]

This bird is sometimes called the silver-eye, ring-eye or blight-bird. We call them "blighties". (Apr 22, 1924,Otago Witness,63)

ringie¶

n. ringer [shearers']

(Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener)) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing) [See quot. at ringer n]]

RINGER (Ringie): The fastest shearer in a gang. He occupies the number one position on the board until successfully challenged. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20) [NOTES: [Shearer's lan guage]]

n. the ring-keeper in a two-up game

Swift the `ringie' shouts with might. (May 16, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,137)

PARTRIDGE Ringie, the. The man that, at two-up, keeps the ring, arranges the wagers, and pays out the winnings: Australian and New Zealand coll.: late C. 19-20 (1937,Dictionary of Slang,700)

A boxer' is a gratuity to theringie' at two-up, a game supplying the phrase `two ladies on bicycles,' two pennies showing Britannia. (Apr 2, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

n. a childrens' marble game [ca1964 Auckland, a game of marbles played in a ring]

FRAME `Treasure' I played ringie and holie. I played funs and keeps. I had pee-wees and bully taws and changers that weren't made of glass mind you. And I won nearly every game because the kids were so dazzled by the look of my stinkers. ... They came for miles to play marbles with me ... (1951,Lagoon, The,116,1961 ed.)

KEITH & MAIN [Photo caption] Marbles became in' orout' capriciously but someome always knew the rules of the various games - holey,'liney' and, seen here, ringey' - which could be played forfuns' or `keeps.' (1984,NZ Yesterdays,288)

ringing¶

n. [(kauri bushmen's)]

REED Deeper scarves were cut out of all Leaning trees to prevent them from splitting up. After sawing to a certain depth ..... each man alternately cut round his side of the tree almost to the front scarf. The adoption of this plan, known as `ringing', caused the wood to break clean when falling. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,157)

n. arse-cutting (from ring = arsehole) [(freezing workers)]

GORDON Pelters: make the arse-cuts, a cut around the ring so that it comes away from the inside. This is also called ringing or arsecutting (ringers and arse-cutters for men who do them). (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: ca1951 May 17 Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c.Colin Gordon]

n. (Rural) ring crutching

The job may be small, such as ring crutching, but those heavy sheep have to be handled. Ideal for full crutch, ringing and wigging, dagging or sale crutch of prime lambs. (Jun 1982,NZ Journal of Agriculture,49)

1 n. (Rural) [sheepdogs] the circling of a mob of sheep.

A bit rash when ringing. (Jul 1911,NZ Farmer,788)

WHYTE The fault of ringing sheep is a very serious one. Ringing means completing a circle around the sheep. It is a waste of time and tends to knock up the sheep. (1927,Sheep-Dog, The,48)

MILLS .. if the sheep move forward he [the sheepdog] may come round in front of you to face them, which is known as 'ringing his sheep.' (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,30)

Ringing - when a dog heads sheep, doesn't stop behind them and goes round and round them - that's ringing. (Dec 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,45)

ringing-in¶

n.

The Greymouth Trotting Club also wrote re the "ringing-in" of a certain horse in that district, stating that the club had authorized its secretary to proceed to the North Island with the object of identifying an animal alleged to have been "rung-in" at Greymouth; also suggesting that the association might financially assist the club in its efforts to stop "ringing-in." (Apr 15, 1897,Otago Witness,32)

The Wellington Trotting Club will investigate a case of alleged ringing in. (Jan 28, 1896,Wanganui Herald,3)

The hearing of the charge in connection with the alleged `ringing-in' trotting case was proceeded with in the Police Court, Dunedin. (Feb 14, 1924,Auckland Weekly News,24)

[Hdg] Alleged "Ringing-In" Auckland Students Charged. (Feb 26, 1924,Otago Witness,9)

If "ringing-in" did occur, did Tucker have anything to do with it? (May 20, 1924,Otago Witness,24)

ringo apple¶

n.

HYDE (1952,Houses by the Sea,132)

ringtail¶

n.

"Ringtail" rumors are now persistent and the gelding being a "clean-skin" it is believed that it might have hailed from New Zealand. (Jun 20, 1929,NZ Truth,13)

A "Ringtail" is a colloquialism employed to describe a horse which is raced under the name of another, usually with the desire to deceive and defraud. (Jul 20, 1955,NZ Truth,25)

Has the "ringtail" entirely been eliminated from trotting in New Zealand? (Feb 28, 1934,NZ Truth,2)

This time it is.. an allegation that there has been a "ringtail" racing. (Jul 20, 1955,NZ Truth,25)

ringtail (possum)¶

n.

ring-tail NZ & Austral. (also called ring-tailed opossum) arboreal opossum with curled prehensile tail. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,658) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 994]]

ringtail snorter¶

n. an exceptional person

When it comes to hot stuff this man North is out on his own, he's a hummer, a ring-tail snorter. (May 2, 1908,NZ Truth,150/1/1)

ringtailed snorter¶

phr. an elaboration of SNORTER, (cf RIPSNORTER), for anything excellent or superior of its kind.

DAVIN She was a real beaut.'Only cost me fifty ackers.' `Did you see the ringtailed snorter old Shorty got hold of.' (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,51)

He was a ring-tailed "snorter", and the overseer thought the world of him. (Apr 25, 1906,Otago Witness,73)

The English colt, Valido, who is reported to be a ring-tailed snorter in the galloping line, will make his first public appearance in the Middle Park Plate to-day. (Feb 3, 1912,NZ Truth,2)

ringworms¶

n.

BRASCH It was very bold, among us [at Waitaki], to wear the horizontally striped socks we called ringworms, especially if the stripes were pronounced in colour ... . (1980,Indirections,64) [NOTES: (Waitaki school)]

rinse¶

n. the drug gamma-hydroxybutyric acid (GHB) (See GHB)

Instead, clubbers reached for drugs like GHB, chemical name gammahydroxybutyric acid, which was affordable and easy to obtain, but when mixed with alcohol acted like an anaesthetic and put users in vulnerable situations, "especially where safe sex was concerned". Last year, four clubbers aged under 21 had to be put on ventilators in Wellington hospital's intensive care unit after taking GBH [sic], a class B drug also known as Rinse. (Sep 26, 2005,Dominion Post,A4) [NOTES: electronic record: http://www.stuff.co.nz/stuff/0,2106,3423102a11,00.html#top Accessed 09/02/06]

Also found at the house was stolen property, including laptops taken in inner-city burglaries as well as quantities of the gamma-hydroxybutyric acid (commonly referred to as rinse or GHB), cannabis plant and seeds, steroids and a pipe used for smoking methamphetamine (speed). (Jul 29, 2003,Independent Herald (Wellington),3)

Some of the people at [his] home that night said he had previously supplied them with drugs, including Rinse, a form of Fantasy. (Aug 6, 2003,Dominion Post,A6)

rintin¶

adj.

HULME ... what would I wish for anyway? A return of the spirit of joy? ... Maybe, considering this rintin shambles of a night, I should wish something for them ... for Simon, what? (1983,Bone People, The,93)

riot pack¶

n.

MAHY "A riot pack," said Richard, meaning that he had bought a large carton holding three litres of wine. (1985,Carpathians, The,112)

During the 1980s around 70c of every dollar earned came from three- or four-litre casks, known by some as "riot packs". (Apr 1, 1995,Evening Post,13)

riovi¶

n. rowi (kiwi)

WILLIAMS The Riovi [possibly Kiwi], this bird was never repletely described to me, but is said to be a very remarkable one, and sometimes caught by the natives. (1844,NZ Journal,113,1956 ed.)

rip¶

n. (Wellington coast)

GREEN The Rip ... we stopped off the entrance of Port Phillip to take a Melbourne pilot on board, and steaming through the `Rip', as the rough water between the heads is called, we let go our anchor ... (1883,High Alps of NZ,27)

WILLIAMS [?Terawhiti Rip] Stood out of [Port Nicholson] harbour. Off the headland got into a strong race (tide rip), observed the ebb tide set to the Southd. (Nov 9, 1839,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,450,1961 ed.)

PUGH-WILLIAMS `When used by seafarers they are generally referring to the tide rips in Cook Strait off Terawhiti. (1951,Letter)

SEDDON All went well until we passed Cape Farewell and Stephen's Island and the Brothers and encountered what they called the rip in Cook Strait. (1968,Seddons, The,46)

MACKENZIE The Rip (Cook Strait) Terawhiti rip The boat [Tamahine c1941] always seemed to head for that notorious stretch of water known as `the rip', and all the chairs ... anchored with chains would turn over, while a nurse in white would move about among the green passengers with much-needed strawberry boxes. -->OED 1. commotion of seas caused by opposing currents or by a rapid current passing over an ... 1836, 1860, 1875 2. tidal wave or current 1903; CC Ransom =US riptide, rip current (1982,WAAF Book,30)

v. (of a pig) slash (a dog) with its tusks

A young man named M'Guiness of West Melton, was badly ripped by a pig at the Addington Saleyards to-day the animal rushing at him and inflicting a gash in his thigh three or four inches in length. (May 17, 1906,Grey River Argus,3)

Caught a fine young boar and Jock got ripped by a large boar (Nov 17, 1849,Torlesse Papers,113,1958 ed.)

n. constr. often the rip a strong tidal current (usually off a headland, point), a TIDE-RIP

The first such instance saw me in my novice days towed from a rip by one of the club veterans. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/37)

CAPT.J.R.KENT Commences with strong Gales and thick misty weather; a strong ripple, and a heavy cross-sea running, the vessle [sic] shipping a quantity of water - (May 29, 1823,Log) [NOTES: 1823 May 29 ripple =?rip Mermaid log in 1940 Howard Rakiura 342]

CARRINGTON the Tide Rips. [? sense] (1841,Journal,29)

SHAW The term [tide-rip] is well-known in New Zealand and especially in Melbourne; I never heard it used in England although I am informed they exist in the Portland firth, and ... near Weymouth. A Tide-rip is caused by a current setting in a certain direction after a gale of wind over perhaps an under surface. (1858,Gallop to the Antipodes, A,125)

ALEXANDER The `rip', or tide, running like a mill-race against us, was terrible. (1863,Incidents of the Maori War,402)

BEATTIE When the water is half to three-quarters out [at Waikouaiti] there is a terrible rip but at full tide it is motionless ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,20)

rip hell out of¶

phr. [a person or thing ca1938]

rip into¶

v. to berate, tear a strip off (a person); to get stuck into (a job of work) [ca1938 Havelock]

McGILL rip into attack with fists or words, often in positive fashion, such as aiming to move a pile of rubble; eg `Let's rip into this digging of the swimming pool, should only take us a few hours.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

rip off¶

v. to rush off

MASTERS I ripped off down to where the nearest pair of dogs were barking. (1960,Back-Country Tales,38)

rip one's nightie¶

phr. make one angry

More than anything, it is the unbearably condescending nature of the bill's wording that really rips my nightie... (Dec 14, 2005,Express (Gay & Lesbian Express),9)

rip up¶

v. >rip somebody (for arse-wife) to berate soundly; `abuse'; to tear one's character to pieces. (cf rip into) [ca1935]

threats from one of [the toughs] torip up' his pursuers.' =(?) swear at ;?? rip into ie. beat up ;? cut to ribbons (ie like ripping up one's stomach)] (1865,Evening Post,1/69/3)

rip, shit or bust¶

phr. as an asseveration or attrib, of action or person who goes bull-at-a-gate at anything without thought to the consequences, or the quality of the result. -->ca1930 Havelock. -->ca1940 (Les Cleveland) [also: rip, shit and bust.]

Greenwood said too many Kiwi developments were "rip, shit and bust" and he believed foreign buyers took better care of their land. (Aug 15, 2004,Sunday Star Times,A15)

Roy Billing was in the original production and reignites his crowd pleasing blustery performance as Tupper the rip-shit-or-bust coach, who truly believes that Tuesday and Thursday down at the clubhouse would do any lad the world of good. (Aug 21, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

The iconic figure of the "rip-shit-and-bust" coach Tupper survives, originally a World War II era throwback, increasingly out of place amid the political, racial and social awakenings of the 1970s. (Oct 18, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

Instead of rip-shit-and-bust coaches who talked only about guts and toughness.., John Hart began using the vocabulary of business, people management and monetarist economics, words like "accuracy" and "efficiency". (Nov 12, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

McGEE The days of the rip-shit-or-bust coach are gone. (1981,Foreskin's Lament,85)

In a fit of name-calling / they fix blame by brawling / as they go at it rip, shit and bust... (Oct 3, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C12)

SUTHERLAND If anything breaks grab our standby truck and keep hauling. It's rip, tip or bust at this game [hauling road metal] and no please or thank you. (1956,Green Kiwi,120,1960 ed.)

It didn't ever seem to occur to him that a leisurely, measured approach might work better than rip shit and bust. (Nov 11, 1983,National Business Review,57)

He'd already picked a name - it would be Loosehead Len and he'd be a right-wing, rip shit and bust Kiwi bloke, opinionated about everything, .. (Sep 1986,Metro,48)

McGILL rip shit and bust a big effort, often sporting; also rip split or bust; eg `Okay, team. If we're to have any chance of pegging this game back in the second half, it's got to be rip, shit and bust!' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

rip, split or bust¶

phr.

CHARLES We'll get that old Buster! [a wild boar] Rip, split or bust! (1981,Black Billy Tea,49)

rip-gut grass¶

1 n. (Rural) Bromus sterilis, a broom.

Loughnan rip-gut grass: barren brome (Bromus sterilis). This grass has a sharp penetrating seed and a heavily barbed awn. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,67)

ripe¶

adj. drunk

HYDE ... a bit ripe. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,190)

MUIR `Up you for the winter, mate. I got some booze to get stuck into now. I'll be bloody ripe by the time the friggin' railcar goes. No bullshit. Gidday, sport. You bloody bastard.' (1960,Word for Word,255)

ripe banana¶

n. an established Asian immigrant

Newly arrived Asians, I am told, call their more established counterparts "ripe bananas" - yellow on the outside and white on the inside. (Jul 17, 2002,NZ Herald,A15)

ripen¶

v. [(whalers')]

BAUCKE Then the cutting in' is begun; the huge slabs of fat are sliced and allowed toripen' in casks, with one head removed. When the last cask is full, the first is emptied into the try-pot, ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,76)

Rippa Rugby¶

n. an introductory form of rugby for primary school children

[Hdg] Rippa Rugby a big hit with primary schools... In Rippa Rugby, a New Zealand Rugby Union initiative, players wear a belt with two velcro flags, passing the ball when a flag is removed and a player yells "ripped". (May 29, 2004,Dominion Post,D1)

ripper¶

n. a good bloke

The men say things like, "You ripper, mate." (Oct 15, 2003,Capital Times,9)

n. Someone who raids a cannabis patch before the growers can harvest the crop

The worst dread of every grower, though, is a new breed of "rippers" who raid a patch, sometimes before it is even ready for harvest... Two years ago rippers were scum... There are so many out there now that it's become accepted. (Jun 29, 1998,Dominion,13)

n. good thing

"I come finally today to bring you tidings of great joy. At last we have the health policy." And what a little ripper it is too. (Nov 19, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

PARK So with huge labour and ingenuity we made that final historic campaign a ripper. (1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,285)

adj. good [1984 16 F4 E43 Pakuranga Coll. 8 RIPPER [something/-one good, -->1984 16 M3 E43 Pakuranga Coll. 18 RIPPER liked, delightful] -->1984 14 F E141 Wgton Girls C. 18 RIPPER]

ripper (beaut): good (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

McGILL ripper! excellent; eg `Got tickets for the game? You have? Ripper!' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

ripper down¶

n. (in a freezing-works)

RIPPERS DOWN (Rotates with shoulder men) (1975,Log of a Superfluous Son, The,42)

ripple¶

n. a tide rip (see rip)

There was a strong tide ripple on it, and the water was of a light sandy colour. (Jul 10, 1855,Daily Southern Cross,3)

..mariners waiting the turn of tide, entering or leaving the harbour, are recommended to keep the Point Lonsdale shore aboard, as the tide there runs fairer, and in bad weather small vessels incur less risk on the Point Lonsdale shore from the tide ripples than towards Port Nepean. (Jun 10, 1854,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

After leaving Lord's Harbour, you come to a critical boat passage between 2 reefs: here are two tides meeting at the flood, which causes a dangerous ripple, this instantly subsides at the ebb when the waters recede from each other. (1835,Boultbee Journal,105,1986 ed.)

n. [goldmining]

WEKEY ... they had the advantage ... of going from one bar of the river to another, ... which, probably for ages, served as ripples on a grand scale, to catch and accumulate the gold-dust brought down by the river, ... (1862,Otago As It Is,65)

BEATTIE There was a minor rush to Coal Creek ... and I think a little gold was got in the ripples. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,172)

MAY RIFFLE OR RIPPLE: both terms were used for the grooves cut across the bottom of a sluice-box or for the much more common wooden bars fixed at right angles, obliquely, or lengthwise, to the bottom of a sluice. The riffleboard' was detachable and formed afalse bottom'. Riffle' was probably a Californian term;ripple' seems to have been more usual on the goldfields of Australasia. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,528,1962 ed.)

Mr. William Beetham ... in Nelson, mentioned the trouble ... occasioned at the erpiodical `clean-up' by the presence of ... lead which collected in the ripples with the gold. (1903,TrNZI,35/403)

ripple board¶

n.

The tailings escape from the ripple through a row of small holes, half an inch in diameter, in the ripple board, pass through a second ripple, then through the third, on to the more gradual incline of the remaining twelve feet of the ripple table. (Jul 6, 1872,Otago Witness,8)

ripple plate¶

n.

VULCAN FOUNDRY .. cast iron sluice and ripple plates ... (Jun 3, 1882,Otago Witness,2)

There is a slight fall between each roller, on which are placed copper ripple plates, so that whatever gold is liberated by the crushing of the first roller has a chance to get amalgamated on the first copper ripples, and so with the second chamber, where the material passes through a rough grating before entering the third or last chamber, where it is retained until fine enough to go through a 240 punched grating, after which it is passed over the final copper ripples. (Apr 12, 1894,Otago Witness,15)

... the water and debris then ran down a sluice channel into boxes fitted with coconut matting and ripple plates'; these caught and retained the gold which was collected at the regularwash-up.' (1940,Tales of Pioneer Women,291,1988 ed.)

ripple table¶

n.

The tailings escape from the ripple through a row of small holes, half an inch in diameter, in the ripple board, pass through a second ripple, then through the third, on to the more gradual incline of the remaining twelve feet of the ripple table. (Jul 6, 1872,Otago Witness,8)

ripsnorter¶

adj.

If this doesn't make for a rip-snorter election campaign, then tough. (May 22, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

riripi¶

n. lilipi spg ripiri [? an error - transposition of sylls]

KNIGHT We got a fiery stick' from some Maoris ... who were waiting for aGoashore' of `Ripiri' to cool ... The mess was in time cool enough, when they all surrounded the great pot, some with pewter spoons, ... but most with shells from the beach ... . (1975,Poyntzfield,18) [NOTES: c1920s Eliza McKenzie in Outlook in 1975 Knight Poyntzfield 18 [reference Wellington 1850s]]

CARKEEK Hadfield in his 1839 diary mentions eating a meal which included boiled flour. This is probably the same food which became known to the Maoris later as riripi. It consisted of flour and water, with sugar [53] to sweeten, boiled and served up as a kind of porridge. In the early whaling days it was often served up to a whole village community from a canoe set up like a trough from which the villagers scooped their requirements in large bowls or paua shells. Many of the Ngati Raukawa of Otaki have vivid recollections of having eaten riripi in their childhood. (1966,Kapiti Coast,52)

ririwa¶

n.

BULLER The Ririwa (Linum monogynum) ... (1878,Forty Years in NZ)

ririwaka¶

n.

HOOKER Ririwaka, Col[enso]. Scirpus maritimus. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

Ririwaka. Scirpus maritimus, Linn. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/50) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

... the outer thatch [was] Toetoe, (Cyperus ustulatus), or Rautahi (Carex ternaria,) or Ririwaka (Scirpus maritimus), or of two kinds of Wiwi, or Rushes (Juncus maritimus, and effusus); ... (1869,TrNZI,/III/34) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

riro¶

n. riroriro

BRASCH The riro's note/ Crosses the ripening day/ (1984,Collected Poems,46)

riroriro¶

n. grey warbler, a small native bird, host to the eggs of the shining cuckoo. [Maori]

Tuis, mokomoko, riroriro native canaries, wrens, robins, and ringeyes, are fairly plentiful. (Jul 21, 1892,Otago Witness,33)

HULME & MORRISON Even the grey warbler is affected.. riroriro's insistent aching call.. abruptly stops. (1989,Homeplaces,111)

Riroriro also establish their territories in late July and August in preparation for nest building. Hearing the riroriro in early July on a beautiful clear winter's afternoon took me by surprise. (Jun 2006,Tumai,76/30)

The grey warbler (riroriro) is just as common in the wilds as he is in the town gardens, and delights the ear with his musical little trill. (Jun 26, 1912,Evening Post,14)

[His] observations are of the little grey warbler to which he gives its Maori name, riro-riro. (Apr 13, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

First among these indications was the early nesting of the little riroriro, or gray warbler. (Sep 28, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,11)

YATE Riroriro - A very small brown bird, with white feathers under the wings and tail. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),58)

POLACK The riroriro is a kind of swallow, not much unlike those in Great Britain. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/301)

DIEFFENBACH 19.Certhiparus maculicandus. ... Voy. de l' Astrol., Zool. 1.210 Momohoua [f. French spg]of the natives of Tasman Bay. Quoy et Gaim. Riro riro of the natives of the Northern Islands. Dieffenbach. ... --as a note to 13. Acanthisitta longpipes, (bush wren)] The bird, with the native name of Didadido, given by M.Lesson, may probably prove a species of this genus. [It did not: HWO] (1842,Travels in NZ,2/189) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/189 [this must be an error of D's]]

THOMSON The family Luscinidae has five species. The Matata, a small low-flying bird with a shrill cry, and the Riro or wren, the smallest bird in New Zealand, are the only species worthy of notice. The Matata has four long and four short tail feathers, similar in texture to those of the Kiwi. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/25)

... Read the papers & did Maori, went for about half an hour in the Domain & found a fantail nest (young ones) & a riroriro's with two young ones & an egg. I am inclined to think the egg is a pipiwharauroa's (white, with purple spots at the larger end). Splitting firewood in the afn. I found a fine large centipede - a weri - body brown, with the articulations very plainly marked, legs a pale blue .. (Oct 20, 1860,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/645,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

Gerygone flaviventris. Riro-riro. Common. (1869,TrNZI,1/160) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

HUTTON 24. GERYGONE FLAVIVENTRIS. Gray. Grey Warbler. Riro-riro. G. assimilis, BULLER. G. aucklandica, PELZ. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,10)

BULLER GERYGONE FLAVIVENTRIS. (GREY WARBLER.) ... Native names.- Riroriro and Koriroriro. {- This is the Grey Warbler, the well -known Riroriro of Maori history and song.} (1873,Birds of New Zealand,107,{1888 2nd edn 1/44} ed.)

I have got a great many birds since you have been away, which I shot with your gun or a catapult (excuse spelling), and which I stuff and hang up by the beak. ... One of them is a New Zealand bittern ... I have also the mako-mako, silver-eye, riro-riro, miro-miro, fanny etc. (Aug 16, 1875,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/399) [NOTES: (?Bill Atkinson, Nelson, 15 years)]

HAY The Riroriro (Gerygone flaviventris) is a little warbler seen about in company with the tauhau. [=?tauhou `silvereye'] (1882,Brighter Britain,2/224)

LADY MARTIN There is a little bird called Riro-riro in New Zealand from its note. (1884,Our Maoris,125 fn)

KELLY ... rerorero (the rainbird) (1892,Journey Through Waitara,7)

MORRIS a bird. Maori name for the Grey-Warbler of New Zealand, Gereygone flaviventris, Gray. See Gerygone. (1898,Austral English,390)

Rí.ro-rí.ro (r&emacr.́.ro.-r&emacr.́.ro.), n. [Maori.] (Zool.) Any New Zealand bird of the genus Gerygone. See GERYGONE. [Local, N. Z.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

~ n. the gray warbler. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

HYDE But here, a little stream meandered under cream-plumed shimmer of huge toi-toi bushes, crimson-billed pukekos with thoughtful expressions waded downstream, and a dart of wings meant riri-riro, the Maori's little bird of laughter, adventuring in the sunlit spaces. (1934,Journalese,109)

riroriro, a bird (Pseudogerygone igata), grey-warbler; favourite foster-parent for young bronze-wing cuckoo. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

POWELL GREY WARBLER (Pseudegerygone igata), Riroriro of the Maoris, is a small brownish grey bird abundant in all parts of New Zealand. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,86)

A little wren managed to squeeze itself through, and it flew off to Kurangai-tuku, and cried,Kurangai-tuku, the man is riro, riro!' -that is, gone, gone, gone. And to this day the bird is known as the riro-riro. (1889,Picturesque Australasia,IV/163) [NOTES: >1889. Cassell's `Picturesque Australasia,' vol. iv. p. 163:]

riroriro: grey warbler. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

riroriro n -s [Maori] : GRAY WARBLER (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1960)

~ n. bird, New Zealand wren, the grey warbler [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),523)

riro-riro ... n. bird, N.Z. wren, grey warbler [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),17)

  1. Gerygone igata (Quoy and Gaimard) Grey Warbler (Riroriro) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,67,1980 ed.)

  2. Gerygone igata (Quoy and Gaimard) Grey Warbler (Riroriro) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,67,1980 ed.)

Grey Warbler Gerygone igata (QUOY & GAIMARD, 1830) ... OTHER NAMES: Riroriro, teetotum. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,278)

riroriro n. NZ grey warbler. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 420]]

rise¶

n. (See top the rise)

n. an upward shaft

Rise: A small section shaft formed by working upwards from a level. (Sep 1999,Ohinemuri Regional History Journal,43 : 14)

HENDERSON (1961,Friends in Chains,188) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 188]

BLYTH Rise: Rising on the ore body. RISE: Quartz-mining term for working in or driving a shaft upwards. (1935,Gold Mining Year Book,11)

McARA Rise: A timbered excavation constructed by working upwards, using upper holes. Rising was done on the three-compartment system, that is with a ladderway on one end and a return airway on the other, with a `box' in the centre. This box was kept filled with ore and used to stand on while drilling the roof, the level of the ore being maintained by, drawing off the surplus ore through a chute at the bottom of the box. Rises were about 9 ft by 4 ft in section and might reach from one level to the next (about 150 ft), or to a sublevel, or from a stope to the level above. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),331)

rise-post¶

n. [(fencing)]

R.GILBERD (OKAIHAU) Posts on an elevation are called `rise-posts' (1951,Letter)

riser¶

n. [goldmining]

HEINZ The rush [to Welshman's in 1867] was not remarkable for the richness of the ground though a few `risers' were found, ... (1974,Bright Fine Gold,29) [NOTES: 1928 Grey River Argus in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 29]

rising¶

adj. Farming: approaching: a rising two-year-old'. used to describe an animalabout to become' a certain age, (e.g., a rising 2-year-old is an animal approaching 2 years old) [US [(farming)]

Rising: Used to describe an animal `about to become' a certain age, e.g., a rising 2-year-old is an animal approaching 2 years (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,7)

n. (i.e. of a Court)

There is a tight' in the affairs of man [sic], which taken at the flood leads on therising'- if you haven't 5s. to ante-up. (Jan 18, 1908,NZ Truth,135/1/3)

n. baking-powder; baking-soda (occas. yeast)

To make the bread, soda and acid for rising were added to the flour. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,174) [NOTES: Writing of 1940]

rising main¶

n.

McARA Rising main: The pump discharge pipe mounted in the shaft. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),331)

Risso's dolphin¶

n. Grampus griseus

Risso's dolphin (Grampus griseus) is the first of the dolphin family to be mentioned. (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/137) [NOTES: (Oliver)]

rito¶

n. growing shoot

Earlier, Ngarimu had sung a karakia and shown me how to cut tussock so that the rito, or growing shoot, wasn't severed. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/40)

POLACK The erect erito [e-acute], and other umbelliferous palm-[68]trees wave their broad leaves proudly amid the varied foliage of the surrounding trees. Ibid. 1/105 There is scarcely a more splendid sight to behold than a New Zealand forest. In the one we now entered, we did not perceive any kouri, or yellow pine-trees; but the totara [a's-acute], or red pine, grew in vast abundance. ... The rito, and innumerable other palm-trees, were in great quantity. Ibid. 1/143 In addition to the fare set before me at supper, a quantity of rito, or hearts of the palm-tree, were also included. This vegetable, which is eaten uncooked, makes a salad unequalled for its excellent flavour, and is held in much esteem by the people. Ibid. 1/287 rito The heart of the delicious palms, called E' Rito, is highly esteemed. The korou, which the branches of another of these umbelliferous trees afford is equally prized, together with the saccharine roots of the ti, cabbage-tree. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/67)

river¶

n. ?mainly Auckland cf CREEK [[see also ?Eaddy GRAVEYARD (?Kaipara)] -->R. Mason notes: in Auckland Province narrow harbours or arms of harbours, mostly on the west coast are often called rivers, and were so named on older maps and in writings. They are in fact formed by the drowning of river systems. [nf in this sense OED, EDD, W3] -->On old maps: The Whangape River, The Herekino River, The Hokianga River; on present-day maps, The Waiuku River. At the present time [1957] the local inhabitants refer to the Hokianga Harbour as the river', as do the people of Herekino to the Herekino harbour. Jane mander's novel The Story of a New Zealand River refers to the Kaipara harbour, I understand. Various arms of kaipara and Hokianga are still namedrivers' on present maps. In Waitemata Harbour, the Whau River; and other branches also rivers.]

KING `1823. May 3rd. - The Rev. J. Butler came and informed us of the wreck of the American schooner Cossack at Shokeehanga (Hokianga) River. (May 3, 1823,Diary) [NOTES: 1823 May 3 John King in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 255]

[]sound, inlet Captain Steine discovered another large river near the entrance of the river William The Fourth, which he named Queen Adelaide River. [McNab comments, p21: The term river was, at that time, applied to what we would now designate a sound, [William IV River] was Tory Channel] (Sep 14, 1832,Log) [NOTES: 1832 Sep 14 Capt. Steine in Courier (Hobart Town) in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 20]

POLACK A river in New Zealand, from twenty to forty miles in length in a direct course, often flows in serpentine directions nearly three times that length; the salt-water rivers are joined at their entrances by fresh-water creeks, many of which pursue routes inland, through perhaps eighty miles of country. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/169 fn)

HOCHSTETTER ... in the vicinity of the Hokianga river of the West Coast. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),143)

SENIOR She [sc a tug] had come down the Kawa Kawa (called a river, but really an arm of the sea, like the Paramatta) from the railway ... (1880,Travel & Trout,174)

HAY ... naturally they cannot know that what with our [sc. North Auckland's] tidal rivers and freshwater creeks, ... we really want no roads ... (1882,Brighter Britain,2/233)

The usual name for the inlet [on Dunedin harbour] appears to have been `The River' [?c1817]. (1895,TrNZI,28/141)

... the Wairiri Creek - a tributary of the Hokianga River. (1905,TrNZI,37/351) [NOTES: Walsh]

BEATTIE ... European families had by this time either returned to Sydney or shifted over to `Otago' (the district around the Otago Harbour, or Otago River as the whalers called it). (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,38)

KING Most of Whina's earliest memories are of `the river', [38] as they always called the [Hokianga] harbour. (1983,Whina,37)

2 n. as in general English: but in early uses (a) note that the epithet freshwater is often prefixed; and (b) note the contrasting British usage (and possibly Australian), e.g. the River Thames, the River Murray, with NZ, the Thames River

HAY Kaipara, a fine basin about eight miles across, having five considerable rivers running into it ... (1832,Notices of NZ,10,1979 ed.)

sc a freshwater river On the East side is a small fresh water river. (1835,Boultbee Journal,54,1986 ed.)

2 n.

... close to the River Pots. (1874,TrNZI,6/148) [NOTES: (Potts)]

River Avon (1883,TrNZI,15/151) [NOTES: (Chilton)]

River Waimakariri River Hawdon (1906,TrNZI,33/266) [NOTES: (Cockayne)]

... the River Hutt (1902,TrNZI,34/99) [NOTES: Hocken]

The River Maruia could be followed south. (1907,TrNZI,39/396) [NOTES: (Townson)]

River Turakina [This seems to be Cockayne's standard style for the TrNZI.] ibid. River Rangitikei p.400 (1908,TrNZI,41/399) [NOTES: (Cockayne)]

FRAME When I had returned to New Zealand and wrote The Adaptable Man set in Suffolk, a sharp-eyed critic noted my inaccurate reference to the Orwell River instead of the correct, River Orwell, my usage being the New Zealand [154] idiom - the Rakaia River, the Waitaki River, the Clutha River - and not the English - River Thames, Humber, Orwell. - (1985,Envoy from Mirror City,153)

river beach¶

n. [aka river-beach]

BEAUTIFULLY SITUATED ALLOTMENTS ON The River Tamaki, in Panmure. .. 59, a beautiful lot, running down to the river beach 1r. 37p. (Apr 10, 1855,Daily Southern Cross,2)

The gold-bearing nature of the country is undoubted, but so many people were so anxious to become rich that where gravel could be found on the river beaches, a dredge was plumped down straight off, without testing the ground in any way. (Sep 18, 1901,Southland Times,3)

The sands of the river beaches were literally golden like the famous goldfields of the Klondike. (Dec 12, 1925,NZ Truth,8)

On the other hand the 40 or 50 miners engaged working the river beaches of the Callery will dread every shower, especially if it is inclined to be warm, fearing lest a flood should come down and sweep away all their labor, including some weeks of preparatory work. (Jun 19, 1899,West Coast Times,2)

Sole Lessee of Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 Hutt River Beaches. (May 1, 1915,Evening Post,15)

A good many Chinamen are working on the river beaches. (Jun 26, 1889,Tuapeka Times,3)

The fortunate prospector was Mr. Thomas Arthur, who ... obtained 200oz. of gold in eight days, by washing the sands of the river-beach. (1887,Handbook NZ Mines,10) [NOTES: 1863 V. Pyke's Report in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 10]

river bed¶

n. [see DNZE; aka river-bed]

The Takaka, though a rapid torrent in the upper part of the valley, is soon altogether lost, by its entering subterranean channels, and we walked along the dry river-bed for several miles, without meeting with the slightest appearance of moisture. (Jan 13, 1844,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,385)

In this dry river bed they commenced working on Saturday, with good expectations of success during the summer. (Dec 15, 1852,New Zealander, The,2)

Some time ago I had a look over a property, the owner of which had reclaimed a considerable area of shingle river bed and turned it into land of first-class quality. (Apr 24, 1907,Otago Witness,8)

R. J. Brown, Pukemaori, applied for a grazing right for the chain road along the old river bed. (Oct 20, 1931,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3)

The Rocky River, Snow's rush, and the Kaituna diggings, have each of them a few parties, who are going on steadily; a larger population is all that is required to develop their riches; they have, in addition to the richness of their river beds, got large flats on their banks, which at no distant date will be the resort of capitalists, the work required to bring them into a producing state being above the means of any ordinary party of diggers. (Mar 17, 1860,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

An application was received from Edward Pain for an occupation license of an island in the Inangahua river bed. (Sep 16, 1886,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

This should convince the most sceptical that the rivers by their actions distribute the gold, which is retained in the rocky crevices on the river bed. (Dec 12, 1925,NZ Truth,8)

River Board¶

n.

The Wairarapa Standard states that the deputation appointed by the Greytown Trustees to wait upon the Provincial Secretary with reference to a Town and River Board, had an interview with him at Featherston on Saturday last. (Jan 9, 1873,Evening Post,2)

McLINTOCK A considerable superstructure of other bodies has gradually come into being - river boards, catchment boards, milk boards, rabbit boards, and the like. (1959,Descriptive Atlas,76)

In every river district there shall be a River Board. Ibid. 235 All rivers, streams, and water courses within any river district constituted under this Act shall.. be to all intents and purposes within and subject to the. jurisdiction of the Board. (1894,NZ Statutes,48 Vict. 49/227)

PUBLIC NOTICE is hereby given that the Opio River Board intends on Wednesday, 7th March, 1923, to make, pursuant to Section 87 of "The River Boards Act, 1908," and of amendments thereof, and Sections 48 and 50 of "The Rating Act, 1908," and its amendments - A GENERAL RATE OF 7/8d in the GBP in Grade One .. on the Rateable Value of all lands within the Opio River District for the year commencing on 1st April, 1922, and ending on 31st March, 1923, and payable in one sum of 14th March, 1923. (Feb 13, 1923,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,2)

PUBLIC NOTICE is hereby given that the Opio River Board intends on Wednesday, 7th March, 1923, to make, pursuant to Section 87 of "The River Boards Act, 1908," and of amendments thereof, and Sections 48 and 50 of "The Rating Act, 1908," and its amendments - A GENERAL RATE OF 7/8d in the GBP in Grade One .. on the Rateable Value of all lands within the Opio River District for the year commencing on 1st April, 1922, and ending on 31st March, 1923, and payable in one sum of 14th March, 1923. (Feb 13, 1923,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,2)

At a meeting of the Kahautara River Board, held to-day, the following resolution was passed:- "That this board respectfully urge the Government not to pass the retrospective legislation as regards river boards, as proposed by Mr. Buchanan, M. P." (Oct 11, 1910,Evening Post,7)

A resolution was passed unanimously - "That the Government be asked to pass an Act forming a central River Board, comprising and amalgamating the existing River Boards Districts, the districts to be divided into wards of as nearly as possible equal rating value, each ward returning one member or more, the rating basis to be the same as now existing, with power to obtain loans." (Aug 10, 1905,Evening Post,7)

THE Ratepayers of the Spring Creek District are hereby requested to await the Meeting at Marlboroughtown on the 20th inst., when it is intended to discuss the attempt at enforced amalgamation, now insidiously carried on by some members of the "Lower Wairau River Board," and that in the meantime they be not cajoled into sig[n]ing any petition whatever, hawked about by their emissaries. (Mar 9, 1895,Marlborough Express,3)

All work will close down on the Hawke's Bay River Board's diversion and flood control scheme. (Mar 16, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,18)

river bugging¶

n.

River bugging is a blast. It's the latest revolution in river rafting - the modern version of going down streams on an old inner tube. (Nov 29, 1999,Evening Post,19)

River City¶

n. a name for Wanganui

[He] was later editor of the Wanganui Chronicle and the defunct Wanganui Herald, spending 14 years in the river city. (Aug 5, 1999,Evening Post,5)

What though of the city that straddles the river - the one with the coat of arms depicting a rampant lion and tuatara.., the one with the terrible slogan "Wanganui - Well Worth the Journey", the old garrison town, the one with street names such as Somme Parade, the "River City", the Wanganui without an h? (Dec 14, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

river claim¶

n. [goldmining]

The Hibernian (a river claim) will commence paddocking in a few days, and they deserve to be well remunerated for the energy and pluck they have displayed for the last three years in all weathers, and under the most trying circumstances. (Apr 28, 1877,Otago Witness,4)

The following applications were granted .. James Cowan and others, protection for three months for the river claim on the Molyneux River, Beaumont ... (Feb 25, 1888,Tuapeka Times,3)

The following applications were dealt with on May 23rd .. E. J. Craighead, Extended river claim. (May 25, 1912,Grey River Argus,1)

They also applied for Certificate of protection of special dredging claim No 2031, extended river claim No 2044, and special river claim 2073. (Aug 17, 1926,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,2)

In the case, Adams v Pringle and others, an appeal from the Warden's decision over a piece of spare ground between the Golden Run Co's and respondent's river claims at Millers Flat, his Honor upheld the Warden's decision, with costs (GBP10 16s). (Sep 27, 1893,Tuapeka Times,5)

At the Warden's Court, Queenstown, on the 11th inst., before Mr. F. Burgess, warden, Jas. M'Mullan, jun., made application for a special river claim of 20 acres, situated at Arthur's Point, one mile below the bridge. (Aug 19, 1903,Otago Witness,23)

Dunstan, 13th June, - ... At the Kawarau ... all the river claims are submerged, the paddocks and tunnels in the banks are mostly fallen in ... Arrow Township, 10th July. - ... Huts, tents, wheels, sluice-boxes - everything on the beach and river claims have been swept off by the torrent, ... (Jul 18, 1863,Otago Witness,7)

river crosser¶

n.

HAAST The man I refer to is a first rate traveller, a keen river crosser, and in every other respect a good bushman, but he is giddy ... and this would be a very great drawback to passing round the coast. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,48)

river crow¶

n. shag, white-throated

BULLER .. not the least interesting feature to me [by the Huka Falls] was this, that a dozen or more of these little [White-throated] Shags (or `River Crows' as they are sometimes called) kept passing and repassing through the misty spray. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/171,1873 ed.)

river diggings¶

n. [cf WET DIGGINGS; cp DRY DIGGINGS; for citation see dry diggings 1864]

The Honourable The Colonial Secretary, &c., &c., &c. Kapanga River Diggings, Coromandel Harbour, 4th November, 1852. (Dec 15, 1852,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,2)

Various tracks to the outlying districts were then discussed, the principal of which was that through Waikaia bush to Whitcomb and Upper Waikaia river diggings. (Mar 28, 1873,Bruce Herald,6)

All the sections offered in Cromarty, the township near Wilson's river diggings, were sold, but there are complaints of want of publicity of the sales, many who would have been buyers not knowing it was to take place. (Dec 17, 1892,Timaru Herald,2)

river flat¶

n. (Rural) [used elsewhere, but widely used and significant in New Zealand's horticulture, agriculture, pastoralism, and viticulture] a level area of land formed from the course of a river.

Every Person desirous of establishing a claim to a particular portion of unoccupied ground, by working, in the ordinary method, for Alluvial Gold, may have his claim marked out on the following scale, viz., not less than .. (4) 20 feet square of table-land, or river flats. (Nov 27, 1852,New Zealander, The,3)

It was persisted in with blind prejudice, that the interior would never support more than a handful of back settlers, who might possibly be able to eke out a scanty living by dint of running a few head of cattle here and there over a few grassy patches of river flat. (Nov 20, 1866,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

The country is of various descriptions .. with some river-flats. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,233)

On Messrs Donald Bros' farm, close to Masterton, on a river flat, they have just threshed a crop of oats. (Mar 1907,NZ Farmer,234)
