NEWTON The country above the lake, with its miles of beach, great carpet-grass basins and heavy river-flats, is ideal country for deer. (1952,High Country Journey,169)

WATERS It split along the top ... and rushed across the riverflat towards Charlie Morel's house. (1976,Mostly a Farmer,97)

OGONOWSKA-COATES ... sheep sometimes went wild, wandering the back country and straggling up the river flats. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,11)

Some river flats in front rising to medium hill with some steep faces. (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,77)

STACEY As we walked down the Acheron, sheep ran down the Acheron face to join others stringing down the river flats. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,67)

It gets quite warm on the river flats and gullies and we get a lot of early morning fog. (Mar 29, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17)

Te Makahi has about 72 ha of fertile river flats suitable for orchards and 161 ha of clean, steep grazable hills. [riverflat; river-flat] (Apr 12, 2002,NZ Farmer,40)

200 acres good land, river flats, near butter factory, GBP1400. (Apr 24, 1903,Bay of Plenty Times,3)

Block IV.: Sections 1, 2, 3, 4, undulating fern, tutu, and grass hills, excellent soil on river flats. (Mar 27, 1880,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

McClymont Thomson, who was a firm believer in the rights of explorers, saw to it that the maps showed the names they gave : Ben Nevis, Nevis river, Lochy river, Roy river and the Devil's Staircase. Ibid. 80 Every creek and every river-flat was prospected. (1959,Exploration of NZ, The,75)

4612 acres of fine Pastoral Country, comprising low undulating hills and river flats, a very large portion of which are ploughable: also 197 acres of leasehold (Gordon's Valley) held on perpetual lease. (Sep 3, 1897,Colonist (Nelson),3)

Despite this, surface water will always be rather slow in disappearing as the whole area is composed of river flat rich soil on a solid clay bottom, which does not draw off the water as quickly as if it were sandy or gravelly. (Aug 11, 1931,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,2)

HAAST Our road lay now ... across a grassy flat, mostly overgrown with the same dense vegetation met with on the banks of all our river-flats, namely the spiny Wild-Irishman, and the bayonet-like Spaniard (Aciphylla Lyallii). (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,124)

The whole valley of the Wangapeka consists of a narrow gorge, with here and there a small river-flat (1879,TrNZI,442)

MANDER It was in his first month, as he passed a river flat one day, that he saw a young man begin the cutting of a sledge track ... (1925,Allen Adair,15,1971 ed.)

DICK The winter months had been long and grim, and had left their marks on mountains, river flats, cattle, sheep, dogs and men. (1964,High Country Family,11)

river flounder¶

n. = black flounder

The Black or River Flounder of New Zealand (Rhombosolea retiaria). The river-flounder is one of the common edible fishes of Wellington. Though not so common as either the yellow or sand flounder, it is much in demand as the chief delicacy among all species of flat fish eaten by the New Zealand public. (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/368) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

Rhombosolea retiaria Hutton. River flounder (black flounder). (1938,TrRSNZ,68/408) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM River or Black Flounder Rhombosolea (Adamasoma) retiaria Hutton (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,405) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 405]

WILLIAMS Patiki mohao, Rhombosolea retiara, river or black flounder. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,271)

MORELAND BLACK FLOUNDER [Rhombosolea retiaria] ... River flounder and mud flounder are widely used alternative names. (1967,Marine Fishes,32)

GRAHAM NEW ZEALAND BLACK FLOUNDER or RIVER FLOUNDER (PATIKI-MOHOAO) Rhombosolea (Adamsoma) retiaria adams Whitley and Phillipps/ It is known to fishermen and those in the fishing industry as the River Flounder as it is caught mostly inside or near the mouths of rivers and enters lakes where it lives chiefly among weeds. To some it is known as the Maori Flounder. I have helped to catch these fish in various rivers in New Zealand, Both in the North and South Islands, from the Bay of Islands, Bay of Plenty, Canterbury and Otago. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,204,2nd ed.)

DOOGUE & MORELAND BLACK FLOUNDER ... Other names: Rhombosolea retiaria; mud flounder, river flounder, estuary flonder; patiki-mahoao (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,215)

WILSON FLOUNDER, BLACK More sole-like in shape than his cousin flounders this fellow also has small, brick-red spots on his back and has the ability - unlike the other flatfish - of being able to live in pure, fresh water. Other names are River Flounder' andMud or Freshwater Flounder'. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,72)

[species name] black flounder .. [scientific name] Rhombosolea retiaria .. [other name(s)] blacks, freshwater flounder, river flounder (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

Black flounder Rhombosolea retiaria Restricted to New Zealand. Alternative names include river flounder, freshwater flounder, or estuary flounder, derived from its habitat. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,144)

PHILLIPPS RHOMBOSOLEA RETIARIA Hutton. Black Flounder; Patiki-mohoao. This species, known generally as `river-flounder,' is occasionally taken in the sea. Common in the estuaries of most large rivers, and often taken many miles inland. (Jul 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,IV/122) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Rhombosolea retiaria Hutton. RIVER-FLOUNDER, BLACK FLOUNDER; PATIKI-MOHOAO. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,29,1971 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] flounder, river 2287-90 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

river gang¶

1 n. (Rural) a mustering team working in Marlborough and North Canterbury.

NEWTON A musterer might state that he is in the River Gang and that again is sufficient. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,50)

NEWTON Blairich is one of the stations that used to get the 'River Gang' to do its mustering .. like the Flying Gang in the Hanmer Spring district they did just the actual mustering, moving on from place to place as the hill work was completed. They covered a tremendous amount of country, all hard going, and the River Gang was widely known. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,52)

river gurnard¶

n. Leptoscopus macropygus, stargazer.

DOOGUE & MORELAND STARGAZER ... Other names: Leptoscopus macropygus; river gurnard, mud gurnard, flat-head gurnard, mud grubber. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,262)

WILSON Most gurnards are brownish-red but larger specimens are often bright red on top and white below. The Stargazer is sometimes known as the Mud Gurnad, River Gurnard or Mud-Grubber Gurnard but is in fact no relation. Similarly the Sea Perch is sometimes called a Rock Gurnard - .. . Ibid. 197 RIVER GURNARD: see Spotted Stargazer Ibid. 208 STARGAZER A distinctive estaurine fish which spends most of its life buried in mud up to the eyes. ... Comes in two varieties - the Common Stargazer and his tubbier cousin the Spotted Stargazer. ... Other names are River Gurnard, Mud Gurnard, Flathead Gurnard and Mud Grubber (1981,Fisherman's Bible,118)

PAUL Stargazer Leptoscopus macropygus Also occurs in south-eastern Australia. Alternatively called estuary stargazer, and mud, river, or flathead gurnard. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,119)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] gurnard, river 1814 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

river lamprey¶

n.

SPEIGHT et al. There are three stages in the life history of the river-lamprey ( Geotria australis) which is known from practically all the Canterbury rivers. (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,191) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury]

river mullet¶

n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] mullet, river 1653 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

river paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a fenced piece of land through which a river flows.

The third paddock going into grass (a river paddock close to the house) includes four distinct soil types. (Apr 13, 1955,Weekly News,35)

river river¶

n. (See rewarewa)

river snot¶

n. (See rock snot)

[heading] 'River snot' noses its way northward AN INVASIVE water weed, commonly known as "rock snot", has been found in the Buller River. (Sep 29, 2005,Dominion Post,A14)

river work¶

n. (Rural) a crossing and recrossing of rivers in mustering or droving sheep.

NEWTON The station carries between 600 and 700 head of cattle (300 breeding cows) and with stock running right to the very headworks, there is a lot of river work. (1952,High Country Journey,173)

I had most of the river work to do as of my two mates, one was an old Gentleman ... the other a better stockman than myself provided there be no water in the question. (Nov 10, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,204,1950 ed.)

river-horse¶

n.

BUTLER He is a good river-horse, and very strong. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,iii/32) [NOTES: 1860 Jan 27 in 1863 Butler First Year iii/32]

1 n. (Rural) [high country] a horse used to cross fast-flowing mountain rivers, often as a pack-horse or harness-horse.

He is a good river-horse and very strong. (1860,BLANK ENTRY,32) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

PORTER Darky lived to a ripe old age and was a wonderful river-horse. (1970,Under the Nor'West Arch,113)

river-tripper¶

n.

Her kauri hull and 103-year-old engine have been lovingly restored by Peter Thompson (no relation to Charlie); and the boiler and engine have been left exposed so river-trippers can watch the metronomic whirl and tick as metal levers and cogs move greasily against each other. (Feb 2005,North & South,114)

river-wash¶

n. [(? goldmining)]

  1. River-bed Gravels and Sands. - These occupy the beds of the Clutha and Kawarau Rivers. ...Throughout the Dunstan and Kawarau Gorges these Gravels, commonly spoken of as river-wash, rest on the schist bottom. ... The only practicable method of winning gold lying at the bottom of this river-wash is dredging. (1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No5 (N.S.)/46) [NOTES: (Park: Cromwell)]

river-washing¶

1 n. (Rural) the washing of fleecewool on sheep's backs by dipping sheep in river pools.

The spout-washers admitted losses of one per cent, the river-washing lost half per cent. (Aug 20, 1864,Weekly News,8)

Let us hope to see this system pursued and extended year by year until river washing and greasy clips will be the exception, and not the rule as it is now. (Apr 9, 1869,North Otago Times,5)

river-weed¶

n. Elodea canadensis. [n (Canterbury spec.)]

(1917,TrNZI,49/286) [NOTES: OED various weeds naturally growing in rivers 2. US An aquatic plant. (Herriott)]

river-working¶

n.

Whilst at the Dunstan I for the first time heard of Fox's Rush, and the Shotover River workings; and as I was on the direct route to those localities I resolved to proceed thither for the purpose of ascertaining the true state of affairs. (Dec 27, 1862,Otago Witness,2)

The river Molyneux still continues high, and river workings are therefore at a standstill; but with the numerous rushes in the neighbourhood there is no lack of employment for the mining population. (Nov 25, 1862,Wellington Independent,3)

Quartz-mining, especially at Macetown and Skipper's Point and neighbourhood, will receive an impetus; river workings, both by dredging and the hydraulic jet processes, will be started in the Shotover and the Kawarau rivers ... (Sep 7, 1888,Otago Witness,12)

Besides the drawbacks mentioned it must not be overlooked that the season was a most unfavourable one for river workings of any kind. (Nov 12, 1901,Southland Times,2)

The road here follows the eastern bank of the creek, and, in addition to the river workings, water races and dams (of which there are several at this spot), a few houses, huts, and gardens, can be seen dotted here and there, filling up and making altogether a very pleasant and agreeable picture. (Feb 5, 1870,Otago Witness,9)

At the Lower Wilson a few parties have been earning small wages in terrace workings in wet weather and river workings in dry. (Mar 15, 1894,Otago Witness,12)

Before the close of the year 1862, 70,000oz.were transmitted by escort from the Dunstan Goldfield; but this was not all derived from the river-workings. (1887,Handbook NZ Mines,8) [NOTES: 1863 V. Pyke's Report in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 8]

Riverbed Mould¶

n. variant of Riverhead Gold q.v.

Matches, ashtray, packet of Riverbed Mould handy? (Dec 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,41)

IRELAND 'Does she smoke Riverbed Mould?' Alan asked, and when I said I'd never heard of that tobacco, he told me that was what all 'real smokers' like himself called Riverbed Gold, which was named after a famous racehorse and had a drawing of the horse next to the label. (1998,Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,91)

Riverhead Gold¶

n. a brand of tobacco

GIBBONS The National Tobacco Company at Port Ahuriri turned out what was called toasted tobacco, Riverhead Gold and Cut Plug No. 10. (1988,Recollections (various authors/titles),38)

riwai¶

n. a potato

Their names have been unchanged, as they are still the same in other islands, whereas the potatoe [sic] is known by different names, as taiwa, riwai, &c., in different districts. (Jul 3, 1847,New Zealander, The,3)

Riwai mau would be potatoes for you to eat; riwai mou, potatoes to be eaten with your flesh, - an offensive curse. (Apr 12, 1851,New Zealander, The,3)

Then, I'd roll out my threadbare Whaariki/ - to help you remember to take your boots/ off - spread an old newspaper on the floor/ and on it place a steaming pot of puha,/ kamo-kamo, riwai, brisket-on-the-bone and/ dumplings what we call: doughboys. (Sep 7, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12) [NOTES: (Hone Tuwhare)]

BAXTER To others my love is a plaited kono / Full or empty, with chunks of riwai. (1972,Collected Poems,537)

HOCHSTETTER The "men" of one party were represented by small potatoes cut in two, called Riwai; those of the other by peachkernels, called Pititi. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),298)

Maori, all t'at pomme-de-terre, t'at riwai, t'at spud, for you. (1917,New Zealand At the Front,163)

SHORTLAND MAHETAU, a potato. Syn. riwai; besides which a variety of other words are used to denote their different kinds. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,309)

REWAI. - Potato. Ibid. 163 `Maori, all t'at pomme-de-terre, t'at riwai, t'at spud, for you.' (1917,New Zealand At the Front,(Glossary) xiv)

REISCHEK First of all, quantities of provisions were brought to the place, kumara, taro, hire, and rewai, birds preserved in oil, . (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,148,1933 ed.)

HENDERSON We're not going to eat dirt like this,' said Jance.Who peeled the riwai today?' (1948,Taina,167)

FINLAYSON There on the river flats were our crops of corn and kumara and riwai that we kids had to hoe. And here and there you see the nikau thatch roofs of our maize cribs. (1966,Brown Man's Burden,120,1973 ed.)

141 riwai: potato. (1973,Brown Man's Burden) [NOTES: (Pearson's Glossary)]

BAXTER To others my love is a plaited kono/ Full or empty,/ With chunks of riwai,/ Meat that stuck to the stones. (1979,Collected Poems,537,1972 ed.)

ADCOCK riwai potato (1982,Contemporary NZ Poetry,143)

BAXTER riwa potato (1982,Selected Poems,189)

2 n. a potato

She actually had to argue with a young Maori offender who sincerely believed that to be a Maori was to be automatically dumber; that to succeed even, in our society, it is necessary to neglect or even forget taha Maori. To become a riwai, a potato, dark outside, white inside. (Sep 28, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

I have been publicly called a riwai (potato), as in brown on the outside, white on the inside. (Sep 23, 2003,BLANK ENTRY,B4)

Bernard Gadd She calls me her riwai - her potato. You get the idea? Brown on the outside, white and hard and cold on the inside. (1981,Where to Go?,15)

riwena¶

n. (See rewena)

riwi¶

n.

One kit contained riwi of different varieties. (1924,Kai Tiaki,XVII/34)

riwiri¶

n. (See rauwiri)

RMA¶

abbr. Resource Management Act

But trying to sort anything out under the RMA is like trying to pass a kidney stone. (Apr 24, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

Although I like the emphasis that the resources Management Act places on local decision-making, I am acutely aware that such local decision making can cause considerable angst in communities throughout the country. The RMA has become a sophisticated tool, more used by lawyers and planners than by the community it was intended to serve. (Jan 13, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

The RMA enshrines preservation of the natural coastal environment, access to the coastline and the protection of outstanding landscapes as matters of national importance. (Jul 20, 2002,Weekend Herald,B6)

Asked about the Resource Management Act, she added Delphically: "We need the RMA to ensure that the knowledge we have is clean and green." (Aug 2, 2001,Dominion,2)

Changes to the proposed streamlined Resource Management Act (RMA) have saved ratepayers a bill of more than $100 million. (Aug 19, 2009,Press, The)

The Resource Management Act (RMA) is truly Byzantine... Ibid. 30 The RMA seeks a balance between private or business enterprise and the public interest. (Jul 7, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

RMFO¶

abbr. Regional Fisheries Management Organisation [ORIGIN: acronym]

These international bodies are called Regional Fisheries Management Organisations - RFMOs, .. We will build on this experience gained in other RFMOs around the world and adopt best practice. (Feb 14, 2006,Dominion Post,B5)

RMS¶

abbr. Refugee and Migrant Service

About 6o refugees will be coming to live in Wellington in December and the Refugee and Migrant Service is gearing up for the influx... RMS is calling for donations of household goods to furnish the refugees' new homes. (Nov 11, 2004,Wellingtonian,2)

RNZ¶

abbr. Radio New Zealand [in NZPOD 1e etc.]

RNZAF¶

abbr. Royal New Zealand Air Force

(1944,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),454)

R.N.Z.A.F. abbrev. for Royal New Zealand Air Force. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,996) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 659; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 421]]

RNZN¶

abbr. Royal New Zealand Navy

R.N.Z.N. abbrev. for Royal New Zealand Navy. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,996) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 659; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 421]]

ro¶

n. stick-insect (Acanthoderus horridus and other sp.)

ANDERSON ro[o], stick-insect (Acanthoderus horridus and other sp.), green or brown in colouring, thorned or foliated and twenty or more varieties. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157)

roa¶

n. (South Island) the great spotted kiwi. [ORIGIN: Maori]

The most notable of these [endemic birds] were kakapo (introduced in 1903), roa or great-spotted kiwi (1915) and tieke (1925). (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/23)

A fourth species of kiwi had been discovered... Till now scientists had recognised three species - the great spotted kiwi or roa in the northwest of the South Island, the little spotted kiwi on Kapiti and a few other islands, and the brown kiwi, scattered from Northland to Stewart Island. (Apr 23, 1993,Dominion,3)

Nine adult great spotted kiwi (roa) were released into the Rotoiti Nature Recovery Project area in which intensive pest control is creating a 5000-hectare protected zone for native species. (Jul 2004,Conservation Action,12)

von HAAST It was the same call as that of the Roa, but much louder and deeper ... (1948,Julius Von Haast,226) [NOTES: 1862 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 226]

CAPLES Near the mouth of the Middle Fiord [of Te Anau], they picked up a stone tomahawk and shot a native emu'. The bird is described as beingcurious among the feathered tribe, having neither wings nor tail'. Caples goes on to say that Other night-loving birds, such as the keewee and green-bird promenaded around our camp all night.' ... [104] However I favour the conclusion that theirnative emu' was the large type of kiwi (roa). (1863,Diary) [NOTES: 1863 P.Q.Caples Diary in 1968 Hall-Jones Early Fiordland 103-104]

  1. Apteryx australis. Roa. South Island Kiwi. (1884,TrNZI,17/191) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

Kakapos, kiwis, and roas, are plentiful on the south side of the river, and there are plenty of penguins on the north-east side of it. (1884,TrNZI,17/485) [NOTES: (Sutherland)]

HARPER While camping on the shore of this lake [Maporika], I heard the cry of the rua, or large brown kiwi, now nearly extinct and very valuable; ... (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,68) [NOTES: (West Coast)]

Roa, n. another Maori name for the largest or Brown Kiwi ... In Maori the word roa means long or big. (1898,Austral English,390)

Another remarkable flightless bird ... is the member of the Apteryx family commonly called by naturalists the roa'. The Maoris say that the proper name of this bird is the `tokoweka'. (1906,TrNZI,38/338)

Apteryx haasti Potts. Great Grey Kiwi; Roa. Judging from the scanty reports, this is still the rarest of the three species of Apteryx. Mr. R. S. Sutherland gives one South Island locality where it may be occasionally seen. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/82) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

roa, roaroa, a bird (Apterxy haastii), large grey kiwi: South Island kiwi. (Jun 1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: (J.C.Andersen)]

POWELL LARGE GREY KIWI (Apteryx haastii), Roa of the Maoris, is almost as large as australis, but is greyist brown, mottled and cross banded with brownish black. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,76)

DEMPSEY At nights, the others ... heard the distant call of a kiwi, `roa' the big Stewart Island kiwi is called, but we saw no trace of the bird. (1964,Little World of Stewart island,74)

~ n. the largest kiwi, brown in color [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

  1. Apteryx haastii Potts, 1872 Great Spotted Kiwi (Roa) South Island, chiefly west of the divide ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,15,1980 ed.)

Great Spotted Kiwi Apteryx haastii POTTS, 1872 ... OTHER NAMES: Roa, large grey kiwi. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,39)

n.

For less talk and more sense we might begin with the far south of this country, where fishermen see themselves as Stewart Islanders - not roa or tokoeka! (Oct 25, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of tall fescue. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Kara cocksfoot may have an advantage sown as a mixture with either maru or roa. (Sep 1985,NZ Dairy Exporter,30)

Cows on the grassgrub-tolerant species, roa tall fescue and maru phalaris milked-on for a further fortnight. (1985,NZ Dairy Exporter,70)

The principal advantages of Roa over ryegrass are its slightly earlier spring growth, its markedly greater vegetative growth over summer and the fact that it allows a greater clover component in a sward. (Apr 1987,NZ Journal of Agriculture,33)

Roa is more persistent than perennial ryegrass over periods of summer drought. (Mar 20, 1991,NZ Farmer,3)

road¶

v. (transitive) also road out: to freight by road

n. a log-way [(kauri bushmen's) ca 1951 R Gilberd (Okaihau) Letter an old name for logway.]

LAING & BLACKWELL If far from water, the carriage [of kauri logs] is more difficult. A skidded road, six to eight feet wide, is formed of greased logs. Thus a sort of rough wooden tramway is made. The logs are hoisted onto this road by means of `jacks', or dragged by a team of bullocks. (1906,Plants of NZ,64,1940 ed.)

MEAD .. a few possibly misleading terms [have been] varied, as for instance [Taylor's] use of `road' indiscriminately for bush trail, bridle track, or formed vehicular road. (1966,Richard Taylor,10)

Road Board¶

n.

.. they had a Road Board composed of Messrs. M'Glashan, Proudfoot, and Reynolds. (Apr 26, 1856,Otago Witness,2)

WAIAREKA ROAD BOARD. A meeting of this Board took place in the Road Board office, Tyne-street, on the 28th May. (Jun 3, 1873,North Otago Times,4)

[WICKHAM] Another remedy that might be tried with advantage is the abolition of the County Councils and Road Boards. (1897,Casual Ramblings,11)

Nominations closed at noon to-day for the election of members to several of the district road boards. (Apr 28, 1909,Wanganui Herald,7)

Later he became a contractor and many a mile of road in the Selwyn County and under the Rakaia Road Board was constructed under his supervision. (Jul 2, 1929,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3)

In the local governing body, which began as a road board and developed into a borough council, Knox was always prominent. (Feb 6, 1904,NZ Observer,4)

In a month or two there will be no Remuera Road Board - but there will be a City Council. (Apr 19, 1913,NZ Observer,5)

The New Zealand Nurses' Memorial Fund has not been forgotten in the holiday season as evidenced by the following subscriptions .. Upper Wangaehu Road Board GBP10. (Jan 1918,Kai Tiaki,19)

The Road Board question is beginning to assume very serious dimensions in the County of Wairarapa East. (Dec 9, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

When a member of the Road Board is voted to the chair, does he remain chairman for a year, or for three years? (Jul 23, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,15)

Acland came home in the evening having had to attend a Road Board at Shanks when, like other road boards they squashed all their own actions of the last four months. (May 14, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,132,1950 ed.)

road bongo¶

n.

Life on the road lends itself naturally to hysteria - put eight people in a minibus for a day and eventually the giggling takes over. Rock groups on tour call it "road bongo". (Sep 21, 1996,Sunday Star Times,A5)

Road Code¶

n.

RICHARDS Road code, drivers' licences and warrants of fitness were unheard of in those days. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,80)

Road Code NZ set of rules issued officially for guidance of road-users. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,659) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

road end hut¶

n. a tramping hut located near to the end of an access road.

Oriwa Biv is in a remote location where DOC does not maintain tracks, and Mt Dagg is a low-use road end hut. (Dec 2004,Footnotes,22/1)

road gang¶

n. a road-workers' team

A long time ago, going from here to there, we would come across a "road gang". Some would be shovelling, some working tractors and some leaning on shovels. (May 17, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

Road Knights¶

n. a mostly Pakeha bikie gang

Behind one set of palisades are the Devil's Henchmen. Inside the other are the Road Knights. Both are motor-cycle gangs, mainly Pakeha. (May 11, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

road line¶

n. (Rural) a line cut through bushland or remote areas, to indicate a road to be laid. [aka road-line]

The next stage is that of the road-line being ditched on the sides, the stuff thrown upon it, and bridges erected where necessary by post and plank. (Apr 19, 1851,Otago Witness,2)

It is rumored - but we can't vouch for the accuracy of it - that as soon as road lines are cut through the bush country the land will be thrown open for free selection as was done in Canterbury ... (Oct 6, 1880,Hawera Star,2)

The two farms, with only a roadline between them, form a compact, easily-wrought and highly productive estate. (1910,Tapanui Station,50)

GUTHRIE-SMITH With the discovery of a road-line striking directly inland from the coast, a new era dawned for pedestrian weeds. [road line; road-line] (1921,Tutira,286)

ALL that parcel of land containing by admeasurement 1 acre and 7 perches, situated in the Parish of Tuhikaramea, in the Newcastle Highway District, and being a road-line traversing Allotment 31, commencing on the south eastern boundary of Alottment 31 at a point distant 150 links from its southernmost angle. (Mar 27, 1884,Waikato Times,3)

With respect to the country sections, no progress has been made, in consequence, it is said, of some difficulty in the road lines on which the settlers are to take their frontage. (Mar 7, 1851,Daily Southern Cross,2)

NOTICE is Hereby Given, that, in consequence of repeated complaints made to the General Board of Road Trustees of obstruction and damage being caused to road lines within the Province, by parties digging holes in removing turf, and other material from, and otherwise injuring and obstructing said road lines, that proceedings will (without further notice) be at once taken, under the 51st section of the "Roads Ordinance, 1856," against any parties so offending. (May 12, 1860,Otago Witness,6)

The members for the Papakaio Subdivision were empowered to have two footbridges erected on road lines in Block 3. (Jun 11, 1879,North Otago Times,2)

An almost level grade traversing a portion of the original road line, and upon which the earthwork would be very light, has been obtained. (Dec 14, 1909,Poverty Bay Herald,5)

A deputation of objectors to the taking of land in Kaiaua Block then waited upon the Council, and stated that their main objection was that the surveyed road line took away too much of their flat land, also that it was land that had belonged to the family for generations. (Dec 3, 1919,Poverty Bay Herald,11)

A 9in. pipe drain 200 yards in length has been laid through Mr Bayne's land and then across the road line and into the creek to carry the rain water coming through the block cutting at the 10 mile peg. (Sep 27, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,4)

HOCKEN Was there a little bridge to build, a small cutting to make, or a portion of an impassable road-line to be improved, there were many to contribute labour, ... (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,160)

The burnt area on each side of the road-line ... (1898,TrNZI,399)

BELL A large clearing opened out on the right, and a little way back from the road-line stood a slab hut - or whare [e-acute], as it is generally called in New Zealand - of a rather better appearance than ordinary, from the iron chimney of which issued the smoke which the travellers had seen. Farther back from the road were yards and a larger building evidently used as a wool-shed. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,8)

We were struggling home with a big night's catch [of rabbits] - struggling down to the road-line, along which the rabbit-cart would travel next day. (Feb 10, 1921,Quick March,45)

road mob¶

n. (Rural) a group of stock driven on the hoof to or from saleyards.

GORDON For days, 'road-mobs' had been converging on Matawhero - recognised as the sale centre holding the largest cattle sales in the country. (1990,Matawhero, Elsewhere and Other Things,17)

road party¶

n.

HAAST Mr. Greenlaw was in charge of the road party, which ... had been sent up to form a bridle-path over the Pass,... (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,119)

Road Services¶

n.

..the Hari Hari team had charted [sic] the Road Services bus to take their team and supporters to the game. (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,221)

road trustee¶

n. (historical)

Every Road Trustee or member of a Road Board must have noticed the extraordinary number of excellent suggestions which have been made to him, both publicly and privately, and how utterly unable he is to carry them out. (Jun 20, 1857,Otago Witness,4)

Mr Martyn has always taken a prominent part in all matters affecting the welfare of the district, and has successively filled the office of Road Trustee, County Councillor and member of the South Auckland Cattle Board, besides taking a very active part as a member of the local racing clubs. (Feb 10, 1881,Waikato Times,2)

road trusteeship¶

n. (historical)

There are plenty of opportunites for a young gentleman to take part in the public business of the district in which he resides; there are the road trusteeships, the school committees, &c. &c. (Apr 6, 1861,Otago Witness,5)

road weed¶

n. wireweed

HIL;GENDORF WIREWEED (Polygonum aviculare), also called road weed, mat weed, knot grass, [pig weed,] and hog weed, is common in cultivated land all over the country. It is an annual, with stems up to 2ft. in length trailing over the ground. The stems have swollen nodes (knot grass') and are very tough (wireweed'). (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,61,1967 ed.)

road weed [=] wireweed [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,64)

road-broken¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of stock] accustomed to being driven on roads.

MILLS One day I came upon a large mob of cattle, weary and footsore. The leading dog had little to do. They had obviously been travelling for weeks and were well road-broken. (1966,Huntaway,194)

road-hopper¶

n. a hitch-hiker [(? obsolete)]

GRAEME-HOLDER Did you ever see such a lot of road-hoppers? (1933,Restless Youth,99)

road-keeper¶

n. a bushrangers' lookout [(criminals' obs)]

He was `road-keeper' in the gang; that is, he preceded the others, and while they were engaged with their victims, stood ready to give warning of danger to his companions. (1866,Maungatapu Murders,11)

road-kill¶

n.

From Cuba Street roadkill to Gandalf's date at the Oscars - you've come a long way, baby. (Apr 3, 2002,Capital Times,7)

And, after the "laying on of the sprigs" ceremony by the Canterbury pack, I extracted myself from the Carisbrook bog like a piece of resurgent road-kill. (Aug 22, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B13)

Possum dishes such as Road Kill, Headlight Delight Pie, Guess That Mess and Shovel-Flipped Roadside Pizza have incensed Animal Liberation Victoria (ALV). (Jun 27, 2004,Sunday Star Times,A7)

[Hdg] Roadkill wine. What better way to spend your Friday afternoon than drinking red wine and eating pie? Especially if the Roadkill Wine in question is a 2000 Hawke's Bay cabernet merlot... (Nov 26, 2004,Dominion Post,A6)

n. animals along the road and roadside killed by passing motorists [The earliest previous reference is from the USA in 28 Dec. 1979. Term commonly used in N America.]

[Hdg] Race to avoid being financial roadkill... This year will go down in share marker history books as one of paving the way for change, but next year exchanges face greater pressure to really shake-up or risk being financial roadkill. (Dec 24, 2001,Evening Post,11)

Further on we pass the whitewashed remains of a pilot whale. It is unusual roadkill - a welcome change from flattened possums. (Jun 25, 2002,Dominion,15)

This infamous collection of genetically unrelated species prefers eau de roadkill - a stomach-turning blend redolent of fetid flesh, with undertones of startled skunk and week-old offal. (May 4, 2003,Sunday Star Times,18)

He was driving one-handed when he hit the possum. It had no chance, except for the chance of a graceful and violent death... "Roadkill," she said softly. "Is that what you call it here?" he said. (Jan 6, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D1)

Historically, hedgehogs have been recorded scavenging shrimps washed up on beaches, dead possums and sheep, and even cannibalising on 'hedgehog pizza' road-kills. (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,No. 306/10)

Some [meat] has gone to an elderly neighbour who was such a fan of rabbit meat he was picking up roadkill and taking it home to cook. (Sep 16, 2004,Dominion Post,C7)

Alternatives [to entertainment] included rolling roadkill into the road, singing all the bits of the Mikado I could remember, reenacting my brief appearance as Old Peasant One in the school production of the Caucasian Chalk Circle, and swerving extremely slowly towards the many cars that sped recklessly through the site. (Dec 30, 2003,Dominion Post,C1)

The Fondue Generation had arrived, and no-one who survived it will ever forget the haute cuisine of the '50s - those unappetising logs of minced meat, followed by whipped-fluff desserts, which contributed to the death of in-home entertainment. Mexican macaroni, or road-kill? You made the call. (Sep 1999,Cuisine,No. 76 : 105)

REDMOND [Hdg] The Road-Kill Cafe. Ibid. 41 Another innovation was "road-killed" venison, that is sold to some of the more gullible, but daring, drivers. (2000,Truckers: NZ Truckers on the Road,36)

"It's bad, Bob, terminally bad ... you've run out of roadkill," says the voice. (Sep 30, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),65)

Bob Brockie [PhD in hedgehogs]... Claims New Zealand is the Roadkill Capital of the Western World... What will the new animal welfare regulations mean for drivers who used to be able to hit-and-run roadkill with impunity? (Jan 16, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

I'm not sure I was ready for the secret passions of truckies, or the nudge-nudge, wink-wink tacky innuendo, scattered like road-kill throughout the programme... Coc-Kroft giggled a lot when one truckie said the radio was a useful "tool to play with.".. Then it was all-abored for the truckie sisterhood. (Jul 26, 2000,Evening Post,10)

Cherry rescues a sick puppy, run-over and left as road-kill, and nurses him back to health. (Sep 18, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

England ended the match as roadkill in the rear-view mirror of a resurgent Irish side. (Nov 11, 2001,Sunday Star Times,B1)

Reeve writes of the rural and patincolous, nodding a wink to monopteral falcon fare - the failure of country capeador - in "Roadkill", the slouched face of a tiny-town counter-dweller in "Central Otago", his nose a parody of the hills. (Sep 15, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

You can also hit bull's eyes by the naming of a dish, e.g. "la rout de la mort" (sic) - "road kill" - is cameron-glazed ponsie of rabbit with kumara mash and balsamic tyre impression. (Jul 7, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,6)

Pukeko, rare in some parts of New Zealand, are plentiful alongside Auckland motorways, where Australasian harrier also quarter the verges for roadkill. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,No. 304/27)

Even better, you could delve into the wonderfully textural world of road kill... <Ibib. 57 [Hdg] Roadkill. (Jul 7, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

The high incidence of sleaze, crooks and mayhem in novels.. has caused Hiassen to be labelled as a crime writer, albiet a very funny and satirical one with characters twice as large as life - like the one-eyed ex-Governor who lives off roadkill. (Feb 9, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

.. back on the highway, roadkill attracts the native New zealand hawk. (Dec 12, 2004,Sunday Star Times,p12)

...the concoction tasted like burned urine with a pronounced after-taste of rotting roadkill. (Jul 28, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A12)

Road Kill is a quick, formulaic tale of a boy, his Harley and an apparently murdered teacher... (Dec 7, 2001,Evening Post,11)

I've drunk Heineken in Amsterdam, Tuborg in Copenhagen and domestic claret in Morocco that might as well have been liquefied roadkill. (Dec 7, 2001,Evening Post,10)

Whatever - it works (when it doesn't wind up as road-kill). (Feb 28, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

n.

I wasn't even between a rock and a hard place - I was roadkill. (Nov 29, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

Bores, you've had it. You're road-kill. (Jan 1, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

Instead I'll awake this morning, hoping Andrew Mehrtens, Sam Tuitupou and the rest haven't been squished overnight by Schalk Burger and his mates; that the flat backline isn't so much a concept as an epithet. For rugby roadkill. (Aug 15, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C8)

Deadpan and blues, she sang of manipulated, hapless men cast off as "road-kill". (Jun 26, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),53)

roadie¶

n. a roadman

Roadies riled [headline] Speed freaks are putting road builders in potentially life-threatening positions. `I'm not scared of dying but the rehearsals are giving me the sh...,' was how one worker known as Blue described the situation at road building sites he had worked on. (Jun 15, 1986,Sunday News,25)

HULME I've known roadies who knew theirs was a high place in the scheme of things, ... (1983,Bone People, The,241)

n. a road user

DESPITE all the ranting and raving by Mr Prebble to the contrary it would appear that even NZ Railways concede that costs by road are cheaper than by rail. ... It is certainly satisfying to have a `roadies' view endorsed by the corporation (Jun 10, 1985,National Business Review,8)

n. [road trip]

He still has friends in the area and they will be doing a roadie up to Dunedin to see him in black. (Aug 3, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B3)

2 n. someone who rides a bicycle on the road, as opposed to an off-road or MTB cyclist

Now it's possible to buy feather-light mountain bikes that can almost foot it with the "roadies", or skinny-tyred fraternity, on smooth surfaces. Ibid. 100 All of this is.. incomprehensible to 99.9 per cent of people who knew all about the joy of riding long before MTBS were invented. These are the "roadies". (Feb 1997,North & South,99)

roading¶

n. ? NZ = roads collectively (Miles Fairburn) -->eg The roading in the district needs money spent on it. [check]

roadless North¶

n. (historical) North Auckland/Northland

".. Whether the Government will find in this treatment a stimulus and encouragement to further exertions on behalf of 'the roadless North' we do not pretend to say ..." (Apr 7, 1894,Evening Post,2)

With special reference to Auckland's roadless north and ill-roaded King Country came a proposal before the Farmers' Union Conference yesterday that the Government should construct and maintain main arterial roads. (Jul 17, 1913,Evening Post,2)

Locals no doubt derived grim satisfaction from the difficulties besetting the parliamentary tour of the "roadless North." (May 2003,NZ Geographic,74)

Some days ago a deputation of Auckland members waited upon the Premier to urge the claims of the "roadless North." (Sep 12, 1893,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

BARR The chauffeur who had driven Sir Joseph Ward over the roadless north in this same 34-horse doesn't know `nerves'. (1908,British Rugby Team in Maoriland,60)

MANDER But the north was not respectable. It was the land of lost men. It was peopled with nomads and wasters. And it was the roadless north', thebarbaric north', where the Maoris still might war upon you in the night. It had no railway beyond Helensville. The Southerner curled his lip at it. (1925,Allen Adair,6,1971 ed.)

REED .. a post bearing the legend Waihopo Landing' seemed to indicate that in comparatively recent times, when the termroadless north' expressed the literal truth, the little settlement was saved by boat. (1946,Farthest North,34)

REED Northland The mill was closed in winter, for the reason that may be apparent only to those who remember the `roadless north' in the later decades of the nineteenth century. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,235)

REED The building was erected when this part of the country [Pukenui] could literally be described as `the roadless north' (1961,North Cape to Bluff,30)

McLAGLAN Smallpox in New Zealand,' scoffed everybody,and in the roadless North! ...' (1965,Stethoscope & Saddlebags,114)

The `roadless North' was despairing of the Liberals, but not yet [pre-WWI] prepared to trust reform. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/365)

THOMAS Nevertheless the Roadless North', to use the term in general use at that time [c1904], was still well named. It was far more accurate then than the termWinterless North' which came later. (1970,Way Up North,72)

THOMAS Nevertheless the Roadless North', to use the term in general use at that time [c1904], was still well named. It was far more accurate then than the termWinterless North' which came later. (1970,Way Up North,72)

roadman¶

n. a road worker

Each roadman was responsible for maintaining a section of the road - clearing slips, filling in potholes - and lived with his family in a hut along his stretch. (Sep 2003,NZ Heritage,No. 90/10)

n. a road worker, roadie

HARPER The roadmen in charge of the [Otira] pass reported very deep drifts ... (Jul 10, 1868,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,129,1914 ed.)

HAAST Immediately ... the Provincial Government had sent on a number of roadmen to repair the worst places, to build bridges, to drain swamps, ... Ibid. 120 Next morning the party of roadmen ... returned over the Pass ... (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,70)

D'AVIGDOR I ... [relate] what a New Zealand hill hotel-keeper and butcher told me:- `I buy a sheep ... I sell the meat ... to the road-men, and use the rest in my hotel.' (1888,Antipodean Notes,76)

BELL [a swagger speaks] But de'il tak' the hour I agreed to gang amang the cockatoos wi' ye, Bill; an' I could wish mysel' back amang the squatters again. Your wee bit farmers are a measly lot ... To be sure, ane is aye made at hame in a bush fa'ers' or roadmen's camp to a share o' what's goin'; ... (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,7)

DUFF It is true that this is primarily a trampers' hut, but trampers don't usually carry periodicals in their swags. ... But here the two journals are now, and I wish I knew how often they are read by the other users of this shelter - rabbiters, deer-cullers, roadmen, storm-bound swaggers, and so on. (Mar 19, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,25,1961 ed.)

McLAGLAN The roadmen were invaluable. Not only did they keep their allotted [176] stretch of road in order but they watched every river and creek. (1965,Stethoscope & Saddlebags,175)

LETHBRIDGE A new-comer was Eddie who was taking a few days off from his job as roadman and from his home and family down near the Timahanga turnoff. (1971,Sunrise on the Hills,84)

BATTYE & EAKIN Well Jock McDonald, the roadman, had an inkling for a while that the dog didn't eat all the meat (1980,Shadow of the Valley,41)

HARTLEY Sometimes we came across one [swagger] boiling his billy in a roadman's clearing ... and eating cold meat and bread from his tucker box (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,113)

n. (Rural) a person who maintained rural gravelled roads before the use of heavy machinery and tar-sealing.

PASCOE The Cunninghams sold injured sheep for meat to the roadmen ... (1959,Great Days in NZ Exploration,124)

NEWTON .. the servicing of the road was done by a solitary road man. (1964,Straggle Muster,27)

NEWTON Bill Harrod, who was renewing an old fenceline, had been a roadman on the Taihape for many years ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,164)

The Wairarapa South County Council built the roadman's cottage which is still there today. (1980,Te Wharau,185)

ASPINALL Joe Dickie worked for many years for the local county as a roadman. [road man] (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,214)

roadroller¶

n.

McGILL roadroller bushman or hick; early C20. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

roads and bridges¶

phr. (historical)

FOR ROADS AND BRIDGES .. The ratepayers of Akitio county, which is situated between Pahiatua and the East Coast, on Saturday carried a proposal to raise GBP28,000 for bridging and road works. (May 22, 1911,Evening Post,7)

The Colonists of Van Dieman's Land could not presume to disparage the settlement of Port Nicholson; they do not question .. the liberal expenditure of the New Zealand company, the vast number of emigrants it has employed in the formation of roads and bridges ... (Dec 26, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

The Hon. A. W. Hogg, Minister for Roads and Bridges, visited the East Road and Ohura country this week. (Mar 4, 1909,Taranaki Herald,3)

WE, the undersigned, Carriers, are obliged through the bad state of the roads and bridges at Silver Stream, Pakuratahi, Waihoine, Waingawa, also the incompleteness of railway accomodation, to raise the up-carriage from Wellington to Masterton fifteen shillings per ton, until such time as the roads and bridges are made good, dated from 1st January, 1876. (Feb 11, 1876,Evening Post,2)

There would still be many millions to be borrowed for the completion of our hydro-electric schemes, telephone extensions, schools, public buildings, roads and bridges and other public works. (Nov 13, 1928,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3)

P. R. Harman, Secretary, South Island Motor Union, asked support in seeking fair treatment in expenditure on Public Works on roads and bridges in the South Island. (Nov 22, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,4)

(1867,Ordinances of Taranaki) [NOTES: 1858 Roads and Bridges Ordinance, 1858. in 1867 Ordinances of Taranaki 93 hist.]

MULGAN Often settlers went right out into the wilds and had to wait long for reasonably good communications. This partly explains the importance of the `roads and bridges member' in the New Zealand Parliament, a term that has well-nigh disappeared. One might laugh at him and deplore his preoccupation with local matters, but road or bridge could be life or death to an outback settler. The central Government was the main source of bounty, so grants were continually asked for. (1958,Making of a New Zealander, The,17)

McLINTOCK Among a rather mediocre team Coates stood out for initiative and vigour. By his sustained use and encouragement of experts, by his disregard for the time-honoured `roads and bridges' system, Coates broke new ground [c1920-1926]. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/365)

roads district¶

n. an administrative district for the maintenance of roads

roads district NZ administrative district for the maintenance of roads; (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,660) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

roadster¶

n. a horse [(station, ? rare)]

W.H.S. ROBERTS We now had quite a large mob of breeding mares on the run, with a very useful stamp of horse which we called a roadster, who gloried in the name of `Sir Roger de Coverley'; ... (Aug 1856,Diary,34) [NOTES: 1856 June W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 34]

roady¶

adj.

[In reply to a vote of thanks to the Contractors and Workmen on the Sumner Road] ... (A voice; Three cheers for the roady mob). (Aug 26, 1857,Lyttelton Times,4)

roany¶

adj.

It takes Bill and I two hours to catch that old roany Maori weed we used for packing tucker. (Jul 5, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/47 : 251)

roar¶

n. noise made by a stag during the rutting season to attract hinds and signal his size to his rivals. Also a synonym for the rut.

LENTLE & SAXTON roar: noise made by a stag during the rutting season to attract hinds and signal his size to his rivals. Also a synonym for the rut. (1991,Red Deer in New Zealand,186)

roarer¶

n. a shepherd who can't command a sufficiently penetrating whistle, so relies on a voice strengthened by years of training

HENDERSON The "roarer" is a shepherd who can't command a sufficiently penetrating whistle, so relies on a voice strengthened by years of training. (1967,Return to Open Country,35)

n. a stag [ca 1925 W.H.B.Orsman (Marlborough)]

n.

PHILLIPS He developed into a 'roarer' (broken-wind) which ended his racing but he remained the King's favourite hack. (2000,First Past the Post,37) [NOTES: Joe Lorrigan "Famous Horse! Sacred Cow?" in The Park Sensation 1987]

BOSWELL He was a `roarer' too; that is, he was broken-winded, so that every breath blew out of his lungs with a horse roar ... (1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,117) [NOTES: cf EDD 4. (3) a restless cow Midl.; nf OED.]

1 n. (Rural) a horse with broken wind.

BOSWELL he was a roarer too - that is, he was broken-winded, so that every breath blew out of his lungs with a hoarse roar like the sound of the worn-out engine of the Dargaville-Kaihu train. (1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,117)

Roaring Meg¶

n. a common name from gold-digging and coaching days for swift, rapid-rising creeks or small rivers (cf CRYING JENNY, GENTLE ANNIE) The first is very small, and in a dry season merely drips from the road [ca 1951 a mountain stream in Tararuas (NCC Small) 1955 Dec 24 Illustrated London News 1113 [caption] -->R. Mason notes of the creek name that the following may have some bearing on the original naming. A model of Londonderry's famous gun `Roaring Meg': in silver on an oak stand, presented to Sir Winston Churchill when he became freeman of Londonderry. cf OED (1575) a huge cannon etc.; (cf Illustr London News. 1955 Dec 24 p1113) (1632) kind of top; (1811) (Geol) Trans. Geol Soc. This structure of clay .... goes by the name of shaggy metal, and the fresh water which makes its way through the pores has the expressive appellation of Roaring Meg.; W3 only common usage (cf. Roaring (adj) 1848. boisterous; (of health) exuberant)]

The Company is to be formed for the purpose of constructing a water-race from the Roaring Meg to German Gully, and Black Ball Creek to German Gully ... (Aug 23, 1887,Grey River Argus,4)

[Photo caption] THE ROARING MEG FALLS, KAWARAU RIVER. (Jul 24, 1907,Otago Witness,49)

McNEISH In 1864 the first true Roaring Meg was built. This was an inn of rock. (1957,Tavern in the Town,238) [NOTES: 1966 edition]

It has to be remembered that below the dam the Shotover River and the streams, "Roaring Meg" and "Gentle Annie" empty into the Kawerau River. (Sep 8, 1926,NZ Observer,2)

The prospecting claim at the Roaring Mag [sic] was granted upon the prospect of one pennyweight to the tin dish, and that at the Five Mile Creek upon two pennyweights to the tin dish. (Jan 24, 1863,Otago Witness,7)

A rush has taken place at the Roaring Meg, one of the tributaries of the Kawarau. (Jan 31, 1863,Otago Witness,8)

The famous Roring Meg, which later surges through Kawarau Gorge, starts in these hills. (Jul 9, 2002,Dominion Post,D3)

Roaring Meg, usually a creek and far more rough and tumble, is apt to be in the neighbourhood of Gentle Annie... Roaring Meg may come from the name of the famous gun of Londonderry. (Sep 1959,Tararua,13/49)

The river known as the "Roaring Meg," in the Otaki Gorge, is to have a bridge erected across it at a cost of GBP53 10s. (Jan 11, 1910,Evening Post,8)

Mr Grenfell describes passing Roaring Meg and Gentle Annie as "child's play:" (Jan 22, 1924,Otago Witness,44)

There were surprised by a party of prospectors.. who.. by way of Kawarau Gorge, Roaring Meg and Gentle Annie, had reached the Arrow river. (Apr 1, 1924,Otago Witness,64)

They are prepared to borrow $1.3 million to harness the Pukeatua Stream, also known as Roaring Meg. (Oct 6, 1992,Evening Post,3)

PYKE By the side of Roaring Meg' ... [3] The mountain torrent where to allusion has been made was the stream named by surveyors as theKirtleburn', but which is best known by the fantastic appellation conferred on it by the miners - Roaring Meg' There are three creeks in succession on this line of road - tributaries of the Kawarau River. ocks, and is calledCrying Jenny' The second, which tumbles down from the mountains impetuously and with great noise, is Roaring Meg' The third, being a sluggish stream, has received, by popular assent, the designation ofGentle Annie' (1874,George Washington Pratt,1,3)

HOLLOWAY [Coach en route for Clyde crossed the Kawarau River, passed Gibbs Town] `Drove over Annie's Creek. And on till we came to within half a mile of Roaring Mag [sic. ?a mis-hearing] - Here is a natural bridge over the River Kawarau. ... A little below this bridge we crossed a Beautiful Mountain Torrent call'd Roaring Mag, and not inaptly ... (Mar 21, 1874,Journal of a Visit)

HOLLOWAY [Coach en route for Clyde crossed the Kawarau River, passed Gibbs Town] `Drove over Annie's Creek. And on till we came to within half a mile of Roaring Mag [sic. ?a mis-hearing] - Here is a natural bridge over the River Kawarau. ... A little below this bridge we crossed a Beautiful Mountain Torrent call'd Roaring Mag, and not inaptly ... (Mar 21, 1874,Journal of a Visit) [NOTES: 1875 (1874 Mar 21) Holloway Journal of a Visit]

DOUGLAS 'Twas sweet upon a Summers eve/To wander with my Nannie/ To hop across the Roaring Meg/ And climb up gentle Annie. (Jan 29, 1891,Journal) [NOTES: 1891 Jan 29 Douglas in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 149]

A TRAMP ... trudging on ... up by the Molyneux; blessing Roaring Meg' and sweating and swearing over theGentle Annie' (1891,Casual Ramblings,108)

HISLOP There are now several bonnie burns coming down the mountain sides to the river, the largest of which are the famous Roaring Meg and Gentle Annie; and a visitor ... may wash his colours of gold from almost anywhere while his wee wife boils the billy. Ibid. 53 ... Roxburgh and Cromwell are well behind, and I slow down ... to enjoy the sight of the water gushing from the spillway of the newly-erected power station at the Roaring Meg corner of the [Kawarau] Gorge. This heavy stream, which breaks so suddenly on a stranger from its very rough surroundings, got its name (according to early-day tradition) from the fact that Meg, one of the two girls on their way to a dancing saloon at Arrow, created such a fuss at crossing this turbulent water that vibrations of her voice loosened rocks on the mountain side to add still further to the roaring of stream and of Meg herself. There are different versions concerning the naming of this stream, and maybe some of this one is my own. ... A few miles further on the next stream to be crossed is the Gentle Annie, called after Meg's pal, who no doubt was a much quieter type of tourist than Meg herself. (1943,Pure Gold,20)

(1959,Tararua,13/49)

McGILKL Roaring Meg a raging river, perhaps near a Gebtle Annie mountain; possibly after legendary Irish landlady Maggie (Mag or Meg) Brennan of the Queenstown area who allegedly bellowed at customers and threw stroppy clients in the nearby creek; ref. James McNeish's Tavern in the Town; also the name of a Londonderry gun. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

DENNIS This side-track crosses two old water races, Wessels'[sic], and Roaring Meg (the latter diverting water by a 30 metre tunnel from nearby Roaring Meg Creek) ... (1981,Paparoas Guide,64)

1 n. (Rural) a raging river.

KENNEDY We passed, during our drive, three mountain torrents of different characters .. Weeping Lizzie, the Roaring Meg, and the Gentle Annie. You may miss seeing Lizzie or Annie, but you cannot escape Meg. She is a rumbling, raging, scolding stream ... (1876,Colonial Travel,187)

MCGILL Roaring Meg a raging river, perhaps near a Gentle Annie mountain (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

2 n. (personal nickname) [?186? 1870]

ELDRED-GRIGG Gentlemen of first rank, William Downie Stewart observed, could be seen ... at Vauxhall [Gardens, Otago Peninsula] in the company of famous prostitutes, such as Roaring Meg and Black Susan. (1980,Southern Gentry,101)

roaring up¶

n. a severe reprimand [ca 1951 Miss G. Hall: (Letter) [? Central Otago] A roaring up': a severe talking to, in the disciplinary sense: such asI gave him a number one roaring up and sent him down the road (q.v.)' cf Part. Roar up: Speak abusively to; shout at Lower classes': from ca 1905 F and G; AC 1919]

roaroa¶

n. as roa [ORIGIN: Maori]

He said the Canterbury Museum received this bird from a collector on the West Coast of this Island, who states that the natives call this species Roaroa, and that a Maori from Bruce Bay informed him these birds were very valorous, and would well defend themselves against the attacks of dogs by kicking. (Oct 15, 1870,Otago Witness,15)

The "roaroa," which is locally known as "the fireman," as far as Mr. Hansen knows, is not found on the eastern side of Preservation Inlet ... (Mar 26, 1910,Evening Post,13)

Apteryx maxima is described [from Nelson] as `a Kiwi, about the size of a turkey ...' The natives distinguish it as the Roaroa. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/15) [NOTES: (Buller Ornithology)]

WILLIAM DOCHERTY 9 Ka-Ka Pos. [pounds]9. 2 dozen Kivi's skins [pounds]7:4:0. ... 6 Rowis skins [pounds]6. [549 1870] If the Roa-Roa is in the country, mark my words, I will find him. (Oct 13, 1870,Diary) [NOTES: 1870 Oct 13 William Docherty in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 548, 549]

HUTTON 61. ? APTERYX MAXIMA. Verr. Great Kiwi. Roa-roa. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,23)

BULLER APTERYX HAASTI. (LARGE GREY KIWI.) ... Native names. Roa or Roaroa, and Kiwi-Karuai. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,371)

  1. Apteryx haastii, Potts. Roa-Roa. - Nothing is known of the breeding habits of this fine species. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,506) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

A. haasti. - Roaroa, Kiwi, Karuai. South Island, in Alpine regions. (1886,TrNZI,18/113) [NOTES: (Martin)]

ANDERSON roa, roaroa, a bird (Apterxy haastii), large grey kiwi: South Island kiwi. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157)

n. the great spotted kiwi, Apteryx haasti

The roaroa (A. haasti) is another bird of "the kiwi kind. (Apr 3, 1890,Otago Witness,00) [NOTES: Check page number]

roastery¶

n. a place for roasting coffee beans

Having quit the part-time job I had at a coffee roastery in order to be available for all the great temping work that was going to come my way, I was most disappointed when two long, broke weeks later I received my first assignment... (Sep 16, 2004,Dominion Post,D1)

[He] says there are other motivations for starting the roastery, alongside the love of good coffee...People's Coffee is one of the first roasteries in New Zealand to solely use Fair Trade coffee. (Aug 19, 2004,Wellingtonian,13)

n.

Aidan Forrest, roastery asssistant "It is necessary to ease coastal congestion the amount of money sounds reasonable given the length of the highway. (Mar 14, 2006,Independent Herald (Wellington),2) [NOTES: Is is unknown whether this citation refers to a coffee roastery or meat roastery (or other).]

rob one's mother's coffin¶

phr. (derogatory reference)

MANDER There were men who did not know what decency was, and who, to use the current phrase, would have robbed their mother's coffin. (1920,Story of a NZ River, The,57,1974 ed.)

Rob's Mob¶

n. supporters of Robert Muldoon

While acknowledging that the station [sc. Radio Pacific] has a "significant" audience, it panders, he says, to the prejudices of the vestiges of Rob's Mob. (Apr 1998,North & South,71)

Many of his [sc. Muldoon's] social views, such as on royalty, now seem quaint, while the hero-worshipping "Rob's Mob" is literally dying out. (Dec 9, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

By contrast, National reaped a "Rob's Mob" harvest among Labours's social conservatives in earlier years... (Oct 29, 2006,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

They took it to the woman, Rob's Mob. (May 24, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48)

I neither liked nor admired him, and deplored his bullying behaviour; I thought he was a damned fool for enabling the notorious Springbok rugby tour of 1981; his constant references to "Rob's Mob" - his imaginary millions of adoring admirers - incensed me; but to call him evil is to go too far. He was just a snappy little bloke whom we made prime minister. (Sep 1, 2011,Dominion Post,B4)

It has a faint echo of Sir Robert Muldoon's "Rob's Mob" but without the deep-red tinge to its neck... (Sep 22, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

First, [Peters] has pinched National's grumpy "Robs's Mob" vote with a more colourful stance on issues such as the Treaty of Waitangi. (Jul 21, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A4)

JAMES On his way to victory in 1975, Muldoon had recruited 'Robsmob' - 'ordinary citizens' from outside National's normal ranks. (1986,Quiet Revolution, The,91)

There are still some people who seem to pine for the days of Muldoon, pensioners mainly, the remnants of "Rob's Mob". (Feb 1992,Metro,8)

Activist members of the National Party, proudly identifying themselves as "Rob's Mob", flocked to hear their new Messiah. (Nov 2, 1995,Times (London),23)

robber¶

n. (Rural) a piglet that takes over the teat of a sow other than its mother, often causing its mother's teat to dry off.

It is not sufficient merely to put the 'robber' back - it will find a way time and time again and if it should be away from its own mother for more than two days, the milk in the quarter at which he was feeding will dry-off. (Jul 7, 1937,Weekly News,76)

n. (Rural) a ewe that takes the lamb of another.

DU FAUR The activities of 'robber' ewes, the influence of blustery weather, wet soil conditions, competition for available feed, the use of poorly trained dogs, the use of 'all-rounders' or huntaways instead of quiet strong-eyed dogs, are also contributing factors to this unsettledness. (1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,87)

A ewe that takes the lamb of another: robbber. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

1 n. (Rural) a high-consuming but poorly-producing dairy cow.

The Kaupokonui Directors, after inspecting and trying Preston's cow detector, a simple and cheap little machine used for the purpose of detecting the robber cows in the herd, have purchased the right to use and sell these machines at a low price to the suppliers. (Nov 27, 1920,Hawera Star,9)

Experience shows that no man knows, without testing, which of his cows are returning a profit and which are the 'robbers' or cows which don't yield sufficient to pay for their keep and milking. (Oct 1, 1926,NZ Farmer,1421)

One farmer who is testing his herd of thirty cows culled out six 'robbers'... (Oct 29, 1927,NZ Dairy Exporter,26)

Cull the robbers - once the unprofitable cows are detected, they should be culled. (Sep 1, 1937,NZ Farmer,7)

Robbity Bob the barber¶

phr. [(folk rhymes)]

NEWBOLD Bob's work-parole date was getting close ... But fortune favours him who perseveres, thought Robert the Bob, ... . (1982,Big Huey, The,187)

roberto¶

n.

[The doorkeeper] gave evidence of having been told off to collect the "robertos" at the main door. (Oct 13, 1917,NZ Truth,5)

robin¶

n. a) any of various small, plump, European birds with an orange breast. b) any of various similar but unrelated Australian birds, with scarlet or pink breasts. c) any of three similar but unrelated New Zealand birds. Also called toutouwai, katuhituhi. [AND name 1823] Miro australis, BUSH ROBIN, NATIVE ROBIN, NEW ZEALAND ROBIN, TOUTOUWAI 1. simplex (distinguish North Island and South Island Robins, and deal with them here: but only if epithet in text: give defin. that covers both races]

The boat dropped us at Motuara Island bird sanctuary near Ship Cove, where robins will eat from your hand and blue penguins nest in boxes, known as penguin pubs, supplied by DOC. (Jun 1, 2004,Dominion Post,A17)

FORSTER The male & female of a small Thrush [[ed. fn] Turdus minutus of Descr. Anim. p.83; ... Now theYellow-breasted Tit ...] was shot, which we hitherto had taken for a variety of the small yellow legged Thrush, commonly called Robin by our Ship's-crew; ... (May 3, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/269)

(Queen Charlotte Sound) ... one [bird] in figure and tameness exactly resembles our Robin [ed. note [South island Robin, Miro australis.]] (Feb 1777,Cook's Journals,3/806,1967 ed.) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/806]

HEAPHY [see Kokaho [South Island Robin]] (1846,Journal of an Expedition)

BRUNNER [?S.I. Robin] we killed a robin. (1847,Great Journey,42,1952 ed.)

LUSH We have a bird called the Robin but though like his British cousin in shape and habits his breast is black. (Jun 9, 1853,Auckland Journals,140,1971 ed.)

BUTLER The lark is nearly identical and the quail is the same - the hawk the same - the robin has its counterpart here in a bird with a slate coloured head and throat with a canary coloured breast, to all intents and purposes it is a robin for all that; ... (Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,44,1960 ed.)

BUTLER - It is Sunday. We rose later than usual. There are five men sleeping in the hut. I sleep in a bunk on one side of the fire, Mr. Haast ... sleeps upon the opposite one; my bullock-driver and hut-keeper have two bunks at the far end of the hut, along the wall; ... The usual mutton and bread for breakfast with a pudding made of flour and water baked in the camp-oven after a joint of meat - Yorkshire pudding, but without eggs. While we were at breakfast, a robin perched on the table and sat there a good while pecking at the sugar. (Apr 1861,Diary) [NOTES: 1861 April Butler's Note in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler - A Memoir 1/87 April, 1861]

BARRINGTON Killed a robin and three wrens; roasted them: the smallest joints I ever saw; . (Apr 13, 1864,Diary) [NOTES: 1864 Apr 13 Barrington Diary in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 406]

Petroica longipes. Totowai. Robin. Common. (1869,TrNZI,1/160) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

PETROICA ALBIFRONS, Gml. Totoara. Robin....PETROICA LONGPIPES, Less. and garn. Robin. (1870,TrNZI,2/60) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

MONEY ... to the end ... suspend ... a robin, or other small bird, newly killed; ... (1871,Knocking About in NZ,32)

The Robin (Petroica albifrons) is a very bold bird ... (1872,TrNZI,4/212) [NOTES: (Travers NZ Birds)]

BULLER This bird is the subject of an article - the Pitoitoi or Toutouwai of the natives and the `Robin' of the colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,120,{1888 2nd edn 1/34} ed.)

DOMETT Miro longpipes The large grey-coated robin - kinsman true/ Of England's delicate highbred bird of home, -/ Ibid.2 /338 Robin ..... Miro longipes - of Lesson and Dr. Buller. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,2/21)

  1. Petroeca macrocephala, Gml. Yellow-breasted Tit or Robin, Miro-miro, Ngoru-ngoru [sic]... Ibid. 30. Petroeca albifrons, Gml. Robin, Toto-ara. - This delightful warbler is decreasing in numbers very rapidly ... (Nov 1884,NZ Journal of Science,286) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

DUCHESS OF BUCKINGHAM [At Bluff] saw some colonial robins; and also oyster birds, or `red bills', with black bodies and red legs and beaks. (1894,Glimpses of Four Continents,127)

HARPER The robin (Miro albifrons) is a constant companion in some localities, as far as the bush limit; ... (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,39)

MORRIS Robin, n. The name, in consequence of their external resemblance to the familiar English bird, is applied, in Australia, to species of the various genera as follows:... The New Zealand species are - -->Chatham Island Robin - Miro traversi, Buller. North Island R. - M. australis, Sparrm. -->South Island R. - M. albifrons, Gmel. -->[NZ Dates 1866 Lady B. S. L; 1872 Domett] (1898,Austral English,390)

Robi.in (r&obreve.bi.&itilde.n), n. [Add.] New Zealand robin (Zool.), the miro. See MIRO, 2. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

PASCOE [Birds South Westland] The New Zealand Robin .. (1899,Mr Explorer Douglas,271,1957 ed.)

I have paid special attention to the nests of three birds- the Native Canary (Orthonyx ochrocephala), the Robin (Myiomoira albifrons), and the Tomtit (Myiomoira macrocephala). Sir Walter Buller says ... that the Blue Crow (Glaucopis cinerea) lays a single egg, and ... leaves the care of the chick to the to the Popokatea, or Canary (Orthonyx albicilla). (1904,TrNZI,36/119)

FERGUSON See here are met .../ The robin's chirp and lintie's trill,/ And mocking bird, with fantail heard,/ And parroquet's green clamouring shrill. (1912,Castle Gay,60)

WILLIAMS Toutou, ... Miro australis, robin. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,518)

Here and there we heard the distant call of the tui ... and when we `spelled', grey-breasted robins fluttered about us cheekily. (1930,NZ Short Stories,19) [NOTES: Arthur H. Adams]

SUTHERLAND The robins, riflemen and tomtits tamed very soon, the robins being an easy first in this respect. (1953,Golden Bush, The,108,1963 ed.)

robin A small lovable bird; in England called `robin redbreast' Australian and New Zealand robins do not have red breasts. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),346)

FALLA et al. TOMTIT Petroica australis Maori name: Toutouwai. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,202)

robin-run-the-hedge¶

n. cleavers

HILGENDORF CLEAVERS (Galium aparine), also called lady's bed straw, goose grass, robin-run-the-hedge, and hairiff, is to be found on road sides and waste places in many parts of both islands. It is an annual, with sprawling stems up to five feet long often forming tangled masses. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,163,1967 ed.)

robinia¶

n. acacia (false a., spiny a.) [[CC Ransom notes: Robinia is the North American locust tree. R. pseudoacacia is Black Locust=Spiny Acacia]

robinia [s] Robinia pseudoacacia L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,64)

robust cardinal fish¶

n.

AYLING ROBUST CARDINALFISH Rosenblattia robusta ... The robust cardinalfish is deeper bodied than the other species of apogonid found in New Zealand. (1982,Collins Guide,211,1984 ed.)

robust skink¶

n. (Environment) a relatively large nocturnal skink both longer and thicker than most; resident on islands off Bay of Plenty. [Oligosoma alani aka pre 2009 Cyclodina alani]

Jenny Jones The robust skink is one of the largest of our New Zealand skinks. It has a SVL [snout to vent length] of 140 killimetres and can weigh up to 60 grams. (2002,Lizards,31)

Robust Skink Cyclodina alani Occurs only on a few offshore islands North East of the North Island. Possibly the largest New Zealand skink it is forest dwelling and strongly nocturnal. (Aug 7, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.reptilepark.co.nz/nzlizard.htm]

The aptly named robust skink.., thickset in all its features, is the archetypal Cyclodina. Ibid 78 "The rare Whitaker's skink and the robust skink have been the main focus of the relocations, with the result that the future of these species is probably brighter now than at any time in the past 1000 years," says Towns. (Jul 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 47 pp 67, 78)

Roc¶

n. regional operating company [ORIGIN: acronym]

Telecom says plan to disband its four regional operating companies will not alter its Kiwi Share obligations... The Rocs are at the heart of the Kiwi Share - a statement enshrined in the company's articles of association when Telecom was sold to Bell Atlantic and Ameritech in 1990. It was an attempt by the then Labour government to protect the interests of the New Zealand public. (Oct 5, 1992,Dominion Infotech Weekly,1)

rock¶

n. any stone [(esp. schoolboys')]

adj. as a distinguishing epithet in the names of plants and animals see found on, around, or in the vicinity of rock or rocks AKEAKE, ANISTOME, BLUEBELL, COTTONPLANT, CUDWEED, DAISY, FERN, FORGET-ME-NOT, KOROMIKO, LILY, GROUNDSEL, MAHOE, SNOWBERRY, SOW-THISTLE; FERN, SPLEENWORT; TREE-DAISY -->of animals [aj or attrib; see also oyster, perch, trout, wren, rock-shell,] (See cod,lark,ling,lizard,lobster)

n. bedrock [(goldminers') see AND]

v. to throw rocks (stones) at [ca 1935 eg Look at Jerry rocking his poor old dog.(schoolboys')]

v. to speed up, to intensify (an action) [ca 1945 We rocked the grog along all night, and Christ! were we sick in the morning! cf P: Rock in: Accelerate or intensify; esp. rock it in! hurry up: Austr.: 20c. B. 1942.]

GASKELL [To a girl singing slowly and sadly] Rock it along. ... She started off sadly again but we wouldn't let her. We rocked it. (1947,Big Game,33)

rock akeake¶

n. Olearia paniculata.

COCKAYNE Olearia Forsteri rock-akeake (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And) (2nd ed.)]

rock anisotome¶

n. Anisotome enysii.

COCKAYNE Anistome Enysii Rock anistome (1919,NZ Plants)

rock borer¶

n.

POWELL ROCK BORER (Anchomasa similis). Grows up to four inches in length. It is very common around Auckland, where it burrows completely out of sight into the soft mudstone of many tidal platforms. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,22)

rock camp¶

1 n. (Rural) an overhang or large shelter rock used by musterers, hunters and stock for shelter.

CURTIS We all agreed that if it rained before we reached the point of no return we would return to the rock camp. (1996,Beneath the Mountain Mist,60)

CURTIS We lost no time in heading for our rock camp and by the time we reached it the wind had dropped and the snow was falling. (1996,Beneath the Mountain Mist,67)

rock cod¶

n. a (usu. alternative and often little used) name for various fishes of coastal reefs

(Black Stewart Island) It was no unusual event ...to land ... Moki, Latris ciliaris; Trumpeter, Latris hecateia; Blue cod or Rock cod, Percis colias; and Red cod, Lotella bacchus. (1872,Appendix Proc. Otago Prov. Council,39)

Some hapukas weighed 80lb., and there were many trumpeters and rock-cod. (1889,TrNZI,21/379)

(Journal Capt Robertson) rockcod, barracouta ... abouke. [poss. blue cod: longer cit.]] (1841,NZ Journal,2/30/69)

HEAPHY The bream, ling, gurnard, herring, sole, rock-cod, and a species of mackarel, are all in abundance, as are also many fish unknown elsewhere [than Wellington]. (1842,New Zealand (various authors/titles),49)

SEWELL Fish are plentiful, herrings (a large kind not so good as English), Rock Cod, a sort of Whiting, moka, small soles, Flounders, Eeels [sic], sometimes Habouka a large fish (which I tasted at Capt Simeon's) something between Cod and Grey Mullet, but not so good as either. (1853,Journal,1/158)

DRURY FISH [MET WITH IN PELORUS]. Rock Cod - Pakiri of the natives, red and brown, or black, very numerous. (1855,Sailing Directions,67)

HURSTHOUSE The best [sea fish] are the Hapuka ... a sort of mackerel, and some mullet, rock-cod, ... and snapper. (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/122)

MACKIE Many on board are busily employed in fishing for rock cod, 1 ft. and 1[half] ft. long. (Jul 22, 1853,Traveller under Concern,124,1973 ed.)

Many ... varieties of sea-fish are caught round the coast, such as barracouta, groper, rock-cod, ling, flounders, soles, gar-fish, and others, all which are plentiful ... (1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The,32)

HECTOR 38. ROCK COD. ... This (Percis colias) is the Coal Fish of Captain Cook and Blue Cod of the settlers in the South, and the Pakirikiri of the Maoris. (1872,Edible Fishes,113)

SENIOR Amongst the sea-fishes fit for food there are ... aua, rock cod, wrasse, and patiki; ... (1880,Travel & Trout,288)

The fish for eating are hapuka, Oligorus gigas; rock cods, Percis colias; tarakihi, (1885,TrNZI,17/198) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

Rock-cod or Blue-cod - <.I>Percis colias. NUMBER OF FISH RECORDED - 6,286. LOCALITIES - Reported from all the stations (1892,TrNZI,24/209) [NOTES: (Thomson)]

... hundreds of young red-cod, rarii (Lotella bacchus), and what I believe are young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru (Percis colias). The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length, and the rawaru, or, as the natives here call them, toitoi' orpanepane', from 2 in. to 6 in. long. (1903,TrNZI,35/319) [NOTES: (Mair Fish in Piako River)]

WILLIAMS kopukopu ... 1. Percis colias, rock-cod. = rawaru, pakirikiri. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,162)

SPEIGHT For instance the Rock-cod (Parapercis colias) a comparatively rare line fish in Canterbury waters, has spiny-rayed fins ... (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,200) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 200]

PARROTT This [Blue Cod] is the fish known to Captain Cook as the Coal-fish', and it has frequently been referred to by older authors as theRock Cod'. It was known to the Maoris as Rawaru' orPakirikiri'. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,141)

2 n. (obsolete) hapuku

SORENSON COD, ROCK (a) Scientific name: Lotella rhacinus. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Rock Cod; Kelp Cod. (c) Other common names: Parrotfish; Soldiers, Kelp, Kelpies, Moreporks, Marblefish, Maori Chief, Wrasse, Bourbon, Guffy, Cloudy Bay Cod, Rasp. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,18)

English Name Rock Cod Native Name Whapuka (1849,NZ Journal,9/125) [NOTES: (quoting Anglo Maori Warder Oct 5)]

SHORTLAND The `hapuku' or rock cod as it is called by the whalers - the finest fish of these seas. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,131)

HAY ... whapuka or rock-cod. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/151)

3 n. a dark purplish-brown morid cod of coastal reefs. Also called Cloudy Bay cod, kelp cod, and (inappropriately) southern hake.

WEEKES The emigrants have been engaged in fishing over the vessels side [in Cloudy Bay] with a hook and line, catching a number of ling and rockcod (Mar 24, 1841,Journal) [NOTES: 1841 Mar 24 Weekes Jnl in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 39]
