A specimen of this rather rare fish [Physiculus (Lotella) rhacinus (Forster)] was captured off Cape Saunders early in 1924, and kept in captivity for several months. Before its death my curiosity was aroused by one of the staff calling it a rock-cod' and stating that that was the name used in the north even where theblue-cod' Parapercis colias was also caught. (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/369) [NOTES: (Young)]

PHILLIPPS Lotella rhacinus (Forster). ROCK-COD or SOUTHERN HAKE (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,23,1971 ed.)

Lotella rhacinus (Forster). Rock cod. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/405) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM ROCK COD or SOUTHERN HAKE Lotella rhacina (Bloch and Schneider) Up to 1891 this fish was universally known to scientists and fishermen as Hake, then for some unknown reason E. R. Waite (Records of the Canterbury Museum, Vol. 1, No. 3) transferred the name Hake to Merluccius gayi, with Whiting as a second alternative common name. ... The most common name among Otago fishermen was Rock Cod, because this fish favours a rocky habitat. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,172)

DOOGUE & MORELAND ROCK COD ... Other names: Lotella rhacinus; Cloudy Bay cod, southern hake. (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,210)

SORENSON COD, ROCK (a) Scientific name: Lotella rhacinus . (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Rock Cod; Kelp Cod. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,18)

PAUL Rock cod Lotella rhacinus ... Common in rocky habitats around New Zealand. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,59)

HULME Simon made the acquaintance of barracouta, ling, trumpeter, and rig, and red cod, kelp cod, and rock cod. (1983,Bone People, The,251) [NOTES: -]

4 n. Pseudophycis bachus, red cod (q.v.).

Rock Cod, or Red Cod, is very common, occurring in the Harbour in large shoals ... (1877,TrNZI,9/486) [NOTES: (P. Thomson, Otago)]

5 n. a rockfish, Acanthoclinus quadridactylus

DOOGUE & MORELAND ROCKFISH ... Other names: Acanthoclinus quadridactylus; rock cod, butterfish; taumaka (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,283)

AYLING ROCKFISH (Rock cod) Acanthoclinus quadridactylus ... The rockfish is a small elongate species, often called rock cod by small children exploring tide pools. (1982,Collins Guide,209,1984 ed.)

Rock College¶

1 n. Field Punishment Centre [Cf budgie cage 1946 JNZ Middle East glossary. Field Punishment Centre, Budgie Cage, Rock College. WWII] (See Cf budgie cage)

2 n. prison [(prisoners')]

HARCOURT I found that some of the alumni of `Rock College' - as the inmates call H.M. Prison, Mt. Eden .... (1942,Parson in Prison,164)

McGILL rock college prison. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

rock fern¶

n. Cheilanthes humilis (formerly sieberi).

(And) Cheilanthes Sieberi (Jul 1920,Victorian Naturalist)

DOBBIE (And) (Nov 21, 1921,Letters)

BROWNSEY & SMITH-DODSWORTH Cheilanthes humilis. (1989,NZ Ferns & Allied Plants)

In dry rocky habitats away from the sea, especially on the eastern side of the South Island, another characteristic assemblage of ferns can be found. This includes the rock fern ()Cheilanthes sicheri), woolly cloak fern (C. distans), blanket fern (Pleurosorus rutifolius), and Pellaea callidirupium. (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/73)

rock gurnard¶

n. = sea perch

WILSON Most gurnards are brownish-red but larger specimens are often bright red on top and white below. The Stargazer is sometimes known as the Mud Gurnard, River Gurnard or Mud-Grubber Gurnard but is in fact no relation. Similarly the Sea Perch is sometimes called a Rock Gurnard - (1981,Fisherman's Bible,118)

rock it into¶

phr.

SARGESON rocking it into her properly: being too savagely vindictive towards her; rocking it into the Government, censuring the Government. (1964,Collected Stories,302)

rock lily¶

n. Arthropodium cirratum ; rengarenga.

Renga-renga lily or rock lily (Arthropodium cirratum) - Tufted, fleshy leaves are surmounted by numerous, usually arching stems bearing many clusters of white, pendulous flowers. (Nov 11, 1993,Evening Post,14)

Arthropodium cirratum (1902,TrNZI,34 :)

LAING & BLACKWELL Arthropodium cirrhatum (The Curled Arthropodium ) ... [102] usually known as the Rock-lily. [(Renga-lily)]. . RENGA(-) LILY Arthropodium cirratum see also RENGARENGA ... [104] Arthropodium cirrhatum (The Curled Arthropodium) ... Usually known as the Rock-lily. [(Renga-lily)]. (1907,Plants of NZ,100,1940 , p. 104 ed.)

(And) Arthropodium cirratum rock lily (1916,Official Trade Register of Nurserymen)

DUNCAN & DAVIES (And) Arthropodium cirratum rock lily (1917,Descriptive Catalogue)

COCKAYNE (And) Arthropodium cirratum rock-lily (1919,NZ Plants,2nd ed. ed.)

COCKAYNE (And) Arthropodium cirratum rock-lily (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

Arthropodium cirratum rock-lily (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology)

DUNCAN & DAVIES ... (And) Arthropodium cirratum rock lily (1925,NZ Native Trees)

The [cliff-hanging] plants chosen were the poor knights lily (Xeronema callistemon) and ringaringa, also called the New Zealand rock lily (Arthropodium cirrhatum). (May 10, 1973,Dominion,5/1)

BROOKER et al. Arthropodium cirrhatum (Forst.f.) R.Br. Common name: Rock lily Maori names: Rengarenga, maikaika, maika ka (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,63)

Then there's the rock lily or rengarenga (Arthropodum cirratum, from the asphodel family) and Cordyline australis, our beloved cabbage tree, which is also known as the palm lily, probably from its great panicles of heavily-scented bloom. (Mar 31, 2000,Dominion,18)

On the rocky knoll near the middle of the [Karewa] islaet the rengrenga, or rock-lily (Arthropodium cirratum), grows in profusion (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/187)

rock lobster¶

n. the marine crayfish Jasus verreauxi and J. edwardsii; a trade name for (esp. export) crayfish tails

rock lobster n 1 : SPINY LOBSTER 2 : the flesh of the Cape crawfish esp. when canned or frozen for use as food (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1966)

(1969,NZ News,5/3) [NOTES: [crayfish under new regs]]

BURTON New Zealand crayfish are usually marketed in the United States as `rock lobster'. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,66)

[species name] rock lobster .. [scientific name] Jasus edwardsii .. [other name(s)] crayfish, crayfish spiny, crays red, lobster red, red crayfish, spiny rock lobster (1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

rock lobster NZ kind of crayfish. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,660) [NOTES: cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 998]]

(Lament for a Crayfish') A thoroughbred crustacean,/ A well-bred cray, 'tis true,/ Yet Standards put a tag on me,/Rock-lobster', Sir, to you!' (1979,SANZ in Reverse,13)

rock melon¶

2 n.

LUSH Blanche bought 8 fine *rock melons for 4/0... Blanche has reduced 6 of them into jam. (Mar 16, 1871,Journal,105) [NOTES: 1975 edition]

At sales during the week prices ranged as follows .. rock melons 3s 6d doz. (Mar 10, 1900,Taranaki Herald,3)

GARDEN SEEDS, ex Spray. - On SALE by the Undersigned, TEN PACKAGES, each containing the following Varieties of NEW GARDEN SEEDS .. Rock Melon, Water Melon ... (Jul 31, 1852,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,89)

Melons, Rock or Musk. It does not pay to sow melon seeds too early. (1949,Brett's Gardening Guide,87)

SCARROW & GOODING Try growing rock melons; these have a delicious perfumed flesh quite different from water melons. (1983,Scarrow's Guide to Gardening in NZ,112)

McDONNELL The Rock Melons can be hollowed out and used as a receptacle for fruit salad. (1991,Grow Your Own Fruit & Vegetables,86)

Rock melons were offering today at 4s a case. (Feb 26, 1910,Evening Post,8)

rock melon n. U.S., Austral., & N.Z. another name for cantaloupe. (1982,Collins Compact Dictionary,998) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 421]]

rock oyster¶

n. Saxostrea glomerata (See also Auckland rock oyster)

BURTON The New Zealand rock oyster lives at the tide marks on rocks and wharf piles in the northern half of the North Island. ... Compared with the plump and juicy Bluff oyster, the rock oyster seems a rather withered specimen, ... (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,60)

... the sand banks were well store'd [sic] with Cockles and clams and in many places were Rock Oysters 2 [fn2] Saxostrea glomerata (Nov 11, 1769,Cook's Journals,I/197,1955 ed.)

PARKINSON A long-boat full of rock oysters, too, were brought aboard of us at one time, ... (Nov 11, 1769,Journal,105)

McNAB Q. What sort of fish did you obtain at New Zealand? A.A great variety and many of the fish are very good. There are snappers (schnapper), mullet, bream, soles, eels, and a great quantity of cockles, and some rock oysters. There is likewise abundance of lobsters, or a fish between a lobster and a craw-fish. (1908,Historical Records,1/550) [NOTES: 1821 May Ensign McCrae's Evidence before Commissioner Bigge in 1908 McNab Historical Records]

Whilst it was being prepared I strayed along the beach knocking off rock oysters (native name tio). (1940,Establishment of New Plymouth Settlement,119) [NOTES: c1846 Weekes My Island in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth]

WILLIAMS Ngakihi, ... rock-oyster. (1892,Dictionary of the Maori Language,110)

The rock-oyster is found over a large area on these coasts, ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,5)

Rock oysters are found around Auckland and northwards principally ... In the straits between the Bluff and Stewart Island large beds exist of the flat, or mud oyster. (1913,Country Work,25)

WILLIAMS Ngakihi, Ostria glomerata, rock-oyster. [1957/228 Saxostrea glomerata ] (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,265)

BEATTIE When I was a child [c1840s] I gathered rock oysters at Waikouaiti .. . (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,49)

McLINTOCK Rock oyster .. .. tio, tio para, tio-repe .. .. Crassostrea glomerata (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

BEAGLEHOLE fn. see Stewart Island Oyster. (1962,Banks Journal,1/431)

NATUSCH Both rock and mud oysters are found all round New Zealand, but only the North Island rock oyster (restricted to the Auckland district) and the Foveaux Strait mud oyster (not confined to Foveaux Strait) are taken commercially. Our three main oysters are Ostrea hefferdi (southern rock oyster), O. sinuata (mud oyster, ... ), and Saxostrea glomerata (northern rock oyster). (1967,Animals of NZ, The,79)

The rock oyster is native to New Zealand, but similar to the Sydney rock oyster. ... The rock oyster is also known as the Auckland rock oyster. (May 1985,Metro,47/28)

[species name] oysters rock .. [scientific name] Saxostrea glomerata .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Rock oyster Saccostrea glomerata ... Native to New Zealand, but very similar to the Sydney rock oyster. ... Once present ... around the northern North Island ... but has now been largely replaced by the Pacific oyster. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,164)

The North Island rock oyster is preferred by many people. (Feb 24, 1909,Otago Witness,57)

It is useless to tell the people who know about the Rock Oyster and its merits; but those who have never tried them should do so and discover their nutricious [sic], stimulating qualities. (May 8, 1914,Evening Post,2)

Rock Oysters - 4d per dozen. (Jun 30, 1868,Evening Post,3)

TINNE These rock-oysters are very small, but deliciously flavoured; ... (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,89)

BARLOW The rough corrugated shelled rock oyster ... are very abundant in places ... (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,134)

rock painting¶

n. a prehistoric Maori or moa-hunter painting

Hamish, nicknamed Owl because he wears glasses, has discovered Maori rock paintings in the Seven Sentinels, a dominating rock formation high above the station. (Mar 9, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

rock shelter¶

n. [cf Theo Schoon Maori rock shelter]

MORRIS Rock-shelter, n. a natural cave-dwelling of the aborigines.[1891 (1898,Austral English,392)

1 n. (Rural) an overhang or rock camp, used by musterers, hunters and stock for shelter.

FARMER On the Coast, rock shelters were common. They came in all shapes and sizes and ranged from spacious weatherproof shelters to those that wouldn't make a decent dog kennel. (1994,Best Job Ever, The,105)

rock snot¶

n. Didymosphenia geminata [Internet search Feb 2006: also used N Amer (Missouri), Austral] (See didymo,river snot)

There are fears that Didymosphenia geminata - known as "rock snot" - will choke waterways. (Sep 30, 2005,Dominion Post,A5)

The spread of "rock snot" algae in South Island rivers is a foot-and-mouth-level emergency that could devastate New Zealand's clean, green image, environmental scientists say. (Oct 1, 2005,Dominion Post,A2)

Known as "rock snot", didymo forms slimy, thick mats on riverbeds and rocks. (Sep 29, 2005,NZ Herald,A7)

rock spider¶

n. (informal) a child molester

The most despised group of inmates in the prison are child molesters, known by a variety of labels, including freaks, nonces, boofheads, Lesters, rock spiders, mullocks and K.F.s. (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

rock spike¶

n. component of post rammer

Post rammer, four way tilt, side shift, collapsible mast, rock spike, had little work, $10,500 + GST. (Nov 29, 2003,Hawke's Bay Today,C15)

rock trout¶

n. Galaxias alepidotus, a freshwater fish, often a kokopu, one of a number of misnamed `trout'. (See kokopu)

It is interesting to note that this fish belongs to the same family (Galaxiidae) as the common kokopo, or New Zealand rock trout, and the inanga (the parent of the New Zealand whitebait), but has been placed in a separate genus (Neochanna) on account of the absence of the paired ventral fins, which characteristic occurs, on the contrary, in all species of the genus Galaxias. (Oct 4, 1930,Evening Post,7)

DIEFFENBACH 61. Galaxias alepidotus. - Cuv., ... Named by the natives of Dusky Bay He-para,' and by Cook's sailorsRock-trout.' [Williams 262 Para a fresh-water fish similar to a ko[o]kopu.] (1843,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/219) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna (Richardson's Fish) in 1843 Dieffenbach NZ 2/219]

HECTOR Also, the settlers of at least some parts of New Zealand have dignified the larger kinds [of Galaxias] with the name of Trout', orRock Trout.' (1872,Edible Fishes,128) [NOTES: 1867 Nov `Ann. and Mag. of Natural History' (Dr.Gunther[u-umlaut] in 1872 Hector Edible Fishes 128]

Also, the settlers in at least some parts of New Zealand have dignified the larger kinds [of Galaxias spp, kokopu] with the name of trout' orrock-trout' (1903,TrNZI,35/317) [NOTES: (Hector)]

BEATTIE Panako - The collector [sc Beattie] asked a Maori about this fish, as it was a new name to him, and received the reply: `The panako is the rock trout, and is nearly extinct. It looks like the kokopara in shape, but it is black in colour.' (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,63)

GRAHAM MINNOW or WHITEBAIT (INANGA) Austrocobitis attenuatus (Jenyns) ... For a long time it has been known to the Maori and to Europeans that our New Zealand Whitebait is the young of a native freshwater fish commonly known as Minnow, or Inanga or Hiwi to the Maori, and erroneously called a Trout. ... The early settlers called it Maori Trout, Native Trout, Rock Trout and Minnow. But it is not a Trout. Nor is it a Minnow, through it resembles the English freshwater Minnow. While the name Trout is not correct, it is and will always be known as such by farmers and naturalists. In the Bay of Plenty, Whitebait is known to the Maori as Porohoe. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,118)

rock wren¶

n. a small bird found amid rocks and streams of the Southern Alps.

[Barrington] also dined on kakapo, white-faced herons, kaka, weka, robins, blue ducks, rock wrens - "T'was the smallest joints I ever saw," he later wrote of the tiny perching bird - but is most famed for eating a rat on one of his many desperate and perilous journeys across the Southern Alps. (Dec 9, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48)

HUTTON 16. XENICUS LONGPIPES. Gml. Rock Wren. ... 17.XENICUS GILVIVENTRIS. Pelz. Rock Wren. X. Haasti, BULLER. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,7)

BUL;LER XENICUS GILVIVENTRIS. (ROCK-WREN.) ... [South Island only] (1873,Birds of New Zealand,117,1888 2nd edn 1/111 ed.)

HAAST The remarkable small rock wren ( Xenicus gilviventris ), of which I had obtained several specimens previously, was also found to enhabit [sic] the large taluses of debris ... on the sides of the high mountains. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,146)

BEATTIE I never saw the native quail, the cuckoo nor the morepork in the Central [Otago, c1860s], but I saw the sparrow-hawk, the rock wren, and plenty of hawks and pihoihoi (ground larks). (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,121)

Amongs[t?] the creepers there are the bush-wren, the rock-wren, the rifleman and the yellow-headed native canary. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,195)

Xenicus gilviventris Pelz. Rock-wren. On the authority of Mr. E. H. Atkinson and Major R. A. Wilson, and the writer, this easily overlooked species is recorded from three localities in the Southern Alps. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/88) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

ROCK-WREN (Xenicus gilviventris). - Always rare in this district [sc. North Canterbury]. (1928,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,9/187) [NOTES: (Hope)]

GUTHRIE-SMITH THE ROCK WREN (Xenicus Gilviventris) [title] [in Westland National Park] (1936,NZ Naturalist,143)

I have ... seen only one Bush Wren, two Rifle Wrens, two Saddlebacks, and no Rock Wrens [in Nelson]. Notes (Buller) (1893,TrNZI,25/59)

The rock-wren and the bush-wren resemble each other generally in the colours of their plumage, but the rock-wren is much rarer. (1924,Otago Witness,6)

Whilst up on the barren country, my heart rejoiced to see a fine colony of rock wrens (1935,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,4/107)

rock wren n 2 : a small short-tailed passerine bird (Xenicus gilviventris) of New Zealand (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1966)

FALLA et al. ROCK WREN Xenicus gilviventris (1966,Birds of New Zealand,194)

McLINTOCK ...one of the primitive New Zealand wrens, the rock wren (Xenicus gilviventris). Ibid. 3/689 WREN, ROCK ( Xenicus gilviventris ). This bird is found in the South Island on exposed slopes of the Southern Alps, among rocks above the forest line. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/207)

NATUSCH The green rock wren, X[enicus] gilviventris , lives near rocky and stream beds in the Southern Alps. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,277)

241. Xenicus gilviventris Pelzeln, 1867 Rock Wren (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,64,1980 ed.)

Rock Wren Xenicus gilviventris PELZELN, 1867 ... European explorers discovered the rock wren in the Southern Alps in the 1860s. The Maoris have no name for the bird and even now it has little contact with people. [Confined to South Island.] (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,266)

Rock wrens in Fiordland prized kakapo feathers above all others for their nests, and this passion was exploited by searchers to ascertain if kakapo were in an area (Mar 2002,NZ Geographic,56/39)

Another rare bird which has been seen is the beautiful little rock wren. (Sep 7, 1942,Evening Post,4)

rock-hop¶

v.

HOLDEN Sneaking along, he rock-hopped a small stream. Ibid. 128 When I reached the creek I rock-hopped my way down it . (1982,Wild Pig,75)

rock-hopper¶

n.

WILSON ROCK-HOPPING One of the most exciting, dangerous and rewarding types of fishing is undoubtedly rock-fishing. The rock-hopper gets added spice in his fishing by his sometimes death-defying attempts to get to the best possie and also to retrieve the fish from a low ledge before the next wave. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,183)

rock-hopping¶

n.

Our first day began at 8am, with four hours of rock-hopping up the north branch of the Hapuku River to reach the foot of the climb. (Nov 23, 2002,Dominion Post,F12)

And I've been doing quite a lot of rock-hopping. (Feb 3, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B8)

n.

THOMSON [Photo caption] Rock-hopping to keep dry feet dry. The creek bed is typical of Canterbury high-country streams. With experience one rivals the mountain goat. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,XII)

WILSON (1981,Fisherman's Bible,183) [NOTES: ROCK-HOPPING One of the most exciting, dangerous and rewarding types of fishing is undoubtedly rock-fishing. The rock-hopper gets added spice in his fishing by his sometimes death-defying attempts to get to the best possie and also to retrieve the fish from a low ledge before the next wave.]

rockchopper¶

rocker¶

n. [(goldmining)]

These rockers are massive structures of wood and iron, and rock in excavations made for the purpose. The rockers work backward and forward in sockets on the edges of their beds. Between each rocker is a strong beam; thus the whole line is connected, so that any motion imparted to one affects all the rockers. (Jun 2, 1876,Daily Southern Cross,1)

PARTIES proceeding to the Gold Field will do well to inspect and provide themselves with one of Jearrad's gold rockers or Long Toms on an approved principle. (Dec 21, 1852,Daily Southern Cross,2)

... `the rocker' for concentrating tailings. (1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,20)

... when sufficient water was not available, the use of a tom (or rocker) had to be resorted to. (1906,NZ Mining Handbook,8)

... when sufficient water was not available, the use of a tom (or rocker) had to be resorted to. (1906,NZ Mining Handbook,8)

n. a boulder poised so that it rocks if trodden on. [(? trampers' and mountaineers': or nonce-word)]

PASCOE [Letter to Strauchon] It is not so much the greasy nature of the boulders, as the fact that numbers of them are `rockers' which makes travelling rather dangerous. (1982,Mr Explorer Douglas,168)

rocket¶

n. a scolding, a shaking up (John Thomson)

Some of the principals are fairly good, whilst the majority of the other performers really deserve a `rocket' (Jun 3, 1897,Otago Witness,39/5)

2 n.

HILGENDORF ROCKET (Diplotaxis muralis), also called yellow rocket and wall mustard, is an annual found in gardens and waste places in scattered localities throughout. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,93,1967 ed.)

rockfish¶

n. ? a scorpionfish

If we turn out a crowd of small fry in a strange place where there may be no suitable food but a horde of wrasse and rockfish for enemies, it is a forlorn hope for one of them to survive. (May 4, 1899,Otago Witness,62)

PARKINSON All the coves of this bay teem with fish of various kinds, such as cuttle-fish, large breams, ... small grey breams, small and large barracootas, flying gurnards, horse-mackarel, dog-fish, soles, dabs, mullets, drums, scorpenas or rock-fish, cole-fish, the beautiful fish called chimera, and shags. [In the Stout Collection copy, Victoria University Library, an early 19th C. or late 18th C. hand has added: `*Baracootas, a fish remarkably smooth about 7 or 8 foot long [dagger] Flying Gurnards, a flying fish, of a remarkable fine Gold Colour. [double dagger] Chimeras, a fish of Silver Colour - [triple dagger] Drum fish, so call'd from the noise they make, - ' (Jan 15, 1770,Journal,114)

ACHERON ...there has been a great catch of fish ...and some red rock fish - (May 1850,Journal) [NOTES: 1850 May Acheron Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 391]

(1870,TrNZI,2/325) [NOTES: (Travers)]

[index to common names 283-293] rockfish 1317-28] (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

n. taumaka

Acanthoclinus quadridactylylus (Bloch and Schn.). (1938,TrRSNZ,68/415) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

POWELL ROCKFISH (Acanthoclinus quadridactylylus ), Taumaka of the Maoris, is the small brownish-olive fish, about 7 inches in length, which is found lurking under boulders at low tide. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,72)

GRAHAM Rockfish (Taumaka) Acanthoclinus quadridactylylus (Bloch and Schn.) (Syn. Blennius littoreus Bloch and Schn. Acanthoclinus fuscus Jenyns, and A. taumaka Clarke)... Rockfish (Taumaka) Acanthoclinus (Taumakoides) trilineatus Griffin (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,411) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 411]

GRAHAM ROCKFISH (TAUMAKA) Acanthoclinus quadridactylylus (Bloch and Schneider) ... [ibid. 322] Those who do know this fish call it Rockfish, but I prefer the Maori name, Taumaka. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,320)

DOOGUE & MORELAND ROCKFISH ... Other names: Acanthoclinus quadridactylus; rock cod, butterfish; taumaka (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,283)

McL.INTOCK Rockfish .. taumaka .. .. Acanthoclinus quadridactylylus (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

MORELAND ROCKFISH [Acanthoclinus quadridactylylus ] ... Taumaka, a Maori name, is not widely used. (1967,Marine Fishes,20)

NATUSCH Family ACANTHOCLINIDAE (rockfishes). The rockfish Acanthoclinus ..., a long, straight fish with the tips of the dorsal fin running parallel to the back, and to the line of the anal and belly fin-tips, is common as a small fish of rock pools, where it hides under stones and seaweed; bigger ones occur in deeper water. (1967,Native Animals of NZ,229)

WILSON ROCKFISH Probably our most common shallow-water fish the ubiqutous little Rockfish is well-known to almost every child who has frequented the seashore. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,199)

AYL;ING ROCKFISH (Rock cod) Acanthoclinus quadridactylylus ... The rockfish is a small elongate species, often called rock cod by small children exploring tide pools. (1982,Collins Guide,209,1984 ed.)

PAUL Rockfish Family Acanthoclinidae. The rockfish, Acanthoclinus quadridactylylus , is dark green with a pale head and stripe, and lives under stones or in crevices in rock pools. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,135)

2 n. kelpfish, rock cod, hiwihiwi

SHERRIN HIWI HIWI (Chironemus Fergussoni). ... It is highly prized by the Natives as a food fish, who say it is principally caught about the East Cape and Tologa [sic] Bay. ... They describe it as a `rock fish', freckled, with white spots, ... (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,45)

4 n.

SORENSON DOGFISH, SPINY (a) Scientific name: Squalus acanthias. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Rockfish. (c) Other common names: Spiky dogfish, Spiny dogs, Southern dogfish, Spotted dogfish, Milky dogs. (d) Principal localities where taken: Largely restricted to cooler southern waters, ranging north to Hawke Bay in winter months. Plentiful off the Otago coast. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,19)

[species name] red bait .. [scientific name] Emmelichthys .. [other name(s)] rock salmon, rockfish, bonnetmouth, job fish (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)
