rockgas¶

n. compressed propane gas (LPG). [Jim writes: Proprietary but (?) in wider use cf. Zip. No dictionary reference. DEH adds: In OED without citation : rock gas, natural gas obtained by boring through rock. Webster's 3rd refers one to "natural gas" gas issuing from the earth's crust through natural openings or bored wells esp. any of various combustible gaseous mixtures that when in the dry state contain largely methane and in the wet state in association with petroleum contain also higher hydrocarbons ( as ethane, propane, butanes and pentanes)...]

McNAUGHTON "I use rock gas for the cooking and hot water"... They looked at the rock gas cylinder there. 'Rock Gas', it said on it, sure enough. Ibid. 136 He used one of the rock gas rings which never gave any trouble, and stood shivering as he waited for the jug to heat. (1986,Countless Signs,132) [NOTES: From Owen Marshall (1982) Body and Soul]

rockhopper penguin¶

n. [Eudyptes chrysocome; also rock-hopper, and rock hopper; aka tufted penguin, crested penguin]

Additions to the collections in the museum this week include eggs of the .. rock hopper penguin ... (Jul 30, 1912,Evening Post,3)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Certainly two species,- the Yellow-eyed and the Blue Penguin, locally known as Rock Hopper, breed on Stewart Island, and I believe near Pegasus there is also one colony of the Tufted Penguin. (1914,Mutton Birds & Other Birds,59)

Rockhopper Penguin Eudyptes chrysocome (Forster, 1781). ... CIRCUMPOLAR ... OTHER NAMES: Crested penguin, tufted penguin. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,49)

During the 1980s and 1990s, many of the world's breeding populations of rockhopper penguins - including those on Antipodes and Campbell Islands and in the Auckland Islands, in New Zealand's subantarctic - went into severe decline. (Sep 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 65/14)

Two kinds of penguins - the rock-hopper, and the crested king penguin - swarmed here. (Mar 30, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,96)

This is the list of eggs Dr Fulton wants to order to make a complete collection for the Museum .. Rock Hopper, Tufted Penguin ... (Sep 20, 1905,Otago Witness,88)

This is the list of eggs Dr Fulton wants to order to make a complete collection for the museum ... Rock Hopper, Tufted Penguin ... (Sep 20, 1905,Otago Witness,88)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Certainly two species,- the Yellow-eyed and the Blue Penguin, locally known as Rock Hopper, breed on Stewart Island, and I believe near Pegasus there is also one colony of the Tufted Penguin. (1914,Mutton Birds & Other Birds,59)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Certainly two species,- the Yellow-eyed and the Blue Penguin, locally known as Rock Hopper, breed on Stewart Island, and I believe near Pegasus there is also one colony of the Tufted Penguin. (1914,Mutton Birds & Other Birds,59)

12. a. Eudyptes chrysocome chrysocome (Forster, 1781) Rockhopper Penguin (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,17,1980 ed.)

FALLA et al. ROCKHOPPER PENGUIN Eudyptes crestatus (1966,Birds of New Zealand,23)

Rockhopper Penguin Eudyptes chrysocome (Forster, 1781). ... CIRCUMPOLAR ... OTHER NAMES: Crested penguin, tufted penguin. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,49)

In the 1940s, there were a million rockhopper penguins on Campbell Island. (Apr 3, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,19)

[Victoria penguins] are much more entitled to the name `rock-hopper' than the other species (Pygoscelis taeniata), which are mush less plentiful and more lumbering in their gait. (1895,TrNZI,27/571)

rocking¶

adj. drunk

LORD We say a man is . . ./ Over the plimsoll',rocking', or that `you're on the roll' - (1921,Ballads of Bung 'Stunology',1976 ed.)

rockling¶

n. (See ling)

AYLING ROCKLING Gaidropsarus novaezelandiae ... The rockling is a small cod found in rock pools and in shallow coastal waters. (1982,Collins Guide,149,1984 ed.)

n. [fish]

MORRIS Rock-ling , n. a marine fish. The Australian R. is Genypterus australis Cast1n., family Ophidiida. The European R. belongs to the genera Onos and Rhinonemus , formerly Motella . Of the genus Genypterus , Gunther says they have an excellent flesh, like cod, well adapted for curing. At the Cape they are known by the name of `Klipvisch,' and in New Zealand as Ling , or Cloudy-Bay Cod. (1898,Austral English,392)

PHILLIPPS Gaidropsarus novae-zelandiae .[sic: no names] (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,24,1971 ed.)

GRAHAM Rock Ling Gaidropsarus novaezelandiae (Hector) (Syn. Motella pacificus Hector, 9th. Rept. Colon. Mus. 1874, 8, not of Temminck and Schegel) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,404) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham]

rockling n , pl rocklings also rockling [rock + ling] 1 : any of several small rather elongate marine cods (family Gadidae); esp : a fish ( Gadus mustela or Motella mustela ) that is common in tide pools along European coasts and has four barbels on the snout and one beneath the chin - called also five-bearded rockling 2 : an Australian and New Zealand fish (genus Genypterus ) of the family Ophidiidae (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1966)

MORELAND LING [ Genypterus blacodes ] ... Also known as rock ling (Australia) and hokarari and hoka (Maori). (1967,Marine Fishes,36)

PAUL The other gadid (true) cod in New Zealand is the rockling, Gaidropsaurus novaezelandiae a small pinkish brown, eel-like fish with one chin and two snout barbels, found under rocks in tide pools and shallow water. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,56)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] rockling 799-801, 814 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] rockling, bearded 816 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Rockwood lily¶

n. Ranunculus lyalli , mountain lily

POTTS (And) Ranunculus Lyallii Rockwood lily *Probably through being found on the Rockwood run in the Malvern Hills, Canterbury. See POO, p. 76. (1882,Out in the Open)

During Victorian times Ranunculus lyalli, the Mt Cook or Mountain Buttercup, was known in England as the "Rockwood Lily."... The exact connection between the "Rockwood Lily" and a Canterbury sheep station presents an interesting puzzle... Rockwood Station, owned by Henry Phillips, was one of the earliest established homesteads... However, the precise connection with Rockwood.. has yet to be discovered. (Feb 11, 1988,Press, The,10)

rocky¶

n. the brush-tailed rock wallaby

Kawau's fourth and most exotic wallaby species, the brush-tailed rock wallaby, or "rocky", may number around 1000. Rockies stick to the Kawau cliffs, occasionally making their way up coastal gullies to forage. This striking orange and chocolate brown-coloured wallaby even scuttles up sloping puriri trunks. (Apr 13, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

rod¶

n.

Rod (storey rod)- Board upon which the chief measurements (usually heights) are marked full size and from which the builder can set out the construction, particularly applying to storey height, brickwork, weatherboarding, sills and lintels. [in pencil: US only]. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,93)

rodingite¶

n. (Geology)

They described their finds and gave them names based on the local geography - dunite from Dun Mountain, and the semi-precious Rodingite from the Roding River. (1990,Tramping in South Island Forest Parks,16)

roe-roe¶

n. early spg of RAURAU

EARP In the [alluvial bush land], which is wooded chiefly with pukateas, kaikateas , and rata trees, and thick underbrush of konine (fuchsia) or roe-roe, kaua kaua (or pepper), &c., entwined with kuriwau or supple-jack, ... (1852,Handbook for Emigrants,230) [NOTES: 1852 Wellington Gazette in Earp Hand-Book for Intending Emigrants 230]

n. [[check that could possibly be roi fernroot]] (See raurau)

roger rum¶

n.

One o'clock in the afternoon saw us on the bank of the creek, eating very wet sugar mixed with "roger rum." (1937,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,VI/105)

Pemmican stew and soup went down - well "watered" with a little Roger Rum. Perhaps this "panther's milk" was the cause of early slumber. (1934,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,III/4)

Rogernome¶

n.

The Rogernomes are set to abolish import licensing, lower tariff barriers and level the playing field. (Oct 8, 1993,Independent (Auckland),10)

[Hdg] Rogernomes may no longer be prophets in their own country but there's still money to be made exporting that expertise (Oct 8, 1993,Independent (Auckland),27)

The Rogernomes of 20 years ago, like aging men who still use Brylcreem [sic], are pitifully trapped in a timewarp. (Sep 10, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

But even many post-Rogernomes, typically trained in the ideal of the US economy, think we are too small and too distant to survive. (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

The Rogernomes have failed to capture the hearts and minds of the young, just as they failed to persuade the rest of us to change their views. (Mar 25, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

The problem was the selfishness, stupidity and blinkered social and political vision of the Rogergnomes. (Jun 29, 1992,Dominion,6)

You even get the odd cadaver still who claims to be "value free" like some ghost Rogernome. (Jul 18, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

Dunne is a surviving Rogernome whg now boasts that he left the Labour Party when it attempted to disown its neoliberal past, a position forced upon it by sheer electoral logic. (Aug 10, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

It would not surprise me if every dyed-in-the wool Reaganist, Bushian, Rogergnome and royalist in Aotearoa-New Zealand hasn't had a coronary over Helen Clark's proposal for a constitutional review ... (Nov 17, 2004,NZ Herald,A16)

But Rogernomes, having little respect for intellectual quality inconsistent with their ideology, penalised those who identified the flaws in their approach, the struggle collapsed, and we end up with shallow meaningless "research" such as that released by Act. (Feb 7, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

.. along with thousands of Labour members who felt similarly betrayed by the policies of the fourth Labour government - fought a long and bitter retreat against the relentless advance of the Rogernomes. (Jul 2, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

Rogernomical¶

adj.

For them [sc. the middle class] there is the growing feeling of having been cheated, of having been led to expect (by social conditioning, by Rogernomical hype) that things would be better for them. (Aug 7, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

[Lange] caught the real public mood again by slowing down the Rogernomical juggernaut before it left the planet entirely. (Aug 27, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

The former leader writer for the New Zealand Herald is never far from the surface, nailing the genesis of these tracks to the "merciless" Rogernomical reforms of the 1980's, which required farmers to diversify to make ends meet. (Jul 28, 2009,Dominion Post,A11)

The former leader writer for the New Zealand Herald is never far from the surface, nailing the genesis of these tracks to the "merciless" Rogernomical reforms of the 1980's, which required farmers to diversify to make ends meet. (Jul 28, 2009,Dominion Post,A11)

Rogernomicise¶

v.

They [cool TV newsreaders] were symbols of a benign paternalism that paraded the daily doses of murder, mayhem and Muldoonism past us and wordlessly reassured us: `There, there, it won't really hurt you. ...' Whatever did happen to that old comfortable world; has it all been Rogernomicised out of existence? Happily no. What we used to call social justice and now term wimpishness still lives. (Nov 7, 1986,National Business Review,11)

Rogernomicist¶

adj.

Sure, this is time-warp thinking, and ignores the fact that (a) Labour is as Rogernomicist as ever economically and even, arguably, fiscally and (b) National and Act's policies are more similar than they are different. (Oct 8, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),P 19)

Rogernomics¶

n. a label applied to the Lange Labour administration's policies of organisational and economic reform, associated with the name of its first Finance Minister, the Hon. Roger Douglas. [also attrib.]

remember those lovely comfy far-off Rogernomics days? (Oct 14, 1993,North & South,22)

If the dreaded fiscal wolverines of Rogernomics and Ruthenasia did us one big favour, it was in systematically taking the ambush and mystique out of the Budget process. (Jun 5, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

A woman walks by a row of civil-suited servants, on her back a hairy toy monkey with a sign on its back simply stating ROGERNOMICS. (Jun 14, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

Although most of the times of "stagnation" were in the first 100 years, two long recessions have occurred in the past 50 years: the 10 years or so that followed the wool-price crash in 1966, and the seven or so years of the Rogernomics recession from 1986. (Oct 30, 2010,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

Welch identifies the princpal achievements of Clark: a rebalancing of her Rogernomics inheritance; leaving a fractious and close-to-collapse Labour Party considerably stronger than she found it; significant progressive social policies ... (Aug 15, 2009,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40)

Labour leader Helen Clark is questioning the appointment of one of the "high priests of Rogernomics and Ruthanasia" as the new head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. (Oct 13, 1998,Dominion,1)

The new difficulty arose when the Crown proposed to transfer them to the flagships of Rogernomics, the State Owned Enterprises (SOEs). (Jun 13, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

Rogernomics kicked out the props from agriculture and a huge make-believe edifice came tumbling down. (Jun 13, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

They were stopped midstream by the cuppa tea fellow and prevented from instituting the Rogercare side to Rogernomics. (Apr 14, 1996,Sunday Star Times,A10)

The arrival of Rogernomics convinced me that political life had gone well beyond a joke. (Dec 11, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

First examined by a working group in 1985, the Electricity (Hazards from Trees) Regulations have lurked in the bureaucracy and the lower reaches of various ministers' in-tray through the Anzus stand-off, Rogernomics, Ruth Richardson's Mother of All Budgets, the America's Cup win, the advent of MMP and the turn of the millennium. (Jan 30, 2000,Sunday Star Times,C8)

They speak of a time before Rogernomics and Ruthanasia, when issues were clear-cut, and people still cared enough to put their bodies on the line for something bigger than themselves. (Sep 13, 1996,Independent (Auckland),18)

We hear a lot these days about the so-called "Rogernomics", a name derived from the so-called "Reagonomics", which in turn is shorthand for "supply-side economics". Both these and "Thatchernomics" ultimately derive their inspiration from the dreaded "Friedmanite monetarism" which does not.. have anything to do with a hectoring American economist who is keen on the works of Monet, but instead has everything to do with a hectoring American economist who has, over the last 10 years, thrown millions of people out of work throughout the Western world. (Jun 15, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35)

Immigration consultancy is a whole new industry, spawned of Rogernomics and its attendant philosophies of deregulation. (Nov 19, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

You are, in fact, an entrepreneur, one of the vibrant new species expected to come away in a carpet of spring green after the bushfire of Rogernomics has razed the old and untoward. (Nov 19, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

In 1995 Kelsey's book systematically challenged that which we have come to call Rogernomics, or could call Prebblemania, and woke us from the daydream of the New Zealand success story. (May 24, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

In 2002, Colin James argued that Helen Clark's government was operating during a period of consolidation, smoothing out some of the most glaring social inequalities created by the 1984-92 policy revolution, while consolidating the key economic changes of Rogernomics and Ruthanasia. (Sep 11, 2005,NZ Herald,Herald on Sunday 4)

Take "Rogernomics". for instance. The term was born on February 23, 1985, as a headline on a Listener interview with Roger Douglas. The following week it was picked up by Bernard Lagan in the Dominion and went on from there to enter the language as a term for mad dog monetarism, Kiwi style. (Apr 3, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

The worst of these misbegotten schemes was Rogernomics, which empowered a handful of selfish and cunning manipulators to amass vast sums of money in the misguided belief that they would make some of it available to lesser mortals. (Jan 28, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),83)

I found myself thrown once more against the aforementioned forces of cultural darkness, a truly awful coalition led by Mammon and the dreaded Roger Nomic, supported by Low Common Denominator, Market Madman and Treasury Philistine. (Jul 16, 1992,Dominion,12)

It is basic to the Rogernomics creed that political action be decisive and as far as possible irreversible. (Jun 1992,Metro,76)

Echoes of Rogernomics, which split left and right factions of the Labour Party, have been reverberating through the High Court at Auckland this week. (Jun 10, 2003,Dominion Post,A11)

JAMES At the heart of the discontent was "Rogernomics" - the popular word for the economic approach of Roger Douglas. Rogernomics deregulated where Muldoon had regulated, turned over to market forces those whom Muldoon had subsidised, cut taxes where Muldoon had raised them, subjected employers and unions to the painful wage discipline of controls on the money supply, exposed Muldoon's State departments to the market by turning trading operations into corporations, and requiring some other departments to earn part of their keep by selling their services. (1989,Rogernomics,1)

What transformed the two major parties into the activist-based organisations they are today? Rogernomics and Ruthanasia. (Aug 18, 2006,Dominion Post,B4)

By the time Rogernomics and Ruthanasia had run their course, New Zealanders had lost control of their finance sector, most of their news media, and much else besides. (Sep 3, 2010,Dominion Post,B6)

If you doubt this, consider the electorate's rejection of Rogernomics in 1990, and Ruthanasia in 1993. (Feb 3, 1995,Dominion,8)

A second doubt is that the first seven years of the Rogernomics regime were disastrous, as the accompanying table shows. (Mar 12, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

Mike Lee sees these ideas as another example of "Roger politics", the phrase coined by Auckland University's Professor Richard Mulgan to describe, as Lee puts it, "the erosion of democratic organisations or their abolition - such as harbour boards, power boards, hospital boards - and the consequent diminishing of public involvement." (Apr 27, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

Rogernomist¶

adj.

Labour's Rogernomist backbones were ill-wished away and, unable to be appeased, the NewLabour dissenters were waved off crisply. (Dec 9, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

rogue¶

v. (with reference to peas) [also roguing verbal noun (below)]

WALLIS Occasionally a woman would pick something up from her table and toss it into a tin can. `Roguing peas,' said Laker. ... He had heard of the practice of roguing. In any given crop of peas it was inevitable there would be some foreign strains, some rogues, which had to be removed if the seed was to be used to grow canning peas. Some of the roguing ... was done in the paddock before harvesting ... (1963,Point of Origin,38)

rogue and villain¶

n. a shilling [rhyming slang]

I plonk 10 rogue and villains on its I suppose, home it rolls and I'm winning a crayfish. rogue and villain....shillin(g) (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

rogue ram¶

1 n. (Rural) a ram that escapes from an enclosed area to impregnate ewes.

Unfortunately a rogue ram had joined some of these ewes early and 24 of the control ewes and 22 of the treated ewes had lambed. (Jul 2004,Country-Wide,39)

roha¶

n. a stingray

DOOGUE & MORELAND SHORTTAIL STINGRAY ... Other names: Dasyatis brevicaudatus; stingray, stingaree; whai, pakaurua, oru, roha (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,192)

WILSON STINGRAY, SHORTTAIL Dasyatis brevicaudatus: ... Also known in New Zealand by the Maori name whai, pakaurua, oru and roha. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,201)

rohe¶

n. area; boundary; district; land; zone [ORIGIN: Maori, [Ma. rohe (-a) margin, territory, outfield, (sport), hand net] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 222. *Judge Durie thought this was a neo-Maori-ism, I understand]

Services are to be delivered throughout the rohe of Mataatua and as such the co-ordinator will need to demonstrate ... (Jan 18, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,15)

The bill [the Taranaki Whanaui ki Te Upoko o Te Ika) Claims Settlement Bill] outlines the key elements of the rohe. The group's rohe is defined as conforming to the boundaries of the Port Nicholson Block. (Dec 24, 2008,Dominion Post,B9)

A defining feature of the Ngai Tahu settlement was the "bolt-ons" - a deferred selection process that allowed the tribe 12 months to buy selected Crown assets, and a perpetual right of first refusal on every surplus Crown asset in its rohe, or tribal area. (Feb 10, 2001,Dominion,28)

Ngati Wai numbers about 7000. Its rohe stretches from Cape Brett in the north to Pakiri and takes in coastal islands including the Poor Knights. (Dec 13, 2005,NZ Herald,A6)

Michael King The country as a whole was divided into a notional network of rohe over which particular iwi and hapu held mana whenua or authority over the land and its resources. (2003,Penguin History of New Zealand,71)

Mana Wahine means the empowerment of women and that could be within their home, their workplace, their community and their rohe. (Apr 20, 2007,Whakatane Beacon,10)

The comments going around the rohe were, "I hope the people who've got it don't return it." (Oct 17, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

The 1870-72 Urewera expeditions were driven by a vengeful Colonial Government (also known as the Kawanatanga), desperate to track down and destroy Te Kooti Arikirangi Te Turuki and his Ringatu guerilla force then regrouping within the boundaries of the Tuhoe tribe's forested rohe. (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

rohe moana¶

n. a customary seafood-gathering area [ORIGIN: Maori, =territorial waters (P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 223); different sense here]

The customary food-gathering /rohe moana follows the coastline ... (Oct 11, 2006,Wairarapa News,36)

.. the Kairakau Lands Trust .. applied to the Minister of Fisheries for mataitai reserve within the boundaries of the Kairakau Lands Trust rohe moana. (Nov 4, 2006,Dominion Post,C15)

Rohe Potae¶

n. King Country [ORIGIN: Maori]

HUTT I... will send a message to my people... to say that the word of our fathers is to stand, and that no liquor shall come into the Rohe Potae." (1991,Maori & Alcohol,103) [NOTES: See Evening Post 8 June 1910 p. 3, quoted in Skerman The Dry Era... MA thesis Univ. Auckland, 1972, p. 131, fn. 70]

The Ringatu leader fled into the headwaters of the Waiau River country, now ultimately intent on making for the King Country (the Rohe Potae still held by the powerful Tainui Confederation under King Tawhiao Te Wherowhero)... Their simple act of wading ashore onto the western banks of the independent Te Rohe Potae effectively ended the complex New Zealand Wars. (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

rohi¶

n. (See roi)

KOHERE Even today, the Maoris of Wairoa regard rohi (loaf, or baker's bread) as the cause of a tribal calamity. (1951,Autobiography of a Maori,52)

rohito¶

n.

POLACK A very similar wood [to the Kahikatoa] exists to the southward, called Rohito, of which carved boxes, for holding small trinkets and feathers, are made by the people. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/395)

rohutu¶

n. a native shrub of the myrtle family. [ORIGIN: Maori]

More than sixty kinds of wood can be utilised for various purposes. .. There yet remain to be cited the following kinds, which, although little employed at the present time are notwithstanding very serviceable. The rohutu (myrtus bullata, Hooker), employed in cabinet work ... (May 25, 1865,Daily Southern Cross,5)

A small settlement on the Wata-roa is Rohutu, (the name of a small tree, myrtus obcordata). (Jun 17, 1908,Grey River Argus,1)

Crowe As the brush-like flowers suggest, rohutu shares the myrtle family with rata, pohutukawa, feijoa and guava. (2009,Which Native Forest Plant?,43)

They were joined by companion plants - such as Myrsine divaricata(weeping matipo), Lophomyrtus obcordata (rohutu), Coprosma propinqua (swamp coprosma), and Olearia virgata (swamp tree daisy) - to re-create an entire plant community and ultimately a self-sustaining rare plant population. (Oct 2003,Footnotes,No. 20/7)

HOOKER Rohutu, Col[enso]. Myrtus pedunculata. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767)

... the curious red fruit of the Titoki, or Titongi, (Alectryon excelsum); the fruit of the Tutu-papa (Coriaria thymifolia); of the New Zealand Bramble, Tataramoa, (Rubus australis); of two of the New Zealand Myrtles, the Ramarama (Myrtus bullata), and the Rohutu (M. pedunculata); of several species of Coprosma, - particlularly the Karamu (C. lucida), and C. robusta), of the Papaauma (C. grandifolia), and of the two littoral species, Taupata (C. retusa), and Tataraheke (C. acerosa); of the Koropuku (Gaultheria depressa); ... and of the Kareao, or Pirita, (Rhipogonum parviflorum). Ibid. 1III/50 (known hard woods.) The Mairetawhake, (Eugenia Maire); the Rohutu (Myrtus pedunculata), ... The Maire (Santalum Cunninghamii) ... the Manoao (Dacrydium Colensoi), a small hard-wooded pine ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Myrtus pedunculata Tohutu (1870,TrNZI,2/122) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

[Native name] Rohutu .. [Settlers' name] Rohutu .. [Family] Myrtaceae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 122]

FEATON MYRTUS OBCORDATA. (Hook.F.) ...The `ROHUTU'. This myrtle is common to both Islands. Ibid. 178 Rohutu [Maori name] .. Rohutu [Settlers' name] .. Myrtus obcordata .. Shrub (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,167)

COLENSO I also found a species of Myrtus, a small slender tree bearing orange-coloured juicy berries ... [The natives] call the tree rohutu. [fn] Myrtus obcordata, Rohutu (1894,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1894 Colenso Excursion Nth Isd in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 29]

LAING & BLACKWELL Myrtus pedunculata (The Pedunculate Myrtle) ... Maori name Rohutu. (1907,Plants of NZ,288,[1940, p. 305] ed.)

Myrtus obcordata Hook. f. .. Rohutu. (1928,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/144)

MARTIN The ROHUTU (M[yrtus] obcordata) is more widespread [than RAMARAMA, M. bullata] ... (1961,Flora NZ,230,1929 ed.)

... a jungle of pepperwood (Pseudowintera colorata), rohutu (Neomyrtus pedunculatus), or the crown fern (Blechnum discolor) does not represent regeneration ... but marks areas of extreme modification. (1971,VUWTC'71,55)

BROOKER et al. Lophomyrtus obcordata (Raoul) Burr. Maori name: Rohutu ... This shrub, and the closely allied Neomyrtus pedunculata (Hook.f.) Allan are found throughout New Zealand. Both are known as `rohutu', and it is possible that both were used for medicine. Lophomyrtus obcordata was known as Myrtus obcordata (Raoul) Hook.f. and Neomyrtus pedunculata was known as Myrtus pedunculata Hook.f. (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,72)

ROHUTU/ Myrtus pedunculata/ Shrub reaching 5m. (1982,Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs,10)

WILSON Neomyrtus pedunculata ROOHUTU ... Shrub or small tree up to 6 m ...(=Myrtus pedunculata). (1982,Stewart Island Plants,61)

758 Lithograph of rohutu foliage. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,31)

roi¶

n.

LEE & KENDALL Ar|oi, s. Fern-root. Ibid. 203 R|oi, s. Fern-root: (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,136)

POLACK The rourou, or plain, was covered with the roi, or fern, and the ever-flowering kaikatoa [a2-acute], which emitted a fragrant odour. Ibid. 1/397 The principal sustenance, anterior to the time of Cook, was the roi, or fern-root, answering the same purpose that bread does with us. Ibid. 1/293 The rohi, or fern, flourishes in an infinity of species - upwards of sixty distinct varieties have been noticed by botanists. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/105)

We were regaled with Rohe (Fern root). (Apr 8, 1842,Journal of Ensign Best,343,1966 ed.)

HOOKER Roi, Col[enso]. Pteris aquilina (root of). (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

CHEESEMAN 971 [Pteris aquilina. Linn. var. esculenta, Hook.f.] (1906,Manual NZ Flora,971)

Certain places became noted for `roi,' the edible rhizome. (1915,TrNZI,47/79)

rokeroke¶

n. a variety of potato [ORIGIN: Maori]

LEE & KENDALL R|oke r|oke; A species of the potatoe. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,203)

roki¶

n.

POLACK fern-roots (roki) (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,2/97)

rolie¶

n.

Dr John Dobson, a drug clinic consultant ..., says flunitrazepan, marketed as Rohypnol, is supposed to be a sleeping tablet. But it has become a favourite with pill popping addicts, and rolies' as they are known, sell on the street for up to $7 each. ...It's the drug that druggies use.' (Apr 30, 1989,Dominion,3)

roll¶

n.

It was an unfortunate day, cold S.W. showers falling and a great roll came up before we got to the ship. (Aug 30, 1877,Chudleigh Diary,261,1950 ed.)

v. [(farmers')]

WOODHOUSE It is difficult to imagine how these two men could skirt, roll, class and carry away the 1600 or so fleeces shorn in a day. Two pressers were paid 1/- a bale. (1982,Blue Cliffs,89)

Commenced shearing at five a.m. I was picking up and rowling [sic] the fleeces (Jan 30, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,75,1950 ed.)

Regarding the respective values of the clips, it is hardly necessary to state that fleeces from March-shorn sheep were not able to be rolled. From them only stained wool and bellies were sorted out ... A star bale sold at a crutching sale made 101/4d., while a fadge of the same wool pooled later made 121/4 pence .. (1929,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,10/326)

n. state of the sea where large swells are present

HARGREAVES When it's got a big roll on it's no good for fishing round the point, it's too rough. But that's good for all the surfers. (1998,On the Next Tide,27)

v. [shearing; ca 1920 (W.H.B. Orsman) I'm rolling this season. Not so hard as pressing]

BATHGATE Meanwhile the pickers up' were busy gathering up the fleeces as they fell from the bereft sheep and carrying them to the sorting table, where they [173] were stripped of thepieces', which were thrown aside, while the best of the fleece was quickly classified, rolled together, and deposited in a kind of bin, according to its quality, whether clothing' orcombing.' (1881,Waitaruna,172)

I then muster for Brown and Engst shears last. I put Manuel and Lyne on to shear to. ... I press. The general hand Hobbs picks up and rolls fleeces. (Dec 9, 1884,Chudleigh Diary,331)

I am to keep and pay a cook ... 1 roller who expects to roll 1000 fleeces a day ..., one fleece boy at 5/- per diem, 2 press men .. (Nov 5, 1904,Chudleigh Diary,425)

J.Dix offered to take the responsibility of the shearing at Taupeka. He would bring 4 good shearers and a cook and roll and sort himself. (Dec 7, 1906,Chudleigh Diary,438,1950 ed.)

HISLOP [Helping press wool] was only one of the many ways I was glad to put in a week-end, if it was not skirting and rolling for some good friend. (1943,Pure Gold,18)

RICHARDS A steam whistle ... blew for the commencement and finish of each run. The wool tables for rolling and skirting were in the centre of the woolboard. Close by stood the classer's table, where he sat and classed each fleece before it was carried by a shed hand to its respective bin. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,113)

v. [criminal slang]

JENKYNS To `roll drunks' was to frequent drinking saloons, to follow any man who left drunk, roll him in the gutter, and rob him .. (1892,Hard Life,165)

Kauhata held Dempsey while Nathan went through Dempsey's pockets. Nathan from the dock said [however] that he had not `rolled' Dempsey. (Jul 30, 1963,NZ Truth,5)

v. [fight, beat up]

Lucas had told him of a fight he had had ... He said he had rolled a guy .... Williams said the expression `rolled a guy' meant belted him up. (Jul 22, 1963,NZ Truth,3)

v. roll one's own, roll (oneself) one (cf roll-y-own n; the makings) [roll your own roll your own (cigarettes)] (See roll your own)

But then Charlie would have rolled himself one and looked up at the hills and pretended he didn't hear. (1952,Arena,31:2)

SARGESON I said if he liked he could take my tin and go roll himself one. (1964,Collected Stories,171)

Roll your own Cigarette while you stroll. (Jul 1, 1916,NZ Truth,9)

"He wouldn't give his own mother a roll." Ibid. 35/1 Acie rolled the coarse spring rolls of hair with a paper and lit up. Ibid.35/4 "If we play it right they'll give us a roll." (Dec 29, 1965,Weekly News,35/2)

COWIE At least half the cigarette smokers [of Christchurch] `rolled-their-own' (1937,New Zealand From Within,13)

SARGESON While he rolled himself one he looked across the flat ... - (1949,I Saw in My Dream,111)

CHERRILL I mostly roll my own cigarettes down home. (1950,Story of a NZ Sheepfarm,40)

v. [(? goldminers', ? nonce)]

The reef ... was very flat-lying, and appeared to `roll' with the contour of the country. (1912,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.15 (NS) [p?]) [NOTES: (Bell and Fraser, Waihi-Tairia)]

n. a rolled cigarette,a roll-your-own

(1952,Arena,31/2)

MIDDLETON (1953,Short Stories (various authors),167) [NOTES: 1953 Middleton in 1966 Short Stories 167 [?187]]

(Dec 29, 1965,Weekly News,35/2) [NOTES: [OEDS]]

1 v. (Rural) [wool handling] to roll up a fleece after skirting.

The fleece-picker takes the fleece by the hind legs, and gathers it towards him; takes it to the rolling table, and throws it out with the outside of the fleece upwards; the roller skirts it, rolls it up tightly, and hands it to the classer, who puts the fleece in the proper bin. (Nov 12, 1902,Otago Witness,74)

CHUDLEIGH Commenced shearing at five a.m. I was picking up and rowling [sic] the fleeces. (Jan 30, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,75) [NOTES: (1950)]

BATHGATE The best of the fleece was quickly classified, rolled together and deposited in a kind of bin. (1881,Waitaruna,173)

WOODHOUSE It is difficult to imagine how these two men could skirt, roll, class and carry away the 1600 or so fleeces shorn in a day. (1982,Blue Cliffs,89)

ROLLING FLEECES. - An experienced person should always be employed to roll up wool. (Nov 11, 1865,Otago Witness,16)

7 n. to defeat in sport

[Hdg] Helter-skelter All Blacks roll South Africa... It was the All Black's first World Cup win against the Springboks... (Sep 2003,Sunday Star Times,A1)

roll in¶

v. turn in

STRONACH About nine o'clock we rolled in, after putting our gear where it could be easily found in the dark. The ground was hard. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,10)

roll off¶

v. (of barrels of oil) [(whalers') 1839] (See cf. stow down)

roll one's swag¶

phr. (Rural) [farm work] to move to another location or when mustering, to pack and move to another mustering hut or camp.

MOWAT Got my cheque for L3 then rolled my swag and put it on my back. (Aug 8, 1912,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

NEWTON .. we had no option but to roll our swags and move on. .. (1964,Straggle Muster,7)

MORRIS They'll be rolling swags in the bunkroom, fixing the pack and saddles too ... (1997,Different Worlds,23)

roll the knot¶

phr. [(obs. musterers')] (See cf roll n)

PETER NEWTON Roll the knot means to roll one's swag - musterers on the bigger places shift camp as the muster progresses and as theirgear' consists of blankets and a change of clothes, this is rolled into a ...bundle for loading onto the packhorse whenever they shift camp. (Apr 21, 1952,Letter)

roll up¶

v. to attend, turn up

The band commences operations by playing an overture, as a notice, I presume, for the public to "roll-up and be in time," and this is a signal to the miners, who are camped in large numbers at the back of the town, to strike up also. (Sep 26, 1865,West Coast Times,2)

The members of the Tukapa Football Club are requested to roll up for practise [sic] on Friday morning at 9.45 o'clock. (Apr 12, 1900,Taranaki Herald,3)

FARRELL `The miners all rolled up to see the fun.' (1887,How He Died,26)

MORRIS to gather, to assemble. (1898,Austral English,393)

BAKER to roll up at a meeting, [etc] these are phrases which came almost as easily to the New Zealand tongue as to the Australian. (1941,NZ Slang,62)

roll up v.int. to attend a meeting, whence ~ n. the attendance at a meeting. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

roll-up v. arrive; n. informal game of bowls. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),17)

roll up ... NZ & Austral. sl. congregate or assemble, colloq. arrive in vehicle or on scene; roll-up NZ & Austral. sl. assembly, meeting. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 1000; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 422]]

2 v.

... the latter is always skirted and classed, whereas the black fleece was rolled up just as taken from the sheep's back, the belly-pieces being also left in. ... For example, white wool divides, when skirted by the roller at the wool-table, thus: Belly pieces, say, 6d. per pound; first pieces, 8d. per pound; ... fragments or locks, 4d. per pound. (1901,TrNZI,33/196)

roll your own¶

phr. [aka roll-your-own, roll one's own, roll his own, roll her own. NB active and passive verbal use, also adjectival]

McGILL We tried every brand, even roll-your-owns of Riverhead tobacco. (1989,Kiwi Baby Boomers,63)

[Advt] Roll your own tobacco. 2/11 a 2 oz. carton. (Dec 19, 1944,Otautau Standard,4)

I lit a pipe. He lit a roll-your-own. (Jun 1999,Metro,69)

'Roll your own' is on most lips. (Apr 1945,NZ Geographer,I/23)

A roll-her-own cigarette is never long absent from her hand. (Feb 1997,North & South,60)

"I have visited the high life," Paki says, crushing a Port Royal roll-your-own dead in the ashtray. (Jul 15, 2000,Evening Post,27)

"Roll your own" cigarette with Red Jacket and get more genuine satisfaction out of smoking. (Mar 25, 1916,NZ Truth,9)

Some time ago for instance, rolling one's own cigarettes became a fashion that spread through the country like wildfire. (Sep 11, 1935,NZ Free Lance,19)

They normally smoke roll-your-own tobacco, which they roll very thin. (Apr 23, 1992,Radio NZ / National Radio,Morning Report)

Though there had been a big increase recently in sale of roll-your-own tobacco it did not compensate for the decline in tailor-made cigarettes.. . We have introduced mild and menthol variants because they want the options they used to get with tailor-made. (Apr 28, 1992,Evening Post,2)

In January last year, another bank officer told police, Gray came in smoking one of his habitual roll-your-owns. (Mar 18, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

[Advt] Prize Crop Cigarette Tobacco for Every Man who Rolls His Own! (Aug 7, 1940,Dominion,14)

[Advt] Everywhere you go - Roll-your-own-smokers say.. Silver Fern for preference. (Jul 14, 1950,Dominion,11)

[Advt] The Three Castles Tobacco. There's no better tobacco for rolling your own. (Sep 12, 1939,Dominion,12)

Prize Crop. For Every Man who Rolls his Own. (Sep 15, 1939,Dominion,13)

I suppose it is a bit of a blow - coming back to New Zealand and down to roll- your-owns and beer. (Oct 22, 1937,King Country Chronicle,5)

[Advt] Prize Crop is.. as easy to roll as my Airfreed Shocksford... For Every Man who Rolls his Own. (Feb 3, 1940,Otago Daily Times,6)

The 1921-Model of flapper ... can `rill her own' whether it be cigarettes or hosiery! (Mar 10, 1922,Quick March,4)

roll-up¶

n. a public meeting or assembly (hist. of goldminers) [[AND 1. hist a mass-meeting of gold-miners called to consider a ... grievance 1861-1948 2. transf an assembly 1899]]

A monster roll-up meeting of miners, to be held for the purpose of bringing a pressure to bear upon the Government, is talked about. (Mar 10, 1873,Daily Southern Cross,2)

'It's just to have a barbie,' says Rhind, 'to have a roll up, see if they like it [bowls] or not.' (2008,NZ Geographic,94/101)

(John Thomson) ... the escort robbery and `Roll up' are taken from events well within his recollection when he was a youth on the West Coast. (Jan 11, 1890,Lyttelton Times)

BOLDREWOOD `Making as much noise as if you'd hired the bell-man for a roll-up' (1890,Miner's Right,xxxv.p. 308:)

(Theatre Preview) There is a `roll up' of the diggers to hunt [the bushrangers] down and the mounted troops appear upon the scene to aid in capturing the outlaw. (Jun 10, 1895,Hawke's Bay Herald)

  • The Death bed Confession - The Western Gully - The Roll Up - Lynch law - The Burning House - A Fugitive - Life for Life. (Jun 27, 1895,Evening Star) [NOTES: (Theatre advertisement) Act 5]

MORRIS a meeting. See preceding verb. (1898,Austral English,393)

~ n. sl. a meeting. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

?? obs in NZ roll-up NZ & Austral. sl. assembly, meeting (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,661)

n. an illegal activity, specific. smoking [(adolescents') 1984 16-17 F E3 Pakuranga Coll. 33 ROLL UP [M4 F4]]

roll-your-own¶

n. >a handmade cigarette, a cigarette made (rolled') from tobacco and papers; a ROLL (cf ROLL @v3) [ca 1938 National Tobacco Company advertisement featuredRollyown'; also a brand of cigarette papers was called `Rolliown']

...one could even smoke a racehorse / roll-me-down whole showering... (Oct 23, 2004,Dominion Post,E10)

The background of all this [bunkhouse life] is tobacco. There are but few pipes, and tailor-made' cigarettes are only a luxury.Roll your own' is on most lips. (1945,NZ Geographer,23) [NOTES: (Pascoe Canterbury High Country)]

SLATTER He hid behind the truck for a few quick puffs at his roll-your-own. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,21)

SARGESON .. where he could remain ... in bed if he wished - to read Truth, smoke his roll-your-own, besides reveal himself as a chain tea-drinker. (1977,Never Enough!,142)

TAYLOR That evening I handed round my box of cigars, but everyone seemed to prefer their roll-your-own cigarettes. (1978,Twilight Hour,30)

HULME You remember that, first of all, you never smoked anything but roll-your-owns? (1986,Te Kaihau,108)

SLIGO ... his throat raw with Park Drive roll-your-owns he'd been smoking solidly Ibid. ... 30 Pearse lit a roll-your-own. (1987,Final Things,9)

roll-your-owner¶

n.

Roll-your-owners and pipe-smokers will pay an extra price for their tobacco. ... Manufacturers say that retailers are free to set their own prices for roll-your-own tobacco. (Jul 31, 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 9.00 pm news [Budget night]]

rolled¶

adj. sc. of gold

HAAST .. I instructed my men to dig for gold; we found, to use a technical expression, `the colour everywhere'. They were generally thin, small scales, often only slightly rolled, and could not, therefore have been brought any distance. Ibid. 85 The wash gold is fine, scaly, and very much rolled, so that there is no doubt it has come some distance in the great river-bed. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,84)

roller¶

n. [criminal slang]

You would be playing into the hands of the "cannons" and "rollers" - the pickpockets who fleece the drunks in bars. (Dec 16, 1953,NZ Observer,5)

n. Farming: in sheep-shearing, one who rolls the shorn fleeces. [[? transfer to WOOL-ROLLER] [1890's see shearing shed hands]]

WOODHOUSE Fred Stuthridge came as a wool-classer in 1904 and was paid GBP1 for each 1000 fleeces with 25/- a week extra for wool-rolling. He was helped by one roller at 25/- a week. (1982,Blue Cliffs,89)

.. the latter is always skirted and classed, whereas the black fleece was rolled up just as taken from the sheep's back, the belly-pieces being also left in. ... For example, white wool divides, when skirted by the roller at the wool-table, thus: Belly pieces, say, 6d. per pound; first pieces, 8d. per pound; ... fragments or locks, 4d. per pound. (1901,TrNZI,33/196)

SWANTON There is the wool-classer with his assistant rollers who number five or six. (1892,Notes on NZ,96)

I am to keep and pay a cook ... 1 roller who expects to roll 1000 fleeces a day ..., one fleece boy at 5/- per diem, 2 press men ... (Nov 5, 1904,Chudleigh Diary,425,1950 ed.)

STUDHOLME At shearing time [at Benmore, 1892] about 55 men were employed in the shed: 28 to 30 shearers, 2 penners-up, 4 pickers-up, 2 broomies, 6 rollers, 1 classer, 1 fleece carrier, 4 piece sorters, 3 pressers, 1 bale brander, 1 butcher and brander. (1940,Te Waimate,208,1954 ed.)

McLEOD One classer, two rollers, two fleece-pickers, two pressers, one penner up, make up the shed contingent and the cook and `offsider' complete the total. (1951,High Country,27)

n.

HAY The logs are easily collected ..., as they can be sent down the sides of ranges by means of screw-jacks, rollers and slides. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/11)

1 n. (Rural) a person who rolls fleeces on the skirting table or wooltable in a woolshed.

SWANTON There is the wool classer with his assistant rollers. (1892,Notes on NZ,96)

BISLEY .. the roller should then turn in the neck end as far as the shoulder ... (1897,Practical Treatise on Wool and Sheep Breeding,37)

RUSSELL This year I have Maori shearers .. the gain .. is that they bring their own women folk to act as rollers etc. (1904,Diary,136) [NOTES: in Hill (1990) Between the Rivers]

NEWTON Hopelessly lost against the tricky bowling of Innes, shearers, rollers and fleecies alike, trusting to luck, lashed wildly at ball after ball. (1949,High Country Days,63)

MEEK Joe was shearing in the woolshed on his pat. As shearer, roller, picker-up and broomie all in one. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,21)

DEANS Four rollers and the classer dealt with the fleeces as they came off the board.. (1964,Pioneers on Port Cooper Plains,113)

roller coating¶

n.

Roller coating- 1. The process by which a film is applied mathematically to sheet material which is passed between rollers, one of which is kept coated with a film of liquid varnish, enamel or lacquer. 2. The application of paint by means of a hand-operated roller. mathematically to sheet material which is passed between rollers, one of (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,94)

roller door¶

n.

...and then I cranked up the roller doors to let some air in and see the rain. (Apr 20, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

roller-up¶

n.

.. Swaggers now come by the score, / And every day you will see more: / Shearers, washers, and half-grown louts, / Pickers-up, and "roustabouts"; / Wool-pressers, too, and rollers-up, / Who with cook and classer make enough ... (Jan 13, 1883,Otago Witness,13)

They brought their own cook, fleece-pickers, and rollers-up, and also their children and dogs. (1900,TrNZI,32/367)

rollie¶

n. a roll-your-own cigarette (See roll one's own)

With that, he stops to light his rollie. (May 1, 2004,Dominion Post,E2)

"Still smoking the rollies, I see, even with the recent huge price hike." (Mar 1996,Strip, The,12)

Some are in uniform and clean-cut, while others are smoking rollies and look pretty tough. (Jul 9, 2005,Sunday Star Times,Souvenir Wrap-up A13)

Geary Sunday morning, they smoked Drum rollies on the verandah, waiting for the landlord to go out. (2003,Man of the People, A,79)

COX Peter was smoking again - it would have been rollies back then, with longer hair and that faded jacket. (1984,Einstein,62)

n. the drug Rohypnol (See also rolie)

"We were all on rollies [Rohypnol]. It's not a very nice display; on rollies you think you're as staunch as, eh."... "Doing rollies," says the kaitiaki, " is now a head-smashable offence in the Black Power." (May 14, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

rolling¶

n. (the making of) a roll-your-own cigarette

[Advt] Silver Fern. For Many Happy Rollings. (Aug 6, 1940,Dominion,6)

1 n. (Rural) of shearing, the bundling of wool fleeces for pressing.

PERRY There are many ways of rolling, but two common ways are as follows:- (1) First throw in the neck so that it will rest on the shoulder and then turn in the two sides to the middle back. Commencing at the tail, roll the fleece towards the neck. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,123)

RICHARDS The wool tables for rolling and skirting were in the centre of the woolboard. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,113)

STACEY I had learned quite a lot about shed work when we work at Kekerengu and was enjoying penning up, fleece picking, skirting and rolling when Whit asked if I would like to have a go. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,51)

PERRY Rolling. - When the wool is opened at the sale it is in the best interests of the seller if the best and most attractive part of the fleece, viz., the shoulder, is exposed to view. ... There are many ways [123] of rolling, but two common ways are as follows:- (1) First throw in the neck so that it will rest on the shoulder and then turn in the two sides to the middle of the back. Commencing at the tail, roll the fleece towards the neck. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,122)

  1. Rolling [heading] There are several methods of rolling a fleece. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,708)

rolling country¶

n. karstland

This is the dilemma faced by over 20 landowners farming the Waitomo karst. They call their land - grassy hills cratered with sinkholes - "rolling country," meaning that it's easy to roll a farm bike here. (Apr 1997,NZ Geographic,No.34/43)

rolling pin¶

n.

DEVANNY Second in choice to eat were the berries of the lawyer vine; next the heart, the "rolling pin" of the nikau palm. (1988,Point of Departure,7) [NOTES: Quoted from c1900]

rolling road¶

n. [kauri logging]

As I went along this creek, I was struck by the great number of rolling roads crammed full of logs - piles of them heaped in the creek whereon the roads abutted; at least about two thousand logs are now awaiting a long desired fresh. (Dec 31, 1862,Daily Southern Cross,9)

We went in by the muddy rolling road, all overgrown with white clover and grass, hearty aliens which it would have greatly astonished Captain Cook to find on the banks of the new Thames. (Apr 1, 1902,NZ Illustrated Magazine,60)

The high road, the rolling road, that leads unto the Hutt, / is under Atkinson's control and free from hump or rut. (Sep 30, 1916,NZ Truth,6)

KIRK When growing at any considerable distance from a creek or river it is necessary to form rolling roads. (1889,Forest Flora,150)

REED An article in the Building World, 1889, had this to say: Logging the Kauri in New Zealand is a rather exciting occupation - that is by therolling road' method of extraction ...' (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,172)

Flotation is the method most commonly used in the kauri districts ... After the trunks are cut into lengths a `rolling-road' is formed to the nearest creek. All the scrub is closely cut down for a width of from twenty-five to thirty feet ... to obtain an approximately even surface, inclined towards the creek. The logs are forced along this road by timber-jacks, which the bushmen use with remarkable skill, and are impelled with a rapidity which is simply astonishing to persons unused to the process. If the creek contains plenty of water the logs float to the nearest booms without further trouble ... (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,331) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

REED Hochstetter in 1889 and Kirk in 1874 [Report to Parliament], refer to rolling roads. Kirk describes them as broad tracks, thirty to forty feet wide, in which every advantage is taken of the natural incline of the surface, and from which all trees have to be removed, the stumps cut level with the surface, inequalities roughly levelled, and large holes filled up. The logs are forced along these roads bytimberjacks' until they reach the water. In this way the logs are moved with great ease. ...[D.H.McMillan] Rolling roads were formed by laying three rickers or other small trees lengthwise to the line of road, and logs were placed crosswise on this road. There might be thirty or forty or more in a fleet. Three men with timber lacks usually operated this job. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,170)

... what was called the rolling road ... was anything up the 30 feet wide, with all the stumps cut down to ground level ... A lot of loose skids would probably be laid on the ground running in the direction the log would travel. The logs were then rolled along the road with jacks, usually two men to a log. (1951,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: [ca -1914] 1951 H.S. McCo[?a]rroll The Days of the Kauri Bushmen [Radio 4: TS]]

But before this [treefelling] has been done rolling-roads have been formed, or tramways laid, involving the vast destruction of arboreal growth ... (1895,TrNZI,28/16)

rolling table¶

n. (Rural) wool table in a woolshed, on which fleeces are rolled before binning.

On turning round he beheld Mr Boyd attired in blue dungaree overalls, he having been engaged assisting at the rolling tables. (Dec 20, 1894,Otago Witness,12)

There are many so-called wool-classers whose experience is limited to a few years at the rolling-table. (1883,Brett's Colonists Guide,215)

The picker-up must be shown how to lift the fleece from the board and how to deliver it upon the rolling-table. (Oct 1902,NZ Farmer,567)

The fleece-picker takes the fleece by the hind legs, and gathers it towards him; takes it to the rolling table, and throws it out with the outside of the flecce upwards; the roller skirts it, rolls it up tightly, and hands it to the classer, who puts the fleece in the proper bin. (Nov 12, 1902,Otago Witness,74)

CARR Fleece-picking. - As soon as a shearer has taken the fleece off and let the sheep go through the port-hole to the counting-out pen, the picker gathers the fleece up in such a manner that she or he can on getting to the rolling table, throw it out with the breech part at the right end. (1913,Country Work,14)

rolls¶

n. marbles [child marble players']

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

rollsman¶

n. the man in an iron foundry who controls the snake of rolled red-hot iron as it comes from the furnace

BAXTER Between five and six the night before , Horse had had the pleasure of sinking fifteen handles at the Green Island pub. Ghandi, the bald rollsman, had held up the first beer to the light ... and had said. `the old boys up in the marble orchard would give their eyeteeth for (1985,Horse,14) [NOTES: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Mills of God) 14]

Romdale¶

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred Romney-Perendale cross sheep.

GORDON & DEVERSON Corriedale, Perendale, Romdale, Coopworth, Drysdale (New Zealand sheep breeds - Romdale is a Romney-Perendale cross.) (1985,NZ English (Gordon & Deverson),39)

Two hundred and eighty-six Romdales sold at $46 for the first cut and $45 ... (Aug 15, 1996,NZ Farmer,35)

For Sale: 1300 Romdale crypt lambs, 300 Romdale crypt lambs ... (2000,Press, The (Acland Glossary),37)

"They are normally called Romdales but we thought everybody else has Romdales, so we'd go with Peraney," Mr Hart says. (Sep 29, 2005,Dominion Post,C8)

Yeah, I drew a Romer last week. (Aug 21, 1944,NZEF Times,IV/165 : 5)

romiromi¶

n. traditional Maori massage [ORIGIN: Maori, romiromi: massage, gently rub (Ryan)]

Traditional healing techniques include..Romiromi which uses greenstone, wood and sea water to remove toxins from the body. (Jan 22, 2006,Sunday Star Times,A5)

Mr Hautapu had been learning and practising traditional Maori massage - romiromi and mirimiri - to help physical, emotional and spiritual healing. (Aug 16, 2005,NZ Herald,A4)

Ron¶

adv. later on

This summer the pipi and cockle beds in "our" harbour were decimated by people not content to take just enough for a meal but a sack or two for Ron as well. (That's "later on" in the local patois.) (Jul 1998,NZ Geographic,No. 39/53)

Rongo¶

n. [ORIGIN: Maori]

FINLAYSON (1938,Brown Man's Burden,21)

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,IV/457)

rongoa¶

n. remedy, medicine; traditional Maori healing [ORIGIN: Maori, aka rongoa Maori; includes attributive usage]

Rongoa encompasses traditional herbal remedies using native plants for such disorders as stomach complaints, bruises, toothache, colds and sore throats as well as traditional massage and prayer. (Jan 22, 2006,Sunday Star Times,A5)

He calls rongoa mumbo jumbo because it combines herbal remedies delivered within a Maori cultural context and that includes prayer. (Jan 30, 2006,NZ Herald,A16)

He calls his mixture rongoa, Maori for medicine, and administers it in one or two teaspoonful lots. Up to 20 ounces of cannabis produce about five litres of milk. (Jun 20, 2004,Sunday Star Times,A7)

Rongoa [traditional medicines] were stored in unlabelled paper bags. No sterilising equipment was available for medicine preparation and the rongoa were made in a garage overhang using aluminium pots and water from a garden tap. (Nov 4, 2003,Dominion Post,A1)

Ihimaera Stacked against one of the walls of the tent are the rongoa and the herbal pharmacy that Paraiti draws on for her work. (2007,Ask the Posts,251)

Hohepa Kereopa could not read and write as a youngster, instead committing to memory traditional Maori medicine and healing methods called rongoa Maori... After learning from his many aunties, Mr Kereopa is recognised as the foremost Tuhoe rongoa expert. (Jul 28, 2001,Dominion,9)

There is much evidence on Maori rongoa and many of those that have used it swear by it. (Feb 14, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,2)

He [Hohepa De La Mere] is devoted to not only treating people, but to passing on his knowledge of rongoa maori. (May 10, 2005,Dominion Post,TV week news, P4)

Hohepa Kereopa could not read and write as a youngster, instead committing to memory traditional Maori medicine and healing methods called rongoa Maori... After learning from his many aunties, Mr Kereopa is recognised as the foremost Tuhoe rongoa expert. (Jul 28, 2001,Dominion Post,9)

Te Whare O Kenehi workers Margaret and Tom Tuakana will be showing walkers the wide range of plants available in the Rotorua region that can be used in traditional Maori medicine (rongoa) and how to collect them without harming the environment. (Sep 15, 2011,Daily Post (Rotorua),A004)

Their clinic is a registered organisation and they provide a variety of free services including traditional rongoa, mirimiri (Maori massage) and other health checks. (Sep 15, 2011,Daily Post (Rotorua),A004)

Teresa Wall, the minstry's deputy director-general of Maori health, told a newpaper earlier this year that "the mere fact that people use rongoa and go back to the practitioners is testament that the services they are given are contributing to their wellbeing". (Jun 21, 2009,Sunday Star Times,C6)

Today there are about 30 rongoa clinics around the country, 15 of them funded by the Health Ministry to promote wellness through massage, prayer, spiritual conselling and cultural support. (Jun 21, 2009,Sunday Star Times,C6)

Rongopai¶

n. gospel, religion

The words Rongo pai are those used by the missionaries for the gospel, as to signify "good news," ... (Jun 10, 1865,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,4)

The speeches were all to the same effect. The substance was this - That Mr. Turton was one of those who had brought them the good tidings ('rongo pai') of the Gospel, and was now forsaking his work to teach them the law; that they could not understand or reconcile this, or as some termed it, worshipping Mammon. (Aug 5, 1859,Daily Southern Cross,3)

He would carry his "Rongo Pai" to Poverty Bay, and then on to the East Cape. (Jul 26, 1884,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

BAUCKE The old tohunga Maori, schooled in the ancient religion, were the first to accept Pai-marire; they were astute enough to recognize that by adopting it they would secure the ancient ascendancy of their class over the people which the Rongopai had impaired but not destroyed. (1928,Where the White Man Treads,133)

COWAN He was a middle-aged man when the missionary impulse set him seeking a field beyond his tribal district, in the cause of the new religion, the Rongo Pai, and the reconciliation of old enemies. (1935,Hero Stories of NZ,53)

rongopai, Gospel (rongo, to hear or something heard; pai, good, good news). (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

rongotea¶

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of wheat. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Oroua shows more resistance to stripe rust than both Kopara and Rongotea. For spring sowings, Rongotea and Oroua will provide the best yields. In Medium to high yiled potential areas, the choice of autumn sown cultivars is between Rongotea and Kopara. (May 1982,NZ Journal of Agriculture,22)

Tiritea was bred from the dame parental combination that gave rise to Rongotea .. Tiritea resembles its sister line, Rongotea, in height and maturity. (1982,NZ Journal of Agriculture,23)

roniu¶

n.

HOOKER Brachycome radicata, Hook. fil. ... Nat. name, `Roniu', Colenso. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants)

HOOKER Roniu, Col[enso]. Brachycome odorata. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

The daisy like flowers of the Roniu (Brachycome odorata,) and the flowering tops of the sweet-scented grass Karetu (Hierchloe redolens), were worn around the neck ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/37) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

WILSON Brachycome radicata Roniu ... Tufted herb often forming small patches ... Flower heads rather inconspicuous daisies ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,196)

RONZ¶

abbr. Rest of New Zealand

For the most part Aucklanders don't care very much at all about the Rest of New Zealand... None of this, RONZers believe, has been reported by the media.. Ibid. 47 If you're a RONZer you may care to skip this next part. (Jun 1999,North & South,46)

Every society has its own variations on the Auckland Vs. the RONZ (rest of New Zealand) theme. (Jul 1999,North & South,14)

For the most part Aucklanders don't care about the Rest of New Zealand... None of this, RONZers believe, has been reported by the media. Ibid. 47 If you're a RONZer you might like to skip this next bit. (Jun 1999,North & South,46)

Roo land¶

n. Australia

In September, 1901, George broke for Roo land,' his avowed intention being toplace his children in life.' (Aug 21, 1909,NZ Truth,217/11/3)

roody doody¶

n. probably an early spg (as KOW-ROWDY-DOWDY) of Maori ruriruri, Williams 352 Ruri, ruriruri ... Song, ditty, generally of an amorous nature, accompanied by gestures.: and English dialect rowdy-rowdy. kow- = ?Maori ko[o] sing; resound; a shout; or perhaps ko a particle. [cf OED rowdy-dowdy `characterised by noisy roughness.' (1882); EDD Rowdy-dowdy: Sc. Ches. a merry-making.]

Markham The women will sit on a heap of potatoes or log, and do what is called "Roody Doody" [ruriruri]. [Footnote. The word is defined in Williams as a song; generally of an amorous nature, accompanied by gestures]. (1834,New Zealand (Heaphy),50,1963 ed.)

MARKHAM The [Maori] will sit on a heap of Potatoes or log, and do what is called a Roody Doody. [a kind of gossiping, impromptu recitative, accompanied by rhythmic dancing etc, of all the happenings around them - scandals about the pas, obscene or lewd observations to discomfort the spectators etc. They will often keep it up for hours - on board ships, with traders or sailors. - and work up sexual passion] (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles))

roof is off, the¶

phr. the sky's the limit [-->THE ROOF'S OFF. THE SKY'S THE LIMIT -->1944 Fullarton Troop Target 70 There were no beg pardons' about this type of warfare [in Crete] ...The roof's off. The sky's the limit' thought Noel, using a gambling metaphor from Colonial woolsheds.]

roof surf¶

v.

A deer "roof surfing" on a stock truck met an untimely death on the main street of Clinton. (Aug 12, 1998,Dominion,3)

rook¶

n.

On the course there was not a bob for him with the rooks, and any old jolly price was bawled about him, and though the owners saw and heard all they could not be drawn into taking even a paltry 40 to 10. (Apr 18, 1908,NZ Truth,148/2/6)

rooker¶

n. a fresh recruit, a rookie

You ought to come to Sling ... Ehoa ... when there's a lot of rookers in. Eny o' the old hands'll be pleased (Sep 19, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,63)

rookery¶

n. a seal colony

All this is accompanied by roarings and bellowings and bleatings, which cause the sound of a large seal rookery to be heard far out to sea above even the thunder of the breakers. (May 9, 1889,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

On one of the neighbouring islands, long since quiescent, a seal rookery has established itself. (Jan 28, 1908,Grey River Argus,4)

Representations are likely to be made here to the Minister of Marine with regard to the close time for seals for subjects of the colony, while outsiders are likely to harry the rookeries with comparative impunity. (May 4, 1894,Star, The,1)

JOHN BISCOE ... they had only seen a few seal, it was thought these were only stragglers from some Rookery near at hand; ... (Nov 22, 1831,Journal) [NOTES: 1831 Nov 22 Capt. John Biscoe Journal in 1982 Richards Whaling and Sealing 40 Also in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 418]

McLEAN A boat goes out on search of a `rookery' as [sealers] term the collected seals on any spot. (1845,Journal,1/42) [NOTES: (Bossworth-an 1827 sealer)]

SHORTLAND This rugged part of the coast was formerly thickly inhabited by seals; and several spots, once their favourite resorts, called rookeries by the sealers, were pointed out by some of the crew ... (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,144)

roopu¶

n. group [ORIGIN: Maori, see Ryan 224.] (See also ropu)

In addition, many positions allocated to Maatua Whangai within this Department would disappear, and other mechanisms need to be developed to maintain the links between social workers and tribal roopu. (1987,Briefing papers - see notes,124) [NOTES: NZ Dept of Social Welfare. Briefing papers for Incoming Minister of Social Welfare, 1987. Wellington: Dept of Social Welfare.]

There was already limited seating in the office and once members of the roopu (Maori group) decided to sit together .. Pakeha staff had little choice but to sit at remaining desks ... (Sep 20, 2003,Dominion Post,A1)

The first astounding facts told to the roopu were of Uiraroa. We, the roopu had taken it for granted that Uiraroa was from Ngati Awa ... (Oct 2006,Pu Kaea,4)

IT WAS the day of the dress rehearsal for the paetaiohi Roopu .. Our roopu is 3rd overall in the Manawatu/Horowhenua region for 2005. (May 23, 2006,NZ Herald,E7,The College Herald ed.)

Within the Universities there are Maori student roopu who exist specifically to provide a 'home away from home' for Maori students. Some of the individual degrees even have Māori student roopu like Te Rakau Ture - the Māori law students' association of the University of Auckland. (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,9,Spring ed.)

rooster¶

n. a male fowl; the main word in NZ (not cock)

2 n. fellow, chap, bloke [OED back to 1785, 1949 April McKain, Fiords Expedition, A.L. Poole 1952 Aug 22 R.Fraser, Internal Affairs Wildlife Branch (R.Mason).]

[see quot. spruiker] (1946,Johnny Enzed in Italy,41)

PASCOE Rooster' is another variant ofjoker' [in high country slang]. (1952,Land Uplifted High,162,1961 ed.)

CRUMP The note invited me to see if I could make head or tail of this rooster. As far as Jim had been able to make out, his name was `Bloodywell Clarry' (1960,Good Keen Man, A,43)

GOLD is easy enough to find on the West Coast. Those in the know can stomp through the bush towards a creek worked by gold miners last century and virtually within minutes pan out a few flecks of the precious metal. Any rooster can go out and do that. (Sep 20, 1987,Dominion Sunday Times,17)

McGILL rooster a person, a genial usage often qualified by old' orodd'; eg Gordon Slatter's A Gun in My Hand: `He's not a bad sorta rooster.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,93)

Talk of the pugnacity of the Gallic cock! Why that game rooster can't strut beyond his dunghill, clip his wings, and cock-a-doodle-doo, without very whelp of bluff old bully feeling bound in honour to show his teeth and bow-wow. (Aug 20, 1859,Taranaki Herald,2)

He then turned and shouted to the group "Who is the rooster on the stand.[sic]" (Dec 23, 1920,Grey River Argus,4)

"And we say to this rooster, 'Right!' we say. 'What's the story about this debentured stock...?" (Jan 26, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

McGEE Well, your average rooster just wants to know where his next square meal's coming from. (1981,Foreskin's Lament,42)

3 n. one who will not get up and dance (i.e. roosts in one place all evening, a once common occurrence in NZ dance halls).

SMITH The mayor in a happy mood / Told a funny tale or two. / When you want to grip the roosters / That's the best thing you can do. [F.N.] `Roosters' - those on the high seats near the door [of a dance or social hall] (1946,Poetical Works,273) [NOTES: [Greymouth]]

4 n.

Blatant megaphones' androosters' who have been got at' are the terms used to describehighly-paid' officials of the Labour Federation. (Jul 7, 1911,Maoriland Worker,18/9/2)

5 n.

ELDRED-GRIGG In Canterbury [in the 1880's], men looking for harvest jobs perched along fences in country townships, and were called `roosters'. (1980,Southern Gentry,121)

rooster's blood¶

n. [WW2, Italy] (See cf. purple death)

Rooster's Blood. (Dec 23, 1944,NZEF Times,18)

DAVIN And I remember how you bust up that Pommy officers' club in Bari'sBut that was after drinking Roosters' Blood.' (1956,Sullen Bell,66)

NEWTON ...I had drunk Zibib' andRooster's Blood' with their brother George in the Middle East and this seemed introduction enough. (1952,High Country Journey,40)

root¶

v. have sexual intercourse with

VIRTUE He had once asked Effie to let him root her. He had come right out and used the word. (1989,Then Upon the Evil Season,60)

Hughes By the end of the movie couples were rooting in the bushes, people were vomiting on the sand, and occasionally also dancing barefoot in the broken glass. (1999,Shooting from the Lip,158)

...who was - you know - rooting who. (Oct 13, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),59)

n. an act of sexual intercourse

MARRINER 'I got a hard-on as soon as I looked at her, 'cause that's exactly the type of root I could use right now; fully submissive.' (2001,Stonedogs,203)

"Mate. I wasn't looking for a relationship. I was looking for a root." (Nov 21, 2001,Capital Times,16)

At any rate, I felt like a horny old toad that evening, and badly wanted a root. (Aug 14, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

HALL Didn't you ask him whether he was having naughties, or roots, or knee-tremblers, or all the other... (1984,Glide Time,77)

root raking¶

1 n. (Rural) the use of a bulldozer or root rake to remove gorse, scrub etc by the roots.

Gorse has been cleared from river flats with root raking at $208/ha. (Jun 1995,NZ Dairy Exporter,105)

root-faced¶

adj. dour, humourless

McGILL root-faced humourless. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

root-rake¶

1 v. (Rural) to slash, then harrow or use a root-rake to clear scrub and weeds.

He has slashed 78ha and root-raked a further 10 ha of 3m gorse. (Mar 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,25)

Development is usually covered with a preburn spray by aircraft, burnt off then root-raked with a bulldozer. (May 4, 1993,NZ Farmer,25)

First the land was root-raked to clear any gorse or scrub. [root rake] (Aug 1, 1996,NZ Farmer,13)

root-raker¶

n. sc of gorse

NEWTON Gorse eradication is ... [a] big problem. The favoured method is first to go over the area with a root-raker ... The rubbish is dozed into heaps and burnt; ... (1973,Big Country,15,1977 ed.)

rootbag¶

n. a woman regarded as an easily taken sexual object, e.g. (below) a female camp-follower of the All Blacks [1984 16 M E93 Pakuranga Coll. 28 ROOT BAG(S) [M5]]

ROMANOS 'Christ, he's not with that rootbag who was sniffing around last night.' (1997,Black,11)

rooted¶

adj. exhausted, done in; worn out, clapped out

I'm fair rooted by then, so I don't want to have to hang round. (Jan 3, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

LAY You're lookin a bit rooted, old chap.'Yeah. had a late night last night.' (1988,Fools on the Hill, The,181)

McGILL rooted exhausted, not necessarily from sexual activity; eg `That second half really took it out of me. I'm rooted!' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

Owen Marshall There's four of them in Paulie's Bard Words troupe. They travel in two rooted vans: one a Bongo and the other a something or other. (2009,Living As A Moon,222)

ROMANOS 'Are you okay, Brian?' 'Claire, I'll say it and I hope you're not offended, but I'm rooted.' (1997,Black,171)

rooter¶

n. a (usu. male) person considered sexually active; a shagger [ca1950s in common use in Wellington]

What would happen if John Banks and Bill Clinton decided upon a joint DNA venture? You'd get some mad rooter. (Jan 5, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),95)

McGill rooter active homosexual. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

n. A machine for loosening the surface of the ground [Two NZ quotes 1950/1965. See OED rooter 1b.]

n. a wild pig; a Captain Cooker

STUDHOLME One docking season, we found abundant evidence of rooters' on the block .... [244] These oldCookers' should be approached with caution. (1940,Te Waimate,240, 244)

rooting¶

n. sexual intercourse

Rooting colloquial term for fornication (1989,Chosen Place,104)

HALL "Rooting"; there's another charming Antipodean word. (1984,Glide Time,44)

ANDERSON 'What's rooting?' I say. 'It's when a man sticks his willy into a lady.' (1999,Long Hot Summer,173)

rootrat¶

n.

McGILL rootrat active homosexual. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

ropata¶

n.

Ropata. Pelargonium australe, var. clandestinum, L'Her[e-acute]. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/40) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

rope¶

n. specifically, the wire rope used to break logs out of the bush (cf ROPEY [ca 1950 R Gilberd Okaihau Letter A log can be hauled forward on the rope', backwards on thetail-rope' and the direction of pull can be varied by the use of a snatch block temporarily attached to a tree on one side or other of the log-way]

The shoe is connected with a steel wire rope about ?in in diameter, which is wound round the drum of the engine. A black rope on the drum, or the horse which usually accompanies the shoeman, takes the shoe into the place where the logs are. (Sep 24, 1902,Otago Witness,72)

Manufacturers of every description of WIRE ROPES. Round Ropes for inclined planes, Collieries, Mines, Railways, Ploughing, etc. (Jan 20, 1890,Inangahua Times,3)

MAHONEY Early haulers were built with one cable drum with a typical capacity of 400 metres (20 chains) of 25 mm (1") diameter rope - it was usually called rope even thought it was actually a wire cable. (1998,Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The,19)

v. to secure (an animal, usually a cow) with a rope (cf. leg-rope) [v (farming)]

After I had examined and roped up the heifer he came into the yard, and I said, "Father, this appears to be one of your heifers, here is a T on it and the top part of an S." (Sep 21, 1861,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

CHAPMAN Alfred roped up and milked Lilly. (1854,Diary,4)

.. or when after the second morning of roping up a heifer, he tries to do so alone, and the beast, after standing for five minutes almost within the bail, wheels round suddenly and drags a half-dry muddy rope, burning like a red-hot iron, through his fingers ... (Mar 13, 1883,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

So the little brat of a beast was roped up, a sadde put on his back and a horse's headstall bridle put on his head, - the two making nearly a complete suit of clothing for it - and the pony was immediately "backed" and taken out for duty as a stock-horse. (Nov 4, 1895,Timaru Herald,2)

v. (See cf. roping stick)

MacCluchey came ... and branded etc. a lot of young horses. It is very hard work ropeing them. (Nov 17, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,66,1950 ed.)

ELWELL Harold with a long pole, had been roping'- that is, throwing the slip-knot over the heads of the cattle that required to be branded. .... He had successfully roped an animal. (1878,Boy Colonists,189)

~ v.t. to lasso.-ro'pable a. of cattle, wild and intractable. Generally, illtempered and intractable.-ro'ping pole n. a pole with a noose of rope at its end used for roping individual cattle in a mob. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

1 n. (Rural) a part of the neck or edge wool of a fleece.

If they've taken off too much wool with the necks, they are just as good as the fleece, but we have to give the 'ropes' a bit of special treatment. At the scour, someone had gone through the result of this sort of skirting a second time, separating the fleece from the 'ropes' which to anyone who has handled wool is a very descriptive term. (Feb 13, 1963,Weekly News,39)

rope road¶

n.

BEARDSLEY rope road (the) ropeway for hauling coal trucks to surface (1984,Blackball 08,245)

An explosion of gas occurred in Beban's section of the rope road at the State Mine Extension yesterday morning, two men named Patrick Roden and John Dunn being severely burnt about the body, face and arms. (Jan 10, 1911,Grey River Argus,4)

The truckers at the Denniston mine have struck for an increase of 1s per day. The Rope Road boys have also struck for an increase. (Jan 26, 1900,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

He then proceeded underground along the same rope road steadily upwards for a mile and a-quarter, when he reached the powder magazine and got his explosives for the day. (Sep 30, 1920,Grey River Argus,4)

rope swinging¶

n.

Kiwis have this thing about vertical rubber experiences. They can't wait to leap from bridges with an elastic band on their feet, fling themselves from aircraft with pros strapped to their back like copulating dragonflies, jump into underground rivers with rubber rings around their middles, "rap jump" - abseil down the outer walls of high-rise buildings - and "zorb", roll down hills inside transparent rubber spheres... Even tiny Takaka not only has bungee jumping but serious "swinging", the latest in fear fads involving a 60 mph, 50 yd flight over an abyss. (May 11, 1997,Sunday Times (UK),6.5)

The man was rope swinging, an adventure pastime similar to bungy jumping, when he fell from the Mangaweka Bridge. (Dec 27, 2000,Evening Post,2)

rope-a-dope¶

adj. (informal)

A classic Rodney Hide rope-a-dope operation ... was fully facilitated by the willingness of some news outlets to present spoon-fed information as their own exclusives. (May 22, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C10)

ropeable¶

adj. violently angry, needing restraint, fit to be tied spg also ropable [OED online: Austral & NZ Slang. ca1945 Victoria Univ. College undergraduates; cf also punning corruption rapeable (of a girl).]

The mother, now "ropable" about the initial DNA results, admits that the teenager "more or less had no one." (Jul 17, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)
