In fairness to the chief officer, he was pretty ropable. (Oct 30, 1963,Dominion,12)

Now Levin-based Swazi - which employs 70 people - is set to lose 93% of a $2 million Defence Force contract to cheaper China, and hard-talking Hughes is ropeable. (2007,NZ Truth)

[He]..suggested the father had been "ropable" to find the trio inside, but the father said that he was merely annoyed. (Nov 30, 2005,Dominion Post,A6)

"I'm ropable," said Graham... "There were 200 people here to vote for this motion and I'm furious." (Apr 9, 1993,Salient,5)

MORRIS Ropeable, adj. (1) Of cattle; so wild and intractable as to be capable of subjection only by being roped. (2) By transference: intractable, angry, out of temper. [1891] (1898,Austral English,394)

DAVIN Well, I must get back to the G1. He's absolutely ropable about the tanks. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,315)

DAVIN Well, I must get back to the G1. He's absolutely ropable about the tanks. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,315)

(May 16, 1958,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21/3)

SLATTER Silly old fool. I bet his old woman's just about ropable by now. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,206)

SYDER & HODGETTS In a wild rage. .in 4;`Rill's ropeable, someone left the gate open and there's a large variety of fowls in his garden. He's using some shocking language.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],923)

ropeable adj. of cattle, wild and intractable, able to be controlled only by roping; by transference angry, out of temper. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

TURNER The word ropeable angry' literally meansneeding to be tied up' and is a cattle term that ha become widely current. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,148)

The worker in the storehouse was `hot' ... The young bloke [his son] had completed [a security questionnaire] - but the father was ropable. (Nov 2, 1966,People's Voice,3)

ropeable, ropable adj. of cattle, wild and intractable, able to be controlled only by roping; by transference, angry, out of temper. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),17)

WILSON `Oh, Dick. What a ropeable young idiot I've been. We should never have got maried like that.' (1976,Pacific Star,131)

ropable or ropeable ... 2. Austral. & N.Z. inf. a. angry. b. wild or intractable: a ropable beast. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1002) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 663; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 423]]

Hastings cowboy Brian Denton is ropeable. He is angered that the word cowboys is being used as a label for wild, reckless behaviour. Last week our ... headline was `Cowboy Truckies Licensed To Kill'. The story highlighted the frivolous approach of some truckies to the handling of dangerous goods. But Mr Denton ... reckons using the word cowboy the same way as slap-happy is to ride rough-shod over the reputation of [rodeo] cowboys. (Apr 17, 1988,Sunday News,15)

McGILL ropeable very angry; from need to rope up a difficult beast; eg `Their coach after the game was ropeable!' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

Ropei.a-ble (r&omacr.pi.&adot.-b'l), a. [See ROPE, v. t., 4. in the Dictionary.] Needing to be lassoed and thus brought under control; unruly; - siad of a horse or bullock. Hence, in a general sense, angry and excited; savage; - used also of persons. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

Mr. R. M'Kenzie was in a particularly "ropable" mood last night, and all the efforts of all the members could not restrain the exuberance which prompted him to move motions to report progress at most inconvenient moments, to the chagrin of Ministers and members who wanted to get on. (Sep 20, 1895,Evening Post,4)

That the idea of the people being roped off at the reception, lest they should get within coo-ee of Royalty and the highly select, is making Wellington ropeable. (Jun 15, 1901,New Zealand Free Lance,22)

Your wife was not in the house at the time. You were ropeable. (Mar 8, 1882,Grey River Argus,2)

The Liberal executive was ropable - to them, it was another instance of the Alliance using the Liberals as a convenience. (Sep 26, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

Paraparaumu woman Lois McInnes said today she was "ropeable" after the Court of Appeal tossed out her challenge to the legality of the new photographic driver's licence. (Apr 11, 2001,Evening Post,9)

The following day the Minister became very angry, almost ropeable in fact, when he read a condensed account of the incident in the Hamilton paper. (Feb 16, 1924,NZ Truth,12)

When he came round he was ropable. (Sep 13, 1913,NZ Observer,16)

Dr Smith said he was "ropable" the Government intended to take historical land records from Nelson, Marlborough and the West Coast and store them in Christchurch. (Sep 12, 2000,Dominion,2)

"You saw what they did? I was bloody ropable! I want their heads on a stake, the two of 'em!. (Sep 30, 1999,Evening Post,18)

ropeboy¶

n.

Two youths who had come from England under engagement made some four months previously were started on that date - one as a rope-boy and the other as a trucker. (Dec 6, 1913,Evening Post,15)

An Italian has trucked in a West Coast mine for twenty years; he is still alone ... ropeboys just starting can feel cocky pride in shouting: Good day, you --- rotten Skypoo bastard!' <i>(Sep 1952,Landfall,6(3): 206</i>) [NOTES: (PearsonFretful Sleepers') Also Sep. p. 23]

ropehead¶

n. a hippie or dope-associated person [Heard on National Radio Spectrum programme (Deborah Nation), used of neo-hippies in Nelson]

He asked Mr Goff "whether he has received reports on which parties in this Parliament support the view generally enunciated by Mr Alexander, and which parties are out there supporting the ropeheads?" (Oct 7, 2004,Dominion Post,A2)

ropeman¶

n. [(loggers')]

HENDERSON [I] had taken one of the first of Westland's mechanical log-haulers out to Bourkes Creek mill, ... Alf acting as ropeman. (1961,Friends in Chains,70)

WANTED. Hauler Driver, 12s; and Assistant Ropeman, 11s. Apply at once, to Seed Bros., Ltd., Mangaroa. (Apr 30, 1914,Evening Post,1)

It turns out (telegraphs our Dunedin correspondent) that the diver Hughes, who so pluckily rescued the Italian miner Varischetti in a West Australian mine on the 28th of last month, was at one time employed as a ropeman in the Roslyn Tramway Company's service. (Apr 16, 1907,Evening Post,4)

Mr F. P. Welsh, labour agent of Masterton, requires a ropeman for log-hauler, good wages will be given to a thoroughly competent man; also married couple for station. (Jul 22, 1904,Bush Advocate,2)

ropey¶

n. a worker who manipulated a log-hauling rope [(bushmen's)] (See rope n)

GEORGE Among the other employees there was.. the 'ropey' whose job it was to fasten a heavy steel rope to the log... (1990,Ohakune,95)

REED Immediately a log was drawn to the whim, the pole was released from the niche, whereupon the `ropey' pulled back the rope and hitched on another log. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,195)

MARRIOTT ... a steam log hauler he would put up with, as long as the ropies would hook on to the tree he had felled and get it out of the way, ... (1981,Life in the Gorge,21)

R. GILBERD The breaker-out is assisted by a `ropey' whose duty is chiefly to carry the snatch-block. (1951,Letter) [NOTES: R. Gilberd Okaihau Letter]

MAHONEY This stopping, rope changing, and starting during a haul required the attentions of a ropey. He walked along within sight of the log, and pulled on the whistle cord at the necessary time. (1998,Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The,19)

adj. shy of, tetchy on the rope (See cf. toey =stroppy)

MUIR ... it was hell's own job rounding the bastards up, I can tell you. God, she was a ropey outfit, that bloody dump. (1960,Word for Word,253)

roping pole¶

n.

(1906,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),623)

roping-pole n. pole with rope noose used for catching horses and cattle. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16)

roping saddle¶

n. (Rural) a stockman's or shepherd's saddle with a rope attached to the horn with which to lead or carry stock.

HOLDEN Next moment Andy, with a grunt, hoisted the wether over the pommel of his roping saddle. (1991,Fall Muster,34)

roping stick¶

n.

(1878,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins))

ELWELL Ernest ... had to get behind the animal, and by dint of prodding with the roping stick ... to force it to run up towards the corner. (1878,Boy Colonists,190)

ropu¶

n. a (Maori) group, company, society, or association [ORIGIN: Maori, also roopu] (See also roopu)

Harawira was the founding member of the Waiariki Maori netball ropu and was awarded the Queen's Service medal for her services to Maori. (Apr 11, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,12 (back page))

'It showcased the diverse range of talents within our roopu,' says Hinauri Mead-Hetet. (2008,Mana,84/44)

rorerore¶

n.

BURTON For preparing small meals in a fowlers' camp or fishermen's bivouac, the open hearth was used and the fish or birds might be grilled on sticks leaning over the glowing embers. Grilling was known as tunutunu or rorerore. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,1)

rori¶

n. a shellfish, Scutus antipodes Fam. Fissurellidae [Name in Oct. 1992 was Scutus breviculus]

HULME & MORRISON When I lift the lid, the rori is undulating beautifully round and round in the steaming water, singing to itself. (1989,Homeplaces,8)

There is a proverbial comparison for a woman's lips when well tattoed; such are said to resemble a rori (Paramphorus australis); the plump black smooth and glossy mantle of this shell-fish appearing, when living, its whole length on both sides from under its narrow back shell, and turning up and enveloping its sides, no doubt originated the proverb. (1881,TrNZI,13 : 71)

ANDERSEN How, cowed and servile, gnawing hunger makes the soul-less frame to stagger, when at dim eventide the reeling form oft seeks to eat the refuse rori, cooked and left by Pare-korau! (1922,Maori Life in Ao-Tea,298)

rorio¶

n.

And then, evoking the spiritual world, there was Richard Nunns with his extraordinary arrray of authentic, rare Maori wind instruments: a whalebone bullroarer, an albatross bone flute, a nose gourd and the rorio (mouth harp). (Oct 31, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

roro¶

n. verandah

ASHTON-WARNER It is a low window that looks out from the Meeting House upon the roro*. [fn] verandah. (1958,Spinster,146)

ASHTON-WARNER (1963,Teacher,207)

roroi¶

n.

BURTON [Title] Roroi (kumara pudding.) (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,4)

rort¶

v. to have sexual intercourse with (= root) [ca1935 Havelock schoolboys ca1949 Football Song : My Old Man's a Fullback etc My old man's a blacksmith, a blacksmith [etc] ... All day he wroughts iron, wroughts iron, [etc] At night he comes home and rorts me.]

n. an act or bout of sexual intercourse; a woman regarded as a sexual object (= root) [ca1935 Havelock schoolboys]

HILLIARD Ian thought of Valerie Kemp. By God, what a rort! (1976,Send Somebody Nice,127)

2 n. act of sharp practice, swindle

NEWBOLD WROUGHT (n) and (v) Trick, conspire, swindle. The wroughter, in British underworld parlance from about 1860, was he who manipulated the cards in the three-card trick. cf P: rorty adj. 1. fine 2. low: amorous: ca1893. (1982,Big Huey, The,256)

(heading) No move yet on tax credit rort (Aug 19, 2009,Press, The)

Members of Parliament love a rort. (Aug 3, 2002,Dominion Post,A14)

Rortagate¶

n.

Since the first flaring of Rortagate, the two parties of Government have spun an intricate web of consultative pathways between ministers on each side. (May 4, 1997,Sunday Star Times,C2)

rorter¶

n. something superior or excellent of its kind [(schoolchildren's)]

BAKER In constant use by our youngsters ... rorter, rumpty, rumptydooler, [etc] cp OED rorty adj low slang (of obscure origin) fine, splendid (ca1864); So P; 2 something exceptionally fine: Aust: since ca1920. (1941,NZ Slang,51)

rorter-snorter¶

n. emphatic form of rorter q.v. (cf. rip-snorter) [ca1938 Havelock schoolchildren]

rose loosestrife¶

n.

loosestrife, rose [s] Lythrum junceum Banks & Sol. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,45)

rose of sharon¶

n.

rose of sharon [s] Hypericum calycinum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,65)

rose on¶

phr. ??

MARKHAM I started with two Sawyers and Natives to go in an old Boat. She had been built for sealing and had been rose on. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),75,1963 ed.)

rose-leaved anise¶

n. [2 entries, rose anise]

COCKAYNE [Angelica rosaefolia] And) (2nd ed.) (1919,NZ Plants)

BROOKER et al. Angelica rosaefolia Hook. Common name: Rose-leaved anise Maori names: Koheriki, kohepiro ... This coastal herb is found in the northern part of New Zealand. (1981,NZ Mail,25)

rose-leaved lawyer¶

n.

Rubus schmidelioides rose-leaved lawyer (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest (AND)]

Rose-Noelle¶

n. a trimaran which capsized in 1989 leaving the four occupants to survive 119 days drifting at sea on the upturned hull before washing ashore on Great Barrier Island.

On September 30 four men were washed ashore on Great Barrier Island long after most had given them up for dead. They had spent 199 days living in their upturned trimaran, the 12.5-metre Rose Noelle. (Nov 20, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10) [NOTES: check whether original says 199 or 119.]

John Glennie's inexperienced crew on the Rose-Noelle were to say later that they believed rescue was just over that horizon every single day of their 119-day drift on the upturned hulls. (Aug 20, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),109)

The story of the four men who survived four months in the upturned hull of the Rose-Noelle is one of endurance on an epic scale. (Oct 11, 2000,Dominion,51)

Four men found at the scene of a break-in on Great Barrier Island claim to be from the yacht Rose-Noelle, lost at sea four months earlier... The Rose-Noelle saga isn't the longest example of survival at sea - three others equal or surpass the trimaran's drift. (Jul 16, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),53)

rosella¶

n. a sheep which has cast or lost most of its wool [(shearers')]

A sheep that has cast most of his wool before shearing, so is very easy to shear. R. is a shearers' word, probably brought from Australia. [1898 Morris Austral-English] gives two meanings for the word but not this one: (1) a sort of parrot; (2) a European who works bare to the waist (North Australian slang). Our word is probably derived from (2). ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Oct 28, 1933,Press, The,17) [NOTES: Acland Grossary]

STUDHOLME The `rosellas'; or easily shorn sheep ... (1940,Te Waimate,112)

NEWTON ROSELLA: A sheep which has lost the wool off its belly, i.e., torn off in matagouri or scrub. A sheep which has lost most of its wool is known as a `rosella.' ] (1949,High Country Days,193)

PARTRIDGE Rosella. 2. In Australia and New Zealand, since ca. 1910, it has been sheep-shearing s. for a sheep bare of wool on thepoints' (hocks, head, foreleg, etc.) and consequently very easy to shear,' Niall Alexander, communucation of Oct. 22, 1939. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1156)

MASTERS My catching pen happened to be filled just on smoko time. In it I noticed right near the front, one rosella (sheep bare of wool except for a few tufts around the neck, and several others that appeared to be bare-bellies. (1960,Back-Country Tales,257)

bare belly: A sheep with defective wool growth caused by a break in the fibre structure. This causes the wool to fall off the belly and legs and is more common in ewes. These sheep are sometimes called `Rosellas'. Ibid. 3/27 (Wallace Shearing Glossary) rosella: A sheep with wool falling out of it. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/21) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

WOODHOUSE We'd a bunch of Aussie shearers, and they come from New South Wales,/ They entertained the rouseys' with a lot of fairy tales/ Of how they shore the jumbucks and rosellas from the hills,/ <i>(1950,Farm & Station Verse,49</i>) [NOTES: c1900-1910 GoldstoneThe Man From Kaiveroo' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 49]

1 n. (Rural) a sheep that has no wool around the neck area or a sheep that is particularly easy to shear, with wool that sloughs off.

STUDHOLME When an old hand and a young one were sharing a catching pen, the former would let the learner in for the 'cobbler' or hard shearing sheep, at the end of every pen, and when the pen had been refilled, quickly catch and shear all the 'rosellas' or easily shorn sheep, before the unfortunate novice had finished his cobbler. (1940,Te Waimate,129)

MASTERS I let him get his third sheep on the board, then grabbed the rosella, hacked the few tufts of wool off and dumped her out of the porthole. (1960,Back-Country Tales,258)

LOUGHNAN rosella: a sheep that has cast most of its wool before shearing. The shearer will usually leave it until last so that he can use it for timing his catch. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,67)

rosella parakeet¶

n.

The predominant birds in the garden are generally introduced - sparrows, thrushes, blackbirds, finches and, in the north, mynas, rosella parakeets and various doves and pigeons. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,25)

rosette plant¶

n. Notothlaspi rosulatum

(1892,NZ Country Journal) [NOTES: (Canterbury A & P Assoc.) (And)]

rosie¶

n. a marble [[ca1912 Berhampore, Wellington]]

HYDE The girls rolled their marbles gingerly up against the school walls, but the boys knelt at the side of the big rings, and very deliberately cannoned one another's rosies and glimmers out of the way. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,30,1970 ed.)

rosin¶

n. gum, especially kauri gum [In Taranaki in the 1930s, resin was always pronounced "rosin" (DEH)]

ELDER I should wish you to bring as much hemp as you possibly can, and such spars and timber as you may, with Mr. Hall, judge valuable. Pork, if it is to be obtained, and salt fish, rosin, or any other natural productions. (1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,55,1934 ed.) [NOTES: 1814 Marsden in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 55]

MARSDEN New Zealand must be always considered as the great emporium of the South Seas, from its local situation, its safe harbours, its navigable rivers, its fine timber for ship building, its rosin, native flax, etc., etc., specimens of which I intend sending to the Society by this conveyance. Ibid. 210 There is here and there the root of a pine which has been burnt into the surface of the ground, and pieces of rosin, which have come from the pine tree, are lying on the ground in all directions. (Sep 22, 1814,Letters & Journals,133,1932 ed.)

Ross Safety Belt¶

n. a life-saving device

Any kind of entanglement or snag of the line could drag the swimmer under. It wasn't until 1948 that the Ross Safety Belt - a harness held together with a single pin - was designed by a New Zealander. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/38)

Ross Sea Region¶

n. the region previously known as the Ross Dependency

The Ross Sea Region used to be known as the Ross Dependency, and is New Zealand's slice of the Antarctic pie... The report indentifies two key pressures on the Ross Sea Region environment. (Mar 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 50/14)

rot¶

v. disparage

He states a soldier was "rotting" a rifle, saying that it would not fire true, and was a "crookie". (Nov 11, 1915,Feilding Star,2)

rot off¶

v. (Rural) [sheep feet] to be afflicted with advanced foot-rot.

WALLACE In the plain language of the country people, the feet of animals suffering from the animals suffering from the effects of the ergot-poison are said to 'rot off.' The description, though rather brusque, is pretty nearly correct. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,307)

rotaflow system¶

n.

I had long heard of the herring-bone milking shed, but the rotaflow system.. was a new development... The Friesan cows walk into individual bails on the slowly revolving platform; the milking cups go on; each cow does a circuit; the cups are automatically removed; and then the cows receive a light spray of water which serves to nudge them out of the bail towards the yard. (May 8, 1993,Dominion,17)

rotary¶

n. (Rural) a rotary design of cowshed, where milkers are located in its centre. [ORIGIN: ellipsis] (See also rotary shed)

A rotary would probably cost from $2500 to $3000 more than a herringbone. (Jul 1971,NZ Dairy Exporter,9)

Jobs Currently it is a semi self-contained unit milking 940 cows for 340 000 thru a new 54 bale [sic] rotary. The main farm of 260 ha will milk some 850 cows thru the 1 year old rotary. (Jan 2002,Fencepost.com,4)

Wing Point Farm is a new conversion milking 800 dairy cows through a 70 bale rotary. (Apr 3, 2002,Dominion,18)

He has sited the new shed on the same site as his previous rotary which now sits close by in the bull paddock. 'The bulls enjoy playing with it,' says Brian with a laugh. [rotary cowshed] (Oct 31, 2002,Opunake and Coastal News,14)

rotary clothesline¶

n.

SLATTER The high paling fences behind the house and the patch of lawn under the rotary clothesline ... (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,103)

rotary herringbone cowshed¶

n. a shed similar to rotary turnstyle except that the milker is in the centre and the cows face outwards.

Rotary Herringbone cowshed. Similar to rotary turnstyle except that the milker is in the centre and the cows face outwards. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,39)

rotary shed¶

n. (See also rotary)

A lot has been written about the various types of rotary shed. (Feb 1972,NZ Dairy Exporter,2)

LAMBERT [Caption] During the 1970s the acceptance of intensive dairying methods.. resulted in the development of further ' production line' techniques such as this rotary milking shed. (1983,Illustrated History of Taranaki,150)

In his new rotary shed, the cows step onto a slowly turning platform and have the cups attached ... When the cows have completed the circuit the cups are removed automatically, enabling Karl to milk 600 cows singlehandedly in an hour. Ibid. 38 I have just watched the afternoon milking of 350 cows. It took about an hour in a rotary shed that has more in common with the Sydney Opera House than with John Scott's old herringbone shed... One at a time, the cows boarded a huge, slow merry-go-round capable of holding 66 animals and stood side by side like slides in a carousel, heads facing the centre. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/32)

rotary turnstyle cowshed¶

n. a shed in which cows are milked on a rotating platform with the milker on the outside and the cows facing the centre.

Rotary turnstyle cowshed. Cows are milked on a rotating platform with the milker on the outside and the cows facing the centre. The cows step on to the platform and reverse off. Cups are put on from behind. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,39)

When he played rugby, the drinking was "colossal". "We'd be at the pub and it would be like going around and around in a rotary cowshed.." (Nov 14, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C5)

rotate¶

v. (See wouldn't it rotate you)

Wouldn't it rotate you! Have to waste another half mug of water to get clean again. (Dec 21, 1942,NZEF Times,II/78 : 17)

I am rotated more than somewhat. (Dec 21, 1942,NZEF Times,II/78 : 19)

rotation length¶

1 n. (Rural) the length of time and rate of movement of stock around a farm.

RENNIE The length of term the herd of cows spend in each paddock is called the rotation length. In summer/autumn the farmer may again 'lengthen' the rotation by grazing cows in the same paddock for two milkings. (1988,Agriculture in NZ,32)

WHITE ET AL The definition of rotation length is often misunderstood. The common definition relates to the proportion of the farm being grazed in one day. Rotation length describes the current rate of movement around the farm. (1999,NZ Pasture and Crop Science,162)

Remember that the farm area is fixed. It is critical not to reduce rotation length if you run out of feed. (Jul 26, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,16)

rotational cross¶

n. a crossbred produced after a period of crossing with a series of breeds used in a set rotation [(farming)]

Crossbred produced after a period of crossing with a series of breeds used in a set rotation. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,15)

rotational grazing¶

1 n. (Rural) the moving of a constant number of stock from paddock to paddock, in order to control feed.

The more effective utilization of pastures is also facilitated by so-called `rotational grazing,' milking cows being followed in a field by dry and young stock or ewes. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,28)

The system of rotational grazing practised on so many dairy farms, should be even more popular than it is.. (Feb 20, 1930,NZ Dairy Exporter,1)

STEVENS Rotational grazing on hill country pasture has a detrimental effect on lamb weight, lambing percentage, wool weight and general thrift. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,61)

MACMILLAN If the farm is well sub-divided you can stock up to several hundred animals per hectare and hold them on to the paddocks for only brief periods. This pattern of feeding stock is called rotational grazing or mob-stocking. (1980,Land Development in the Chatham Islands,17)

BARNES Rotational grazing was not much used by dairy farmers in the 1940s; the length of fencing seemed to many to make the idea uneconomic. (1987,Country Calendar (TVNZ),99)

rotationally graze¶

1 v. (Rural) to move stock into several different grazing locations throughout the year.

To maintain good growth during this period, calves should be rotationally grazed from three weeks of age, so that a fresh grazing area is provided daily. (Sep 1961,NZ Journal of Agriculture,231)

Ewes and lamb are set-stocked from lambing until weaning. Ewe lambs are then rotationally grazed until mid-May, when they go on to kale. (Jan 1965,NZ Journal of Agriculture,45)

BARDSLEY We mob-stocked and rotationally grazed, so disease spread. (2000,Land Girls, The,160)

roto¶

n. (See rata)

rotobaler¶

1 n. (Rural) a baling machine that produces round bales.

ASPINALL The station has a complicated machine called a rotobaler which makes round bales. (1976,High Country Sheep Station,34)

Rotoehu Ash¶

n. Geol. definition

The first day commenced near Matawai where a 6 m thick sequence (from Rotoehu Ash 50 kyr to Taupo Pumice 1800 yrs B.P.) is preserved in a road cutting on SH2 a few kilometers east of Matawai. ... At the top of Panikau Hill a thin but relative [sic] complete distal section is preserved and contains Rotoehu Ash through to Taupo Pumice. (Jul 1984,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,65/17)

Stratigraphic position: mud overlying Rotoehu Ash. (May 1976,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,41/22)

rotoflow¶

1 n. (Rural) a rotary design of cowshed.

Another shed is being built. A 50-bale rotor-flow rotary. (Aug 8, 1996,NZ Farmer,20)

Consistent fertiliser history, 36 bale rotoflow cowshed. (Jun 23, 2001,Dominion,39)

First farms with improvements like this are hard to find. 24 bale rotoflow cowshed, excellent racing and farm buildings. [rotor-flow] (Oct 17, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,19)

Rotoiti Breccia¶

n. Geol. definition

Howarth, R. Relative and absolute age of the Rotoiti Breccia formation. (Nov 1976,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,42/26)

Rotokawa Ash¶

n. Geol. definition

Above the latter is a form of diatomaceous silt at the base of which is a thin layer Rotokawa Ash, undated but thought to be c.4000 years B.P. (May 1975,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,39/35-6)

Rotokawau Ash¶

n. Geol. definition

On field appearance and stratigraphy, the thin tephra was considered not to be an Okataina tephra [sic, small 't'] (Kaiharoa or Whakatane Tephra) but perhaps a tephra from Taupo or the basaltic Rotokawau Ash. (Oct 1984,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,66/18) [NOTES: Is this the same as Rotokawa Ash???]

Rotomahana Mud¶

n. Geol. definition

The upper part of the section comprises Taupo Pumice, Kaharoa Ash and Rotomahana Mud intercalated with beds of peat. (May 1975,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,39/36)

Rotorainer¶

n. (Rural) [from trade name] a rotary spray irrigation plant.

They have decided on a low pressure Roto-rainer. (Jul 14, 1983,NZ Farmer,31)

The Roto-rainer itself has taken some getting used to. (Aug 23, 1984,NZ Farmer,28)

Irrigation planning and management experience (Rotar rainers [sic] and Gun.) (Nov 18, 2000,Press, The,43)

This property is one of the best of its type. The total area is spray irrigated by two Rotorainers. (Nov 25, 2000,Press, The,64)

Rotorua Ash¶

n. Geol. definition

The base of the section comprises ridges of pumice sand gravel mantled by Okareka Ash, Rerewhakaaitu Ash and Rotorua Ash now truncated by lake waters when the lake level was at an elevation of 284 m as against the present day elevation of 279.7 m. (May 1975,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,39/35)

Rotorua smell¶

n. a smell of hydrogen sulphide

[Hydrogen sulphide] can be detected as a `Rotorua' smell at one part in two million. (Aug 1955,AJHR,H31A/15) [NOTES: (Report of the Fumes Enquiry, Auckland)]

Rotorua smelt¶

n. Retropinna lacustris

NATUSCH Usually smaller [than the two-inch Southland smelt] is the Rotorua smelt, R. lacustris, which occurs naturally in cold as well as thermal lakes. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,209)

GRAHAM399 Rotorua Smelt Retropinna lacustris Stokell (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 399]

Rotorua tea cakes¶

n. recipe

ROTORUA TEA CAKES flour ... baking powder ... butter to be rubbed in, 1 egg, and enough milk to moisten and drop on shelf. (1908,Souvenir of All Nations Fair,41)

Rototuna waffles¶

n. recipe

BASHAM ROTOTUNA WAFFLES ... flour ... butter ... milk ... salt ... baking powder ... 3 eggs beaten separately ... Have the irons hot ... cook a few minutes ... serve either hot or cold with golden syrup. (1939,Aunt Daisy's Cookery Book,141)

Rotovegas¶

n. Rotorua [ORIGIN: blend, Popularised by Craig Marriner's novel "Stonedogs" but according to Linda Clark and Marriner on Radio NZ Nine to Noon (23/7/02) it has been around and used for some time.]

Some predicted there would be a quickie divorce in Roto-vegas and another Alliance before the year was out. (Aug 13, 2002,Dominion Post,B6)

It's appropriate that Forestcorp's operational base is in Rotorua, known to some as Roto Vegas because of its glitzy tour (Feb 11, 1995,Dominion,12)

Here, at last, was star quality. Rotovegas star quality. (Sep 11, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

MARRINER A day or so later, your Mr X.. found a need to kill two patched Black Power members and one associate, all hailing from your home town of sunny Roto-Vegas. (2001,Stonedogs,349)

Rotovegas News and Times (Nov 9, 2004,Radio NZ / National Radio)

Stonedogs, by Craig Marriner... It's a real Kiwi story and it's set in Rotovegas. (Feb 4, 2006,Time Out,4)

Organising a weekend at Rotovegas, with a hot pool included. (Feb 8, 2006,Viva,5)

Summer in Rotovegas and it's hosing down. (Feb 14, 2009,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

We've got Rotovegas. (Jul 14, 2004,TV1)

It takes place in an animal kingdom he knows well, the netherworld of drug dealing and gang banging in Roto-Vegas, before heading on a dark road-trip to murder. (Jul 27, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

Known as Roto-Vegas for its tourist kitsch appeal, Rotorua is quite a different kettle of trout... (Sep 19, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),40)

I'm from Rotorua, which is also known as "Rotovegas", I wasn't aware Dannevirke had the same sort of nickname! (Oct 29, 2001,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.geocities.com/dannevirkefire/Feedback.htm]

Rotorua's CBD ban: Is banning ratbags from Rotovegas central an infringement of their human rights or a piece of inspired thinking? (Aug 6, 2006,Sunday Star Times,A9)

Chiefs take jackpot in Rotovegas spree [headline] That cued a rather confident and well lubricated gentleman sitting in the main stand at last night's venue to stand and roar: "welcome to Rotovegas you Bulls". (Mar 23, 2008,Sunday Star Times,B5)

But they have begun to call the place "Roto-vegas" for a reason -- the density of motels and gimcrack places is near the tipping point. (Apr 4, 2004,Washington Post,P.01) [NOTES: Steve Hendrix]

Mary Wilson A staff member who has been away on leave for a while came back today and he said Rotovegas was the name of a country music band based in Rotorua that was set up by Sid Hughes in the 1980s. They were playing around with names for the band and came up with Rotovegas. I have not been able to find anything yet to confirm this - unfortunately we have not indexed the Daily Post for the 1980s yet. (May 1, 2003,Personal Communication) [NOTES: MaryEllen.Wilson@rdc.govt.nz]

rotten¶

adj. very drunk, espec. in GET ROTTEN. (cf (GET) STINKING [ca1940 Les Cleveland]

rotten corn¶

n. kanga pirau, fermented corn

MERDEITH I sampled a new Maori dish on this trip - kanga kopirau (rotten corn). It has a bouquet just about as potent as the dead whale I mentioned in my last. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,146,1935 ed.)

Nothing can be more pitiable than the nonsense talked to these poor men and women, taken from their pigstye-like hut, and their diet of rotten corn, and assured that they are the greatest and finest fellows imaginable. (Jan 14, 1864,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Professor Behring .. might try to induce us to follow in the "healthful" exercise of feeding on the rotten corn which our dusky brethren relish so much ... (Apr 20, 1905,Wanganui Herald,2)

The stench from the rotten corn near the settlements is something awful. (Jul 29, 1887,Bay of Plenty Times,2)

He had had two wives before and he married them in the Maori style, sans ceremony, sans kai, try s'sark [sic] or rotten corn banquets, and he found the results eminently satisfactory. (Feb 20, 1915,NZ Truth,6)

Yet this sensitive organisation always appeared to be the more strange when the horribly stinking smells of two of their common articles of food - often, in the olden times, in daily use - are considered: rotten corn (maize, in the cob) long steeped in water to soften it, and dried shark. (Mar 4, 1893,Timaru Herald,4)

rotten eggs¶

1 n. a flower, Eschscholtzia california [also rotten egg plant]

Even more of a nuisance to New Zealand farmers are Californian poppies, Escholzia californica, better known in Centra Otago in my childhood as rotten eggs. This was probably for the intense orange of the flowers... In its home in California, great sweeps of egg-yolk gold against the blue leaves are breathtaking. Since the rotten egg has become a darling of the landscape designer, several colours have evolved, including pink, a near brown, and a beautiful soft clotted-cream that comes true from seed year after year. (Jun 4, 1999,Dominion,12)

2 n. [schoolboys' game]

GEORGE TURNER A game played by rolling a tennis ball into holes each occupied by a player, who, if the ball gets into his hole, tries tobrand' the roller. Possibly a game peculiar to our school.' (1931,Diary) [NOTES: 1931 George Turner Diary (Dannevirke)]

TURNER In small schools without proper playing fields, games were spontaneous and enjoyable, and holes could be dug freely in the school grounds for Rotten Eggs, in which a tennis ball is rolled into the nest of one of the players and all run while the boy with the ball has to brand another player (i.e. hit him with the ball). (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,159)

rotten fish plant¶

n.

rotten fish plant [=] fish-guts plant [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,65)

rotten rock¶

n.

He simply followed a sheep track across the rugged, steep terrain, some of it like granite, some of it crumbling "rotten rock", debris from which almost buried the crawler. (Mar 2005,NZ Geographic,72/27)

The fern and scrub covering the hillside is some 140 feet above the road, and immediately beneath it irregular strata of 'rotten rock' juts out. (Sep 6, 1929,Evening Post,10)

About 5 miles of clay road was given a good coating of soft stone which was called Rotten Rock. (Jun 2001,NZ Memories,No. 30/13)

rottie¶

n. (informal) a rottweiler dog [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Having a murderous, heaving rottie lunging about in the front yard makes an ugly statement about the humans within. (May 3, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

Did ya see Hartie being torn to pieces by those rotties last night? (Dec 5, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A135)

Except for the rottie and the baby,.. he seems free of encumbrances of any kind. (Jan 11, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

Who knows what a rottie's tail looks like, or what might have grown out the back of a boxer? (Nov 13, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35)

Till recent years, you could say there were A-grade biters.. breeds that, if not well-handled, could go to the bad side, such as rotties, german shepherds and dobermanns. (Mar 8, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

Plans by TV show-maker Cloud 9 of Avalon for a movie theme park a rottie's bark from Naenae sound surreal (Aug 26, 2000,Evening Post,20)

rotty¶

n. as rottie q.v.

It's just a small place. It's a bit rundown and looks like it should have a rotty out the back. (Mar 21, 1999,Sunday Star Times,F1)

rotutu¶

n.

The manuka, mahoe, akeake, rotutu, lacebark and flax seedlings will grow to be "gigantic and humungous" says Mitchell Campbell and Jason Ranguia, though the exact names of the plants escape them. (Aug 2000,Elements,No. 5 : 6)

rough¶

n. a fish [(fishermen's)]

[species name] mixed fish .. [scientific name] -- [other name(s)] roughs, rubbish fish, felix (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

v. to shear sheep roughly and badly, esp. as ROUGH 'EM [(shearers')]

McKEE WRIGHT But he wouldn't shear [sheep] ... in to rough them through. (1897,Station Ballads,37) [NOTES: (`The Bloke that Ran Across a Snag')]

ROUGH 'EM. The opposite to `pink 'em', and meaning rough shearing and a bad job of the sheep. (1956,Wool Away!,156)

MILLS To keep level [with the ringer] the challenger started to rough them out a bit'. This did [130] not suit the boss whochipped' him quite a few times ... and then sacked him. (1960,Sheep-O,129)

Rough 'm. Rough shearing. Opposite to pink 'em. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,58)

v. (Rural) to shear carelessly.

BOWEN Rough 'em. The opposite to 'pink 'em' and meaning rough shearing and a bad job of the sheep. (1955,Wool Away!,156)

MILLS To keep level the challenger started to 'rough them out a bit.' (1960,Sheep-O,129)

MAF Rough 'em: Rough shearing. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,58)

1 n. (Rural) a land area containing second growth blackberry, bracken or scrub.

In the breaking in the land from the rough, Mr Anderson follows a regular system and is gradually covering the whole farm. (Apr 1, 1944,NZ Dairy Exporter,4)

TAIT Now a highly developed property, Putere was taken up in the rough in 1928. (1955,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,33)

ANDERSON Most of the sheep are now coming down into the valleys and getting the young grass have taken the rough off. (1962,Life's Roundabout, A,75)

NEWTON There are of course still about 2,500 acres still in the rough - bush and scrub ... [in the rough] (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,167)

rough as (old) boots¶

phr. [ca1920s WHB Orsman; -->ca1950s Wanganui see rough as houses; rough as old boots (DEH) Taranaki 1930s]

rough as a bag of files¶

phr.

... but as the engine was still rough as a bag of files, the pilot wared a `washout' and headed for home. (Sep 15, 1918,Kia-ora Coo-ee,Second Series 3/2,1981 ed.)

rough as a bag/bags/sacks¶

phr. [also (as) rough as a pig's breakfast]

Idiomatic use of `as' to introduce a simile. ... Two may possibly be Canterbury expressions (at least, I never heard them outside the province): (1) As rough as a bag. (2) As rough as a pig's breakfast. (Sep 9, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

BAKER ... rough as a bag (the Australians also have rough as bags), and rough as a pig's breakfast. (1941,NZ Slang,53)

BENNETT The Australian rough as bags' has becamerough as sacks'. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,91)

Smarten `em up. .... Rough as bags. (1946,Johnny Enzed in the Middle East,23)

PARTRIDGE Rough as a bag or rough as a pig's breakfast. Uncouth: New Zealand and Australian: C. 20. B., 1941 and 1942. Cf rough as .. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1157)

WHITWORTH ... the kids were rough as bags and the food wasn't very choice. (1950,Otago Interval,50)

SYDER & HODGETTS Very rough in manners, and/or appearance. .in 4;`He's unkempt, spits and swears regardless of time and place he's as rough as a bag.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS]) [NOTES: (1962-63) 1974 SYDER AND HODGETTS Aust. and NZ English [TS] 15]

TURNER There is simile: as mad as a snake',as bald as a bandicoot' (an embroidery on the English bald as a coot'),as happy as larry', rough as bags' (which I know better in the variantrough as sacks'), `as wet as a shag'. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The)

THERE are twenty-two acceptors in the event, and most of them are, as they say in the classics, rough as sacks. (Oct 7, 1926,NZ Truth,11)

rough as a pig's breakfast¶

phr. [see Baker NZ Slang p.53 (also rough as a dog's breakfast: ca1910 W.H.B. Orsman)]

rough as a soojee bag¶

phr.

BEATTIE [Sugar] came in mats, the big ones weighing 180 lbs, and was often called mat sugar'. This mat was native made, being a pleated plant, and was pretty well square. Outside this mat, and covering it, was a coarse bag called a soojee (or suji?) bag. A familiar saying of the early days was,As rough as a soojee bag', and this saying was applied to both people and things. Up to 1863 I never saw sugar except in mats ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,97)

rough as bags¶

phr. roughly made or done; rough and ready; very untidy [cf. other 'rough as' expressions]

HYDE I haven't seen a dance in months, outside of the local hops, and they're as rough as bags. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,144,1970 ed.)

SLATTER He's as rough as bags but his heart is right. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,44)

TURNER There is simile: as mad as a snake',as bald as a bandicoot' (an embroidery on the English bald as a coot'),as happy as larry', rough as bags' (which I know better in the variantrough as sacks'), `as wet as a shag'. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,115)

MASON sc. violent MAORI GIRL: ... I took him on after my girl friend Tui got fed up with him. But he could be rough, rough as bags. Beat me up once, and that was the finish. (1974,Hand on the Rail, The,30)

As a consequence one night towards the end of June there appeared at a farm in the Waerenga Valley a youngish man who might best be described as "rough as bags." (Aug 1, 1929,NZ Truth,7)

rough as guts¶

phr. (See cf. rough-as-guts adj)

Our Sergeant sez we are as `rough as gutz' (Jul 5, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,253)

HOLDEN ...a pretty typical pighunter's firearm: rough as guts but still capable of delivering the goods. (1982,Wild Pig,10)

HENDERSON `Rough as guts,' said some. But to stay there [at the hut] for a few days brought an affinity with shattered stumps ... (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,134)

McGILL rough as guts crude, inferior, very rough; eg `This car is as rough as guts. Needs servicing, for sure.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

Cool. Rough as guts (edited on two VCRs) and mad as a bicycle, Back of the Y stands as their best attempt at the worst possible taste. (Jan 27, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

Our sergeant sez we are as "rough as gutz". (Jul 5, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/47 : 253)

rough as houses¶

phr. [(also rough as boots) p.c. I.W.A.Jamieson His father used it c1950s Wanganui; WHBO c1940s]

rough chervil¶

n.

rough chervil [s] Chaerophyllum temulum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,65)

rough comfrey¶

n.

rough comfrey [s] Symphytum asperum Lep. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,65)

rough country¶

1 n. (Rural) land that is difficult to access easily, to muster, manage and graze [ with a low carrying-capacity and often with growth of weeds and scrub.]

The Maories [sic] were emboldened by the result of former wars, especially that in the North, which, carried on in a rough country, where natural obstacles crippled the operations of regular troops, was not conducted or concluded in such a way as to impress the Maories with the prowess of our troops ... (Oct 6, 1860,Otago Witness,5)

The body was brought 40 miles over rough country to town for an inquest. (Apr 22, 1871,Evening Post,2)

He took up a run in South Canterbury, but owing to the rough country and rabbits abandoned it. (Dec 7, 1891,Evening Post,2)

NEAVE This is, in fact, a region which is appropriately spoken of, as `rough country' - a region where a horse will plunge without hesitation into a rushing stream, ... (1980,Land of Munros, The,54) [NOTES: 1888 Christian Shirres Diary in 1980 Neave The Land of Munros 54]

NEWTON I might here explain that to a musterer, the term rough country does not imply hard shingle country, but rock-bound bluffy country. Ibid. 85 ... he had cut up a bit rough over the affair. (1947,Wayleggo,56)

After crossing the valley of the same name, it passes along some rough country, and again reaches the foot of the hills ... (Jan 3, 1852,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,178)

The winged bicycle is expected to be of considerable use in providing fast locomotion over bad roads and even across rough country. (Jan 9, 1913,Grey River Argus,8)

BARKER .. many of the men I wanted to reach lived twenty-five or even thirty miles away with very rough country in between. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,122)

In the Auckland district ploughing varies greatly between light and comparatively level lands and rough or bush country. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,293)

100 2-tooth ewes from up-river, 40 18-month steers, off rough country. (Jan 31, 1905,Hawera Star,3)

The silent heading dog is a necessity on rough country. (Mar 1931,NZ Farmer,231)

On this grade there is a considerable area of rough country suitable only for wethers. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,100)

STUDHOLME .. these two erected forty chains over rough country in five days. (1940,Te Waimate,87)

NEWTON .. to a musterer the term rough country does not imply hard shingle country but rockbound bluffy country. (1947,Wayleggo,56)

It took sixteen men 22 hours to carry him twelve miles, owing to the rough country. (Jun 26, 1907,Grey River Argus,4)

Five miles of rough country at Lower Hutt gave the Brooklyn runners an opportunity of tasting the type of stuff they are likely to encounter in the provincial championships. (Jul 25, 1929,NZ Truth,17)

Later a number of carloads of searchers arrived from Orepuki and Tuatapere and assisted in searching the farm, which is very rough country. (Oct 13, 1931,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,2)

rough dory¶

n.

GRAHAM Rough Dory Capromimus abbreviatus (Hector) (Syn. Antigonis mulleri Klunzinger) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,404) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 404]

WILSON ROUGH DORY: see John Dory (1981,Fisherman's Bible,197)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] dory, rough 1024 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

rough feed¶

1 n. (Rural) stock feed containing rank growth, fern and weeds.

There were 137 acres under crop and 150 acres of rough feed surface-sown. (Oct 13, 1866,Weekly News,5)

When the farm was taken over ten years ago, the 200 acres in grass supported browntop and rough feed. (May 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,14)

CHINN I decided to use bullocks instead of horses to pull the vehicles conveying the flax. Rough feed was available in the forest and river-bed for them, so I had no problem in that direction. (1963,Packtrack to Highway,107)

GORDON They [wild Hokonui sheep] prefer rough feed and will eat heads and thistles before they touch the clover. [rough-fed] (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,101)

rough gecko¶

n. widespread in the Marlborough region this gecko has enlarged scales over the upper surfaces of its body, unusual in a New Zealand lizard. [Naultinus rudis aka rough scaled gecko, rough-scaled gecko. The other NZ lizard with pronounced scaliness is the Marlborough green, or manuka, gecko.]

Despite such constraints, a boldly patterned rough-scaled gecko appears almost invisible among manuka blossom (top left), even the textured scales assisting in the deception. (Sep 2010,NZ Geographic,50)

The Rough Scaled or Rough Gecko is confined to the Kaikoura Ranges, on the east coast of New Zealand's South Island. They generally live in manuka and kanuka, known as tea tree and in forests also. Most active by day. Parts of the gecko are covered in rough scales giving rise to its name. (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: Date is an estimate http://www.nhc.net.nz/index/lizards-new-zealand/rough-gecko/rough-gecko.htm]

Ormandy, 20, an installation installer, and Stirton, 30, a dancer, had been jointly charged after the geckos -- two Northland green geckos and a rough gecko -- were found at their home in the Christchurch suburb of Richmond three weeks ago. (May 3, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nzherald.co.nz/richmond-limited/news/article.cfm?o_id=176&objectid=10380100]

Widlife experts feared the two Northland Green Geckos and one Rough Gecko were destined for the international black market. (Apr 12, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz-customs-service/news/article.cfm?o_id=360&objectid=10377174]

rough it¶

v. and vbl n ROUGHING IT) live a rough life; live on rough fare or in rough quarters' is very frequent from 1838 [get quot]. It is often italicised or used within quotation marks, indicating that many early writers considered itcolonial' usage

THOMSON Genteel settlers .... unused, as the expressive colonial phrase goes, to `rough it'. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,313)

HURSTHOUSE ... so long as he were willing to work, and `rough it' for the first year or so, ... (1861,New Zealand (various authors/titles),257)

WILSON ... we are supposed to be `roughing it'; ... (1894,In the Land of the Tui,89) [NOTES: 1890 Mar 3 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 89]

[He] found there was a culture of "roughing it" in Dunedin, whereby students expected some level of discomfort, and just "got on with it". (Nov 11, 2003,Dominion Post,A8)

rough leatherjacket¶

n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] leatherjacket, rough 2333-40 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

rough on rats¶

phr. ? as a catchphrase, hard on rats (? with an implied pun on a well-known brand of rat-poison (`Rough-on-Rats') if it existed then [AND 1888 (get this cit: ?literal) = bad luck: HWO- but is the NZ sense this or merely transf.] -

DUNCAN [The dog] became .... `rough on rats' (1888,Wakatipians,53)

Rough Riders¶

n. Boer War volunteers from NZ

C.E. & E.L. CHRISTIAN NZ Rough Riders ... (1900,Our Boys)

SKEY [Title] To the New Zealand Rough-Riders (Title page and cover: The Rough Riders Contingent for South Africa) (1900,Patriotic Rhymes,1)

HAYDON The third contingent, or Rough Riders. (1907,New Zealanders & the Boer War,59)

MOORE It may not be amiss to explain how the name Rough Riders' came to be applied to the contingents. The Premier .... expressed a strong opinion that we should not accept the title ofBushmen' which had been adopted in Australian. [because of possible confusion with the Bushmen of South Africa] .... As they were not regularly trained troops, and were to be good riders ready for rough work, he thought they should be called `Rough Riders', and expressed the hope that they would be particularly rough on the enemy. Accordingly the name was adopted, and under it the Third and Fourth Contingents have been raised. (1907,With the Fourth NZ Rough Riders,10)

BROWN The departure of a few lads to the Boer War at the turn of the century - Rough Riders they were called. .... (1949,Short History of Belfast, Canterbury,12)

CRESSWELL When however the Boer War began and Canterbury started recruiting her special contingent of Rough Riders, prices for many commodities, and especially for oats on which the Rough Riders' horses were to be fed - these commodity prices began to rise. (1951,Canterbury Tales,86)

MASTERS At the time [1897] Charlie Golding, who later, during the South African war, served with the famous contingent of rough riders was working at [67] the time [sic] for Rhymers. (1959,Tales of the Mails,66)

HARWOOD [Boer War] At the start of the Boer War he enlisted in the 5th Contingent of Rough Riders' The nameRough Riders' was given to the New Zealand troops by thte[sic] Premier, the Right Hon. Richard John Seddon. He was of the opinion that they should not be called `Bushmen' as the Australian men were called. He had been told that the Bushmen of Africa were held in contempt and he objected to New Zealand men starting with a name that would suggest anything but the respects he was quite sure they would be entitled to. (1982,Heritage Trail,64)

Kimberly was safe on Sunday last, and Mr. Cecil Rhodes commands the Rough Riders there. (Oct 25, 1899,Evening Post,4)

[Caption] Auckland Rough Riders for Fourth Contingent; The First Parade at Potter's Paddock. (Feb 16, 1900,Auckland Weekly News,Suppl. 5)

The value of such men as our Rough Riders in actual warfare is very amply demonstrated. (Feb 23, 1900,Auckland Weekly News,Suppl. 8)

Aucklanders' farewell to their contingent of Rough Riders was an event which thousands of people will be pleased to remember. (Mar 16, 1900,Auckland Weekly News,Suppl. 2)

rough sheep¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep that has missed a docking, shearing or muster and is often wild. (See double-fleecer; double-decker; hermit; long tailer)

The tobacco may be put in wire cages or gunny bags, and allowed to boil ten minutes, 400 gallons at once, in malt tanks, the lids being on; but the best plan is to infuse under pressure of steam from a boiler, a pipe from which would heat the dip in the morning and regulate the temperature afterwards, which with newly shorn sheep should be 115 to 118 deg., and in rough sheep 120 to 125 deg. About 1 minutes for shorn and 2 for rough sheep should be effectual. (Jan 23, 1875,Otago Witness,18)

CHALLENGE. THROUGH some ill-feeling against me at the Oroua Downs, I am willing to shear Mr. Jenkins, in long-wool sheep, for any sum from GBP5 to GBP20; but I do not call it fair shearing for another man to shear all the rough sheep out of his pen. JOSEPH MORRISON. (Dec 3, 1884,Wanganui Herald,3)

In all 6,789 sheep, 25 head cattle, and 6 horses were sold as follows: .. 59 rough sheep at 9s 8d, 1117 crossbred lambs to 4s 11d. (Feb 27, 1896,Otago Witness,26)

NEWTON Rough Sheep: Domesticated sheep which has escaped musterers and has gone semi-wild. Distinct from the real wild sheep of Canterbury, and unlike them do not shed their wool. Consequently they become overburdened with wool, which at times reached such length that it drags on the ground Ibid. Wayleggo 29 ... Catching stragglers and rough sheep. Ibid. 154 These sheep were real wild sheep - not the ordinary domestic sheep gone wild. The latter, long-tailers and woolies which have escaped muster and gone semi-wild, are known as `rough sheep' (1947,Wayleggo,[Gloss].)

We finished shearing on the 6th February, and then there were 14,229; and I believe that near 100 rough sheep that were not mustered at shearing, were included in the count at delivery. (Mar 21, 1868,Otago Witness,6)

SMITH Busy making a paddock with James Smith, my cousin, at back of house for rams & rough sheep (said rough sheep consist of stragglers found on run after shearing.) (Jan 12, 1864,Diary,22) [NOTES: in Patterson (1998) Hey Days and Dray Days]

SMITH After this I rode to the Native Pah and got a Maori to shear the rough sheep. (Feb 15, 1864,Diary)

NEWTON On the Gap's block where the ridge is particularly ragged, there is nearly always a little mob of these rough sheep. Rough sheep are a curse to musterers, and when they are caught, they usually finish up as mutton. (1947,Wayleggo,94)

NEWTON .. longtailers and woollies which have escaped muster and gone semi-wild are known as 'rough' sheep. (1966,Boss's Story, The,154)

HENDERSON This country has only just been taken over by the station off Craigieburn and there was [sic] a lot of rough sheep on it. (1969,Open Country Calling,39)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Record tallies, rough sheep, tough tucker and crook guts all figure in yarns that are passed on. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,34)

In 9 hours Wi Henare shore 354 sheep - ewes and lambs - and in week of 48 hours his record was 1600, and this among rough sheep, it is said. (Jan 27, 1917,Poverty Bay Herald,8)

WRIGHT They were big rough sheep on the Maimai, fit to make a shearer's heart Settle down about his boot-tops on the morning of the start. (1897,Station Ballads,35)

NEWTON These sheep were the real wild sheep - not the ordinary domestic sheep gone wild. The latter, long-tailers and woollies which have escaped muster and gone semi-wild, are known as "rough" sheep. (1966,Boss's Story, The,154)

rough skate¶

n. [aka spotted skate]

DOOGUE & MORELAND ROUGH SKATE ... Other names: Raja australis; whai (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,192)

MORELAND ROUGH SKATE [Raja australis] ... Other names include skate and sometimes spotted skate. (1967,Marine Fishes,14)

AYLING ROUGH SKATE Raja nasuta ... The rough skate is named for the many small prickles on the upper surface of the disc that give the skin a distinctive rough texture. (1982,Collins Guide,75,1984 ed.)

PAUL Rough skate Raja nasuta ... Common around New Zealand . (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,34)

SORENSON SKATE (a) Scientific name: Raja nasuta. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Skate. (c) Other common names: Smooth Skate (R. nasuta); Rough Skate (Raja australis); Stingray; Stingaree; Flaps (trade name for Skate `wings'). (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Wellington, Nelson, Picton, Banks Peninsula, Timaru, Greymouth. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,43)

[species name] rough skate .. [scientific name] Raja nasuta .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] skate, rough 291 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

MORELAND ROUGH SKATE ROUGH SKATE [Raja australis] ... Other names include skate and sometimes spotted skate. (1967,Marine Fishes,14)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] skate, spotted 291 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

rough stock¶

n. inferior stock (See cf. clean stock)

CRAY The window dressing' has covered a good deal ofrough stock' of doubtful value. (1933,National Welfare,32)

A strong feeling was expressed that the time had arrived when we must do something better with our land than continue to use it only as a run for rough stock. (Apr 16, 1883,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

rough stuff¶

n. coarse gold

SMITH ... That brought the colours' up to sight. Some times therough' stuff too [i.e. coarse gold] (1946,Poetical Works,200)

rough tree fern¶

n. Dicksonia squarrosa

Sometimes called the Rough tree fern, [Dicksonia squarrosa] has dark harsh leaves and occasionally sprouts offsets at the base. (Nov 30, 2002,Dominion Post,F15)

More familiar is the wheki or rough tree fern (Dicksonia squarrosa), which produced buds on its trunk. (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/69)

FIELD (And) (1890,Ferns of NZ)

(And) (1916,Dunedin Field Club Plant Catalogues)

RICHARDS D[icksonia] squarrosa ... Slender or Rough Tree-fern. WEKI. (1952,Chatham Islands,8)

rough tree fern [=] wheki [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,65)

WILSON Dicksonia squarrosa WHEKII ... Rough tree fern ... Trunk dark brown or black, rough with persistent stalk bases, ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,420)

rough-as-guts¶

adj.

The Purple Death has scored a few hits over the festive season. It's a wine with a difference, recommended as `rough-as-guts' drinking. ... Word of the Purple Death has been spread by mouth but has even reached as far south as the Antarctic. ... At around $10 a bottle, few liquor outlets sell it as well as the Sapich brothers out Henderson way, in West Auckland. (Jan 4, 1987,Sunday News,3)

adj.

The No. 8 fencing wire is that long-standing bastion of national identity reflecting rough-as-guts innovators living off the land. (Apr 13, 2000,Evening Post,4)

He even went to shearing school and, during university breaks, when he was about 20, hung about with a rough-as-guts gang. (Apr 22, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

rough-faced shag¶

n. (Environment)

King Shag Leucocarbo carunculatus (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Carunculated shag, Marlborough Sounds shag, rough-faced shag, Cook Strait cormorant. ... The only shag with pink feet in the Cook Strait and Marlborough Sounds area. Prominent caruncles at base of bill. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,118)

BULLER PHALACROCORAX CARUNCULATUS. (ROUGH-FACED SHAG.) [Buller 1888 shifts 1873 P. carunculatus to P. imperialis, Emperor Shag; and makes a new entry for P. carunculatus, as Rough-faced Shag.] (1873,Birds of New Zealand,332,1888 2nd edn 2/155 ed.)

Hypoleucus carunculatus Gm. Rough-faced Shag. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/75) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

rough-guts¶

n. roughly-behaved person; ill-bred person (See cf rough as guts)

How dare that little rough-guts make fun of Firpo. (1949,Landfall,9/50) [NOTES: (B. Mason)]

rough-meter¶

n.

A test with a `rough-meter,' an instrument attached to the front axle of a car, recorded only nine inches of rise and fall to the mile over the runway, the lowest runway figures the engineers had heard of and giving almost a concrete billiard table compared with the Whenuapai surface. (Sep 10, 1963,Evening Post,28)

Rough-on-Rats¶

n. a former brand of rat poison

A young man named William Ayres took a dose of "Rough on Rats" in a brothel in Grey-street... It came out in the evidence that "rough on rats" consisted of arsenic, magnesia, and a little charcoal. (Mar 26, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,00)

[Advt] R-r-rats! Rats! Rats! Rough on Rats! Hang your dogs and drown your cats; We give a plan for every man To clear his house with Rough on Rats. (May 28, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,37)

[Advt] Rough on Rats is the most extensively advertised and has the largest sale of any Rat, Mouse, Vermin and Insect destroyer in the world. Sold to all nations. (Jul 25, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,35)

LAWLOR Willie, and two other brats, / Licked up all the Rough-on-Rats. / Father said, when mother cried, / 'Never mind, they'll die outside.' (1962,More Wellington Days,79)

A married woman named Catherine Sims, wife of a labourer, committed suicide by taking rough-on-rats. (Jun 15, 1900,Wanganui Herald,2)

Joseph Peebles, who attempted suicide by taking "rough on rats" was committed for trial at the Supreme Court this morning. (Mar 12, 1884,Grey River Argus,2)

She was conscious and admitted having "taken some 'rough on rats' in water," ... (Aug 7, 1890,Otago Witness,30)

"ROUGH ON RATS." -Cleans out rats, mice, roaches, flies, ants, bed-bugs, beetles, insects, skunks, jack-rabbits, gophers. (Jun 2, 1883,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

Afterwards he endeavored to commit suicide by drinking a bottle of "rough on rats," but he was nursed back to a sufficient state of physical fitness to expiate on the scaffold, that penalty which the Supreme Court allotted him. (Sep 29, 1923,NZ Truth,5)

The jury returned a verdict "That the deceased [sc. a 16-year old girl] took a dose of 'rough on rats' while in a state of temporary insanity caused by reading sensational literature." (Jul 17, 1890,Otago Witness,18)

The unfortunate man, after administering "rough on rats" to the children, gave them morphine to ease their pain. (Dec 4, 1890,Otago Witness,31)

[Advt] Don't die in the House. "Rough on Rats" cleans out rats, mice, beetles, roaches, bed-bugs, flies, ants, insects, moles, jack-rabbits, gophers, 7d. (Jan 6, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

At the inquest on the body of Alice Barnaby, who committed suicide at Wellington by taking "Rough on Rats," a verdict was returned that the deceased committed suicide while in a state of temporary insanity. (Jun 14, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

The deceased, who was 32 years of age, took the greater portion of a box of "Rough on Rats" and immediately became seriously ill. (Oct 13, 1917,Wairarapa Daily Times,4)

rough-rider¶

n. a horse-breaker; a rider of unbroken horses [NZ quotations: 1879-1947]

W.H.S. ROBERTS Sometimes the horse succeeds in throwing the rider at the first bound, but a good rough rider defies it for a long time, unless the horse manages to jump out of the saddle or burst the girths. (Aug 23, 1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 Aug 23 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 35]

SWANTON They [unbroken horses] are saddled and mounted by rough riders. (1892,Notes on NZ,122)

2 n.

DILKE Maori rough-riders .... (1868,Greater Britain,393)

2 n.

BAUGHAN [A farmer,] his hat a `rough-rider' felt. [i.e., a slouch hat] (1904,Life in NZ) [NOTES: 1904 Baughan Life in NZ (Empire Review Mar: 176)]

rough-riding¶

n.

On a cattle-run the tasks of mustering and drafting the stock and branding the youngsters are very heavy work, needing the display of considerable powers of rough-riding among the horsemen; while on a sheep-run the lambing and shearing seasons tax every power of the station-hands. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,157)

SUTTON-SMITH Apart from simple climbing there was, for example, `crossing' the plantation on the treetops, and Rough-riding, in which one player sat on a fir tree branch while the others took the end of it and pulled it up and down and then let it go flying up in the air. The player who could stay on the longest was the rough-riding champion. Of a similar nature was Buck-jumping, in which individual players rode a macrocarpa or gum branch [113] to see who could rise the highest. (1981,History of Children's Play,112)

rough-up¶

adj.

There is a rough-up jockey in Ameria named Duggan, who is not particular as to whether he causes a jockey to be knocked over the rails, under the rails, or any other old place. (Sep 10, 1910,NZ Truth,272/2/4)

n. a fight, a free-for-all

Having given him a rough-up, and knowing that the old horse had a bit of pace left, they thought he was good enough for the journey. (May 31, 1884,Evening Post,4)

The fourth round opened with a rough-up, in which Thomas lost his coolness and suffered a lot. (Mar 25, 1909,Taranaki Herald,6)

CHURCH I enjoyed that rough-up (1916,Tonks,91)

MILLER, C.T. & T. Hurt my knee a little in a wrestling match on my bunk during one of the usual roughups. (Aug 15, 1917,Diary,121,1939 ed.)

St. Hippo and Royal Rose had a real solid rough-up on the training track on Friday morning. (Aug 3, 1893,Otago Witness,30)

The three year old Fanny Fisher colt had a "rough-up" before he left, and acquitted himself so well that I should advise readers of the WAIKATO TIMES who are fond of having "a bet" on a good thing, to invest a pound on him for the Canterbury Derby. (Oct 10, 1876,Waikato Times,2)

roughage¶

n. rough growth; scrub [(farming)]

The pastures have a magnificent growth, absolutely free from roughage and with good body in the grass. (May 9, 1908,Taranaki Herald,4)

STUDHOLME The first work of the settlers was to burn off the roughage on large areas of country. .... [82] before lighting a rough facing ... covered with roughage. (1940,Te Waimate,80, 82)

LEVY Roughage - Pasture growth grown to maturity and remaining in situ for winter and summer grazing. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,362)

This will be more needed this season because of the very small hay crop and the small amount of roughage available on all pastures. (Jan 26, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,2)

The pig is an omnivorous animal and needs "roughage" and fresh green feed for his best health and growth, and to produce meat of the best quality. (Apr 24, 1901,Otago Witness,7)

There should be a good deal of roughage left for the autumn, which always materially helps the winter feeding, because the stock do not require to go on the turnips so early. (Jan 12, 1926,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,2)

roughie¶

n. a racehorse which is a rank outsider

One would recommend any young fellow taking on the sport to get a good one in the first place, as all know it takes a good sort to win these days, and the best horse is cheaper to keep than a roughie. (Dec 14, 1920,Grey River Argus,4)

It is wonderful the difference a fashionable jockey makes to a horse's price. With a `roughie' on they go out at 20 to 1, but when a crack jockey is up they are often 6 to 4 propositions. (Jul 16, 1910,NZ Truth,264/2/8) [NOTES: [contrast AND 2. an outsider (horse) 1922]]

Backing a roughie gives as good a chance of a return as following the money - favourites have a poor record in the cup. (Dec 31, 1989,Sunday Star (Auckland),B12)

[Hdg] Graeme oozes confidence in Easter roughie. (Apr 22, 2001,Sunday Star Times,B12)

It was of very little avail to them when the "roughie" won easily. (Mar 7, 1908,NZ Truth,2)

The "jim" went on the Karamu prad, but the jockey became unseated during the race and the second favorite [sic] running off the course let the "roughie" to win comfortably. (Jun 11, 1910,NZ Truth,2)

Khama 9.13 has a roughie's chance only, but nothing in the tail commands more than a passing thought. (Jul 13, 1907,NZ Truth,2)

Roughie: a roughie is more than just someone who has had a late night! Also known as 'a long shot' or a 'rank outsider', it is a horse with very long odds. .. if you win on a roughie, you will be basking in the glory all day. (Dec 5, 2007,Dominion Post Entertain Wellington,23) [NOTES: Wellington Cup Carnival promotion]

n. a poor game

When you play a roughie, everyone knows about it, but if you get the chance to play again, you lift yourself. (Dec 3, 1999,Evening Post,22)

2 n. [(station)] (See cf. woollie n.; rough sheep)

NEWTON [get quot] Ibid. 115 Those odd little lots of dodging old `roughies' (1947,Wayleggo,94)

N EWTON When he took over [the station], the only domestic sheep were `roughies' - long tailers and doubles that had multiplied from those which had escaped the wind-up muster four years before. (1973,Big Country,86,1977 ed.)

RICHARDS a rough or hard-to-shear sheep I did not intend to be caught with roughies' left in my pen when the pressure was on. A shearer will always try to put onearound' his mate when he has a full pen of sheep to pick from. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,93)

3 n.

... I hasten to explain, the stock agent bought on our behalf, a further dozen 18-month steers. `They're roughies,' he advised by phone on the day of the purchase and I admit we waited with just a little trepidation for them to arrive. (May 12, 1985,NZ Times,8)

4 n. an unqualified or rough-and-ready builder or craftsman

WILLIAMS A type ... leading characteristics anarchical tendency. Pride in being a `roughie'. (Feb 27, 1915,New Zealander's Diary,20) [NOTES: (c1922)]

Mr Quigley expressed concern that there were some `roughies' - unqualified carpenters - engaged in building .... (Mar 10, 1975,Dominion,2)

roughing¶

n.

It is a very shorte spell after so much roughing [on a West Coast trip]. (Jun 7, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,189,1950 ed.)

BARKER Two gentlemen of the proposed party were `new chums' like myself, and were strongly in favour of a little roughing ... (1867,Station Life in NZ,126,1870 ed.)

DAVIDSON When our family arrived in the colony first we experienced some heavy roughing. (1889,Stories of NZ Life,40)

roughing out¶

1 n. (Rural) the using of machines with blades to clear land of large trees, leaving some debris behind in windrows.

FERRIS The roughing-out work was done with either a bulldozer or treedozer. The treedozer had the advantage of leaving a windrow on either side of the blade as it passes through the ground surface in the roughing out operation. When the treedozer was used for roughing out, windrows were left throughout the paddock containing stumps, bush, debris and some soil. (1940,Cavalcade of Farming 1840-1940)

roughy¶

2 n. Paratrachichthys trailli

AYLING COMMON ROUGHY (Sandpaper fish) Paratrachichthys trailli ... This species of roughy has small rough scales and because of this [175] feature it is sometimes known as the sandpaper fish. ... Common roughys are found throughout New Zealand, although they are rarely seen north of Cook Strait. (1982,Collins Guide,174,1984 ed.)

Paratrachichthys trailli (Hutton). ... The Roughy or Sand-paper Fish, as the species is called, is not uncommon in trawler catches in New Zealand and southern Australia. (1939,TrNZI,69/231) [NOTES: (Whitley and Phillipps)]

roughy/roughie¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep that has missed at least one docking or shearing. (See double-fleecer; double-decker; hermit; double)

NEWTON When the Brooksdale gang is out these roughies duck down the Castle Hill side and vice versa. (1947,Wayleggo,94)

NEWTON When he took over, the only domestic sheep were 'roughies' - longtailers and doubles that had multiplied from those which had escaped the wind-up muster four years before. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,86)

STACEY Bill had been straggle mustering at the Camden and found there were quite a few roughies that it was impossible to drive in. We were shooting and skinning goats and wild sheep and catching the roughies and shearing them. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,149)

PETER We straggle a block and trace the roughies as they usually have a double fleece. ie we muster for the stragglers and blade-shear bellies and under neck so they can walk out. (2000,Peter Glossary,2)

round¶

n. a tailor-made cigarette [ca1983 Oct 21 Ray Hancox Heard it used in Havelock Pub.]

n.

Wire is called by number or gauge, while posts are rounds, half-rounds or quarters. (May 9, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),51)

n. (goldmining)

HOGG 'Twas when the Rocky River rush began/ ... `and stories told/ Of ounces gotten in a single pan,/ Of nuggety, and round, and shotty gold./ The news like a bush fire through the diggings ran,/ (1875,Lays and Rhymes,176)

McARA Round: A pattern of holes, such as a drift round. `The round' generally referred to the completely drilled and charged drive face. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),331)

1 n. (Rural) a circular-shaped bale of hay.

But small bales have not been completely replaced by the big rounds and big squares. (Oct 19, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,22)

Hay for sale. $4.50, size 15 rounds. Hay, top quality rounds, no weed. (Apr 13, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,24)

Hay straw and balage, rounds and squares, good quality. (Jul 18, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,26)

2 n. a split post

[Advt] 700 No 1 3.0m round posts (Jun 2, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,16)

round finned whaler¶

n. [round finned whaler shark; no supporting evidence of usage yet]

Round-finned whaler, Carcharinus lamia. This species is the lamia,' orrequin,' of the early writers. It is found in the Pacific in small numbers, being most probably identical with [261] the fish recorded as Carcharinus macrurus (Rams. & Ogil. ...1888) ... Fig. 3. - Round finned whaler, Carcharinus lamia. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

round the world for ninepence¶

phr. methylated spirits (as a drink)

(Round the World for Ninepence, Jessies's [sic] Dream, Fix Bayonets, devotees called methylated spirits, recommending orange juice as a dilutant. Diluted or neat, it can, and does, cause blindness). (Jun 10, 1984,NZ Times,10) [NOTES: (J. Henderson)]

McGILL round the world for threepence/fourpence/ninepence drinking methylated spirits: reinforced by Jim Henderson's memorable description of his one snort of meths, mistaken for cough mixture, as `utterly vile, then chest lit up like a cauliflower.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

round trap¶

n. [(obs) [?d.] E. Fairburn Maharatanga 8 Previous to this [sc. first cricket game 1833-4] the only game with bat and ball which we New Zealand boys knew was Round Trap,]

round-leaved beech¶

n. Nothofagus menziesii

KIRK With the view of obviating the confusion caused by the misuse of the common names hitherto applied to the New Zealand beeches, I would suggest the adoption of new names based on the obvious characteristics of their foliage:- For Fagus fusca, tooth-leaved beech; for Fagus solandri, entire-leaved beech; and for Fagus menziesii, round-leaved beech. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,17)

round-leaved mint¶

n.

mint, round-leaved [s] Mentha rotundifolia (L.) Huds. Ibid. 65 round-leaved mint [s] Mentha rotundifolia (L.) Huds. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,49)

round-up¶

n. [also rounding up n. below]

SWANTON Previous to shearing those is the general muster, which means the rounding up and bringing in of all the sheep, good and bad, on the `run' (1892,Notes on NZ,97)

AYSON Minor adventures in rounding up wild cattle in swamp country running up from the lake on the north side of Taratu also befell Thomas. Single-handed, he one day made a very satisfactory round-up .. (1937,Thomas,44)

roundabout¶

n. a (? missionary) garment to hide the nakedness of Maori women.

LUSH In two minutes the whole lot [of the bathing Maori schoolgirls] stood quietly looking at us, clothed from top to toe in their long full roundabouts. [177] In came a file of five young Maori women, the head scholars in their blue striped roundabouts. (Jan 17, 1856,Auckland Journals,176)

THOMSON For these [domestic] services the whaler engaged to dress his wife in a `round about,' treat her kindly, .... (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/293)

PAUL [The Maori women's] usual dress is .... a shapeless sack of printed calico, called a `roundabout', tied round the neck but loose at the waist. (1861,New Zealand, As It Was and As It Is,17)

BAINES I also gave [the Maori girl] eight yards of Navy blue print (which every one knows is enough for a `roundabout') (1874,Edward Crewe,118)

PHILIPS The hosters [at Waiwera 1850] did not dress for dinner ... her usual attire being a Maori roundabout. (1890,Reminiscences of Early Days,7)

COWAN Ngapuhi girls ... well plumped-out of figure, swing up and down the roadway flaunting the print gowns and the brightly-coloured `roundabouts' and the glittering ear-rings bought with the dollars of the sailormen. (1922,NZ Wars, The,1/7)

COWAN The payment ... consisted of ... 100 figs of tobacco, four greenstone pendants, ... two `roundabouts' (loose brightly coloured blouses for the ladies), and one axe. (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,33)

roundie¶

n. a tailor-made cigarette [(naval and prisoners') ca1948 N.Z. Navy (Les Cleveland) ca1984 also prison slang.] (See also round)

Ihimaera & Long He was smoking roundies! (1982,Into the World of Light,175)

NEWBOLD (1982,Big Huey, The,253)

roundmouth¶

n. Cyclothone microdon (Gunther)

GRAHAM Roundmouth Cyclothone microdon (Gunther) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,400) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 400]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] roundmouth 562 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Roundtable¶

n. the New Zealand Business Roundtable, a business association and pressure group, of right wing and extreme free market views. In extended use, a synonym for well-off people likely to have such views.

GEE "It's Round Table country, mate. The rates are something fearful." (1992,Going West,88)

This made me think that the allegations of the roundtable involvement are true and the ad is in fact illegitimate. (Oct 12, 2000,City Voice,3)

(Jun 5, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26) [NOTES: The Roundtable is sharpening its freemarket axe for the Dairy Board... The Roundtable is intent on grafting its basic freemarket ideology onto agriculture.]

roupo¶

n. (See raupo)

rourou¶

n. contribution; food basket http://translator.kedri.info/translate.php [noun.]
