The arts and crafts section comprised tukutuku, ... plaiting (rourou [fn A small basket used for cooked food.], rough kits and floor mats), taniko work and making poi balls. (Mar 28, 1936,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/212) [NOTES: Ngata : 1936 Mar 28 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/212 (Ngata)]

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,2/155)

TE PUKENGANUI [sic] O TUWHARETOA WANANGA .. All whanau asked to donate a rourou please For rourou donations please phone: Gerry Karekare... (Aug 16, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,16)

rouse¶

1 v. (Rural) to work as a shedhand or rouseabout with shearers.

WILLIAMS .. he'd had time to get his first taste of the magical shearing world, 'rousing' in local sheds for Jack Harrison and Wally Smith. (1993,Gone West for Shearing,62)

rouse (onto)¶

v. to scold

NEWTON ... his aversion to children nearly got Madge down. ... He was always inclined to rouse onto our kiddies.... (1966,Boss's Story, The,104)

Sargeson roused him up hill and down dale: dressed him down thoroughly; roused on to me, scolded me. (1964,Collected Stories,303) [NOTES: Pearson Glossary]

rouse about¶

v.

Her involvement with netball was encouraged by her mother. `I used to go along to practices and if Mum needed someone to rouse about on the court she'd yell out to me.' (Sep 27, 1983,Dominion,11/6)

rouse/roust¶

v. to make a fuss, become angry

About time the Manawatu Railway Company started running Sunday trains. The religion relating rummies will rouse a bit, but that's only a detail. (Oct 20, 1906,NZ Truth,70/1/4)

... for in the Australiasian vernacular the person who rousts' orrouses' goes temporarily mad and yells, and is an irresponsible person while he is rousting' orrousing', and the condition so nearly approaches the mild insanity of the wowser in his neurotic outbursts of oratory that Churchill must be congratulated upon stumbling upon a great truth. (Apr 15, 1911,NZ Truth,303/1/2)

rouseabout¶

n.

Soon the shuffling of shoes and squeaking of doors multiply as shearers and rouseabouts (shedhands or "rousies") make their way up to the cookhouse. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/80)

He was employed as a rouseabout at the Criterion Hotel for the last 12 months and accumulated a variety of goods to the total value of about L40, nearly all from the hotel and the property of the licensee and his family and of the boarders and servants. (Jun 13, 1891,Grey River Argus,2)

DARE My official capacity was cowboy or `rouseabout', meaning odd jobber ... (1956,Rouseabout Jane,146)

Daniel Driscoll, a rouse-about-man in the employ of Gillon and Devery, of No Town, appeared to answer to a charge of maliciously assaulting one John Foley, of No Town, on the 14th inst. (Jul 25, 1876,Grey River Argus,2)

Sergeant-Major Thompson called Peter Stobo, residing at the Imperial Hotel, Herbet, who deposed that Dallas was employed by Mr Watson as general rouse-about, and slept in the room next to witness. (May 4, 1881,North Otago Times,2)

DAVIN So Hawk had taken against the nice new house and stayed on in the rouseabouts'shack. (Mar 2, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

Hotel-keepers complain that they are unable to get the aristocrats of labour to work for them when they advertise "Wanted, a rouseabout." (Jun 25, 1904,NZ Observer,7)

HENDERSON The two became devoted to each other, the vigorous little rouseabout-gardener carrying him round on his back at every opportunity. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,26)

ELKINGTON When a man first goes on a station and is not an old hand he is engaged as a "roustabout," which means that he is given jobs which do not require much experience and in which he works under other men. (1906,Adrift in NZ,145)

On the other hand, Kiwi comedians only have to master Gumboot, the language of roustabouts, fishermen and sportscasters, and they're away screaming. (May 15, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),70)

He had steadily sunk through the various stages of gentleman at large, digger,.. rouseabout, to the bedrock of continual swagging. (Nov 11, 1897,Otago Witness,50)

He [a union secretary] has returned to work three days a week as, in his words, a "rouseabout". (Jan 28, 1993,Dominion,2)

Gillespie.. had joined his father as rouseabout, and then shepherd, many years ago. (Jul 22, 1924,Otago Witness,58)

n. (Rural) a shearing gang worker who sweeps the board and occasionally does extra duties.

If the shearing is put off for another 10 days the harvest will be on before the shearing is near finished, and the rouseabouts will leave for the harvest, as well as the slow shearers. (Nov 20, 1876,North Otago Times,2)

And now for the rouse abouts. Their case is not the best in the world. They, like the shearers, have to put up with bad food and bad accomodation, and like musterers they complain of not being paid in proportion to the work they do. The rouseabout has to work ten hours a day, and nine or thereabouts on Saturdays. (Feb 5, 1891,North Otago Times,3)

WILLIAMS Would take what came, nor shirk nor fret, 'brander,' 'rouseabout' or dagger ... (1889,Colonial Couplets,28)

Prior to getting a farm of my own, I knocked around on stations and farms in many capacities from station cadet to rouseabout. (Feb 20, 1930,NZ Dairy Exporter,45)

WILSON & FRASER They had a Maori youth who acted as cowboy and general rouseabout. (1936,Book of the Pioneers, The,31)

WOODHOUSE Mr Guthrie-Smith and Mr Stuart and I did all the sheep work, but we were all rouseabouts then and did whatever was wanted. (1959,Guthrie-Smith of Tutira,23)

BECKETT No back country sheep station is without its rouseabout. (1978,Mountains of Erewhon, The,24)

LOUGHNAN rouseabout or rousey: a general farm hand. In that context the term is now rather rare. In a shearing gang it refers to all those who are not actually shearers. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,67)

SALISBURY There were several men who went under the designation of rouseabout, or general hand. (1994,I Was So Lucky,7)

1 v. (Rural) to act as a general hand on a farm or station.

GORDON I would have been about three and a half years rouseabouting and also packing for the shepherds [with packhorses.] (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,106)

WANTED, an active Lad, about 15, who can ride and rousabout. (Feb 11, 1890,Hawke's Bay Herald,1)

1 n. (Rural) a general farm hand, who does many different duties.

Their mode of living is on the strict hand-to-mouth principle; the future is a disagreeable prospect, which they endeavour to ignore, content if the present affords them a fair modicum of enjoyment; big cheques are earned, but they are melted with much greater celerity; and so the round of life goes on from year to year, until old age finds them still on the wallaby, burdened with aches and pains, unfitted for the only work of which they know anything, and glad to accept the billet of a farm yard "rouseabout," or "wood and water Joey." (Dec 2, 1882,Waikato Times,2)

WANTED, a steady Man, a Permanent SITUATION on a Farm or Station, as Rousabout, or to drive a team of horses. (Dec 14, 1878,Timaru Herald,4)

WILLIAMS Would take what came, nor shirk nor fret, 'brander,' 'rouseabout' or dagger ... (1889,Colonial Couplets,28)

Prior to getting a farm of my own, I knocked around on stations and farms in many capacities from station cadet to rouseabout. (Feb 20, 1930,NZ Dairy Exporter,45)

WILSON & FRASER They had a Maori youth who acted as cowboy and general rouseabout. (1936,Book of the Pioneers, The,31)

WOODHOUSE Mr Guthrie-Smith and Mr Stuart and I did all the sheep work, but we were all rouseabouts then and did whatever was wanted. (1959,Guthrie-Smith of Tutira,23)

BECKETT No back country sheep station is without its rouseabout. (1978,Mountains of Erewhon, The,24)

LOUGHNAN rouseabout or rousey: a general farm hand. In that context the term is now rather rare. In a shearing gang it refers to all those who are not actually shearers. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,67)

SALISBURY There were several men who went under the designation of rouseabout, or general hand. (1994,I Was So Lucky,7)

rouseabouting¶

n. (Rural) acting as a general hand in a shearing gang or on a farming property.

Rouseabouting can be an international job. (Mar 1988,More Magazine,29)

Shearing, and so rouseabouting, is a seasonal game. (Mar 1988,More Magazine,31)

n.

[caption] Above: Rouseabouting can be an international job. Here Margaret Way (in red) and friend Robin are pictured atop a wool pile in an English woolshed. No woolpresses here,' comments Margaret.Robin and I wound each one of these fleeces by hand.' (Mar 1988,More Magazine,29)

rousey¶

n. (See rousie)

rousie¶

v. [It's one thing to pay a Maori to rousie for you or to shear your sheep ...]

n. a rouseabout

Soon the shuffling of shoes and squeaking of doors multiply as shearers and rouseabouts (shedhands or "rousies") make their way up to the cookhouse. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/80)

Club is the rousie whose days as a shearer are rumoured to have finished with a gunshot wound. (Jun 10, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

So the hope we fondly cherished that he soon would fade away / Was ne'er fulfilled in eighteen eighty-nine; / But we rallied round the "rousey" when the shed cut out that day, / And gave three ringing cheers for auld lang syne. (Jan 6, 1909,Otago Witness,71)

WOODHOUSE They entertained the `rouseys' with a lot of fairy tales . (1950,Farm & Station Verse,49) [NOTES: c1900-1910 W. Goldstone in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 49]

MEEK And the rouseys in their shirt-sleeves passed the pannikins around. Ibid. 111 ROUSEY, ROUSEABOUT: Shed hands in a shearing-shed who can be called on to do, or help with any job. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,11)

(1952,Arena)

MIDDLETON (1966,Short Stories (various authors),189) [NOTES: 1953 Middleton in 1966 Short Stories 189 [get quot]]

BOWEN ROUSIE. This is the poor old rouseabout who has a great variety of jobs. Australians sometimes call this hand a `blue tongue'. (1956,Wool Away!,157)

SCRYMGEOUR The bell rang, the whole procedure stopped, shearers trooped out, half shorn sheep were pushed back into the catching pens. Jimmy Greave the classer hurriedly whispered to William Steuart to desist, but loppies, rousies, and even young Jim, who was assisting to pen up, followed out from the side door to where the shoots from the stands gave the nearest exit, to the level space of the outside turf, that made eventually the [boxing] ring. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,50)

MIDDLETON `Don't tell me you're one of the rousies, Sonny ....?'[sic] (1964,Walk on the Beach,166) [NOTES: (Not for a Seagull)]

MIDDLETON What with the dogs the roussies and penners-up and daggers brought to give them a hand in the shed and yards ... (1966,NZ Short Stories,127,1976 ed.)

SHEEP-O: The call, timid from beginners, imperious from guns for the rousie (rouse-about) to fill the catching pen. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20) [NOTES: [Shearer's language]]

[caption] A change from school work: Christine McIntyre, a fifth former at Wanganui Girls College and daughter of Apiti farmer Rusty McIntyre, rousies during the [shearing] competition. (Apr 23, 1981,Dominion,6)

CHARLES But you will hear the rousies singing as they head down to the pub. (1981,Black Billy Tea,28)

BEATON GINNY: Nah. Only time I stopped was when I worked the sheds. ...I was a fucken good rousy. Even sheared a sheep once. (1984,Outside In,106) [NOTES: [in a shearing gang]]

RICHARDS I gathered by the ... excitement among the rousies that Roger Pearce was going to `burn me off' with his next full pen. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,93)

A rouseabout - also variously known as a rousie, woolhandler, shedhand, fleeco, the person `picking up' or a blue tongue - is responsible for the passage of wool after being shorn from the sheep's back to the wool press where it is baled. Ibid. 33 A rousie, or wool winder as they're called in England, would at least pay for half a return ticket from New Zealand in the two-month season there. (Mar 1988,More Magazine,31)

McGILL rousie rouseabout or shearing shed hand. ANZ. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

As youngsters they worked around the sheds as rousies. (Jun 1998,Mana,No. 22: 53)

FARRELL So Martin moved on, rousie for a gang, a spell at the freezer in Prestwick, a few months on a fishing boat round Stewart Island. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,57)

n. (Rural) a shearing shedhand.

NEWTON They had eight rousies on the board ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,29)

WATERSON Finally Wart's crew was sorted out. Four shearers, five rousies and a cook. (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,60)

WATERSON .. this Ned Jones came over from Wales to work as a rousie in my shearing gang. (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,151)

He became involved in the wool industry when he met a guy in a pub, who offered him a job as a rousy. [rousey; rousy] (2001,Wool Grower,Winter 24)

1 v. (Rural) to act as a general worker, especially in a shearing shed.

MCMILLAN But now he 'rousies' for the gang, his shearing days are done. (1975,More From the High Country,49)

WILLIAMS This fella was a wee Aussie guy, he didn't know bugger all, he knew nothing and he couldn't rousie for nothing. (1999,Tales from the Shearing Shed,15)

WILLIAMS Like most people Tui Two Bob entered the shearing industry through her father, starting out rousieing for him in 1982. (1999,Tales from the Shearing Shed,31)

1 n. (Rural) a general farm assistant or rural dogsbody.

NEWTON The 'rousie' had the billy boiling so .. they collected the tucker box and sought a prominence, where they could get a full view of the flat. (1949,High Country Days,22)

NEWTON Besides Ray Birdsall there are nine musterers and shepherds, the majority of them there only for the mustering season. There are also two or three 'rousies', a cowman-gardener, a book-keeper, and a permanent rabbiter. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,29)

LOUGHNAN rouseabout or rousey: a general farm hand. In that context the term is now rather rare. In a shearing gang it refers to all those who are not actually shearers. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,67)

FIRTH For other outside work, a rousie will have to be employed. (1988,Farmers are Bananas,136)

But I served for years as a rousie during my varsity vacations and I have studied the art in great depth. (May 2002,Growing Today,61)

rousie's chewing gum¶

n.

rousie's chewing gum: Dags. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/27) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

rousie's handpiece¶

1 n. (Rural) a woolshed broom.

WARD rousie's handpiece: a broom. (1997,Glossary,1)

rousie's handpiece: broom. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

roust¶

v. to stir up, scold [ca1900 He rousted them up for getting drunk cf P. rouse 2. pron [raus] to grouse, scold esp. if coarsely: Aust: 20c. 3. upbraid with many words: Aust:20; AC 1900-1910.]

2 v. to dig out; to rummage and find; to rake out; rout out - [ca 1900 He went in and rousted her out of bed]

roust on¶

v.

She told her ... husband she'd rowst' on him. Her idea ofrowsting', as she called it, was to send for a peeler. (Jan 27, 1906,NZ Truth,32/8/6)

v. to turn on (a person)

He "rousted," as the saying goes, on the man who sacked him. (Feb 13, 1904,NZ Observer,2)

roustabout¶

n. a rouseabout, a handyman (espec. on a station or farm,a slushy

After a while, I thought to meself thim good paple had betther business than showing a roustabout the road, and that if I was to foind it, I'd betther use the sivin sinses that had been given me for that purpose. (Sep 6, 1884,Waikato Times,1)

Just as the first roustabout dumped his basket of coal a quick, little squall came up, from where nobody knew, and lifting my Panama off my head, whirled it beyond my reach. (Dec 23, 1899,Taranaki Herald,4)

We have had our fill of swamp bush felling in winter ... Only the roustabouts count among all hands. Not the ploughmen. (Jun 25, 1888,Chudleigh Diary,362,1950 ed.)

ELKINGTON ... roustabout ... (1906,Adrift in NZ,145)

MANDER I'm willing to ... get any kind of job I can.' ...I didn't send you to Oxford to become a roustabout.' (1925,Allen Adair,4,1971 ed.)

LEE Rabbiters, harvesters, shearers, ploughmen, roustabouts, leaving their jobs, carrying their swags, and with eyes turned towards homes in Dunedin, were frequently headed off by the hotels. (1934,Children of the Poor,26,1949 ed.)

LEE ... roustabout ... (1936,Hunted, The,207)

BIERNACKI When one fo the roust-abouts [on the station] kicked him (1949,Poems, Verses and Rhymes,6)

FRAME Alan found it hard to decide ... finding a job as a wharfie, farm roustabout, shearing hand, [etc] (1963,Reservoir, The,162) [NOTES: (Triumph of Poetry)]

STEWART Frank March had begun life as a roustabout on Hawke's Bay sheep farms. (1981,Hot & Copper Sky,18)

roustabout ... 2. Austral. & N.Z. a variant of rouseabout (sense 1). (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1006) [NOTES: [contrast NZPOD 665]]

The work of roustabouts was covered by the New Zealand Oil Exploration Award and their membership should be that of the New Zealand Labourers Union. (Dec 20, 1983,Dominion,5)

Rousei.a-bouti. (rousi.&adot.-bouti.), n. [Add.] 2. A general Rousti.a-bouti. (rousti.&adot.-bouti.), hand or man of all work on a sheep station; esp., a man employed at shearing time to assist the shearers but not to shear sheep himself. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

WANTED, Roustabout for hotel work; must be sober and good cleaner. (Nov 11, 1910,Evening Post,1)

1 n. (Rural) a general farm or stationhand.

CHUDLEIGH Only the roustabouts count among all hands. (Jun 25, 1888,Chudleigh Diary,362) [NOTES: (1950)]

ELKINGTON When a man first goes on a station and is not an old hand, he is engaged as a 'roustabout.' (1906,Adrift in NZ,145)

ANDERSON .. I secured a job at fifteen shillings a week, as roustabout on St Helen's station ... (1962,Life's Roundabout, A,24)

MCCONOCHIE In his younger days he had worked as a roustabout on a Marlborough sheep station. (1966,You'll Learn No Harm from the Hills,24)

NEWTON .. during the evening he cunningly drew the old roustabout out. (1972,Sheep Thief,113)

Shearers, washers, and half-grown louts, / Pickers-up, and "roustabouts" ... (Jan 13, 1883,Otago Witness,13)

roustabout steward¶

n. also called a patrol steward, one on a shift with no fixed work location who can be called to wherever needed [ca1989 Sep 11 Public address system of ferry `Arahura' Would the roustabout steward please call at the shop.]

roustabouting¶

n. = rouseabouting

The next two years were spent busking, labouring, casual electrical work, and roustabouting with Wirths Circus and as a member of a touring troupe, 'The Gaieties". (Aug 2002,NZ Memories,37/6)

rouster¶

n. [ca1938 espec. schoolboys'] (See cf. poofter)

1 n. (Rural) a long-tailed sheep.

SCURR Rouster:- long-tailed sheep. (2000,Rabbiters' Glossary,3)

Rouster: a long-tailed sheep. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

2 n. anything excellent of its kind [ca1938 Havelock schoolchildren]

roustie¶

1 n. (Rural) a general hand in a shearing shed or in a station work team.

HENDERSON The rousties flew up and down the board while the table-hands tore at the necks and skirtings the moment the fleece was thrown. (1969,Open Country Calling,258)

rousy¶

n. (See rousie)

route¶

n. special sense used in DOC's national track classification and familiar to trampers

RHODES & CEDERMAN A route is lightly marked or possibly defined only by natural features such as ridges and streams. (1989,Wairarapa Walks,00) [NOTES: check page]

rover¶

n. an extra man on the chain to help out when needed [(freezing workers')]

COLIN GORDON If you get behind [on your part of the chain] yell out for the rover, an extra man who [helps out at need] and keeps the chaps `up the chain'. He helps anybody, and will give you a cut up the chain, that is, do jobs for you. (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication)

1 n. (Rural) a multiskilled slaughterman.

LOUGHNAN rover: that chain slaughterman who knows every cut and who therefore has the task of stepping in and helping where pressure of work has become heavy .. unless he shares such favours very fairly he will soon find the delegate asking the foreman to appoint a different rover. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,67)

row up¶

v. (Rural) to tedder hay.

They hay is ready to be baled, usually within 24 hours - it doesn't need teddering or rowing up. (Sep 24, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,Farming Today 7)

v. ?=rouse [(? nonce ) [? possibly rowsing meant]]

SATCHELL [Of Maoris who were not keeping up a contracted log-supply] I'm really doing your work in rowing them up (1902,Land of the Lost,17,1971 ed.)

SMITHYMAN The locution is strange to me. ... Is this Satchell's version of rousing or rousting? (1971,BLANK ENTRY,213) [NOTES: fn 2]

Rowdies¶

n. the Radical Association, or Rads; abusive [Political name for Wakefield's party] by Featherston : the `Rads' [Radicals] for Wakefield's party frequent : OED Orig American : in genl use 1st quote 1865 - and 2 following quotes of political rowdies [n pl (hist)]

The Rowdies' and theRads' [radicals] (1858,Wellington Election Songs,8)

BAILEY & ROTH Show a bold front, the Rowdies are beneath us. (1967,Shanties,25) [NOTES: 1858 Wellington Independent 30 June in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 25]

rowdy hat¶

n.

BUTLER Hither come more of the shaggy-complexioned men with the rowdy hats; looking at them with awe and befitting respect. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,29)

n.

SINCLAIR The working settler commonly dressed in a blue woollen shirt or blouse, moleskin or cord trousers, boots, and the slouch felt hats known as rowdy' (that is, backwoodsmen's) hats. Butler called themexceedingly rowdy hats'. (1959,History of New Zealand,101)

rowdy, the¶

n. the ready cash, money [obs.]

Mr Punch... abjures (?or abhors - check) all contact with "filthy lucre" but he will accept instead.. any amount of the following substitutes, that is to say - any amount of "the rhino", "the ready", "the stumpy", "the brads", "the tin", "the brass", "the dumps", "the rowdy", "the shiners", "the mopusses" (wherewith people buy diamonds and topazes). (Dec 5, 1860,Taranaki Punch,8)

rowdy-dowdy¶

adj.

One of those rowdy-dowdy days on the Waipa, Midshipman Foljambe had a pretty narrow escape. (Dec 21, 1912,NZ Free Lance,5)

rowdy-hatted¶

adj.

BUTL;ER How shall I describe everything - the little townlet, ... the scattered wooden boxes of houses, with ragged roods of scrubby ground between them - tussocks of brown grass - the huge wide-leaved flax ... the healthy clear-complexioned men, shaggy-bearded, rowdy-hatted, and independent, .pictures of rude health and strength .. - the stores, supplying all heterogeneous commodities - (Jan 27, 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,iii/28)

VON HAAST It was practically over when the opposing witnesses ... [found] their old friend in the `rowdy' hat now attired in the wig and gown of the cross-examining counsel. (1948,Julius Von Haast,44) [NOTES: [c1860s]]

rowi¶

n. the South Island brown kiwi [ORIGIN: Maori]

All professional kiwi hunters, we had worked together before with the rowi, Apteryx rowii. (Jul 5, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

Amongst the specimens of birds, there are skins of the rowi and kiwi. (Jan 11, 1869,West Coast Times,2)

  1. Apteryx australis, Shaw. Rowi, Big Kiwi. ... One of the former nesting places I examined near Lake Mapourika, on the West Coast. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,505) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

Apteryx oweni Gould. Little Grey Kiwi; Rowi. Three localities are reported in the South Island where this small species still occurs. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/82) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

Ornithologists have separated the brown kiwi into three subspecies: the North Island brown kiwi Apteryx australis mantelli; the South Island brown kiwi A. a. australis; and the Stewart Island brown kiwi A. a. lawryi. ... OTHER NAMES: Rowi, Tokoeka. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,38)

They don't have the vice-like grip, steel-band arms and powerful piston legs Reay has developed ridding rowi (new Zealand's rarest kiwi) habitat of stoats. (Jan 1, 2006,Dominion Post,A8)

Rowley's parakeet¶

n.

BULLER PLATYCERCUS ROWLEYI. (ROWLEY'S PARRAKEET.) (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/147)

royal¶

n. (obsolete) a wharfie who got regularly selected for work by the foreman under the old auction block' system (occas., by seamen, for a mate'smate') [ca1963 p.c. J. Winchester, Wellington: boss's royal a waterfront term for a boss's stooge or pet]

Invariably the "royals" receive preference. These watersiders are well known to the stevedores. (Nov 24, 1938,NZ Observer,7)

Each foreman had his regulars, known as "bulls" or "royals" ... (1993,Wharfie,p12)

royal albatross¶

n. (Environment) royal albatross. D. epomophora, a huge black and white seabird breeding exclusively in the NZ region; of two races: northern and southern royal albatross. D. e. sanfordi, breeding on the Chatham Islands and Otago Peninsula, and southern D. e. epomophora, breeding on subantarctic islands.

While on a recent cruise, Commander Ayscough, of H.M.S. Ringdove, collected specimens of a number of birds, which he presented to the Christchurch Museum. These have now been placed on exhibition in the New Zealand room, and include a Royal albatross from Campbell Island, a pair of woodhens from Stewart Island, a paroquet and a ground lark from the Antipodes Islands, and a bush hawk from the Auckland Islands. (Feb 7, 1900,Star, The,3)

The Buller collection of butterflies and several cases of butterflies from the islands adjacent to New Guinea are now on view at the Museum. The new case of birds, which is now only wanting labels, comprises, amongst other things, an adult Royal albatross, two stages of the young in down of the wandering albatross, also a specimen of the shy albatross, and two or three others of the rarer kind. (Jul 1, 1911,Evening Post,9)

The arrival at the heads last year of ten Royal Albatross was regarded as an event of the first importance in local scientific circles. (Sep 21, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,20)

Harold is a royal albatross, not only an endangered species but a spectacular one. Dunedin has the good luck to have a royal albatross breeding colony on the end of its peninsula. (Oct 2, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

A 5km wire-netted boardwalk provides easy access to observe hillsides of royal albatross, the birds calling and clacking beaks in greeting as their mates wheel and glide home each evening. (Mar 18, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

FALLA et al. ROYAL ALBATROSS Diomedia epomophora Maori name: Toroa. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,30)

  1. Diomedia epomophora sanfordi (Murphy, 1917) Northern Royal Albatross ... 19.b. Diomedia epomophora epomophora Lesson 1825 Southern Royal Albatross (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,60)

  2. Diomedia epomophora sanfordi (Murphy, 1917) Northern Royal Albatross ... 19.b. Diomedia epomophora epomophora Lesson 1825 Southern Royal Albatross (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,19) [NOTES: 1980 edition]

Royal Colonial Institute¶

n.

SINCLAIR In New Zealand, alone of the self-governing colonies, there was no local Imperial Federation League. The Royal Colonial Institute had a tiny membership of the respectable rich. (1959,History of New Zealand,220)

royal fern¶

n.

Less threatening are the now widespread male ferns (Dryopteris affinis and D. filixmas), [80] royal fern (Osmuda regalis), which is well established in swampy areas of the northern North Island, and the ferny azolla (Azolla pinnata), which is common in slow-mowing freshwater in northern New Zealand. (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/79)

Royal fern is well established in the Lower Waikato/Hauraki Plains area, reaching heights of up to 2.5 m, with no current options for eradication. (Jul 2006,Climate Update, The (NIWA),Aquatic Biodiversity & Biosecurity)

Royal Gala¶

n. a variety of dessert apple

Royal Gala: Developed in New Zealand from a red sport of the Gala in 1965, and named in honour of Queen Elizabeth II, this is our second largest volume variety. (Mar 27, 2004,Dominion Post,E6)

BATEMAN Royal Gala... A redder sport of the Gala. (1986,Illustrated Encycl. of NZ,45)

ROYAL GALA. Discovered by Mr Ten Hove of Matamata in 1969. A red sport of the Gala variety. (1991,New Zealand's Best Apple Recipes,12)

royal penguin¶

n.

One case contains birds only, including .. a furry baby royal penguin. (May 24, 1906,Evening Post,3)

In appearance and size somewhat similar, but belonging to a district genus is the Royal Penguin, in which the yellow margin of the crown is found only on the front portion of the head, and the beak is longer than in the other varieties of this genus. (Apr 14, 1920,Grey River Argus,6)

A muff made made by Mr. Liardet from the skin of a royal penguin, from the Macquarrie Islands, was sold at a large figure. (Jan 8, 1890,Evening Post,2)

15/401 Eudyptes sclegeli, Royal Penguin.' ... TheRoyals' leave the island in June, and return in October. (1883,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Scott Macquarie Island)]

Eudyptes chrysolophus. (The Royal Penguin.) (1892,TrNZI,24/71) [NOTES: (Buller)]

The chief industry now [on Macquarie Island] is the boiling-down of the royal penguin (E. schlegeli). (1895,TrNZI,27/563)

Royal Penguin Eudyptes chrysolophus BRANDT, 1837 ... The royal penguin nests on Macquarie Island, in vast colonies ... (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,48)

royal soaks' express¶

n.

More colourful.. is the "fruitiest" train of them all, running after hotel closing hours between Dunedin and Port Chalmers, and rejoicing in the soubriquet of the "Royal Soaks' Express". (Jul 18, 1928,NZ Free Lance,35)

royal spoonbill.¶

n.

A communication was received from Mr. J. M'Donald, Acting Director of the Dominion Museum, stating that, from the description of the bird given by Mr. Leith, the bird was, without doubt, a specimen of the royal spoonbill (platalea regia). (Jun 15, 1922,Evening Post,5)

Two different kinds of ibis have turned up in the Dominion, the Australian white ibis and the glossy ibis, while the royal spoonbill of Australia has also been seen on four occasions, two of these being in the Wairarapa district. (Jul 16, 1932,Evening Post,9)

Oystercatchers, royal spoonbills, godwits and turnstones flock to the spit from late September to earfly April. (May 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 63/13)

Kotuku-ngutupapa, Platalea melanorhyncha, royal spoonbill . [1957/150 P. regia] (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,175)

101. Platalea leucorodia regia Gould, 1838 Royal Spoonbill (Kotuku-ngutupapa) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,36,1980 ed.)

Royal Spoonbill Platalea regia GOULD, 1838 ... OTHER NAME: Kotuku-ngutupapa . ... Known to the Maori as kotuku-ngutupapa, the royal spoonbill must have reached New Zealand from Australia many times before European settlement. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,137)

Could it be another kotuku? No, no. This bird flew with outstretched neck - a royal spoonbill. (1987,MsCellany: Women Writers' Prose & Poetry,72)

The following papers were read and discussed .."On the occurrence of the Platalea Regia (royal spoonbill) in New Zealand," by the President ... (Jul 31, 1876,Evening Post,2)

We were approaching Waverley, where, perched on flood-strewn logs, was the reason for our journey - royal spoonbills.... Flying with slow rhythmic sweeps of their wings, the royal spoonbills were the epitome of grace. (Oct 2, 2004,Dominion Post,E16)

royaller¶

n.

WILLIAMS Joe Devcich almost brought off a "royaller" in the last when Peranui ran third. (1987,Racing for Gold,174)

On the first Saturday I was out, I decided to make it a royaller. To make it a royaller....to have a really good time (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

NEA LAP, after being abused for her first day run, all but paid a royaller when she ran second to Pewa at Woodville on the second day. (Dec 18, 1930,NZ Truth,14)

The North Midland game was a royaller for Parker, who scored five tries, and then had to go off with an injury to his leg, which however is not serious. (Oct 18, 1924,NZ Truth,11)

Roys Peak gecko¶

n. a rare and brightly spotted gecko from Otago highlands. [Hoplodactylus "Roys Peak" aka Orange-spotted gecko]

The data collected during the three surveys of Roys Peak and outlined in this report provide only limited data on distribution. However, it appears Roys Peak geckos are an alpine gecko, as all specimens were found above 1000 m, and below this altitude common geckos Hoplodactylus ` Southern Alps' (Hitchmough 1997) were numerous. (2001,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/casn344.pdf 2001 Tocher, M.D.; Marshall, LJ, 2001. Surveys for Hoplodactylus aff. granulatus, Roys Peak and Mt Alpha, Wanaka.]

The discovery of a lizard assumed to be Roys Peak gecko on Cluden Pastoral Lease is of national significance. This species has a threat status of Nationally Critical (Hitchmough, 2002). (2002,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.linz.govt.nz/docs/crownproperty/high-country-leases/leaselist/cluden-crr-pt1.pdf Copied to site Feb 05]

Other reptiles present in the catchment include McCann's skinks, common skinks, cryptic skinks, Southern Alps geckos, common geckos, Cromwell Gorge geckos and Roys Peak geckos. (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://web.tarrasnz.com/Otago%20Regional%20Council/Lindis%20Catchment%20information%20sheet%20-%20Feb%2009.pdf]

RRF¶

abbr. Ready Reaction Force

RRF abbr. NZ Ready Reaction Force. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,666) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

RSA¶

abbr. Returned Services' [formerly Soldiers'] Association

It was the Dawn Paraders. The R.S.A. men marching. Marching in honour of their fallen comrades. (1987,Tall Half-Backs,34)

New Zealand's social life for the old has been built around the RSAs, the TABs, the Cosmopolitan Clubs. (Oct 25, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

Owen Marshall It was a long concrete and corrugated iron building between the RSA and a yard of yellow and red agricultural machinery. (2005,Watch of Gryphons,164)

Some still gather later at an RSA or in a bar, remembering old battles when they were young men. (Apr 25, 1993,Sunday Times (NZ),8)

And now the RSAs are emptying. (Feb 1992,Metro,8)

Wellington's infamous 'harbour breeze' battered me down to Ghuznee Street to the old RSA building. (Dec 1991,Cuisine,92)

I can only assume that your reporter has no knowledge of the position which the RSA holds in the local community. (Jan 1992,Metro,16)

[Hdg] Support from R.S.A. (Sep 21, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,23)

The next time the Returned Soldiers' Association gives a dinner, those responsible.. will make it clear that the soldiers themselves are giving the dinner. (May 5, 1917,NZ Truth,2)

There was an impression about that the R.S.A. was opposed to the scheme. (Dec 7, 1920,Otago Witness,23)

I parked on the cliff-top, in front of the obelisk cenotaph where the RSA used to gather on Anzac Day, their lapels ablaze with paper poppies. (Feb 1993,Metro,113)

RSA badge¶

n.

HAMILTON I'm not asking you to spit in the eye of every individual you see ... merging from an insurance office wearing an R.S.A. badge. (1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,197)

HALL BOSS. Short, fussy, worried - ... Wears RSA badge and very conservative. (1977,Glide Time,10)

BENNETT So I put up an R.S.A. badge but soon took it down. (1980,Canterbury Tale, A,106)

GREY RETURNED SOLDIERS ASSOCIATION ANZAC MEMORIAL SERVICE .. DRESS: Mufti, wearing R.S.A. Badge. (Apr 22, 1920,Grey River Argus,1)

The raising of the curtain revealed an attractive scene on the stage, the Follies, in Pierrot garb, sitting around in a semi-circle, whilst overhead was suspended an enlarged representation of the R.S.A. badge, and prominently displayed was an enlarged photograph of General Birdwood. (Mar 2, 1917,Poverty Bay Herald,9)

RSAA¶

Our Refugee Status Appeals Authority [RSAA] has already ruled that Zaoui does indeed face a genuine risk of torture and death, if deported. (May 1, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

The cables reveal MFAT's efforts to inspire foreign criticism of the government's quasi-judicial Refugee Status Appeals Authority (RSSA) sic... (Jul 31, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

Although he has been declared by the SIS to be a risk to national security, Zaoui has also been declared to be a genuine refugee by the Refugee Status Appeals Authority (RSSA). When it suits the government, the RSAA is touted to the skies. (Mar 20, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

RT¶

abbr. artillery

There weren't too many of us from the S.A.S., but I know us and the R.T. (artillery that is) were getting stuck in. (1975,NZ Short Stories III,140) [NOTES: 1975 Mitcalfe `Black Cat' in 1975 NZ Short Stories III 140]

RTD¶

abbr. ready-to-drink [ORIGIN: acronym, Internet search Feb 2006: also used in Austral, Brazil, China, India, Taiwan, N Amer]

...the ready-to-drink (RTD) market was behind a revitalisation of the spirits market, which had been flat for about 10 years... A greater variety of RTDs is also coming our way, and in many cases they will end up in the hands of young women. (Apr 25, 2004,Sunday Times (NZ),D4)

Driven by the ready-to-drink, or rtd sector, consumption has gone up from 2.45 million litres in 1955... (Feb 4, 2006,Dominion Post,C2)

The New Zealand RTD (ready-to-drink) market is heading towards three million cases... Independent Liquor's decision to replace its beer halls with RTD halls, and its development of many successful RTDs, has seen it break successfully into the Australian market. (Nov 2000,Legends in Their Lifetime,11)

But the loss has been offset, at least in part, by strong growth in sales of "ready to drink" (RTD) spirit mixes popular with young people.... "Nothing new that's come out has kicked off in the way RTDs have." (Nov 21, 2000,Evening Post,2)

RU¶

abbr.

[check quot] (Jun 1958,NZ Timber Journal,59/2)

rua¶

n. a storage pit for root vegetables, esp. kumara and potatoes (cf PIT n)

... the object was very simply attained in the dry porous soil by the rua. This was a circular pit sunk in the ground 5 ft. or 6 ft. deep and about the same in diameter, narrowing in at the top and closed by a trap-door made of a wooden slab. (1903,TrNZI,35/21)

LEE & KENDALL D|ua, s. A house, vessel, &c. to contain stores. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,151)

H. WILLIAMS In the afternoon shifted our quarters on account of the rain to a Rua where we were very comfortable by the aid of a good fire. (Jun 11, 1831,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,181,1961 ed.)

TAYLOR It is like a person carrying a large back load of kumara to the rua (an underground store with a very small entrance to it) ... (Oct 7, 1852,Journal,8/46)

T.S.GRACE He very kindly took my Natives to his `rua' of potatoes and told them to take what were in it! (Oct 23, 1863,Pioneer Missionary Among the Maoris, A,123,1928 ed.)

MANING The kumera were dug ... then all hands set to work ... to ... carry off the crop to the storehouse or rua ... (1863,Old New Zealand,(xi) 171)

MORRIS Maori word (used in North Island) for a pit, cave or hole. A place for storing roots, such as potatoes, etc. Formerly some of these rua had carved entrances. (1898,Austral English,396/2)

(1953,Short Stories (various authors),54) [NOTES: 1901 Grace Tales of a Dying Race in 1953 Short Stories 54]

TREGEAR Artificial caves or pits (rua) were excavated for the purpose of storing tubers as food. (1904,Maori Race, The,282)

BAUCKE (1928,Where the White Man Treads,286)

~ a. storage pit for edible roots. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

In the ngahuru' he would turn up with a horse to haul thekumara' to the rua [ed fn: Pit, in this case for storing kumara] and empty kits, sure that he would have the loan of the sledge at the end of the day to take some of the harvest home with him, - ... (Oct 17, 1930,Na To Hoa Aroha,2/64) [NOTES: Ngata]

Andersen rua, pit; hole; pit-store for provisions. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Maori Words in English]

rua: storage pit. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,1/34)

LYON Their chief quest was a pot hole which might be described as much like a Maori rua or potato pit. A soft seam of rock played on by the tumbling waters and some stones always on the grind and move, wore down and sideways till the top was smaller than the bottom and an arched roof was the result, and a small opening at the top received through the ages particles of gold. The heavy swirl and pressure of water was unable to twist the gold contents out of the pot hole, and so a store of gold collected in the bottom and might contain nuggets as well as dust. (1952,Faring South,158)

~ n. Maori word for a storage pit for edible roots [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),624)

rua ... n. Maori word for storage pit for edible roots [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),17)

JENKIN At the south end of the beach [in Waipao Bay, Moturoa Isd] he found several rua (kumara pits) half washed away by the sea. (1970,NZ Mysteries,56)

BURTON Apart from kumara, which usually had to be kept in the rua or storage pit, the pataka was used to store all the food which would be needed to eke out the meagre supplies which would be harvested over the lean winter months. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,3)

n. a variety of potato

I am a couch potato / A chip off the old block / Who sits upon the sofa / And flops around the clock. / My mother's a King Edward /My father is a Rua / My ancestry's bicultural / No wonder there's no cure... (Jul 11, 2004,NZ Catholic,7) [NOTES: "Iva Verse"]

BRANDENBURG Rua. This is a maincrop variety still gaining ground in Canterbury... Rua produces a large, coarse-leafed plant keeping up top growth well into the autumn. (1980,Outdoor Vegetable Growing,111)

The best potato buy would be the 10-kilogram handgrip paper bag of ruas. (Aug 24, 1999,Dominion,9)

BENTLEY & FRASER A chap growing spuds near Opua/ Sent a ton to a lady, to woo'er,/ Of ancient King Edwards,/ But what got her bedwards/ Were newer, and fewer, and Rua. (1985,Grand Limerick Tour, A,No. 5)

HILL As I lifted the third root - `Crikey, you wann try ruas instead.' (1988,More from Moaville,40)

Rua - a good all-purpose variety. (Sep 1985,NZ Gardener,20)

"Rua" is a selection from the cross 'Katahdin by Harford .... Rua may be a safer variety to grow where there is a risk of soils being wet in the autumn. (1960,AJHR,H-34/3) [NOTES: Check pagination]

She rightly gets stuck into the growers of the despicable Rua potatoes, and has some interesting things to say about our new approaches to roast dinners. (Dec 18, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),105)

n.

BAUCKE Hence, when ... a large tangi or other party reduced his pataka or rua kumera contents, he ... made shift with fern-root, berries, or mamaku (tree fern) until the next year's crop came in. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,281)

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The) [NOTES: [spg RUAKUMARA]]

n.

These subterranean chambers [for protection from shell attack, etc] (ruas, or pits, the Maoris called them) were usually six feet deep; ... (1922,NZ Wars, The,1/52)

n.

BELICH ... Kawiti had independently invented the anti-artillery bunker. These pits, or rua as they were called by the Maoris, were underground compartments roofed with beams of timber. Ibid. 337 rua pit, anti-artillery bunker (1986,NZ Wars, The,52)

rua kumara¶

n. [storage pit for kumara]

Replicas of ancient pataka, (carved food storage house), kauta (shelter for food preparation) and rua kumara (carved kumara storage pit) will be built using traditional Maori stone tools. (Oct 25, 2003,Waikato Times,6) [NOTES: carved kumara storage pit - sic]

Rua, the¶

n. (informal) Porirua

As a newish lad to the "Rua", I was not surprised of people's perceptions as outlined in your article about Porirua's dangers. (Jan 12, 2004,Dominion Post,4)

Ruaite¶

n. a follower of Rua (Kenana) (Tuhoe prophet)

[Caption] `The rising generation of Ruaites' ... [to picture of Maori children at Maungapohatu]. (Apr 23, 1908,Auckland Weekly News) [NOTES: 1908 Apr 23 Auckland Weekly News in 1979 Binney et al Mihaia 56]

ruanui¶

n. (Rural) a strain of New Zealand-bred perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne). [ORIGIN: Maori, see Turner ELANZ p.171]

LEVY Ariki ryegrass will be the first away, followed shortly by Ruanui perennial ryegrass. (1970,Grasslands of NZ,174)

LEVY For primary forest burn..Ruanui perennial ryegrass 10lbs. (1970,Grasslands of NZ,183)

Ryegrass cultivars differ markedly in susceptibility. Ruanui and Ariki are often more severely infected [with blind seed disease] than manawa and Paroa, probably because the latter two cultivars flower later. (Oct 1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture) [NOTES: No page number given in RNZEL (Bardsley)]

Establishment data from the experiment on direct-drilling Ruanui or Nui into existing swards indicate that Ruanui was not as suited to this method of introduction as the more vigorous Nui. (Mar 1979,NZ Journal of Agriculture,57)

One contributing factor I think has been a change from Ruanui to Nui in the seed mix. (Jun 25, 1981,NZ Farmer,27)

Ruanui has been popular overseas because it was available and cheap.. (Oct 9, 1986,NZ Farmer,61)

Ruanui - a general-purpose perennial reyegrass with peak growth in late spring-early summer, for use in permanent pasture. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,17)

Ruapehu clang¶

n. [(skiers')]

J. ORSMAN Foggy and poor ski-ing weather. (Oct 10, 1983,Personal Communication)

Ruapehu scud¶

n.

(1983,Personal Communication) [NOTES: (W.J. Orsman)]

Ruapehu snow¶

n.

I. DAVEY Ruapehu Snow is a King Country bushman's version of billy-made Yorkshire pudding. I demonstrated this a few months ago, but woe and alack, the `snow' turned into sinkers. (Jul 29, 1966,Letter) [NOTES: 1966 July 29 Letter fr.I.Davey (Whangarei)]

Ruapehu throat¶

n.

Chemists and doctors in Hawke's Bay are now treating a new ailment - "Ruapehu Throat". It is a severe irritation caused by a fine abrasive dust from the volcano. (Nov 26, 1945,NZEF Times,IV/231 : 4)

Ruatangata Sandstone¶

n. Geol defn.

The northern three quarters of the peninsular is underlain by undeformed, northeast-dipping, massive to crudely bedded glauconitic sandstone (Ruatangata Sandstone, Te Kuiti Group, Runangan-early Whaingaroan) known from drillholes to be over 129 m and possibly up to 300 m thick (Fig. 2; Ferrar 1925 p. 43). (Aug 1989,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,85/19)

ruatara¶

n. tuatara (obs.)

Unu ngarara or ngarara burrows were frequently met with on the plains. ... The ngarara was darker in colour than the ruatara. They varied in size from two or three feet in length, and ten to twenty inches in girth ... (1875,TrNZI,7/296) [NOTES: (Stack)]

Ruaumoko¶

n. Maori god of earthquakes

Morey puts them in their place with the belly-rambling laughter of a Ruauamoko or a Tangaroa. (Sep 18, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

In the darkness, Mo sees and hears spirits that don't know they are dead. Angus can't see them, but he knows the mine is the way to reach Ruamoko, god of earthquakes, volcanoes and the unborn child. (Sep 29, 2003,Dominion Post,B9) [NOTES: check spelling Ruamoko]

Rongopai Broughton introduces us to the ever-threatening and unpredictable Ruaumoko, god of earthquakes, who vents his wrath wherever geological faultlines are... (Dec 3, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

...the air of ominous portent builds to true catastrophe by way of a bass rumbling, which may be the awakening of Ruamoko, the god of volcanoes, earthquakes and the unborn child. (Oct 5, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),25)

He knows the mine is the way to reach Ruamoko, god of earthquakes, volcanoes and the unborn child. (Dec 4, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

RUB¶

abbr. Rich Urban Biker

Rosemary McLeod's interest in rebels.. raised some wry smiles among the hardcore motorcycling fratenity; the men (and women) who have always ridden large motorcycles but whose thunder has largely been stolen by recent arrivals on the scene. The so-called RUBs - ruch urban bikers. (Mar 17, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A10)

rub noses¶

phr. to hongi [a long-used descriptive Pakeha misconception of the Maori HONGI `salute by pressing the noses together; incorrectly called rub noses.' (Williams)]

MARSDEN When the public confusion was a little over, Moodee Why and the hoary warrior rubbed noses as a token of reconciliation, but Matanghee refused this salutation and appeared sullen. (1819,Letters & Journals,187,1932 ed.)

EARLE (1832,Narrative of a Nine Months Residence in NZ) [NOTES: check]

MARKHAM ... Moyterra [Moetara] as the Europeans called him came on board and rubbed Noses with Captain Crow and Oakes and greeted all the Men, ... (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),29,1963 ed.)

MARSHAL ...rubbed noses in token of amity (1834,Narrative of Two Visits,165)

DARWIN On coming near one of the huts I was much amused by seeing in due form the ceremony of rubbing, or, as it ought to be called, pressing noses. The women, on our first approach, began uttering something in a most dolorous voice, they then squatted themselves down and held up their faces; my companion standing over them, one after another, placed the bridge of his nose at right angles to theirs, and commenced pressing. (1845,Voyage of the Beagle,Ch.XVIII (Everyman edn) 407,1860 ed.) [NOTES: 1835 Dec 23 in 1845 (1860) Darwin Voyage of Beagle]

BOULTBEE ... these people saluted us by rubbing noses. (1835,Boultbee Journal,71,1986 ed.) [NOTES: See also 1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 189]

Many of the old chiefs insist[ed] on rubbing noses with me (1840,NZ Journal,1/16/199)

BEST N.B. To rub noses is a mark of great esteem but the Mauries seem aware that we do not admire the custom and only Nose with us on peculiar occasions. (1840,Journal,233,1966 ed.)

HENRY WEEKES Acquaintances on meeting ... rub noses (1841,Journal,6)

COLENSO Such disgust is only surpassed when such a being condescends to ... rub noses with the white man. (1844,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1844 Colenso Excurs. North Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 12]

MATTHEWS Every native in the little villages greeted us, and one venerable old lady would cry over and rub noses with the teacher (Mar 2, 1854,Journal) [NOTES: 1854 Mar 2 J.Matthews Journal in 1940 Matthews Matthews of Kaitaia 193]

Just before Mr. MacLean went away ..., the contending chiefs met and rubbed noses, so that no doubt Mr. MacLean will report in Auckland that all is right here ... (Sep 2, 1857,Lyttelton Times,5)

HUNT Here we stopped, and the canoes were drawn up in front of the pa, amidst much tangi-ing, and shouts of `Haeremai, haeremai, haeremai!' - the usual amount of shaking hands and rubbing noses being over, a long korero, or talk, ensued. (1866,Chatham Islands,17)

SHAND After the recital of this, they then saluted by rubbing noses (hongi), as with the Maori, and wailed over their losses. (1911,Moriori People of the Chatham Islands, The,5)

SHADBOLT ... they [old Maori women] rubbed noses in the old Maori fashion instead. I couldn't have stood too much of that, though; my nose would have got raw. I didn't need to look in a mirror to know it was getting shiny. (1965,Among the Cinders,24)

CORBALLIS & GARRETT Further changes were made before the first Tangi' (in Contemporary Maori Writing) became the definitive version (in Pounamu, Pounamu). ... The charactersrub' noses in the earlier version; they press' them in the later one. ... [24] Finally, in three passages (pp. 126, 130) - but not in a fourth (p. 128) - thepa' becomes a meeting house'. ... (Pa' tends to have pejorative associations in Pakeha parlance, ...) (1984,Witi Ihimaera,23)

I was introduced to him and metaphorically rubbed noses with him on behalf of the Race. (Mar 11, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/66) [NOTES: Buck]

LINKLATER This old lady cannot speak English, but she has asked me to say that she would like to press noses with you. (1953,Year of Space, A,201,1953 ed.)

... after the speeches were completed an invitation was made to rub noses, shake hands and have kai. (Nov 12, 1988,Dominion,3)

Campbell Had we been Maoris of course we should there and then have also squatted down and rubbed noses. Hereafter I will explain why at such meetings the natives do not jump up and say how glad they are to see you, but welcome you in woe-begone `Haere mai's', squatting down and rubbing the lugubrious nose until the spectacle is anything but pleasant to look at. (1881,Poenamo,Bk3/2/142)

2 phr. transferred uses: see citations

BAKER In modern colloquial speech we find that to rub noses is used loosely for (a) to greet (a person), (b) to kiss (someone), (c) to plunge into a private conversation with heads close together. (1941,NZ Slang,21)

Johnson The hilltop view.. Allows you to rub noses with [get at close quarters with] a natural arrangement of the common trees and shrubs. (1997,Pick of the Bunch,153) [NOTES: cf. rub shoulders with]

rub-a-dub¶

n. the drug, ascetic anhydride

A large number of the terms gathered from the prison were to do with drugs and devices and ways of taking them... Some interesting ones include:.. rub-a-dub (used occasionally to refer to ascetic anhydride, an agent added to Class B drugs, for example, to turn them into Class A drugs, for example, heroin). (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

n. a rub, a massage

WILLIAMS What's the matter with you bums, anyway? My rub-down not classy enough for you anymore? ... I mean is Carlton ready for a health studio, mate?' ...Right. Got to give them something they think they are missing. What about you, Les? You'd be in for a bit of the ah ... [sic] other, the high-class rubadub, wouldn't you?' (1979,Skin Deep,18)

n. the pub [rubbity-dub ca1950 Vic. O'Leary Common in Hawkes Bay. 1981 Auckland Savings Bank, Queen Street (Goldie Brown Collection) Rub-a-dub: hotel, pub] (See rubbity-dub)

There are many examples of rhyming slang in use at Paparua:..rub-a-dub for the pub. (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

The genial Sandy / Serves out the shandy / And keeps up the rep' of therub' (Jun 23, 1906,NZ Truth,53/3)

I gazed upon the motley crowd / Within this `rub-a-dub' (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book)

rub-de-dub¶

n. (See rubbity(-dub))

rub-down¶

n. search [(prisoners')]

newbold the screws gave us a rub-down. A screw ran his thumb around the top of my pants and discovered the letter I had concealed. (1982,Big Huey, The,33)

rubber¶

n. (on a milking machine)

COWLEY He rinsed the machines in the washing water, turned them on, then released the rubbers. (1979,Growing Season, The,70)

v. of a vehicle, to approach on rubber tires?; with a play on stealing up on and foxing lovers having a cuddle

A taxi rubbered along, and the Nosey Posey therein honked and showed recognition. (Sep 2, 1918,Quick March,1)

1 n. (Rural) a farm animal that rubs on fences, branches etc usually as a result of infestation with ticks, lice, keds etc.

HENDERSON Certain farmers hold that certain sheep are persistent rubbers and consistent producers of sandy and earthy fleeces while others are not. (1968,Growing Better Wool,81)

rubber duckie¶

n. an outpowered rubber boat

Rubber Duckies.. are the three man outboard powered rubber boats used in surf racing. They are offically known as IRBs - inflatable rubber boats. (Dec 20, 2000,Capital Times,5) [NOTES: check date]

rubber foot¶

1 n. (Rural) a gumboot.

A sheep ran down to greet me, walking on my rubber feet. (2002,Lifestyle Farmer,June/July 7)

rubber gun¶

n.

PARTRIDGE Rubber gun. `A big gun firing at a very long range': military: 1917; ob. B & P. Esp. a German naval high-velocity shell, which the New Zealanders called rubber guts. (1937,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,710)

rubber ring¶

n. espec. in pl. (slices of) luncheon sausage. [(boarding schoolboys') ca1941 (St Patricks, Silverstream)]

rubbidy¶

n. pub (See rubbity(-dub))

rubbish¶

v. to criticise severely

(Jun 1968,Comment,33/2)

(Mar 26, 1969,NZ News,1/3-4)

McGILL rubbish to dismiss, criticise harshly or tease; eg `I wouldn't rubbish him just yet, he could still come good.' NZA. c.1925, Brit. later. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

n. useless vegetation, weeds

[The swivel sheaths of the double furrow plough] cut through mountains of loose piri-piri and other tough rubbish. (Nov 16, 1882,Chudleigh Diary,314,1950 ed.)

rubbish collector¶

n.

SARGESON It was said that one [absent-minded scholar] had arrived at the college with his household rubbish after leaving his umbrella outside his gate to be collected by the *rubbish-collector. (1965,Memoirs of a Peon,47)

rubbish fish¶

n.

rubbish juice¶

n. (informal)

The council's closed landfills manager Craig Calland says tests will include running a Geiger counter over the site and testing "rubbish juice" - which runs into groundwater and nearby Kaiwharawhara Stream. (Jul 21, 2005,Wellingtonian,2)

n. garbage tin, refuse tin

ELDRED-GRIGG Walking towards the back door, that slot in the house, neither inside nor outside our home, we pass the rubbish tin. (1995,Mum,305)

rubbity¶

n. rubbity-dub, pub

I hop off at the rubbidy, borrow a couple of Plymouth Sounds and get on the pig's ear. rubbidy (dub)....pub (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

HILLIARD Anybody seen Charlie?'In the rubbity this arfto. He's probably flakers.' (1978,Glory and the Dream, The,166)

McGILL rubbidy pub, rhyming slang `rub-a-dub/pub'; aka rubbity, rubbidy-dub, rubberdy and rubby. ANZ. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

n. a plane

The Morris [-] Shorthorn aeroplane was called a rubbity' in the Desert in 1915-1916 because its pusher engine made arubbity-rubbity' sound. (Jan 18, 1953,Radio 2ZB) [NOTES: Wellington Veterans' Session.]

rubbity-dub¶

n. a pub [ORIGIN: rhyming slang, various spellings] (See also rubbity)

SLATTER Give us a bloody beer.' ...Turn it up, Tom. This isn't the rubblededub. This is pie-cart' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,165)

SYDER & HODGETTS The public house. .in 4;`I'm going to the rubbidy dub, to have a couple of beers, that's where I'm going.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],933) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust. and NZ English [TS] 933]

McCALLUM So on a Saturday I went down to the local rubberty dub to have a few with the boys. (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,85)

[Hori] Our credit department is informed that you were seen at the local ruberty dub, when you made a cash purchase of ten half-gallon jars of beer... (Jun 1963,Home Life,2)

NEWBOLD RUB-DE-DUB (n) Pub. (1982,Big Huey, The,253)

I thought you might like to take me and the publisher over to the rubbity-dub for a sarsaparilla snifter. (May 23, 1951,NZ Truth,15)

A bloke's a mug to pay a sprat at the rubbitydub for nine ounces with a collar on when he can make a whole bottle of the stuff at home for about fivepence. (Jan 26, 1955,NZ Truth,4)

I'm just vacuuming the inside before taking it [sc. the car] to the rubbity-dub. (1993,Heard)

rubble¶

n.

Rubble, dry- Rubble walling built without mortar. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,95)

rubblededub¶

n. pub (See rubbity(-dub))

SLATTER He shrugs off the other one who is trying to restrain him and pounds the counter. Pour us a beer, sport. Come on, get cracking. Haven't got all day. Give us a bloody beer.' His friend takes his arm and says,Turn it up, Tom. This isn't the rubblededub. This is the pie-cart.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,165)

rubbling¶

n. [(gumdigging)]

An expert has estimated that the industry [sc. gum digging] will keep 3000 men employed for the next hundred years if rubbling is resorted to to gather in the chips, dust and small nuts. (Feb 20, 1926,NZ Observer,2)

rube¶

n. anything excellent or superior of its kind (short for RUBYDAZZLER) [ORIGIN: abbreviation, also as adj. (children's obs)]

BAKER In constant use by our youngsters ... rubydazzler, .... rube, grouse, [etc.] (1941,NZ Slang,51)

ruby¶

n. short for RUBYDAZZLER [1953 14 M A16 Thames DHS 8 RUBY]

ruby rock¶

n. [mining]

The mineral usually occurs in a dark green matrix... the rubies and matrix forming a very beautiful rock known to the miners as "ruby rock". (1987,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,ns.1/77) [NOTES: (Bell and Fraser-Hokitika)]

ruby-dazzler¶

n. anything excellent or superior of its kind. [(children's obsolescent) ca1935 Havelock; 14-15 M A3 Thames DHS 8 RUBY DAZZLER [M4]]

BAKER In constant use by our youngsters ... bobbydazzler, rubydazzler, [etc]. (1941,NZ Slang,51)

CASEY The old man took a ruby-dazzler on the nose and went reeling back - (1963,As Short a Spring,275)

McGILL rubydazzler excellent person or thing, a rube for short; variant of Brit. bobbydazzler'; egAll those scones, for how many of you ratbags! That Noeline's a rubydazzler, and I hope you appreciate it.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

rubyfish¶

n.

GRAHAM Ruby Fish Plagiogeneion rubiginosus (Hutton) ... Ruby Fish Serranops maculicauda Regan .. Ruby Fish Lepidoperca inornata Regan ... Ruby Fish Aulacocephalus temmincki Bleeker (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,406) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 406]

AYL.ING RUBY FISH Plagiogeneion rubiginosus ... Body colour of this species is a uniform dark red. (1982,Collins Guide,223,1984 ed.)

[species name] ruby fish .. [scientific name] Plagiogeneion rubiginosus .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Rubyfish Plagiogeneion rubiginosus Also occurs around southern Australia and South Africa. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,95)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] rubyfish 1450-3 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

n.

Black cardinalfish, frostfish, ghost shark, ribaldo, rubyfish, sea perch, trumpeter, white warehou and yellow-eyed mullet have now been included... Other reductions to catch limits are to specific stocks of grey mullet, barracouta and oreo dory. (Sep 12, 1998,Dominion,2)

rudderfish¶

n. Centrolophus maoricus Ogilby

GRAHAM Rudderfish Centrolophus maoricus Ogilby .. Rudderfish Centrolophus huttoni Waite... Rudderfish Cristaculeus dycritus Thompson (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,405) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 405]

AYLING RUDDERFISH Centrolophus niger ... The rudderfish is an elongate species with a rounded snout. (1982,Collins Guide,402,1984 ed.)

[species name] rudderfish .. [scientific name] Centrolophus niger .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Rudderfish Centrolophus niger Widespread in temperate seas of the world. In some areas known as blackfish. Mid to dark brown on the head .. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,139)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] rudderfish 2162-5, 2200 RUDDERFISHES 2160-203 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

A somewhat similar fish is found in company with those odd, tropic fishes known as "cowfish," and are called "cow pilots"; while still another is known as the "rudderfish," and always keeps close to the rudder or sternpost of vessels. (Aug 3, 1904,Otago Witness,68)

rue¶

2 n. (See pine,rue)

In an economic point of view, the chief trees of the Middle Island, are the Red and White Pine, respectively called by the Maoris: the former Mai or Matai (Podicarpus spicata),[fn] the latter the Kahikatea (Podocarpus dacrydioides). [ed. fn] Black Rue of Otago, Hook., f.; Miro, Black Rue or Black Pine in Otago, Hector; Miro, often confounded with Black Pine, Balfour; Matai, Colenso, - Mai or Matai (Taylor) (1869,TrNZI,1/III/12) [NOTES: (Monro).]

rugbification¶

n.

The postage stamps. The weet-bix cartons. Was nothing safe from rugbification? (Dec 15, 2005,Dominion Post,D3)

rugby tragic¶

n. an extreme rugby fan

Nicholls is a Christchurch lawyer who is a rugby tragic. (Dec 9, 2005,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,2)

rugby was the winner¶

phr. rugby platitude, frequently associated with All Black captain, Sean Fitzpatrick

The crowd was relaxed, the terrible tensions of the winter were gone and for once the cliche was apt, rugby really was the winner. (Jul 14, 2001,Evening Post,33)

rugby, racing and beer¶

phr.

Phillips says we are a more complicated and diverse society than in the 1950's, when rugby, racing and beer reigned. (Sep 18, 2010,Your Weekend,9)

rugby-bashing¶

n.

Rugby-bashing comes in a clear second to the game itself as the national sport. (Oct 13, 1999,Evening Post,23)

rugby-head¶

n. [Internet search Feb 2006: also used Austral.; India; Sth Africa. Most citations appear to be from NZ. earliest dates needed.]

Leanne says most of the girls she's met on tour are "dolly birds" on a blatant man and publicity hunt. (Jun 19, 2005,Dominion Post,A2)

Everyone just crammed into the gridlock of rugby-heads... (Jul 11, 2005,NZ Herald,A7)

Bands of drunken, promiscuous young women are as accepted a feature as bands of young male rugby-heads. (Sep 24, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

rugby-immune¶

adj.

Nicky sipped her Tui beer proudly and my two rugby-immune children took turns waving a large inflatable blue hand with the pointing finger that a friend's grandad had lent us. (Dec 15, 2005,Dominion Post,D3)

rugbyed out¶

adj. tired of too much rugby [heard on radio talkback show 19/11/2000]

New Zealand is rugby'd out and the unnecessary and unnecessarily prolonged examination of the All Black coaches was the final straw. (Oct 9, 2001,Dominion,26)

The same, it seem, also applied to Atiga who admits that after a hefty diet of touring in 2002-03 and feeling "rugbyed out" he acted on his parents' advice and declined selection for the Blues in the 2003 Super 12. (Sep 26, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B6)

rugbyite¶

n.

At frequent intervals also we.. are visited by Rugbyites from across the Tasman Sea. (Jul 6, 1900,Auckland Weekly News,8)

rugged up¶

adj.

To reach the castle I must pass through a market where local women rugged up in big coats and fur hats are selling woollen jumpers with images of the castle knitted into them... (Jul 28, 2002,Dominion Post,C11)

With that thinness came such cold that even on a mild summer's day he was rugged up in layer upon layer of clothing to keep warm. (May 23, 1993,Sunday Times (NZ),10)

rugger¶

2 n.

Most ruggers dislike university, because they can't stand being utter nobodies after enjoying status (as ruggers) at school. (Feb 2003,Salient,Orientation 2003/30)

rules¶

n. something liked [[x RULES] -->1984 17 F E.ho;1953 Pakuranga Coll. 4 RULES -->1984 17 F E54 Pakuranga Coll. 4 RULES -->1984 17 M E112Pakuranga Coll. 4 RULES -->1984 17 M E113Pakuranga Coll. 4 RULES -->1984 17 F E57 Pakuranga Coll. 4 RULLES]

rum-a-rum¶

n. (See ramarama)

rumaki¶

n. (language) immersion [ORIGIN: Maori]

Awatea Immersion Unit catering for both Bilingual and Rumaki options (restricted numbers - get application in early). (Oct 25, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

rumble¶

n. a (gang) fight [ca1979 Aug 25 TV1 Commentary The Auckland v Pumas match with shoving and pushing leading to a rumble. 1984 16-17 F E4 Pakuranga Coll. 30B RUMBLE [fight] [F7 M9] -->1984 14 F E138 Wgton Girls C. 30B RUMBLE -->WF n. (4) 1946]

words and sayings sent in by `Tuesdate' readers - things their parents said when they were at school: rumble fight (Jun 29, 1976,Evening Post,14/6)

rumble ... 8. U.S. & N.Z. sl. a gang fight. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1009) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 426]]

n. a fall

Believe ye.. That the tenderfoot and Zambuck, Working madly in the trenches, Comes a "gutzer" in those trenches, And is taught to take a rumble. (Jun 21, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/46 : 221)

v. esp. of gangs, to fight; to raid, attack [(criminals')]

We were not formed to be rumbling (fighting) all the time. (Aug 21, 1979,Press, The,19/10)

Newbold If they touch you, we'll rumble them. (1982,Big Huey, The,213)

rumjar¶

n. [(WW1 : ?France)]

RUM-JAR. - A German bomb, smaller than a Minnenwerfer: fired from a trench mortar. Ibid. 32 And when the Minnies' twist and twire,/ Andrumjars' bob and bust,/ While five-point-mines' and otherfruit'/ Stir up the bloomin' dust,/ (1917,New Zealand At the Front,(Glossary) xiv)

STEWART At 5.45 a.m. ... a perfect tornado of shells rumjars' andpineapples' burst afresh on the same section of the line. (1921,NZ Division,152)

rummering¶

n. [1980 Ballantyne Penfriend 27 Be glad to take you rummering, I says. ... we head for the stream. Nothing flash in the way of gaffs ... and after we make it downstream ... I hand him the pipe and tell him what he has to do is whack the eel when I toss it into the bank.]

rummy¶

n.

About time the Manawatu Railway Company started running Sunday trains. The religion relating rummies will rouse a bit, but that's only a detail. (Oct 20, 1906,NZ Truth,70/1/4)

rummy-rum¶

n. (See ramarama)

rump-munching¶

n. (Rural) [sheepdogs] the biting of the rumps of sheep being worked.

SINCLAIR He went around the back of the mob, biting every second sheep hard on the rump. He did an encore of the previous rump-munching. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,58)

rumpty¶

n. anything excellent or superior of its class [esp. by children[cf 1906 June 2 Truth [p?]`Rumpty' Reid compliments the workers.] ca1935 Havelock children. eg You little rumpty. (also attrib./adj.)] (See rumptydooler)

What a rumpty ... (Jan 29, 1945,2NZEF Times) [NOTES: 1945 Jan 29 2 NZEF Times JNZ]

SLATTER I've seen some rumpty parties in kitchens (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,200)

McGILL rumty excellent person or thing; contraction of rum-ti-tum', an English expansion ofrum', excellent. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,94)

adj. unlovely; in poor repair; disreputable [(?esp. by adults), ca1950 p.c. Ken Griffiths (Auckland)]

IAN BREWARD The other day I came across an expression at work which was a new one to me - rumpty'. It was used by two different people. One used it of a car which was almost in the last stages of disrepair. The other used it of the sawmill in its early stages when it was badly designed and ratherHeath Robinsonish' (Jan 25, 1958,Letter) [NOTES: (Whakatane)]

  • a story in NZ speech. ... baching in a rumpty old shack .... (Nov 4, 1985,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1985 Nov 4 National Radio Correspondence School Session]

New Brighton is now regarded as a rumpty part of Christchurch, but it always was, to people who didn't live there. (Oct 1, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

Real baches he describes as "rumpty" and you didn't have to worry about them and spend your day polishing and vacuuming and maintaining them. (Aug 2, 2003,Independent Herald (Wellington),F18)

2 n. a fuss, an uproar

MORRIESON [Written by schoolboy on flyleaf of North and Hillard's Latin Grammar] Stay for me, I shall not fail/ To meet you in that hollow vale,/ But what a rumpty there will be/ If thou shouldst bring this book with thee! (1981,Predicament,21,1974 ed.)

rumptydooler¶

n. an elaboration of rumpty (in favourable sense) [ca1935 Havelock children]

BAKER (1941,NZ Slang,51) [NOTES: [see RUMPTY]]

rumpus room¶

n. a room in house for general family recreation [Jim writes: In NZPOD but not in DNZE. NSOD and Collins tag it as NAmer, Aust and NZ. A very common feature of modern NZ houses, often mentioned in "for sale" ads. An integral part of NZE since circa 1970. The term did not occur in the English Property Supplement to a 1987 Midlands newspaper.]

The kids will play all day downstairs in the 3 bedrooms and large rumpus opening out onto the wooden decks and multi-levelled lawns. (Nov 22, 2000,Property Press,4)

run¶

adj. [one ref to Austral Eng]

(1898,Austral English)

n. sc of gold [goldmining]

The different runs of gold .... have not been traced further than Wetherstone's Flat. Ibid. D/6/18 The gold is more dispersed, so as not form any distinct run ... (1863,AJHR,D/6/15) [NOTES: (Pyke Goldfields Reports)]

The greater part of Bluebottle Terrace has not been subjected, to sufficient reconcentration to render the drifts payable `runs' of gold may yet be found on or near the Blue Bottom. (1906,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.1 (N.S.): 93) [NOTES: (Bell-Hokitika)]

SUTHERLAND There was a `run' of gold somewhere in the head of the valley but it had not been satisfactorily plotted. (1953,Golden Bush, The,41,1963 ed.)

n. grazing land [also cattle run, sheep run Acland distinguished six uses of the noun, because of change or extension of the meaning of the original borrowing; run off, (Farming) land which is not part of a developed farm but which is used for intermittent grazing.] (See also cattle run,sheep run)

FOR SALE, a Small Farm, part of which is heavily timbered, convenient to a shipping place, with plenty of water, and a good run for cattle. (Apr 23, 1864,Otago Witness,12)

Run.- The pioneers of sheep farming in New Zealand and Australia came from various classes; but there were few among them who had been sheep farmers before and fewer still who were scientists. If they had been sheep farmers they would probably have used the English or Scotch sheep farming words (as they did to some extent) and fitted them to the new conditions. If they had been scientists they would have invented exact names for everything new, and translated them into Latin. What they did do was to take the handiest word they could think of and give it a new meaning, As time went on the word they had chosen changed or extended its meaning. The best example of all this is the word run. (Nov 18, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: >Acland's senses 1 and 5 seem to be the central ones, with the others being specialisations of, or obvious inferences from those. -->cf also Morris]

[Cont] (1) The country held under a particular lease or pastoral license. [sic] (PAUL, p. 92) (2) Group of rs. held by one owner, or in one station. The whole area is spoken of as a r. (C.RH., p. 90) (3) Leasehold as opposed to freehold. (Sheep returns, 1878) (4) Open as opposed to fenced country. Out on the r.'; i.e., not in any of the paddocks. ([1874 Lady Barker Station Life], p. 62) (5) Adjective. R. sheep, r. cattle, as opposed to paddock sheep or milking cows and hand-reared calves. (C.) (6) As equivalent to station: e.g.He has sold his r.'; One of the best rs. in Canterbury.' In this sense r. did not always include the sheep, as the word s[tation]. does. This usage is now uncommon and r. in these contexts would probably mean small grazing r. ([1874 Kennaway Crusts], p. 86;Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement],p. 152) (7) A block of country, a division of a r. E.g. ewe r. upper r. This sense was always rare, but is still in use on some ss. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (8) To keep or carry.He runs merinos'; `the station runs 10,000 sheep' ([1898 Morris Austral-English]; C) (Nov 15, 1933,Press, The,15)

MORRIS Run, n. (1) Tract of land over which sheep or cattle may graze. It is curious that what in England is called a sheep-walk, in Australia is a sheep-run. In the Western United States it is a sheep -ranch. Originally the squatter, or sheep-farmer, did not own the land. It was unfenced, and he simply had the right of grazing or `running' his sheep or cattle on it. Subsequently, in many cases, he purchased the freehold, and the word is now applied to a large station- property, fenced or unfenced. (See quotation, 1883.) [1826] (1898,Austral English,397)

TURNER First a run is a parcel of land as leased. A sheepfarmer might own several adjacent runs of land, in this sense, and the whole station' so formed might also be termed a run. In the third sense a run was leasehold as opposed to freehold land; in a fourth sense, open land as opposed to fenced land. It might be used as an adjective, e.g. run cattle. It might be the equivalent of station but without including the sheep, i.e.He sold his run' need not imply that he sold his sheep, but `He sold his station' would. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,50)

run: [1] This word has several uses but the most common refers to a stretch of work. The official shearing time of two hours is called a run'. The day is divided into four of these. 7.30am-9.30am, smoke-o; 10.00am-12 noon, dinner; 1.00pm-3.00pm smoke-o; 3.30pm-5.30pm, tea. [2] Also another name for a sheep station. [3] Also the contract circuit. A shearing contractor will arrange arun' of sheds for his gang each season. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/27) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

It is bounded by the Western Coast where there is some good Land, and dry run for Sheep. (Jun 19, 1840,New Zealand Advertiser and Bay of Islands Gazette,3)

v. [sheep farming, one cit]

The station runs 10,000 sheep. (1933,Press, The) [NOTES: Acland]

adj. aj or attrib ?or combin. esp. run country, run hunting, run licence, run sheep see also run book, run cattle, run cow, runholder, runholding

Lambs ... while ewes are being shorn ... are being wigged or eye-clipped ... Through eye clipping, wool blindness is avoided; a wool-blind sheep is seriously hampered on run country in its search for feed and consequently does not thrive. (Oct 16, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,349)

THOMAS He proceeded to raise cattle on a large area of leasehold run country, mostly north of Hukatere. (1970,Way Up North,63)

v. [unclear; one cit]

... the defendant conductor, who has a wife and four children (youngest a week old) was alleged to be running yet another girl besides the complainant. (Mar 13, 1909,NZ Truth,195/5/1)

v. (Rural) [sheepdogs and their controllers] to work.

NEWTON .. the musterer freqently gets his team to bark while at heel (i.e. alongside him) the object being to frighten sheep along without actually running a dog. (1966,Boss's Story, The,185)

MCGREGOR If you do run him in a paddock he should never be allowed to get too close to his sheep as this only makes the sheep over exert themselves ... (1980,Dog's Life, A,39)

DREAVER I was there in the days before major development started on the tussock, and the blocks were large and it seemed you could run a dog for miles. (1994,Catlins River Wisp Run,57)

KAY As young men, Anthony II's sons shared a great love of country, for its bush, birds, animals, shooting, horse riding, running sheep dogs, or just the freedom and the challenge of ownership. (1996,Anthony Wall, Settler of Porirua,168)

Waipukurau Stock Sale: Well bred dogs ready to run. (Dec 8, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,30)

v. (Rural) [sheep or cattle] to move together in a string or mob in one direction.

NEWTON .. sheep don't run as they used to - and this militates against clean mustering. (1966,Boss's Story, The,121)

v. [as a general catchphrase, heard on English TV; no citations]

v. [to run past, meaning to check with]

McGILL run past someone present work for assessment or opinion; eg `I'd like to run these figures past you one more time, okay?' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,95)

n. a liberty-leave [(? nautical)]

DILKE Even sailors on shore `for a run' here wear cord breeches and high tight-fitting boots, often armed with spurs, though, as there are no horses except those of the Gold-Coast Police, they cannot enjoy much riding. (1868,Greater Britain,1/335)

v. (Rural) to manage or own a property.

TAIT After his death, it was run by managers ... (1961,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III,153)

NEWTON In earlier days Orongorongo was run in with Tora Station. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,7)

n. the effective length of the saw less the diameter or width of the trunk or log being sawn [tree felling]

MOORE I decide to put in a side-scarf' to give a betterrun' for the saw, even though this is a 9-foot one ... (1969,From Forest to Farm,89)

v. (Rural) [farmer or land] to graze or carry stock.
