He further maintained that the defendant, holding a license [sic] to run cattle on the Dunedin Hundred, his bull running on that Hundred could not be held to be straying or running at large, and that the Wardens of the Hundred having the power under the Land Regulations of determining the description of cattle to be allowed to run within the Hundred, the Entire Animals Ordinance was inoperative within Hundreds, except so far as the Wardens adopted it as one of their regulations. (May 15, 1858,Otago Witness,3)

The person, or in the case of a lease to two or more persons holding or occupying any land within a district, under or by virtue of any grant from the Crown, or any mining, mineral, or agricultural lease, shall be entitled to run three head of great cattle free of charge, provided that in the case of a Crown Grant, or a lease to two or more persons jointly, the number of cattle which they shall be together entitled to run shall be no more than three head. (Mar 17, 1870,Tuapeka Times,5)

Mr. Robertson hoped that applications would only be granted to those who were really entitled to run cattle on the goldfields. (Sep 5, 1868,Tuapeka Times,3)

At the present partial law allows the Maori to prohibit all cattle from running on his land, a [sic] meeting of the Europeans and Maoris was held here some time since, at which the latter claimed, and the former, without much demur, agreed to pay, 5s. per head annually for such of their cattle as should run on the Maori land. (Oct 22, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,2)

The Mayor informed the members that Mr Jas. Bayly had waited on him, in company with Cr. Klenner, in reference to the recreation reserve, and stated that permission had been given him by Mr Knight to run cattle in the reserve, Mr Knight at that time being a member of the old Town Board, and also a member of the Reserves Committee. (Feb 11, 1905,Taranaki Herald,3)

"..Taking the majority of farms here, a certain proportion of cattle are run with the sheep with the object of keeping down the rank or coarser grasses, so that it would be an easy matter to test whether some such system as the following would not give such good results ..." (Aug 19, 1908,Tuapeka Times,4)

A number of the farmers have lately taken to sheep-feeding, and I suppose they are not disposed to substitute at present cows for sheep; yet a combination of cattle and sheep is better for the land, it being advisable to give land which has been much run with sheep a rest for a while from stock of that description and run cattle on it exclusively. (Aug 30, 1894,Otago Witness,23)

The ewes can then be boxed up again and run in convenient sized mobs. (Mar 1918,NZ Farmer,271)

ACLAND The dry cattle were run further out than the sheep. (1930,Early Canterbury Runs,241)

TURNER The word might be used as a transitive verb. 'He runs Merinos' i.e. has Merino sheep as his stock. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,iii 50)

GASCOIGNE Run in this manner, the sheep fatten quickly ... (1965,From the Top of a Hill,122)

FEARON In 1956 Dunolly was running 2,100 sheep and 280 cows, but by 1965 when it was put on the market, it was running 4,100 sheep and 370 cows. (1980,Te Wharau,40)

v. (Rural) [sheep or cattle] to graze.

We have 36 head of cattle running this winter on the back bush land. (Aug 8, 1854,BLANK ENTRY,154) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers I]

DEANS The hardest day I can recall was about 1901 when the lambs from 3,000 Merino ewes running on the Bush Gully block had to be marked in one day. (1964,Pioneers on Port Cooper Plains,114)

NEWTON At the time of my visit the hoggets were running on one of these new blocks ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,164)

MAF .. stock run on less productive land make a contribution toward overhead costs ... (1989,BLANK ENTRY,122) [NOTES: Economic Evaluation of Agroforestry in Otago]

n. (Rural) a course followed by a dog in a dog trial competition.

NEWTON Run: ... Also a dog's performance during a particular job is referred to as his `run', i.e. he puts up a good run or otherwise. (1966,Boss's Story, The,189)

NEWTON But for the fact that that his outrun was excessively wide he put up a good run ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,195)

The sheep must be removed if a competitor's dog has made contact with them and the run is subsequently terminated for any reason. (1991,Constitution of NZ Dog Trial Assoc,31)

KERR I had long decided being pedantic over poor runs was a waste of judging time; anyone scoring 85 or under these days has no show. (2000,High Times in the High Country,159)

v. [AND used elsewhere but recorded earliest in Aust. and apparently chiefly Aust. OED(S v. 43. c.: 1. trans to provide pasture for (sheep, cattle); to raise stock (also absol) 1795, 1828 2. v.i. of stock, to graze 3. of land 1. to provide sustenance for animals] (See run n)

(8) To keep or carry. "He runs merinos"; "The station runs 10,000 sheep." (AE.;C). (Nov 18, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

PHARAZYN Asked 80 acres and back hill ... to run sheep and cattle upon (1848,Journal,169)

HOCKEN Under the original terms, land purchasers were entitled upon payment of an annual license fee of 10s. 6d. to depasture or run sheep and cattle upon such waste lands within the block as remained unappropriated. ... though Captain Cargill was then gazetted Commissioner of Crown Lands for the Otago block only, he received no definite instructions upon the subject of granting the runs. [139] The result was that he merely filed the applications for depasturage licenses as they were presented to him, whilst the applicants were left to pursue their further course as seemed best to them. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,138) [NOTES: 1890 J.C.H.Chapman in 1898 Hocken Contributions 138-139]

NEAVE I have some recollections of my uncles only running about one thousand, two hundred sheep on the entire block. (1980,Land of Munros, The,72)

run v. ... NZ & Austral. have (specified livestock) on one's property (run cattle, sheep, etc.); (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,668)

By 1850 Flaxbourne was running 11,000 Merion sheep. (2008,NZ Memories,73/51)

n. (Rural) a period in which shearers shear sheep between intervals [ measured in hours or in numbers of sheep.]

Run .. (3) Stretch of work. Shearers work for an hour before breakfast .. (Nov 18, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

BOWEN Run. The shearing time between official stops, smokos or meals. (1955,Wool Away!,157)

RIDDOLLS Each [catching pen] pen should be large enough to hold a normal "run", eg, for a two hours' run, 30 sheep. (1958,Farm Engineering,353)

n. in specific uses, chiefly station or farming

WOODHOUSE ... the record shearing run of 19 nothing 9 (1909,Farm & Station Verse,52) [NOTES: 1909 Geo. Meek. `Wet Sheep' in Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 52]

Run.- ... 3. Stretch of work [shearing]. Shearers work for an hour before breakfast, two stretches in the morning and three in the afternoon. The stretches are divided by meal-times and smokos (q.v.). (C.) (Nov 18, 1933,Press, The,15)

BOWEN No one knows better than I how a bad run can tend to get a man down - a run of sticky sheep, or gear not cutting the best, ... <13> A shearer should not start an early morning run without a cup of tea ... 157 RUN. The shearing time worked between official stops, smokos, or meals. (1955,Wool Away!,7)

Tally: The number of sheep shorn during a run or other specified period. However, the general term is also used to describe a shearer's capacity to shear in a day. E.g. `He has a tally of 120.' (Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: H.A.L. Laing]

McLINTOCK ... actual shearing time is probably nine hours, with spells' (breaks) between six typicalruns' totalling three hours. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/229)

Run:The period of shearing between breaks for `smoko' and meals. (Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

MOORE The men work in `runs' none of which exceeds one and three-quarters hours - a work day totalling eight and three-quarter hours. (1969,From Forest to Farm,84)

FERNANDEZ Andrew was troubled about the [shearing] gang's knocking off ... He had enough sheep in for another run. (1973,Tussock Fever,64)

RUN: The period of shearing between breaks for `smoko' or meals. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20) [NOTES: [Shearer's language]]

Run: Interval of time between breaks when shearing. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,58)

RICHARDS Sometimes several combs and a dozen cutters may be used, or blunted, during a run'. . <i>Ibid.</i> 94 The following day, Jim (later Sir Eruera [Tirikatene]) became mybarrow-boy' and washed and dried my used gear each run for the privilege of shearing the first sheep. Ibid. 113 A steam whistle ... blew for the commencement and finish of each run. The wool tables for rolling and skirting were in the centre of the woolboard. Close by stood the classer's table, where he sat and classed each fleece before it was carried by a shed hand to its respective bin. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,72)

My first `run' (the period of work between breaks for tucker) went by in a blur. (Mar 1988,More Magazine,30)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Run. The area held as a station; includes the area under pastoral lease. Also refers to a period of work; the shearers divide the working periods of their days into runs. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,97)

n. various periods of work: 8-10am etc

n. (Rural) [shearing or crutching gangs] a circuit or number of woolsheds to work. (See crutching run)

When a man [shearer] made arrangements to go to a `run' of two or three sheds he only deposited 20s, which carried him through the run. (May 26, 1911,Maoriland Worker,12/11/4)

SMITH As an inducement for the men to work for them [shearing contractors] arrange a `run of sheds' to follow one another. (1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,72)

SHARPE Each group of Maoris developed its own `run', or succession of woolsheds in which the group did shearing as of right ... (1962,Country Occasions,36)

.. focusing instead on rugby and taking a variety of jobs - including a crutching run - to support himself. (Jun 9, 2006,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,10)

RUSSELL This year I have Maori shearers, Taranaki Te Ua engaged them for me and they do his shed, the Tuna Nui shed and Hill at Fernhill, which gives them a good run. (1904,Diary,136) [NOTES: in Hill (1990) Between the Rivers]

WATERSON When he heard that this Steve fellow was a top shearer and could use another hand when his run started up, Wart became quite interested. (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,24)

Quality shearers and shedhands required for large 2nd shear run. (Jun 22, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,27)

adj. [farming; run licence, run-holder]

HURSTHOUSE Pastoral lands are the wild grazing lands ... leased ... for a term of years under a deed termed a `run licence,' to the emigrant who, embarking on pastoral pursuits, becomes what is indifferently termed a run-holder, sheep-farmer, flock-master, or Squatter. (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/512)

adj. [farming; one cit: run-sale]

... 155,500 acres of similar land, the temporary licenses of which expire in 1901; and 22,918 acres of pastoral land passed in at the last run-sale. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,30)

n. a usual beat or haunt (?on a free range) [[move forward to ?@n4 if admit] cf RUN @v4 cf also PIG-RUN (?does fowl-run belong here]]

My new horse got through the fence yesterday and has gone full bare [?=bore] back to his old run. (Sep 22, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,104,1950 ed.)

adj. [farming; one cit: runseekers]

BEATTIE Next day the two run-seekers [in Otago Central in 1859] met her husband coming with the cattle. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,26)

v. to send a dog out (See cf also running out)

15 Run.- (1) To send [a dog]. (2) Work [of a young dog]. `That dog is just beginning to r.' 3. Stretch of work [shearing]. Shearers work for an hour before breakfast, two stretches in te morning and three in the afternoon. The stretches are divided by meal-times and smokos (q.v.). (C.) (Nov 18, 1933,Press, The) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

`Never run a dog unless you must; never run a dog behind you.' Ibid.34 It was wise to start them from a distance, because if started suddenly they were likely to scatter, and that meant running a dog. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,24)

1 n. (Rural) a large grazing or pastoral property. [rural]

PAUL The occupiers of runs will also take charge of cattle ... (1853,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,21)

PAUL In New Zealand a well-bred merino flock, on a good run, will fully average 4 lbs. (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,40)

FULLER The dwelling-house is generally termed the 'station:' while the land, the pasture of which is rented from the Government, is termed the 'run.' (1859,Five Years' Residence in New Zealand,147)

MCKEE WRIGHT .. the run is broken up for hungry cockatoos ... (1898,Station Ballads,46)

Two-thirds of this number are on small grazing-runs .. The remainder are on freehold runs .. The runs of the Ashburton County lie behind, and are a modified extension of, a belt of brown-top country.. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,99)

A case is known where all sheep were wintered on the run, and the death-rate was 20 per cent. to 30 per cent. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,103)

Stores are brought down off the hill runs to be finished off on the luscious paspalum-white clover pastures on the flats. (Jan 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,15)

TAIT Te Aratipi was originally the outstation of Mrs G P Donnelly's Waimarama run. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,41)

.. this run is still regarded as being good, although isolated summer country ... (Sep 28, 1961,NZ Farmer,16)

DOMINY He portrays an "ideal" run as representing extensive use of land, located in a remote area at high elevation with steep and rugged terrain, with harsh winters, short growing seasons, shallow soil and little pasture development. Bob Hall .. differentiates a sheep station from a run ... (2001,Calling the Station Home,139)

2 v. on pasture

WAKEFIELD (Letter from Nelson) We have about 1400 [sheep] running in the Upper Motueka Valley Ibid. 310 On the site of Dunedin ... a Mr.Anderson had, in April 1847, 300 sheep and 50 head of cattle running. (1847,Handbook for New Zealand, The,149)

We have 36 head of cattle running this winter on the back bush land.... The bush feed keeps the cattle in fine order in winter time. -->1865 Dec 1 in 1914 History of North Otago (1978) 177 Mr. Holmes' sheep are running on native grass and the above increase has been obtained at one lambing. (Aug 8, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/154,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W.Richmond)]

2 n. [slang for dismissal]

BAKER to give a person his running shoes ... an extension of the phrase to get the run, to be dimissed or fired - (1941,NZ Slang,53)

2 v. to have a free range on a place, pasture etc cf RUN @n8

All persons are hereby cautioned against disturbing the Horses now running in the neighbourhood of Rangiora, or driving any of them without permission of J.H. WARD, Rangiora. (Jul 1, 1857,Lyttelton Times,1)

2 n. ?? run=station, station=run in some early usage cf 8copied from 1a)

He also reports having sold by private contract, on account of Messrs Miles and Co., Christchurch the Lake Heron Run, with the sheep thereon, to Messrs Dunbar Bros. (Apr 8, 1881,North Otago Times,2)

WELD The first care of the intending sheep-farmer will naturally be to select a run' or sheep-walk. ... But if the selection of the station orrun' is important ... (1851,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,6)

As to the preemptive right, please send me the best description you can of what we should apply for. We have a right to `80 acres at one of the stations and 10 acres at each of the other stations erected upon the run' ... It seems, however, that there must be a station of some sort at the place where preemptive is applied for; but it would be easy to have a hut put up at any place where we wanted to take our land. (Apr 20, 1863,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/37,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

BARKER Fuel is ... very expensive, as we have no available `bush' on the Run; ... Ibid. 73 Our friend . owns a large station ... At the back [74] of his run the hills rise ro a great height .. (1866,Station Life in NZ,62,1870 ed.)

n: an extensive grazing property usually in South Island tussock country (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,5)

2 n. `range' ?without reference to leasing or licensing an area (=STATION in sense of total run)

run n. a range of pasture for feeding stock (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

run A large area of land on which sheep or cattle, or both, are grazed; in America a `ranch' (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),349,8th edn ed.)

run n. grazing area for sheep or cattle; (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),624)

ANDERSON The areas shown as `high country' runs or stations vary in size from 2,000 to 40,000 hectares and are used for grazing sheep. When these stations were first taken up ... There were no fences on these early high country runs, ... . (1981,Both Sides of the River,8)

2 n. leasehold as distinct from freehold

CHAPMAN Thirty acres of average available land may be found with many miles of run for the cattle. (1831,Journal and Letters (Walker),1/50)

PHARAZYN ... looking out for a run upon the coast. (1846,Journal,19)

WAKEFIELD Another advantage is to be found in the absence of burrs in the New Zealand runs; [fn] in New South Wales these are found to tear the wool, ... Ibid. 169 The custom has been, like that of New South Wales, to let the cattle ... rove at large over a tract of country, generally called a run. ... When wanted to be branded ... they are driven by men on horseback, armed with long whips, into a strong fold, called a stock-yard. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,123)

2 n. [farming, unspecified]

... give us possession of a new run for a period of years. (Sep 5, 1849,Deans' Letters,155,1937 ed.)

[The cattle] are always in the open air, or, as they would say in New Zealand, `on the run' (1849,Handbook of New Zealand,24) [NOTES: 1849 Allom in Earp's NZ Handbook (Notes on NZ 1849) 24]

DILLON The run which [the sheep] are on is magnificent (1850,Letters,295)

... splendid sheep runs (Jan 9, 1851,Journal of Edward Ward,107,1951 ed.)

SAM STEPHENS Each owner rents or has a licnce for a `Run', as it is called, from 5 to 50,000 acres. (1851,Journal,504)

WELD I consider double that sum as the most favourable amount that can be invested in the formation of a sheep-station; for on a good run, 2000 sheep can be kept ... Ibid. 6 The first care of the intending sheep-farmer will naturally be to select a run' or sheep-walk. ... But if the selection of the station orrun' is important ... (1851,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,5)

I have secured the prettiest spot and the best run in the whole district. (Feb 26, 1851,Torlesse Papers,1958,200 ed.)

H. TOPELL Here it all runs upon Stations - Sheep runs - good and bad Country - Cattle and Stock. (1853,Journal,1/312,1980 ed.)

ROCHFORT [The Station owner] has some excellent paddocks fenced in. The run is bounded on one side by the Turakina river, on the other three by a good post-and-rail fence. The sheep require but little looking after, as they cannot get over the boundary. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,25)

STUDHOLME February, 1855. Run 39. 35,000 acres (Feb 1954,Te Waimate,45) [NOTES: 1855 Feb in 1940 Studholme Te Waimate (1954) 45]

WANTED TO PURCHASE The Good Will of a RUN inside the Canterbury Province, with or without from 2000 to 3000 Ewes. (Jul 1, 1857,Lyttelton Times,1)

HARPER Stayed with [Tripp] some days to see the working of the run, a mountain tract of 40,000 acres, scarcely trodden as yet by foot of man. (Sep 1, 1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,21,1914 ed.)

ACLAND ... it will be as well to mention the way in which a sheep-farmer settles himself on his sheep-walk, or `run', as it is called ... (1858,Notes on Sheepfarming in NZ,7)

FULLER The dwelling-house is generally termed the Station'; while the land, the pasture of which is rented from the Government, is termed theRun' ... The term [`station'] is often applied collectively to represent the whole occupation. (1859,Five Years' Residence in New Zealand,147)

BUTLER Thus, a run of 20,000 acres will be worth 2,000l. (Feb 10, 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,iv/41)

2/54 When two or three adjoining runs are in one man's holding he must have as many flocks and establishments as runs to fulfil the exact letter of the regulations, which require stock to be on every run during the whole term of the licensee .... [sic] (Jul 3, 1863,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1960) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

MEREDITH I go out on the run, bring in the first mob of sheep I come across, and select one that is not too fat, generally a merino if I can find one. Most of the crossbreds would have [42] about an inch thick of fat on the ribs. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,41,1935 ed.)

NEAVE On the high runs, the snow is lying very deep, and a large number of sheep are snowed up in them, ... (1980,Land of Munros, The,56) [NOTES: 1877 May William Shirres Copybook in 1980 Neave The Land of Munros 56]

HOCKEN Under the original terms, land purchasers were entitled upon payment of an annual license fee of 10s. 6d. to depasture or run sheep and cattle upon such waste lands within the block as remained unappropriated. ... though Captain Cargill was then gazetted Commissioner of Crown Lands for the Otago block only, he received no definite instructions upon the subject of granting the runs. [139] The result was that he merely filed the applications for depasturage licenses as they were presented to him, whilst the applicants were left to pursue their further course as seemed best to them. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,138)

The stock on these high-country farms may graze in altitudes as high as about 1500 to 1800 metres, though most of the `runs' utilise areas up to about 900 m only (1974,NZ Agriculture,57)

run ... 61. (esp. in Australia and New Zealand) a tract of land for grazing livestock. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1010) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 668; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 426]]

BREMNER Run large area needed for early sheepfarming, often held on Crown Pastoral Lease before land was available for freehold. (1985,Woolscours of NZ,9)

I do not know the number of horses and oxen on the run. They roam over miles of country and are as wild as if they had never seen a man and many very savage. (Jan 22, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,26)

Draper ... and myself were on the run all day cutting out bullocks we succeeded in yarding about 60. It is very hard to cut out so many; ... When they are hot and savage they do not care for the stockwhip. (Mar 13, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,28)

The Government intends cutting up the Ormaglade run, in the Teviot district, of 28,000 acres, into four small grazing runs of 7000 acres each. (Apr 3, 1908,Wanganui Herald,7)

3 n. [3. (does following definition apply here, or with cits go to 1 above: an extensive grazing property (usu. in South Island tussock country))]

LADY BARKER We have no available bush on the Run. (1866,Station Life in NZ,62,1870 ed.)

They [friends] have been abusing me for not coming to stay with them ever since they started the run [Castle Hill]. (Jun 21, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,191,1950 ed.)

SWANTON We now leave the smaller class of sheep farm and come to the large runs' orstations', as they are called. (1892,Notes on NZ,93)

MULGAN Mark felt a real sympathy for some of the men and women out back in the high country - where runs ran right up to the glaciers (1934,Spur of Morning,236)

BEATTIE It is usually understood that in the early days, the word station' [qv.] denoted the owner's house and its immediate buildings, whilerun' meant the whole property .... (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,115)

run: station property on which sheep and cattle are grazed. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

NEWTON [gloss.] Run: a large grazing property. (1947,Wayleggo)

SCOTT The run was then taken up by Mrs. Margaret Preston ... of Longlands Station, ... and went with that station to Joseph Preston who held it until 1938 when it was divided. (1948,Run, Estate and Farm,65)

McLAGLAN A distant connection of mine had a run in a lonely place touching the upper reaches of the Wanganui River. (1965,Stethoscope & Saddlebags,184)

NEWTON Run: A large grazing property. (1966,Boss's Story, The,189)

McLINTOCK The back country runs have quite a vocabulary of their own ... Among these are the terms run or station, terms which the New Zealanders took over from Australia, ... (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679)

Run: an extensive grazing property usually in South Island tussock country. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,5)

run n. grazing area for sheep and cattle; (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),17)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Run. The area held as a station; includes the area under pastoral lease. Also refers to a period of work; the shearers divide the working periods of their days into runs. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,97)

3 v. (of news) to spread rapidly

HOGG The news like bush fire thro' the diggings ran. (1875,Lays and Rhymes,176)

4 v. [run like a hairy dog]

SLATTER I've just seen him running like a hairy dog all over Lancaster Park. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,127)

4 v. [run like a hairy goat]

SLATTER An it ran like a hairy goat an I did me chips. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,23)

TURN ER Even in this [passage from Slatter Gun in My Hand], there are two expressions with which I am not personally directly familiar, cat's bar, presumably ladies bar' and ran like a hairy goatran badly', an Australianism, recorded by Baker. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,120)

McGILL run like a hairy goat very slow or very fast; often of racehorse; eg Gordon Slatter's A Gun in My Hand: `It ran like a hairy goat an I did me chips [money].' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,95)

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,120) [NOTES: [see GOAT: transfer to here ?]]

4 n. ?possibly add here cattle-, sheep-run; dairy-run [one citation: dairy run]

WANTED, a PARTNER, sleeping or active, to take a share in a good Dairy Run, near a thriving town; ... (Feb 2, 1861,Otago Witness,10)

8 v. [run the ship]

It has been the custom for a good number of years for the Shipping Companies to select an experienced man from the ranks of the Union to act as Foreman, or what is known in waterside parlance as `running the ship' (Aug 3, 1912,NZ Truth,371/4/4)

8 v. [no entries]

9 v. [one unconnected citation]

Pitch the tent. (1933,Press, The) [NOTES: Acland]

run a banker¶

phr. (Rural) [braided or small rivers] to be filled bank to bank with water.

BELL Mr Couper found the Tukituki running a 'banker' and rising fast. (1967,Hawke's Bay Stations Scrapbook II,9)

BRUCE .. owing to heavy rain in the mountains, when they arrived at the Ashley River, it was running a banker. (1977,Life in the Hinterland of the South Island,40)

FORRESTER It was running a banker, and was impossible to ford on foot. (1983,Chopper Boys, The,114)

STACEY A few weedy, wool-blind hoggets held up proceedings and one, just to be awkward, staggered out onto a rock jutting out into the river which was running a banker. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,97)

run a charge¶

phr. to put a `brew' of liquid through (an illicit) still.

WILSON ... they proposed lighting the fire and letting me see them `run a charge.' (1944,Moonshine,94)

run a mile¶

n. a children's game

SUTTON-SMITH There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. West Coast: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; Wellington: Who Goes Round My Stone Wall, Beg o' My Neighbor, Bellahonie, Run a Mile, On and Off the Bridge, Here Come Two Nuns, Colours, Isaac and Rebecca. Scrag, Diabolo, Bumble Puppy, Homai, Fives; Auckland: My Fair Young Lady, Rushes and Reeds, Surrender the Tower, Walls, Ball Hopscotch, ball games, Solomon Says; Hawkes Bay: Wolf Wolf Go Home, Homai; Canterbury: Poor Old Tom, Rats and Rabbits and Rips, Steps, Skin the Snake, Steal a Peg, Toodle-em-Buck, The Gag; Golden Bay: Who's That Walking Round My House Tonight, I've Come to See Poor Mary Jane, Steps and Stairs, Creeping, Branding, O'Leary; Otago: Sir Roger de Coverley, Who's That Knocking at My Door. (1981,History of Children's Play,231)

run bait¶

n.

McDOWALL The fat shape of koara whitebait, their milkiness, and the fact that they tend to be more slimy than other whitebait, has resulted in them being called "jelly bait". Others know them as "run bait" because they start to run earlier after floods than other species. (1984,NZ Whitebait Book, The)

Run Book¶

n. [station hist]

WAITE It appears the Run Book in Dunedin was opened on September first 1852. -->nf OED. (1948,Pioneering in South Otago,38)

run bull¶

1 n. (Rural) a bull grazed on an extensive area with little attention.

NEWTON Their cattle also have an enviable reputation and they sell anything up to forty run bulls. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,185)

AXBEY No one lived permanently at the Ada, and the run bulls were confined in a large paddock with a high-wire fence. (1991,Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns,114)

run cattle¶

n. (See also run cow)

BEATTIE I climbed up to see some of the cattle, and run cattle are always wild, and found there were no planks on top only the railing. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,151)

RICHARDS It is also necessary to have a certain number of run-cattle on a sheep farm. They eat out any rank and tufty grass, weeds ... that are unpalatable to sheep. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,149)

1 n. (Rural) a store cattle beast used for breeding and grazing and seldom handled.

An appreciable shortage in run cattle is apparent. (Sep 1, 1925,NZ Farmer,1425)

MILLS ET AL Then if on the way home a paddock of dry sheep or run cattle requires looking at and perhaps shifting, they have the dogs with them to do the job. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,97)

MILLS ET AL run cattle, which apart from providing additional income, play an important role by regulating and controlling pastures in the best possible condition for sheep; and fattening cattle, usually grazed and finished off on heavier country. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,103)

ALLEN It had carried approximately 5,000 sheep as well as run cattle. (1980,Farm on the Wanganui River, A,18)

WAIRARAPA HEREFORD & SHORT-HORN STUD AND RUN CATTLE. (Apr 5, 1919,Poverty Bay Herald,10)

run country¶

1 n. (Rural) pastoral grazing land [usually high country.]

In some of the abandoned run country in Otago the ground was quite bare. (Dec 4, 1909,Tuapeka Times,4)

The aggressive nature of the brown-top is plainly seen throughout the run country, where it is a common exotic grass ... (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,99)

The small area of turnips grown on the run country (about 1,000 acres) is, of course, quite inadequate for the needs of such country. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,102)

STUDHOLME Late burning in itself is bad enough, but combined with bunny, it is often fatal to run country. (1940,Te Waimate,97)

.. too hilly to become, in parts, first-class sheep and run country. (Dec 5, 1940,NZ Farmer,25)

NEWTON .. although the run country is badly infested with manuka scrub, it is a good block. (1952,High Country Journey,179)

run cow¶

n.

POWDRELL Practical farmers sometimes put two calves on to one duffer cow, or to a run cow for five or six weeks ... (1920,Dairy Farming in NZ,42)

1 n. (Rural) a store or station cattle beast or one that is left grazing with little attention.

Run cows made from GBP11. 6/- to GBP11. 7/-. (Sep 1, 1949,NZ Farmer,24)

Run cows with calves at foot sold at GBP19 8/-. (Dec 20, 1951,NZ Farmer,45)

1800 ewes, 1000 hoggets, 170 run cows. (Sep 14, 1961,NZ Farmer,93)

NEWTON Besides the stud stock there are another 500 run cows ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,204)

SINCLAIR A run cow which broke from the railway yards at Taihape caused a vast amount more trouble. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,86)

Run cows generally in lower condition than last year. (Nov 13, 1975,NZ Farmer,7)

ASPINALL The station 'run' cows are left to return to their favourite areas in the East and West branches. (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,160)

run cray¶

n. a light-coloured crayfish

WILSON Fishermen often use the term `run crayfish' for light-coloured crayfish, with yellow being a more prominent colour than usual. These runcrays are either males or juvenile females, and they are usually potted on the outer edges of the rough bottom where it merges into sand, or on light rough bottom where the rock outcrops are small. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,41)

run crayfish¶

n. see cit.

WILSON Fishermen often use the term `run crayfish' for light-coloured crayfish, with yellow being a more prominent colour than usual. These run crays are either males or juvenile females, and they are usually potted on the outer edges of the rough bottom where it merges into sand, or on light rough bottom where the rock outcrops are small. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,41)

run down¶

v.

NOLAN Run down: to reduce the flow of water through a sluice box and to let the waste slowly clear itself prior to extracting the gold-bearing residues. (1983,Gold Fossicker's Handbook,113)

run for one's colours¶

phr. to serve a probationary period [gang slang]

In December, 1974, there were about 20 patch members and there were also a few `running for their colours' - serving a probationary period. (Jun 17, 1975,Dominion,3)

run house¶

1 n. (Rural) a homestead on a sheep or cattle run.

KERR They bought a farm down country near Duntroon, sold the run house and woolshed and a bit of land around it ... (2000,High Times in the High Country,162)

run in¶

v. (Rural) to muster (sheep)

NEWTON We wanted a mutton one night, and against my better judgment, I took Sam out to run in the killers. (1964,Straggle Muster,74)

v. of milking cows, to bring them into the milking shed [ca1940 Still used of bring cows to the bails at milking.]

He has to `run in' the cows by himself which takes a long time for sometimes they are feeding some little way from the homestead. (1889,Colonia,23)

RICHARDS Unfortunately in the afternoon we got ahead of the musterers, so the manager had to run in a mob of undagged cotty sheep that were being held until the cut out. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,130)

n. [[? omit]]

WAITT Akaroa is conveniently situated as a run in [for whaling vessels] (1856,Progress of Canterbury, NZ, The,14)

run like a hairy goat¶

phr. of persons, to run away quickly or suddenly; of motors, etc., to `run' badly, unevenly.

LETHBRIDGE `I'd been asleep. I went charging up that / face like a hairy goat, just in time to see you jokers starting the muster. (1971,Sunrise on the Hills,38)

FERNANDEZ Damn thing's [sc. a shearing motor] running like a hairy goat.' ...I suppose it's worn out,' said Bessie ... (1973,Tussock Fever,33)

DAVIS Ever since, she [a moped]'s going like the one big hairy goat. Crook benzine, that's the story. (1964,Watersiders,137)

phr. perform badly in a race

JOURNET Should Z [a horse] win his race he is said to have struck form. Should Z lose his race, especially when you have backed him, he is said to have run like a hairy goat, another foolish term as hairy goats are reputedly both agile and swift. (1954,Take My Tip,77)

SLATTER An [sic] it ran like a hairy goat an I did me chips (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,23)

TURNER ... ran like a hairy goat `ran badly', an Austral- ianism, recorded by Baker. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,120)

run like a redshank/like redshanks¶

phr.

We rode up, and received the first confirmation of our fears; they told us that no one would venture in with despatches, that the troops were driven clean off the field and left their dead and wounded. The expression used was "They ran like red shanks." (Aug 26, 1882,Taranaki Herald,2)

Dr. Findlay, who is nick-named the Government apologist, ran like a red shank until he got the ear of a reporter, and to him he confided his utter astonishment at such a change being made by a retired magistrate against his administration. (Nov 19, 1910,NZ Truth,282/1/2)

run of one's teeth¶

phr. rations, food [station]

BATHGATE If wet weather should come on .... everything would be stopped in the way of [shearing] work, while all hands would still require to have `the run of their teeth' (1881,Waitaruna,173)

I arranged to join him as a cadet .... at the cost of ten shillings a week and the `run of my teeth' (1888,Wakatipians,4)

run off¶

v. draft or direct some stock to a new paddock or pen.

NEWTON Anything gone in the mouth had been dotted and these were run off and penned on their own. (1949,High Country,117)

MILLS ET AL There may be 'strangers' in the mob. These he will pick up by their various earmarks and run off into a separate pen if available... (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,72)

LOUGHNAN run off: (v): to separate by the use of drafting gates. (1981,Glossary,69)

v. (of sheep) be worked successfully by a dog.

KERR I can see the way the sheep run off him. (2000,High Times in the High Country,14)

v. turn out stock on to paddocks.

When sheep are being fed on turnips, they should be run off on to grass at night. (1919,Wool in NZ,14)

TAIT Mr Hull had purchased 230 acres of sandhill country on the coast west of Waiuku, where forward conditioned cattle are 'run off' during the wettest part of the winter. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,127)

The hoggets are run off for the nights and weekends when they are grazed on pasture. (Mar 2, 1961,NZ Farmer,11)

While the ewes are on their winter sacrifice paddock they are run off daily for a two-hour feed on either grass or turnips. (Aug 13, 1970,NZ Farmer,38)

1 n. (Rural) a supplementary feed paddock for animals being fattened on crops.

PERRY .. it is always advisable to give them [lambs] a run off on to grass whilst they are on the rape. 71 A paddock with surplus grass, as a run off to the turnip paddock is quite good ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,70)

A run-off from the rape on to a grass pasture is also desirable. (Dec 20, 1928,NZ Journal of Agriculture,414)

EDGAR Hoggets which are wintered on turnips should be provided with a grass run-off. (1959,NZ Farmers' Veterinary Guide,164)

LOUGHNAN run off; a paddock used as a camp for sheep being grazed on turnips etc. and where they normally receive their dry rations such as hay. Cattle on supplementary feed will usually have a run-off too. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,69)

2 n. (Rural) a spell or period of time that stock can be temporarily placed on crop or pasture.

When feeding rape it is good practice to allow the lambs a run off on to a grass field. (Oct 1, 1926,NZ Farmer,1413)

In June they are put on ridged swedes with a run-off to young grass. [run-off] (Nov 8, 1951,NZ Farmer,60)

3 n. (Rural) a draft of animals away from the main flock or herd.

.. 'Will you take the line or a run off, asks the auctioneer, meaning 'Will you take them all, or part of them?' (Nov 4, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

LOUGHNAN run-off: stock counted straight out of a mob without drafting; the usual practice if the buyer does not want the whole line. A shrewd buyer will insist on the first run-off, this on the principle that the strongest animals take the lead. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,68)

run out¶

v. (Rural) [a sheepdog on a dog trial course] to make a move toward sheep.

The second dog, Sweep, ran out on a good cast to the right and took charge well. (Jul 2, 1923,NZ Farmer,951)

NEWTON It is instinctive for a heading dog to cast when running out. (1947,Wayleggo,153)

KERR 'John, it's taken most dogs three minutes to run out.' (2000,High Times in the High Country,158)

v. (Rural) [ post and batten splitting] to complete a split too soon with a short length or narrow width.

Posts which run out in the splitting and are short can be split into battens ... (Jul 2, 1923,NZ Farmer,927)

v. (Rural) [fencing] to feed out wire from a coil.

Mary had 'run out' the wire for him when he had put that first fence up. (Apr 29, 1932,NZ Dairy Exporter,69)

FISK Once the end strainers and angle posts are all in you are ready to run out a wire to get to a line. (1996,Practical Smallfarming,13)

FISK Real fencers seem to prefer running out all wires at once. (1996,Practical Smallfarming,15)

v.

BOWEN This way the comb enters nicely on the off leg and it takes little time to run out. (1955,Wool Away!,26)

NEWTON Run-out: The act of running out to head sheep. Outrun - the manner in which the dog runs out. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,169)

run plan¶

1 n. (Rural) a long-term plan formed by Catchment Board personnel and property owners for high-country land under ecological threat.

JOHNSON Technical proposals on land retirement schemes for tussock grassland properties are known as 'run plans' ... (1970,Soil Conservation and Land Retirement,2)

JOHNSON .. a further 600 acres has been oversown by the runholder independently of the run plan. (1970,Soil Conservation and Land Retirement,18)

DOMINY Revealing initiative, the "Downs" runholder and his lawyer decided to form a Land Company in 1969, the year before the pastoral lease was to be renewed, and to implement a run plan. (2001,Calling the Station Home,107)

DOMINY A run plan based on the report was drawn up by the Catchment Board ... The run plan and the development scheme were worked out to carry 3,000 stock units. (2001,Calling the Station Home,108)

run rings around/round¶

phr. to overcome or surpass (a person) easily; to easily better (a person) at; to beat hollow [ca1900 (well pre-WW1); orig. Aust/NZ? now in UK dictionaries unlabelled]

MORRIS Run Rings Round to run round: to beat out and out. A picturesque bit of Australian slang. One runner runs straight to the goal, the other is so much better that he can run round and round his competitor, and yet reach the goal first. [1891] (1898,Austral English,390)

BAKER [The Australasian] to run rings around a person, which can be used in both literal and figurative senses ... [On] January 3, 1940, the version to make rings round was used in a leader of the London Times. ... There is every reason to suspect that it came from the shearing shed ... to ring a shed and to be a ringer. (1941,NZ Slang,38)

TURNER A new chum ... would ... hear such colloquial expressions as to run rings round `to excel easily'. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,51)

RICHARDS My new [95] friends warned me that he would `run rings' round the lot of us. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,94)

run sheep¶

n. (See cf. paddock sheep)

The sheep from Otago were principally grass fed, and too few run sheep were received to form any conclusion as regards the respective merits of the sheep in the three Provinces. (Oct 13, 1871,North Otago Times,2)

9548 sheep shorn, 139 bales pressed. I think sheep and wool will be up to last year; run sheep much better. Ewe and paddock sheep not so good. Lice in wool and [dust from] ploughed ground all through Ewe mob. All the paddock sheeps wool must be scoured. (Nov 15, 1889,Chudleigh Diary,368,1950 ed.)

run station¶

n. (Rural) an early dwelling on a large land holding.

BARRER They drove with their goods in a bullock dray, taking with them twenty head of cattle and three horses, besides the six bullocks. At night, they camped at run stations whenever possible, and at other times they made up a bed under the dray. (1939,Brave Days: Pioneer Women of New Zealand,268)

run the bottles on¶

phr. to provide drinking water during a rugby game

It was great to have Filo running the bottles on as well. (Oct 23, 2000,Dominion,28)

run the cutter¶

phr. to procure beer in a vessel (poss. orig. on the sly) for drinking off the licensed premises, often after hours.

He runs the cutter between a brothel in Frederick-Street and a nearby hotel', remarked Tec. Cassells of a crook in the S.M.'s court during the week.Running the cutter' is a variant of the Sydney expression running the rabbit' and the Yankee ones ofrushing the growler' or `the can' Which all mean the same thing i.e. fetching beer in a vessel. (Dec 22, 1906,NZ Truth,79/5/8)

I used to `run the cutter' with a dish From Side Street where we set the Daily Sun. (Aug 1933,Oreti Anthology, The,12)

[Cartoon of Jack Lovelock running with a rigger of beer in his arms, captioned] Jack Lovelock `Running the cutter' (1937,Otago Capping Book,25)

BENNETT Running the cutter (i.e. obtaining liquor for people who cannot get it themselves) is used without any appreciation of its original meaning of smuggling. (1843,English as it is spoken in NZ,89)

The party [of railway track layers] is provided with ... a jigger to maintain communications with the tunnel-mouth - and to `run the cutter' for the morning lunch and afternoon tea which is brewed outside. (Feb 4, 1953,Evening Post,8)

BIDDY PURCELL . `Pat [her husband] used to run the cutter when he was at St. Pats College in the 1930s' [= bring in illicit booze] (Oct 5, 1972,Personal Communication) [NOTES: ca1972 Oct 5 Havelock Biddy Purcell, publican's wife]

BAXTER And Horse had run the cutter down to the pub to bring back three gallon jars of beer. (1962,Horse,20,1958 ed.) [NOTES: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Mills of God) 20]

CHARLES67 The expression running the cutter' has its origins in the whaling days. ...Grog shops' sprang up wherever ships called regularly ... When a ship lay at anchor, most of the crew would go ashore and an anchor watch' would be left aboard. Very often, some thirsty soul ... wouldborrow' the cutter and slip ashore for rum ... This was running the cutter'. Later, in days when some areas were under prohibition, the term was used for the job of going to the nearest licensed hotel for liquor. ... And the driver comes in and breasts up to the bar./ He says,Give me a jar and a couple of crates,/ For I am running the cutter tonight for me mates!'/... `We are fresh out of beer,/So that's why I'm here,/ Running the cutter tonight./ (1981,Black Billy Tea)

run up¶

v. to travel to the source of (a creek)

BARRINGTON Up by daylight to run this creek up. Reached its Sources that afternoon. (Dec 31, 1863,Diary) [NOTES: 1863 Dec 31 Barrington Diary in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 395]

run, the¶

n.

The diggers being of migratory habit, it is exceedingly difficult to identify the individual culprit, and if caught he invariably claims a right to fire what he calls "the run". (Jan 29, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,15)

run-bred¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of store stock] born and raised on a station or grazing run. (See station-bred)

Run bred cattle are also in favour at the moment. (Oct 6, 1938,NZ Farmer,42)

run-of-the-land¶

adj. (Rural) ordinary or utilitarian [the NZ farmer's equivalent of run-of-the-mill].

From the late 60s and early 70s the emphasis moved away from those pampered highly-fed cattle to more of a run-of-the-land animal. (May 31, 2002,Dominion,31)

run-off¶

n. (Rural) (dog trials) a dog's final run.

In the run-off which he won, he struck three spirited sheep. (Aug 2, 1951,NZ Farmer,20)

Runoff - at Island and National Championships, the seven dogs in the call at the end of the first round run off for the title - aggregate of two runs. (Dec 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,45)

I feel sorry for Don as in both run-offs he was unable to complete. (Aug 15, 1984,NZ Journal of Agriculture,21)

.. he and his Hinkle made the yarding runoff at this year's Nationals. [runoff, run off] (Sep 1985,NZ Journal of Agriculture,48)

1 n. (Rural) a grazing area away from a main run or property; an off-run.

Run-off: an area of land, perhaps separated from the main area where young stock or dry (non-lactating) animals are run (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,5)

.. they [cows] should not have more than an hour or two a day on the crop and they should have hay fed to them on the grass paddock used as a run-off. (May 20, 1933,Hawera Star,7)

A winter run-off can be of tremendous assistance to the satisfactory management of soils which poach ... (May 1957,NZ Journal of Agriculture,481)

Dairy farmers with rough runoffs are faced with a difficult problem. (Feb 1966,NZ Journal of Agriculture,63)

About the end of July the cows were taken from the run-off to the home farm and run as a springing mob. (Nov 1975,NZ Dairy Exporter,11)

FEARON Reg had bought the block as a run-off for cattle, in the hopes that the recently developed manuka blight would destroy the young manuka on the block. (1980,Te Wharau,51)

They lease a property from Mrs Brown's brother. "We use it as a sort of run-off." (Mar 29, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17)

Bareland - runoff situated approximately 18km south of Waipukurau. An ideal runoff for both sheep or cattle. (Aug 18, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,26)

run-off paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a grazing area adjacent to rotationally grazed or set stocking areas that is only occasionally used.

Press (Acland Gloss) Nov 25 Run off - paddock used with turnips or green feed on which the sheep may camp and get what extra feed they can. (Nov 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),25)

.. crops are fed off in breaks, lambs are not allowed over areas already grazed, and heavily-contaminated run-off pastures are avoided. (May 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,492)

STEVENS Although a grass run-off, or hay - or both - is usually provided ... (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,I 19)

GASCOIGNE we drove the remainder of the flock back to the run-off paddock and then rode home for the knives. [run-off pasture] (1965,From the Top of a Hill,125)

run-on¶

adj. describes the team that commences a game

Isaia Toeva was stunned to hear his name in the run-on XV. ... After just on full NPC match for Auckland, the shy Samoan-born fulback is still getting over the shock of being named in the 35-man squad - let alone the run-on side - to play Scotland on Sunday (NZT). (Nov 25, 2005,NZ Herald,D9)

Former All Black captain Taine Randall and Otago teammate Pita Alatini have been replaced.. in the run-on team for Sunday's rugby test against France. (Nov 9, 2000,Dominion,1)

run-out¶

n. (Rural) a paddock or pasture area where the feed has been eaten out or died or where reversion has taken place.

On the farm of Mr G.F.Hughes at Springston, cereals and grass were overdrilled into a runout towards brown top reversion. [runout] (Dec 31, 1964,NZ Farmer,8)

1 adj. (Rural) [of land] spent through over-grazing and lack of replenishment with fertiliser etc.

We can also resuscitate run-out pasture far better, quicker and cheaper than by re-ploughing and resowing. (Apr 1, 1944,Dairy Exporter (NZ),24)

Not many people can be making a more praiseworthy effort to rehabilitate a run-out, badly reverted farm than Mr Bob Wech ... (Dec 2, 1954,NZ Farmer,3)

GORDON Run-out paddocks are ploughed up, put into swedes, to be fed off the following winter, and then put down in both grass and oats. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,182)

1 n. (Rural) [dog trials] the initial part of a course for heading dogs.

LILICO A perfect run-out should be a circle all the way from the start till he gets round behind the sheep. (1919,Breeding and Training of Sheep Dogs,18)

Crutchley's Rae lost points in the run-out for taking a zig-zag course, but headed and lifted well. (Jul 5, 1951,NZ Farmer,32)

It was considered by many to be about the longest run-out in the country, and the pull also is far from easy. It's a run-out where a dog can easily go wrong. (Mar 9, 1967,NZ Farmer,37)

The runout went across a long flat then into a face that had clumps of Matagouri across and up it. (Jul 15, 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60)

GORDON The orthodox run out or cast on a dog trial hill is on the triallist's right of the sheep. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,48)

run-owner¶

n.

Those Wanganui cricketers who formed the team that visited Nelson in 1873 will regret the news contained in the following telegram from Nelson dated Friday last:- "Yesterday afternoon an inquest was held at Wakefield on the body of Melville Sellon, who was a runowner, and well known a few years since as a crack cricketer ..." (Apr 26, 1880,Wanganui Herald,2)

D'AVIDGOR ... the run-owners are [73] clamouring for more ships, though they grumble at the average price of 4-1/2d. a pound, which is all their mutton realizes in London. (1888,Antipodean Notes,72)

BEATTIE When I first read this inscription [in the Memorial Church, Cave], the word sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term forrunholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., flock owners,'flock masters,' pastoralists,'run holders,' run owners,'sheep owners,' sheep holders,'sheep masters,' squatters,'station holders,' station owners,'stock holders,[sic] and stock owners.' The wordsheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,11)

Stories of all sorts have come to light, one being that he, himself a very large run-owner, organised the squatter class to reduce the wages of sheperds by importing Pacific Island labour; but the Islander did not take to sheperding, and the attempt failed. (Jun 10, 1907,Evening Post,2)

Jack was advised that it would be to his future benefit, probably, if he could obtain employment on a station; and among his letters of introduction was one to Mr John Campbell, a small runowner at a station some five miles or so from Riversdale, which, as everyone knows, is on the Gore-Lumsden line of railway. (Dec 21, 1893,Otago Witness,7)

run-through¶

n. (Rural) a dipping/spraying race.

He hasn't yet found a 100% effective dip and uses a run-through. (Sep 10, 1970,NZ Farmer,35)

n. type of milking shed

LOCKE It was a "run-through" type with gates that opened for the cows to leave the bails and move straight into the paddock. (1984,Kauri & The Willow, The,148)

1 n. (Rural) a race that runs alongside and parallel to another, for ease of access between pens in sheepyards.

RIDDOLLS The run-through, which consists of a long alleyway, parallel with the drafting race, is a useful adjunct in any set of yards. (1958,Farm Engineering,341)

runa¶

n.

HOOKER Runa, Lindsay. Rumex sp. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

COWAN Boiled flax-root water poured on the wounds, and also dock-root (runa), well scraped and boiled, were our favourite remedies for gunshot and bayonet wounds. (1922,NZ Wars, The,2/26,1983 ed.)

WILSON Rumex flexuosus NATIVE DOCK ...Runa ... Leaves brown-green. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,164)

runanga¶

n. a tribal corporate body to manage iwi affairs [ORIGIN: Maori]

She says the runanga has accumulated funds of between $6 million and $6.5 million... Established under its own act of Parliament, after a robust consultation period of 18 months, the Ngati Porou runanga includes 20 trustees who are elected by postal vote every three years. (Apr 12, 2004,Dominion Post,B5)

[Ngai Tahu's] development arm had a host of programmes, as did the 18 papatipu (local) runanga, through which development money was also channelled. (Sep 28, 1997,Sunday Star Times,A6)

n. an assembly, council. [ORIGIN: Maori, ?divide into purely Maori contexts and those where the word is used in Pakeha administrative contexts]

It appears that the natives there are beyond all restraint. They have broken loose altogether, laugh at the idea of a Commissioner coming among them, refuse to suffer even the forms of enquiry, and use language so outrageous concerning the Queen, the Governor, and the white runanga as to be without a parallel in the country up to the present time. (Jan 10, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,2)

DIEFFENBACH Runanga - assembly, council (1843,Travels in NZ,2/834) [NOTES: NZ (Dictionary NZ Language)]

This arrangement was proposed by Potata's runanga. (Jun 21, 1858,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/411,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (J.Morgan)]

RUTHERFORD That the native runangas, or councils of the tribes, should ... be recognised by the Government ... (1949,Selected Documents,108k) [NOTES: 1860 May 12 W. Martin Memorandum to Governor Gore Browne in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 108k]

BUDDLE That no European Magistrate shall have jurisdiction within native boundaries, but all disputes shall be settled by the runanga. (1860,Maori King Movement,6)

At 9 a.m. the different runangas were called out, armed, and marched two deep round the flagstaff twice ... (Apr 6, 1861,Otago Witness,6)

RUTHERFORD It is the desire of the Queen, and this also is the thought of Governor Grey and of the runanga of the Pakehas, that the Maoris should also do for themselves as the Europeans do. (1949,Selected Documents,115) [NOTES: 1861 Dec 8 Govenor Grey to the Duke of Newcastle -->transf = General Assembly, ?Legislative Council in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 115]

(1971,Documents and Speeches,137) [NOTES: (1861) 1971 Documents and Speeches 137 quoting A to J's 1861 [=District Council]]

... on one occasion [in the 1850s] during the sittings of the General Assembly, the outside of the house was beseiged by crowds of Natives, listening and wondering what the white people inside could possible be doing, and whether they were holding a secret meeting or runanga to kill the Maories! He [Mr. Rogan] remarks that at this time the Maories first adopted the term runanga,' the termkomiti' having previously been used by them in respect to deliberative meetings. (Aug 23, 1862,Otago Witness,3)

(Mar 8, 1863,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/29,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond) [SEE HUI: ?Pakeha context]]

MOSER A few years back we used to hear a meeting of the tribes simply termed a korero', atalk', or a ko-miti', acommittee', and it is only lately that our ears have been regaled with the high sounding term, `runanga'. (1863,Mahoe Leaves,28)

GORST Village Runangas were chosen by the New Zealand Ministry as the foundation on which the `new institutions' were to be built. (1864,Maori King, The,248)

MEADE The runanga ... was assembled at the great pah today This plan of having native magistrates and runangas, or councils, composed of them and the teachers, originated with Wanganui. (Dec 21, 1864,Ride Through Disturbed Districts) [NOTES: 1864 Dec 21 Meade Ride through Disturbed Districts in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 433]

TAYLOR The result of a grand runanga was embodied in a brief and highly figurative letter written to all the tribes. (1868,Past and Present of NZ,121)

GORST ... the Waikato district was very especially under the jurisdiction of the Maori King and his Runanga. Ibid. 210 The supreme authority, legislative and judicial resided in the village Runanga. Ibid. 211 ... a official Report of Mr Turton. . . a magistrate in Waikato, made in 1861 ... `The Maori Court; or Runanga,was opened. Old Riwai sat as judge. The case, one of Koreroteka (slander) was introduced, and argued by two young men as roias (lawyers)' . . (1908,New Zealand Revisited,1)

COWAN This runanga consisted of Rewi Maniapoto (the tumuaki, or head of the council), his ... cousins ... and several other chiefs. (1922,NZ Wars, The,1/184)

BAUCKE (1928,Where the White Man Treads,33)

runanga, assembly; council; so, whare-runanga, meeting-house. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

runanga: council, assembly. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

SINCLAIR Grey and the New Premier, William Fox, set about introducing in Maori districts a system of `indirect rule' such as the Stafford ministry had advocated in 1858. Maori runanga (assemblies) in the various districts were to recommend to the Governor the laws they required. He could introduce them by Order-in-Council without seeking parliamentary assent. Ibid., 302 [Maori glossary] runanga Assembly (1959,History of New Zealand,132)

No more [land] should be sold to Europeans without the consent of the federated tribes, and Maori disputes should be settled by their own runangas. (1960,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/139)

IHIMAERA Here [in Turanga, c1851], particularly, the native council, the runanga, was in control of Pakeha trading, and it set the price of products, not the Pakeha. b. a meeting with (1986,Matriarch, The,68)

Mr Rolleston held a runanga [meeting] of the Hau haus. (Jan 27, 1868,Chudleigh Diary,214,1950 ed.)

Mr Tau has not released details of specific locations, but Ngai Tahu members, runanga (local councils) and the tribe own land across the South Island... (Jun 6, 2006,Dominion Post,A8)

It is fair to say the runanga (Maori council) is open to working with us to make sure we can continue to provide the 24-hour learning and boarding school concept in the best way. (Nov 28, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A3)

In the absence of authentic tribal structures such as runanga, trust boards have, in recent years, expanded their functions to include lobbying Parliament on a wide range of political issues. (Dec 1992,Metro,148)

Pursuant to the provisions of the New Zealand Public Health and Disability Act 2000, the following meeting of the Maori Health Runanga is notified for the month of November 2005. (Oct 26, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,11)

"You may go to any Maori region, there's a runanga or trust. That didn't use to be the case. Runanga have the physical resourses and the language, whereas the kohanga trust doesn't have the localised capacity." (Apr 9, 2005,Dominion Post,E3)

A great native runanga will be held at Galatea, Bay of Plenty, in a few days respecting the sale of land to the Government. (May 9, 1874,Evening Post,2)

'Right,' said Maria. 'It's time to educate your Maori friends. I'll offer a cookery school down at the runanga.' (2003,Huia 5: Contemp. Maori Fiction,27)

He began attending runanga meetings at Takahanga in the early 1990s and was elected a trustee in 1994. (Jul 29, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

Over the past five years about $10 million has gone into the runanga. (1995,Mana,No. 10 : 65)

The young officer's costume was as primitive as his river boat -a cabbage-tree hat, a Crimean shirt, and a kilt mat of woven flax belted round his waist. (Nov 1937,NZ Railways Magazine,18)

Te Waka.. paddled three miles up the river.. where the Kingite runanga, a Council of the district chiefs, was sitting. (Nov 1937,NZ Railways Magazine,18)

On the Runanga, from 1928, I had the privilege fof hearing from the sons of the men who had actually signed the document [sc. the Treaty] (Aug 11, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

Others signed on behalf of waka (canoe confederations), trust boards and runanga (multi-tribal councils). (Feb 1993,Metro,126)

2 n. a house or place of assembly, a meeting house

HARPER After service they [Maoris] provide dinner for me in their `Runanga' or Social Hall, a low long wooden room, (Feb 5, 1868,Letters from Gunner 7/516,126,1914 ed.)

REISCHEK The baskets were bound together with strings of flax, and piled up in separate heaps to a height of about 15 feet on the free places before the meeting-house (runanga). (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,148,1933 ed.)

SEDDON ... and then to write sitting down on the floor of a Maori runanga and without table, chair or other convenience to record word by word a series of rapidly delivered translated speeches. (1969,Seddons, The,63)

runanga house¶

n. meeting house (Maori whare runanga)

They accordingly opposed the passage of the carts, and when he succeeded in getting two of these by, they rushed upon all four, seized all the goods, and carried them into their runanga house, Te Ika-roa-a-Maui. (Oct 4, 1862,Taranaki Herald,2)

The Hon. Messrs Bryce and Rolleston are here. The former meets the natives at Runanga House re certain land claims at Piako. (Mar 21, 1882,North Otago Times,2)

KENNEDY The building was formerly a Runanga, or meeting-house of the Hau-Hau rebels ... (1876,Colonial Travel,252)

) ... each people should retain its whakapapa and korero and not be led astray by the versions of other tribes. But the marae and runanga house discussions between hosts and distinguished visitors must have resulted in a fair amount of interpolation. (May 30, 1931,Na To Hoa Aroha,2/152,1987 ed.) [NOTES: Ngata]

GRACE they assisted him to re-robe, and led him to their runanga-house, treating him with every consideration. (1899,Sketch of the NZ War,2)

[S.I. use] ... the tang ... lasted for several days ... the remains laid [sic] in state in the runanga house at Tairooa [sic] Pah. (Aug 19, 1905,NZ Truth,9/5/6)

These will have to be revived in the carvings of the many runanga houses projected throughout the North. (Jun 11, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/87) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

... Matuahu - Te Kooti's most important pa where he had his runanga [31] council (house) but which was found abandoned. (1983,Land of the Mist,30)

Early on the morning of the 26th, the British ensign was seen flying in front of the Runanga house, and the expression on every face of the assembly was that of pleasurable excitement. (Apr 22, 1862,Hawke's Bay Herald,2)

The carvings for the runanga house and various whares having been prepared in Rotoroa. (Sep 1, 1910,Poverty Bay Herald,5)

At Okahu, a runanga house has been erected. (Feb 1, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,15)

Runangan¶

adj. Geol. classification

These collections are especially important as this sequence is the type of the Runangan Stage, and also contains the Whaingaroan hypostratotype. (Mar 1986,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,71/45)

The northern three quarters of the peninsular is underlain by undeformed, northeast-dipping, massive to crudely bedded glauconitic sandstone (Ruatangata Sandstone, Te Kuiti Group, Runangan-early Whaingaroan) known from drillholes to be over 129 m and possibly up to 300 m thick (Fig. 2; Ferrar 1925 p. 43). (Aug 1989,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,85/19)

runanganui¶

n. a general council [ORIGIN: Maori] (See runanga)

And so it happened that Sharples spent most of the 1980s chairing both the Ngati Kahungunu runanganui (overall council) and the Hoani Waititi Marae committee, dashing between Hawkes Bay and West Auckland, all the while working for Maori Affairs and raising a family. (Dec 2004,North & South,69)

rung-in¶

adj. substituted unexpectedly or at short notice (cf. ring in v., ring-in n.)

Fanning They are ...disgusted at seeing a `rung-in' man in the place which they had been fitting themselves to fill in many a hard battle. (1910,Players and Slayers,45)

rungateeda¶

n. (See rangatira)

rungatyeeda¶

n. (See rangatira)

runhold¶

n. [Jim writes: Not recorded in DNZE in Acland's sheep station glossary.]

BURDON I shot a mob of eight on Hull's runhold. (1996,Hunting for DOC,15)

1 n. (Rural) a grazing property.

BURDON Access was through a runhold in the back of Springfield (1994,Hunting for a Buck,15)

BURDON I shot a mob of eight on Hull's runhold. (1996,Hunting for DOC,120)

runholder¶

n. owner (occas. manager) of a stock-run or station [(cf the various (near) synonyms: flock-owner, pastoralist, Sheep-farmer, sheep-king, squatter, station- owner, stockholder, Stockowner, woolgrower, etc) [AND spec comb ru@n4 1863]

Apparently the runholder has only to petition for large blocks of the choicest agricultural land, and they are granted forthwith, but should the adjoining runholders follow the example of the holder 327 (and in common justice they have an equal right to the same privilage - viz., free-selection before survey), the land that will be left to be dealt with for settlement when the leases of the runs fall in will be of inferior quality. (May 13, 1882,Otago Witness,12)

HURSTHOUSE Pastoral lands are the wild grazing lands ... leased ... for a term of years under a deed termed a `run licence,' to the emigrant who, embarking on pastoral pursuits, becomes what is indifferently termed a run-holder, sheep-farmer, flock-master, or Squatter. (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/512)

... the month's grace customarily allowed to defaulting runholders by the land Office had elapsed, ... (Jul 1, 1857,Lyttelton Times,6)

He the prince of all the squatters,/ Largest holder of runholders:- (1866,Canterbury Rhymes,61) [NOTES: 1858 Feb in 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 61]

FULLER the runholder ... . (1859,Five Years' Residence in New Zealand,162)

George and I started early ... with all the D brand cattle on the run. They belong to Deans the oldest runholder in Canterbury. (Sep 22, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,59,1950 ed.)

GRIFFITHS It is absolutely necessary for a runholder to wait long enough to learn what will be the best site for his head station. (1971,King Wakatip,98) [NOTES: 1863 Feb W.G. Rees in 1971 Griffiths King Wakatip 98]

BUTLER Every [Canterbury] run-holder has a preemptive right over 250 acres round his homestead, and 50 acres round any other buildings he may have upon his run. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,viii/115)

The runholders, squatters, sheepfarmers, or whatever else they may be called ... (1865,Evening Post,1/26/2)

NEAVE Dear Mother, Your son is at last a runholder. I have bought a run ... (May 20, 1865,Letter) [NOTES: 1865 May 20 Neave letter in 1981 Anderson Both Sides of the River 53]

But then one third of the runholders have had to do the same. (Jun 3, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,188,1950 ed.)

T.S.GRACE Runholders of a certain stamp will not thank me for this. (Jun 1868,Journal,193) [NOTES: 1868 June T.S.Grace Journal in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 193]

KENNAWAY ... and as time passed, and gave the run- holders power to smooth [sic] them away, the roughings and campings gradually ceased, and the life bettered every day, . (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,224)

VOGEL The tenants of the waste lands, or `runholders' were allowed a right of pre-emption. (1875,Official Handbook of NZ,128)

HOCKEN I `cooeed' for a long time, and when I had given up all hope Mr.Clapcott, the runholder, kindly came across for me, ... and made me comfortable for the night. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,150)

Boundary disputes between adjoining runholders are settled by arbitration under the direction of the Land Board, ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,73)

PERRY For these reasons it usually pays a runholder best in the long run to breed up his own flock ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,92)

Run holder.- Squatter, station owner, or (recent) owner of a small grazing run. This or stock owner was the proper designation of a squatter in the early days. (C.) (Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

MARSH They were the wool-growers, the run-holders, the sheep-cockies, the back-countrymen. (1945,Died in the Wool,12)

MILLER There is the ...runholder and more important station owner; there is the cow cocky, the gold miner ... the Public Works raceman ... (1946,There Was Gold,13)

BEATTIE [In 1851 a number of Australian squatters' came over and took up runholding] Over here [in Canterbury the Australiansquatters'] were called runholders. ... [11] see SHEEPMEN... [11] When I first read this inscription [in the Memorial Church, Cave], the word sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term forrunholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., flock owners,'flock masters,' pastoralists,'run holders,' run owners,'sheep owners,' sheep holders,'sheep masters,' squatters,'station holders,' station owners,'stock holders,[sic] and stock owners.' The wordsheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,10)

(`Central Otago') [Regulations] legalized at that time [1856], allowed land outside the original Otago Block to be bought for grazing-runs at a low cost. (Runholders were allowed 80 acres for the homestead block with 10 acres for each outstation.) (1948,Our Own Country,135) [NOTES: 1948 Our Own Country (from Korero, AEWS magazine) 135]

SINCLAIR The sheep farmer needed considerable initial capital, not to buy land, ... but to buy sheep, and if he were not the original run-holder, to purchase the `goodwill' of a sheep run. (1959,History of New Zealand,91)

OLIVER Sheep brought the runholders and later the station-owners. The runholders owned only the sheep which they pastured on great stretches of leased land; ... (1963,Story of New Zealand, The,107)

TOMLINSON The early run-holders brought their sheep down for shearing to what (1968,Remembered Trails,35)

McNAUGHTON Jim, the runholder, persuaded Bluey to stay on and give a hand to lamb the paddock ewes. (1970,Tat,89)

run holder: A run holder is the LEASE HOLDER on a cattle or sheep station when the government actually owns the land. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,86)

BREMNER Runholder usually men of education and capital who took up Crown Land for sheepfarming - `squatter'. (1985,Woolscours of NZ,9)

SHERWOOD The words flew, and enriched Celia's [an English visitor's] vocabulary. Duck shoving' was the local name for buck-passing between government departments. AQueen Street farmer' was a city slicker who owned land or stock for tax-fiddle reasons. Skite' anddrongo' were terms of abuse. A cow-cockie' was a dairy farmer and inferior for some reason to arunholder' concerned only with sheep. A `piker' was a faint-hearted person who gave up the fight too soon, ... (1985,Botanist at Bay)

STUDHOLME The run-holders were hard,' continued Mr Carrodus,but times were hard too. (1985,Coldstream,125)

runholder n. NZ & Austral. owner or manager of sheep or cattle run. (1968,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,668) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

OGONOWSKA-COATES Runholder. Station owner (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,97)

First, let an impartial estimate of all the pasturage be made (as to the estimate contained in your leading article, I can only say "Credeat Judaeus Apella," or, - a Wairau runholder may believe it but I can't), however, I should imagine the smaller the pasturage, the more reason for its equitable and economical distribution. (Apr 17, 1852,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,31)

1 n. (Rural) a person owning or leasing a pastoral holding [usually large and stocked with run sheep or cattle.]

HURSTHOUSE .. the emigrant who, embarking on pastoral pursuits, becomes what is indifferently termed a run-holder, sheep-farmer, flock-master, or Squatter. (1857,Hutchinsons of New Zealand, The,II)

Every run-holder has a pre-emptive right over 250 acres round his homestead, and 50 acres round any other buildings he may have upon his run. (1860,BLANK ENTRY,95) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

The large runholder is losing money. (Apr 1908,NZ Farmer,320)

Already three hundred [heifers] have been sent from Stratford to a Canterbury run-holder who is cutting up his sheep run into milking farms and putting on sharemilkers. (Jun 4, 1910,Hawera Star,4)

STUDHOLME Runholders later reduced this trouble [woolblindness] by using open-faced rams. (1940,Te Waimate,119)

ROBERTS & TURNER NZ High The dream many young station hands have of eventually becoming run-holders themselves is unlikely to be realised today ... (1983,NZ High Country Four Seasons,16)

ASPINALL Burning off has for many years past been a tool of management, used by runholders and graziers ... (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,192)

Mr Brown (48) is runholder of the 11,000 ha Glenthorne Station ... [run-holder] (Aug 1, 1996,NZ Farmer,05)

runholders' disease¶

1 n. (Rural) alcoholism.

ANGUS One early observer wrote of a shepherd who 'took to rum in pannikins, which soon finished him'; alcoholism was the 'runholders' disease' and 'dram drinking' and 'shouting' were common. (1981,Aspiring Settlers,70)

runholding¶

n. [aka run holding, run-holding]

But by that exemption two things would be done which were not desirable: the stockowner would be encouraged to maintain as long as possible the tenure of mere run-holding which was exempted; and the cultivator would be deterred from going to settle in a pastoral district. (Jan 18, 1854,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,3)

Dr Featherson has been forced by the pressure from without to take the matter in hand. He started on Monday to attend a Native meeting in the runholding portion of the Wairarapa, and when passing through the west district he was hissed by the Taita Volunteers who had just been dismissed from parade. (Aug 29, 1863,Taranaki Herald,2)

I have asked the proprietor of the Independent to allow me about two columns on Saturday to answer, in my own name, his conveniently anonymous champion of the imaginary "run-holding aristocracy." (Feb 24, 1870,Evening Post,2)

In the majority of instances, the former lessees re-purchased, and where this was not the case the purchasers belonged to the runholding class. (Mar 1, 1882,Grey River Argus,2)

BEATTIE ... Hopkinson was a Swede who left his mark on Otago runholding annals ... Ibid.117 ... in the fifties he early became aware of the efforts of the runholding class to open up the backblocks .. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,92)

(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,10) [NOTES: [see RUNHOLDER]]

McLAGLAN In a well-to-do run-holding area were a popular doctor pair, Dr C. and his wife Dr Helen C. (she was even more popular then he). (1965,Stethoscope & Saddlebags,130)

Other evidences of precaution were forthcoming in the facts that a "departmental" short-hand writer was in attendance, that the typewriter manipulator had been changed, and that Lawyer H. D. Acland, of the runholding family, was present to watch Col. MacGibbon's interests. (Jan 19, 1918,NZ Truth,5)

The largest run-holding company in the colony could only be fined GBP1 a day for overdue rent, and yet a hard-working, struggling settler on 3000 acres, with only GBP15 rent for the half-year, is to be fined GBP31 on GBP15 rent 31 days overdue. (Nov 16, 1893,Otago Witness,20)

1 n. (Rural) the leasing or ownership of a large pastoral property. [aka run holding, run-holding]

MCLAUCHLAN Runholding held up economically until well into the 1860s. (1981,Farming of NZ,90)

runi-runi¶

n.

... this reminiscence reminds me, too, of the variety of bush berries which we children would eat [in Carterton in the 1860s] - the white pine berries, the runi-runi, and ti-toke, these last very much resembling a raspberry, with a black seed on the head of it. (Feb 10, 1921,Quick March,13)

runner¶

n. an informant

Mike Moore used to say, 'He's a runner.' That's an old union term, and it means someone who will always go to the boss. Didn't matter who it was, David Lange, Mike, Geoffrey Palmer. (May 19, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

n. the small intestine of a sheep

It came out in a sausage skin case ... It was explained that the matter removed from the `runners' or plain guts from the abattoir created the atmospheric unpleasantness,... (Oct 19, 1912,NZ Truth,382/1/5)
