MACDONALD From certain intestines sausage casings are prepared, and in 1887 Henry Berry & Co. contracted to purchase ... clean runners', after which various firms carried on the business of doing the finishing for market. <i>Ibid.</i> 72 An important by-product is sausage casings, which are made from several parts of the gut, the main source being the very long small intestine of the sheep. This, in the untreated state, is called arunner'. (1957,Canterbury Frozen Meat Company,69)

n. a fugitive [(? West Coast diggings)]

DILKE These cheerful prisoners are for the most part `runners' - sailors who have broken their agreements in order to get upon the diggings. (1868,Greater Britain,1/336)

1 n. (Rural) [stock sales] a young cattle beast, often still running with its mother [ favoured by butchers.]

.. good quality runners and vealers were in short supply. (Nov 2, 1939,NZ Farmer,34)

Best cows and runners sold to GBP39 10/-.. (Nov 8, 1951,NZ Farmer,39)

Heavy supplies of runners and vealers have shown an easing tendency. (Dec 20, 1951,NZ Farmer,45)

Calves: good sorts firm, plainer easier. Heavy runners GBP30 to GBP34. (Nov 5, 1953,NZ Farmer,34)

Stock report..cow and runner $970.. (May 24, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17)

Stock report - cows and runners $390 - $1010 (Jun 14, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,21)

2 n.

SIMPSON a boy who delivers newspapers house to house. Into these tubes the `runner' pops the morning or evening newspaper. (1945,If You'd Care to Know,134)

running board¶

1 n. (Rural) the long shearing area in a conventionally designed woolshed.

The old long or running boards oblige shedhands to race up and down dodging shearers and catching pen doors. (Jun 1, 1994,NZ Farmer,25)

running ground¶

n.

McARA Running ground: Loose ground containing water; an excavation could be made only by supporting it bit by bit as it was driven, using the procedure known as forepoling. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),331)

running joint¶

n.

Running joint- Pipe with sufficiently lengthy thread to allow a back nut and socket to be screwed on, the socket finishing flush with the end of the pipe. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,96)

Running of the Sheep¶

phr. the world's largest urban sheep running event held in Te Kuiti.

Most towns have at least one big event each year; Napier is famous for its Art Deco festival, Hokitika for its Wild Food Festival, Invercargill has the Oyster Festival, Te Kuiti celebrates The Running of the Sheep and Whangamata goes fifties with its Beach Hop. (Jul 2007,NZ Retail,19)

Who needs Pamplona's bulls when Te Kuiti's got the Running of the Sheep (April 4, run in conjunction with the national shearing champs)? (Apr 2009,North & South,20)

A chartered train leaves Palmerston North for Te Kuiti on Saturday, April 4, for the Running of the Sheep - the world's largest urban sheep run. (Feb 17, 2009,Dominion Post,A9)

While the NZ Shears Running of the Sheep is just one of the fun events surrounding the 21st New Zealand Shearing Championships, there will be serious action at the championships ... (Mar 30, 2005,Scoop,1)

running out¶

n. [2 different senses below]

NEWTON He [a sheep dog] wasn't particularly good at running out and he was a bit slack at hand - he was too kind and sheep had no fear of him whatever. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,67)

running out: Allowing the shears to run beyond the intended length of the blow into the unshorn fleece wool. This is bad shearing and results in costly second cuts. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/27) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

n. (Rural) the approaching of a sheep dog to either hold, lift or pull sheep.

NEWTON The Sweep breed, great dogs to cast, were noted for their running out ... (1973,Big Country of the South Island,157)

running shingle¶

n.

STRONACH We walked for two hours, and the going was rough, with boggy and uneven ground near the creek, and running shingle on the slopes. Ibid. 11(?) ... here I had my first experience of climbing in running shingle. We went straight up, and for each two steps up we slid back one (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,11)

1 n. (Rural) [ S. I.high country] loose pieces of angular rock weathered by snow, wind and ice that move when walked on.

.. erosion in the form of running shingle in particular has reached such a stage ... (May 3, 1945,NZ Farmer,11)

Bluffs, gorges, running shingle and strips of tussock reach up to snowy, jagged crests.. Running shingle, contrary to widespread belief, is quite safe. (Apr 13, 1955,Weekly News,34)

NEWTON Shingle country: Typical South Island high country is characterised by bare shingle tops and faces - the latter often 'running' shingle. (1964,Straggle Muster,165)

GIBSON .. Opposite this on the west side was the Gladstone face and basin, which seemed to be nothing else but miles of running shingle. (1990,Among the High Hills of Canterbury,68)

running the cutter¶

phr.

It is not quite certain.. what one should call the bottles which are usually requisitioned for the gentle duty of "running the cutter". (Jun 4, 1910,NZ Truth,7)

runt¶

n. a small or unthrifty sheep or lamb; a weed [(farmers']

WALKER The first runts you see of what should be prime wethers. (1902,Zealandia's Guerdon,56)

runty¶

n. (Rural) a feeble newborn lamb.

a feeble lamb: a runty. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

1 adj. (Rural) [sp. use] [of newborn lambs] small and weak.

.. trial participants found that most of their small, runty lambs were in their unvaccinated mob. (2002,Wool Grower,Winter 5)

runway¶

n.

SEDDON One of our friends comes to us with the news that whitebait are running in the Teremakau River and that the rills or runways we made last week with large stones on the bank of the river may be `jumped' by early comers causes the working bee to break up. (1968,Seddons, The,20)

rupe¶

n. a pigeon

rupe, the pigeon, see kereru[u]. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

rupture-wort¶

n.

rupture-wort [s] Herniaria [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,65)

Rural Bank¶

n.

Today's Rural Bank is responsible for realising much of New Zealand's export potential, from the sea as well as the land. We're supporting the Orange Roughy, squid, tuna, mussel and crayfish fisheries the same way we support traditional farming. (Advt). (Apr 6, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),72)

Rural Bank NZ (in full Rural Banking and Finance Corporation) a government-sponsored organization financing agriculture, fisheries, etc. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,669) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

Rural Banking & Finance Corporation, known commonly as the Rural Bank, was a government-funded bank charged with providing loans to individuals or organisations engaged in any sort of farming or farm support industry, or the fishing industry. (1986,Illustrated Encycl. of NZ,1080)

A $2 billion guarantee by the Government for Rural Bank borrowing was not recorded by the Treasury in the Government accounts as the result of an 'administrative oversight' according to the Audit Office. (Oct 18, 1991,Dominion,14)

The Rural Bank already has something like $1400 million out with the farnming community; they'll need a much bigger budget if they're to maintain that and take over the investor's role as well. (Feb 6, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)

rural delivery¶

adj.

The Postmaster-General's Report for 1916 stated:- "On the 1st November, 1916, a travelling post office was established on the Masterton-Waingawa-Matahiwi rural-delivery route. (1955,Postage Stamps of NZ,III/149)

YEREX On application at your local post office you can be placed on a rural delivery run, for which you pay an annual fee. You need to rent an R.D. box.Ibid. 142 Most rural deliveries are made six days a week. (1988,Best of Both Worlds,141)

We had minor problems, one of these being the position of our rural delivery letterbox. (Feb 1993,Dairy Exporter (NZ),65)

MIDDLETON Every afternoon it was Zelda's job to collect the paper and the mail from the rural delivery box. (1964,Walk on the Beach,15) [NOTES: (Beach)]

No, the rural delivery contractor is sorting mail into pigeon holes. (1987,MsCellany: Women Writers' Prose & Poetry,23)

HILL There were no simple wooden boxes with a red metal flag on a hinge that the Rural Delivery driver could raise to show when the cream cheque called. (1985,Moaville Magic,63)

DAVIES Lastly, he delivered the sealed mail bags to those who lived outside rural mail delivery areas. (1984,Bread and Roses,73)

1 n. (Rural) the means by which mail, newspapers, bread, groceries and library books are distributed by truck, van, bus or boat in rural areas.

As roads became better, motor transport could be used in back-block areas, and more and more of the smaller post offices could be closed and the settlers given rural delivery service which brought the post office to their front gate. Ibid. 17. With the introduction of rural deliveries many country post offices were closed and the number is now [sc. 1955] a thousand less than at its peak of 2,042 offices in 1915. (1955,Postage Stamps of NZ,III/16)

For some years the Wellington-Picton ferry steamer used to call at several of the Bays in Queen Charlotte Sound and to drop the mail. On December 8, 1911, a general survey was made of the service, which at the time was known as the "Rural Delivery Marlborough Sounds", and it was decided not to disturb the arrangements which then existed for the delivery of the mail by ferry. (1955,Postage Stamps of NZ,III/266)

McGILL It was a great treat to get up at 6 a.m. and do the rural delivery, about 30 miles all round. (1989,Kiwi Baby Boomers,10)

Hawera and Ararata, via Frazer Road (rural delivery), thrice weekly. (Sep 1, 1906,Wanganui Herald,2)

ELLISON There was no Rural Delivery then. (1956,Whirinaki Valley, The,28)

MUDGWAY Rural Deliveries: R D 1. Otane-Pukehau-Anaroa-Argyll East. This rural delivery commenced in 1919 when it covered a 31 mile (49 km) route from Otane to Otane. [RD] (1999,125 Years Off the Beaten Track,16)

It was a major background noise of our growing up, SMPs, national pricing, rural delivery, the bloody Poms, the confounded European protectionists ... (Jul 19, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

TENDERS FOR INLAND MAIL SERVICES FOR 1897, 1898, AND 1899 .. 16. Birkenhead and Birkdale, rural delivery. (Aug 15, 1896,Observer (Auckland),3)

rural fire volunteer¶

n.

The Wellington Emergency Management Office (WEMO) is eager to hear from good keen people who can assist in the city's community-based emergency centre... WEMO also wants to hear from anyone interested in training as a rural fire volunteer. (Jun 2001,Absolutely Positively Wellington,2)

rural land¶

n.

HAS FOR SALE - Town, Suburban and Rural Land of every description. (Dec 30, 1909,Hawera & Normanby Star,7)

The sum of 101l, if contributed immediately, will secure one acre of building land in the first town, on which the church and parsonage may be built, and 100 acres of continuous rural land, which will form a glebe, and the company will give a free cabin passage to the clergyman, if he proceeds with the first colony. (Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,7)

WAKEFIELD [Terms of Purchase of Land in the Settlement of Otago' agreed on by theOtago Association' and the Company] 16 In exchange for each sum of 120l. 10s. ... each Purchaser to receive ... three separate Land-Orders, namely, for the Town quarter-acre, the ten acres of Suburban Land, and the fifty acres of Rural Land, respectively. These lands to be severally selected according to priority of choice, to be determined by Ballot. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,317)

RURAL LAND FOR DISCHARGED SOLDIERS. (May 18, 1918,Poverty Bay Herald,1)

rural mail delivery¶

n. [also attrib.]

Mr. Kirkbride wanted the Minister to adopt the rural mail delivery system of the United States. (Sep 8, 1906,Evening Post,2)

OUTBACK SETTLERS [heading] ... Mr.Guthrie has replied that at the opening of the war a system of rural mail delivery services was in process of being introduced ... (Oct 1, 1918,Quick March,19)

I, (the Wanderer), was in Dipton and through the courtesy of the driver of the Rural Mail Delivery, saw something of Dipton Village and surrounding country. (Apr 7, 1931,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,1)

TURNER worked for a mail contractor named James W. Thompson, of Te Kawa, and had been in the habit of carrying the mail over the Pokuru rural mail delivery district, both delivering and collecting letters and parcels. (Nov 18, 1926,NZ Truth,5)

Lastly, he delivered the sealed mail bags to those who lived outside rural mail delivery areas. (1997,North & South,67) [NOTES: check year (orig. entered as 1897) and find month]

About the same time a rural mail delivery was also established. (Oct 2003,NZ Memories,No. 44/32)

rural marae¶

n.

The particular territory of Ormsby's fiction is that of the contemporary rural marae - the sort of environment in which he grew up... (Mar 15, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52)

rural section¶

n.

Each "land purchaser" was entitled to a "town" acre, a 50-acre section of "suburban" land, and a 150-acre "rural" section. (1940,Tales of Pioneer Women,143) [NOTES: Pagination from 1988 edition]

Timaru township, allotment 90, part of rural section 8. (Apr 20, 1865,Timaru Herald,4)

Eyreton Road District. - Rural sections numbered 468, 297, 71, in red; and all intervening roads and streams. (Jun 19, 1871,Star, The,3)

TOWN and COUNTRY LAND for SALE. - Several Town and Suburban Sections alread[y] chosen, and Suburban and Rural Sections with the right of early choices, to be Sold. (Sep 10, 1842,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,105)

WAKEFIELD Two hundred and fifty Town-sections [at New Plymouth], with their orders of choice ..., each with a Rural section of 50 acres attached ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,284)

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN, that applications from HOLDERS OF LAND ORDERS, for the choice of Town and Rural Sections, will be received at the Land Office of the [Canterbury] Association on and after the 17th day of February next. (Jan 18, 1851,Lyttelton Times,1)

It was also resolved to recommend the Minister to approve of surrender of small grazing Run 17, rural section 36206, Station Peak, for the same reason. (May 13, 1897,Star, The,2)

To C.D. and others the occupiers and owners of No.37, Rural Section, Grey District. (Dec 18, 1858,Taranaki Herald,4)

All that area, 100 links in width, situate in the Orari Survey District, commencing at a point on the bank of the Orari River in Rural Section No. 18836 ... (Sep 15, 1888,Timaru Herald,4)

The rural sections, to be allotted further out in the country, were not surveyed at this time and were therefore unavailable. (1943,St Michael's Angl.Ch.,6)

Rural Support Group¶

1 n. (Rural) a rural neighbourhood watch organisation.

Apart from alarms, another strong tool to help fight crime in the country is a Rural Support Group. A Rural Support Group makes that network more efficient. For information on how to set up a Rural Support Group ... (2001,Lifestyle Farmer,Feb/March 59)

Rural Women¶

n. (Rural) a female farming organisation [formerly known as WDFF or the Women's Division of the Federated Farmers, WDFU, or more commonly, Women's Division].

.. she was also a guest speaker at the Women's Division Federated Farmers (now Rural Women) conference. (Jul 8, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,17)

From October 15, a date auspiciously chosen because of its designation as World Rural Women's Day, the 70 year-old organisation [WDFF] will be known as Rural Women New Zealand. (Sep 24, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,Farming Today Supplement 36)

Mrs Nitschke believes the name change to Rural Women comes at a good time. (Oct 28, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,18)

This month's re-branding of the former Women's Division Federated Farmers under a new name - Rural Women - is fantastic, says the Blenheim woman who thought up the name 15 years ago .. They used to think you had to be a farmer or a farmer's wife but Rural Women includes anybody that is interested in the rural sector. (Jul 15, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,18)

ruralsexual¶

n. a manly rural male

Thanks to Meads, we might inadvertently be coining a new phrase for an old trend - "ruralsexual"... One of those ruralsexuals, prop Carl Hayman, made a name for himself as a 21-year-old with a 41-year-old's beard, becoming the 1000th All Black when he made his debut in 2001. (Jun 27, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),19)

ruriruri¶

n. ? love poems or songs; song, ditty, generally of an amorous nature, accompanied by gestures (Williams p. 352) which Best may be using light-heartedly; or ? a mis-reading of pukapukas `books'. [occas. humorous: spg Roody Doody, Rure Rure Maori ruri, ruriruri] (See rowdy-dowdy,kow-rowdy-dowdy)

MARKHAM The Women will sit on a heap of Potatoes or log, and do what is called `Roody Doody' [ruriruri]; ... (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),50,1963 ed.)

MARKHAM The Women will sit on a heap of Potatoes or log, and do what is called `Roody Doody' [ruriruri]; ... (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),50,1963 ed.)

I have collected some more Rure Rures which are good. Some time since I bought Lady Blessingtons and ... waded through the whole of them except her conversations with Lord Byron. (Mar 10, 1842,Journal of Ensign Best,355,1966 ed.)

ruru¶

n. owl [The form (nf W.) poss. represents he ruru.]

Many [kiore] are slow and weak-looking and will invariably be taken by native predators such as kahu, ruru and pukeko. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/24)

Athene Novae Zelandiae. More-Pork. Heruru. Kou-kou. (1869,TrNZI,1/160) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

It was easy to see why he was nicknamed "Ruru", the night owl. (Feb 1997,North & South,29)

ruru-whekau¶

n. whekau [ORIGIN: Maori]

BULLER SCELOGLAUX ALBIFACIES. (LAUGHING-OWL.) ... Native names. Whekau, Ruru-whekau, and Kakaha; `Laughing Jackass' of the colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,21,{1888 2nd edn 1/198} ed.)

rusa¶

n. large E. Ind. variety of deer farmed in NZ

rusa n. large E. Ind. variety of deer farmed in NZ. [L from Malay] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,669) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

rush¶

n. . [swamp plant, unspecified]

Towards sunset we emerged from the wood, which had served to protect us from a heavy rain, into a salt marsh thickly covered with rushes and flax. (May 9, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

ANDERSON (1777,Cook's Journals) [NOTES: [get quot]]

HOOKER Rush. Juncus (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

HILGENDORF RUSHES (Juncus polyanthemos [spp]) often called by their Maori name of Wiwi, are well known in all damp pastures. [Several different species grow on cultivated ground.] (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,54,1967 ed.)

<rush [=] bog-rush: cladium: leptocarpus: spike-rush: wire-rush [s] Ibid. rushes [s] [12 Juncus spp.] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,65)

n. the drug isobutyl nitrite [drug]

Those charges relate to supplying the youths with isobutyl nitrite, a drug populatr with homosexuals and commonly known as rush. It is a relaxant and enhances sexual pleasure, but is dangerous and can cause sedation, dizziness, fainting and even death. (Feb 23, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A12)

Defence counsel Tim Fournier said the drug - isobutyl nitrite, known as "rush" - had only a short-term effect. (Apr 10, 2003,Dominion Post,A5)

v. >v.t. to hurry along (cattle) [cattle farming]

WOODHOUSE Down the slopes we rushed them [sc. cattle] hell for leather,/ Towards the open country and the yard. (1950,Farm & Station Verse,67) [NOTES: Quoted from STUDHOLME 1938]

Then the success attending the export of frozen mutton caused a number of the settlers to rush their cattle into the markets, and sell at any price in order to get on to sheep. (Jan 25, 1884,Taranaki Herald,2)

n. [plant disease]

A disease called "Rush" has made its appearance among the peach orchards in the district, and has wrought considerable damage among the late varieties. (Mar 6, 1918,Otago Witness,22)

v. to seize upon, either by force or before the appointed time. Compare Jump. [1896. Modern: Those who had no tickets broke through and rushed all the seats.' The dancers becoming very hungry did not stand on ceremony, but rushed the supper.']

v. to stampede [cattle farming]

[We] went to get some more cattle for Mellish out of Rowleys mob. ... We brought some home and vainly endeavoured to yard them but as all took to rushing we let them go. (Oct 2, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,105,1950 ed.)

v. (? in general sense of rush v) [goldmining]

HEYWOOD We brought from Sydney several men rushing to the Otago diggings. (1863,Vacation Tour at the Antipodes, A,161)

Joe Potter, humping his bluey across the scrub-covered Waitui flats, when he and Steel rushed Flannigan's Find, little thought he would ever see an important town in that place ... (Nov 1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,108)

v. to occupy by an influx of gold diggers [goldmining]

The Highbury has been rushed, condemned, almost deserted, and yet survives. (1862,Otago: Its Goldfields and ReSources,26)

The place was rushed' by about 500 men, who speedily deserted it and declared the Waitahuna to be aduffer' (1863,AJHR,D/6/3) [NOTES: (Pyke Report Goldfields. See also V. Pyke's Report in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 5]

A man comes to a place some time after it has been `rushed'; ... (Apr 2, 1864,All the Year Round) [NOTES: 1864 Apr 2 All the Year Round in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 18]

PYKE Our object was to work only the richest spots, as we did not know how soon we might be discovered and rushed.' <i>ibid.</i> 85The fact that we were liable to be rushed' at any time, and our claims limited to 24 feet square did not affect Fox's or West's parties, who worked eight hours a day, with frequentspells' and Saturday half-holidays. (1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago,74,1962 ed.)

HARPER Westland, or `West Coast', as it is more commonly called, was rushed by gold-diggers in the early sixties, (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,30)

Our object was to work only the richest spots, as we did not know how soon we might be discovered and `rushed'. (Aug 23, 1962,Otago Witness,7)

I am afraid the place will be over rushed, as 4000 are reported as on their way from Melbourne. (Sep 17, 1861,Wellington Independent,5)

A nineteen ounce nugget was unearthed at the rush last week and several other heavy finds are also reported, but the area is very limited, and is already greatly over rushed. (Apr 9, 1877,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

n. a place where gold is found, and to which consequently a crowd of diggers `rush.' [1855] [goldmining; nb ref to place not process]

PFAFF We were on the Five Mile, and then went on to Hunt's rush. I was there when Hunt got away from a big crowd in the bush. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,8)

rush n. a stampede of cattle, etc.; a hurried gathering of miners as a place where gold has been found for the first time;-v.i. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

BEATTIE Their father lived at Caversham, and at the time of Gabriel's rush he built an hotel at Caversham ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,81)

~ n. the hurrying of diggers to a new gold field; the field itself; a stampede of cattle. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),624)

SEDDON Undefeated, on they came to the West Coast rush. ibid. 38 The exciting days when fresh finds of gold were reported and wild rushes took place were over. (1968,Seddons, The,37)

rush ... 2 n. ... NZ & Austral. sudden migration of numbers of people to goldfield or other claim (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,669) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 1012, sense 10]]

The ... impossibility of keeping workmen whilst the perpetual excitement of new `rushes' is maintained, was making contractors hang back ... (Feb 15, 1863,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/23,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

n. [goldmining] (See gold-rush)

SWAINSON In order to check an immediate and indiscriminate rush to the spot, ... the Government now issued provisional regulations,* under which licenses might be obtained by the public to dig, search for, and remove alluvial gold. (1853,Auckland,104)

There is some talk of a rush to a spot some miles beyond the Slate River, ... (Aug 22, 1857,Lyttelton Times,4)

I've circulated rumours, not a few,/ Of people finding nuggets by the score,/ To cause a rush, ... (Oct 22, 1862,Lyttelton Times) [NOTES: 1862 Oct 22 Lyttelton Times in 1948 Von Haast Julius Bon Haast 259]

J.G. WALKER He [the miner] was very civil, told us that two of his mates had followed a man to see if they could find a new rush, ... '[ (Jan 12, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker)) [NOTES: (Central Otago)]

HEYWOOD No doubt the old settlers have made a good thing out of the rush. (1863,Vacation Tour at the Antipodes, A,167)

I've circulated rumours .../ Of people finding nuggets by the score,/ To cause a rush, ... (1866,Canterbury Rhymes,92) [NOTES: 1862 Oct in 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 92]

McCOMBIE (1861,Australian Sketches,86)

FARJEON ... when the diggings first broke out, he was a Cheap Jack, as they call them, trading at all the new rushes. (1866,Grif: a Story of Colonial Life,39)

McLEAN New `rushes' on Goldfields, as a rule, are not advantageous to the digger or the state. (1869,Papers,31/190)

PYKE .. it was the time of the great Dunstan `Rush', and a host of miners were hurrying from all parts of New Zealand ... (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/ii/8 .,(1889,1974) ed.)

MORRIS (I) The hurrying off of diggers to a new field (1898,Austral English,398)

HOCKEN ... some old Australian diggers, engaged in cutting a dray track ..., discovered the precious metal in sufficient quantity to create a fever of expectation and a `rush.' (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,198)

He next found his way to New Zealand, and arrived at the time of the Gabriel's Gully rush, his brothers having arrived prior to him. (Feb 1, 1917,Grey River Argus,2)

THE BIG BAY RUSH. (Aug 25, 1886,Star, The,4)

v. to charge a man [Contraction for to rush-at. [1861] .]

MORRIS Rush, v. (1898,Austral English,398)

n. a stampede of lambs or bullocks [animal stampede]

Only about half an hour elapsed from the time I heard the rush of cattle in the bush, until I saw them drove into the yard. (Sep 10, 1874,West Coast Times,2)

Let us imagine, if we can, a mad rush of cattle, goaded by desperate men, in the small hours of the morning, upon the position held by that gallant little band. (Mar 4, 1902,Taranaki Herald,2)

rush n. a stampede of cattle, etc.; a hurried gathering of miners as a place where gold has been found for the first time;-v.i. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

~ n. the hurrying of diggers to a new gold field; the field itself; a stampede of cattle. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),624)

BOSWELL Then new gumfields were opened farther north ..., and a diggers' rush gave my brothers intermittent employment, they taking it in turns to pack the diggers to their new quarters. (1956,Dim Horizons,58,1955 ed.)

rush fern¶

n. Schizea fistulosa

POTTS (And) (1882,Out in the Open)

COCKAYNE (And) Schizea fistulosa rush-fern (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

GUTHRIE-SMITH ... a man could plant one foot on ryegrass of the deepest green and the other on rush fern (Schizea sp.) a species that delight in utter barren-ness. (1936,NZ Naturalist,46)

rush ho¶

exclam. to the goldrush!

According to the E. Star, "Rush Ho," is again the order of the day, and the Waimea is now the latest El Dorado. (Aug 13, 1866,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

PFAFF Thatcher sang [c1860s]:- The cry is now `Rush Ho!' and away the diggers go,/ To the norrard now they make their way. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,26)

rush house¶

n.

Mrs HENRY WILLIAMS Mrs. Davis, myself and all the children took possession of the two remaining rooms in the rush hut, or as the natives called it, `The Whare tow tow,' ... (Apr 15, 1933,Letter) [NOTES: 1824 Aug 15 Mrs Henry Williams letter in 1940 Matthews Matthews of Kaitaia 9]

rush hut¶

n.

Mrs HENRY WILLIAMS Mrs. Davis, myself and all the children took possession of the two remaining rooms in the rush hut, or as the natives called it, `The Whare tow tow,' ... (Aug 15, 1824,Letter) [NOTES: 1824 Aug 15 Mrs Henry Williams letter in 1940 Matthews Matthews of Kaitaia 9]

rush whare¶

n. (Rural) a small house made from raupo or rushes.

BARRER They camped the first night in a rush whare where, with children and dogs, they lay in their blankets on the mud floor. (1939,Brave Days: Pioneer Women of New Zealand,217)

1901-6 General shift in housestyle from rush whare to wooden houses in Maori villages with improvements in sanitation. (Oct 2002,NZ Family Physician,29/5/346)

rush-raft¶

1 n. (Rural) a mokihi or raft made of rushes or flax-flower stems.

GUTHRIE-SMITH During the siege of the island, mokihi or rush-rafts were used, and all sides of the pa attacked. (1921,Tutira,83)

rusher¶

n. a beast given to rushing or charging [farming]

We allude to the erratic and by no means well-disposed mobs of cattle, and the solitary bullocks known technically as "rushers," that daily terrify and jeopardize the Queen's lieges on the road to Port Charmers. (Feb 27, 1864,Otago Witness,13)

HAY Only occasionally we find it necessary to slaughter some unmanageable rusher, a cow, or bullock. (1882,Brighter Britain,1/158)

n. someone rushing to the goldfields

BOWMAN When Thomson landed in 1862 .. he found himself among the "rushers", tramping in company with his brother Andrew to the goldfields. (1948,Port Chalmers,18)

DON European rushers' hither and thither preferred todwell in tents' (1905,Annual Tour Chinese in Otago,1)

BOWMEN He found himself among the `rushers' (1948,Port Chalmers,18)

rushes and reeds¶

n. a children's game

SUTTON-SMITH There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. West Coast: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; Wellington: Who Goes Round My Stone Wall, Beg o' My Neighbor, Bellahonie, Run a Mile, On and Off the Bridge, Here Come Two Nuns, Colours, Isaac and Rebecca. Scrag, Diabolo, Bumble Puppy, Homai, Fives; Auckland: My Fair Young Lady, Rushes and Reeds, Surrender the Tower, Walls, Ball Hopscotch, ball games, Solomon Says; (1981,History of Children's Play,231)

rushing¶

n. [gold]

May The goldfields press complained of `headstrong and indiscriminate rushing' in 1865, a complaint still being echoed in 1867: (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,280,2nd ed.)

HEYWOOD Our old friends, Cobb and Co., had followed their `rushing' friends from Victoria. (1863,Vacation Tour at the Antipodes, A,162)

adj. [farming]

The rushing of the cow past the horse and very near it, in witness's opinion, caused Scrivener's horse to bolt. (Aug 25, 1908,Taranaki Herald,2)

[Rev.J.G.Engst] would face man or the devil [452] bible in hand but he would take a stick to a rushing cow. (Nov 1, 1910,Chudleigh Diary,451)

Russell lupin¶

n.

lupin, Russell [s] Lupinus polyphyllus . Lindl . Lupinus polyphyllus X arboreus . (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,45)

Russellitis¶

n.

Russellitis describes the easy life, on the dole or other income, spending most of the day wind-surfing - an easy life that would be what in other places would be called `gone troppo' (May 5, 1984,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Programme on Russell. 1984 May 5 2YA Wellington]

Russian comfrey¶

n.

Russian comfrey [s] Symphytum X uplandicum Nym. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,66)

Russian knapweed¶

n.

knapweed Russian [s] Centaurea repens L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,42)

Russian knapweed [s] Centaurea repens L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,66)

Russian scare¶

n. the threat of coastal invasion of New Zealand during the 1870s and 1880s

The fort was occupied by the New Zealand army from the Russian scare till the end of World War I and was again garrisoned during World War II. (2006,Internet - see Notes,2) [NOTES: www.nzlive.com/en/rss?lang=en&type=search_events&sort=ranking&tag=ww2]

John Wilson The later Russian scare of 1885 grew out of Anglo-Russian rivalry in Afghanistan and led to the building of major fortifications along New Zealand's coast. (Apr 2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.tera.govt.nz/NewZealanders/NewZealandPeoples/RussiansUkraniansAn ...]

The walled fort, dating from 1886, survives today and is the most complete "Russian scare" fort in New Zealand. (2006,Internet - see Notes,2) [NOTES: www.doc.govt.nz/templates/PlaceProfile.aspx?id=35293]

On the left-hand side of School Road, high up on the ridge above, is one of the forts built in the four main centres during the second 'Russian scare' of 1885. (2005,Internet - see Notes,2) [NOTES: www.wellington.govt.nz/services/heritage/pdfs/northernsuburbs.01.pdf (from 1998 brochure)]

Stapleton Around the early 1870s the so called "Russian scare", that is the threat of invasion to New Zealand from the sea, the Boroughs of Hokitika, Greymouth and Westport raised concerns to Government, which led to one of each of these cannons being despatched as a means of defence of the coast and river mouths. (2007,Wanderings in Westland: Trips down Memory Lane,49)

W L Ruffell In 1878 diplomatic relations with Russia became strained bringing about what New Zealand history records as 'the first Russian scare'... Early in 1885 when hostilities were believed imminent New Zealand experienced 'the second Russian scare'. (2006,Internet - see Notes,4) [NOTES: www.riv.co.nz/rnza/hist/pf/pf2.htm website of NZPFOCA (NZ Permanent Force Old Comrades Assn.)]

rusticated¶

adj.

The warehouse will have a frontage to Queen-street of 66 feet, with a depth to the rear of 80 feet, the elevation being 41 feet. It is to be built in the Italian style of architecture ; the facings to be of pressed brick, relieved by freestone dressings, with rusticated pilasters and quoins surmounted by cornices. (Oct 4, 1861,Daily Southern Cross,2)

Cornice, architrave, scotia[,] skirting and dado mouldings, rough and dressed timber of all kinds, including "T" and "G" flooring, lining, rusticated and shelving kept in stock. (Oct 10, 1896,Grey River Argus,4)

THE KARAKA SAWMILLS have large stocks of Timber on hand, both at their Town Yards and at their Mills, Te Karaka, consisting of Rusticated Weather Boards, T. and G. Flooring, Skirting, Mouldings, etc. (Jun 2, 1904,Poverty Bay Herald,1)

Flooring, Rusticated Bds., and Matched Lining 8s 6d [per 100ft]. (Jun 8, 1889,Wanganui Herald,4)

ON SALE, American Shelving .. Rusticated Boards, White Pine, Kauri, and Deal ... (Jun 14, 1879,North Otago Times,3)

Rusticated Boarding, T. and G. Flooring, T.G.B. and V. lining. (Oct 1, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,3)

At the same time (c 1870s) the rusticated weatherboard made its appearance - the invention of it being attributed to Toxwood, who was an artichtect [sic] trained in Denmark. . . In the days of the wooden rusticated house.. the wealth of the fortunate owner was reflected in the character and elaboration of the external adornment. Ibid. 21 The plain rusticated wall with stops was the lowest degree; if quoins were mitred at the corners that was an indication of greater refinement; but for the highest type and the wealthier client the quoins must be ovolo molded. (Apr 1935,NZ Inst. Arch. Journal,20)

KNIGHT & WALES There are three arched recesses rusticated with vermiculated piers and arch stones. (1988,Buildings of Dunedin,174) [NOTES: Quoted from 1868]

KNIGHT & WALES The lower half of the facade is rusticated and the upper storey is decorated with coupled columns against the wall, with Ionic capitals. (1988,Buildings of Dunedin,205)

SHAW A Greek survival building faced with Tasmanian sandstone, the facade has a rusticated ground floor with attached fluted Doric columns supporting an entablature and cornice. (1991,NZ Architecture,24)

SALMOND Another kind of weatherboard which became popular in the 1880's was the "rusticated" board, where the top edge was planed down to fit behind a rebate in the edge of the next board. The completed wall showed pronounced grooves which resembled channel-jointed stonework, and in more elaborate houses timber quoins at corners assisted the illusion. The introduction of the rusticated board has been attributed to the Wellington architect Julius Toxward in the 1860s. (1986,Old New Zealand Houses,114)

rusticated or rusticating n. (in New Zealand) a wide type of weatherboarding used in older houses. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1013) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 427]]

rustication¶

n.

STACKPOOLE In all of these.. his [sc. Toxward's] very individual choice of decorative motifs was plain... on the National Bank the rustication of the upper storey behind corinthian columns. (1977,Colonial Architecture in NZ,175)

KNIGHT & WALES Rustication: Masonry with sunk joins chamfered or rebated or roughened surfaces. The back of the rustication is the face line of the wall. (1988,Buildings of Dunedin,248)

SHAW Rustication: Masonry with sunk joins chamfered or rebated or roughened surfaces. The back of the rustication is the face line of the wall. (1991,NZ Alpine Journal,207)

rusty¶

adj. the sense `bad tempered; cross, nasty,' (OED a3) is used in NZ mainly of animals other than horses, bulls, boars, dogs etc.

[Old dogs] get caught by a rusty old boar sometimes. ... We bailed a rusty old sod up one day. a common nickname-shortening of the name Russell, whether or not the person named has red hair. (Apr 19, 1962,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5) [NOTES: (Interview: Murphy / Crump) ca1900 Havelock.]

rusty fern¶

n. Sphaerocionum ferrugineum [[Omit as transl. bookname]??]

MARTIN ... the much larger, handsome, bronze-coloured RUSTY FERN (Sphaerocionum ferrugineum) commonly drapes the caudex of a tree-fern with its numerous, overlapping, pendulous fronds. (1961,Flora NZ,100,1929 ed.)

rusty gold¶

n.

After lunch, the Professor tested some specimens submitted to him by local men, and amongst other things showed the method of cleaning rusty gold. (Apr 24, 1886,West Coast Times,2)

Prior to the floods the indications were such that the directors and shareholders fully believed that the dredge was about to realise expectations. For the few hours that she was on the first bottom, coarse, rusty gold, characteristic of that particular place, was got, but the river rose again, and another opportunity did not occur. (Aug 7, 1901,Otago Witness,25)

Mr Gordon referred to the existence in this colony of "rusty" gold, which was coated with oxide of iron and refused to amalgamate easily. (Mar 6, 1890,Otago Witness,21)

MAY The mercury plates were seldom perfect: the finest gold was lost by flotation while with cemented gold a thin coating of iron oxide (rusty gold') often prevented amalgamation. The mercury itself becamesick' or `floured'; both sodium and nitric acid were employed to improve its amalgamating qualities. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,238,1962 ed.)

Ruthanasia¶

n.

Labour leader Helen Clark is questioning the appointment of one of the "high priests of Rogernomics and Ruthanasia" as the new head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. (Oct 13, 1998,Dominion,1)

The leader, deputy and a handful of others are queasy about the Ruthanasia era. Who isn't? (Sep 14, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

They speak of a time before Rogernomics and Ruthanasia, when issues were clear-cut, and people still cared enough to put their bodies on the line for something bigger than themselves. (Sep 13, 1996,Independent (Auckland),18)

In 2002, Colin James argued that Helen Clark's government was operating during a period of consolidation, smoothing out some of the most glaring social inequalities created by the 1984-92 policy revolution, while consolidating the key economic changes of Rogernomics and Ruthanasia. (Sep 11, 2005,NZ Herald,Herald on Sunday 4)

And for most of us, those sensual childhood delights intensify and deepen with age. "Let's go into the garden" becomes a universal cry from the heart that can be heard more often as the economic climate worsens and Ruthanasia (Mary Varnham's delightful term) rampages in the wake of Rogernomics unrelieved by shafts of light or the chiaroscuro effects to be found in the personal Eden of the garden. (Sep 21, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),79)

What transformed the two major parties into the activist-based organisations they are today? Rogernomics and Ruthanasia. (Aug 18, 2006,Dominion Post,B4)

(Sep 3, 2010,Dominion Post,B6) [NOTES: By the time Rogernomics and Ruthanasia had run their course, New Zealanders had lost control of their finance sector, most of their news media, and much else besides.]

If you doubt this, consider the electorate's rejection of Rogernomics in 1990, and Ruthanasia in 1993. (Feb 3, 1995,Dominion,8)

Miss Clark said Labour or a Labour-Anderton government could be trusted. "There was a phenomenon with Rogernomics in the 80s and Ruthanasia in the 90s when the big parties lost their way." (Jun 12, 2002,Evening Post,1)

Ruthenomics¶

n.

Ruthenomics was no kinder coming from Shipley, but it was easier on the ear, thanks to her beautifully mellifluous vowels. (Feb 16, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

rutitira¶

n. ?= mingimingi

CHEESEMAN [Cyathodes robusta, Hook.f.] Rutitira. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,412)

RICHARDS Cyathodes ... robusta ... A shrub 4-15 ft. high, it forms large round bushes ... Distinguished from its New Zealand cousin C. acerosa by its broader, bigger leaves ... and its larger fruits it [sic] is only found on the Chathams. (1952,Chatham Islands,56)

ruva-ruva¶

n. (See rewarewa)
